summary: Oil futures are on track for the longest monthly gain in over five years, rising for a fourth consecutive month, ahead of an Opec meeting in Vienna. Libya's Petroleum Facilities Guard captured key oil terminals, while US production declines and global surplus eases. Opec is unlikely to agree on output limits, sticking to Saudi Arabia's strategy of squeezing out rivals. West Texas Intermediate futures rose to $49.49 a barrel, and Brent futures rose 0.9% to $49.76 a barrel, setting a fourth-monthly increase.

site_title: Air France-KLM in talks to sell stake in catering unit to China's HNA
summary: Air France-KLM is in exclusive negotiations with China's HNA Group to sell a 49.99% stake in its catering business Servair for 475 million euros. The deal would transfer operational control to HNA, which has been expanding globally through its acquisition of Gategroup Holdings for $1.5 billion. The partnership aims to create a leading platform in the inflight catering business, subject to HNA's acquisition of Gategroup.

site_title: Pilots, oil workers strike as France seeks way out of crisis
summary: French government struggles to calm nationwide strikes and protests ahead of the Euro 2016 soccer tournament. Air France pilots voted to go on strike, while oil storage workers extended their job walkout, amid tense labor reform talks. The government seeks deals with individual firms, such as the state-run SNCF rail operator, to blunt protests. Despite Prime Minister Manuel Valls' openness to changes, Labour Minister Myriam El Khomri insists on the bill, which has already been watered down.

site_title: South Korea April industrial output falls again, worse than expected
summary: South Korea's industrial output fell 1.3% in April, its second consecutive decline, exceeding expectations. This marks a 2.8% annual decline, worse than the forecasted 1% drop. The service sector saw a 0.5% monthly rise. The decline raises concerns over the sector's strength, following a revised 0.6% decline in March.

site_title: Mothballed ships in SE Asia show pain inflicted by oil slump
summary: A shipping industry crisis due to the oil slump has led to a surge in ship layups in South-east Asia, with popular anchorage spots near Singapore and Indonesia becoming crowded. Companies like Ocean Shipcare and Brubay Shipcare are struggling to find space, with some considering hiring more staff. The industry faces chronic oversupply, low container shipments, and a lacklustre market, with the worst yet to come this year as large deliveries of vessels ordered during boom times in 2013-2014 are set to arrive.

images.alt_text: Not everyone in shipping is bemoaning the industry's worst crisis in living memory: a cluster of companies that help preserve equipment and provide security for vessels parked around South-east Asia are busier than they have been for years.

site_title: France's Hollande holds ground on contested labour reform bill
summary: French President Francois Hollande has reaffirmed his commitment to a contentious labour reform bill, stating that the principles behind the bill's most contentious proposal will remain in place despite intense pressure from unions and protests. The bill, which aims to loosen France's rigid labour regulations, awaits debate in the Senate after being forced through the lower chamber without a vote. Hollande has vowed to pass the bill into law, but acknowledged the risk of social unrest derailing the Euro 2016 soccer tournament.

site_title: Update: China's HNA buys 13% of Virgin Australia, plans larger stake
summary: China's HNA Group agreed to buy at least 13% of Virgin Australia Holdings Ltd, adding a foothold in the Australian airline with a deal worth A$159 million. HNA plans to increase its stake to 20% over time, following a series of acquisitions. The deal brings another major shareholder to join Air New Zealand, Etihad Airways, and Singapore Airlines on Virgin's shareholder registry, amid speculation that Singapore Air may snap up Air New Zealand's potential 26% stake.

images.alt_text: Virgin Australia said on Tuesday it had entered into a deal with HNA Aviation Group for the Chinese conglomerate to invest A$159 million (S$158 million) through an equity placement.

site_title: Brazil to name new Treasury chief ahead of debt talks: source
summary: Brazil's finance minister Henrique Meirelles plans to name Ana Paula Vescovi, an economist and former finance secretary of Espirito Santos, as the country's new Treasury chief. Vescovi will play a key role in debt talks with states aiming to ease their debt with the federal government in exchange for tougher spending rules. The negotiations are set to start this week, following Meirelles' efforts to rebalance the country's overdrawn public accounts since taking office earlier this month.

site_title: Many corals dead or dying on Barrier Reef: scientists
summary: Scientists report that at least 35% of corals in the northern and central regions of Australia's Great Barrier Reef are dead or dying due to mass bleaching caused by global warming. This is the third mass bleaching event in 18 years, with the current event being more extreme. Recovery will take a decade or more, and the largest and oldest corals are likely to take much longer to recover. The reef is already under pressure from climate change, farming run-off, and development.

site_title: Europe: Shares climb, dollar firms on Fed hike expectations
summary: European shares reached a four-week high on Monday, with the dollar index hitting a two-month peak, as investors anticipate a US Federal Reserve interest rate hike in the coming months. Fed Chair Yellen and St Louis Fed President Bullard expressed hawkish views, increasing the likelihood of a rate increase at the June 14-15 meeting. The dollar rose 0.14% against a basket of currencies, while the euro zone's blue-chip index rose 0.38%. Investors are bracing for the June move, despite concerns about global liquidity, and will closely monitor the US non-farm payrolls report on Friday.

site_title: Hailstorms badly damage French vineyards, mainly Cognac
summary: Severe hailstorms hit French vineyards, particularly Cognac, Chablis, and Beaujolais, causing significant damage. Up to 8% of Cognac's vineyards, 6-8% of Chablis' and 6% of Beaujolais' vineyards were badly damaged, with hailstones up to 1.5 cm long. The storms also resulted in 600 hectares of damage in Burgundy and 1,000 hectares in Beaujolais. The damage is expected to reduce the 2016 harvest and impact future harvests. The FNSEA farm union is calling for government support for affected producers.

site_title: Chad ex-dictator gets life in 'warning' to despots
summary: A special court in Senegal sentenced former Chadian dictator Hissene Habre to life in jail for war crimes and crimes against humanity, a rare conviction seen as a warning to repressive rulers worldwide. Habre, who ruled Chad from 1982-1990, was found guilty of war crimes, crimes against humanity, rape, and forced slavery, resulting in the deaths of up to 40,000 people. The verdict brings closure to victims and their families, and sets a precedent for holding former leaders accountable for human rights abuses.

site_title: Cache Logistics Trust dragged into tenant's rental dispute with logistics giant Schenker
summary: Cache Logistics Trust, the manager of warehouse owner Cache Logistics Trust, has been drawn into a dispute with sub-tenant Schenker, a German logistics giant, over rent issues at the Schenker Megahub in Singapore. The property, valued at S$116.8 million, was purpose-built for Schenker and has been the anchor end-user for over five years. The dispute is over rental payments, with C&P Land, the property owner, seeking compensation from Schenker. The case highlights potential issues with the logistics sector in Singapore.

site_title: Japan's April factory output up 0.3% m-o-m
summary: Japan's factory output unexpectedly rose 0.3% in April, beating market forecasts for a 1.5% drop. Despite weak exports and earthquakes in southern Japan, production held up. Manufacturers predict a 2.2% increase in May and a 0.3% rise in June. This suggests production is resilient despite economic challenges.

images.alt_text: Japanese industrial output unexpectedly rose 0.3 per cent in April, government data showed on Tuesday, suggesting production was holding up despite weak exports and the hit from a series of earthquakes in southern Japan during the month.

site_title: India set to retain fastest growing economy tag
summary: India's economy likely maintained its position as the world's fastest-growing large economy, with a 7.5% year-on-year growth rate between January and March, surpassing the previous quarter's 7.3%. Despite a slowdown in exports, cooling inflation and lower interest rates boosted consumer demand, with sales of passenger cars and two-wheelers growing at a double-digit pace. The Reserve Bank of India is expected to keep interest rates on hold, and a sustained improvement in private investment is seen as crucial for the growth momentum to last.

images.alt_text: India probably gathered momentum to hold its ranking as the world's fastest growing large economy in the quarter through March, giving Prime Minister Narendra Modi more to celebrate after completing two years in office last week.

site_title: South-east Asia is winning more Japanese investment than China
summary: Japanese investment in South-east Asia has surpassed China for the third consecutive year, with $250 billion in outstanding foreign direct investment as of last year, according to Bank of Japan data. This growth is driven by the region's potential and low labor costs, as tensions between Japan and China reduce investment appeal. The pace of investment has accelerated, with the amount of Japanese investment to Asean nations tripling from five years ago.

site_title: Federal Reserve, China fears force investors to check out of Asia
summary: Global investors are selling Asian assets amid concerns over China's economy and potential US interest rate hikes. A net $3.2 billion left Asian equity markets between May 1 and 24, with Indonesia's and South Korea's bond markets also experiencing outflows. Market participants are worried that the Fed's rate hikes could weaken China's economy and lead to currency volatility, potentially causing Asian markets to fall 5-10%. Despite the region's relatively healthy economies, asset managers expect further weakness in emerging markets and are positioning accordingly.

site_title: White House back to normal after security lockdown
summary: A brief, partial lockdown at the White House was lifted on Monday after a metal object was tossed over the fence, prompting a security sweep. The object was determined to be harmless, and the White House returned to normal operations. The incident occurred on the US Memorial Day holiday, with President Barack Obama visiting Arlington National Cemetery earlier in the day. No one was injured, and the individual who threw the object was apprehended without incident.

site_title: Fighting the Taiwanese recession with home-style crowdfunding
summary: Taiwan's government has launched an exchange-based crowdfunding program for technology startups to combat the recession. The two-year-old initiative, endorsed by the Taipei Exchange, has helped 87 companies raise NT$1.1 billion from individual and professional investors. So far, only three companies have hit their targets and earned public listings, with Brinno Inc seeing its market value grow 16 times since joining the program. The government aims to create a NT$100 billion nationwide innovation fund to support startups, but sustainable revenue growth remains the main attraction for investors.

site_title: Kerry to head to China for talks
summary: US Secretary of State John Kerry will visit China from June 5-7 for talks on various issues, including the South China Sea dispute and economic cooperation. The visit comes amid heightened tensions between the two nations. Kerry will also stop in Mongolia and France, where he will attend the US-China Strategic and Economic Dialogue and a Middle East peace conference. The trip aims to strengthen bilateral ties and address regional and global challenges.

site_title: Brazil's anti-corruption agency employees demand minister's ouster
summary: Brazil's anti-corruption Ministry employees protested at the presidential palace, demanding the removal of Minister Fabiano Silveira over a leaked recording criticizing prosecutors in the Petrobras graft investigation. Over 1,000 employees, including 250 management positions, participated, and some have refused to return to work until Silveira's removal. The demonstration is a response to Silveira's appointment 18 days ago, which was seen as a power grab by interim President Michel Temer.

site_title: Asia: Stocks little changed as investors weigh data, rate hike
summary: Asian stocks remained unchanged, poised for their largest monthly drop since January, as investors weighed economic data and the prospects for higher US interest rates. The MSCI Asia Pacific Index rose less than 0.1% to 128.28, while the yen weakened to 110.82 per US dollar following Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's remarks. Data showed Japan's jobless rate was 3.2% in April, beating forecasts, and household spending fell 0.4%. The regional gauge has slumped 14% this year amid concerns over global growth and US borrowing costs.

site_title: Gold hits 3-1/2 month low on firmer dollar after Yellen comments
summary: Gold fell to a 3-1/2 month low of $1,199.60 per ounce on May 30, 2016, after Federal Reserve chief Janet Yellen hinted at higher interest rates, bolstering the dollar and increasing the opportunity cost of holding gold. The dollar surged to two-month highs, making gold more expensive for holders of other currencies. This marked the ninth consecutive session of losses for gold, its longest losing streak since March 2015, with hedge funds and money managers cutting their bullish bets on the metal.

site_title: Big airline LATAM suspends flights to Venezuela
summary: LATAM, Latin America's largest airline, suspended flights to Venezuela indefinitely due to the country's economic crisis. The airline cited challenging macroeconomic conditions in Latin America as the reason for the suspension. LATAM will stop flights from Sao Paulo, Lima, and Santiago to Caracas by August 1, and passengers will be reimbursed. The move follows Lufthansa's suspension of flights to Venezuela, citing the country's difficult economic situation and inability to transfer foreign currency.

site_title: Airbus sales chief sees room to raise A320 production
summary: Airbus' sales chief, John Leahy, suggests increasing production of the A320 jet to 60 or 63 units per month, depending on demand, but no immediate decision is needed. This contradicts COO Tom Williams' earlier statement that production may not exceed 60 units per month. Leahy's comments were made after Airbus received several new orders for the A320. The company's production rate could be adjusted in the future based on demand, but a decision is not expected for several years.

site_title: Missed Rio payment 'credit negative' for all Brazilian states: Moody's
summary: Brazil's missed debt payments by Rio de Janeiro to foreign institutions, such as a French development bank, have been deemed "credit negative" for all Brazilian states by Moody's Investors Service. This highlights the federal government's responsibility for states' debts to foreign institutions. The government may step in to honor the state's debt with the Inter-American Development Bank by discounting the amount from its monthly tax revenue transfer. The move aims to mitigate the impact on the administration's finances amidst Brazil's economic downturn.

site_title: Corporate tourism means more to Singapore than hospitality
summary: Singapore's corporate tourism sector contributes significantly to its economy, generating US$5.2 billion in 2014 from business visitors. The country's MICE (meetings, incentives, conventions, and exhibitions) events pipeline remains strong, driven by the government's MICE2020 roadmap. Corporate tourism is not only crucial for hospitality businesses but also presents opportunities for other industries, including infrastructure, security, retail, and business services. As the global economy slows, Singapore's MICE sector is expected to continue driving growth, making it a promising niche for businesses to tap into.

site_title: Argentine president to reinvest Bahamas riches at home
summary: Argentine President Mauricio Macri announced plans to repatriate $1.2 million from his account in the Bahamas, following the Panama Papers controversy. The funds will be reinvested in Argentine treasury bills. Macri's name emerged in the leak of documents showing he was on the boards of two offshore companies linked to his father, a wealthy business magnate. The move comes as Macri faces criticism over his handling of offshore assets.

site_title: Strong Jaguar Land Rover sales drive tripling of profit at India's Tata Motors
summary: Tata Motors Ltd's net profit tripled in the latest quarter due to strong sales of Jaguar Land Rover luxury vehicles and trucks in India. Jaguar Land Rover sales rose 28% to 158,813 vehicles, driven by demand for the Jaguar XE and Discovery Sport. The company also saw a 19% increase in sales in China, after a 10% drop in the previous quarter. This growth contributed to Tata Motors' higher revenue, making it India's top automaker.

site_title: SGX launches sustainability equity indices
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has launched four new equity indices based on sustainability criteria, with assessments from Sustainalytics. The indices include the SGX Sustainability Index, SGX Sustainability Leaders Index, SGX Sustainability Enhanced, and SGX Sustainability Leaders Enhanced. These indices will help investors assess the sustainability practices of Singapore-listed companies and identify ESG leaders. The move is in response to growing demand for transparent benchmarking tools and increasing importance of ESG in investment decisions.

site_title: Boeing mulls over larger engine for biggest 737 MAXs: sources
summary: Boeing is considering adding a larger LEAP-1A engine to its 737 MAX 9, a modified version of the engine used on Airbus's A321neo, to gain a capacity advantage over the 185-seat A321neo. This move would enable the 178-seat jet to fit 12 or more extra passengers. However, the upgrade would cost an estimated $1-2 billion and could weaken the advantage of commonality with the smaller LEAP used on the rest of the 737 MAX fleet. The decision reflects Boeing's growing pragmatism in the face of lost sales to Airbus.

site_title: EU, Berlin oppose Chinese bid for German robotics maker
summary: Top officials in the EU and Germany oppose a Chinese takeover bid of German industrial robotics supplier Kuka, citing concerns over strategic importance for European industry and potential restrictions on foreign ownership. European Digital Economy Commissioner Guenther Oettinger questioned whether China would allow a foreign company to take a stake in Kuka. German Vice Chancellor Sigmar Gabriel also expressed concerns, with the government stating it does not involve itself in business affairs. The proposed deal values Kuka at 4.6 billion euros and seeks at least a 30% stake.

site_title: Venture partner Alumina seeking to block business split, says Alcoa
summary: Alcoa Inc is facing a potential roadblock in its plan to split its manufacturing business from its legacy smelting and refining segment. Joint-venture partner Alumina Ltd is threatening to interfere with the split unless Alcoa grants concessions to the Australian firm. Alumina claims it has "no consent or first-refusal rights" in connection with Alcoa's separation and is seeking to block the split. Alcoa has filed a lawsuit in Delaware Chancery Court to resolve the dispute, with the company confident it will win.

site_title: Malaysia scandal strains longest bull market as foreigners sell
summary: Malaysia's longest bull market has taken a hit due to the ongoing scandal surrounding 1Malaysia Development Bhd. Foreign investors have sold a net 3.9 billion ringgit of Malaysian shares in the past five weeks, leading to the biggest outflow of foreign funds in eight months. The FTSE Bursa Malaysia KLCI Index has retreated almost 6% from its April peak, pushing Malaysia's stock index behind its emerging peers in South-east Asia. The scandal has sparked concerns about the country's economic growth, which is forecast to expand at the slowest pace in seven years in 2016.

images.alt_text: One of the worst global financial scandals is taking its toll on the world's longest bull market run.

site_title: American exceptionalism seems to be fading
summary: US politics is experiencing a shift away from traditional American exceptionalism, characterized by a more ideological divide between the two major parties. The 2016 presidential campaign, marked by the emergence of Donald Trump and Bernie Sanders as unconventional candidates, has accelerated this trend. Trump's nationalist and anti-immigrant stance, and Sanders' socialist agenda, are echoing the ideologies of European right-wing and left-wing parties. This divergence is reflected in the increasing polarization of the US political landscape, with both parties becoming more entrenched in their positions, making compromise on major policy issues increasingly difficult.

site_title: Maersk Drilling takes delivery of jack-up rig from SembMarine
summary: Maersk Drilling has taken delivery of the jack-up rig Maersk Highlander from Sembcorp Marine, originally built for Hercules Offshore. The rig was constructed based on the Friede & Goldman JU 2000E design and will be deployed in the Culzean field development off the UK. Maersk Drilling acquired the rig for US$190 million, with a US$420 million contract fixed on a five-year term charter. The acquisition represents an opportunity for Maersk Drilling to acquire a newbuild harsh environment jack-up with a firm long-term contract.

site_title: Mickey Mouse boosting China's gloomy economy
summary: China's slowing economy is not dampening tourism, with Shanghai Disneyland attracting almost 1 million visitors before its official opening. The Chinese consumer is expected to triple tourism spending by 2020, driven by industry investment that jumped 42% last year. Tourism is a bright spot, offsetting slower manufacturing growth, and policymakers plan to use its development to lift 12 million people out of poverty. Air travel, land development, and the cruise industry are also booming, with China becoming the world's largest domestic air travel market and the cruise industry experiencing rapid growth.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Cityneon Holdings, a creator of innovative exhibitions, is expected to see earnings growth with the acquisition of Victory Hill Exhibitions. The company has secured IP rights for Marvel's The Avengers and Transformers, and is expected to have six permanent sets by 2017 and eight by 2018. Analysts forecast a "neutral" rating, with Valuetronics Holdings and RHB Research citing a potential earnings drag from its LED unit and consumer electronics segment.

site_title: New credit card scrutiny sends Indonesians back to cash
summary: Indonesia's plan to track all credit card transactions to combat tax evasion and money laundering has led to a shift back to cash, with card transactions falling 4% in April and cancellations more than doubling. The government's efforts to boost tax revenues and combat illicit money flows are being hindered by the return to paper currency, which is difficult to track. The decline in credit card transactions is expected to be temporary, but experts warn that it may make it harder to prove corruption cases.

site_title: Abe gets heat at home over delaying of sales tax hike
summary: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is facing domestic pressure to delay Japan's planned sales tax hike, with some members of his ruling Liberal Democratic Party and opposition groups calling for a general election. Abe secured a G7 mandate to delay the hike, but is under pressure from his own party and opposition to postpone it further. A delay would likely rob him of the chance to reform Japan's post-war Constitution, and could also erode his coalition's influence in parliament.

images.alt_text: Mr Abe (right) talks with Speaker of the Lower House of the Parliament Tadanori Oshima at a ceremony for Japan's unidentified war dead in Tokyo on Monday. Key members of his own governing Liberal Democratic Party (LDP) are pushing him to call a general election.

site_title: Good news for the middle class!
summary: A recent article suggests that the middle class may be less stressed than previously thought. The media's focus on negative news creates a pessimistic bias, but the article argues that reality is often predictable and reassuring. This shift in perspective could lead to a more positive outlook on the middle class's well-being.

site_title: Delaying Rio Games would give "false security" on Zika: WHO panel head
summary: A World Health Organization (WHO) panel head, David Heymann, has stated that delaying the Rio Olympics due to Zika fears would give a "false sense of security" as travelers constantly visit Brazil, increasing the risk of the virus spread. Heymann emphasized that the issue is not the Olympics, but rather the globalized travel that occurs regularly, making it difficult to completely prevent the virus's spread. He recommended that athletes and citizens of child-bearing age take precautions, such as using mosquito repellents and practicing safe sex, to minimize the risk of contracting the virus.

images.alt_text: Postponing the Rio Olympics due to fears that the event could speed the spread of the Zika virus would give a "false" sense of security because travellers are constantly going in and out of Brazil, a senior World Health Organization (WHO) official said.

site_title: CMA makes conditional general offer for NOL
summary: France's CMA CGM has made a voluntary conditional general offer for Singapore's Neptune Orient Lines (NOL) valued at S$3.4 billion, or S$1.30 per share. The offer is conditional on receiving acceptances representing over 50% of NOL's voting rights. CMA CGM has no intention to increase the offer price, and the offer will become unconditional once it receives an irrevocable undertaking from Lentor Investments to tender around 66.78% of NOL's shares. NOL's shares closed at S$1.30 on Monday, up half a cent, amid a weaker container trade demand and challenging freight rate environment.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Crystal Jade opening more outlets in Asian cities
summary: Crystal Jade Culinary Concept Holdings plans to open at least 14 new restaurants in Asia by the end of the year, with locations in 9 cities across China, Cambodia, Hong Kong, Myanmar, Vietnam, and South Korea. The first outlet will open in Siem Reap, Cambodia by end-June, followed by openings in Shanghai, Hong Kong, and Ho Chi Minh City. The company aims to expand its presence in the region and cater to a growing number of visitors.

site_title: Japan Foods' Q4 profit falls 68%, mainly on impairment charge
summary: Japan Foods reported a 68% decline in Q4 profit to S$465,000 due to a one-off impairment charge of S$810,000 from store closures and increased royalty fees. Revenue and gross profit rose 6% each. The company's share of results from associated firms fell 30.2% to S$196,000. The impairment charge led to a 338% increase in other operating expenses to S$1.11 million, resulting from store closures and higher royalty fees.

site_title: URA directs GEM Residences to tweak triple-key units
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) has directed joint developers Gamuda, Maxdin, and Evia Real Estate to modify 980 sq ft triple-key units at GEM Residences, removing kitchens from two sub-units to align with the approved floor plan. The units, marketed with three kitchens, were a major draw for investors, but the URA has requested changes to reflect the approved plans. As a result, buyers have switched to standard three-bedroom units, with only a few TRIO units sold.

site_title: Emerging currencies bruised after Fed signals US rates rise
summary: Emerging-market currencies declined, extending their worst monthly decline since August, after Federal Reserve chief Janet Yellen signaled interest rate hikes in June and July. Asian currencies led the retreat, with the South African rand and Chinese yuan weakening. The Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index extended its biggest monthly advance since September 2014, and Fed Funds futures jumped on the news. The MSCI Emerging Markets Currency Index is down 3.1% in May, on course for the first monthly weakening since January, amid rising US interest rates.

site_title: Default risks loom over wealth management products worth 35% of China's GDP
summary: China's $3.6 trillion wealth management product (WMP) market faces significant risks, with default chain reactions possible due to increasing interbank holdings. WMPs, which invest in corporate bonds, stocks, and derivatives, have grown to 2.6 trillion yuan, with 85% of holdings coming from other WMPs. This interconnectedness raises concerns about a potential liquidity crunch and bank funding issues, particularly given China's economic slowdown and recent defaults. Experts warn that the market's instability may lead to widespread losses, impacting bank funding and the overall financial system.

site_title: Do Keppel and SembMarine need to raise Sete Brasil provisions?
summary: Keppel and SembMarine, the yard groups involved in the bankrupt Sete Brasil rig building contracts, may need to raise provisions to recover their investments. A US$221 million lawsuit by EIG Investment has added Brazil's Odebrecht SA and other shipyards as defendants, potentially drawing the yard groups into the legal battles. The yard groups have made provisions of S$230 million and S$329 million, but analysts question if these are adequate considering the depressed state of the offshore drilling market and the likelihood of Petrobras reneging on contracts.

site_title: What's the story of your startup?
summary: A startup's success can be attributed to its narrative, much like a story. Founders should focus on building a durable team of "humans" with unique personalities, rather than trying to portray themselves as perfect. A clear and compelling plot, starting with a clear beginning and end, is also crucial. Startups should avoid "helicopter parenting" and allow the business to take on a life of its own. Finally, founders must be willing to face challenges and earn personal glory through great effort. By following these principles, startups can increase their chances of success.

site_title: Multiple factors working against Taiwan dollar
summary: Taiwan's dollar is at risk of significant losses due to multiple factors, including the new president's stance on China, a possible US rate hike, and falling sales at Apple. Strategists predict a 4.3% drop in the Taiwanese dollar to NT$34 by year-end, with some estimating a 2.9% slide to NT$33.50. The island's economy, reliant on exports, has been shrinking for three consecutive quarters, and President Tsai Ing-wen's election win may worsen its prospects.

site_title: French liqueurs go exotic with unusual ingredients
summary: French liqueur producers are incorporating unusual ingredients into their products, such as rose petals, tea, and lychees, to cater to adventurous drinkers. The industry's annual trade fair, Printemps des Liqueurs, showcased a range of unique liqueurs, with 53% of France's production going for export. Established firms like Giffard and Maison l'Heritier-Guyot continue to respect traditional ingredients, while also innovating with global trends, such as using tea in Japan.

site_title: Swiber, Pacific Radiance up next for debt revamp
summary: Singaporean banks are restructuring debt for offshore and marine companies Swiber Holdings and Pacific Radiance, with one option considering extending loan repayment tenures to 15 years. This move aims to help the companies navigate a protracted down-cycle in the industry. The debt restructuring may come with interest rate hikes, with analysts estimating a 1-2 percentage point increase. The two companies have high gearing ratios, with Pacific Radiance's net gearing expected to rise to 1.3x this year due to increased capital expenditure.

site_title: Hedge funds stepping back from gold
summary: Hedge funds are reducing their bets on a gold price rally amid expectations of a US interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve. The net-long position in gold futures and options fell 26% to 169,491 contracts, with prices losing 2.9% last week to settle at $1,216.70 an ounce. The decline in gold prices is attributed to rising interest rates, which make the metal less competitive against interest-bearing assets and strengthen the dollar. This move comes as the economy improves, with the US gross domestic product rising in the first quarter.

site_title: Small completed apartments continue to lag bigger units in price
summary: Singapore's small condo units continue to lag behind larger units in price, with a 0.7% decrease in the sub-index for units up to 506 sq ft since December 2015. This is attributed to increased competition from nearby HDB flats, which offer more space at the same monthly rental quantum. The overall Singapore Residential Price Index (SRPI) dipped 0.1% over the same period. Market watchers attribute the weak leasing demand for small units to the increased completion of such properties in the suburbs.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: GIC among bidders for Sithe power assets: sources
summary: A consortium including Singapore's GIC, Macquarie Group, and Malaysian power company Malakoff Corp has submitted a non-binding offer for Sithe Global Power's stakes in two Philippine power plants. The bid could fetch over US$1 billion. This follows a private sale process for the company, which is owned by The Blackstone Group. The consortium's interest in the assets marks a significant development in the energy sector, with the potential for a substantial investment in the Philippines' power infrastructure.

images.alt_text: A group including Singapore's sovereign wealth fund GIC is among suitors that have submitted bids for Sithe Global Power's stakes in two Philippine power plants, people with knowledge of the matter said.

site_title: Heng is 'recovering well' and 'lucid': PM Lee
summary: Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat is recovering well after undergoing brain surgery two weeks ago due to a stroke caused by an aneurysm. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong reported that Heng is now "fully lucid, communicative, and cheerful" after a visit. Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam took over Heng's duties, while Minister for Industry S Iswaran was appointed co-chair of the Committee on the Future Economy. Heng expressed gratitude to his supporters, particularly his Tampines residents, for their well wishes during his recovery.

images.alt_text: After undergoing brain surgery two weeks ago, Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat is now "fully lucid, communicative, and cheerful," Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong revealed in a Facebook post.

site_title: Singapore to develop world's first tropical data centre that guzzles less energy: Yaacob
summary: Singapore is developing the world's first Tropical Data Centre, aiming to reduce energy consumption by up to 40%. Trials are underway to design and test the centre, which can operate in high-temperature, high-humidity conditions. This innovative project is part of Singapore's efforts to develop sustainable solutions for real-life problems.

images.alt_text: Minister for Communications and Information Yaacob Ibrahim, speaking at the Ministerial Forum on InfoComm Technology (ICT) on Monday, indicated that trials are ongoing to develop the world's first Tropical Data Centre (TDC), which could cut energy consumption by such centres by up to 40 per cent.

site_title: Potential for further Hiroshimas remains
summary: US President Barack Obama delivered an emotional address at Japan's Hiroshima Peace Memorial, honoring the nearly 100,000 victims of the 1945 atomic bomb attack. He emphasized the need for humanity to balance its capacity for good and evil, and pledged a commitment to a nuclear-weapon-free world. While some criticized the absence of an apology, many Japanese survivors and relatives of the victims welcomed Obama's words, which aimed to convey a moral principle rather than a specific policy. Obama's speech was seen as a step forward for peace, but the potential for further Hiroshimas remains as long as conflicts within and between nations persist.

site_title: Analysts slash UEM Sunrise's earnings forecast
summary: Analysts have slashed their earnings forecast for UEM Sunrise, citing a 90% drop in profit from the same period last year. The company's first-quarter profit was RM3 million, and sales of RM229 million were only 15% of its target. Despite a healthy balance sheet, UEM Sunrise's performance underscores the housing slump in Iskandar Malaysia, where aggressive Chinese builders have exacerbated conditions. The company plans to diversify out of Nusajaya and focus on local projects, but analysts expect little impact from these efforts in the near term.

site_title: What brands need to survive in a digital world
summary: A UK music retailer, HMV, has successfully adapted to digital disruption by refocusing on its core strengths and forming a closer connection with customers. The company's turnaround can be attributed to cost-cutting measures and diversifying its products, such as entertainment-themed collectibles and apparel. The key to digital transformation lies in re-examining how brands relate to customers' needs and wants, rather than just technology. Companies should apply three basic principles: focusing on customer orientation, offering products that meet customers' emotional needs, and being selective in their customer segments.

site_title: Air traffic growth slows to most sluggish since January 2015
summary: Global air traffic growth slowed to 4.6% in April, the most sluggish pace since January 2015, due to the Brussels Airport attack. However, freight traffic showed a 3.2% increase. If excluding the impact of the attack, global passenger traffic would have grown 5% year-over-year. IATA chief Tony Tyler attributed the slowdown to lower oil prices and a subdued global economic environment, predicting a potential shift in demand growth.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: 'Tourists go home': Spain's tourism surge brings backlash
summary: Spain's tourism surge has sparked a backlash in the country, with many locals expressing frustration over the strain on services, infrastructure, and daily life. Graffiti with slogans "Tourists go home" has appeared in cities like Palma de Mallorca, highlighting concerns about overcrowding, noise, and disruption to local communities. While tourism has helped Spain recover from recession and alleviate jobs crisis, some argue that the growth is unsustainable and should be controlled or limited. Local authorities are exploring measures such as taxes on tourists and capping accommodation to mitigate the issue.

site_title: War bunker provides storage space for fine wines in Hong Kong
summary: A converted British war bunker in Hong Kong has been transformed into a state-of-the-art wine storage facility, offering secure and climate-controlled space for fine wine collectors. The complex, built in the 1930s, has been converted into six 1,000-square-foot bunkers with reinforced concrete and soil protection, and features advanced security measures such as wetsuits, facial recognition software, and multi-code access. The bunker holds two of the world's most expensive bottles of wine and has become a hub for fine wine sales in Asia, with the city hosting Vinexpo, Asia's largest wine and spirits fair.

images.alt_text: The government has sought to encourage the nascent local wine storage industry, creating the world's first Wine Storage Management Systems Certification Scheme in 2009.

site_title: China bets on duty-free paradise to keep luxury spenders at home
summary: China is creating a duty-free paradise on the southern island of Hainan to boost local consumption, spur domestic tourism, and keep luxury spenders within the country. Since February, duty-free spending restrictions have been relaxed, with HNA Group Co Ltd reporting a 160% surge in sales. The government has also opened 19 more duty-free shops nationwide. The island's luxurious resorts and beaches are attracting developers, with state-controlled CITS opening the country's first duty-free shopping centre in 2014. However, market watchers believe that the future of luxury demand will be driven by Chinese consumers increasingly shopping at home.

site_title: STI weakens amid lowest volume this year
summary: The Straits Times Index closed at 2,796.75, a 5.76-point loss, amid the lowest volume this year, likely due to Wall Street's closure on Monday. Noble Group's stock plummeted 8.2% to S$0.28 on volume of 131.6 million after its CEO's resignation. Dealers described trading conditions as quiet, and analysts predict a bearish market, with Bank of America-Merrill Lynch estimating 80% of investors have a negative stance on Asia/emerging market equities.

site_title: For many Chinese migrants, the lure of the city is fading
summary: China's urbanization drive, which aims to boost consumption and economic growth, is slowing down as migrants struggle to build a future in cities. The number of migrant workers dropped 1.5% in 2015, and many are returning home due to difficulties in earning a decent wage and buying property. The government's goal of 60% of the population living in urban areas by 2020 is at risk, with analysts citing a lack of access to social services and a restrictive hukou system as major impediments.

site_title: June jitters rouse fund managers into casting their hedging nets wide
summary: Global fund managers are expanding their hedging strategies ahead of June's high-profile risk events, including the EU referendum and Opec meeting. They're turning to government bonds, gold, and the Japanese yen to mitigate potential market volatility. Many bond funds are showing positive returns this year, and some are using foreign currencies to hedge against risk. Beyond June, investors are preparing for the US presidential elections and potential trade barriers, with some buying gold as a protection against economic uncertainty.

site_title: Citibank cardholders will soon be able to use Samsung Pay
summary: Citibank Singapore cardholders will be able to use Samsung Pay starting next month, after the mobile payment service added the bank to its portfolio of banks and payment networks. This expansion allows users to make payments across Singapore using the service, which can be used at both NFC and old credit card terminals. Samsung Pay can store up to 10 cards, compared to Apple Pay's limit of eight, and is expected to be available on the Galaxy S7 and other Samsung devices.

images.alt_text: Samsung Pay announced on Monday that it has added Citibank Singapore to its portfolio of banks and payment networks.

site_title: Singapore slips in global competitiveness rankings
summary: Singapore has dropped to fourth place in IMD's world competitiveness rankings, down from third the previous year, due to high costs and talent attraction. Despite this, economists say the city-state remains highly competitive and attribute the drop to perennial issues. The IMD report highlights the need for Singapore to strengthen its production of qualified engineers and managers, as well as improve its business environment and policy stability. Regional competition is increasing, with Asian economies such as Indonesia and Malaysia falling in rankings, but Singapore's relative competitiveness may be eroded by the rising skills and infrastructure of other Asean economies.

site_title: China's BYD opens electric car showroom to stoke public interest
summary: Chinese carmaker BYD has opened an electric car showroom in Singapore, marking a significant step in promoting mass adoption of electric vehicles in the city-state. The showroom, in collaboration with Smart Group, features the BYD e6, an all-electric compact vehicle that can cover up to 300km on a single charge. BYD aims to raise public awareness and eventually sell the cars, with Smart Group overseeing import and distribution. The move is part of BYD's efforts to expand its electric vehicle market presence, following a successful year of selling 58,000 new-energy vehicles in 2015.

site_title: Bank of China plane unit's HK$8.7b IPO reflects Asian aviation growth
summary: BOC Aviation, a unit of Bank of China, has raised HK$8.7 billion (S$1.5 billion) in its initial public offering, the second-largest in Asia this year. The airline leasing company plans to use the funds to acquire new planes, benefiting from rising demand in Asia's growing aviation market. With airlines in the region expected to triple their fleet over the next 20 years, BOC Aviation is well-positioned to capitalize on the trend, with 270 planes already in operation.

site_title: The future kitchen knows what's in your fridge
summary: Innit Inc, a Silicon Valley-based tech company, has developed a "Connected Food" platform that allows users to see the contents of their fridge and access thousands of recipes through a smartphone app. The technology, set to launch in 2017, will be integrated into select kitchen appliances, including fridges and ovens, and will provide users with cooking instructions and suggestions. While the technology promises to simplify cooking and reduce food waste, concerns have been raised about the potential for personal data sharing and the feasibility of the system, with some experts questioning its practicality and the need for added complexity in the kitchen.

site_title: CSC, HP Enterprise merge to become IT services giant
summary: CSC, a Tysons Corner, Virginia-based IT services company, merged with Hewlett Packard Enterprise Co's services business to form the world's largest pure IT services company, valued at US$26 billion. The combined entity will serve 5,000 organizations in 70 countries, with CSC's CEO Mike Lawrie as chairman, president, and CEO. The deal, structured to be tax-free, aims to reduce costs by US$1 billion and create a more focused technology company. The new entity will operate independently of single hardware providers and establish key partnerships for success.

site_title: Panel identifies areas of focus to improve SMEs' prospects
summary: A panel representing Singapore's small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) has released its work plan for 2016-2018, focusing on key areas to improve SME prospects. The plan prioritizes advocacy, introducing initiatives to address concerns, and enhancing human resource capabilities. Key areas of focus include building compliance costs, empowering internationalization, and collaborating with the government to support SME growth. The SME Committee aims to address challenges such as market depression, competition, and regulatory pressures through targeted initiatives and closer government-business dialogue.

images.alt_text: The SME Committee (SMEC) will spearhead projects in areas such as building SMEs' human resource capabilities, empowering smaller companies to internationalise and collaborating with the government to ensure that compliance costs are kept manageable for businesses.
Mindy Tan

site_title: Luxe brands fight to woo Internet generation
summary: Luxury brands are facing a challenge as the millennial generation, born between the early 1980s and the 2000s, increasingly demands a digital presence and high-quality experiences. With 92 million millennials in the US, luxury brands are struggling to attract and retain their attention. According to Goldman Sachs and Deloitte, millennials require significant investment and are more mercurial consumers, making brand loyalty uncertain. Luxury brands such as Burberry and LVMH are taking steps to adapt, including digital strategies and social media presence, to appeal to this demographic.

site_title: Investors raise bet on rising gasoil prices: ICE
summary: Speculators increased their bets on rising gasoil prices for a second week, with a 15% increase in net long holdings in gasoil futures and options, according to InterContinental Exchange data. This follows ongoing strikes at France's refineries. In contrast, speculators reduced their net long positions in Brent crude oil futures. The data suggests investors are optimistic about future gasoil prices amid refinery disruptions.

site_title: German inflation back in black in May as prices rise by 0.1%: stats office
summary: Germany's inflation rate returned to positive territory in May, rising 0.1% from the previous month, driven by increased prices for rents and services. This follows a 0.1% decrease in April. The Harmonized Index of Consumer Prices (HICP) stood at zero percent, indicating no change. Final data will be published on June 10.

site_title: European stocks little changed as investors mull US rate hike
summary: European stocks remained largely unchanged as investors considered the potential for a US interest rate hike, with the Stoxx Europe 600 Index adding 0.1% to 350.14. Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's comments on a possible rate hike in the coming months weighed on markets, despite a rebound in optimism. The number of shares changing hands was significantly lower than usual, with investors also pulling money out of European funds, totaling $39 billion in 16 weeks.

site_title: Hollywood's golden age alive and kicking at retirement home
summary: A retirement community in Woodland Hills, California, is home to a who's who of Hollywood's golden age, including cast and crew members from iconic films like Doctor Zhivago, Star Trek, and Fiddler on the Roof. The Motion Picture and Television Fund, founded in 1921, provides care for industry professionals who often lack job protection and financial security. Residents pay for their room and board, while the fund covers the rest, and many still work professionally, producing original programming at the community's in-house TV station.

site_title: Modi's mid-term report card shows more positives than negatives
summary: India's Narendra Modi-led government has completed two years in office, showcasing achievements such as a 7.6% GDP growth, near-half inflation reduction, and historic low petroleum prices. The government has also reduced corruption and improved infrastructure, with over 200 million new bank accounts opened under the Jan-Dhan Yojana scheme. However, challenges remain, including a stressed banking sector, drought, and legislative logjams on key reforms. Despite this, the government's mid-term report card shows more positives than negatives, with Modi maintaining an approval rating of over 60%.

site_title: French transport to be hit ahead of Euro 2016
summary: French transport is set to face disruptions ahead of Euro 2016, with air and train strikes threatening to bring chaos to the country. Unions, including the CGT, are demanding the scrapping of labor reforms, which the government refuses to do. Strikes on the national rail network and Paris Metro are planned, while air travelers face more cancellations and delays. The strikes come as France prepares to host the football championships, with tourism chiefs expressing concerns that the unrest will deter visitors.

site_title: No slowdown for India despite global uncertainty: Jaitley
summary: India's economic growth is expected to continue its world-beating pace despite global uncertainty, according to Finance Minister Arun Jaitley. India's GDP expanded 7.5% in January to March, and the government expects to meet its budget deficit target of 3.5% of GDP. Jaitley emphasized the need to implement the goods-and-services tax and reduce corporate tax rates, and also prioritized modernizing infrastructure, spending on rural areas, and strengthening social security. Finance Minister Arun Jaitley assured that India's economy will not slow down despite global uncertainty.

site_title: Town councils run estates well: MND
summary: Singapore's 16 town councils have been banded "Green" in estate cleanliness and lift performance, with none receiving a "Red" banding. However, some councils, including Potong Pasir and Aljunied-Hougang-Punggol East, remain in the "Amber" banding for maintenance and service issues. The Ministry of National Development (MND) noted that obstruction of common areas is a major issue, accounting for 36% of total maintenance observations in FY2015. Only five town councils achieved a "Green" banding for estate maintenance.

images.alt_text: The banding for Aljunied-Hougang-Punggol East was left pending for service and conservancy charges arrears, while the rest of the 14 town councils were given the "Green" banding.

site_title: India'a Tata Motors Q4 net profit triples on strong JLR sales
summary: Tata Motors Ltd, India's top automaker, reported a three-fold rise in quarterly net profit to 51.7 billion rupees, driven by strong sales at Jaguar Land Rover and higher demand for trucks. The profit beat analyst estimates and was boosted by a one-time gain from an insurance payment for damaged Jaguar Land Rover cars. Net sales rose 19% to 799.3 billion rupees, with operating margin at Jaguar Land Rover falling to 16.2% from 17.4% a year earlier.

site_title: Heng Swee Keat now lucid and communicative: PM Lee
summary: Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat has made a significant recovery after undergoing brain surgery two weeks ago, according to Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong. Heng was "fully lucid, communicative, and cheerful" upon his visit, with PM Lee expressing delight at his progress. This comes after Heng was hospitalized on May 12 due to a stroke caused by an aneurysm. The Prime Minister had previously assured that Heng would remain under intensive care for some time, and arrangements had been made to cover his duties.

site_title: Carrying on with the EU project as best as possible if UK leaves
summary: European leaders prepare for the potential UK exit from the EU, which could be the most significant setback in the bloc's history. Discussions focus on responding to the immediate aftermath, including economic market volatility, and long-term strategies to emphasize the EU's resilience and integrity. Some policymakers advocate for caution, while others, including European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker, favor a stronger integrationist response, particularly in security and defense policy, which could be accelerated in the event of a British exit.

site_title: Former Swiss fund manager on trial for suspected US$800m fraud
summary: A former Swiss fund manager, Dieter Behring, went on trial on Monday for suspected US$800 million fraud. Behring, 61, is accused of securities fraud and money laundering, with proceedings scheduled for five weeks. He maintained his innocence, claiming he did nothing wrong, while prosecutors allege he enriched himself by promising investors rich returns that ultimately resulted in losses. The trial is set to last until July 1, with Behring facing charges related to his investment empire, which collapsed in 2004.

site_title: Philippines' PLDT, Globe to buy San Miguel telecoms assets for US$1.5b
summary: The Philippines' top two telecoms firms, PLDT and Globe, agreed to buy San Miguel Corp's assets for nearly $1.5 billion, upgrading slow internet services. The deal, valued at 69.1 billion pesos, includes a prized 700-megahertz frequency. Each firm will acquire 50% of the San Miguel telecoms business, with the companies to return certain frequencies to the government, allowing a third competitor to enter the market. The deal is subject to shareholder and regulatory approvals, but is expected to reinforce the leading pair's grip on the market.

site_title: AGMs hit by shortage of electronic polling devices
summary: A shortage of electronic polling devices has affected several companies' annual general meetings (AGMs) in Singapore, leading to manual polling in some cases. At least two companies, including Kingsmen Creatives, had to resort to manual polling due to unavailability of electronic devices. The rental prices for these devices are high, with costs ranging from S$1,000 to tens of thousands for a small group. The clustering of AGMs around late-April has exacerbated the issue, with some companies facing difficulties in anticipating turnout.

site_title: Eager to win market share from London, France eases debt issue rules
summary: France has relaxed rules for international borrowers issuing short- and medium-term debt, aiming to boost Paris as a key financial hub. The move follows Britain's potential exit from the European Union, which could shift London's dominance. The updated rules allow for European languages and accounting norms, making it easier for non-French companies to sell debt in France. The French short- and medium-term debt market, valued at 300 billion euros, is the second-largest in Europe.

site_title: As Singapore retools, fresh takes on labour numbers
summary: Singapore is retooling its economy, potentially leading to a slow increase in unemployment, with forecasts suggesting a rise of 0.5-1.5 percentage points over the next few years. Despite a low unemployment rate of 1.9%, economists expect a slight increase due to economic restructuring, which may signal transformation rather than instability. The focus on transforming industries and shrinking quotas on low-cost foreign labor has already benefited job seekers, and policymakers must balance the need to create meaningful jobs with the impact of automation and skills mismatches.

images.alt_text: With reports emerging of layoffs in various sectors, expectations of an increase in unemployment are on the rise.

site_title: Global air passenger traffic demand up 4.6% in April: IATA
summary: Global air passenger traffic demand rose 4.6% in April, surpassing air freight demand, which grew 3.2%, according to the International Air Transport Association (IATA). IATA head Tony Tyler stated that air freight demand is weak and unlikely to see an uptick. The airline industry will provide an updated forecast for 2016 profitability at its annual meeting in Dublin.

site_title: US union say Verizon to add 1,300 jobs, provide 10.9% pay hikes
summary: Verizon Communications Inc has agreed to add 1,300 new jobs on the US East Coast and provide 10.9% pay hikes over four years under a tentative deal with unions, the Communications Workers of America. The deal includes signing bonuses, profit-sharing, and pension increases, reversing outsourcing measures. Striking workers will return to work on Wednesday. The agreement follows a two-week strike that began on April 13.

images.alt_text: Verizon Communications Inc has agreed to add 1,300 new jobs on the US East Coast and provide 10.9 per cent in pay raises over four years under a tentative deal between the company and unions, the Communications Workers of America said on Monday.

site_title: CMA CGM makes voluntary conditional general offer for NOL after fulfilling pre-conditions
summary: France's CMA CGM has made a voluntary conditional general offer for Neptune Orient Lines (NOL) at S$1.30 per share. The offer becomes unconditional once CMA receives acceptances of around 66.78% of NOL shares, supported by an irrevocable undertaking from Lentor Investments. CMA has stated it has no intention to increase the offer price. The deal is subject to meeting the 50% voting rights threshold.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Noble CEO resigns; firm to sell profitable US unit
summary: Noble Group's CEO Yusuf Alireza has resigned "for family reasons" amid the firm's financial struggles. The company will sell its US energy-distribution firm Noble Americas Energy Solutions (NAES) to raise cash, despite its profitability. Two co-CEOs, William Randall and Jeff Frase, have been appointed to replace Alireza. The move sent Noble shares down 8% and raises concerns about the firm's solvency, following a year-long uncertainty and a downgrade to junk status by credit rating agencies.

site_title: Straits Trading Building may fetch record psf price
summary: Indonesian tycoon Tahir is nearing a deal to buy Straits Trading Building on Battery Road in Singapore for S$560 million, a record S$3,520 per square foot based on the property's net lettable area. The sale would translate to a gross yield of 3.5% and a net yield of 2.8%, with Tahir expected to hold the property for long-term investment. The sale would be a new high for an entire office building, surpassing the previous record set in 2008 for Commerz Real's purchase of 71 Robinson Road.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Frustrated Juncker urges EU leaders to back TTIP trade talks
summary: European Commission President Jean-Claude Juncker urged EU leaders to back free trade talks with the US on the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) at a June summit. Despite growing opposition from anti-globalization groups, Juncker aims to conclude talks by the end of 2016. EU leaders, including German Vice Chancellor Sigmar Gabriel and French President Francois Hollande, have expressed skepticism, with Gabriel questioning the deal's worth and Hollande demanding more concessions from the US. A sense of urgency to clinch an accord before US President Barack Obama leaves office in January is building.

site_title: HTL International to wind up two subsidiaries
summary: HTL International Holdings is restructuring its business by closing two sofa manufacturing plants in Yangzhou and Shanghai. The subsidiaries operating these plants, HTL Furniture (Yangzhou) Co and TBC Furniture (Shanghai) Co, will be wound up and their activities redistributed to other plants in Jiangsu, China.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: US markets closed for Memorial Day
summary: US stock markets closed on Monday for Memorial Day. Meanwhile, Singapore stocks rose 5 days in a row ahead of GDP data release. Asia markets remained positive despite US President Trump's new threats. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty. Airalo raised $220 million in funding, lifting its valuation to over $1 billion. The STI index in Singapore rose 0.4% on Thursday, driven by investors' positive outlook despite tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views.

site_title: Four re-appointed to MAS board of directors
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has re-appointed four members to the MAS board of directors, including Lim Hng Kiang, Lim Chee Onn, Peter Ong Boon Kwee, and Prof Tan Chorh Chuan, for a further term of two years. The appointments will take effect from June 1, with Lim Hng Kiang also serving as deputy chairman of the MAS board. The re-appointments aim to maintain stability and expertise on the MAS board.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer received 9.8 times oversubscription. US stocks opened lower amid a fresh tariff salvo by Trump on Canada. Creative Technology warned of potential H2 revenue below target, with similar operating loss to H1. London's Heathrow considers higher fees for a £10b upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran, is set to become OCBC's new CEO. MAS and PBOC plan to deepen cooperation in green and transition finance, ahead of Singapore's GDP data release.

site_title: Vietnam plans US$5.5b expansion to double Hanoi airport capacity
summary: Vietnam plans a US$5.5-billion expansion of Hanoi's Noi Bai International Airport to double its capacity to 50 million passengers per year by 2030, addressing growing passenger demand. The airport's current capacity is expected to be over-stretched by 2019. Vietnam's aviation market is among the world's 10 fastest growing in percentage terms, driven by economic growth and competition among domestic airlines. The expansion is part of the country's broader plans to develop its aviation industry, including a new US$16-billion airport near Ho Chi Minh City.

site_title: Secura to buy industrial property at Alexandra Terrace for S$16.5 million
summary: SECURA Group has been granted an option to acquire a six-storey industrial property at 38 Alexandra Terrace for S$16.5 million. The property, with a gross floor area of 2,100 square meters, is situated on freehold land. The purchase will be funded by S$4 million from SECURA's initial public offering, with the remaining amount to be secured from financial institutions.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: No slowdown for India despite global uncertainty, Jaitley says
summary: India's growth is expected to continue its world-beating pace despite global uncertainty, according to Finance Minister Arun Jaitley. India's GDP expanded 7.5% in January to March, and the government aims to meet its budget deficit target of 3.5% of GDP. Jaitley also announced plans to modernize infrastructure, spend more on rural areas, and strengthen social security. The government expects to maintain a balance between a strong rupee and a realistic one to support exports.

site_title: Soilbuild Construction proposes preferential offering
summary: Soilbuild Construction Group is proposing a non-renounceable, non-underwritten preferential offering to raise S$8.1 million. The offering includes up to 167.37 million warrants, exercisable at S$0.18 for each new share, with an estimated proceeds of S$30.1 million if all warrants are exercised. The funds will be used for acquiring plant and equipment in Myanmar, working capital, and expansion in Singapore, with the aim of strengthening the company's capital base and positioning it for business growth.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Paris tourism hit by attacks, protests
summary: Paris tourism is facing a fresh challenge from recent violent strikes and protests, which have led to a decline in bookings from Japanese, Russian, and Chinese tourists. Hotel bookings are down 56%, 35%, and 13.9% respectively, with the city's tourist board warning that the disastrous consequences of the 2015 attacks are still felt. The recent social unrest and violent clashes have reinforced fears among tourists, with unions threatening to disrupt transport for the Euro 2016 football championship.

site_title: Latest China debt moves may bring index inclusion, US$155b inflow: JPM
summary: China's relaxation of foreign participation rules may lead to at least $155 billion in investment flows if its government bonds are included in global indexes, according to JPMorgan. The move, announced by the state foreign exchange regulator, allows foreign institutions to remit funds freely. This suggests China is "serious about attracting foreign capital" and increases the likelihood of its government bonds entering benchmark indexes. The development is seen as a positive sign for China's economic growth and may have implications for its GDP growth and policymaking.

images.alt_text: Chinese government bonds could receive at least US$155 billion of investment flows should the relaxation of rules around foreign participation lead to their inclusion in various global indexes, JPMorgan said on Monday.

site_title: KSH posts 47.6% rise in full-year earnings on back of Beijing project
summary: KSH Holdings posted a 47.6% rise in full-year net profit to S$61.5 million, driven by a 82.8% increase in associates' share of results, primarily from a completed Beijing property project. Turnover dipped 0.3% and construction revenue also decreased 0.3%. The company declared a final dividend of 1.5 cents and a special cash dividend of 0.5 cents per share, totaling 2 cents per share.

site_title: Former Zurich Insurance chief commits suicide: company
summary: Former Zurich Insurance CEO Martin Senn, 59, has committed suicide, according to the company. Senn served as CEO from 2010 to last December. His death comes nearly three years after the company's former CFO, Pierre Wauthier, also took his own life in 2013, prompting a shake-up at the insurance provider. Zurich Insurance expressed its "deepest sympathies" to Senn's family and will not provide further comments out of respect for him and his family.

site_title: China: Stocks close up marginally, policy uncertainty tempers demand
summary: China's stocks closed up marginally on Monday due to uncertainty over monetary policy. Investors remain cautious, with volumes plunging amid expectations that China's manufacturing sector growth stalled in May. The economy's recovery remains uncertain, and official data is expected to show stagnant growth. This has tempered demand and kept investors on the sidelines, affecting market activity.

site_title: Chuan Hup's subsidiary enters into fresh loan agreement with PSD Holdings
summary: CH Biovest, a subsidiary of CHUAN Hup Holdings, has entered into a two-year loan agreement with PSD Holdings for US$7 million at 8% interest per annum. This follows a previous loan of US$10 million granted to PSD in April. The loan aims to optimise returns on available funds and enhance shareholder value, consistent with CHUAN Hup's overall objective.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Europe: Equities mixed at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets opened with mixed results, with Paris' CAC 40 easing 0.2% to 4,507.09 points, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 index rose 0.7% to 10,293.43 points. Madrid's IBEX 35 added 0.04% to 9,111.00. Trading was closed in London for a bank holiday.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index slipped 7.32 points to close at 1,629.87 on Monday, ending lower. 1.55 billion lots valued at RM1.65 billion were traded, with 300 gains and 546 losses.

site_title: German negotiated wages rise by 2.1% in first quarter
summary: German negotiated wages rose by 2.1% on average in the first quarter compared to last year, outpacing consumer prices which increased by 0.3%. The wage hikes are relatively moderate compared to last year's agreements, boosting expectations for private consumption to drive growth in Europe's largest economy this year.

images.alt_text: Negotiated wages in Germany rose by 2.1 per cent on average in the first quarter compared with the same period last year, data showed on Monday, boosting expectations that private consumption will prop up growth in Europe's largest economy this year.

site_title: Samsung Pay adds Citibank Singapore to bank, payment networks
summary: Samsung Pay has added Citibank Singapore to its payment network, allowing Citibank credit card members to make payments using compatible Samsung mobile phones. This expansion follows previous additions of Visa and MasterCard credit or debit cards issued by major banks in Singapore. Samsung Pay is now accepted "almost anywhere" and is expected to roll out in June.

site_title: SGX launches four sustainability stock indices
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has launched four new equity indices focused on sustainability, using assessments from Sustainalytics. The indices include the SGX Sustainability Index, SGX Sustainability Leaders Index, and two enhanced versions that consider ESG scores. These indices aim to provide transparent benchmarking tools for investors to assess the sustainability practices of SGX-listed companies, helping to identify ESG leaders and profile companies with strong credentials among international investors. The launch reflects growing demand for ESG-focused investments and tools.

site_title: French Q1 GDP revised up to 0.6% q-o-q
summary: French Q1 GDP revised up to 0.6% q-o-q, stronger-than-expected growth driven by a 1.0% surge in consumer spending and a 1.6% increase in investment, according to the INSEE national statistics agency. This beats analysts' forecast of 0.5% growth. The stronger-than-expected growth is a positive sign for the French economy, which has been struggling in recent years.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Noble Group CEO Yusuf Alireza has resigned due to family reasons. The company plans to sell its US energy marketing subsidiary. Meanwhile, Singapore's 4G mobile services will soon have minimum standards, and Samsung Pay has added Citibank Singapore to its bank and payment networks. The Straits Times Index closed weaker on Monday in one of the quietest trading sessions of the year.

site_title: Euro-area economic confidence rises as ECB stimulus kicks in
summary: The European Central Bank's stimulus program appears to be having a positive impact on the euro-area economy, as economic confidence rose for a second month in May. The index of executive and consumer sentiment increased to 104.7, the highest level in four months. The ECB is expected to keep its ultra-loose policy unchanged, with inflation and growth projections potentially revised upward. Vice President Vitor Constancio is optimistic about reaching the inflation goal by 2018, citing rising oil prices and the upgraded stimulus program.

images.alt_text: Euro-area economic confidence rose for a second month in May as the European Central Bank prepares to present updated economic projections that could provide further clues about the impact of its stimulus program.

site_title: 8 in 10 Singapore employees work harder for higher pay: Randstad
summary: According to Randstad's 2016 research, 80% of Singapore employees work harder for higher pay, with career progression and personal development also being key motivators. Despite a Ministry of Manpower recommended limit of 44 working hours per week, 47% of workers exceed this limit, with men working more hours than women. The country director suggests this may be due to the uncertain economic climate, but expects the willingness to work overtime to decrease with a more stable economy.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks soar as hopes for tax-hike delay lift mood
summary: Tokyo's benchmark index surged 1.39% to close at 17,068.02, driven by a weaker yen and hopes of delaying a consumption tax hike. The Nikkei 225 and Topix index rose 1.19% and 1.36%, respectively. Investors are optimistic about the potential delay, lifting mood and powering shares higher.

site_title: China iron ore, steel bounce off 3-mth lows; sentiment stays weak
summary: China's iron ore and steel futures bounced back from three-month lows, closing up 0.2% and 0.9% respectively. Despite this, overall market sentiment remains weak due to rising supply and seasonal demand decline. Rebar prices fell 20% in May, their largest monthly drop since 2009, and inventories decreased after three weeks of increase. China's Tangshan steel production was cut due to air pollution concerns, providing temporary support to prices.

site_title: Takata said to rule out bankruptcy as it seeks funds from buyer
summary: Takata Corp, facing record air-bag recalls, has ruled out bankruptcy and is seeking buyers to inject funds, with a goal of maintaining its core businesses. Lazard Ltd will meet manufacturers and financial firms to find potential buyers by fall, and a consortium of investors is also being considered. The company plans to remain listed, sell non-core operations, and dilute the founding family's stake in exchange for capital. Talks with potential buyers are at the preliminary stage, with negotiations ongoing with Honda Motor Co over the recall bill.

site_title: Thai central bank says baht weakness in line with regional FX, will smooth excessive moves
summary: Thailand's central bank governor Veerathai Santiprabhob stated that the country's baht weakness is in line with regional currencies. The baht hit a near four-month low against the dollar due to external factors like market sentiment and the US Federal Reserve's policy. The central bank will monitor the volatility to prevent it from becoming a problem and maintain the baht at appropriate levels, comparable to regional peers.

site_title: Thai junta lifts ban on overseas travel by politicians
summary: Thailand's military government has lifted a ban on overseas travel by some politicians, effective Wednesday. The move, made by Defence Minister Prawit Wongsuwan, indicates the junta's trust in politicians and marks a step towards easing restrictions ahead of an August referendum on a draft constitution. The ban, imposed two years ago, excluded politicians with pending legal cases, including former Prime Minister Yingluck Shinawatra. The decision was welcomed by politicians but criticized by some, who argued the ban was unjustified from the start.

site_title: 1MDB pays coupon for debt after missing two interest payments
summary: Malaysia's 1Malaysia Development Bhd (1MDB) has paid the coupon on its Islamic debt after missing two interest payments on other securities. The company made a 143.8 million ringgit payment on its 5 billion ringgit notes due 2039. 1MDB had previously missed payments due to a dispute with Abu Dhabi's International Petroleum Investment Co, leading to a default in April. The company denies wrongdoing and maintains it has sufficient liquidity to make interest payments and service its debt obligations.

site_title: Indonesia central bank to change transaction rules for JIBOR: statement
summary: Indonesia's central bank will modify the Jakarta International Offered Rate (JIBOR) transaction rules, including extending the lending period to three months and increasing the maximum transaction to 20 billion rupiah. The changes aim to provide more credible market interest rates and widen the interbank transaction window to 20 minutes. The central bank also plans to double the maximum allowed transactions.

site_title: Seoul: Won ends near 1-week low on strong dollar; stocks steady
summary: The South Korean won fell to its weakest level in nearly a week, closing at 1,191.8 per dollar, down 1.1% from Friday's close, due to a strong US dollar after Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen suggested an interest rate hike. South Korean shares were little changed, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) closing 0.1% lower at 1,967.13. Foreign investors bought 121.9 billion won worth of Kospi shares.

site_title: Airbus cuts A380 costs by shifting overheads to A320 programme
summary: Airbus is reducing the costs of its A380 superjumbo by redirecting overheads to the A320 programme, aiming to maintain its recent breakeven level. The company is shifting resources to a Hamburg assembly line for the A320neo, which will utilize a building previously used for the A380. This move comes as weak sales put pressure on A380 deliveries, and the company seeks to boost efficiency and competitiveness in the market.

site_title: Australia: Shares hold near 9-mth peak, NZ hits record high
summary: Australian shares held near a 9-month peak on Monday, driven by a rebound in oil prices and offsetting weakness in the mining sector. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 2.1 points, or 0.04%, to 5,408.0, while New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index scaled a record high, finishing at 7,019.6. This marks a 3% monthly gain for both indices, following one of the worst starts to the year.
