site_title: Singapore shares close weaker in lowest volume of the year
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 5.76 points to 2,796.75, marking one of the quietest sessions of the year, due to Wall Street's Memorial Day closure. Trading volume was the lowest of 2016, with only 834.5 million units worth S$600 million traded. Noble Group's CEO resignation and appointment of co-CEOs led to a 8.2% drop in the stock price. The Hang Seng Index added 52.62 points to close at 20,629.39.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 4.70 points to 1632.68. The market saw 31.34 million lots traded worth RM10.44 million, with 82 losers outnumbering 79 gainers.

site_title: HSBC tightens Hong Kong safe-deposit box rules to boost defences
summary: HSBC Holdings has introduced new rules for its safe-deposit boxes in Hong Kong, requiring customers to refrain from depositing items that could be considered "nuisances" or of "illegal or offensive nature". The bank aims to bolster its defenses against financial crimes, following a trend among global financial firms under scrutiny for money laundering and tax evasion. The new clauses, which include items such as explosive, inflammable, or stolen property, will further strengthen the bank's regulatory programs and compliance efforts, with a total expenditure of $700 million in the first quarter.

site_title: Prices of completed private apartments, condos rose 0.3% m-o-m in April: NUS index
summary: Singapore's completed private apartment and condo prices rose 0.3% in April, according to the National University of Singapore's (NUS) Overall Singapore Residential Price Index. This contrasts with a 1.1% decline in March. The Central Region saw a 0.4% increase, while the Non-Central Region experienced a 0.2% rise. Small units, defined as those up to 506 sq ft, also saw a 0.2% increase in April, after a 0.1% decline in March.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Wanda Group offers HK$34.5b to privatise property unit
summary: Dalian Wanda Group Co is offering HK$34.5 billion to buy out and privatize its Hong Kong-listed property unit, Dalian Wanda Commercial Properties Co, citing the unit's substantial undervaluation. The company will pay HK$52.80 for each Hong Kong-traded share, up from an earlier offer of at least HK$48. The move aims to re-list the shopping-mall operator on mainland China, following concerns from China's stock regulator about overseas listings flooding the market.

images.alt_text: Chinese billionaire Wang Jianlin's Dalian Wanda Group Co is offering HK$34.5 billion (S$6.14 billion) to buy out and privatise its Hong Kong-listed property unit as it seeks a higher valuation for the business on mainland stock exchanges.

site_title: US dollar extends gains on rate hike hopes
summary: The US dollar extended its gains in Asia on Monday due to speculation of a US rate hike, bolstered by comments from Federal Reserve boss Janet Yellen. The dollar rose to 110.95 yen from 110.37 yen on Friday, while the euro weakened to US$1.1103 from US$1.1113. A US rate hike is expected to boost the dollar against other currencies, and China's yuan fell to a five-year low against the dollar. The People's Bank of China attributed the decline to a stronger dollar due to Fed rate hike expectations.

site_title: Recovery in Chinese property market 'rather fragile,' S&P says
summary: S&P Global Ratings warns that China's property market recovery, fueled by government stimulus, is "rather fragile." The agency has downgraded 11 developers this year, citing reliance on short-term debt, margin pressure, and the risk of overpaying for land banks. The recovery is driven by liquidity, but S&P believes it may not be sustainable. This assessment is based on the developers' financial struggles and the oversupply of homes in lower-tier cities.

images.alt_text: A recovery in the Chinese property market that's been fuelled by government stimulus may not be sustainable, according to S&P Global Ratings, which has cut ratings on 11 developers this year.

site_title: Noble shareholders will be hoping Alireza was wrong: Gadfly
summary: Noble Group, a commodity trader, is selling its North American electricity-trading unit, Noble Americas Energy Solutions, after former CEO Yusuf Alireza had previously rejected the idea. The sale, expected to raise significant cash and profits, is part of Noble's efforts to free up resources and become more profitable. Despite Alireza's previous stance, the unit delivered its second-highest operating income in the first quarter, and its sale is unlikely to significantly impact Noble's balance sheet. The sale will likely benefit bondholders but may disappoint equity investors.

site_title: Oil dips as dollar rallies on news of possible US rate hike
summary: Oil prices fell in Asia on Monday after US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen hinted at a possible interest rate hike, potentially boosting the dollar and making oil more expensive. A stronger dollar makes dollar-priced oil more expensive, hurting demand and prices. Yellen's comments also raised hopes for a tightening global market ahead of an OPEC meeting this week.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks rise on bargain hunting; ASE extends gains
summary: Taiwan's main stock index rose 0.3% to 8,489.07 on Monday, driven by bargain hunting and gains in Advanced Semiconductor Engineering Inc. The company announced plans to join forces with a rival to form a new holding company, boosting investor sentiment. The electronics subindex and financials subindex also saw gains of 0.2% and 0.7% respectively.

site_title: Japan will delay sales tax hike by two and a half years: Abe
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has decided to delay the sales tax hike by two and a half years, aiming to avoid a potential economic blow. The decision comes ahead of an upper house election in July. Finance Minister Taro Aso opposed the delay, suggesting Abe should dissolve parliament and call a snap election instead.

site_title: Yuan extends weekly decline as PBOC weakens fixing to 2011 low
summary: The offshore yuan extended its weekly decline, weakening to a 2011 low after China's central bank cut the daily reference rate by 0.45% to 6.5784 per US dollar. This follows the US dollar's strength, which is poised for its biggest monthly gain since September 2014. The yuan in Hong Kong slipped 0.16% to 6.5866, its lowest level since February 3, marking four consecutive weeks of losses.

site_title: Chinese state-run bank reveals details of yuan fixing mechanism
summary: China's state-run bank, China Citic Bank Corp, has revealed details of the yuan's reference rate mechanism, including lenders that provide prices and how the system was tweaked after market turmoil in January. The mechanism, which considers previous day's yuan closing price and basket movements, aims to respond to dollar moves asymmetrically. The People's Bank of China has increased the exchange rate's two-way flexibility and maintains basic stability, amid the yuan's 1.6% decline this month. Analysts expect the mechanism to improve forecasting, but warn of potential manipulation.

site_title: Australia to auction A$16m confiscated bitcoins
summary: Australia will auction A$16 million worth of confiscated bitcoins on June 20-21, with 24,518 coins up for sale. This is the first such auction outside the US, following the 2014-2015 sale of 170,000 bitcoins by US Marshals after the closure of Silk Road. The auction is seen as a response to the surge in demand for digital currency, which has reached its highest level in nearly two years.

site_title: Hong Kong and Shanghai end higher as Asia rallies
summary: Hong Kong and Shanghai stocks rose on Monday, following a rally in Asia amid hints of a potential US interest rate hike. The Hang Seng Index increased 0.26% to 20,629.39, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.05% to 2,822.45. This follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and fresh records for the S&P 500 and Nasdaq in the US.

site_title: Australia: Shares near 9-month peak, NZ stocks scales all-time high
summary: Australian shares near a nine-month peak, while New Zealand stocks reach an all-time high, driven by a rebound in oil prices and gains in energy firms. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.1% and the S&P/NZX 50 index reached a record high, both on track for a 3% monthly gain. Energy firms like LNG, WorleyParsons, and Santos gained, while miners like BHP Billiton and Newcrest fell.

site_title: Minimum standards soon for 4G mobile telephony: minister
summary: Singapore to impose minimum standards for 4G mobile services, with a focus on Quality of Service (QoS) framework, covering both outdoor and indoor service quality. The move aims to enhance sensor data collection and support the country's Smart Nation plans, which leverage nationwide broadband connectivity. The Infocomm Media Development Authority (IMDA) will oversee the implementation, considering both infocomm and media aspects. This aligns with Singapore's goal of building a secure and resilient infrastructure to maintain reliability and trust. The country also plans to launch its National Cybersecurity Strategy document in October.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollar drift near multi-month lows after Fed rate remarks
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars dropped to multi-month lows after Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen hinted at a US interest rate hike as early as June. The Australian dollar fell to US$0.7169, while the New Zealand dollar touched its lowest in two months at US$0.6676. Investors are cautious ahead of upcoming economic data releases and a potential rate hike. The Aussie has lost 0.5% last week and is on track for its largest monthly drop in 18 months, mainly due to speculation of a US rate hike.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei hits more than 1-month high on weak yen, sales tax hike delay
summary: Japan's Nikkei share average rose 0.9% to a one-month high of 16,985.62 on May 30, driven by a weak yen and news of a delayed sales tax hike. US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen hinted at a near-term interest rate hike, supporting sentiment. The Nikkei's highest level since April 28 was reached amid improved economic and labor market conditions.

site_title: Malaysia's bond bids fewest since 2014 as debt shunned on Fed
summary: Malaysia's bond auction drew the fewest orders since 2014 as rising US interest-rate odds and a weakened currency sapped demand. The government sold 4 billion ringgit of five-year notes at a yield of 3.62%, with bids for only 1.42 times the offered amount. This follows Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's comments on possible US interest-rate increases, which has led to a selloff in emerging-market currencies and bonds. The sale was the least since December 2014, and Malaysia's ringgit has slumped 5.2% in May due to concerns over a state investment fund scandal.

site_title: Gone in four hours: LendLease sells all 391 Sydney apartments
summary: LendLease Group sold all 391 apartments at its Sydney project in just four hours, with over 400 potential buyers attending the event. The apartments were priced from A$630,000 to A$3.5 million, and the sellout comes amid renewed investor confidence following regulatory changes. The demand for inner-city homes remains buoyant, despite a looming oversupply of new apartments, which are expected to total 34,300 in the next year and double to 81,696 in the next 24 months.

site_title: Update: AirAsia gets US$1b offer to acquire leasing company
summary: AirAsia Bhd received a US$1 billion offer to acquire its aircraft-leasing company, Asia Aviation Capital Ltd. The airline intends to divest the business at some point, with CEO Tony Fernandes stating it's a "very powerful cash generator." AirAsia shares gained 4.2% after the announcement, amid a surge in the airline's profits. The leasing business can be more lucrative than operating an airline, prompting conglomerates to enter the industry.

site_title: Asia: Shares slip, dollar firm after Yellen's hike remarks
summary: Asian shares declined 0.25% on Monday, weighed down by concerns over a potential US interest rate hike, while the dollar surged to fresh highs following Federal Reserve chief Janet Yellen's comments. Yellen suggested the Fed could raise interest rates "in the coming months" if economic growth and the labor market continue to improve. The dollar index rose 0.3% to two-month highs, while the euro hit 2-1/2 month lows.

site_title: China fixes yuan at over five-year low against US dollar
summary: China's central bank set the yuan currency at a 5-year low against the US dollar at 6.5784 to US$1.0, down 0.45% from its previous fix. This move is seen as a sign of weakness in anticipation of higher US interest rates. The People's Bank of China maintains control over the currency, allowing it to rise or fall only 2% on either side of the daily fix. This move could have implications for the global economy and currency markets.

site_title: South Korea April department store sales growth at 3-month high
summary: South Korea's department store sales in April rose 4.3% from last year, the fastest pace in three months, driven by warmer weather and holidays. Sales of foreign brands surged 8.6% and discount store sales rebounded 1.7% after a decline in March. The additional public holiday in mid-April and warmer-than-usual weather contributed to the growth, with apparel seeing the most demand. This marks the best performance since a 9.0% jump in January.

site_title: Singapore stocks open lower after rate hike hints
summary: Singapore's benchmark Straits Times Index (STI) fell 4.78 points to 2,797.73 points, down 0.17%, after US Federal Reserve chairman Janet Yellen hinted at rate hikes in the coming months. The move followed other Fed officials' preparations for a second hike. Despite this, the STI has been on a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data. Top gainers included DBS, Singtel, and Jardine Strategic.

site_title: Flash: Noble CEO Yusuf Alireza resigns
summary: Noble CEO Yusuf Alireza has resigned. The company announced it will sell its US energy marketing subsidiary. This move comes after Alireza's departure. Details on the subsidiary's sale were not provided in the article.

site_title: Sembcorp delivers Hercules jack-up rig to Maersk, to receive US$190m final payment
summary: Sembcorp Marine delivered the jack-up rig Maersk Highlander to Maersk Drilling after initially being contracted to Hercules Offshore. The rig's construction was completed on schedule with zero near-misses, and it will start a five-year contract with Maersk Oil and partners worth US$420 million. Maersk Drilling will pay Sembcorp Marine US$190 million for the rig, settling the final payment. This deal resolves concerns that Hercules Offshore would be forced to declare bankruptcy.

site_title: Philippines' PLDT, Globe to acquire San Miguel's US$1.5b telco assets
summary: The Philippines' top two telecom firms, PLDT and Globe, have agreed to jointly acquire San Miguel's US$1.5 billion telecommunications assets, valued at 69.1 billion pesos. Each firm will acquire 50% of San Miguel's telco business, including a prized 700-megahertz frequency. The deal aims to improve internet and data services, with PLDT to return certain radio frequencies to the government, allowing for a third competitor to enter the market.

site_title: Seoul: Won falls to near 1-week low on Yellen remarks, stocks edge down
summary: The South Korean won fell to a near 1-week low of 1,190.2 per dollar after US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's speech on Friday hinted at a possible interest rate hike in June or July. Yellen stated that the Fed should raise interest rates if the economy picks up, suggesting an increase in the coming months. This led to a 0.9% decline in the won's value, its lowest since May 24.

site_title: Gold slumps to lowest level since February on Fed rate outlook
summary: Gold prices plummeted to a 9-month low, falling as much as 1% to $1,200.03 an ounce, following Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's statement that another interest-rate hike is likely in the coming months due to the improving US economy. This marks the worst 9-day run for gold prices in over a year, with a potential for the largest monthly loss since 2013. Bets on a rate hike in June and July remain high, with the US dollar spot index climbing 0.2% on Monday.

images.alt_text: Gold sank to the lowest level since February after Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen said the improving US economy meant another interest-rate hike would probably be in order "in the coming months", pushing the dollar to the highest since March.

site_title: Many corals dead or dying on Barrier Reef: scientists
summary: At least 35% of corals in the northern and central regions of Australia's Great Barrier Reef are dead or dying due to mass bleaching, scientists say. The bleaching event, caused by global warming, is the third time in 18 years the reef has experienced mass bleaching. Recovery is expected to take at least a decade, with the largest and oldest corals likely to take much longer to recover. The reef is already under pressure from climate change, farming run-off, and development.

site_title: China default chain reaction threatens products worth 35% of GDP
summary: China's wealth management products (WMPs) are facing a risk of a default chain reaction, threatening assets worth 35% of the country's GDP. The WMPs, which are sold by banks but often reside off their balance sheets, have swelled to 2.6 trillion yuan (S$545.4 billion) in value, with at least 10 Chinese companies defaulting on onshore bonds this year. The products' high yields and implicit backing of banks or local governments have led to concerns that a widespread loss of confidence could trigger a global financial crisis.

images.alt_text: The risk of a default chain reaction is looming over the US$3.6 trillion market for wealth management products in China.

site_title: IMF turns its back on Europeans in Greece bailout
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has refused to support Greece's third bailout program with its own financial contribution, citing a lack of a concrete plan to substantially cut the country's debt burden. The IMF demands that European countries implement measures such as cutting interest rates, extending repayment periods, and setting a long grace period before Greece must start repaying its debts. The fund's decision has raised concerns about the sustainability of Greece's finances and its ability to repay its debts, which total $16.2 billion.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open up on tax hike delay hope
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 0.82% on Monday, extending a three-session gain, as investors hoped the government would delay a planned consumption tax hike. The Nikkei 225 index reached 16,973.72, while the Topix index gained 0.71%. The positive sentiment was driven by expectations of a delay to the tax hike, which was initially set for October 2016.

site_title: RBS to cut 450 service jobs as it narrows focus in UK
summary: Royal Bank of Scotland Group Plc is cutting 450 service jobs in the UK as it narrows its focus on the country. The move is part of CEO Ross McEwan's efforts to reduce costs and maintain profitability amid low interest rates and slowing economic growth. This is the latest in a series of cost-cutting measures, with thousands of jobs and assets being shed worldwide since the bank's 2008 bailout. The restructuring aims to align the bank's support services with its new business focus.

site_title: US: Markets closed on Monday for holiday
summary: US financial markets will be closed on Monday for a public holiday. The US stock market, including the S&P 500 and Nasdaq, edged to fresh records despite ongoing tariff uncertainty. Asia markets, such as Singapore, also saw gains, with the STI up 0.4% on Thursday. Meanwhile, eSIM platform Airalo raised $220 million in funding, lifting its valuation to over $1 billion.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Noble Group, Sembcorp Marine, Tat Hong
summary: Sembcorp Marine delivered a jack-up rig to Maersk Highlander UK after settling a final payment of US$190 million. Noble Group CEO Yusuf Alireza resigned amid the sale of its US subsidiary Noble Americas Energy Solutions to bolster its balance sheet. Tat Hong Holdings reported a S$40 million loss in the fourth quarter due to sliding revenues and impairment charges.

site_title: Australia new homes sales fall in April: industry survey
summary: Australia's new homes sales fell 4.7% seasonally in April, according to the Housing Industry Association (HIA) survey, after a 8.9% surge in March. Detached home sales declined 3% and multi-unit sales dropped 10.8%. The decline signals mild home construction activity, with HIA Economist Diwa Hopkins expecting a modest decline in 2016, largely driven by multi-unit construction. This outcome still indicates healthy home construction activity throughout 2016.

images.alt_text: Sales of new homes in Australia fell in April after a surprisingly strong surge the previous month, an industry survey showed on Monday, an outcome that still pointed to healthy home construction.

site_title: New credit card scrutiny sends Indonesians back to cash
summary: Indonesia's plan to track all credit card transactions to combat tax evasion and money laundering has led to a decline in credit card usage, with card transactions dropping 4% in April and the number of transactions falling by 2 million. The return to cash is a temporary setback for the government's efforts to boost tax revenues, and consumers are wary of the increased scrutiny on their transactions. The decree, which requires credit card providers to submit transaction details to the tax office, has resulted in card cancellations and a preference for cash, which is already used for 85% of transactions in the country.

site_title: Fed's Bullard says global markets seem well-prepared for summer rate hike
summary: St Louis Federal Reserve President James Bullard stated that global markets appear to be "well-prepared" for a summer interest rate hike from the Fed. He expressed optimism that a possible rate increase could come off smoothly, despite not specifying a date. Revised US GDP growth data showed a rebound in the second quarter, potentially giving the Fed ammunition to raise interest rates as early as June or July. Bullard also emphasized the Fed's independence from politics, saying he hopes neither presidential candidate will politicize monetary policy.

site_title: Store closure impairment charges drag Japan Foods Q4 net profit down 68%
summary: Japan Foods Holdings reported a 68% decline in Q4 net profit to S$465,000 due to an impairment charge of S$810,000 from store closures. Despite this, revenue and gross profit increased by 6% each. The company attributed its stable sales to its seasonal promotions and menu rejuvenation strategies. For the full year, net profit declined 20% to S$3.8 million, while revenue remained flat at S$63 million.

site_title: Anything goes as French liqueurs keep up with world trends
summary: French liqueurs are adapting to global trends, offering a range of exotic ingredients such as rose petals, litchis, and elderflower. The industry's annual trade fair saw visitors sample tipples like these, as French producers export 53% of their 89 million bottles a year. Companies like Giffard and Maison l'Heritier-Guyot are embracing innovation while respecting traditional recipes, with sales soaring 40% in the past five years, largely driven by US demand for cocktails.

images.alt_text: Whether the ingredients are traditional, exotic or frankly bizarre, French liqueurs are reliable "ambassadors of quality", an industry leader says.

site_title: Dollar hits 1 month high against yen after Yellen builds rate hike expectations
summary: The US dollar reached a one-month high against the yen after Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen hinted at a near-term interest rate hike, citing improving US economic indicators. The dollar index rose to 95.828, its highest in two months, while the euro hovered near a 2.5-month low. Japan's planned delay of a sales tax hike and potential supplementary budget boost to the economy also supported the dollar. The delay is seen as a positive for the yen, but could lead to further monetary easing, weakening the currency.

site_title: Football: Victorious Real get hero's welcome in Spanish capital
summary: Real Madrid fans celebrated the team's historic 11th European Cup win with thousands in the streets of Madrid and a packed 80,000-seat Santiago Bernabeu stadium. The team returned home after beating Atletico Madrid in a penalty shootout in Milan, with fans showering them with praise and adoration. The open-top bus parade featured the team holding the trophy aloft as fans chanted "How can I not love you!" in the Plaza de Cibeles. The victory marked a triumphant return to the Spanish capital for Real Madrid's heroes.

site_title: Japan retail sales stall in April as Abe mulls delay to tax hike
summary: Japan's retail sales growth stalled in April, with sales remaining unchanged from the previous month, contradicting economists' forecasts of a 0.6% decline. The 0.8% decline from a year earlier also fell short of expectations. The stagnation in sales growth has fueled speculation that Prime Minister Shinzo Abe will delay a planned sales-tax increase, citing the risk of a global economic crisis and the need to sustain Japan's economic recovery. Experts believe a delay is likely, citing stagnant wages and private consumption.

site_title: Noble CEO resigns; Noble to sell US energy marketing subsidiary
summary: Yusuf Alireza, 45, CEO of Noble Group, has resigned due to family reasons. Noble will sell US energy marketing firm Noble Americas Energy Solutions to raise cash, with William Randall and Jeff Frase appointed as co-CEOs. Alireza guided the company through a challenging period, but shares fell amid market doubts over solvency during a commodity slump. The company accepted his resignation, citing a "huge commitment of time and energy" over the past 18 months.

site_title: Judge criticised by Trump unseals documents in Trump University case
summary: US District Judge Gonzalo Curiel has unsealed documents in the Trump University real estate school lawsuit, which accuses the school of misleading thousands of people who paid up to $35,000 for seminars. Judge Curiel signed the order despite Trump's criticism, calling him a "hater" for his handling of the case. Trump had previously made derogatory comments about Curiel, stating he was a "hater" and a "hostile judge" appointed by former President Barack Obama.

site_title: Iran orders social media sites to store data inside country
summary: Iran has ordered foreign social media sites to store data about Iranian users on servers within the country, giving them a year to comply. The move, part of the country's strict internet controls, raises concerns over privacy and security. The Supreme Council of Cyberspace stated that the measure is based on the "guidelines and concerns of the supreme leader" and will affect messaging app Telegram, which has 20 million users in Iran. The new requirement aims to ensure the continued activity of Iranian citizens on foreign messaging platforms.

site_title: Pope gives awards to Richard Gere, George Clooney and Salma Hayek
summary: Pope Francis awarded medals to actors Richard Gere, George Clooney, and actress Salma Hayek at a Vatican event promoting the Scholas Occurrentes foundation, which links technology and arts for social integration and peace. The foundation, inspired by the pontiff, aims to promote cultural exchange through celebrity ambassadors. Clooney attended with his wife, Amal, a lawyer, and the actors were chosen for their role in promoting one of the foundation's arts projects.

site_title: Obama's Hiroshima visit raises profile of possible Abe successor
summary: US President Barack Obama's visit to the Hiroshima peace memorial has raised the profile of Japanese Foreign Minister Fumio Kishida, a potential successor to Prime Minister Shinzo Abe. Kishida arranged the historic event, which marked a high point in his over 20 years in politics. His role in the ceremony is expected to further boost his profile, particularly among voters who favor him over other potential successors. Kishida's liberal stance and efforts to ease tensions with China and South Korea have also been highlighted, but his lack of experience in economic issues remains a concern.

images.alt_text: Japanese Foreign Minister Fumio Kishida (pictured) is widely seen as a possible successor to Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, and his role in laying the groundwork for the ceremony will further raise his profile in a country where polls showed the vast majority of voters favored the visit.

site_title: Dutch PostNl ends merger talks with Belgium's Bpost
summary: Dutch postal company PostNL announced the end of merger talks with Belgium's Bpost due to disagreements on terms. PostNL stated that the talks had concluded without an agreement. The companies had been exploring a potential partnership in the European postal market.

site_title: Peru's Fujimori seen winning presidential election next week: poll
summary: Peru's presidential contender Keiko Fujimori is seen beating rival Pedro Pablo Kuczynski in the June 5 run-off election, according to an Ipsos poll. Fujimori, 40, is projected to garner 45.9% of votes, while Kuczynski, 77, is expected to receive 40.6%. The poll has a 2.3 point margin of error and was conducted between May 26-27. Fujimori has solidified her lead despite a scandal involving her top aide, and she and Kuczynski will face off in the last televised debate before voters cast their ballots.

site_title: Negative rates failing to spur investment at Europe's companies
summary: Europe's companies are failing to be spurred into investment by negative interest rates, with 84% of surveyed businesses saying the measures have had no effect on their growth plans. This is a blow to central banks hoping to revive growth through negative rates and quantitative easing. The survey also highlighted late payments as a threat to growth, with 33% of participants saying they regard not being paid on time as a threat to overall survival. This issue is particularly pronounced among small and medium-sized companies, which are forced to accept late payments due to larger corporations.

site_title: China bets on duty-free paradise to keep luxury spenders at home
summary: China is launching a duty-free shopping paradise on the southern island of Hainan to boost local consumption and keep luxury spenders at home. The move comes as sales of luxury goods fell 2% last year due to a campaign against demonstrations of wealth among public officials and economic slowdown. Hainan's duty-free shops offer products priced 30% less than the mainland, but the choice of products is limited. The island's development aims to attract tourists and become a hub for luxury retail, with plans for luxury resorts, hotels, and a deep-water port.

site_title: US dollar index up on Yellen's rate hike remarks
summary: The US dollar index surged to a two-month high after Federal Reserve chair Janet Yellen hinted at a possible interest rate increase in the coming months. Yellen's remarks, made in Boston, were seen as a positive sign for the dollar, which rose 0.6% to 95.745. This move follows revised upward US economic growth for the first quarter and minutes from the April meeting showing Fed officials feeling the economy could be ready for another rate increase in June.

site_title: Turkey marks Constantinople "conquest"
summary: Turkey marked the 563rd anniversary of the Ottoman conquest of Istanbul with a large party and fireworks show in the city. The event commemorated the 1453 capture of Istanbul by Ottoman Sultan Mehmet II, also known as "the Conqueror." The celebration featured a fly past by the Air Force, a 3D mapping of the city as it was in 1453, and the presence of Turkish President Recip Tayyip Erdogan and Prime Minister Binali Yildirim. The event came amid heightened security, with over 9,000 police and military personnel on duty.

site_title: Goldman sees end of yuan 'sweet spot' spurring capital outflows
summary: Goldman Sachs predicts the end of China's temporary "sweet spot" exchange rate will spur renewed capital outflows, driven by a stronger US dollar and potential interest rate hikes. The yuan has declined 1.3% against the dollar this month, prompting concerns of a repeat of the 2015 turmoil that led to $1 trillion in annual capital outflows. The People's Bank of China has policy tools to manage the depreciation, but analysts expect the yuan to weaken 12.5% to 7.5 dollars by the end of the year.

site_title: How cheap oil and fewer nose jobs are hurting Thai health stocks
summary: Thai health stocks are experiencing a decline due to a decrease in Middle Eastern patients canceling treatments abroad and weak growth outlooks in the Gulf states. Bumrungrad Hospital Plc, the country's top medical tourism destination, has seen a 17% slump in patient volumes from the UAE, its second-biggest source of overseas visitors. The economic slowdown in the Middle East and rising competition from local clinics are curbing demand, affecting hospital stocks' valuations. Despite this, analysts remain bullish on the sector in the long term, citing growth potential in countries like Myanmar and Vietnam.

site_title: Oil near US$50 amid drop in US rigs, disruptions in Nigeria
summary: Oil prices rose near US$50 amid a drop in US rigs and disruptions in Nigeria. US rigs targeting crude fell to 316, with over 1,000 rigs dropped since last year. Nigerian militant attacks on pipelines further reduced supply, contributing to the rebound in oil prices. The US West Texas Intermediate crude gained 39 cents to US$49.72 a barrel, while Brent crude rose 36 cents to US$49.68 a barrel. The disruptions and output declines have helped to erode a global glut, leading to a price increase.

images.alt_text: Oil traded near US$50 after a drop in active rigs in the US and further supply disruption in Nigeria.

site_title: What you should know before renting a storage unit
summary: When considering renting a storage unit, it's essential to weigh the benefits against the potential long-term costs. Before renting, research facilities and ask about security measures, accessibility, and pricing. Set a realistic deadline and choose the smallest unit to avoid overfilling. Consider how often you'll need to access the unit and choose a facility that suits your needs. Carefully review the contract and consider insurance options. Additionally, consider hiring a company to transport your belongings to the storage facility for added convenience.

site_title: UN concerned about rising political tensions in Cambodia
summary: The United Nations is concerned about escalating tensions in Cambodia, where Prime Minister Hun Sen's ruling party is accused of persecuting the opposition. The opposition Cambodia National Rescue Party has accused the CPP of cheating in the 2013 election, and leaders are facing legal charges they claim are politically motivated. The UN's Ban Ki-moon expressed concern about the escalating tensions, emphasizing the need for a non-threatening environment of democratic dialogue for stability and prosperity. The situation is tense, with the opposition threatening mass protests and a parliamentary boycott if a key leader, Kem Sokha, is arrested.

site_title: Australia police use pepper spray as nationalists clash with anti-racism protesters
summary: Australian police used pepper spray to disperse clashes between right-wing nationalists and anti-racism protesters in Melbourne, with the United Patriots Front organizing a "Stop the Far Left" rally. The protesters, many of whom wore masks, clashed with anti-racism demonstrators, with one UPF member being kicked by activists. Two people were arrested for rioting and assault. Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull acknowledged that eliminating racism is a "work in progress," despite Australia being considered the most multicultural society in the world.

site_title: One of the world's greatest art collections hides behind this fence
summary: A large collection of artworks, including masterpieces by ancient Rome, old masters, and Picasso, is stored in free ports, tax-friendly zones in Switzerland and around the world. These free ports offer controlled climates, discreet record keeping, and tax savings, making them attractive to high-net-worth individuals (HNWIs) who view art as a capital asset. However, the trend has raised concerns about the use of these storage spaces for illegal activities and the effect on art itself, with some arguing that storing art in free ports perverts its purpose.

site_title: Oil production in Canada's Fort McMurray coming back online
summary: Oil production in Canada's Fort McMurray oil sands area is returning to normal after a month-long forest fire, with thousands of workers returning to their jobs. Suncor, a Canadian petroleum producer, has restarted production at two facilities, with plans to bring in more employees to support operations. The fire, which ordered 100,000 people to evacuate, did not damage any of Suncor's facilities, reducing Canada's oil output by an estimated 1.2 million barrels per day.

site_title: P&G looks to gain market share in Asia-Pacific
summary: Procter & Gamble (P&G) aims to gain market share in the Asia-Pacific region by leveraging digital platforms and TV to raise awareness of its brands and offering samples to attract new customers. The company's Asia-Pacific operations focus on countries such as Indonesia, Vietnam, and the Philippines, where growth is accelerating. P&G's existing brands are market leaders in their respective categories, and the company is introducing new products to fill gaps in the market. The region's growth potential and increasing population and GDP make it a key growth engine for the company.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: South Korea's June manufacturing confidence hits 7-month high
summary: South Korea's manufacturing confidence hit a 7-month high in June, with the manufacturing business survey index (BSI) rising to 72, the highest since November 2022. The index showed improvement in sentiment for both conglomerates and exporters, with companies catering to local consumers expecting slightly worsening conditions. The Bank of Korea expects exports to improve mildly in the coming months due to rising global oil prices. This marks the third consecutive month of improvement in manufacturing confidence, suggesting the economy may have bottomed out.

site_title: Sanctions gone, Iran kicks off EU trade drive in Poland
summary: Iran's foreign minister Javad Zarif launched an EU trade drive in Poland, marking the country's first major move to boost business with the West after sanctions were lifted in January. Zarif aims to increase annual bilateral trade between Poland and Iran to $1 billion, a goal also shared by Poland's ambassador to Tehran. The visit comes after major Western powers expressed support for doing business with Iran, despite US sanctions remaining in place. Zarif will also travel to Finland, Sweden, and Latvia before ending his trip on June 2.

site_title: Brexit campaign slams Cameron as Conservative rift widens
summary: Prime Minister David Cameron's Conservative Party is experiencing a widening rift over Brexit, with prominent campaigners Boris Johnson and Michael Gove accusing him of breaking his promise to cut annual immigration to tens of thousands. The migrant flow last year reached 330,000, exceeding the pledged target. Conservative lawmakers are growing increasingly dissatisfied with Cameron's leadership, with over 40 lawmakers reportedly ready to back a vote of no-confidence. The debate has turned acrimonious, with both the Remain and Leave campaigns accusing each other of misleading voters.

site_title: Hamilton ends his wait with Monaco GP victory
summary: Lewis Hamilton secured a surprise victory at the Monaco Grand Prix, ending his six-month winless streak. Hamilton took advantage of a bungled pit stop by rival Daniel Ricciardo to drive to a 7.2-second win. This marked his second Monaco triumph and 44th career win, as well as his first this season. Hamilton's victory trimmed the leader's advantage to 24 points in the title race, keeping his title defense alive.

site_title: Rates: To raise or not to raise
summary: The US Federal Reserve is considering a 0.25 percentage point interest rate hike in June, according to the minutes of the April FOMC meeting. The committee discussed the global and US economies, productivity growth, and spending patterns, with no material change in their medium-term outlook assessments. Despite soft spending in the first quarter, participants believed the apparent trend was unlikely to persist.

site_title: Stocks stage rebound, but is the market bull alive and kicking?
summary: US stocks rebounded last week after markets adjusted to a possible midsummer Federal Reserve rate hike, with oil prices stabilizing. Jobs data this week may confirm the US economy is exiting a soft patch, but it's unlikely to determine if the bull market is alive. The S&P 500 has not recorded new highs since 2014, with a year without a new high averaging a 15.8% decline in price performance. Financial sector leadership and rising Treasury rates may support equities, but a rate hike is expected in June or July, which could impact the market.

site_title: Killing of gorilla to save boy at Ohio zoo sparks outrage
summary: A 4-year-old boy fell into the gorilla enclosure at the Cincinnati Zoo, prompting zoo officials to fatally shoot the 400-pound gorilla, Harambe. The decision to use lethal force was made to prevent further harm to the child. The child suffered non-life-threatening injuries and was taken to a hospital. The incident sparked outrage and calls for the parents to be held accountable, with over 2,000 people signing a petition criticizing the zoo and police. Charges against the parents are pending, and the zoo has faced criticism for its decision, with some comparing it to a similar incident at the Pittsburgh Zoo in 2013.

site_title: Global airport trade group opposes new checkpoints
summary: The head of Airports Council International opposes new checkpoints outside airport terminals as proposed by the UN's International Civil Aviation Organization. Angela Gittens argues that external checkpoints could create a new target and trap people in a line, making them vulnerable to attacks. The ICAO is discussing creating a new standard for public areas of airports, but Gittens recommends avoiding such checkpoints.

site_title: Buying by company directors falls
summary: Singaporean company directors bought back a total of S$40.7 million worth of shares in 16 companies over the past week, marking the third consecutive week of buyback activity. Despite a decline in director buying, the overall value of repurchases increased. Notable purchases include Global Logistic Properties, which bought back S$40.7 million worth of shares, and chairman Quek Leng Chan of GL Limited, who purchased 544,000 shares. The buying activity was driven by companies rebounding from recent price drops, with shares rising by as much as 15% in some cases.

site_title: Boeing mulls larger engine for biggest 737 MAX
summary: Boeing is considering a larger engine for its 737 MAX, the company's largest narrowbody airliner, to counter Airbus's A321neo, which outsells it by four to one. The modified LEAP-1A engine would add range and capacity, potentially lengthening the 178-seat jet to 190 passengers. However, this change would incur significant costs, estimated at $1-2 billion, and raise concerns about commonality with the smaller LEAP used on the rest of the 737 MAX fleet. Boeing aims to defend its 737 franchise and carve out a space in the middle of the market between the 737 and wide-body jets.

site_title: Spain's wine industry is hiccuping from its excesses
summary: Spain's wine industry is struggling due to overproduction, which has led to low prices and a damaged reputation. The country's largest wine region, Castile-La Mancha, produces half of Spain's wine in bulk, often for re-export and blending with other wines. This has resulted in Spain losing export revenue to Italy, with the country's bulk wine displacing Italian exports in France. Some producers, such as El Progreso, are reconsidering their bulk-focused approach, while others, like La Rioja, have successfully implemented bottling requirements, which has helped to improve their wine's quality and reputation.

site_title: Making decisions as a board: minimising circular resolutions
summary: Corporate boards are increasingly using written resolutions to minimize the time spent on discussions, but this practice should be used sparingly. Written resolutions can disguise issues that management wants to avoid discussion or scrutiny, and may not allow for robust discussion and debate. The board should only use written resolutions for routine matters that cannot wait, or for issues where the board is already aware and needs final formal approval. Boards should understand when to use written resolutions and ensure that all directors have responded to the resolution before acting on it, allowing for dissenting directors to raise questions or objections.

site_title: US oil drillers cut rigs despite price recovery: Baker Hughes
summary: US oil drillers cut 2 rigs, bringing the total to 316, the lowest since October 2009. This marks the ninth week of rig cuts in the last 10, despite crude prices testing a 7-month high at $50 a barrel. The rig count is about half of the 646 rigs a year ago. Analysts predict range-bound markets for the next few months as supply outages clear a crude glut, with a price rise above $50 potentially fueling new drilling projects.

site_title: Negative rates failing to spur investment at Europe's firms
summary: Europe's companies are failing to invest due to prolonged negative interest rates, with 84% of surveyed businesses stating low interest rates have no effect on their growth plans. The strategy of keeping interest rates low has not created stability, according to a report by Swedish debt collector Intrum Justitia AB. This marks a blow to central banks hoping to revive growth through negative rates and quantitative easing. The survey also identified late payments as a threat to growth, with 33% of participants regarding late payments as a threat to overall survival.

site_title: 1997: A crack in the baht
summary: In 1997, the Bank of Thailand shocked markets by floating the baht, causing a 18% value plunge and triggering the Asian financial crisis. The crisis, which began with the baht's float, sent regional currencies plummeting, led to corporate bankruptcies, and had a lasting impact on the region. The same year saw the return of Hong Kong to China, marking the end of British colonial rule, and the acquisition of APL by NOL, which remains a topic of controversy.

site_title: France rules out Google tax deal, more firms could be targeted
summary: France has ruled out a tax deal with Google, stating it will "go all the way" to ensure multinationals pay their taxes. Following police raids on Google's Paris headquarters and McDonald's French headquarters, Finance Minister Michel Sapin said France will apply the law and not negotiate with the companies. The government is seeking back taxes from Google, estimated to be around 1.6 billion euros, and is investigating McDonald's for unpaid taxes on profits funnelled through Luxembourg and Switzerland.

site_title: Carmakers recall over 12 million US vehicles over Takata air bags
summary: Eight US carmakers are recalling over 12 million vehicles due to defective Takata air bag inflators, which can explode and spray metal shrapnel. The recall affects passenger-side inflators, with Honda recalling 4.5 million and Fiat Chrysler recalling 4.3 million vehicles. The defective inflators have been linked to at least 13 deaths and over 100 injuries worldwide. The recalls, which began in 2016, are the result of US government pressure on Takata to declare 40 million inflators defective by 2019, and will involve recalls by 17 carmakers.

images.alt_text: Eight carmakers say they are recalling more than 12 million US vehicles for defective Takata air bag inflators, widening the largest-ever car safety effort to more passenger-side devices.

site_title: Fund manager aims to transform Asia forestry sector
summary: Australia-based forestry investment manager New Forests aims to transform the Asia forestry sector with its US$170 million fund focused on sustainable forestry. The firm, with over A$2.8 billion in assets under management, has set up the 10-year Tropical Asia Forest Fund (TAFF), backed by European pension funds, international development banks, and an American fund. TAFF plans to invest in certified plantation forestry in Asia, where demand for timber, wood fibre, and natural rubber is expected to rise with growing living standards. The fund aims to restore peatland and promote sustainable forestry practices, with a potential return of US$19.4 million from the sale of rubber.

site_title: TSA's long lines were avoidable, travellers and experts say
summary: The Transportation Security Administration (TSA) is facing criticism for its handling of long lines and frustrated travelers, with some experts and airline representatives attributing the issue to a lack of resources. Despite a 15% increase in passenger travel, the TSA's workforce has declined to 44,900 screeners from 47,000 in 2013. The agency has been plagued by mismanagement, low staff morale, and high attrition rates among screeners. The TSA's administrator, Peter Neffenger, has acknowledged the agency's struggles and is working to address the issues, including hiring more staff and redirecting funds to pay for new equipment.

site_title: Brexit campaign shifts focus to immigration in attack on Cameron
summary: UK Prime Minister David Cameron is under fire from Brexit campaign leaders Boris Johnson and Michael Gove for failing to cut annual immigration to tens of thousands, a pledge made by the Conservative Party before the EU referendum. The debate has turned acrimonious with less than a month to go before the June 23 referendum. The Leave campaign is shifting focus to the impact of EU membership on migration, while the Remain campaign continues to focus on the potential economic damage of Brexit, with 88% of economists agreeing an exit would cause economic damage.

site_title: Vitamins join the 'clean label' bandwagon
summary: Ritual, a company co-founded by Katerina Schneider, is launching a multivitamin product with a "clean label" approach, stripping out unwanted ingredients such as aluminium, titanium dioxide, and gelatin. The company has attracted over $1 million in financing and will begin shipping the product in July. This trend, part of the "free of" movement, is driven by consumers demanding transparency about the ingredients and sources of vitamins. The vitamin and supplement industry is responding to the growing interest in transparency, with companies like Olly and SmartyPants Vitamins already offering clean vitamin products.

site_title: Japanese consumers divided between thrift and extravagance
summary: In Japan, consumers are increasingly opting for thriftiness, with many ordering small portions of prepared foods and buying second-hand clothing at discounted prices. The rise in thriftiness coincides with stagnant consumer spending, which has been affected by the country's consumption tax hike and weaker yen. However, some consumers are willing to splurge on luxury items, such as high-end beauty appliances and unique experiences, as long as they offer a sense of joy or satisfaction. This divide between extravagance and frugality has been a persistent trend in Japan, with some retailers, like Uniqlo and Nitori, thriving in a market dominated by low-cost and discount stores.

site_title: Series on corporate giving
summary: The Singapore government launches the Company of Good initiative, a program to encourage corporate giving and leadership in philanthropy. Led by the National Volunteer & Philanthropy Centre (NVPC) and the Singapore Business Federation Foundation, the program aims to convert non-givers into givers and multipliers of good. Examples of impactful corporate giving will be highlighted, including Samsui Supplies and Services, which now serves 500,000 meals annually to underprivileged communities. The program seeks to maximize its impact by targeting corporates, which can reach a large number of employees and create a culture of contribution.

site_title: Adidas courts controversy with camouflage at French Open
summary: Adidas has courted controversy at the French Open with its bold, camouflage-inspired tennis outfits, featuring black-and-white zebra stripes. The designs, part of Adidas' Y-3 collection, were meant to "minimise distractions" for players but instead drew criticism for being too eye-catching and disrupting the traditional French Open fashion identity. The bold look stands out against Nike's more muted palette, and its availability in Adidas stores may set a trend for the US Open.

images.alt_text: Jo-Wilfried Tsonga and Ana Ivanovic were among the players wearing Adidas' eye-boggling zebra stripes at this year's French Open.

site_title: Finding the right balance
summary: Newly-installed chef Alex Phan takes over at Restaurant Ember Hotel, a 14-year-old Singaporean restaurant, aiming to balance old classics with new local-infused creations. Phan has retained some beloved dishes while introducing market-to-table cuisine, such as crispy tempura-fried sakura ebi pasta and a tender confit duck leg. However, some dishes, like the pumpkin soup and dessert, show room for improvement. With a tough task ahead, Phan has three months to establish himself and find the right balance between tradition and innovation.

site_title: CNMC's Kelantan gold mine shines as production picks up
summary: CNMC Goldmine Holdings has seen a significant increase in gold production, tripling from 12,649 ounces in 2013 to over 30,000 ounces last year. The company's production growth is driven by its 81% ownership of the Sokor project in Kelantan, Malaysia, which contains 618,000 ounces of gold resources. CNMC's all-in costs of production have fallen to $608 an ounce, and the company expects to produce 35,600 ounces of gold in 2016, with a focus on expanding its ore processing capacity. Analysts view CNMC as a "high return, low downside risk" investment.
