site_title: Alabbar-led group's US$1.8b Americana deal collapses
summary: A Dubai-based investor group led by Mohamed Alabbar's Emaar Properties PJSC failed to buy a 69% stake in Kuwait Food Co, the operator of KFC, TGI Friday's, and Pizza Hut in the Middle East and North Africa, for US$1.8 billion. The deal, which had been in the works for over two years, ended without a final agreement due to a lack of progress. The collapse marks the latest twist in a sale process that saw multiple parties, including Temasek Holdings and KKR & Co, express interest in the company.

site_title: Autohome founder's electric car foray draws Musk comparison
summary: Li Xiang, founder of Autohome Inc, aims to start selling a commuter electric car by the end of 2017 that can be recharged as easily as a mobile phone. The car, designed to meet 90% of commuters' needs, will be powered by two 10kg batteries and have an upper speed limit of 70 kph. Chehejia, Li's Beijing-based electric vehicle business, has raised $525 million in funding and plans to start manufacturing in 2018. The company faces policy uncertainties as a major challenge, but Li believes it can penetrate the Chinese electric car market successfully.

site_title: Key drivers are window-dressing, US rates, Brexit
summary: Singapore stocks await answers to three key questions: will there be a month-ending "window-dressing" push, will the US Federal Reserve raise interest rates, and will the UK vote to exit the eurozone in the Brexit referendum. The market is also watching China's economic data and oil prices. Traders will be debating the implications of each event, with the US economy seen as robust enough to withstand rate hikes. Polls on the Brexit referendum remain inconclusive, adding to market uncertainty.

site_title: Coal India posts higher Q4 profit but misses market estimates
summary: Coal India Ltd, the world's largest coal producer, reported a Q4 profit of 42.5 billion rupees, missing market estimates of 45.5 billion rupees. The company's deliveries rose 7.8% to 145.2 million tonnes, but sales per tonne fell 7.5% to 1,429.5 rupees. A glut in the market and lower international prices contributed to the missed estimates. Coal India aims to nearly double its annual output to one billion tonnes in four years, and will increase prices by 6.29% from May 30.

site_title: Despite rally in China, steel and iron ore face worst month
summary: Chinese commodities rallied on Friday, with steel and iron ore futures still on track for their largest monthly falls on record. The gains were attributed to short-term production curbs in China's biggest steelmaking city, Tangshan, which ordered mills to cut production for five days to ease air pollution. Analysts believe the curbs will tighten supply, leading to higher prices. Despite the rally, steel futures still face a 24% loss in May, the largest since 2009.

site_title: Abe moves quickly to capitalise on success at G-7 summit
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is expected to delay the consumption tax hike from April 2017 to October 2019, while announcing a fresh spending package to boost the economy. The move comes after G-7 leaders pledged to strengthen economic policy responses and avoid a global crisis. Abe plans to apply further fiscal stimulus and structural reform, with a supplementary budget worth 5-10 trillion yen, and will also delay the national sales tax hike. This decision is seen as a response to the global economic uncertainty and a key move to support Abe's claim that the global economy is at risk of a crisis.

site_title: China's Zoomlion abandons pursuit of cranemaker Terex
summary: China's Zoomlion abandons pursuit of US crane maker Terex after terminating negotiations due to inability to reach crucial terms. Zoomlion had initially bid US$30 a share in January, but Terex instead sold its material handling and port solutions business to Konecranes for US$1.3 billion. Terex will proceed with plans to sell the business to Konecranes, which is expected to close in January. The decision allows Terex to continue discussions with Zoomlion and address potential regulatory concerns.

site_title: Europe taste for volcanic pepper lifts Cameroon
summary: Cameroon's Penja valley has become a significant producer of white pepper, with production surging to 300 tonnes a year, up from 18 tonnes five years ago. The unique volcanic soil and French entrepreneur Erwann de Kerros' discovery have contributed to its rise in popularity, fetching up to 31.25 euros per 100 grams. The European Union's geographical indications label has protected the product, boosting its reputation and providing economic benefits to farmers, with prices paid locally increasing fivefold. This has attracted hundreds of new farmers to the industry, with six more African products expected to receive the label in the near future.

site_title: How renovations can affect the value of a home
summary: Sellers who want to recoup more of their investment in home renovations are advised to opt for "boring" updates, such as new insulation, garage doors, and roofs, which have a higher return on investment. Renovations like new kitchens and bathrooms, while desirable, have a lower return, typically recovering only 67% of their cost. The type of renovation and market demand also play a significant role in determining its value. Additionally, renovations beyond three years may not significantly impact the home's value, as the "new car smell" wears off.

site_title: Hamilton wins Monaco showcase
summary: Lewis Hamilton won the Monaco Grand Prix, his first win of the season, after a crash-filled event. Hamilton's teammate Nico Rosberg finished seventh, 93.2 seconds behind, after being told to let Hamilton pass early. Daniel Ricciardo finished second for Red Bull, and Sergio Perez third for Force India. The win cuts Rosberg's lead over Hamilton to 24 points, 6 of 21 rounds into the season.

site_title: Mapletree Logistics Trust to pick up 4 Sydney warehouses for A$85m
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust has agreed to acquire four dry warehouse facilities in Sydney, Australia for A$85 million (S$84.4 million), expected to be accretive at the distribution level. The properties are 100% leased, with a weighted average lease expiry of 5.5 years, and will contribute 6.1% to the trust's overall gross revenue. The acquisition will grow the trust's portfolio to 122 properties with a book value of S$5.2 billion, and is expected to be completed in July subject to approval.

site_title: Abe aide says delaying Japan sales-tax increase is only option
summary: Japan will likely delay increasing its sales tax for 2.5 years from April 2017 due to economic recovery concerns, according to Hakubun Shimomura, an aide to Prime Minister Shinzo Abe. The decision comes amid a slowdown in the Chinese economy and weaker equities markets, which are negatively affecting Japanese consumer spending. If Abe fails to proceed with the tax increase, it may indicate the failure of his economic policies, leading to his cabinet members' resignation.

site_title: Insurance no easy sell - there's an image problem
summary: US life insurance sales are declining despite the growing millennial generation starting families, with 30% of Americans needing more coverage. The industry's complex and confusing products, lengthy paperwork, and pushy sales tactics contribute to the image problem. Experts recommend term policies and buying through employers, but the industry has struggled to adapt to changing consumer behavior. Companies like Northwestern Mutual are innovating with digital tools and personalized financial planning, but face-to-face meetings remain essential for selling insurance products. The industry must rethink its approach to emphasize insurance's benefits for customers during their lifetimes.

site_title: Lots of trouble brewing at Technics Oil & Gas
summary: Eversendai Corp, a Malaysian-listed turnkey contractor, has acquired a 29.87% stake in Technics Oil & Gas, a Singapore-based company that makes process modules and gas compression units for oil and gas players. Technics' stock value plummeted over 80% in mid-February after it failed to secure a major deal, and it has since faced several challenges, including a lawsuit from a connected entity and a lease dispute with Soilbuild Business Reit. Eversendai's stake in Technics has been built up through several transactions, and its involvement has raised questions about whether it is a white knight or an injured horseman.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Publicly traded insurers losing ground to mutual companies
summary: US life insurance companies, including publicly traded giants like MetLife and Prudential, are losing market share to mutual companies due to persistent shareholder calls for higher returns. Since 2008, publicly traded insurers have seen their share of the $4 trillion US life insurance market shrink, with mutual companies earning a record 31.5% of premiums. The trend is attributed to rock-bottom interest rates and pressure to deliver short-term profits, leading to lower credit ratings and higher capital costs. This has made it difficult for publicly traded companies to compete, with some, like MetLife, planning to exit the life insurance business.

site_title: Bayer close to picking financing banks for Monsanto bid: sources
summary: Bayer is close to selecting banks to arrange funds for its proposed acquisition of Monsanto Co, valued at US$62 billion. The German company will likely raise over US$40 billion in short-term bridge financing and most of the remainder in term loans. Bayer has interviewed lenders and is likely to select about half a dozen banks, with banks offering up to US$50 billion in bridge loans. Funding negotiations are ongoing, with Bayer considering selling convertible debt and banks offering additional financing to give Bayer room to increase its offer.

site_title: Opportunities in Russia
summary: Singapore businesses see opportunities in Russia despite the country's economic slowdown and Western sanctions. Experts believe Russia's established research and innovation culture, strong manufacturing sector, and growing demand for electronics components make it an attractive market. However, challenges such as language barriers, unpredictable leadership, and intellectual property concerns must be addressed. Many companies, including electronics distributors and recruitment firms, are already exploring business opportunities in Russia, with some seeing potential in the country's special economic zones like Skolkovo. A free trade agreement with Russia is expected to boost economic ties and open up more opportunities for Singaporean organizations.

site_title: Low Thia Khiang survives challenge from Chen Show Mao for WP top post
summary: Workers' Party chief Low Thia Khiang was re-elected secretary-general despite being challenged by Chen Show Mao. Low secured 61 votes, while Chen received 45. Chen was re-elected to the party's Central Executive Council. The party also appointed 28 new cadres, with up to two-thirds brought in by Low. The election results come after the party appointed new members to the CEC in 2015.

images.alt_text: Mr Low, who took up the secretary-general role in 2001, was said to have retained his seat with 61 votes versus 45 for Mr Chen.

site_title: Rising rates
summary: Singapore stocks have recorded a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, while the US stock market reached fresh records despite ongoing tariff concerns. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq indices edged higher, driven by gains in mining and healthcare sectors. Meanwhile, Asia's stocks rally continued, with traders brushing off new Trump threats. Notable deals include Sam Goi's mandatory offer for the rest of PSC at S$0.40 per share.

site_title: Pricing ecosystem services
summary: A growing trend in Singapore supports pricing ecosystem services, which include valuable resources like clean water and fertile soil, and good environmental practices. This concept, similar to carbon credits, may be traded to promote sustainable practices. However, no specific implementation or results are mentioned in the provided articles.

site_title: Africa far from debt crisis, says regional bank
summary: Africa is not facing a debt crisis, despite commercial lending to the continent increasing, according to the African Development Bank. Debt levels across the continent's 54 countries average 17-18% of GDP, considered low. While some countries have high debt levels, the bank says the economies are resilient and growth is expected to exceed 4.5% in 2017. The bank is prepared to assist countries that ask for help and could work with other lenders to manage debt and implement reforms.

site_title: French PM says he will not bow to labour reform protestors
summary: French Prime Minister Manuel Valls has refused to back down on labor reform, despite protests and strikes by unions such as the hardline CGT. Valls stated that conceding to protesters would be a short-term gain that would ultimately lead to loss of control. The government is under pressure to find a solution before the Euro 2016 soccer tournament, which the CGT has threatened to disrupt. Finance Minister Michel Sapin emphasized the government's firm stance, saying it would be wrong to compromise on labor unions' support.

site_title: First phase of new global forex code of conduct formulated
summary: A global code of conduct for the foreign exchange market has been formulated by 16 central banks, aiming to counter rate rigging, insider dealing, and corruption. The code, led by the Reserve Bank of Australia, Federal Reserve Bank of New York, and Bank of England, includes six principles: promoting a fair, liquid, and transparent market, avoiding disruptive transactions, and disclosing price ranges. The code is designed to rebuild trust in the market and encourage honest and fair trading practices among traders and banks.

site_title: Small plane crashes in New York's Hudson River, one dead
summary: A small plane, a World War II-era P-47 Thunderbolt, crashed into the Hudson River in New York on Friday, killing one person believed to be the pilot. The plane was set to participate in an air show this weekend. After a search, divers recovered the body, confirming the fatality. The cause of the crash is currently under investigation.

site_title: Empty chairs at empty tables explained
summary: The Singapore production of Les Misérables experienced a last-minute cancellation on its opening night due to a human error by Sistic's ticketing unit, which mistakenly sold tickets to a dress rehearsal show on May 29 to the public. The error was not discovered until five months later, and affected ticket-holders were only contacted and offered replacement tickets after a commentary by The Business Times raised concerns. The show's promoter and producer have since clarified that the May 29 show was a dress rehearsal and not intended for paying patrons, and the production is set to proceed as scheduled.

site_title: Messi due to go on trial in Spain for tax fraud
summary: Lionel Messi is set to go on trial in Barcelona on Tuesday for allegedly defrauding Spain of over four million euros in unpaid taxes. The five-time World Player of the Year and his father, Jorge Horacio Messi, are accused of using fake companies in Belize and Uruguay to avoid paying taxes on Messi's image rights from 2007-09. The trial will run until June 2, and Messi may only show up for his testimony, as prosecutors are seeking a jail sentence of 22-and-a-half months. If found guilty, the sentence is likely to be suspended due to its length.

images.alt_text: The football star and his defence team have argued that the player's father handled his finances without reporting to him.

site_title: Alabbar-led group's US$1.8b Americana acquisition collapses
summary: A Dubai-based investor group led by Mohamed Alabbar ended talks to buy a 69% stake in Kuwait Food Co, a Middle Eastern fast-food operator valued at $1.8 billion. The deal had been in the works for at least two years, with various parties expressing interest, including Temasek Holdings and KKR & Co. The talks collapsed without a final agreement, with Al Khair National for Stocks and Real Estate LLC stating that negotiations were ended due to a lack of a deal. The stake in Americana, which operates KFC and other restaurants, will remain on the market.

site_title: Emerging market flows return as investors look for value
summary: Investors are shifting their focus to emerging markets, with fund managers moving from "underweight" to "neutral" on the asset class. Notably, Latin America has seen significant net inflows, with Brazil up 26% year-to-date. Fund managers favor countries with strong domestic growth, low reliance on dollar borrowings, and companies with "incredible business models" such as e-commerce and stock exchanges. The main concern is the US interest rate hike cycle, but analysts believe sentiment will improve if the US dollar stops strengthening and corporate profitability improves.

site_title: Most economists say Brexit will harm economy
summary: Most economists in the UK's financial district and academia believe the economy will be harmed if Britain leaves the European Union. A poll of over 600 economists found that 88% said an exit would damage Britain's growth prospects over the next five years and 82% said it would have a negative impact on household incomes. The poll is a boost for Prime Minister David Cameron, who is leading the campaign to stay in the EU at a referendum on June 23.

site_title: Chinese users criticise Microsoft's push for Windows 10 upgrade
summary: Chinese users are criticizing Microsoft for its mandatory upgrade to Windows 10, citing the lack of an opt-out option and potential financial losses. Over 1.2 million posts on Weibo express discontent, with a legal adviser stating that users have the right to file lawsuits against the company. Microsoft claims that users have the option to cancel or reschedule the upgrade, but critics argue that the pop-up window does not provide a clear decline option. The move has disrupted business operations and caused financial losses, prompting calls for fair play and user rights.

site_title: Singapore's third bus operator Tower Transit launches first 9 services
summary: Singapore's third bus operator, Tower Transit, launched its first nine services on May 29, 2016, under the Government's bus contracting regime. This move aims to deliver higher bus standards for commuters. The launch marks a new start for the country's bus sector, following the introduction of two previous operators.

site_title: Abu Dhabi govt may act to address property glut
summary: Abu Dhabi's property market is over-supplied, with residential prices flat in the first quarter of 2016. The government may take steps to address the imbalance, with Chairman of Abu Dhabi's economic department Ali Majid al-Mansouri stating there is a difference between supply and demand. Unit completions are at a 10-year low, attributed to developer wariness, liquidity issues, and regulation. The government plans to issue tenders for $5.45 billion in infrastructure works, potentially involving public-private partnerships, to help balance the market.

site_title: Mapletree Logistics Trust to pay A$85m for four Sydney warehouses
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust is acquiring four dry warehouse facilities in Sydney, Australia for A$85 million. The purchase expands the trust's Sydney footprint to five assets, totaling 108,300 sq m. The properties are fully leased to established local industry players with a weighted-average lease expiry of 5.5 years. The acquisition aims to grow the trust's presence in the Australian logistics market.

site_title: French govt keeps up tough line as petrol shortages ease
summary: The French government remains firm on a contentious labour law despite protests and petrol shortages. Demonstrators blockaded oil refineries and struck transport networks, forcing the government to dip into strategic fuel reserves. The law aims to free up France's rigid labour market, but unions demand its scrapping. President Francois Hollande and Prime Minister Manuel Valls vowed to defend the law, with further protests and strikes expected this week. Despite improving petrol shortages, the situation remains tense ahead of the Euro 2016 championships.

images.alt_text: Mr Valls said he would "ensure that people can buy petrol and that businesses won't be penalised by the blockages".

site_title: Johnny Depp ordered to stay away from wife over abuse claim
summary: Johnny Depp was ordered by a Los Angeles court to stay 91m away from his wife Amber Heard, who claims he physically and verbally abused her during their relationship. Heard appeared in court with a black eye, showing pictures of her injuries and alleging Depp offered her money to stay quiet after a fight. The order will be reviewed on June 17, with Heard seeking spousal support and custody of their dogs.

site_title: Korean Air passengers recall near-disaster at Tokyo airport
summary: A Korean Air Boeing 777 experienced a near-disaster at Tokyo's Haneda airport on Friday when one of its twin engines caught fire while gaining speed for take-off. All 302 passengers and 17 crew members evacuated safely via emergency slides onto the runway. The plane, in service for 15 years, had the troubled engine installed a year and a half ago. The South Korean transport ministry sent investigators to Japan to determine the cause of the accident, which was reportedly triggered by a bang and plume of black smoke from the wing.

site_title: Regulation key in unlocking value in industry 4.0
summary: The Fourth Industrial Revolution, driven by emerging technologies, is poised to disrupt industries globally, with digital transformation at its core. Policymakers must balance innovation with consumer protection, fostering a regulatory framework that encourages business growth while safeguarding consumer rights. Effective regulation can create incentives for companies to realize societal value, but the pace of innovation outstrips regulatory change, posing a challenge for regulators to keep pace. To address this, regulators must adopt a more integrated approach, considering global and trans-regional developments, and establish policies that promote innovation while protecting consumers.

site_title: Obama wraps up historic Asia trip
summary: US President Barack Obama concluded a historic Asia trip, visiting Vietnam and Japan. He lifted an arms embargo on Vietnam, four decades after the US withdrew its last troops, and appealed to its leaders to lift authoritarianism. Obama also paid tribute to Hiroshima's victims and raised concerns over escalating tensions with North Korea. The trip aimed to deepen US involvement in the region, amid China's growing influence and reclamation projects in the South China Sea. Obama's visit comes ahead of his presidency's end in eight months.

site_title: Vintage plane crashed in Hudson River during emergency landing -owner
summary: A vintage World War Two-era P-47 Thunderbolt plane crashed into the Hudson River off Manhattan on May 29, 2016, during an emergency landing. The pilot, William Gordon, 56, of Key West, Florida, was killed. The American Airpower Museum stated that Gordon executed a "forced emergency landing" after the aircraft's engine failed. An investigation by the FAA and NTSB is underway. The incident occurred during Fleet Week, a US military celebration, and was witnessed by several people who saw the pilot struggling to exit the cockpit after the plane struck the water.

images.alt_text: The pilot of a World War Two-era plane killed in a crash in the Hudson River off Manhattan on Friday evening was trying to execute an emergency landing, the museum that owned the vintage aircraft said.

site_title: Checkmate? Purists fight to revive Myanmar's ancient chess
summary: In Myanmar, a unique form of chess called Sittuyin is struggling to survive due to a lack of traditional sets and knowledge about the rules. The game, which dates back over a thousand years, features distinctive pieces and moves that echo ancient warfare strategies. Efforts to revive the game include modernizing rules, creating affordable sets, and developing mobile apps. Despite its rarity, Sittuyin has been recognized as an important addition to the global pantheon of chess varieties, with experts calling for its preservation to promote cultural diversity.

site_title: French finmin rules out Google tax deal
summary: France's Finance Minister Michel Sapin ruled out a tax deal with Google, stating that France "will go all the way" to ensure multinationals pay their taxes. Police raided Google's Paris headquarters and McDonald's French headquarters in separate investigations into tax evasion. Sapin said France will not negotiate tax deals like Britain did with Google, and that the country is seeking €1.6 billion in back taxes from Google. The investigations build on previous work by French tax authorities, who have already raked in €3.3 billion in back taxes from five multinationals in 2015.

site_title: Pakistani PM to undergo heart surgery in London
summary: Pakistani Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif will undergo open heart surgery in London on Tuesday. The surgery, his second in five years, is due to a complication from an earlier procedure in 2011. Sharif's daughter Maryam Nawaz Sharif tweeted that prayers are the most effective medicine for her father, and Defence Minister Khawaja Asif said he will be hospitalized for a week after the surgery. Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi also wished Sharif well, and Sharif is expected to return to Pakistan after recovery.

images.alt_text: Pakistani Prime Minister Nawaz Sharif will undergo open heart surgery in London on Tuesday, his family and media said.

site_title: Citigroup says Saudi Arabia is best emerging market for deals
summary: Citigroup believes Saudi Arabia is the best emerging market for deals due to the country's planned privatisations, including a share sale in Saudi Arabian Oil Co., which could value the company at over $2 trillion. The move is part of Crown Prince Mohammed bin Salman's Vision 2030 plan to restructure the economy and reduce reliance on oil. Global investment banks, including Citigroup, JPMorgan Chase, and HSBC, are competing for roles advising the government on various deals, including an initial public offering scheduled for 2018.

site_title: Private firm hired to hunt for EgyptAir black boxes
summary: EgyptAir Flight MS804 crashed in the Mediterranean last week, killing 66 people. A private firm, Deep Ocean Search (DOS), has been hired to search and retrieve the two data recorders from the wreckage. The Egyptian government signed an agreement with DOS to carry out the process. The crash occurred between the Greek island of Crete and Egypt's north coast, and an investigation into the cause of the accident is ongoing.

site_title: Global airport trade group opposes new checkpoints after attacks
summary: The head of Airports Council International, Angela Gittens, opposes the creation of new checkpoints outside airport terminals as a proposed global security standard by the UN's International Civil Aviation Organisation. Gittens believes external checkpoints could create a new target and compromise airport security. The ICAO is discussing a new standard for security rules in public areas of airports, which are currently run by local authorities. Gittens advocates for a focus on internal airport security measures instead.

site_title: Extreme connectivity
summary: Plantronics introduces the Voyager 5200 Bluetooth headset, designed for extreme use. The device features a flexible rubber shell and a foldable hook-like design for a secure fit. It also boasts advanced connectivity and noise handling capabilities, allowing for clear communication in harsh environments. The headset's innovative design and technology make it ideal for users who need reliable communication in demanding situations.

site_title: Oil prices slip from US$50 level
summary: World oil prices dropped on Friday, falling below the US$50 level, as traders took profits after crude rose above the psychological threshold earlier in the week. The drop was attributed to evidence of a fall in supplies. In the US, traders remained cautious ahead of the Memorial Day holiday weekend, with many already out.

site_title: Outrage in multi-ethnic Malaysia as government backs Islamic law
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak's government has backed an Islamic penal code that includes amputations and stoning, sparking outrage among critics and ethnic minority groups. The bill, which includes enhanced punishment for certain offenses, was submitted to parliament despite opposition from allies and critics, who argue it undermines the country's secular constitution. Najib claims the bill is "misunderstood" and only applies to Muslims, but critics say it's a ploy to appease Muslim voters ahead of by-elections and a general election in 2018.

site_title: All about team effort
summary: The Boustead Group, a Malaysian company, has been a long-time supporter of the Business Times Corporate Golf League, both as a sponsor and participating team since its inception in 2010.

site_title: Singing the song of angry men
summary: A Singaporean production of Les Miserables was initially set to open on May 29 but was cancelled and rescheduled for May 31. The promoter failed to provide an explanation for the cancellation, only offering replacement tickets to affected ticket buyers. The author of an article, a self-proclaimed Les Miz fan, was also unable to receive a response from the promoter's corporate communications team after a month of follow-up inquiries. The lack of transparency and customer service has sparked criticism, with some suggesting that the audience should be compensated for the inconvenience.

site_title: Justin Bieber hit with Sorry copyright suit
summary: Casey Dienel, a singer known as White Hinterland, has filed a copyright lawsuit against Justin Bieber, claiming he stole a distinctive vocal riff from her song "Ring The Bell" in his hit single "Sorry". The lawsuit alleges Bieber's team took the riff without permission, distorting it electronically. Dienel is seeking "substantial" profits from Bieber's song, which will be determined at a jury trial. The country's international and domestic bonds have performed well this year, with returns of 10.1% and 10% respectively, the best in emerging Asia. A rating upgrade is expected to boost the region's appeal, as other emerging markets such as Brazil and Poland suffer downgrades. Indonesian debt is seen as having room to rally in the event of an upgrade, with local bonds attracting significant foreign investment.

site_title: Yellen may help pave way for higher rates on Friday
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen may signal a potential rate hike in July, according to market expectations. Yellen's cautious tone since the last rate hike in December suggests she is reevaluating the US economy's inflation and global risks. Markets have already increased expectations of a second hike, with a 55% probability of a July move. Yellen's upcoming appearance at Harvard University may provide insight into her thoughts on inflation and global risks, potentially paving the way for a higher interest rate in July.

site_title: SBI posts sharpest fall in profit since 2011
summary: State Bank of India (SBI), India's largest lender by assets, reported a 66% drop in net income to 12.6 billion rupees for the first quarter of 2016, due to a surge in provisions for bad loans. The lender's gross bad-loan ratio widened to 6.5% and provisions for bad loans jumped 58%. SBI aims to bolster profits despite uncertain outlook for bad loans, with analysts expecting a stronger balance sheet and profit growth from next year. The central bank audit has triggered a surge in provisions, but SBI's capital-adequacy ratio remains at 13.1%.

site_title: Tat Hong drops dividend as Q4 loss more than doubles
summary: Tat Hong Holdings, a crane rental company, posted a Q4 net loss of S$39.81 million, more than doubling from the previous year, due to weakness in the construction sector. Revenue fell 7% to S$126.72 million, with its distribution segment being hit hardest. The company declared zero final dividend and warned of continued market weakness and project completions hurting turnover. For the full year, Tat Hong posted a net loss of S$39.31 million, with revenue falling 13% to S$528.23 million.

site_title: 6 Bangladeshi workers detained under ISA charged with financing terrorism
summary: Six Bangladeshi workers detained under Singapore's Internal Security Act (ISA) have been charged with financing terrorism. The six men, aged 26-31, were part of the Islamic State in Bangladesh (ISB) and planned attacks to topple the Bangladeshi government. They were charged with providing or collecting money for terrorism under the Terrorism (Suppression of Financing) Act. The men, led by Rahman Mizanur, are expected to plead guilty on May 31, marking the first prosecution under the Act.

images.alt_text: Six Bangladeshi workers detained last month under the Internal Security Act (ISA) were charged on Friday (May 27) with financing terrorism.

site_title: Fuel-sipping Ssangyong
summary: The Ssangyong Tivoli Diesel is a compact crossover with a powerful yet economical 1.6L turbodiesel engine, producing 115 hp and 300 Nm of torque. The vehicle has excellent low-end oomph, good NVH levels, and consumes just 5.5 liters per 100km. It comes with a 6-speed automatic transmission, Smart Steer function, and a spacious cabin. The Tivoli Diesel costs S$10,000 more than the petrol version but offers impressive fuel economy and lower diesel prices, making it a viable alternative for those seeking a fuel-efficient vehicle.

site_title: Malaysian PM says police to investigate Wall Street Journal over leaked document
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak announced that the police will investigate the Wall Street Journal over leaking a confidential document related to an inquiry into the scandal-hit government fund 1Malaysia Development Bhd. The document was published by the Wall Street Journal, which denied publishing fake information and remains committed to fair reporting. Najib emphasized the seriousness of publishing confidential documents under Malaysia's Official Secrets Act and called for answers from the Wall Street Journal.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Brokerages have upgraded their ratings for Yangzijiang Shipbuilding (YZJ) to "buy" due to its strong financial performance and established track record in the shipbuilding industry. YZJ's cash pile and good execution abilities inspire confidence among customers, with a potential upside of 18.7%. City Developments (CDL) is also seen as a positive pick, with a move to unlock the value of its high-end properties through a profit participation securities structure. Valuetronics Holdings, which has seen a 19.6% year-on-year fall in revenue, is also upgraded to "add" due to its growth in the industrial and commercial electronics segment.

site_title: Aerospace industry takes small steps toward Big Data
summary: The aerospace industry is taking small steps towards leveraging Big Data to reduce production costs, optimize flight routes, and improve aircraft maintenance. Despite the potential of sensors and data analysis, planemakers and suppliers are struggling to fully utilize the technology. Executives from companies like Airbus and Snecma are discussing digitalization strategies, which could lead to improved engine production, optimized routes, and real-time monitoring of aircraft systems. However, significant industrial issues and coordination challenges remain to be addressed before the industry can fully capitalize on the benefits of Big Data.

site_title: Preventing a stroke
summary: Most strokes are potentially preventable, and they can occur in people of all ages, not just older individuals. Atrial fibrillation (AF), an abnormal heart rhythm, is a major cause of stroke and can occur in those over 60, as well as younger people with high thyroid hormones. Symptoms of AF include a fluttering heart and breathlessness, which should not be dismissed as anxiety. By being aware of these risks and taking preventative measures, such as managing blood pressure and cholesterol levels, individuals can reduce their risk of stroke.

images.alt_text: CLOSER LOOK: New strokes detected on magnetic resonance imaging brain scans were significantly higher than clinically detectable strokes; brain image by MRI scanner at the CEMEREM in Marseille.

site_title: UK lawmakers say both sides of Brexit debate make bogus claims
summary: UK lawmakers recommend an "amnesty" for misleading claims made by both sides in the Brexit debate, citing the public's confusion. The Treasury Select Committee's report does not reach a conclusion on the costs and benefits of EU membership. Chairman Andrew Tyrie stated that the "arms race" of claims has been confusing the public. The report's findings do not impact the upcoming June 23 referendum.

images.alt_text: Both sides in Britain's referendum on whether to stay in the European Union should agree an "amnesty" on misleading and bogus claims, a parliamentary report said on Friday.

site_title: Paris and Berlin ready new EU plan for after Brexit vote
summary: European Union heavyweights France and Germany are preparing a joint plan for the EU's future, regardless of the outcome of the Brexit referendum. The plan, which will focus on communication and values, is set to be discussed by French President Francois Hollande and German Chancellor Angela Merkel in eastern France on Sunday. The joint initiative aims to address security and youth unemployment issues across the EU, and will not be limited to the eurozone. The plan is seen as a response to the potential consequences of Britain's potential exit from the EU.

site_title: Technology enables individuals to build institutions: Microsoft chief
summary: Microsoft CEO Satya Nadella emphasized the importance of digital technology in empowering individuals to build institutions that outlast them. During a visit to Singapore, he signed a memorandum of understanding with the National University of Singapore (NUS) to collaborate on data-science education and research. The partnership aims to develop a pool of skilled individuals in data analytics and research, supporting Singapore's "Smart Nation" vision. Microsoft will provide education programs and advanced analytics tools, while NUS will focus on research areas such as data science, deep learning, and artificial intelligence.

site_title: Six appeal
summary: The Honda Jade RS is a six-seat sports wagon with a 2-2-2 seating configuration. It boasts a sleek design, low belt line, and big wheels. The interior features a pair of captain seats in the second row, individual seats in the third row, and a versatile cargo area that can be folded flat. The Jade RS is powered by a 1.5-litre turbocharged engine delivering 150 hp and 203 Nm to the front wheels. It has a smooth and linear performance, with a seven-step continuously variable transmission and a well-weighted steering system.

site_title: ISEC Healthcare to buy four medical clinics in diversification
summary: ISEC Healthcare plans to acquire four medical clinics in Singapore for approximately S$13.9 million, expanding into general medical services and aesthetic treatment services. The clinics have a stable income stream and profit track record for the past five years. The acquisition will allow ISEC to tap into the patient base of the clinics and expand its services to HDB neighborhoods. The vendors will receive half of the consideration in cash and the other half in new shares at a 10% discount. The deal includes profit guarantees and employment contracts for five years.

site_title: Consumer sentiment in US increased less than forecast in May
summary: US consumer confidence rose to 94.7 in May, less than forecast, as Americans became slightly less optimistic about the economy ahead of the presidential election. Household purchasing power is improving, with 64% of Americans expecting their finances to improve over the next 12 months. The current conditions index reached 109.9, its highest level since January 2007, while expectations six months from now rose to 84.9. Respondents also expect lower inflation rates, with 2.4% projected for the next year, the lowest since September 2010.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 6.1 points to close at 1,637.19, driven by gains in 403 stocks while 390 lost value. 1.84 billion lots valued at RM1.94 billion were traded.

site_title: Blackstone said planning US$1.1b sale of European hotels
summary: Blackstone Group LP plans to sell European hotel buildings operated under Hilton Worldwide Holdings Inc's DoubleTree brand for approximately $1.53 billion. The hotels are located in London, Dublin, and Amsterdam. This sale is part of a trend of European hotel owners selling properties to capitalize on growing travel demand in the region, which saw a 79% increase in lodging deals to 23 billion euros in 2015.

site_title: Mermaid Maritime bags subsea contracts off the Middle East, Thailand
summary: Singapore-listed Mermaid Maritime has secured subsea contracts worth US$62 million off the Middle East and Thailand. The company's western hemisphere business unit won seven projects with an estimated aggregate value of US$11 million in Saudi Arabia, while a one-year extension to an existing contract valued at US$51 million was granted in Thailand. Mermaid's CEO, Chalermchai Mahagitsiri, stated the company was awarded work for the 12th consecutive year from the same client.

site_title: Singapore property market may reach bottom before HK
summary: Singapore's property market may be nearing its bottom, potentially before Hong Kong, according to LaSalle Investment Management. Home prices in Singapore have dropped 1.2% since September and 9% from their peak in 2013, while Hong Kong prices have fallen 13% since September. LaSalle's Chris Chow believes Singapore's market is further along in its correction cycle and may be closer to a bottom, citing a stronger demand for logistics investments in China and Japan.

site_title: US Q1 economic growth revised up to 0.8%
summary: US economic growth in the first quarter was revised up to 0.8% annual rate, beating initial estimates of 0.5%. The upward revision was driven by increased spending on home building and inventory investment by businesses. The economy also saw a rebound in after-tax corporate profits, growing at a 0.6% rate. Despite a strong dollar and sluggish global demand, the economy has shown signs of regaining momentum in the second quarter, with retail sales and housing starts surging in April.

site_title: Easing of car loan rules comes with potential downside
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has relaxed vehicle financing restrictions, allowing loan quantum to rise to 60% or 70% of car price and maximum loan tenure to seven years. The move is expected to boost demand for new cars and stimulate the economy, but may lead to higher COE premiums. COE premiums are likely to rise by an average of S$10,000 over the next 12 months, generating an additional S$800 million in revenue for the government. The easing of rules aims to promote financial prudence and a car-lite society, but raises concerns about the potential for overstretching among car buyers.

site_title: Oil prices fall back after breaching US$50
summary: World oil prices fell on Friday after breaching the US$50 mark, with traders banking profits. This move comes after crude prices rose above US$50 on evidence of lower supplies. Analysts warn that the surge could trigger North American shale producers to resume output, potentially making it unprofitable for them to compete with traditional producers like Opec and Russia.

site_title: US: Wall St opens flat as focus turns to Yellen
summary: US stocks opened flat on Friday, with the Dow Jones industrial average rising 6.51 points to 17,834.8, the S&P 500 index gaining 1.57 points to 2,091.67, and the Nasdaq composite index adding 2.83 points to 4,904.59. The focus turned to Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's speech for clues on the timing of the next interest rate hike, but investors seemed unconcerned, brushing off recent US President Trump's threats to extend the stocks rally.

site_title: Xyec to be absorbed into Tokyo-listed Mamezou after delisting
summary: Xyec Holdings, a Japanese engineering and IT services provider, will be delisted and merged with its controlling shareholder, Mamezou Holdings, after a privatization bid. The merger agreement was reached, with Xyec's extraordinary general meeting scheduled for June 30. The delisting and merger will be governed by Japanese law, not Singaporean law. This marks the end of Xyec's time on the Catalist exchange.

site_title: China, EU Commission edge towards deal on market economy status
summary: The European Commission and China are close to a deal on China's market economy status, which would benefit Beijing and make it easier for China to export into the EU. The EU wants to enhance its ability to defend itself against cheap Chinese imports, while China is willing to retaliate if the deal is not reached. The Commission's proposal will be debated by EU lawmakers, who have previously rejected considering China as a market economy in trade disputes, citing concerns over record Chinese steel output. A deal would avoid a WTO dispute and a wider trade war.

site_title: Obama pays tribute at Hiroshima nuclear memorial
summary: Barack Obama paid tribute to Hiroshima nuclear memorial victims, becoming the first sitting US leader to visit the site. He laid a wreath, honoring the 71-year-old nuclear attack that changed the world. Obama reflected on the devastating force of the bomb, urging a moral revolution to balance technological progress. He emphasized the importance of imagining the moment the bomb fell and feeling the dread of those affected, calling for a renewed focus on human institutions.

site_title: SHS plans to acquire corrosion control firms related to controlling shareholder
summary: SHS Holdings plans to acquire four corrosion control material providers for S$56.3 million to S$75 million. The acquisition is subject to shareholder approval at an extraordinary general meeting. The firm is owned by controlling shareholder Mr. Teng, who also owns Entraco Marine Engineering and Entraco Offshore. The proposed deal aims to strengthen SHS's position in the industry, but no specific details on the expected outcomes or timeline have been released.

site_title: YCH, Pangan Lestari ink MOU to develop cold chain supply management
summary: YCH Indonesia and PT Pangan Lestari signed a memorandum of understanding (MOU) to develop integrated cold chain supply management in Indonesia. The partnership aims to facilitate retail, catering, and distribution through facility expansion and new site development. Over the next six months, the companies will collaborate on feasibility studies, supply chain management services, and joint marketing activities targeting Indonesian customers, particularly in the quick service restaurant sector. The move is expected to enhance supply chain efficiency and support Singaporean SMEs' expansion into the Indonesian market.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's services industry business receipts fell 3.8% in Q1, according to the Department of Statistics. Standard Chartered Bank increased its investments in Singapore with a $45 million purchase of a Changi Business Park office. Meanwhile, French insurer AXA announced a management reshuffle under its new CEO. Hackers linked to a $81 million heist from Bangladesh's central bank were also linked to a Philippine bank attack and the 2014 Sony hack, according to Symantec Corp.

site_title: World's biggest hedge funds lose market share: Preqin
summary: The world's largest hedge funds lost market share to smaller rivals in the past year due to underperformance, according to Preqin. The total assets of funds with over $1 billion dropped to 88% from 92% in the year-earlier period. Thirty-seven percent of these funds lost investor money, but a majority secured net inflows. Despite this, 98 new funds reached the $1 billion threshold, including five new launches, as the average hedge fund lost 0.63% in the first quarter.

site_title: Lereno Bio-Chem to buy Malaysian property developer Majubina Projects in RTO
summary: Lereno Bio-Chem Ltd, a Singaporean cash company, plans to acquire Malaysian property developer Majubina Projects for S$50 million through a reverse takeover (RTO). The acquisition is part of Lereno's corporate strategy to transform into a property developer. Majubina Projects is involved in various sectors, including property development, civil works, and commodities trading. The proposed acquisition aims to lift Lereno's "cash company" status, and the deal is expected to be fulfilled by the issuance of new shares.

site_title: Singapore court revokes bail decision for ex-BSI wealth manager
summary: A Singapore High Court has revoked bail for Yeo Jiawei, a former wealth manager at BSI, in connection with the city-state's money laundering investigation into 1Malaysia Development Berhad. Yeo, who is facing nine charges, will remain in prison while awaiting his trial. Prosecutors presented fresh evidence, including secret profits of around $18 million, and the court urged both sides to expedite the trial for two of the charges. The case is linked to illicit money transfers and is part of a broader international investigation.

site_title: India's Tata Group enters e-commerce market with apparel, electronics website
summary: Tata Group, India's largest conglomerate, launched its e-commerce venture, Tata Cliq, a marketplace for apparel and electronics, after a year-and-a-half development at a cost of "several hundred million dollars." The move aims to capitalize on India's growing middle class and rapid internet adoption, with online merchandise sales expected to reach $220 billion by 2025. Tata Cliq focuses on profit margins and unit economics, avoiding discounts and instead building inventory networks around existing store locations, as the e-commerce market in India is dominated by deep-pocketed international retailers and startups.

site_title: Swiss banks, retailers to launch mobile payments platform for shoppers
summary: Switzerland's five largest banks and major retailers, including Coop and Swisscom, will launch a mobile payments platform called TWINT later this year. The system, set to combine existing mobile payment systems, will allow consumers to pay for goods and services using their smartphones. Participating banks include UBS, Credit Suisse, PostFinance, Raiffeisen, and ZKB, with the aim of creating a unified digital payment system for the country. The TWINT platform is expected to be open to other retailers as well, expanding the country's mobile payment capabilities.

site_title: Tap to eat
summary: Singapore's food delivery market has grown significantly with the launch of new services, including UberEATS, Deliveroo, foodpanda, and Hawker.Today. UberEATS, launched on May 25, 2016, offers delivery from over 100 restaurants, primarily in central zones. Deliveroo, launched six months earlier, boasts 1,200 restaurants and 1,100 riders, with plans to expand islandwide. foodpanda has seen a 20% monthly growth rate and has over 1,000 riders. Hawker.Today, a local startup, aims to serve 2,000 hawker stalls by the end of the year. Despite the growing competition, the market still has room for expansion, with estimates suggesting a demand of over 200,000 orders per day.
