site_title: How airports can get rid of TSA screeners
summary: Airports are exploring the option of replacing TSA screeners with private contractors to alleviate security line congestion. Several airports, including Phoenix Sky Harbor International Airport and Seattle Tacoma International Airport, are researching the Screening Partnership Program, which allows private firms to follow the same security protocols as federal officers. However, the effectiveness of private screeners is disputed, with some airports experiencing longer lines and missed flights despite hiring private contractors. The TSA argues there is no correlation between security wait times and the use of federal or private screeners, while security experts recommend increasing screening officers, PreCheck enrollment, and dog sniffers to improve wait times.

site_title: StanChart increases investment in Singapore to improve efficiency
summary: Standard Chartered Bank has increased its investment in Singapore to improve efficiency by buying a second office building in Changi Business Park for S$45 million. The bank has spent a total of S$104.5 million on two properties, consolidating its 7,000 staff across two main locations. This move aims to enhance operational efficiency and better serve its 4,000 employees currently based in Changi Business Park.

site_title: Japan follows US in ordering more Takata air bag recalls
summary: Japan has ordered carmakers to recall an additional 7 million vehicles with Takata air bag inflators, bringing the total to 19.6 million. The US regulator had previously recalled up to 40 million air bags linked to deadly malfunctions. Moisture in the inflators causes misfires and ruptures, resulting in over a dozen deaths and hundreds of injuries globally. Car manufacturers must complete the repairs by March 2019, while Takata aims to provide replacement inflators as soon as possible.

site_title: Singapore shares close higher for week - was it month-ending window-dressing?
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 1.3% to 2,802.51 for the week, driven by a 29.2-point gain on Friday. However, trading volume was low, with 72% of the week's best volume coming from 30 index components. Some analysts suggest month-ending window-dressing may have contributed to the rise, while others note the lack of significant news or events in the past week. The index's rally may not be sustainable, and investors remain cautious due to tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Push for encryption law falters despite Apple case spotlight
summary: US lawmakers' push for a law requiring technology companies to provide law enforcement with a "back door" to encrypted communications has largely faltered, despite a 2016 San Bernardino shooting that killed 14 people. Draft legislation by Senators Richard Burr and Dianne Feinstein is unlikely to be introduced this year, and even if it were, it would likely fail to advance. The momentum behind the effort has dissipated, with lawmakers and the tech sector losing interest in the proposal.

site_title: GIC consortium said among bidders for Sithe Global Power assets
summary: A consortium including Singapore's GIC Pte, Macquarie Infrastructure Corp, and Malakoff Corp submitted a non-binding offer for Sithe Global Power LLC's stakes in two Philippine power plants, Mariveles and Dinginin. The sale could fetch over $1 billion. Thailand's Ratchaburi Electricity Generating Holding Pcl, Aboitiz Power Corp, and Japan's Marubeni Corp also placed bids. The deal is part of the rising trend of dealmaking in the Asia Pacific power and utilities industries, with $170 billion in announced mergers and acquisitions in 2024.

site_title: Shanghai: Stocks fall for 6th straight week on economy fears
summary: China's Shanghai Composite Index fell fractionally lower, marking a sixth straight week of losses, as industrial profit data raised concerns about the economy's health. The index declined 0.2% for the week, losing over 8% since mid-April. Investors remain cautious, citing worries about China's economic health and a possible US rate hike. Trading volume in Shanghai reached a near five-month low, with sector performance mixed.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times, while US stocks opened lower due to fresh tariffs on Canada. Creative Technology warned of lower-than-expected H2 revenue and operating loss similar to H1. London's Heathrow plans to increase airport fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case. OCBC announced Tan Teck Long as its incoming CEO. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) and People's Bank of China (PBOC) will deepen cooperation in green and transition finance. Singapore stocks rallied for the 5th consecutive day ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: Daimler invests 3b euros in clean diesel technology
summary: Daimler invests 3 billion euros in clean diesel technology, aiming to reduce diesel exhaust pollution levels in its European diesel cars. The investment includes selective catalytic reduction technology, particulate filters, and engine technology improvements such as turbocharging and intercooling. The company has already announced a 2.6 billion euro investment in February.

images.alt_text: Daimler said it will spend 3 billion euros (S$4.6 billion) to curtail diesel exhaust pollution levels by modifying its engines and exhaust treatment systems including through a software update for some Mercedes-Benz passenger cars.

site_title: New farm for Chew's Group to require S$77m in capex
summary: Chew's Group, an egg producer, plans to build a new farm requiring S$77 million in capital expenditure. The funding will come from government sale proceeds and borrowings. The new farm will have an integrated farming concept and allow production to double from 500,000 to 1 million eggs per day. Chew's will lease the current Murai facilities for poultry farming for three years, ensuring business continuity. The relocation is expected to be completed by May 31, 2019.

site_title: Taiwan cuts 2016 GDP outlook again as export slide deepens
summary: Taiwan's government has cut its 2016 GDP outlook for the third time, citing weak demand for technology exports and China's slowdown. The revised forecast now predicts 1.06% growth, down from a previous 1.47% estimate. The country's economy contracted 0.68% in the first quarter, but showed a revised growth of 3.14% on a seasonally-adjusted basis. This marks the third downgrade in forecasts since February, highlighting the challenges facing Taiwan's trade-reliant economy.

site_title: 6 Bangladeshi workers detained last month under ISA charged with financing terrorism
summary: Six Bangladeshi workers detained under the ISA in May were charged with financing terrorism, with the group planning attacks to topple the Bangladeshi government. The men, aged 26-31, were part of the Islamic State in Bangladesh (ISB). They were among eight arrested in late March and early April. The charges are related to their alleged plans to destabilize the Bangladeshi government.

site_title: Technics Oil & Gas: Not aware of explanation for unusual trading activity
summary: Technics Oil & Gas stated it is unaware of any information explaining the unusual price and volume movements in its shares, closing at S$0.07 after opening at S$0.083, down 7.4 cents. The company recently announced several legal suits, including a bank guarantee dispute and loan repayment issues. Technics is in compliance with listing rules and has not provided any explanation for the trading activity.

site_title: Hong Kong shares end at 3-week high on hopes of more China link-ups
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 0.9% to a three-week high on Friday, driven by hopes of expanded cross-border investment opportunities with China. The Hang Seng index gained 3.6% for the week. Traders expect China's approval of a plan to link the Shenzhen and Hong Kong stock markets, as well as the expansion of the Shanghai-Hong Kong connect programme. This news revived buying interest and lifted the China Enterprises Index 0.8%.

site_title: India will have 8-10 state-owned banks after consolidation: Fin Min's Sinha
summary: India plans to consolidate its state-owned banks to 8-10 "very competitive" banks, down from 27, according to junior Finance Minister Jayant Sinha. The move aims to improve the struggling banks' competitiveness, with some expected to become large-scale global players. Sinha's comments come as state-owned banks face a weight of bad loans, highlighting the need for consolidation to strengthen the banking sector.

site_title: 'Most beloved elephant in Japan' dies, aged 69
summary: Hanako, Japan's oldest elephant, aged 69, died quietly after spending 69 years in captivity. The cause of death was unknown, and an autopsy was scheduled. Hanako gained international attention last year for her cramped living conditions, leading to improvements. She became a media star after a heart-wrenching blog post and a viral petition, with over 400,000 signatures. Hanako lived longer than the average 55-60-year life span of wild elephants and was described as a "gentle giant" with a dark past.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei rises amid prospect of tax hike delay, weaker yen
summary: Japanese stocks rose 0.4% on Friday, driven by speculation that Prime Minister Shinzo Abe may delay a sales tax hike scheduled for next April. The Nikkei share average ended at 16,834.84, with exporters' shares mixed amid a volatile yen. Market optimism over US interest rate hikes and global economic growth lifted stocks, with Panasonic and Sharp Corp gaining. Toshiba Corp surged 11% after JP Morgan raised its rating of the firm's stock to "overweight".

site_title: Tat Hong deepens loss in Q4, drops dividend
summary: Tat Hong Holdings, a crane rental company, reported a widened net loss of S$39.81 million in its fourth quarter, a 133% increase from the same period last year. Revenue also declined 7% year-on-year to S$126.72 million. The company's weakness in the construction sector is attributed to ongoing economic challenges.

images.alt_text: CRANE rental company Tat Hong Holdings sank deeper into the red in its fourth quarter, as weakness in the construction sector continued to bite.

site_title: Maybank's quarterly profit falls 16% on higher provisions
summary: Malaysia's largest lender, Maybank, reported a 16% drop in first-quarter profit to 1.43 billion ringgit due to increased provisions for loan restructuring. The bank cited a subdued operating environment and slower economic growth in Malaysia. Despite this, Maybank expects a "satisfactory" financial performance for the year. This comes as smaller rival CIMB Group Holdings Bhd also maintains a cautious outlook for the year due to regional economic challenges.

site_title: Singapore's services industry business receipts down 3.8% in Q1
summary: Singapore's services industry business receipts declined 3.8% in Q1 2016, with the education services industry recording the highest growth of 5.6%. The health & social services industry saw a 2.9% increase, while the business services and recreation & personal services industries fell 7.5% and 7.3% respectively. On a year-on-year basis, business receipts rose 0.3%.

images.alt_text: Business receipts of Singapore's services industries (excluding wholesale & retail trade and accommodation & food services) fell 3.8 per cent in the first quarter of 2016 over the previous quarter, according to data released by the Department of Statistics on Friday.

site_title: Indonesia to sign oil, LPG import deal with Iran
summary: Indonesia is set to sign a deal with Iran for the purchase of crude oil and liquefied petroleum gas (LPG) on Sunday, according to an official from state energy company Pertamina. Energy Minister Sudirman Said is expected to attend the OPEC meeting in Vienna on June 2. This deal is seen as a significant move for Indonesia's energy needs, and the country's energy minister is leading the delegation to sign the agreement.

site_title: Philips lighting shares soar after 750m euro Dutch IPO
summary: Philips Lighting, the world's largest general luminaries business, raised 750 million euros (S$1.15 billion) in its initial public offering (IPO) with shares jumping 5.7% to 21.14 euros in their trading debut. The Dutch parent company, Royal Philips, listed the business in Amsterdam after failing to conclude a private sale, and plans to retain 71.25% of the stake. The IPO marks a shift towards focusing on the global health-care market, with CEO Frans van Houten stating the move will allow the company to focus on the fast-growing health technology market.

images.alt_text: Philips Lighting NV shares jumped in their trading debut after Dutch parent company Royal Philips NV raised 750 million euros (S$1.15 billion) in an initial public offering of the world's biggest general luminaries business.

site_title: Vietnam's Jan-May crude oil exports drop 20.6% y/y: govt
summary: Vietnam's crude oil exports dropped 20.6% in January-May, reaching 3.06 million tonnes, resulting in a 49.2% decline in export revenues to $883 million. Oil product imports rose 27.6% to 5.4 million tonnes, while liquefied petroleum gas imports increased 3%. The country's crude oil production averaged 350,000 barrels per day.

site_title: French vessel containing black box probes arrives to EgyptAir search zone
summary: A French vessel carrying specialized probes has arrived at the search zone for the EgyptAir jet that crashed last week, killing 66 people. The vessel, operated by Alcen's AlSEAMAR, is equipped with DETECTOR-6000 systems designed to detect black-box pinger signals over long distances. Despite a week of searching, investigators have yet to find any clear evidence of the plane's final moments. The probe's arrival marks a new step in the search effort, but officials still have no clear picture of the crash's cause or circumstances.

images.alt_text: A French vessel carrying specialist probes designed to detect black box pinger signals has arrived to the search area where an EgyptAir jet is believed to have crashed last week, sources on the investigation committee said on Friday.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks end at 2-week high, won steady
summary: South Korean shares rose 0.6% on Friday, closing at a two-week high and ending a four-week losing streak, as foreign investors sought bargains. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) gained 1.1% for the week. The South Korean won remained nearly flat, quoted at 1,179.3 to the dollar.

site_title: AXA names new management team under new CEO ahead of investor day
summary: AXA has announced a new management team under its incoming CEO, Thomas Buberl, who is expected to focus on shareholder returns and digital transformation. The reshuffle includes Benoit Claveranne as chief transformation officer and Paul Evans in charge of life and saving, global health division. Analysts expect the new management to target earnings growth above consensus and signal a possibility of higher dividends. AXA also plans to post an exceptional gain of 1.1 billion euros from real estate disposals in the US, freeing up capital for higher returns.

images.alt_text: French insurer AXA on Friday announced a broad management reshuffle under its incoming CEO, who is expected to focus on shareholder returns and digital transformation when he presents a strategic plan on June 21.

site_title: Europe: Equities ease lower at open
summary: European stock markets declined at the start of trading on Friday, with London's FTSE 100 index down 0.04%, Frankfurt's DAX 30 index down 0.1%, and Paris' CAC 40 index down 0.3%. The declines followed a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks. US stocks, however, edged to fresh records despite ongoing US-EU trade talks and tariff uncertainty. The S&P 500 and Nasdaq indices rose, with investors seemingly unaffected by recent Trump threats.

site_title: HKEx aims to launch first exchange-traded USD/CNH option this year: exec
summary: The Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing Ltd (HKEx) plans to launch the world's first exchange-traded USD/CNH option product by the end of this year, amid growing demand to hedge currency risk due to a more volatile yuan. The move comes after the People's Bank of China allowed more two-way volatility in the currency. HKEx is also considering introducing yuan currency futures against the Korean won and the British pound, following the successful launch of four yuan futures next Monday.

site_title: Symantec says Swift heist linked to Philippines attack, Sony hack
summary: Hackers linked to the $81 million Bangladesh central bank heist in 2016 have also been linked to an attack on a bank in the Philippines and the 2014 Sony Pictures hack. The US has previously blamed the Sony attack on North Korea, while cybersecurity firm BAE Systems found similar code used in both attacks. The attacks occurred in October last year and the Philippines bank was not named.

site_title: India's Maruti Suzuki to recall 77,380 vehicles
summary: Maruti Suzuki India Ltd is recalling 77,380 vehicles to upgrade airbag controller software and replace faulty fuel filters. The recall affects 75,419 Baleno cars, 1,961 DZire diesel hatchback cars, and includes diesel cars manufactured between August 2015 and March 2016. Dealers will contact buyers starting May 31 to arrange inspections and replacements. The move aims to address safety concerns and prevent potential issues with the vehicles.

site_title: Dollar climbs, traders await Yellen speech for Fed clues
summary: The US dollar index rose 0.1% on Friday, on track for its strongest monthly performance since November, amid expectations of a Federal Reserve rate hike in June. The dollar has gained 2.3% this month, driven by hawkish comments from Fed officials. Fed Chair Janet Yellen's speech next week is expected to provide further guidance, with investors awaiting data on US non-farm payrolls and ISM data. The euro eased to $1.1180, while the yen remained flat against the dollar.

images.alt_text: The dollar index rose on Friday, on track for its strongest monthly performance since last November amid expectations the Federal Reserve may raise rates in coming months and investors awaiting fresh guidance from the head of the US central bank.

site_title: Duterte death squad fears rise as Philippine police kill eight
summary: Philippine police have killed eight suspected drug dealers in a series of raids, sparking fears of mass extra-judicial killings under President-elect Rodrigo Duterte's rule. Three petty criminals were also murdered in Duterte's hometown of Davao. Authorities claim the killings were lawful, but critics fear a surge in violence under Duterte's leadership. The incidents have deepened concerns about the potential for human rights abuses under the new administration, which begins on June 30.

site_title: India Inc shows growth spreading by end of Modi's sophomore year
summary: India's economy is showing signs of broad-based growth, with companies posting their best earnings results since Prime Minister Narendra Modi took power two years ago. The country is forecast to have a 7.5% year-on-year growth rate in the January-March quarter, slightly faster than the previous quarter. Operating profits for 289 companies reporting results jumped 25.5% year-on-year, with sectors tied to infrastructure and capital goods showing signs of recovery. Despite weak private investment and low capacity utilization, the outlook appears to be brightening, with lower interest rates and government spending supporting growth.

site_title: China faces headaches from warming Viet-US ties
summary: The US and Vietnam have strengthened ties, complicating China's strategic outlook in the South China Sea. US President Barack Obama lifted the arms embargo on Vietnam during a visit, stating it was not directed at China. Regional military sources and analysts believe China will face short-term headaches, including increased regional military presence, and long-term strategic challenges due to Vietnam's growing military capabilities and strengthened relations with the US. This development may limit China's influence in the region.

site_title: Australia: Shares hit nine month top; NZ index nears 7000 points
summary: Australian shares reached a nine-month high, closing at 5,405.90, driven by buying in big banks and healthcare firms. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.3% on Thursday and hit 5,427.70 at midday. Investors remained cautious ahead of US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's speech, potentially signaling interest rate changes.

site_title: China's services trade deficit narrows to US$20.3b in April: FX regulator
summary: China's services trade deficit narrowed to $20.3 billion in April, down from $21 billion in March, largely due to a $18.3 billion gap in spending between Chinese and foreign tourists. China had a $44.4 billion surplus on trade of goods in April. The commerce ministry expects China's services trade to grow rapidly, exceeding $750 billion in 2016.

images.alt_text: China's trade deficit in services narrowed to US$20.3 billion in April from US$21 billion in March, the foreign exchange regulator said on Thursday.

site_title: Yen edges up after G7 vows against forex market intervention
summary: The yen edged up against the dollar and euro after the G7 reaffirmed its commitment not to intervene in foreign exchange markets, citing the risk of competitive devaluation and disorderly movements. The dollar fell to 109.74 yen, while the euro edged lower to 122.83 yen. Analysts attributed the yen's rise to thin trading ahead of US economic growth data and a speech by Federal Reserve chief Janet Yellen, which may provide clues about a possible interest rate hike. The G7's stance is seen as a relief for Japan, which has threatened to intervene in forex markets to tame a resurgent yen.

site_title: Hot stock: Technics Oil & Gas down more than 23% on legal woes
summary: Technics Oil & Gas shares plummeted 23% to S$0.065 on Friday, amid a series of legal woes. The company faced two writs of summons from former director Ting Tiong Ching and Hup Seng Offshore Engineering, claiming repayment of loans and interest. The Singapore Exchange (SGX) issued a query on trading activity, citing "unusual volume movements". This is the second query in three months, prompting a query by SGX.

site_title: Chinese, Malaysians charged after large Australia drug haul
summary: Australian authorities have charged 14 suspects, including eight Chinese and six Malaysians, over a massive AUD200 million ice seizure. The suspects were allegedly part of an international drug ring, with the drugs transported from a commercial fishing boat to Western Australia via small watercraft. The charges carry a maximum penalty of life imprisonment, and police praised the cooperation between agencies in targeting complex criminal syndicates. The seizure is considered the biggest in Western Australia this year, and the charges mark a significant disruption to an organised crime network.

site_title: Global steel oversupply must be 'urgently addressed': G7
summary: World leaders at the G7 summit warned that the global steel oversupply must be "urgently addressed" and attributed the issue to governments that contribute to excess capacity, hinting at China. China is accused of flooding the market with steel products sold below cost, violating global trade rules. The Group of Seven called for the elimination of market distorting measures and enhancement of market function to address the issue. Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe emphasized the need for close communication with China to abide by international trade rules and ensure coexistence and prosperity.

site_title: NZ budget's strong economic, fiscal outlooks are credit positive: Moody's
summary: Moody's Investors Service has stated that New Zealand's budget is credit positive due to strong economic and fiscal outlooks. The government now expects a NZ$668 million surplus in 2016 and NZ$719 million in 2017, surpassing previous forecasts. Moody's considers the projections reasonable but notes risks from economic failure, housing prices, household debt, and lower dairy prices. The rapid population growth poses a challenge for social services and infrastructure, prompting the government to invest in infrastructure. Moody's rates New Zealand at triple A.

site_title: Korean Air evacuates plane at Japan's Haneda airport after engine smoke
summary: Korean Air evacuated 319 passengers and crew from a Boeing 777 at Japan's Haneda Airport after smoke came from its left engine. The aircraft, due to fly to Seoul, was sprayed with foam by fire trucks and had four emergency slides deployed. Authorities temporarily closed the airport, Japan's busiest hub, in response to the incident. The cause of the smoke is not specified, but the plane is powered by two Pratt & Whitney PW4000 engines. The evacuation occurred on May 27, 2016.

site_title: Australia: Stocks hit nine-month high, NZ up on banks, health care
summary: Australian and New Zealand shares rose on Friday, with the S&P/ASX 200 index reaching a nine-month high. The index was up 0.54% at 5,417.10, driven by gains in big banks and health care stocks. CSL Ltd, a top health care stock, reached an all-time high. Markets are now awaiting US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's comments, which may impact interest rates.

site_title: Push for encryption law falters despite Apple case spotlight
summary: US lawmakers' push for a law requiring technology companies to provide law enforcement with a "back door" to encrypted communications has stalled, just months after a San Bernardino shooting left 14 dead. The proposed legislation, led by Senators Richard Burr and Dianne Feinstein, is unlikely to be introduced this year and would face significant opposition from the tech sector. The effort to create a backdoor for law enforcement has largely lost momentum, with key supporters losing interest.

site_title: Zoomlion drops Terex acquisition plan after disagreements
summary: Zoomlion Heavy Industry Science and Technology Co has dropped its plan to acquire US-based crane maker Terex Corp after failing to agree on terms in negotiations that began four months ago. The Chinese company had initially raised its takeover offer to US$31 per share, but ultimately was unable to reach an agreement with Terex. The deal would have given Zoomlion a market valuation of US$2.7 billion. Terex shares fell 3.45% to US$24.33 following the news.

site_title: Boxing: Philippines' gold dream fades as Pacquiao rules out Rio
summary: Philippines boxing legend Manny Pacquiao has ruled out competing in the upcoming Rio Olympics, even if professional boxers were allowed to participate. Pacquiao, who was elected to the Senate and is considering a presidential run, prioritizes his legislative duties over his boxing career. The International Boxing Association had proposed allowing professionals to compete, but Pacquiao says he doesn't have enough time to prepare. The decision may be a blow to the Philippines' Olympic hopes, which had seen Pacquiao as a potential gold medal contender.

site_title: Japan developers may cancel 70% of solar on rules, BNEF says
summary: Japan's Ministry of Economy, Trade and Industry approved 75 gigawatts of solar projects, but 53 gigawatts remain offline due to a backlog. A new law change may cancel up to 70% of approved projects, including 22.2 gigawatts of larger projects and 13.2 gigawatts of smaller ones, if they fail to secure a grid connection by March 31. The change aims to address the growing backlog of solar projects, with Bloomberg New Energy Finance estimating 37.2 gigawatts will be canceled under the new rule.

site_title: China's yuan off early highs on US dollar demand, eyes on Yellen speech
summary: China's yuan closed at 6.5603 per US dollar, down slightly from midday, after early highs amid corporate demand for US dollars and anticipation of a potential US interest rate hike. The yuan has lost 1.2% against the US dollar in May, with pessimistic bets rising to the largest since early February. The People's Bank of China set the midpoint rate at 6.5490 per US dollar, and offshore markets showed a 0.06% softer trade. Despite expectations of a rate hike, Chinese traders believe Beijing will keep a firm hand on the yuan's movements.

images.alt_text: The yuan came off early highs on Friday amid robust corporate demand for US dollars and as traders awaited a speech by Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen later in the day for more clues on the timing of the next US interest rate hike.

site_title: Brexit a 'serious risk to growth': G7 leaders
summary: G7 leaders warn a British secession from the European Union in the June 23 referendum could have disastrous economic consequences, reversing global trade and investment trends. They stress that the decision is up to British voters, but express concerns over potential global selloffs, violent currency fluctuations, and economic turmoil. The International Monetary Fund has also warned of a severe global market reaction to a "Leave" vote, while G7 finance ministers earlier warned of a global "shock".

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks climb to new 1-month high; chip firms rally
summary: Taiwan's main TAIEX index rose 0.4% to a fresh one-month high of 8,431.22 points, driven by gains in chip firms Advanced Semiconductor Engineering Inc and Siliconware Precision Industries. The electronics subindex surged 0.5% and ASE surged 10%, while the Taiwan dollar firmed to T$32.508 per US dollar.

site_title: Singapore property closer to bottom than Hong Kong: LaSalle Investment Management
summary: Singapore's property market may be closer to a bottom than Hong Kong's, according to LaSalle Investment Management. Home prices in both cities have corrected amid a slowdown in regional economies. In Hong Kong, prices have dropped 13% since September, while in Singapore, they have fallen 9% from the 2013 peak. LaSalle believes Singapore's market is further advanced in its correction, with a possible bottom in sight, and is shifting focus to investments in China and Japan.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open slightly higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened slightly higher on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 1.130 points to 1631.110. The market saw a 105-94 gain-to-lose ratio, with 58.3 million lots traded worth RM42.5 million.

site_title: G7 vows growth, fudges FX, frets North Korea, Russia, China
summary: The Group of Seven industrial powers pledged to seek strong global growth while papering over differences on currencies and stimulus policies. They committed to market-based exchange rates and avoiding competitive devaluation, and vowed a more forceful policy mix to achieve balanced growth. The G7 also expressed concern over North Korea, Russia, and maritime disputes involving China, and called for countries to settle disputes by peaceful means. The group emphasized the need for flexible fiscal policy and increasing global aid for refugees and displaced people.

site_title: Clinton: Email controversy won't affect my White House bid
summary: Hillary Clinton defended her use of a private email server for official correspondence as US secretary of state, stating it was comparable to her predecessors. A critical State Department investigation found fault in her use of personal email for government business, but Clinton vowed it wouldn't affect her White House bid, saying "nothing has changed."

images.alt_text: Hillary Clinton defended her use of a private email server for official correspondence while US secretary of state on Thursday, insisting her actions were no different than that of her predecessors.

site_title: What's for dinner? Seaweed, at Chile's top restaurant
summary: Chilean chef Rodolfo Guzman's restaurant, Borago, has gained international recognition for its unique use of seaweed, algae, and other marine delicacies. The 42nd-ranked restaurant in the world's 50 best list, Borago celebrates local ingredients, including "sea figs," beach chard, and rock clovers, which are rich in protein and have distinct salty flavors. Guzman's vision aims to promote Chile's endemic plant life and indigenous Mapuche roots, setting the nation's cuisine apart from its neighbor Peru, which is a culinary darling.

site_title: Venezuelan opposition investigating alleged corruption amounting to US$69b
summary: Venezuela's opposition-controlled legislature is investigating 89 alleged cases of corruption involving US$69 billion, deposited into accounts abroad, involving current and former government officials. The probe examines sectors such as food and health, and irregularities linked to tight currency controls. The investigation aims to "locate where the money is" and "repatriate it." This comes as President Nicolas Maduro's government faces criticism over its handling of the country's severe economic crisis, including shortages of food and medicine. The probe is seen as a response to Maduro's party's defeat in parliamentary elections in December.

site_title: Two tourists killed, two missing in speed boat accident at Koh Samui
summary: Two foreign tourists, a 28-year-old British woman and a 29-year-old German woman, were killed in a speed boat accident off Koh Samui in Thailand. Two others, a woman from Hong Kong and a man from the UK, are missing. The boat, carrying 32 tourists and four crew, capsized after being slammed by a wave near a rocky stretch of coast. Four tourists were hospitalized for injuries, and the Thai captain of the speedboat has been detained for questioning. The incident highlights the risks of weak safety regulations in the tourism industry.

site_title: Gold on track for biggest decline in 9 weeks
summary: Gold prices are on track for their biggest weekly decline in nine weeks, falling about 2.4% so far this week. Despite a 0.2% gain early on Friday, spot gold remains near seven-week lows. Positive economic data suggests US interest rates may rise in the next two months, boosting expectations for gold prices.

site_title: Hong Kong and Shanghai slide in early trade
summary: Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index and Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.27% and 0.16% respectively, while the Shenzhen Composite Index decreased 0.25%. The declines followed US stocks finishing slightly lower.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars set to end May with large losses
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars are expected to end May with significant losses despite a brief recovery on Friday. The Australian dollar rose to US$0.7224, but major resistance was found at US$0.7250. Both currencies remain under pressure ahead of upcoming economic data releases in Australia. The New Zealand dollar has not been mentioned in the article.

site_title: China flags room to boost government debt to support growth
summary: China's government has room to borrow more to support economic growth, with overall risks from government debt at a manageable level. The Ministry of Finance stated that China's debt ratio remains below international warning levels, allowing for gradual leverage. This move aims to help the corporate sector deleverage, according to experts. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers, but the country's government debt is seen as a manageable risk.

site_title: Bank of Korea says it sees exports slump easing
summary: South Korea's central bank, the Bank of Korea, expects the country's export slump to ease, but not immediately. Key factors contributing to this optimism include rising oil prices and a slight recovery in display and steel product prices. However, the bank notes that the export decline will not turn around drastically due to sluggishness in major customer countries such as China. Domestic consumption and construction investment are expected to rise in the coming months, while capital investment is likely to remain unchanged. The Bank of Korea's projection suggests a gradual improvement in exports.

site_title: Gawker hires banker to explore sale after Hulk Hogan suit
summary: Gawker Media Inc has hired a banker to explore strategic options, including a possible sale, amid a potentially crippling US$140 million damages award in a defamation suit by former pro wrestler Hulk Hogan. The company, secretly bankrolled by billionaire investor Peter Thiel, is fighting the verdict and can still appeal to a higher Florida court. Gawker is not currently for sale, but may change its stance if it loses an appeal.

site_title: World economy is an 'urgent priority': G7 leaders
summary: G7 leaders have identified boosting the world economy as an "urgent priority" amidst moderate but below-potential growth. The group agreed to strengthen economic policy responses in a cooperative manner, employing a balanced policy mix to achieve strong, sustainable growth. They also reaffirmed their commitment to using monetary, fiscal, and structural policies to strengthen global demand and address supply constraints. Despite lingering divisions over the approach, the G7 left the door open for a go-your-own-way approach, indicating a need for further cooperation to address the economic challenges facing member nations.

site_title: Samsung Electronics to launch Samsung Pay web payments app
summary: Samsung Electronics is set to launch Samsung Pay mini, a web payments app, in South Korea as early as June. Compatible with both Android and Apple devices, the app aims to simplify online transactions. Currently, Samsung Pay requires additional steps for online payments, but the app seeks to bridge this gap. The move is part of Samsung's strategy to defend market share and make its mobile payments service more convenient for users.

site_title: Singapore shares open 17.2 points higher on Friday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 17.19 points to 2,783.85 on Friday, driven by gains in Asian stocks. The index saw 77 gainers and 40 losers, with 36.9 million shares changing hands. Gains were seen in stocks like Magnus Energy, HPH Trust, and Cedar Strategic. This marks the 5th day of a rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Japan's Abe fails in bid to have G7 warn of global crisis risk
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's bid to have the G7 leaders warn of a global economic crisis risk was unsuccessful. The final G7 communique declared that the countries have strengthened their economies to avoid another crisis, instead of using stronger warning language. Abe had proposed the language to express concerns about the risk of a global economic crisis if timely policy responses are not taken. The G7 leaders decided to maintain a more cautious tone in their statement.

site_title: Panama's top court seeks extradition of ex-president Martinelli from US
summary: Panama's Supreme Court has ordered the government to request the extradition of former President Ricardo Martinelli from the US, where he is believed to be living in Miami. Martinelli is accused of using public money to spy on over 150 people and is a suspected co-conspirator in a bribery scheme involving software giant SAP. His administration was marked by corruption allegations, and his presidency was marred by scandals. A US federal judge previously identified Martinelli as one of the alleged co-conspirators in the bribery scheme.

site_title: Theranos sued over blood tests, in proposed class action
summary: Theranos Inc, a blood-testing company, has been sued in a proposed class action over alleged "massive failures" in its blood tests, claiming it misrepresented test accuracy and quality. The lawsuit, filed in the US District Court for the Northern District of California, accuses the company of breach of contract, false advertising, and consumer fraud. Thousands of consumers may be eligible to join the lawsuit, citing over 6 million tests performed. Theranos denies the claims and vows to defend itself, amid recent regulatory actions and a voided results period.

site_title: China eyes turning South China islands into Maldives-style resorts
summary: China plans to develop some South China Sea islands into luxury resorts, similar to the Maldives, to boost civilian presence and counter its military claims. The move aims to cement China's claims to the energy-rich waters, which are also claimed by neighboring countries. China started tourist cruises in the South China Sea in 2013, and the new developments will focus on areas without a military presence. The plan is part of China's efforts to increase its civilian presence in the disputed waters.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks near 2-week high on bargain hunting, won nearly flat
summary: South Korean shares rose to a near two-week high on Friday, driven by bargain hunting and gains in shipping stocks. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) increased 0.2% to 1,962.19 points. Offshore investors purchased 14.5 billion won worth of KOSPI shares, while shipping companies Hyundai Merchant Marine and Hanjin Shipping surged 25.9% and 29.7% respectively. The South Korean won was slightly higher, snapping three consecutive weeks of falls, ahead of the US Federal Reserve meeting and Britain's EU referendum.

site_title: Corporate Japan much more downbeat about escape from deflation
summary: Japan's corporate sector is increasingly pessimistic about escaping deflation, with 70% of firms expecting no decisive escape in the foreseeable future, up from 48% in January. Most companies believe Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's growth strategy will not significantly improve the economy, citing wage concerns, a shrinking population, and a planned sales tax hike. The survey found 79% of companies worried about consumer prices returning to deflation, and 66% thought the government's plans would not lead to significant economic improvement.

site_title: Japan's Abe considering 2-year delay in sales tax hike
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe is considering a two-year delay in the planned sales tax hike, originally set for April 2017. The decision comes after Abe warned of a potential global financial crisis at the G7 summit in western Japan. Abe will discuss the idea with Finance Minister Taro Aso and the head of his ruling party's coalition partner. The potential delay would provide relief to consumers and businesses, but could also increase the country's debt burden.

site_title: Asia: Stocks rise ahead of Yellen speech as Japan shares advance
summary: Asian stocks rose ahead of US Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen's speech, with the MSCI Asia Pacific Index gaining 0.3% to 127.76. Japanese shares climbed on speculation of delaying a sales tax increase, while the US jobless claims and pending home sales showed little clarity on the impact of higher interest rates. Odds of the Fed raising interest rates in June have pulled back to 28%, and investors await Yellen's comments on the Fed's plans, with some viewing equity markets as a value opportunity.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open higher following inflation data
summary: Tokyo shares opened higher on Friday after inflation data showed prices fell 0.3% in April, meeting market expectations. The Nikkei 225 index rose 0.18% to 16,802.48, while the Topix index increased 0.12% to 1,344.12. The positive start follows a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks, where the Straits Times Index (STI) rose 0.4% on Thursday.

site_title: Vietnam restricted access to Facebook during Obama visit: activists
summary: Vietnam restricted access to Facebook during President Barack Obama's visit, with the social media site blocked or restricted from Sunday to Wednesday, according to activist organizations Access Now and Viet Tan. This move coincides with a trend of restrictions on Facebook in countries like China, Uganda, and Turkey during politically sensitive times. The restriction was reportedly part of a broader crackdown on human rights and political dissidents in Vietnam.

site_title: PS4 sales hit 40m as Sony console dominates
summary: Sony Interactive Entertainment announced that PlayStation 4 sales have reached 40 million units, surpassing the industry's expectations. The console has dominated the market for the latest-generation consoles, with nearly double the sales of the Xbox One. This milestone is a testament to the PS4's strong adoption since its introduction in 2013, and Sony expects to further drive growth with virtual reality experiences and expanded game lineups.

site_title: Troubled Swiss bank BSI says new management not linked to 1MDB scandal
summary: Swiss bank BSI, ordered to shut down due to alleged ties to 1MDB scandal, has new CEO Roberto Isolani, who claims current management is not implicated. Isolani stated accusations date back three to four years and belong to the past. Swiss regulators approved BSI's dissolution and takeover by EFG International, with the condition of integrating and dissolving the bank within 12 months. The regulators also ordered the seizure of 95 million Swiss francs of "illegally generated" profits and are investigating two former top managers.

site_title: Philippine central bank sees May annual inflation at 1.1% to 1.9%
summary: The Bangko Sentral ng Pilipinas predicts Philippine annual inflation in May to be 1.1% to 1.9%, driven by higher domestic oil and food prices and lower power rates. This is unchanged from April's 1.1% inflation rate. The central bank will implement an interest rate corridor and term deposit auction facility starting June 3 to improve monetary policy transmission. The bank has maintained its 2-4% inflation target for the year, standing pat on interest rates since October 2014.

site_title: Brexit could trigger Scottish referendum by 2018, Salmond says
summary: Former Scottish National Party leader Alex Salmond suggests a UK vote to leave the European Union could trigger a second Scottish independence referendum by 2018. He argues that if Scotland votes to remain in the EU and England votes to leave, it would be a change in circumstances justifying another referendum. The Scottish government, led by Nicola Sturgeon, has the votes to call a second referendum, and Salmond believes Scots would decide to leave the UK in such a vote.

images.alt_text: A UK vote to leave the European Union could trigger a second Scottish independence referendum within two years, former Scottish National Party leader Alex Salmond said.

site_title: Deep-water search for EgyptAir black boxes to start 'in coming days': France's BEA
summary: France's BEA air safety agency says a deep-water search for EgyptAir's crashed jet will start in the coming days, using a French navy surveillance vessel and three deep-water devices. The search aims to locate the wreckage and black boxes, which have been emitting signals for about a month. Egypt and France are sharing costs, and investigators are exploring various theories, including terrorism, as the cause of the May 19 crash that killed all 66 people on board.

site_title: Microsoft-Facebook laying trans-Atlantic Internet line
summary: Microsoft and Facebook have announced a partnership to lay a high-speed Internet cable, dubbed "Marea", across the Atlantic Ocean. The 6,600 kilometer cable system will have an expected capacity of 160 terabytes per second, connecting the US to southern Europe and linking to hubs in Africa, Asia, the Middle East, and other parts of Europe. The project aims to meet growing demand for fast, reliable data connections, with completion expected by late 2017. The Marea cable will be the highest-capacity sub-sea cable to cross the Atlantic, with Microsoft and Facebook working with global communications company Telxius on the project.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SingHaiyi, CDL, Neo Group, IHH Healthcare
summary:

Singaporean property development group SingHaiyi reported a 47.1% drop in net profit to S$8.35 million for Q4 2016. City Developments Ltd (CDL) is attempting its third profit participation securities structure, involving 48 apartments worth S$350 million. Neo Group's full-year revenue jumped 62% to S$125.4 million, driven by acquisitions. IHH Healthcare reported a 37% year-on-year jump in Q1 net profit to RM235.5 million, driven by sustained organic growth and revenue from new hospitals. The companies' results are seen as part of a broader rally in Singapore stocks ahead of GDP data.

site_title: China April industrial profits up 4.2% year-on-year
summary: China's industrial profits rose 4.2% year-on-year to 502 billion yuan in April, following a 6.5% increase in the first four months of 2016. The growth slowed from March, where profits rose 7.4%. Product inventories at industrial firms fell 1.2% year-on-year, marking the first drop in recent years. State firms' profits dropped 8.4% in the January-April period, contrasting with the overall growth.

images.alt_text: Profits of China's industrial firms in April rose 4.2 per cent from the same period last year to 502 billion yuan (S$105.24 billion), though growth slowed significantly from March, the statistics bureau said on Friday.

site_title: Tiffany's "old-world luxury" fails to charm millennials
summary: Tiffany & Co's "old-world luxury" is failing to appeal to millennials, with one 28-year-old man stating that diamond rings found in the diamond district in Manhattan were comparable in style and quality to those at Tiffany's, at a significantly lower price. This trend suggests that the brand's traditional appeal as a status symbol is waning among younger generations.

site_title: Obama to make history with Hiroshima journey
summary: President Barack Obama is set to become the first sitting US leader to visit Hiroshima, Japan, on Friday, over 7 decades after the US dropped the first atomic bomb. The trip marks seven years since Obama called for the elimination of atomic arms and comes in his final year in office. Obama will lay flowers at the Hiroshima Peace Memorial Park and speak at the site of the atomic bombing, highlighting present dangers and reaffirming the shared vision of a world without nuclear weapons.

site_title: Justin Bieber is sued over riff in smash hit 'Sorry'
summary: Justin Bieber is being sued for allegedly stealing a vocal riff from indie artist Casey Dienel's 2014 song "Ring the Bell" in his 2015 hit "Sorry". Dienel claims the two songs share a "virtually identical" riff, which she says was used without permission in Bieber's song for over 8 seconds. The lawsuit, filed in the US District Court in Nashville, seeks unspecified damages, including profits generated by "Sorry". Bieber's team has not commented on the claims. This is the latest in a series of copyright infringement lawsuits involving well-known artists.

site_title: Temporary space station habitat fails to inflate
summary: NASA aborted an attempt to deploy a temporary habitat, known as the Bigelow Expandable Activity Module (Beam), at the International Space Station after it failed to inflate to full size. Despite two hours of effort, the module expanded only a few inches. NASA will hold a news conference to discuss the problem and determine next steps. The crew on board the ISS is safe, and the space station is in a stable configuration. The experiment aims to test expandable habitats for future Moon or Mars missions.

site_title: Trump wins enough delegates to clinch nomination
summary: Donald Trump secured the support of enough delegates to clinch the Republican presidential nomination, with 1,238 delegates backing him, one more than the 1,237 needed. Trump's delegate count rose after unbound delegates pledged to support him, and he was already considered the presumptive nominee. The Republican Party will officially confirm the results at its national convention in July. Trump's campaign is facing turmoil, with key figures in the party establishment expressing concern about his tone and policy specifics.

site_title: Google wins in retrial of Oracle copyright lawsuit
summary: Google has won a retrial of a copyright lawsuit brought by Oracle over the use of Java programming language in its Android smartphone operating system. A jury ruled that Google did not unfairly appropriate parts of the Java language, saving the tech giant from a possible multibillion-dollar verdict. Oracle had sought $9 billion in damages, but the verdict represents a win for Google and the tech industry, as extending copyright protection to code could threaten innovation. Google said the verdict is a win for the Android ecosystem and software developers.

site_title: SingHaiyi Q4 profit falls 47%, revenue jumps 63.8%
summary: SingHaiyi reported a net profit of S$8.35 million for its Q4 2016, down 47.1% from the previous year, with revenue rising 63.8% to S$8.12 million. The decline in profit was attributed to lower earnings per share, while the increase in revenue was largely due to contributions from the Pasir Ris One DBSS project and sales of completed units in Vietnam Town.

site_title: Europe: Shares end little changed; Banco Popular cash call hits banks
summary: European shares ended little changed on Thursday, with the STOXX Europe 600 and FTSEurofirst 300 indices gaining 0.1% and 0.2%, respectively. The pan-European banking sector index fell 0.5% after Banco Popular announced a 2.5 billion euro cash call, sparking fears of potential capital hikes in other European banks. The STOXX 600 Basic Resources index rose 1% due to a rise in copper prices, while ArcelorMittal's 6.9% gain contributed to the overall increase.

site_title: Beijing picks London for first yuan-bond outside China
summary: China has issued the first renminbi-denominated sovereign bond outside of China, worth 3.0 billion yuan (S$632 million), in London. The move aims to strengthen the UK's economic and financial ties with China. The bond is seen as a sign of closer ties between the two nations, following a state visit by President Xi Jinping last year. The UK is seeking a key economic partner, with Britain voting on EU membership next month. The bond auction marks a significant step in the UK-China relationship, with finance minister George Osborne praising London's attractiveness to foreign investors.

site_title: Japan consumer prices down 0.3% in April
summary: Japan's core consumer prices fell 0.3% in April, below the Bank of Japan's 2.0% target. This is the second consecutive month of decline, as the country's economy continues to face challenges. The Internal Affairs Ministry released the data, which excludes volatile fresh food prices. The result is a slight improvement from a forecast of a 0.4% fall. The decline in consumer prices is a concern for the government, as it may indicate a slowing economy.

images.alt_text: Japan's core consumer prices fell 0.3 per cent in April on-year, the government said on Friday, remaining way below the Bank of Japan's 2.0 per cent target.

site_title: Facebook extends lead as news gateway: study
summary: A study by the Pew Research Center found that 62% of US adults get news on social media, with 66% of Facebook users and 59% of Twitter users accessing news on the platforms. Facebook reaches two-thirds of US adults, making it a primary news source for 44% of the population. The study comes amid scrutiny over Facebook's role as a news gateway, with the platform defending itself against allegations of suppressing conservative news content. Facebook is updating its guidelines to clarify content decisions are not based on politics or ideology.

site_title: Britain launches review into Sharia courts
summary: Britain's government has launched an independent review into possible discriminatory practices against women in informal Sharia courts in England and Wales. The review, led by Islamic studies expert Mona Siddiqui, aims to investigate whether some Sharia councils legitimize forced marriages and issue unfair divorces. The review follows reports of women being victims of discriminatory decisions by Sharia councils, with an estimated 30 councils operating in Britain. The government will make recommendations to address the issue and ensure Sharia law does not exploit or misuse its principles.

site_title: US dollar slips after US data dampens Fed rate hike bets
summary: The US dollar fell against major currencies after weak US economic data, including a 0.8% decline in non-defense capital goods orders, raised doubts about a June or July Federal Reserve interest rate increase. The US dollar index hit its lowest level in eight days, and euro and yen rose against the dollar. Fed funds futures contracts implied a 26% chance of a rate hike in June, down from 32% on Wednesday. The decline reduced the dollar's gains since May 18, when minutes from the Fed's April policy meeting suggested a near-term rate increase.

images.alt_text: The US dollar fell against the euro, yen, and franc on Thursday after US economic data showed weakness in business spending plans, denting expectations for a Federal Reserve interest rate increase in June or July.

site_title: UN climate talks flesh out landmark Paris pact
summary: Climate diplomats from 196 countries concluded a 10-day technical session in Bonn, Germany, to flesh out the Paris Agreement. They made progress on a "rule book" for implementation, but still face challenges, particularly in ramping up national plans to reduce greenhouse gas emissions. The pact aims to cap global warming at 1.5°C, but voluntary pledges would still lead to a 3°C increase, a catastrophic scenario. Developing countries pushed for financial aid and a timetable for clean energy, while the European Union expressed concerns about its member states' ratification.

images.alt_text: Climate diplomats wrapped up technical talks Thursday saying they were on the right track but still far from delivering on the promise of the historic pact forged in December.

site_title: Several buyers eyeing Virgin Australia stake: Branson
summary: Richard Branson, founder of Virgin Group, said several buyers are eyeing a stake in Virgin Australia, with discussions underway. Air New Zealand's 26% stake is up for sale, and potential buyers include Singapore Airlines and Etihad Airways. Virgin Group, which owns 10% of Virgin Australia, may increase its stake but hasn't confirmed plans. Branson expressed support for Virgin Australia and believes the airline's brand is valuable.

site_title: US rates may rise 'fairly soon,' Brexit a concern: Fed's Powell
summary: The US Federal Reserve is expected to raise interest rates "fairly soon," according to Governor Jerome Powell, citing a solid economy and inflation and employment goals. However, uncertainty surrounding the Brexit referendum is causing caution, with Powell noting that the Fed will exercise "caution" as it considers a rate increase at its June 14-15 policy meeting. The Fed's decision will be closely watched, with market expectations shifting in favor of a rate hike in July.

site_title: 'Nightmare' infection found in US for first time
summary: A superbug resistant to all known medications has been found in the US for the first time, raising concerns about the dwindling effectiveness of antibiotics. The case involved a 49-year-old woman in Pennsylvania with a urinary tract infection caused by carbapenem-resistant Enterobacteriaceae (CRE), a "nightmare" bacteria. This is the first reported case of the superbug in the US. The Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) is urging caution and increased vigilance in hospitals and healthcare facilities to prevent the spread of the infection.

images.alt_text: A superbug resistant to all known medications has been found in the United States for the first time, raising new concern about the dwindling effectiveness of antibiotics, the top US public health official said on Thursday.

site_title: Christian art with an Asian flavour
summary: A new exhibition at the Asian Civilisations Museum in Singapore showcases Christian art with an Asian flavour, highlighting the significant contributions of skilled Asian craftsmen in creating church artefacts since the 13th century. The "Christianity in Asia: Sacred Art and Visual Splendour" exhibition features over 150 objects from 20 institutions in six countries, offering a unique global perspective on the spread of Christianity in Asia. This is the first time a museum has focused exclusively on Asian-made Christian art, providing a fresh insight into the region's rich cultural heritage.

site_title: BOE adjusts capital rules for global banks with UK retail arms
summary: The Bank of England (BOE) has adjusted capital rules for global banks with UK retail arms, requiring deposit-taking banks with assets of £175 billion or more to set aside an additional "systemic risk" capital buffer. This change mainly affects RBS due to its large UK retail arm and relatively low global capital requirements. The BOE aims to prevent a repeat of the 2007-09 financial crisis and has set a target of a 13.5% capital buffer equivalent to risk-weighted assets. The change ensures global banks hold enough capital to absorb losses at their international and ring-fenced retail arms.

site_title: Robots may become new norm in accounting and finance
summary: Robots are increasingly being adopted in accounting and finance, with robotic process automation (RPA) set to transform the sector. According to Deloitte's 2015 report, over half of surveyed leaders anticipate an increased use of RPA by 2017. While concerns over job displacement are valid, finance professionals can adapt by acquiring skills beyond traditional accounting and finance knowledge, and embracing technology to automate time-consuming and repetitive tasks, ultimately enhancing their role as business strategists.

site_title: BP to slash US$2-4b off Tangguh LNG budget
summary: BP plans to slash US$2-4 billion from the US$12 billion budget for the Tangguh liquefied natural gas project in Indonesia, following sectorial downturns sparked by the oil price collapse. Indicative cost reductions from project tenders suggest the plan is on course, with bids for key contracts coming in at lower values. The sectorial downturn has freed up capacity and lowered costs, with day rates for offshore drilling and production activities experiencing significant reductions.

site_title: CBL & Associates said to be under probe by FBI, SEC for fraud
summary: CBL & Associates Properties Inc, a US retail landlord, is under investigation by the FBI and SEC for alleged accounting fraud. The company's stock fell 8.4% after a Wall Street Journal report claimed the firm falsified information on financial statements to banks. Former employees have allegedly inflated rental income and occupancy rates. CBL denies the allegations, stating they are "completely baseless" and that none of its executives have been contacted by investigators. Federal investigators are also looking into the relationship between CBL and US Senator Bob Corker.

site_title: UK consumer confidence edges up but Brexit vote clouds outlook
summary: UK consumer confidence rose to -1 in May, up from -3 in April, but uncertainty over the Brexit referendum clouded the economic outlook. The optimism about the economy in the year ahead was weaker than a year earlier. Market research firm GfK attributed the increase in confidence to a rebound from a low reading in April, while still acknowledging that the Brexit vote has a negative impact on consumer sentiment.

images.alt_text: Morale among British consumers edged up in May but uncertainty around next month's referendum on European Union membership continued to cloud the economic outlook, a survey showed on Friday.

site_title: Car loan tenures raised to 7 years; loan limits also up
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has relaxed vehicle financing restrictions, allowing buyers to borrow up to 70% of a car's price and pay it back over a maximum of seven years. The move follows sustained moderation in COE premiums and inflationary pressures over the last three years. The changes apply to cars with an open market value of up to S$20,000, with a maximum loan-to-value ratio of 60%. The MAS aims to promote financial prudence while supporting the promotion of a "car-lite" society.

site_title: Oil prices top US$50 a barrel but then recede
summary: Oil prices briefly surpassed $50 a barrel for the first time this year, driven by decreased global supply glut. However, prices receded, closing at $49.48 a barrel in the US and $49.59 a barrel in London. The move follows recent oil outages and production cuts, but analysts remain skeptical, citing near-historic US oil inventories and uncertain demand outlooks. Some expect the $50 threshold to act as a temporary ceiling, and Opec may not cut production at its upcoming summit.

site_title: Microsoft to cut up to 1,850 jobs, quit making smartphones
summary: Microsoft to cut up to 1,850 jobs, ending its smartphone manufacturing business, which will impact 1,350 jobs in Finland and 500 globally. The decision results in a $950 million impairment and restructuring charge. Microsoft will continue to develop software and support existing Lumia phones, but will no longer manufacture devices.

site_title: China loses world no. 2 creditor rank to Germany amid yuan woes
summary: China lost its position as the world's second-largest supplier of external credit to Germany for the first time in at least a decade due to yuan woes, with China's net foreign assets falling to $1.6 trillion and Germany's rising to $1.62 trillion in 2015. Despite this, China is expected to regain its position in the coming years. China's overseas asset purchases are increasingly coming from the private sector, not the official sector, and are focused on the US, Australia, and UK.

site_title: US: Stocks end flat ahead of growth data
summary: US stocks ended flat on Thursday ahead of the release of first-quarter GDP data, which could be revised higher. Investors were cautious due to the potential for interest rate hikes and the speech by Federal Reserve Chair Janet Yellen. Analysts expect the market to remain volatile until the data is released.

site_title: S Korea's Park facing last chance to push through reforms, boost growth
summary: South Korean President Park Geun-hye is facing her last chance to pass legislation aimed at boosting the country's economy, which has been flagging. She needs to pass bills to loosen the labor market, boost the services industry, and ease regulations to create jobs and growth. With a legislature set to soon be in opposition control, Park's chances of success are uncertain. Her fourth year in office is her final term, making this a critical moment for her economic reforms.

site_title: Neo Group posts S$6m full-year profit
summary: Neo Group, a Singaporean food caterer, reported a net profit of S$6.06 million for the 12 months ended March 31, 2016, a decrease from S$7.4 million in the previous year. Revenue jumped 62% to S$125.4 million, driven by acquisitions and the maiden 10-month revenue from its food manufacturing subsidiary. The company's CEO, Neo Kah Kiat, expressed confidence in the group's ability to capture more market share and expand overseas.

site_title: Golden age of global trade may be about to end
summary: Global trade, as a share of GDP, has reached a record high in real terms, but the global trade in goods has stagnated. Instead, virtual trade in services, such as music, films, and books, has increased, with more transactions taking place in the digital realm. Technological advancements like robotics and 3D printing are changing supply chains, potentially erasing the benefits of low labour rates and shifting production closer to consumers. This shift may lead to a decline in global trade and impact shipping companies and countries that have benefited from increased trade volumes.

site_title: Easier, contactless payment with Apple Pay for OCBC customers
summary: OCBC Bank reported a significant surge in Apple Pay adoption, with over 10,000 customers activating their credit cards within 24 hours of launch. The bank attributed the growth to its position as market leader in contactless payments, with a 50% year-on-year increase in contactless transactions. OCBC is promoting Apple Pay through a two-day roadshow and offering S$1 deals and 3% cash rebates to encourage adoption. The bank's head of lifestyle financing expects wallets like Apple Pay to drive the next evolution in mobile payments.

site_title: Nearly 60, and still going strong
summary: Dick Lee, a renowned Singaporean musician, is celebrating his 60th birthday with a concert series, "The ICON Series", which kicks off on August 19 at The Star Theatre. The concert will feature songs from his career, including his debut album "Life Story" and hit musicals like "Fried Rice Paradise" and "Beauty World". Lee, who has topped charts, designed clothes, and directed the National Day Parade, will also sing songs produced through collaborations with Hong Kong stars. The concert aims to preserve and celebrate Singapore's music heritage, with the Sing50 Fund reaching out to students to inspire the next generation of artists.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Buildings here still have room to improve: Lawrence Wong
summary: Singapore's National Development Minister Lawrence Wong emphasized the need for buildings to be designed with inclusivity, environmental sustainability, and smart technologies. The government aims for 80% of buildings to be "green" by 2030, and is supporting industry players through various initiatives. Wong also highlighted the importance of adopting productive construction methods, such as prefabricated construction, to reduce labor costs and environmental impact. The government plans to drive changes in the building sector to support its major infrastructure plans, including the development of new Central Business Districts and urban landscapes.

site_title: Takata hires Lazard to head financial restructuring effort
summary: Takata Corp has hired investment bank Lazard Ltd to lead a financial restructuring effort following its recall of faulty air bags linked to 13 deaths and over 100 injuries worldwide. The company aims to resolve costs and avoid bankruptcy, while reforming its governance structure and ensuring equitable treatment of claims. Takata has been in talks with automakers to reach a consensual resolution, and is seeking new investment to address financial and operational issues. The recall affects 35 million to 40 million US air bag inflators, and 17 automakers will recall them by 2019.

site_title: Citigroup smiley face turns sour as CFTC finds rate rigging
summary: Citigroup agreed to pay US$425 million to settle US Commodity Futures Trading Commission (CFTC) allegations that it manipulated key financial benchmarks, including ISDAFIX, from 2007-2012. The alleged manipulation involved buying and selling US government debt to influence the benchmark's value. The CFTC cited electronic communications from Citibank traders discussing how they moved the benchmark around 11am New York time. Citigroup will bolster its surveillance to avoid future misconduct, and the case demonstrates the CFTC's commitment to investigating efforts to manipulate financial benchmarks.

images.alt_text: The New York-based bank neither admitted to nor denied the allegations by the CFTC. The alleged ISDAFIX violations generated most of the penalty: US$250 million.

site_title: First shared-facilities Lube Park in Asia opens in Singapore
summary: The first shared-facilities Lube Park in Asia, located in Singapore, was launched on May 26, 2016. The park, a joint venture between Shell, Sinopec, and Total, features shared facilities such as an import-export jetty, pipelines, and a tank farm. The project aims to reduce costs and increase efficiency for the three energy giants, which are expanding their production to meet growing regional demand in the Asia-Pacific region.

site_title: US oil explorers going ahead with drilling projects
summary: US oil explorers Exxon Mobil and Chevron are proceeding with major drilling projects despite shareholder rejections of resolutions aimed at curtailing exploration for new oil fields. Exxon chairman Rex Tillerson said the company plans to tap 20 billion barrels of crude, enough to supply every refinery in the US for over three years. Executives insist demand for crude-derived fuels will continue to expand, particularly in countries like India. Environmental critics argue that future climate rules will make it unprofitable for the companies to harvest their reserves.

images.alt_text: Shareholders of Exxon Mobil Corp and Chevron Corp on Wednesday overwhelmingly rejected resolutions backed by environmental activists that would have curtailed exploration for new oil fields.

site_title: Bank Negara closes its case against 1MDB after firm pays fine for non-compliance
summary: Bank Negara Malaysia has closed its investigation into 1MDB after the firm paid a fine of RM16 million for non-compliance with central bank directives. The central bank's governor, Muhammad Ibrahim, stated that Bank Negara is ready to assist other enforcement agencies in their probes, despite criticism from those who hoped for a more independent investigation. The Auditor-General's report on 1MDB remains classified, and the company's assets are set to be transferred to the finance ministry, with plans to dissolve it after its debts are repaid.

images.alt_text: Bank Negara Malaysia considers its investigation into state-owned 1MDB to be concluded following the latter's payment of an administrative compound, levied because of its non-compliance with the central bank's directives.

site_title: UOB Painting winner holds solo show
summary: UOB Painting of the Year winner Benjamin Cruz is holding a solo exhibition, "Vision and Visionaries," at the UOB Art Gallery until June 8. The 15 paintings showcase Cruz's transition from abstract to abstract realist art, combining figurative images of Singapore buildings with textured swirls of colors. Cruz, who won the award in 2015, is now pursuing painting full-time after his children completed their studies and are financially independent. The exhibition features Cruz's mixed media techniques and inspirations from nature.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Increase in inequality easing since 2012
summary: Global inequality has been slowing down since 2012, according to the IMD World Competitiveness Ranking, which analyzed 26 years of economic and business data. Despite increased wealth in the richest countries, income gaps between countries have reduced due to the financial crisis' negative impact on rich countries and poorer countries' development. Inequality varies by country and economic sector, with the manufacturing sector experiencing a widening gap in salaries. The gap between CEO pay in poor and rich countries has increased 33-fold over 20 years, with the richest countries' CEOs seeing a 10-fold increase in pay.

site_title: Norway to regulate sovereign wealth fund's tax haven exposure
summary: Norway plans to regulate its $850 billion sovereign wealth fund's exposure to tax havens, following the Panama Papers leaks. The government will examine both the fund's own use of tax avoidance structures and those of companies it invests in. The move aims to combat tax evasion and ensure transparency. The finance committee recommends a two-pronged approach, with parliament expected to publish its findings on Friday. This step is a response to the global backlash against tax havens and aims to prevent negative tax planning by companies.

images.alt_text: Norway will take a first step this week towards using its US$850 billion sovereign wealth fund, the world's biggest, as a tool to combat the use of tax havens, two key members of parliament's finance committee said on Wednesday.

site_title: Japan pushes for bold growth strategy on first day of Ise-Shima summit
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe urged G7 leaders to launch concerted fiscal and monetary actions and make structural economic reforms to boost growth, amid global economic stagnation. Abe won support from US President Barack Obama and German Chancellor Angela Merkel, who emphasized the need for stable growth but acknowledged risks. A communique to be issued at the summit will promote the "three-arrow policy" of bold monetary policy, flexible fiscal spending, and structural reforms. The G7 leaders agreed on the need to stimulate demand and use fiscal tools to achieve this, with individual countries deciding how to deploy fiscal stimulus.

site_title: AirAsia to expand fleet, with eye on China-led regional demand
summary: AirAsia plans to expand its fleet with an initial 5 aircraft additions this year, and up to 10 more in 2017, depending on demand. The airline aims to tap into China's growing air-travel market, which is projected to surpass the US in two decades. AirAsia also plans to increase destinations in China from 18 and flight frequencies in the country. The expansion is driven by the region's projected growth, with China leading the way.

site_title: Angry Birds film fails to take flight
summary: The Angry Birds Movie, directed by Clay Kaytis and Fergal Reilly, has grossed over $155 million worldwide despite failing to live up to its game's success. The film, written by Jon Vitti, has a meta and humorous approach but lacks depth. It took the top spot in North America with a $39 million opening, surpassing Captain America: Civil War. The film's failure to soar to the same heights as the game leaves it feeling like a "sleeper hit" that didn't quite take flight.

images.alt_text: Birds take on pigs in this video-game- to-film adaptation but the movie feels like its wings have been clipped.
Dylan Tan

site_title: Brokers' take
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Singapore telcos performed well in Q1, with results meeting expectations. Circles.Life's launch of mobile services didn't significantly impact the three main telcos. Investors are expected to seek out these companies for their defensive businesses and stable dividend payouts. Religare Health Trust's expansion plans and Sarine Technologies' diamond sales data are also positive indicators. The diamond industry's recovery remains on track, with US CPI for jewellery rising 5% and Indian polished diamond exports increasing 9%. These data points support Sarine's path to normalcy in 2016. Singtel is the top pick, followed by Sarine Technologies.

site_title: CapitaLand launches Raffles City Shenzhen
summary: CapitaLand launched Raffles City Shenzhen, the first Raffles City mall in south China, in Nanshan District. The 70,000 sq m mall features smart technologies, including an in-mall navigation tool and online-payment options, and has achieved a committed occupancy of over 50% a year ahead of its scheduled opening in the second quarter of 2024. Co-chairman of the Singapore-Guangdong Collaboration Council, Ong Ye Kung, attended the topping-out ceremony, highlighting the similarities between Singapore and China's transformation and positioning both countries for new fortunes and prosperity.

site_title: A bonus for fans of Beaune wines
summary: The Hospices de Beaune, a French wine charity, will host a dinner event in Singapore on Saturday, featuring some of its finest wines, including three Grand Cru wines. The event will include a charity auction, with proceeds going to The Titular Roman Catholic Archbishop of Singapore. The dinner will be paired with a three-course meal and will include a private tour of the Seguin-Moreau cooperage in Beaune.
