summary: Oil prices rose to nearly US$50 a barrel for the first time in seven months, driven by a sharp fall in US inventories and supply disruptions worldwide. A series of outages, including wildfires in Canada and violence in Nigeria, cut global oil supply by nearly 4 million barrels per day. The market is expected to move out of a surplus situation, with some analysts predicting a rebalancing in six months. Oil prices are influenced by fundamentals, rather than equities and currencies, according to SEB head commodities strategist Bjarne Schieldrop.

site_title: Steel industry calls on G7 to protect it from China
summary: The steel industry is urging the G7 to protect it from China's cheap steel exports, which have distorted global markets and caused losses for European and US producers. The industry associations, including EUROFER, have called for action against countries that do not respect market economy conditions, particularly China, which they claim is responsible for the global steel glut. The White House has confirmed that reducing global industrial overcapacity will be discussed during the Japan G7 talks, with the EU rejecting loosening of trade defenses against China.

site_title: US dollar holds gains against yen as markets turn risk-on
summary: The US dollar maintained its gains against the yen on Wednesday, driven by rising expectations of a US interest rate hike, following strong data on US new-home sales. The dollar jumped to 109.91 yen from 109.99 yen, while the euro edged higher to 122.60 yen. The move was seen as a sign of improved risk appetite in regional markets, with investors looking for better returns amid a strengthening US economy. Analysts believe the data supports a gradual rise in US interest rates, potentially as early as next month.

images.alt_text: The US dollar held gains against the yen on Wednesday after risk appetite among Asian investors jumped on the back of rising expectations of a rise in US borrowing costs.

site_title: Spread between US oil and natural gas hits 20-month high
summary: US crude futures have rebounded 88% since February, reaching $49 a barrel, and widened the spread between oil and natural gas to its highest level in 20 months at 25:1. The higher oil prices and flat gas prices have prompted drillers to seek more valuable oil and natural gas liquids, potentially shifting US production. This is the highest spread since September 2014, with crude averaging 19 times over gas in 2015, the lowest in five years.

images.alt_text: The 88 percent rebound of US crude futures since hitting a 13-year low in February widened the spread between oil and natural gas to its highest level in 20 months on Wednesday.

site_title: Trek 2000 CFO assisting in CAD investigations
summary: Trek 2000's CFO, Gurcharan Singh, has been questioned by Singapore's white collar crime police unit, the Commercial Affairs Department (CAD), in an investigation into a possible offence under Chapter 224 of the Penal Code. The CAD has requested corporate documents, banking records, and information technology equipment. Trek 2000's president of regional sales, head of research and development, and other employees are assisting with the investigation, which has not disclosed any further details or whether an offence has been committed. The company maintains that its business and operations remain unaffected.

site_title: Wilmar unit creates new JV in India
summary: Wilmar International's joint venture subsidiary, Adani Wilmar, is merging functions with Indian consumer goods firm Ruchi Soya to create a new company. The joint venture will own and manage procurement, sales, and marketing businesses, reducing costs and boosting efficiency. It will also have exclusive rights to market and distribute finished products in India, addressing the country's complex agricultural environment and mismatch between farm productivity and consumption. Adani and Wilmar will jointly hold 66.66% equity, while Ruchi Soya will hold 33.34%.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 5.12 points to close at 1,630.96 on Wednesday, with 1.73 billion lots valued at RM1.81 billion traded. Gainers outnumbered losers 302-510. This upward trend follows a broader market rally in Asia and globally, driven by positive sentiments despite US trade uncertainty and the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Panama Canal fever sweeps globe again as new era in trade nears
summary: The Panama Canal is set to reopen with a new expansion, tripling its capacity and reducing travel time for cargo ships. The $5 billion upgrade will allow massive tankers to pass through, shaving 11 days off the typical round trip to the Far East, benefiting US natural-gas producers and importers. The expansion is expected to trigger a multibillion-dollar dredging and building binge at ports in the US, Caribbean, and South America, with the canal potentially becoming a distribution hub for global manufacturers. The upgrade will not solve all the canal's challenges, but is crucial for a country that risks losing relevance if it doesn't grow to handle larger vessels.

site_title: Saudi wealth fund said to weigh US$8b bid for financial hub
summary: Saudi Arabia's Public Investment Fund is set to make a US$8 billion bid for Riyadh's King Abdullah Financial District, a project plagued by delays and cost overruns. The fund, aiming to become the world's largest sovereign wealth fund, may pay for the project's unfinished development, including undeveloped plots. The project's completion and management will be overseen by a new company. The bid comes as Saudi Arabia seeks to rehabilitate the project and is also working to increase its assets to US$2 trillion.

site_title: Hong Kong ends up after rally, but Shanghai slides
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 2.71% on Wednesday, tracking a Wall Street and European rally. The Hang Seng Index reached 20,368.05, while Shanghai and Shenzhen indexes fell 0.23% and 0.24% respectively. The gains were attributed to global market momentum, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite US trade uncertainty.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's economy grew 1.8% in Q1, within expectations, driven by manufacturing's better-than-expected performance. The Singapore Exchange confirmed exclusive talks to buy the Baltic Exchange, while CMA CGM's acquisition of Neptune Orient Lines received Chinese regulatory clearance. Changi Airport saw a 9.2% increase in passenger traffic in April. Meanwhile, Singapore Post deputy chairman Goh Yeow Tin resigned, and Jason Holdings suspended executives over alleged improper transactions. The Straits Times Index rose 16.43 points to 2,766.66.

site_title: Brexit could force UK to extend austerity by two years
summary: The UK may be forced to extend austerity for two years if it leaves the European Union, according to a report by the Institute for Fiscal Studies. A Brexit could lead to a budget deficit of up to 30 billion pounds, making it difficult for the government to balance the books by the end of the decade. The report warns that a vote to leave the EU could plunge the UK into recession and increase borrowing by 39 billion pounds over two years.

site_title: US: Wall St rallies as higher oil boosts energy stocks
summary: US stocks rose on Wednesday, extending gains from Tuesday, as oil prices rose above $50 a barrel and investors became more optimistic about a potential interest rate hike in June. The Dow Jones industrial average gained 93.58 points, or 0.53%, to 17,799.63, while the S&P 500 rose 10.14 points, or 0.49%, to 2,086.2. The energy index led the gainers, with oil majors Exxon and Chevron up 0.7%. This follows recent comments from policymakers raising expectations of a rate hike, with a 37.5% chance now priced in for June.

site_title: SGX confirms exclusive talks with Baltic Exchange
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has confirmed exclusive talks to buy the Baltic Exchange, a maritime information provider based in London. The talks, which began on May 25, are set to last until June 30. SGX CEO Loh Boon Chye expressed enthusiasm for the potential deal, stating that the company will maintain Baltic Exchange's headquarters and market benchmark production model. The deal, if successful, would see the exchange keep the company's governance model and multiple clearing house model intact, with both parties set to meet with shareholders and stakeholders in the coming weeks.

site_title: Global watchdog says shadow-banking supervision too patchy
summary: The Financial Stability Board stated that global supervision of the shadow banking sector, estimated at US$35 trillion, remains patchy, making it difficult to spot risks. This sector has shifted risks from traditional banks to shadow banking, including repurchase agreements and securitization. Policymakers acknowledge the sector's potential for alternative funding but remain cautious due to the 2007-09 financial crisis. Regulatory efforts to address the sector's risks are ongoing.

site_title: Religare Health Trust's distributable income for Q4 up 1.4% to S$15.3m
summary: Religare Health Trust reported a 1.4% rise in distributable income to S$15.3 million for Q4, driven by underlying business growth and a favorable exchange rate. Revenue excluding straight lining fell 2.8% to S$33.8 million, while net service fee and hospital income slid 3.4% year-over-year. The trust's gearing remained low at 18.1%. Despite a volatile economic outlook, the healthcare sector is expected to remain stable, with RHT's clinical establishments providing specialty medical treatments.

site_title: Indonesia central bank sees possibility of monetary easing in June
summary: Indonesia's central bank governor Agus Martowardojo expressed possibility of monetary easing in June if financial stability is maintained. He stated that data support would be crucial for the easing of monetary policies. The central bank also plans to ease rules on buying second homes, currently banning down payments before construction.

site_title: EgyptAir to contract French, Italian companies for black boxes search
summary: EgyptAir has contracted French and Italian companies to search for the black boxes of its crashed plane, EgyptAir 804, in the Mediterranean Sea. The plane, which had 66 people on board, crashed on May 18 with 30 Egyptians and 15 French nationals. The search, 3,000 meters deep, aims to find clues in debris and human remains. Investigators are still looking for the plane and its recorders, which could explain the cause of the crash.

images.alt_text: EgyptAir will contract two foreign companies, one French and one Italian, to help search for the black boxes of its plane that crashed in the Mediterranean, the airline's chairman said on Wednesday.

site_title: Technics fails to restrain Soilbuild Reit from calling on S$11.9m guarantee on lease payment
summary: TECHNICS Oil & Gas failed to stop Soilbuild Business Space Reit from calling on a S$11.85 million bank guarantee for 18 months' rent on the second year lease of its 70 Loyang Way premises. Soilbuild Reit had filed a lawsuit against Technics, claiming rent and late interest payments. The dispute was settled when UOB paid the guarantee to Soilbuild Reit. Technics filed a writ of summons and injunction last week, but ultimately failed to restrain Soilbuild Reit's actions.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Vogue Café prepares pop-up champagne lounge for London
summary: Vogue Café, the first pop-up champagne lounge in Western Europe, will open in London next month as part of British Vogue's centenary celebrations. The outpost will serve champagne, cocktails, and food, including sandwiches and afternoon tea. Located at Westfield in west London, the pop-up will be open from June 16 to September 18. This is the first of several Vogue Café locations, including Moscow, Asia, and the Middle East, under licensing arrangements with Condé Nast International.

site_title: Luxury jeweler Tiffany reports steepest sales drop in 6 qtrs
summary: Tiffany & Co. reported its steepest sales drop in six quarters, missing analyst estimates, due to a strong dollar discouraging tourists from buying its high-end jewelry. The company forecast a mid-single digit percentage fall in full-year profit. Shares fell 4.5% to $61 in premarket trading. The decline was attributed to a decline in revenue from markets outside the US, with a strong dollar eating into sales.

images.alt_text: Tiffany & Co reported its steepest sales drop in six quarters, missing analysts'estimates, as a strong dollar discouraged tourists from buying its high-end jewelry and ate into revenue from markets outside the United States.

site_title: Europe: Shares hit new 4-week high, Novo Nordisk leads
summary: European shares reached a new 4-week high, driven by a 0.7% gain in the FTSEurofirst 300 index. Novo Nordisk led the market higher after a US advisory panel recommended approval of its diabetes drug, while copper prices lifted miners. However, Marks & Spencer fell 6.3% after its new boss's turnaround plan impacted short-term profits.

site_title: Microsoft may cut 1,850 jobs as Nadella pares phone ambitions
summary: Microsoft is set to cut up to 1,850 jobs and take a $950 million impairment charge due to a shift in its smartphone strategy under CEO Satya Nadella. The company will focus on business customers and cloud services, rather than competing in the global smartphone market. This move comes after the company wrote off $9.5 billion in its Nokia acquisition and sold its feature phone unit for $350 million. Nadella aims to restore growth in PCs by concentrating on Windows 10 and slashing costs.

images.alt_text: Microsoft Corp will cut as many as 1,850 jobs and take a new impairment charge as chief executive officer Satya Nadella pares back the company's ambitions in smartphones.

site_title: Singapore shares close higher in line with Wall St, but off intraday highs
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) rose 16.43 points to 2,766.66 on Wednesday, following a Wall Street rally. The Hang Seng Index gained 2.7% and the Nikkei 1.6%. The STI's rise was attributed to better-than-expected housing numbers and a rise in oil prices. However, the index finished 24 points below its intraday high due to low liquidity and a decline in retail business. The market's low liquidity and lack of retail activity led to a downbeat mood among dealers.

site_title: Three new board members appointed to Singapore Tote Board
summary: The Singapore Tote Board has appointed three new board members: Permanent Secretary Chew Hock Yong, Anita Fam, and Fang Ai Lian. Kon Yin Tong and Patrick Lee will retire from the board, with Chew taking effect on May 1 and the others on June 1. The Tote Board will have 11 members, including Chairman Moses Lee, and will continue to channel funds to grant-making projects benefiting Singapore.

site_title: German business confidence rises on sunny outlook
summary: German business confidence rose to 107.7 points in May, beating expectations, with companies more satisfied with their current situation and optimistic about the future. The economy is growing at a robust pace, driven by domestic demand, low unemployment, and rising wages. However, economists warn that the strong first-quarter growth is unlikely to be repeated in subsequent quarters, with quarterly GDP growth expected to remain between 0.3-0.4% for the remainder of the year.

site_title: Nomura cuts executive pay to 3-year low as Daiwa increases
summary: Nomura Holdings Inc cut executive pay by 18% to the lowest level in three years, following a 42% decline in net income to 131.6 billion yen. The move comes after the firm failed to achieve a goal of returning overseas operations to profit. Daiwa Securities Group Inc, a local competitor, increased executives' pay by 9.2%. The drop in compensation at Nomura is attributed to cost-cutting measures and a focus on reducing overseas losses.

site_title: Malaysia's 1MDB says has made full payment of central bank fine
summary: Malaysia's 1Malaysia Development Berhad (1MDB) has made full payment of a fine imposed by the country's central bank, Bank Negara Malaysia (BNM). The fund confirmed it had paid the compound in compliance with BNM's decision, issued last month for failing to comply with bank rules. The payment resolves a fine of an unspecified amount, but the exact figure was not disclosed.

site_title: Australia immigration policy threatens to hijack election agenda
summary: Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull's election agenda may be hijacked by the country's harsh immigration policy and offshore detention camps. The government has vowed to stop refugees from Indonesia and Sri Lanka from reaching Australia, while critics accuse them of xenophobia and human rights abuses. Former director of mental health services Peter Young claims police accessed his phone records and accused the government of attempting to cover up deaths in custody and intimidating aid workers. The country goes to the polls on July 2, with immigration and border security issues expected to sway the election.

site_title: Taiwan's new government has no schedule for resuming China trade talks: minister
summary: Taiwan's new government, led by President Tsai Ing-wen's Democratic Progressive Party, has no schedule to resume trade talks with China. Economics Minister Lee Chih-kung stated that a proposed "supervisory law" must pass parliament before trade talks can proceed, as it requires legislative consent before, during, and after negotiations with Beijing. Beijing has condemned the bill, which critics say could paralyze relations. The DPP aims to balance democratic principles with maintaining a peaceful and predictable relationship with China.

images.alt_text: Taiwan's new government has no schedule for re-starting trade talks with China, Economics Minister Lee Chih-kung said on Wednesday, adding that the independence-leaning ruling party's first wanted to pass a bill governing oversight of all aspects of negotiations with Beijing.

site_title: Bayer says it's confident it can meet Monsanto deal demands
summary: Bayer is confident it can meet Monsanto's demands after the US seed company rejected its $62 billion takeover bid. Despite the rejection, Bayer expressed its belief in the benefits of a merger and left the door open for further discussions. The company's stock rallied after Bayer's comments, rising to $113.49. Bayer faces regulatory hurdles and competition concerns, with some analysts speculating the company may need to raise its bid to secure the deal.

images.alt_text: Bayer AG, whose US$62 billion takeover bid was rejected earlier by Monsanto Co, said it's confident it can overcome the seed company's concerns about the regulatory and financing risks related to a deal that would create the world's largest supplier of seeds and crop chemicals.

site_title: Indonesia central bank flags possible monetary easing in June
summary: Indonesia's central bank governor, Agus Martowardojo, has signaled possible monetary easing in June to stimulate the slowing economy. The decision would depend on stable economic conditions, but a disappointing first quarter growth outlook and a weak rupiah have raised concerns. The bank's next policy review is set for June 15, with a rate decision expected the following day. The rupiah has slumped to its weakest level in three months, and hawkish comments from Fed officials have put pressure on the currency.

site_title: World better forget about US$100 crude coming back, Norway says
summary: Norway's petroleum and energy minister, Tord Lien, says the US$100 crude price is unlikely to return, citing the oil market's rebalancing and easing global glut. Despite a 70% surge in Brent crude prices, Lien advises against planning for US$100 crude, instead suggesting a more realistic target of US$60. Norway is focusing on maintaining production from existing deposits and exploring new areas, such as the Arctic Barents Sea, to ensure economic growth and stability.

site_title: Young Vietnamese quiz Obama on rap, weed and good looks
summary: US President Barack Obama engaged in a lively town hall meeting with young Vietnamese in Ho Chi Minh City, discussing topics such as rap, weed smoking, and environmental issues. Obama praised hip-hop's global impact and criticized Vietnam's suppression of critical artists. He also addressed questions about his alleged marijuana use and environmental concerns, urging international cooperation to prevent disaster. The meeting was seen as a departure from the usual remoteness of Vietnamese politicians, who are often criticized for lacking charisma.

images.alt_text: Barack Obama fielded questions on Wednesday on everything from rap and weed smoking to his good looks at a lively meeting with young Vietnamese, who see the US leader as a far cry from their staid Communist rulers.

site_title: Sime Darby profit soars 60% but outlook weak
summary: Malaysia's Sime Darby, the world's largest listed palm-oil producer, reported a 60% quarterly profit rise to RM663.4 million in January-March. However, the company warned of a weak outlook due to slow global demand and lower output affected by El Nino weather. Revenue rose 2.4% to RM10.2 billion, but earnings for the first nine months were 10.9% lower than last year's pace. Sime Darby attributed the improved earnings to sales of certain assets, but expects a tougher performance in the fiscal year ending June 30.

images.alt_text: Malaysia's Sime Darby, the world's biggest listed palm-oil producer, on Wednesday announced a 60 per cent quarterly profit rise but warned of a tough outlook amid slow global demand and lower weather-reduced output.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher, extending global gains
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 1.57% to 16,757.35, following a rally on Wall Street and in Europe. Sony advanced 6.3% after investors ignored a weak profit forecast. The broader Topix index climbed 1.23%. The gains extended a global trend, with the S&P 500 and Nasdaq reaching fresh records despite US-EU trade uncertainty.

site_title: Childhood goes up in smoke for Indonesian tobacco farm workers
summary: Indonesian tobacco farm workers, many of whom are children, face hazardous conditions, including acute nicotine poisoning from harvesting tobacco leaves with bare hands. A Human Rights Watch report found 132 children aged 8-17 working on tobacco farms in four provinces, with some earning as little as $1-2 per day. Companies like Philip Morris International Inc. have taken steps to address the issue, but the Indonesian government and other stakeholders must also cooperate to reform the industry.

site_title: ECB's Nowotny says sees no major problems from possible Brexit
summary: European Central Bank Governing Council member Ewald Nowotny stated that a possible Brexit would not cause significant problems for the financial system, as it has been discussed for some time. Nowotny expressed confidence that an upcoming ECB stress test would not have a negative outcome. He noted that the market's reaction to a Brexit would be minimal if it were to occur.

site_title: Yuan weakens, midpoint set at 5-year low as bets on Fed rate hike increase
summary: The yuan weakened to a 5-year low against the dollar, with the midpoint set at 6.5693 per dollar, as bets on a US interest rate hike increased. The dollar index reached a two-month peak, supported by robust US housing data. The yuan has depreciated 1.3% against the dollar this month, with the offshore yuan trading only 0.05% softer than the onshore spot. The People's Bank of China fixed the midpoint rate, indicating alignment between onshore and offshore expectations for the yuan.

site_title: Trump Tower becomes hot New York tourist magnet
summary: Trump Tower in New York has become a popular tourist destination, attracting Americans, Israelis, and Europeans alike. The 68-story glass tower, where Donald Trump resides, features a marble atrium and public private space that allows passersby to enter until 10 pm. Visitors can shop for Trump souvenirs, eat at Trump restaurants, and catch a glimpse of the billionaire and his family. The building's residents, including some famous figures, are protected from the crowd and have their own entrance.

images.alt_text: New York is packed with some of the most iconic tourist attractions in the world but there's a hot new ticket in town: Trump Tower on Fifth Avenue.

site_title: China said to plan asking US on timing of Federal Reserve rate hike
summary: China plans to ask the US about the timing of a potential Federal Reserve interest-rate increase in June during annual talks in Beijing. The Chinese delegation aims to determine whether a June or July rate hike is more likely, as China's policymakers prepare for the impact on financial markets and the yuan. China's exchange rate has weakened as expectations rise for the Fed to boost borrowing costs, with the yuan having dropped about 1.2% this month. The US-China Strategic and Economic dialog talks will take place on June 6-7, a week before the Fed's next policy meeting.

site_title: Toyota to invest 49b yen to build new car plant in Malaysia
summary: Toyota plans to invest 49 billion yen (approximately $621 million) to build a new 50,000-cars-a-year factory in Malaysia, starting operations in early 2019. The new plant, located in Klang, Selangor, will focus on commercial vehicles, employing new production technologies. The existing factory will stop building passenger cars, and the facility will be part of a reorganisation of Toyota's Malaysian operations.

site_title: Strike-hit France smashes blockades as fuel runs dry
summary: French police dispersed a blockade at an oil depot near the Belgian border, ending a strike that had caused fuel shortages, with a fifth of petrol stations in France running low. The blockade, which had been in place since Thursday, was cleared without confrontation. The strike is part of a broader labor reform battle, with unions stepping up strikes. The incident highlights the ongoing tensions between workers and the government over labor reforms in France.

site_title: China: Stocks give up gains amid yuan depreciation worries
summary: China's stocks fell 0.1-0.2% on Wednesday, reversing early gains, amid yuan depreciation concerns and a stronger dollar. The CSI300 index and Shanghai Composite Index declined, while trading volume shrunk to nearly four-month lows. Fresh worries about money outflows and a possible US interest rate hike next month contributed to the decline. The yuan eased to near its February trough, and most sectors fell, with transportation shares leading the decline.

images.alt_text: China stocks gave up early gains to end weaker on Wednesday despite a sharp rebound in Hong Kong, as yuan depreciation fears resurfaced on the back of a stronger dollar and a possible US rate hike next month.

site_title: Asia: Stocks surge on global rally as oil rebounds
summary: Asia stocks surged on Wednesday, driven by a global rally and a rebound in oil prices. Energy stocks led the gains in Hong Kong and Sydney, while a weaker yen lifted exporters in Tokyo. The US new-home sales figures, which showed a surge in April, prompted analysts to see a strengthening in the housing market and a possible US interest rate hike. Markets are now reacting positively to the news, with investors coming around to the idea of a rate hike as an indication of economic strength.

site_title: NGOs slam Japan for investing abroad in carbon-polluting coal
summary: NGOs have criticized Japan for investing heavily in coal-powered energy abroad, despite its own commitment to reducing carbon emissions. Japan has invested over $22 billion in coal plants since 2007, more than any other G-7 country. Environmental groups argue that such investments hinder efforts to transition to renewable energy and exacerbate climate change. The criticism comes ahead of Japan's hosting of the G-7 summit, where climate change will be a key topic.

site_title: Oil prices push closer to US$50, US crude hits highest in 7 months
summary: Oil prices surged closer to US$50 a barrel on Wednesday, with US crude reaching its highest in 7 months, as a larger-than-expected drawdown in US crude inventories and strong US home sales supported the market. US crude futures rose 62 US cents to US$49.24 a barrel, while Brent futures rose 55 US cents to US$49.16 a barrel. The drawdown was attributed to falling imports due to Canadian wildfires and a strengthening US economy.

site_title: Trump wins Washington primary and nears delegate threshold
summary: Donald Trump won the Washington primary, putting him near the delegate threshold to secure the Republican nomination. Trump has 24 delegates and is likely to capture the remaining 313 delegates needed by June 7, securing the nomination. Trump began running a general election campaign, criticizing Hillary Clinton and assembling a fundraising team. He has announced six co-chairs for his joint fundraising operation with the Republican National Committee.

site_title: Changi passenger traffic up 9.2% in April, driven partly by Northeast Asia, Southeast Asia
summary: Changi Airport in Singapore experienced a 9.2% year-on-year increase in passenger traffic in April, reaching 4.79 million passengers. Aircraft movements and cargo shipments also saw significant growth, with 4.3% and 7.2% increases, respectively. Double-digit growth in air travel to and from North East Asia, South East Asia, and Africa contributed to the increase, while American routes saw weaker performance. Traffic between Singapore and top 10 country markets grew, with countries like China, Japan, and Vietnam experiencing over 10% growth.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Iron ore's fall hobbles Australia dollar, NZ dollar steadies on trade data
summary: The Australian dollar hovered near three-month lows due to falling iron ore prices and speculation of further Reserve Bank of Australia easing. The currency traded at US$0.7181, with next support levels at US$0.7109 and US$0.7065. In contrast, the New Zealand dollar steadied after a higher-than-expected trade surplus in April, trading at US$0.6753. The Australian government bond futures also dipped, while New Zealand government bonds eased slightly.

site_title: China clears path for CMA CGM's merger with NOL
summary: CMA CGM, a French container shipping group, has received regulatory clearance from China's Anti-Monopoly Bureau for its proposed S$3.4 billion acquisition of Singapore-listed Neptune Orient Lines (NOL). This clearance, along with the European Commission's conditional approval, paves the way for CMA CGM to announce a voluntary general cash offer for NOL by June 2. The acquisition will be part of CMA CGM's Ocean Alliance, which also includes Cosco China Shipping, Evergreen Line, and Orient Overseas Container Line. The deal is expected to be completed once pre-conditions, including US and EU antitrust clearances, are met.

images.alt_text: FRENCH container shipping group CMA CGM expects to announce soon a voluntary general cash offer for its proposed S$3.4 billion acquisition of Singapore-listed Neptune Orient Lines (NOL) after receiving the regulatory clearance from the Chinese government for the takeover bid.

site_title: Thai central bank concerned about risks to financial stability: minutes
summary: Thailand's central bank, the Bank of Thailand, held interest rates steady at 1.50% in May due to rising risks to financial stability. The decision was made despite a prolonged low interest rate environment and concerns about a potential snapback in global bond yields. The bank's policy committee cited search-for-yield behavior, weakened debt service ability of agricultural households and smaller businesses, and a fragile economic recovery as key concerns. The decision was seen as a cautious move to maintain financial stability, with most economists expecting no policy change in the near future.

site_title: Smart home gadgets need to live together
summary: Smart home devices will become more mainstream as they learn to work together seamlessly, industry insiders say. Companies like Google, Amazon, and Apple are developing virtual assistants and smart home technologies to manage devices wirelessly. Google's virtual home assistant, Google Home, and Amazon's Echo will compete, while Apple's HomeKit framework allows devices to work together. Experts believe the key to adoption is the value of devices working together, and a growing array of service providers and gadget makers will drive growth in the smart home market.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks open higher after global rally
summary: Hong Kong and Shanghai stocks opened higher on Wednesday, tracking overnight gains in US and European markets. The Hang Seng Index surged 1.85%, while the Shanghai Composite Index rose 0.47% and the Shenzhen Composite Index gained 0.64%. The global rally was driven by positive sentiments despite ongoing trade uncertainty and tariff threats.

site_title: China state-owned firms' profits down 8.4% y-o-y in Jan-April
summary: China's state-owned firms reported a 8.4% year-on-year decline in profits from January to April, with total profits reaching 652.26 billion yuan. Revenues fell 1.7% to 13.52 trillion yuan. Coal, steel, and nonferrous metals companies posted losses, while oil, chemical, and building material companies saw profits decline. The finance ministry attributed the decline to reforms aimed at improving efficiency in sprawling state-owned enterprises. Total debts of state-owned companies increased 18% to 81.91 trillion yuan, with debts of centrally-administered companies rising 23.4%.

images.alt_text: China's state-owned firms'profits fell 8.4 per cent year-on-year in the first four months of this year, the finance ministry said.

site_title: Updated quick takes: Singapore growth fundamentals remain anaemic
summary: Singapore's economy grew 1.8% in the first quarter of 2016, driven by a better-than-expected manufacturing sector, but the services sector contracted, with transport and storage activities declining for the second quarter. Economists warn of anaemic growth fundamentals and a risk of China reforms sparking a demand drop, with some forecasting a 3-5% decline in non-oil domestic exports (NODX). The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) maintains its 1-3% growth forecast for 2016, citing underlying fundamentals as weak.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Israel PM's travel expenses under scrutiny
summary: Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu's travel expenses have come under scrutiny with the release of a state comptroller's report on alleged overcharging and conflict of interest. The report, covering 2003-05, found that Netanyahu and his family received funding from external bodies without reporting it to state oversight bodies. The premier's lawyer denies any wrongdoing, but police have renewed an inquiry into the allegations. The attorney general's office is also investigating, and Netanyahu has pledged to deal with the issue "without delay."

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 3.570 points to 1630.010 on Wednesday, driven by a 115-78 gain-to-lose ratio. Volume reached 94.8 million lots worth RM48.1 million.

site_title: China studying to open up commodities futures market
summary: China plans to study opening its commodities futures market to banks and other financial institutions, aiming to increase offshore investment and launch new commodity futures products, including crude oil and iron ore. The move follows concerns about a potential boom-and-bust cycle in the market. The China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) will closely monitor the market and introduce new products to boost liquidity. The plan aims to increase market efficiency and reduce reliance on state-owned enterprises.

images.alt_text: China will study to allow banks and other financial institutions to enter the country's commodities futures market, a senior executive at the China Securities Regulatory Commission (CSRC) said on Wednesday.

site_title: China to encourage domestic airlines to go overseas: regulator
summary: China's aviation regulator plans to expand air rights and improve route allocation for domestic airlines to participate in the international market. The goal is to become a "strong civil aviation nation" despite challenges like insufficient safety resources and a "crude way of development". The policy aims to encourage domestic airlines to explore overseas markets, potentially increasing China's global influence in aviation.

images.alt_text: China will further expand air rights and improve the way it allocates international routes to domestic airlines as it tries to encourage them to participate in the international market, the country's aviation regulator said on Wednesday.

site_title: BOJ Kuroda: Economy recovering but consumption lacks strength
summary: Bank of Japan governor Haruhiko Kuroda stated the economy is recovering moderately, but private consumption remains weak. Kuroda emphasized the need for rising wages and household income to boost spending. He rejected the idea of changing the 2% inflation target, instead maintaining its specific time frame. The BOJ continues to focus on achieving its inflation target, despite the economy's moderate growth.

site_title: Carter warns Trump White House bid fueling racism
summary: Former US President Jimmy Carter warned that Donald Trump's White House bid has fueled racism, tapping a reservoir of "inherent racism." Carter stated that Trump's campaign has reawakened the country to unresolved racial issues, particularly with racially conscious Republicans opposing an African American president. Carter aims to address these issues at the New Baptist Covenant Summit 2016, where he will convene white, black, Hispanic, and Asian Baptists to heal the racial divide.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks at 1-week high on positive US data, won edges up
summary: South Korean stocks reached a one-week high on Wednesday, driven by positive US data that suggested the world's largest economy was gaining strength. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) rose 1.1% to 1,958.21 points, with Samsung Electronics and Hyundai Mobis gaining 1.6% and 2.9% respectively. Foreign investors purchased a net 61.9 billion Korean won worth of Kospi shares, supporting the index. The South Korean won also edged up 0.3% against the US dollar.

site_title: Philippine imports up 11.7% in March year-on-year
summary: Philippine imports rose 11.7% year-on-year in March, driven by double-digit increases in electronic, iron and steel, industrial machinery and equipment imports. Total imports in the first quarter reached $18.6 billion, a 8.8% increase from the same period last year. Electronic imports accounted for 27.7% of total imports in March, with semiconductor components experiencing a 15.8% year-on-year increase.

site_title: London's City finance hub braces for possible Brexit
summary: London's financial district is preparing for a potential Brexit, with major firms like HSBC and Deutsche Bank planning to shift activities abroad and boost liquidity to avoid a credit crunch. The Bank of England is also boosting liquidity to mitigate risks. Experts predict 100,000 job losses in the financial sector, with some firms considering relocation to Paris or Dublin. While some business leaders are calling for a "Remain" vote, others believe Brexit could boost the British economy, citing the potential for a more favorable business environment.

site_title: Singapore's second-largest developer sees cheaper deals
summary: Singapore's second-largest developer, City Developments Ltd, may acquire offices this year due to rising interest rates making such assets cheaper globally. CEO Grant Kelley sees a deflationary trend in assets for the next 12-24 months, driven by increased interest rates and decreased liquidity. The firm has been diversifying outside Singapore and is focused on five key markets, including China, Australia, and the US. City Developments has reported a 14% decline in profit and will meet its target of investing S$5 billion in overseas markets by 2018.

images.alt_text: City Developments Ltd, Singapore's second-largest developer, may seek to buy offices this year as rising interest rates makes such assets cheaper worldwide.

site_title: UN chief fuels presidential speculation with South Korea trip
summary: UN Secretary General Ban Ki-Moon's six-day visit to South Korea has fueled speculation about his potential presidential run in the country. Ban, set to step down at the end of the year, has been welcomed by the ruling conservative Saenuri party, which may consider him as its candidate. Ban enjoys high popularity ratings in South Korea, but some critics, including Seoul mayor Park Won-Soon, have raised concerns about potential conflicts of interest. Ban's future plans remain unclear, but his visit has reignited discussions about his potential presidential bid.

site_title: Singapore shares open 1.3% higher on Wednesday
summary: Singapore shares rose 1.31% on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index reaching 2,786.38. Gainers outnumbered losers 106 to 25, driven by gains in telecommunications and banking stocks, including Singapore Telecommunications, DBS Group Holdings, and United Overseas Bank. The rally follows a 5-day streak ahead of GDP data and despite US trade uncertainty.

site_title: China to protect IP, won't over-regulate innovation: Premier Li
summary: China's Premier Li Keqiang stated that the country will focus on protecting intellectual property and commercial secrets while maintaining a fair playing field for domestic and foreign companies. New innovations will be allowed to grow without over-regulation, even when conflicting with traditional industries. This move aims to encourage economic growth through entrepreneurship and innovation, while still supporting state firms with government oversight.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SembMarine, Keppel, SingPost, Valuetronics
summary: SembCorp Marine and Keppel Corp denied being served with papers in a reported suit by EIG Management Co against Petrobras. SingPost deputy chairman Goh Yeow Tin will resign on June 24 to focus on other commitments. Valuetronics Holdings reported a 19.3% drop in net profit due to exiting mass-market LED bulbs.

site_title: French maps from 1781 that helped free America to be auctioned
summary: French military engineers created maps and sketches in 1781 to aid the American rebels in the War of Independence, which are being auctioned off next month in France. The documents, including two large maps and six sketches, were drawn by hand and show British defenses along the East Coast, including fortifications near New York. The sale, handled by a family-owned auction house, is expected to fetch a significant price, with bidding starting at 10,000 euros, and is seen as a rare opportunity for American collectors and museums to acquire a piece of American history.

site_title: Fitch downgrades Credit Suisse on challenging capital markets
summary: Fitch Ratings downgraded Credit Suisse's long-term default rating to A-minus and viability rating to A-minus due to the bank's reliance on difficult capital markets, particularly in Europe and Asia. The downgrade follows a second consecutive quarterly loss for the Swiss bank, its worst start to a year since the financial crisis. The agency expects the bank's strategic restructuring to face challenges in unfavourable fixed income and equities markets.

images.alt_text: Fitch Ratings downgraded Credit Suisse Group's long-term default rating by a notch to A-minus and its viability rating to A-minus from A, citing the Swiss bank's reliance on difficult capital markets.

site_title: URA releases sales conditions for reserve site at West Coast Vale
summary: The Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) released sales conditions for a 16,378-square-metre residential site at West Coast Vale, offering up to 520 units under the first-half 2016 Government Land Sales programme. The site has a 99-year lease and a permissible potential gross floor area of 45,858 sq m. The URA is now accepting applications for the site, which is available for purchase under the Reserve List.

site_title: Jason suspends key executives over alleged improper transactions
summary: Jason Holdings suspends CEO Jason Sim and operations director New Sze Wei over alleged improper transactions involving deposits and prepayments, and lack of documentation on payments made by a subsidiary. An internal audit report found discrepancies between physical inventory and accounting records. The company plans to find an interim CEO and is under scrutiny from the Singapore Exchange and its sponsor, Canaccord Genuity Singapore, for potential breaches of corporate governance rules. The board believes directors may have breached fiduciary duties and Sim may have breached disclosure requirements.

images.alt_text: Flooring specialist Jason Holdings has suspended chief executive Jason Sim and operations director New Sze Wei over allegations of improper transactions.

site_title: Quick takes: Singapore growth fundamentals remain anaemic
summary: Singapore's economy grew 1.8% in the first quarter of 2016, driven by a better-than-expected manufacturing sector, but the services sector declined, sparking concerns about anaemic growth fundamentals. Economists predict a 1-3% growth forecast for 2016, citing regional demand and trade growth slowdowns, with China reforms and potential US policy normalization adding to downside risks. The services sector's contraction poses significant downside risk to growth in the coming quarters, with the goods-producing industries being the only silver lining.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: On the agenda but off guest list, China eyes G-7 in Japan
summary: China is set to attend a G-7 summit in Japan, despite being excluded from the guest list, amid tensions over its economic slowdown and territorial disputes in the South China Sea. The meeting, hosted by Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, will focus on China's economic slowdown and the South China Sea disputes, with US President Barack Obama and other G-7 leaders attending. China has summoned diplomats from the G-7 nations to try to persuade them not to bring up the disputes during the summit, but experts say any criticism could further irritate China and strain relations.

site_title: Asia: Stocks rise as US home sales surge, rate-hike bets climb
summary: Asian stocks rose as the MSCI Asia Pacific Index rebounded from a seven-week low, driven by a surge in US home sales and speculation that the US economy can withstand higher interest rates. The MSCI Asia Pacific Index climbed 0.8% and Japan's Topix index added 1.6%, with odds of a Federal Reserve rate increase in June rising to 34% from 4% last week. Investors also focused on companies' investments in ride-hailing services and driverless cars, with Sony Corp surging 5.3% and Toyota Motor Corp increasing 1.9%.

site_title: Singapore's total trade in Q1 plunges 9.7%; NODX down 9%
summary: Singapore's trade in Q1 2016 plummeted 9.7% due to a 9% decline in non-oil domestic exports (NODX). The country's trade forecast for 2016 has been revised downward to a 6-8% decline, with NODX expected to fall 3-5%. This marks a continuation of the 7.7% decline in Q4 2015.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks at nearly 1-month high, techs jump
summary: Taiwan's stocks reached a nearly one-month high on May 25, 2016, driven by rallies on Wall Street and regional bourses. The main Taiex index rose 1.0% to 8,379.59 points, with tech heavyweights leading the way. Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co (TSMC) and Hon Hai Precision Industry jumped 1.3% and 3% respectively. The Taiwan dollar also gained T$0.06 to T$32.660 per US dollar.

site_title: 2016 growth to be 'broadly similar' to 2015 as conditions worsen slightly: MTI
summary: The Singapore government has maintained its growth forecast for 2016, expecting a range of 1-3% despite worsening conditions in advanced economies. Conditions have deteriorated marginally since the start of the year, with risks including China's reforms, US interest rate normalisation, and the UK's potential exit from the EU. Domestically, oil and trade-related sectors are expected to be adversely affected, while finance and insurance, and wholesale trade sectors will moderate in growth, and tourism-related sectors will experience a boost.

site_title: Singapore's services sector expands 1.4% in Q1, offsetting manufacturing's 1% decline
summary: Singapore's services sector expanded 1.4% in Q1 2016, offsetting a 1% decline in manufacturing. The construction sector grew 6.2%, contributing to a 1.8% overall GDP growth rate. Manufacturing growth was primarily affected by the transport and precision engineering clusters, while the services sector saw growth across all segments except transportation & storage. The Ministry of Trade and Industry maintained its 2016 GDP growth forecast at 1-3%.

site_title: Property loans, the glass chin of China banks
summary: China's top banks have increased lending to homebuyers and developers, reaching a 12.4 trillion yuan (S$2.6 trillion) mortgage and loan exposure, a 28% share of total loans. This has raised concerns about a property market bubble, with prices in major cities soaring and developers saddled with debt from previous real-estate bubbles. Experts warn of potential consequences if prices drop, citing a reliance on property collateral and over-heated prices, with some estimating non-performing loans could be as high as 15-35% of total loans.

site_title: Eurozone reaches deal on Greek bailout funds, debt
summary: Eurozone finance ministers agree to a 10.3 billion euro bailout package for Greece, unlocking debt relief as demanded by the IMF. The deal comes after Greek lawmakers passed spending cuts and tax hikes. Eurogroup chief Jeroen Dijsselbloem called the agreement an "important moment" in the Greek program. The bailout package is part of a larger bailout program for Greece, which has been struggling with debt.

site_title: Gold hits 4-week low as US rate hike outlook weighs
summary: Gold prices fell to a 4-week low on May 24, 2016, due to hawkish comments from Federal Reserve officials and a strengthening dollar, which lifted interest rates and boosted the dollar's value. This has pushed gold down over 4% in May, its biggest monthly decline since November. Gold is highly sensitive to rising interest rates, which increase the opportunity cost of holding the non-yielding metal and boost the dollar, in which it is priced.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks surge at open
summary: Tokyo stocks surged 1.61% at the open on Wednesday, driven by a weaker yen lifting exporters. The Nikkei 225 index rose 265.59 points to 16,764.35, while the Topix index of all first section shares rose 18.93 points to 1,345.43. This follows a global rally, with the US S&P 500 and Nasdaq also reaching fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Trump, aiming to offset money disadvantage, escalates Clinton attacks
summary: Donald Trump escalated attacks on Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton, using a strategy of making incendiary statements to gain free media coverage and put her on the defensive. Trump's campaign is working to offset Clinton's large campaign war chest, and his attacks include allegations of rape against Bill Clinton and the suicide of a former aide to the former president. The strategy may be working, with Trump raising more attention than Clinton. Clinton's campaign and super PACs have $46 million and $30 million, respectively, compared to Trump's $2 million, and will likely depend on surrogates to combat Trump's attacks.

site_title: SingPost deputy chairman Goh who led integration efforts to resign from June 24
summary: SingPost deputy chairman Goh Yeow Tin is resigning on June 24 to devote more time to other commitments. He was appointed in 2014 to oversee post-merger integration activities. This is the latest in a series of resignations, following former chairman Lim Ho Kee and independent director Keith Tay, amid concerns over corporate governance lapses. Goh's resignation comes after he was made an executive director in January 2016.

site_title: US to seek death penalty against accused South Carolina church shooter
summary: Federal prosecutors will seek the death penalty for Dylann Roof, 22, accused of killing nine black parishioners in a racially motivated attack at a Charleston, South Carolina church in June 2015. Attorney General Loretta Lynch stated that the "nature of the alleged crime and the resulting harm compelled this decision." The attack on Emanuel African Methodist Episcopal Church intensified the debate about race in America, leaving the country shaken.

site_title: EU plans to free up Internet shopping, set Netflix quotas
summary: The European Union plans to unveil proposals to make it easier for internet shoppers to buy goods and services across borders, and to force Netflix and Amazon to accept quotas for European content. The plan aims to create a digital single market, but critics have labeled the separate proposal to compel streaming giants to devote 20% of their content to European programming as "prehistoric" and protectionist. The proposals also include a ban on "geoblocking" and require online retailers to sell goods to customers throughout the EU without additional delivery costs.

images.alt_text: The EU is set to unveil proposals Wednesday to make firms lift international barriers for Internet shoppers, and to force Netflix and Amazon to accept quotas for European movies and TV shows.

site_title: US oil price hits 2016 high on hopes of lower inventories
summary: US oil prices rose to a seven-month high, reaching $48.62 a barrel, amid expectations of lower US inventories and production problems in Nigeria. The price increase follows a two-day slump and is driven by traders' anticipation of a decline in US supplies, despite wildfires in Canada's largest crude supplier. The US benchmark West Texas Intermediate for July delivery advanced 54 US cents, its highest closing price since October.

site_title: New Zealand immigration boom makes its books harder to balance
summary: New Zealand's finance minister, Bill English, is facing challenges in balancing the budget due to record immigration and weaker-than-expected tax revenues. The nation's net immigration reached 68,110 people in the year through April, putting pressure on public services and infrastructure. English's budget forecast now expects a deficit of NZ$401 million, down from the original projection of a surplus. To address this, the government may reduce spending and lower capital spending, while prioritizing debt repayment. English aims to reduce debt to 20% of GDP by 2020, but critics argue this should not come at the expense of tax cuts.

site_title: HP Enterprise to merge IT services unit with Computer Sciences
summary: Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) plans to spin off and merge its struggling IT services business with Computer Sciences Corp, focusing on its cloud services and other fast-growing units. The move is expected to allow HPE to concentrate on its core business. Shares of both companies rose significantly following the announcement, with HPE's shares increasing 10.5% and Computer Sciences' shares jumping 19.5%. The deal aims to improve HPE's financial performance and enhance its competitiveness in the market.

site_title: Brazil's Temer seeks constitutional change to curb public spending
summary: Brazil's interim President Michel Temer plans to seek a constitutional change to limit public spending growth, aiming to curb a record fiscal deficit and regain investor confidence. The proposed amendment would restrict state spending to the previous year's inflation rate, excluding debt payments. Temer seeks Congressional approval for a record deficit of 170.4 billion reais, and plans to reform the pension system after developing a national consensus. The move aims to restore Brazil's credit rating, bring down interest rates, and drag the economy out of its worst recession in decades.

site_title: Four Fed banks called for discount rate hike
summary: Four US Federal Reserve banks - Kansas City, Richmond, Cleveland, and San Francisco - have called for a discount rate hike, up from two in March. The Kansas City and Richmond banks have pushed for an increase in the discount rate for two consecutive meetings. The Fed opted to hold the rate steady in April, but most officials consider a June rate hike if second-quarter growth improves. The San Francisco Fed's John Williams expects two to three rate hikes this year, and Fed Chair Janet Yellen's views are generally aligned with his.

site_title: Brazil president urges economy reforms, slams 'psychological aggression'
summary: Brazil's acting president Michel Temer urged economic reforms to combat the country's crippling recession, slamming "psychological aggression" against his government amid impeachment proceedings. Temer proposed austerity measures, including cutting public spending and increasing debt repayment, to balance the budget. His government faces criticism over its handling of the economy, which is facing a record primary budget deficit of 170.5 billion reais. Temer's authority is also being tested by leaked recordings of his key ally discussing a plot to remove suspended President Dilma Rousseff.

site_title: Oil attacks in Nigeria's south hit power, water supply
summary: Militant attacks in Nigeria's Niger delta region have disrupted oil production, causing a shortage of gas in pumping stations. This has led to power outages and turned off water supplies in Lagos, the country's commercial hub, affecting over 20 million people. The attacks have cut oil output to 1.4 million barrels per day, exacerbating government revenue losses from the global oil price slump. The Lagos Water Corporation is working to provide alternative power supply, while households and businesses rely on generators due to the shortage.

site_title: Sanders seeks Kentucky recount after narrow Clinton win
summary: US Senator Bernie Sanders is seeking a recount of votes in Kentucky's Democratic presidential primary, where Hillary Clinton won by less than 2,000 votes. Sanders requested a full recount of all voting machines and absentee ballots in the state. Although a recount is unlikely to change the outcome, it could provide a psychological boost to Sanders. Clinton leads Sanders by 9.5 percentage points in California, and has amassed 2,301 delegates needed to clinch the nomination, leaving Sanders 82 delegates short.

site_title: Canada PM Trudeau's popularity soars
summary: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau's popularity has reached a new high, with 54% of respondents in a poll preferring him as prime minister. The poll, conducted by Nanos, found Trudeau's personal best in popularity, following a challenging day in office where he was involved in a physical altercation with fellow lawmakers. The results come as Trudeau's Liberal party continues to lead in Canadian politics.

site_title: DNA samples taken as searchers hunt for EgyptAir plane
summary: Egyptian forensics officials collected DNA from relatives of EgyptAir MS804 victims to help identify body parts retrieved from the Mediterranean. The Airbus A320's two black boxes are still being searched for, with French and Egyptian aviation officials saying it's too soon to determine the cause of the crash. The aircraft transmitted automated messages indicating smoke in the cabin and a fault in the Flight Control Unit before contact was lost. The search continues, with specialized French equipment and a submersible deployed to locate the black boxes.

site_title: Wells Fargo lowers financial targets, cuts energy loan exposure
summary: Wells Fargo lowered its financial targets, cutting its return on assets and shareholder equity to 1.1-1.4% and 11-14% respectively. The bank attributed the move to low interest rates, higher capital requirements, and increasing credit costs. Wells Fargo is also reducing its exposure to troubled energy loans, with 68% of reviewed loans having credit lines cut. The bank expects "continued stress" in its energy loans throughout 2016, with potential for additional reserve builds and credit losses.

site_title: No sign of EgyptAir plane technical problems before takeoff: sources
summary: EgyptAir Flight 804, which disappeared on May 19, 2016, did not show technical problems before takeoff, according to Egyptian investigation committee sources. The plane transmitted 11 electronic messages before vanishing, with the third message indicating a rise in temperature of the co-pilot's window. The investigation is looking for clues in human remains and debris, and the black box recorders, which could explain the cause of the crash, have not been located. Egyptian officials have given differing accounts of the plane's final moments, and investigators are still analyzing scraps of data from the jet's last minutes of flight.

site_title: Top UN official urges 'new approach' to aid
summary: Top UN official Helen Clark urges a 'new approach' to aid, citing that spending on humanitarian relief has tripled in the last 10 years but still falls short. She emphasizes that preventing crises is crucial, and that sustaining communities with basic services costs significantly less than providing aid after a crisis. Clark calls for a fundamental rethink of the aid system, citing under-subscribed appeals, at the World Humanitarian Summit in Istanbul.

images.alt_text: Spending on humanitarian relief has tripled in the last 10 years but is still too small to meet demand, a top UN official told AFP Tuesday as she called for a fundamental re-think of the aid system.

site_title: Google ex-boss Schmidt reveals he has an iPhone
summary: Google's former CEO Eric Schmidt appeared at the Startup Europe Fest in Amsterdam, where he revealed he has an iPhone and a Samsung, sparking laughter and a show of hands that favored iPhones over Androids. The event highlighted the ongoing battle between Apple and Google, with Schmidt urging European entrepreneurs to support start-ups and Google hiring thousands of Europeans annually. Apple CEO Tim Cook also attended, defending his company's app store and emphasizing the importance of innovation and creativity.

site_title: Singapore economy grows by 1.8% in Q1, largely within expectations
summary: Singapore's economy grew by 1.8% in the first quarter of 2016, within expectations, driven by a better-than-expected manufacturing sector and a slower-than-expected services sector. The government maintains its forecast of a 1-3% growth in 2016. Full estimates slightly fell short of market consensus, but the headline print remained unchanged at 1.8%. The economy has barely grown from the previous quarter, with a 0.2% increase on a seasonally adjusted basis.

images.alt_text: Headline growth for Singapore's economy in the first quarter of this year was largely within expectations with a 1.8 per cent year-on-year expansion, as manufacturing posted a better showing than predicted earlier while the services sector slipped.

site_title: Brexit seems increasingly unlikely to corporate-debt investors
summary: UK corporate-debt investors are increasingly optimistic about a Brexit outcome, with growing confidence that the UK will reject leaving the EU. Sterling has strengthened against the dollar and euro, and borrowing costs for investment-grade issuers in sterling have fallen to 3.23% from 3.70% in February. Bookmakers have cut the odds on a June 23 status quo victory, and opinion polls suggest a lead for the campaign to remain in the EU. Investors expect a narrow premium to hold debt denominated in sterling, indicating a reduced concern about Brexit.

images.alt_text: Sterling has risen against the dollar and the euro over the past two weeks, aided by opinion polls suggesting a lead for the campaign to remain in the EU.

site_title: Goldman Sachs sees Malaysian deals evaporate amid 1MDB concerns
summary: Goldman Sachs' business in Malaysia has significantly declined amid concerns over its dealings with 1Malaysia Development Bank Bhd. The bank was omitted from a list of banks invited to bid on a US$750 million bond sale in December, following a period of negative publicity over its 1MDB fees. Goldman Sachs' Malaysian deal activity has fallen, with the firm ranking 18th in mergers advisory and behind global rivals. The bank's association with 1MDB, led by former star banker Tim Leissner, has led to a wider collapse in its Malaysian business.

site_title: Europe: Shares rise as euro falls, investors weigh Fed talk
summary: European stocks rose 2.3% to a six-week high, driven by the euro's decline to a two-month low against the dollar. Investors are assessing the implications of a possible Federal Reserve interest rate increase as early as June. European companies, which generate half their sales abroad, are benefiting from lower borrowing costs. The Stoxx 600 index closed at 344.49, with insurers leading the gains.

site_title: Foreign investors more loyal to Germany than ever before: study
summary: Foreign investors are more loyal to Germany than ever before, with 8% planning to relocate parts of their operation elsewhere, according to a survey by EY. Germany ranks as the most attractive business location in Europe, with 69% of businesses naming it as one of the top three investment locations. Investors are attracted to Germany's well-educated workforce, communications, and transport, but are concerned about rising anti-immigrant sentiment and increasing attacks on refugees. The cost of labor in Germany is also a negative factor, with 37% of investors finding it unattractive.

site_title: US dollar rises in anticipation of Fed rate hike soon
summary: The US dollar strengthened against the euro and yen due to market expectations of a Federal Reserve interest rate hike in the next couple of months. Philadelphia Fed President Patrick Harker's comments signaling a possible rate hike of two or three times this year contributed to the dollar's rise. Meanwhile, the British pound rose as opinion polls suggested a likely "Remain" vote in the June 23 referendum, potentially avoiding a Brexit. Markets are now raising bets on a rate hike at the July meeting, with odds above 50% for the first time in two months.

site_title: US$ hits 8-week high against euro
summary: The US dollar reached an eight-week high against the euro, strengthening across the board, amid speculation that the US Federal Reserve will raise interest rates again. The Australian dollar fell by over one percent, its weakest since early March, while the US dollar rose 0.4 percent against the euro, reaching US$1.11685. This move was partly driven by investors bringing forward their bets on future interest rate hikes.

site_title: Suzhou land sales halted as bids exceed limits
summary: China's land auction for Suzhou was halted after bids exceeded limits, with prices surpassing ceilings set by the local government. The two plots, in the city's west Gaoxin district, had initial asking prices of 1 billion yuan and 2.7 billion yuan, but prices reached 2.1 billion yuan and 4.7 billion yuan, more than double the initial prices. This move aims to curb a surge in prices in top economic hubs, following a 98% decline in land sales in China's four first-tier cities in April compared to the same period last year.

site_title: VW 'on track' to meet deadline for diesel-rigging settlement
summary: US District Judge Charles Breyer says Volkswagen AG is on track to meet a June deadline to settle with US car owners over the diesel-rigging scandal, which affected 480,000 vehicles. The proposed $10 billion settlement includes buybacks, cash compensation, and a fund to address damages. The plan also covers 85,000 tainted 3-litre engines in the US. Volkswagen has set aside $25 billion to cover costs, but faces ongoing federal and state investigations, and other obstacles to recovery.

images.alt_text: The federal judge demanding Volkswagen AG fix 480,000 diesel-cheating vehicles in the US or get them off the road said the automaker is on pace to meet next month's deadline to reach a deal with car owners.

site_title: Google offers new features to local search ads
summary: Google is introducing new features to local search ads, allowing businesses to promote offers, browse product inventories, and menus on Google Maps and Google.com. The new feature will automatically show ads to users along their driving route, and nearly one-third of all mobile searches on Google are related to location. This move aims to enhance user experience and provide more value to businesses.

images.alt_text: Google Maps will soon carry promotional offers from nearby businesses along with ads and allow users to browse product inventories and menus.

site_title: US expecting cheapest retail prices for ground beef in two years
summary: The US is expecting the cheapest retail prices for ground beef in two years, with prices potentially dropping as much as 2% this year due to bumper grains crops and increased cattle production. The US Department of Agriculture predicts annual production will increase for the first time since 2010, benefiting consumers and hedge funds betting on low-cost meat to stimulate demand. With Memorial Day marking the unofficial start of summer and the grilling season, consumers can expect cheaper burgers and other party staples, including ice cream and potato chips, which are at their lowest levels since August.

site_title: Monsanto: US$62b Bayer bid too low, but open to talks
summary: US agribusiness giant Monsanto Co rejected a $62 billion takeover bid by Germany's Bayer AG, citing the offer as "too low" and "incomplete." Bayer, which would gain control of Monsanto's seeds, farm pesticides, and genetically modified crops, is willing to engage in further talks. The deal faces regulatory challenges, including concerns over antitrust and the concentration of power in the agricultural industry. Bayer's shares fell after the rejection, while Monsanto's shares rose.

site_title: Dutch MPs vote to strip jihadists of dual nationality
summary: Dutch MPs have voted to strip dual nationals of their Dutch citizenship if they join terror groups like the Islamic State, even if they haven't been convicted of a crime. The lower house of parliament approved the bill to revoke citizenship of people with dual nationality who join foreign terror groups. The move aims to prevent returning jihadists from posing a threat to national security. However, the ruling doesn't apply to those with only Dutch nationality, and some leftist parties have expressed concerns it could lead to greater radicalization.

site_title: Volkswagen, Toyota buy into ridesharing
summary: Volkswagen and Toyota have partnered with ridesharing companies Uber and Gett, respectively. Toyota will explore collaboration through trials in expanding countries, while Volkswagen invested $300 million in Gett for on-demand mobility technology. The partnerships aim to create new leasing options and develop in-car apps. This move follows General Motors and Lyft's joint car rental service in March, as carmakers seek to boost vehicle availability for rideshare apps.

site_title: AIG and Aviva offer motorists two-year insurance policies
summary: AIG and Aviva are offering two-year car insurance policies to Singaporean motorists, providing a hedge against premium increases and protection against claims loading. This novel product allows customers to pay annually instead of the usual annual payment. The two-year policy offers double the standard coverage period, giving customers a more flexible and cost-effective option.

site_title: China's Huawei sues Samsung Electronics claiming mobile patent infringement
summary: Huawei Technologies Co Ltd filed lawsuits against Samsung Electronics Co Ltd, claiming infringement of smartphone patents in the US and China. Huawei alleges Samsung used unlicensed 4G technology, operating systems, and user interface software in its phones. The lawsuit marks a reversal of roles in China, where Samsung was once the leading smartphone vendor but has since lost market share to local brands. Huawei, which generates most of its revenue from telecommunications infrastructure, has been granted 50,377 patents globally.

site_title: French government breaks blockades as petrol runs short
summary: The French government has broken blockades and strikes at refineries, threatening to paralyze the country just three weeks before the Euro 2016 football tournament. The blockades, driven by the CGT union, were aimed at forcing the Socialist government to withdraw planned labor law reforms. Police used tear gas and water cannons to clear the blockades at the Fos-sur-Mer refinery near Marseille. The union vowed to continue the disruption until the government meets their demands.

site_title: Funding for global tech startups should return: Temasek
summary: Temasek executive suggests funding for global tech startups should return despite valuations not rebounding to 2015 levels. Investors are pressing for less inflated values, driven by concerns of a tech bubble. Capital inflows to the sector have eased since last year, with some startups needing only cash and a working app to enter the market.

site_title: Facebook to tweak Trending Topics although probe finds no political bias
summary: Facebook will change its Trending Topics section by removing the top-10 list of websites, introducing clearer guidelines for human editors, and more training to avoid ideological or political bias. An internal probe found no evidence of political bias, despite Republican Senator John Thune's letter demanding explanations. The company will also review procedures more robustly.

site_title: Sovereign funds seek out yields in illiquid private debt funds
summary: Sovereign funds are investing in private debt, with 35% of funds now invested in the sector, up 11 percentage points from 2015. These funds provide loans for various purposes, including aircraft leasing and lawsuit financing. Specialist private debt vehicles are booming as a result, offering higher returns than traditional bonds.

site_title: Indonesia eases foreign ownership curbs in 'big bang' liberalisation
summary: Indonesia has issued new regulations easing foreign ownership curbs in various sectors, including tourism businesses, transportation firms, and movie theatres, as part of President Joko Widodo's strategy to liberalize the economy. The new decree allows foreigners to own 67% of certain businesses, such as department stores and telecommunications services, and eases restrictions on sectors like tourism and transportation. However, foreign ownership caps remain in place for small e-commerce businesses and telecommunications tower services. The move aims to attract foreign investment and expand the manufacturing and tourism sectors in Southeast Asia's largest economy.

images.alt_text: The liberalisation is part of President Joko's strategy to expand the manufacturing and tourism sectors in South-east Asia's largest economy, to reduce its reliance on exporting raw commodities.

site_title: Uptick in colon cancer rates among people under 50
summary: A US study of over a million people over 10 years found a 11.4% rise in colon cancer cases among those under 50, with 136 new cases annually. This rise comes despite overall colon cancer rates declining in recent years. Younger patients tend to be diagnosed with more advanced cancers, with 31% diagnosed at stage three and 25% at stage four. The study highlights the need for increased awareness and screenings among younger populations, particularly non-white patients, to combat this trend.

site_title: HK exchange to work quickly to build China bond connect: CEO
summary: Hong Kong Exchanges and Clearing (HKEX) plans to quickly establish a bond connect with China's interbank bond market, giving global investors access to yuan-related assets. The concept is similar to the Shanghai-Hong Kong Stock Connect, which connected the two markets in 2014. This move is expected to allow global banks to develop offshore yuan interest rate products, following China's decision to open its interbank bond market to foreigners. The plan aims to increase investment opportunities in China's onshore bond market, which has a total of 48.5 trillion yuan in outstanding bonds.

site_title: MAS to shut down BSI Singapore for anti-money laundering breaches
summary: The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) has ordered the shutdown of BSI Singapore, a Swiss private bank, due to anti-money laundering breaches. The bank was found to have failed to conduct enhanced customer due diligence and monitor suspicious transactions, resulting in 41 breaches of anti-money laundering rules. Six individuals, including former BSI staff and senior management, have been referred to the prosecutor for a criminal offence assessment. The bank's assets totaling US$4 billion were managed by clients including 1Malaysia Development Bhd, a scandal-hit Malaysian state-backed firm.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: US rate-hike fears weaken STI by 16.7 pts
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index fell 16.7 points to 2,750.23 on Tuesday, with the entire market recording a weak volume of 966.2 million units. US Federal Reserve officials' comments on interest rate hikes weakened the market, with 40-point rise in Dow futures and late-afternoon rebound in Hong Kong. The market is expected to remain range-bound, with earnings slightly below expectations, and a recovering oil price.

site_title: Hwang Capital up 18% on buyout offer from its chairman
summary: Hwang Capital, a Malaysian money lender, surged 18% to RM2.60 after its chairman, Hwang Lip Teik, offered RM2.65 cash per share to take the company private. The offer price is 20% higher than the last traded price of RM2.21. The move is seen as a respite for minority shareholders amid a 5.5% market decline in the past month. The company's shares are heavily influenced by DBS Bank, which owns 24% of its shares, and the offer is conditional on receiving more than 50% of the voting shares.

site_title: New security plan from Swift after hacker heists
summary: Swift, the international banking secure messaging service, plans to launch a five-point security programme to rebuild its reputation after a series of hacker heists, including the $81 million Bangladesh Bank heist in February. CEO Gottfried Leibbrandt will unveil the plan at a financial services conference in Brussels this week. The programme aims to improve information sharing, security procedures, and the use of software to spot fraudulent payments. Swift will also provide tighter guidelines for auditors and regulators. The cooperative will not take sole responsibility for security, citing the need for other authorities to also play a role in preventing future attacks.

site_title: Data analytics startup Sense Infosys secures S$2m funding
summary: Singapore-based data analytics startup Sense Infosys secured S$2 million in funding, allowing it to expand research and development, sales, and support operations. The investment, led by Jason Venture, will aid in developing maritime and security data analytics products.
