Oil Search dropped 1.6%, Whitehaven Coal fell 3%, and Flight Centre Travel Group plummeted 6% to a nine-month low. Miners, however, rose, with BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto gaining 0.7% and 0.4%, respectively. New Zealand's benchmark index also fell 0.5% to its lowest level in two weeks.

site_title: China to sell 3b yuan of sovereign bonds in London
summary: China plans to issue 3 billion yuan (S$630.8 million) of sovereign bonds in London, its first offshore issuance outside of Hong Kong, in an effort to increase the yuan's global usage. The bonds will be listed on the London Stock Exchange and follow last year's issuance of one-year bills. The move aims to meet IMF requirements for liquidity of global reserve currencies, with regulators seeking to broaden the yuan's offshore assets. The offering is seen as a step to boost the yuan's global usage, following the IMF's planned addition of the yuan to its reserve currency basket from October 1.

site_title: Broker's take: Religare raises expectations of ThaiBev restructuring
summary: Shares of Thai Beverage Public Co (ThaiBev) rose 1.7% to 87.5 Singapore cents after Religare analyst Nirgunan Tiruchelvam raised his target price to S$1.10, citing a 50% probability of ThaiBev's parent TCC restructuring its holdings in ThaiBev, Fraser & Neave, and Frasers Centrepoint Limited. A potential restructuring could see F&N split from other businesses, with its F&B business injected into ThaiBev, which would then dispose of its 29% stake in F&N.

site_title: Hong Kong Exchange to work quickly to build a China bond connect scheme
summary: Hong Kong Exchange and Clearing's CEO Charles Li plans to quickly build a bond trading scheme with China, similar to the successful Shanghai-Hong Kong Stock Connect program. The focus shifts from stock trading to adding more currency and fixed-income products due to the onshore stock market crash in 2015 and weak Chinese markets. In 2016, the exchange aims to launch new yuan currency futures contracts, including euro-yuan, yen-yuan, and yuan-US dollar futures, to capitalize on the growing yuan foreign exchange rate.

site_title: China signs deal with Sudan to build nuclear reactor
summary: China has signed a framework agreement with Sudan to build the African nation's first nuclear reactor, marking the country's expansion into the global nuclear sector. The deal was signed during a visit by China's top energy official, Nur Bekri, and is part of China's efforts to develop the necessary experience and expertise to become a dominant player. This marks the latest in China's nuclear expansion, following deals with countries such as Romania, Saudi Arabia, and Argentina.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars friendless, RBA remarks awaited
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars fell against the US dollar, with the Australian dollar easing to US$0.7211 and the New Zealand dollar to US$0.6758. This decline was driven by renewed weakness in commodity and equity markets, sending investors to the safety of the yen. The Reserve Bank of Australia is expected to cut rates to a record low of 1.5% later this year, while the US Federal Reserve is seen raising rates as early as June.

site_title: Singapore's Housing Board launches 8,940 flats for sale in May
summary: The Housing & Development Board (HDB) of Singapore launched 8,940 flats for sale in May, including 3,770 Build-To-Order units and 5,170 Sale of Balance Flats units across 25 towns and estates. This is the second BTO launch for 2016, bringing the total to 7,940 units offered in the first half of the year. The total 13,110 flats offered meet the housing needs of Singaporeans, with the latest exercise contributing to the ongoing housing market demand.

images.alt_text: The Housing & Development Board (HDB) of Singapore on Tuesday launched 8,940 flats for sale under the May 2016 Build-To-Order (BTO) and Sale of Balance Flats (SBF) exercise.
Angela Tan

site_title: Gold holds four-day drop as Fed 'procession' signals rate rise
summary: Gold prices declined for a fourth consecutive day, falling 0.2% to $1,248.20 an ounce, as Federal Reserve officials signaled a possible rate hike in June, increasing the odds to 32% since May. The comments from Fed officials, including Patrick Harker and John Williams, support higher borrowing costs, strengthening the US dollar and reducing gold's appeal. The decline erodes gold's 2016 gains, with traders pricing in a higher chance of a rate increase sooner rather than later.

site_title: Fed may not shrink swollen portfolio to pre-crisis size: Harker
summary: The Federal Reserve may not shrink its portfolio to pre-crisis size of $900 billion, according to Philadelphia Fed President Patrick Harker. The Fed is currently studying its portfolio size, considering lower expected long-term rates, and has not set a specific target. This contradicts previous statements that the Fed would shrink its portfolio once interest rates rise higher. Harker's comments echo those made by San Francisco Fed President John Williams, who also expressed uncertainty about the portfolio's future size.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 5.580 points to 1631.270. Volume was 28.4 million lots worth RM8.68 million, with losers outnumbering gainers 72 to 52.

site_title: KIT unit believes Basslink outage covered by insurance
summary: The manager of Keppel Infrastructure Trust's Basslink unit believes a recent Australian electric line outage is covered by insurance, classified as a force majeure event. A repair vessel reached the fault location on May 20, with a return to service expected in late June. The outage, which occurred in December 2015, is not expected to have a material financial impact on the trust's financial year-end results.

site_title: Nissan mulls sale of stake in auto parts supplier Calsonic Kansei
summary: Nissan is considering selling its 41% stake in Calsonic Kansei, a Japanese auto parts supplier, to raise funds for electric car and AI research. The sale could fetch over $1.26 billion, with major foreign parts makers and US/European investment funds interested. Nissan plans to seek bids in June, citing the need to boost Calsonic Kansei's competitiveness. The move comes as Nissan seeks to strengthen its competitiveness against rivals like Toyota and Volkswagen.

site_title: Head of security for US TSA removed from post
summary: The head of security for the US Transportation Security Administration (TSA), Kelly Hoggan, has been removed from his position after criticism over long security lines at airport checkpoints. Hoggan was replaced by his deputy, Darby LaJoye, who will serve on an acting basis. The decision comes amid a surge in passenger volumes and long lines, with the TSA blaming the issue on a lack of security screeners. Hoggan had previously faced criticism for receiving large bonuses, and the agency has since taken steps to improve security operations, including adding screeners at busy airports.

site_title: South Korea to make it easier for foreign funds to trade stocks
summary: South Korea plans to test a system allowing overseas investors to trade local stocks through a single account, called an omnibus, as part of efforts to be included in MSCI's developed-market equity indexes. The system will be tested from May 25 to September 2016, with four offshore banks, two brokerages, and a global investment firm participating. The goal is to officially launch the system in 2017, which would make it easier for foreign funds to invest in South Korean assets and potentially upgrade the country's status from emerging to developed market.

site_title: Japan's net external assets fall for 1st time in 5 years, still top creditor
summary: Japan's net external assets fell for the first time in five years to 339.26 trillion yen at end-2015, mainly due to the rising yen. Despite this, Japan remained the world's largest creditor nation, surpassing Germany with 195.24 trillion yen in net assets. Japan's gross external assets rose 0.7% to 948.73 trillion yen, while external debt grew 5.3% to 609.47 trillion yen. The yen's rise against the euro reduced the appraised value of external assets by 17.4 trillion yen.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares open lower on stronger yen, Fed worries
summary: Tokyo shares opened lower on May 24, 2016, due to a stronger yen and concerns over US central bank policy. The Nikkei 225 index fell 0.30% and the Topix index dropped 0.34%. The weaker yen hurt exporters, while traders were worried about US monetary policy, following a weak lead from Wall Street.

site_title: 1MDB blot eclipsed by oil means ringgit rally to top forecaster
summary: The Malaysian ringgit, the worst-performing currency in the first quarter of 2016, may rally due to subsiding political risks and potential oil price gains. Top forecaster ING Groep NV predicts a 9% jump by September 30, citing the prime minister's election victory in Sarawak and the currency's undervaluation. Analysts at Standard Chartered Plc also expect the ringgit to appreciate, driven by oil prices and interest rate decisions. Despite concerns over 1MDB, the ringgit's correlation with oil prices suggests it may reprise its appreciation.

site_title: KOP subsidiaries, directors receive writ of summons
summary: KOP subsidiaries and directors received a writ of summons from Bachmeer Capital, an investment vehicle of substantial shareholder Wang Xuan, who holds an 8.19% stake in the company. KOP denies the claims and is seeking legal advice to defend the matter. The company will make further announcements as developments unfold.

site_title: Bank of America wins reversal of US$1.27b penalty in US mortgage case
summary: A US appeals court overturned a US$1.27 billion penalty against Bank of America for its role in the 2008 financial crisis. The court ruled that the evidence was insufficient to prove the bank was liable for mortgage fraud under federal fraud statutes. The penalty was related to a mortgage program called "Hustle" run by former Countrywide Financial Corp, which Bank of America bought in 2008. The decision deals a major setback to the US Justice Department.

site_title: Egypt prosecutor seeks data on crashed plane from France, Greece
summary: Egypt's public prosecutor has requested data from France and Greece on the crashed EgyptAir plane. The prosecutor wants documents, audio and video records, and transcripts of calls between the pilot and Greek air traffic control officials. The plane vanished off radar screens while entering Egyptian airspace over the Mediterranean, with 10 crew and 56 passengers on board. French investigators have found signs of smoke on board, but the cause of the crash remains unknown, with possible explanations including sabotage or a technical fault.

site_title: Yen shored up by risk aversion, commodity currencies sag on declining oil
summary: The yen strengthened against major currencies, driven by risk aversion and declining expectations of Japanese currency weakening. The US warned Japan against intervening to weaken the yen, exacerbating the rift. Commodity currencies, such as the Australian and Canadian dollars, declined due to falling oil prices. The dollar, initially risen to a three-week high, gave back gains to the yen. A decline in global equities and hawkish Fed comments also contributed to the yen's gain, while the dollar index remained steady near a two-month high.

site_title: Asia: Stocks decline as yen weighs on Japan, Fed hawks speak
summary: Asian stocks declined for the first time in three days as a stronger yen weighed on Japan's exporters, with the MSCI Asia Pacific Index falling 0.2% to 125.91. The US dollar strengthened against the yen, 0.8% higher on Monday, and speculation mounted that the US Federal Reserve may raise interest rates. Other regional markets, including Australia, New Zealand, and South Korea, also declined, with losses ranging from 0.3% to 0.5%.

site_title: France's Macron says divisive labour reforms should be tougher
summary: French Economy Minister Emmanuel Macron says the country's divisive labor reforms should be tougher, calling for further weakening of collective bargaining by unions. Macron, a potential presidential candidate, advocates for salary negotiations to occur closer to company level and greater wage restraint to boost industrial competitiveness. The reforms, pushed by unpopular President Francois Hollande, have sparked strikes and divisions within the Socialist government. Macron's comments may fuel opposition but have not damaged his approval ratings, which are higher than Hollande's.

site_title: Fed's Harker adds to drumbeat of approaching US rate hikes
summary: Federal Reserve President Patrick Harker expects the central bank to raise interest rates two or three times in 2016, with possible hikes in June or July. Harker's comments reinforce the Fed's message of taking action to boost the US economy, which has recovered from a weak winter. He also predicts inflation will reach 2% by next year and US economic growth will be "meaningfully more upbeat" than the first quarter's 0.5% rate.

site_title: Chesapeake swaps debt for equity for second time in May
summary: Chesapeake Energy Corp, the second-largest US natural gas producer, swapped debt for equity for the second time in May, issuing about 37.1 million shares in exchange for senior notes worth $166 million. The company has over $9 billion in debt and has lost more than three-fourths of its stock value over the past year. This is the second debt-for-equity swap by Chesapeake this month, following a similar transaction earlier in May.

site_title: Stocks to watch: KOP, Serrano, Keppel Infrastructure Trust, Xpress
summary: KOP, a property developer, received a writ of summons from substantial shareholder Wang Xuan, prompting the company to defend against the suit. Serrano, an interior design firm, applied for a 12-week stay of proceedings against creditors. Keppel Infrastructure Trust's Basslink unit claimed a recent Australia cable outage was a force majeure event and therefore covered by insurance. Xpress Holdings shares resumed trading after the company said it's in talks for a potential minority stake in a China supermarket business, with plans to add smart technologies to its core businesses.

site_title: Facebook, Google scrutinised amid French online ad sector probe
summary: French regulators are launching an antitrust probe into the online display-advertising sector, focusing on Facebook, Google, and Twitter. The probe aims to assess the importance of data collection and exploitation in the sector, with potential risks including the ability to offer services in different segments. The French Competition Authority will examine Facebook's market power and strategy, including its data collection tools. The findings could lead to recommendations for new laws or advice for companies to modify their behavior, with individual antitrust probes possible if warranted.

images.alt_text: The digital display-advertising sector - led in the US by Facebook Inc, Google and Twitter Inc - faces a potential antitrust crackdown as French regulators start an inquiry with a view to publishing final findings in the second half of next year.

site_title: Xpress in talks for stake in Chinese supermarket; to expand scope of business
summary: XPRESS Holdings is in talks for a minority stake in a Chinese supermarket business, aiming to expand its scope of business with smart technologies, publishing, and investment. The company's shares have surged 32.8% since May 13, but no agreement has been reached on the joint venture. Xpress plans to seek shareholder approval to add new activities to its core businesses. The company's shares will resume trading on Tuesday after being halted on Monday.

site_title: Facebook changing guidelines for trending topics after probe
summary: Facebook is changing its guidelines for trending topics after allegations of political bias in its selections. The company will no longer require stories to appear on specific sites, including the New York Times and Buzzfeed, to be considered trending. Facebook found no evidence of systemic bias in its investigation, but acknowledged a possibility of isolated actions with improper motives. The change comes after US Senator John Thune and conservative groups expressed concerns about the feature, prompting CEO Mark Zuckerberg to meet with them to discuss the issue. Facebook will also stop using a curated RSS feed for news.

site_title: Brexit would make vacations pricier for Britons, Cameron says
summary: UK Prime Minister David Cameron warned that a Brexit would make vacations pricier for Britons, citing a projected 12% depreciation of the pound and a resulting increase in travel costs. An average 8-night trip to an EU destination would cost an extra £230, while a 2-week US trip would rise by £620. A weaker pound would also reduce the value of savings and jeopardize cheap flights and mobile roaming charges.

site_title: Fracking in Britain approved for first time since 2011
summary: A shale gas fracking project in North Yorkshire, Britain, won approval for the first time since 2011, with councillors voting 7-4 in favour of the plan despite 4,375 objections. The project, by firm Third Energy, aims to release oil and gas from a well two miles deep. Locals expressed concerns over environmental damage, water contamination, and climate change, but the company claimed a strong safety record. The decision was met with protests and criticism from environmental groups, who vowed to continue fighting the project.

site_title: Oil prices dip as Canadian oil evacuations lifted
summary: Canadian officials lifted evacuation orders for oil production sites in Alberta, reducing supply disruptions. Oil prices dropped 33 US cents to $48.08 a barrel for West Texas Intermediate and 37 US cents to $48.35 a barrel for Brent North Sea oil. The move alleviated fears of global supply disruptions, but Iranian officials vowed to keep pumping aggressively, supporting market doubts about OPEC's ability to curb oversupply. The decision followed failed talks in Doha last month to cap production.

site_title: Thailand's unresolved political stalemate has economic costs
summary: Thailand's ongoing political stalemate has significant economic costs. The country, the second-largest in Southeast Asia, has been relatively stable since the military takeover in 2014, but at the cost of civil liberties and economic stagnation. The military has suspended protests and prosecutions under sedition laws, and a draft constitution, which would give broad powers to the army, is set to be put to a public referendum on August 7. The outcome could lead to further delays in national elections and continued military control, hindering the economy's recovery, which has stuttered due to global economic stagnation and China's slowdown.

site_title: Investment banks suffer worst first quarter since financial crisis: survey
summary: Investment banks worldwide reported a 25% decline in revenue in the first quarter, the worst start since the 2008 financial crisis. Economic uncertainty, low oil prices, and near-zero interest rates contributed to the decline. Trading in fixed income, currencies, and commodities fell 28% year-on-year, with FICC divisions down 49% and headcount down 33% since 2011. Other divisions also experienced revenue declines, with equity businesses down 20% and investment banking divisions down 25%.

images.alt_text: Revenue at the world's 12 largest investment banks fell 25 per cent in the first quarter from a year ago as economic uncertainty and investor caution led to the slowest start since the financial crisis, a survey showed on Tuesday.

site_title: Singapore's STI slips 0.3% to 2,758.70 at opening
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 0.3% to 2,758.70 at the opening of trading on Tuesday, May 24, 2016. The decline came after 45.1 million shares worth S$40.8 million changed hands, with warehouse developer Global Logistic Properties leading the blue chips in terms of traded value. The number of losers outweighed gainers 69 to 44.

site_title: Oracle sued Google over a hamburger, Java trial jury told
summary: Oracle Corp sued Google over alleged copyright infringement of Java programming code used in Android operating system. A Google lawyer likened the issue to a hamburger, comparing the packages of Java code to a menu. This is the first and potentially final phase of the trial.

site_title: Deutsche Bank post-crisis mortgage positions said probed by SEC
summary: The US Securities and Exchange Commission is investigating Deutsche Bank AG over allegations that it inflated the value of mortgage-bond securities and masked losses around 2013. The investigation focuses on positions overseen by Troy Dixon, who ran the bank's trading for US government-backed mortgage bonds. The SEC is looking into whether the bank delayed recording losses on those securities, potentially boosting earnings in 2013. This is the latest in a series of regulatory issues for Deutsche Bank, which has paid over $12.6 billion in fines and lawsuits since 2012.

site_title: Spotify losses deepen despite rapid expansion
summary: Spotify reported a 173 million euro net loss in 2015, despite a 80% revenue jump to 1.945 billion euros, with 89 million active monthly users and 28 million paying subscribers. The company attributes its growth to its model supporting profitability at scale, with plans to invest in product and marketing initiatives to accelerate reach. Despite facing competition from tech giants like Apple and rival services, Spotify remains confident in its ability to generate substantial revenues and improve margins as its reach expands.

site_title: Goldman sees 35% chance on US rate hike in June
summary: Goldman Sachs economists predict a 35% chance the US Federal Reserve will raise its target federal funds rate at the June 14-15 policy meeting, with a 35% and 20% probability of rate hikes at the July 26-27 and September 20-21 meetings, respectively.

site_title: Europe: Shares slide as Bayer leads chemicals drop, oil falls
summary: European shares slid 0.3% to 337.13, led by a 5.6% drop in Bayer and chemical shares, while oil producers fell as crude retreated for a fourth day. Investors await potential US Federal Reserve interest rate increase, with regional Fed chiefs set to provide insights. The Stoxx 600 is down 3.9% from its recent peak, and Greece's ASE Index jumped 1.5% after creditors agreed to disburse 11 billion euros.

site_title: Coca-Cola cuts output in Venezuela due to sugar shortage
summary: The Coca-Cola Company has cut back production of its popular sodas in Venezuela due to a sugar shortage. The shortage, caused by suppliers ceasing operations due to a lack of raw materials, has impacted the production of sugar-sweetened beverages like Coca-Cola. However, the company will continue to produce its zero-sugar drinks and bottled water. This is the latest in a series of foreign firms to halt or slow production in Venezuela due to the country's economic turmoil and shortages of key products.

site_title: Swift to unveil new security plan after hackers' heists
summary: Swift, the international banking messaging service, plans to launch a new security program in response to the Bangladesh Bank heist, which saw $81 million stolen. The program, announced by CEO Gottfried Leibbrandt, aims to improve information sharing, security procedures, and the use of software to spot fraudulent payments. The plan includes tighter guidelines for auditors and regulators and a five-point plan to rebuild Swift's reputation. Critics argue Swift should be more active in auditing clients and cutting off those with poor security, but Leibbrandt says other authorities also have a role in security.

images.alt_text: The Swift secure messaging service that underpins international banking said it plans to launch a new security programme as it fights to rebuild its reputation in the wake of the Bangladesh Bank heist.

site_title: Gulf countries, Canada to cooperate in anti-IS fight
summary: Gulf Arab foreign ministers and Canadian Foreign Minister Stephane Dion agreed to strengthen cooperation in the fight against the Islamic State group and other jihadist organizations. They aimed to "dry up" sources of finance for these groups, emphasizing that the campaign against them is not linked to a specific religion or sect. The statement noted that the war on terror is a global issue, requiring international cooperation to combat terrorism effectively.

site_title: US dollar holds steady vs euro; yen climbs
summary: The US dollar held steady against the euro, while the yen rose 0.8% against the greenback and euro, following a speech by James Bullard, president of the St Louis Fed, who hinted at a June US rate hike. The Fed's hawkish signals have led to a 30% chance of a rate hike at the June FOMC meeting, according to market expectations. The yen also rose due to weak Japanese trade data and the Group of Seven's warning against currency intervention.

site_title: Deutsche Bank credit rating cut by Moody's on overhaul struggle
summary: Deutsche Bank's credit rating was cut by Moody's Investors Service to Baa2 from Baa1, with its long-term deposit rating falling to A3. The downgrade reflects the bank's struggle to carry out its turnaround. Despite this, Deutsche Bank's senior unsecured debt rating remains investment grade, and its long-term deposit rating is still in 'A' territory, according to the bank's chief financial officer. The rating cut does not affect the bank's ability to meet its obligations.

site_title: Angelina Jolie named visiting professor of London university
summary: Angelina Jolie has been named a visiting professor at London School of Economics, contributing to a master's program on "women, peace and security". She joins William Hague, Jane Connors, and Madeleine Rees as a "visiting professor in practice". Jolie, a UN refugee agency envoy, hopes to broaden discussion on advancing women's rights and ending impunity for crimes affecting women, particularly in conflict. The program aims to promote gender equality and help women affected by conflict worldwide, with students able to apply for the course starting in August.

site_title: EU finance services chief says Britain faces barriers if it quits EU
summary: EU finance services chief Jonathan Hill warns that Britain would face trade barriers if it leaves the European Union and its single market, potentially harming the City of London financial district. As Britain's biggest export earner, financial services are a significant contributor to the economy. Hill's comments come as the UK prepares for a June 23 referendum on EU membership.

site_title: NTU, Italian aerospace firm in S$4.2m research collaboration
summary: Nanyang Technological University (NTU) in Singapore has partnered with Italian aerospace firm Leonardo-Finmeccanica in a S$4.2 million research collaboration to develop lighter, stronger helicopters and improve flight performance. The five-year programme will focus on innovative composite materials and aerodynamics research modelling. NTU scientists will work with Leonardo-Finmeccanica engineers to research and develop new manufacturing and materials technologies for next-generation helicopters and aircraft.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: MH370 kin concerned search for jet about to end, seek extension
summary: The search for missing Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370, which vanished in 2014, is set to end by early August, prompting concern from next-of-kin who are calling for the search to be extended. The Australian-led search, which has cost up to $130 million, has found only five pieces of debris from the jet, with many suspecting a cover-up. Voice370, an international network of MH370 next-of-kin, is appealing for a concerted effort to find more debris and piece together what happened, citing the mystery as one of the greatest in aviation history.

site_title: DBS ties up with SGX to digitalise trading account application
summary: DBS Bank has partnered with the Singapore Exchange (SGX) to launch a digital application process for customers to set up trading accounts and link them to their Central Depository Account (CDP) accounts. This initiative allows customers to apply online, reducing the time required to start trading from 10 days to just 4 days. The move is aimed at increasing convenience and efficiency for retail investors.

site_title: IS blasts in Syria regime heartland kill more than 148
summary: IS blasts in Syria's regime heartland killed over 148 people in northwestern Syria, in the deadliest attacks yet in the regime's coastal heartland. The bombings targeted bus stations, hospitals, and civilian sites in Jableh and Tartus, with at least eight children among the victims. IS claimed the attacks, saying its fighters targeted "Alawite gatherings" in the minority sect from which President Bashar al-Assad hails. The attacks come as IS faces mounting pressure in Syria and Iraq, and as world powers struggle to rekindle UN-brokered peace negotiations.

images.alt_text: More than 148 people were killed Monday in bombings claimed by the Islamic State group in northwestern Syria, the deadliest attacks yet in the regime's coastal heartland.

site_title: Corruption scandal throws Brazil's interim government into disarray
summary: Brazil's interim government, led by Michel Temer, faces a major crisis after acting planning minister Romero Juca stepped aside following a leaked recording of a conversation discussing using impeachment to derail a corruption probe. The recording, released by the Folha newspaper, appears to show Juca discussing a "national pact" to stop the probe, Operation Car Wash, and calls for a change in government to stop the "bleeding" of Brazil's economy. Juca's departure threatens Temer's authority and legitimacy, with opposition leaders claiming the impeachment process is a coup in disguise.

site_title: CAAS upgrades training for airport & aircraft emergencies
summary: CAAS has upgraded its Airport Foam Tender Driving Simulator (AFTDS) at the Singapore Aviation Academy (SAA) to enhance airport emergency training. The next-generation simulator features more realistic scenarios, increased training capacity, and updated Changi Airport layout. The upgrades will benefit airport emergency personnel training programmes, including the Airport Fire Officers and Senior Airport Fire Officers courses, which have trained over 1,600 participants. The simulator aims to improve response preparedness and safety at Changi Airport, aligning with the authority's commitment to maintaining high safety standards.

site_title: Peru declares mercury poison emergency due to gold mining
summary: Peru has declared an environmental emergency in 11 Amazon jungle districts due to mercury pollution from unregulated gold mining. High levels of mercury were found in river water, fish, and local populations, posing serious health risks. The government has sent medical aid and non-contaminated food supplies to the region and advised people not to eat contaminated catfish. Environment Minister Manuel Pulgar-Vidal has vowed to shut down illegal mining operations to address the problem, warning that the consequences of inaction will last for 80 years.

site_title: Asian Americans' votes could make a difference
summary: Donald Trump's presidential campaign has been driven by "Angry White Men" who feel threatened by demographic changes, but his bigotry and xenophobic rhetoric have alienated Asian American voters. Despite being a minority group that has traditionally voted Republican, Asian Americans have gravitated towards the Democratic Party in recent elections. Young and educated Asian Americans are particularly offended by Trump's comments on trade policies and his mocking of Asian languages. Trump's campaign has failed to project an inclusive approach towards Asian Americans, and his supporters admit that he is not sensitive to their concerns.

site_title: On display in Versailles: Napoleon's glorious car collection
summary: A museum in Versailles, La Gallerie Des Carrosses, has reopened with a collection of 12 carriages used by Napoleon and his family in the 18th and 19th centuries. The carriages, featuring gilded interiors, monogrammed wood carvings, and eight-stallion horsepower, are on display for free after a nine-year restoration. The collection includes six compact sedan chairs, a coronation coach commissioned by Louis XVIII, and a funerary coach for Louis XVIII, showcasing life during the pre-revolutionary Ancien Regime. The exhibition highlights the opulence and extravagance of the French aristocracy.

site_title: Petrol shortage as French labour reform protesters block refineries
summary: Protesters in France blockaded oil refineries and fuel depots in response to government labour reform, causing petrol shortages and tailbacks in parts of the country. The CGT union, which is leading the strikes, claims the law will erode job security and do little to address unemployment. The government insists the reform will make the labour market more flexible and create jobs. The situation has worsened since Sunday, with 1,500 petrol stations running dry, and authorities have imposed rationing in some areas. Strikes and demonstrations are planned to continue, with the CGT threatening to escalate the action.

images.alt_text: Petrol shortages caused long tailbacks of motorists in parts of France on Monday as protesters angry over government labour reforms blockaded some of the country's oil refineries and fuel depots.

site_title: Eurozone business growth slows, but not in Germany, France
summary: Eurozone business growth slowed to a 16-month low in May, reaching 52.9, according to Markit's Composite Purchasing Managers' Index. However, Germany and France showed stronger growth, suggesting smaller member countries may be struggling. This marks a reversal from the strong acceleration in growth seen in the first three months of the year.

site_title: Novartis executive exodus complicates drugmaker's rebuilding job
summary: Novartis is facing a leadership crisis with seven top executives departing in five months, including the head of pharmaceuticals David Epstein. The exits come as CEO Joe Jimenez tries to address a 25% decline in the company's share price since July. Analysts say the departures reflect ongoing management instability and ongoing challenges, including a struggling product pipeline and the expiry of a key patent. The company's share price has fallen sharply compared to its peers, making it a challenge for Jimenez to revive Novartis's fortunes.

images.alt_text: With seven departures in the space of five months, Novartis's top management is in upheaval just as CEO Joe Jimenez tries to tackle a list of challenges that have seen the drug firm's share price fall 25 per cent since July.

site_title: Toyota recalls 1.6m US vehicles for Takata air bags
summary: Toyota recalls 1.6 million US vehicles due to faulty Takata air bag inflators, which have been linked to over 100 injuries and 13 deaths worldwide. The recall includes Corolla, Matrix, Yaris, 4Runner, and Lexus models built between 2006 and 2011. This is the largest recall in US auto safety history, with Toyota now recalling 4.73 million vehicles in the US for Takata air bags. 17 automakers, including Toyota, are recalling Takata vehicles in a series of reports due to the inflators' potential to rupture and send shrapnel into vehicles.

site_title: Brexit supporters bite back over EU rules on bananas
summary: Brexit campaigners claim the EU imposes unnecessary rules on everyday items like bananas, vacuum cleaners, kettles, and toasters. The EU's regulation on bananas sets standards for shape and quality, while vacuum cleaners face an energy consumption limit of 900 watts. The claims are disputed, with the European Commission stating no new rules are planned for kettles, toasters, or vacuum cleaners. The EU has clarified that children under eight are not banned from blowing balloons, only recommended to be supervised.

site_title: Samsung breaks with past to halt smartphone dip
summary: Samsung Electronics has undergone a painful overhaul to reverse its slide in the smartphone business, shifting from a "phone-for-all-needs" approach to one that emphasizes economies of scale. The company has streamlined its product line-up, phased out unpopular models, and focused on high-end features like OLED screens. This strategy has led to a stabilization of the handset business, with Samsung reporting its best profit in nearly two years in January-March. However, the company still faces challenges, including stagnant smartphone industry growth and a need to innovate to drive revenue growth.

site_title: Chinese firms using crowdfunding sites to crack US market
summary: Chinese tech companies are using crowdfunding sites to raise funds for US market expansion. XGimi Technology, a Chinese manufacturer of miniature projectors, raised over $300,000 on IndieGoGo for a new LED projector, receiving positive coverage from tech blogs. This trend is part of Chinese firms' increasing use of crowdfunding to access US capital, marking a shift in their market entry strategies.

site_title: Panda bond market finally looks set to move past its publicity phase
summary: Global Logistic Properties (GLP) is planning to issue panda bonds on the Shanghai Stock Exchange, marking a significant milestone for the panda bond market. The Singapore-listed company, which has large business operations in China, aims to strengthen its market position and use the yuan to support its mainland business. The 1.5 billion yuan offering is expected to be the first foreign issuer to launch panda bonds in both the stock exchange and interbank markets, demonstrating GLP's resolve in the face of stringent issuance thresholds.

site_title: Amsterdam stakes claim as springboard for startups
summary: Amsterdam is positioning itself as a key startup hub, with entrepreneurs like David Vermeulen opting to establish their businesses in the city due to its relatively low costs and accessible international market. Vermeulen, founder of the matchmaking website InnerCircle, chose Amsterdam for its "ideal market for testing" and potential for international expansion. The city's startup ecosystem is gaining traction, with various initiatives and hubs emerging to support innovation and entrepreneurship. Amsterdam's appeal as a startup springboard is expected to continue, with the city's unique blend of affordability and accessibility making it an attractive location for startups.

site_title: Remembering what went right & why on Bill's watch
summary: Bill Clinton's presidency, which ended in 2001, was marked by impressive economic growth, with a boom that surpassed the Reagan era in every dimension. The Clinton economy created more jobs, grew faster, and saw a significant rise in real wages for ordinary workers. The boom was fueled by the widespread adoption of technology in the 1990s, which led to a surge in productivity and business investment. Clinton's policies, including raising taxes on the wealthy, did not hinder prosperity. The Clinton-era boom offers lessons for a potential Clinton II administration, including the effectiveness of tax policies and the importance of full employment in raising wages.

site_title: Malaysia to build aviation hub to complement Changi
summary: Malaysia plans to transform 100 square kilometers of land around its Kuala Lumpur International Airport into an aviation hub called KLIA Aeropolis, which aims to attract air cargo, logistics, and aerospace services. The project is expected to contribute RM30 billion to Malaysia's economic growth and create 56,000 jobs over 15 years. The hub will complement Singapore's Changi airport, with officials stating they are not competing with it, but rather capturing the spillover effect from growing air travel demand in Asia.

site_title: Opec set for another meeting with no accord
summary: Opec is set to hold a meeting on June 2 without reaching an agreement on oil supply, sticking to Saudi Arabia's strategy of pumping near-record volumes to squeeze out rivals. The strategy appears to be working, with oil prices rebounding 80% to nearly $50 a barrel. Analysts say the Saudi approach is finally paying off, and Opec's current policy calls into question the organization's basic purpose. The group's ministerial meeting in December ended without an agreement on an output ceiling, and experts question whether Opec is "dead or just in a coma."

site_title: Markets react badly to Japan's failure to secure its aims at G-7 meeting
summary: Japan's failure to secure its goals at the G-7 meeting has led to a negative market reaction, with Tokyo share prices dropping and the yen gaining. Manufacturing activity in May fell at its fastest rate in over 3 years, and exports dropped 10% in April, marking a seventh consecutive monthly decline. The data could bolster Japan's case that the country's economy is being particularly hard hit, with Prime Minister Shinzo Abe set to press his case at the G-7 summit later this week.

site_title: Underestimating the problems of renegotiating trade arrangements post-Brexit
summary: Economist Gerard Lyons, who advised Boris Johnson during the Brexit campaign, has published a book presenting a pro-Brexit view of the UK's EU membership. Lyons argues that the UK can easily rejoin the EU if it leaves, but critics point out this is unlikely and ignores the economic disruption Brexit would cause. Lyons' book is seen as not providing a balanced account, and experts argue that his views underestimate the economic importance of EU membership for multinational corporations. Lyons' pro-Brexit stance is criticized for being based on a lack of leadership and a failure to consider the long-term consequences of the UK's decision.

site_title: Indonesia says tax amnesty will boost revenue by US$12b
summary: Indonesia's finance minister, Bambang Brodjonegoro, estimated that a tax amnesty programme will boost tax revenue by US$12.12 billion, exceeding the central bank's and analysts' estimates of US$41 billion and US$9.1 trillion rupiah, respectively. The programme aims to encourage taxpayers to declare untaxed assets at home and abroad, broadening the country's tax base. With 6,500 undeclared offshore assets totaling over US$800 billion, the government hopes to improve tax compliance and fairness in the country.

site_title: US rate, Brexit issues keep market on edge
summary: The Singapore Stock Exchange (STI) edged up 3.11 points on Monday, reaching 2,766.93, despite concerns over a potential US rate hike and the Brexit referendum. The STI is still down 2.5% from the end of April and 4% so far this year, due to worries over interest rates, China's economy, and a slump in crude oil. Analysts expect the STI to remain within the 2,700-2,835 range, citing the potential for a brief pullback in the USD/SGD exchange rate.

site_title: SATS Q4 profit dips to S$50.7m
summary: SATS Ltd reported a 1.7% year-on-year dip in Q4 net profit to S$50.7 million, driven by a 7.4% decline in food solutions revenue. Revenue from its food distribution business was transferred to a joint venture, and the weaker Japanese yen also contributed to the decline. However, the group's overall revenue would have improved 6.6% excluding the transfer. Operating profit rose 11.2% to S$49.7 million. SATS proposed a final dividend of 10 cents per share, and announced Euleen Goh as its new chairman, replacing Edmund Cheng.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: CME in talks with warehouse firms to boost metal storage network
summary: The CME Group is in talks with warehouse firms to expand its metal storage network globally, aiming to challenge the London Metal Exchange's (LME) dominance. The move follows controversy surrounding the LME warehouse system, with the CME seeking to increase its locations in Asia, the US, and Europe. The CME has a network of 24 approved warehouses, while the LME has over 600. The CME's expansion is seen as a bold move to poach business from the LME, with some new contracts aimed at taking on the LME's lead and zinc contracts.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: ComfortDelGro Corp's Q1 results came within expectations, with a focus on regulatory changes in the land transport sector. The company is expected to benefit from the new bus government contracting model, while the taxi industry's regulatory changes may lead to further loosening of strict taxi standards. NeraTel is selling its payment solutions business for S$88 million, lifting its "trading buy" rating. UOL Group has entered into a sale and purchase agreement to acquire a London office building for S$197.2 million.

site_title: Rare Burgundy collection fetches 4.2m francs
summary: A rare collection of 1,407 bottles from Domaine de la Romanee-Conti's Burgundy estate sold for 4.2 million Swiss francs at a Geneva auction house, beating expectations. The collection, stored for 15 years, includes 7 grand crus produced between 1952 and 2011. The top lots included a 1999 Romanee-Conti jeroboam sold for 60,000 Swiss francs. The sale showcases the rarity and value of Domaine de la Romanee-Conti's wines, with only 200 bottles expected to be made this year and over 100,000 people on a waiting list.

site_title: Dollar falls versus yen on Japan trade data, weaker Nikkei
summary: The Japanese yen rose 0.8% against the dollar and euro, boosted by robust trade data and a G-7 disagreement on currencies. The dollar index remained steady, and analysts expect US data to support tightening expectations, potentially leading to a rate hike. The Nikkei fell over 1%, adding to the yen's gains, and investors remain selective in their long dollar positions, with some selling the dollar against the yen on rallies.

site_title: Obama lifts 50-year ban on weapon sales to Vietnam
summary: US President Barack Obama announced the lifting of a 50-year ban on weapon sales to Vietnam, ending a decades-old embargo. The move aims to strengthen ties between the two countries, driven by trade and shared security concerns over China's expansion in the South China Sea. Vietnam's military will now be able to acquire advanced surveillance technology, including drones and radar systems, from the US. The decision is expected to infuriate Beijing, but will also provide Vietnam with leverage in future arms deals. The move marks a significant shift in US-Vietnam relations, which have improved significantly since the end of the Vietnam War in 1975.

site_title: Banks turn to digital ledger amid fraud in US$4t trade finance
summary: Banks are exploring distributed-ledger technology, similar to bitcoin's blockchain, to combat fraud in the US$4 trillion trade-financing industry. Standard Chartered and DBS Group Holdings have teamed up to develop an electronic ledger of invoices, and other lenders like Bank of America and HSBC are also investigating blockchain applications. The technology could help reduce costs and eliminate paper invoices, but banks must agree on common standards and platforms to make it work. The International Chamber of Commerce reports that 20% of banks have seen an increase in fraud allegations, with estimated losses of hundreds of millions of dollars in past cases.

site_title: Big data for small businesses
summary: Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) can start leveraging big data and analytics by taking "baby steps" towards harnessing its potential. Despite the huge opportunities, many SMEs are hesitant due to lack of skills, high costs, and reluctance to change. However, with advancements in technology and decreasing costs, SMEs can now access the necessary tools and infrastructure to tap into big data. By focusing on critical business data sets and creating interdisciplinary teams, SMEs can start to reap the benefits of big data and analytics, becoming more competitive and efficient in the process.

images.alt_text: We are seeing an explosion of the digital universe. It is impossible to comprehend just how much data is produced each day - and just how little of it is really being put to use. This creates a vast blue ocean of opportunities for enterprises to tap into and elevate their current hold in their respective marketplaces.

site_title: Shun Tak acquires its first hotel site in S'pore
summary: HONG KONG-LISTED Shun Tak Holdings has acquired a prime freehold site in Singapore for S$145 million. The site, located at 9 Cuscaden Road, has a land area of 25,741 sq ft and is zoned "hotel" in the 2014 Master Plan. The sale price reflects a land rate of about S$2,145 psf per plot ratio. Shun Tak's core businesses are in property, transportation, hospitality, and investment sectors, and it is likely to build a hotel on the site.

site_title: Singapore to call a projected S$2.82b of infocomm technology tenders
summary: Singapore has announced a projected S$2.82 billion in infocomm technology (ICT) tenders for fiscal 2016, focusing on infrastructure and ICT security bulk contracts. The majority of funds will be spent on infrastructure projects, with a focus on enhancing ICT infrastructure to support the government's Smart Nation initiative. The government aims to modernize data centers, expand WiFi connectivity in schools, and improve cybersecurity, particularly in Internet of Things (IoT) related security. The IDA has also launched an Accreditation@IDA scheme to support local technology companies, particularly SMEs, in competing for government tenders.

site_title: G-7 meeting will also have significant geopolitical dialogue
summary: The G-7 summit, hosted by Japan, will focus on both economic and geopolitical issues. The summit comes amid heightened concerns over the global economy and significant downside risks, including the UK's EU referendum. Key topics include North Korea's nuclear tests, maritime security in the South China Sea, and the Middle East, particularly in Syria, Libya, and Iran. The G-7 is expected to discuss potential sanctions against North Korea, strengthen trilateral information sharing, and deploy a US missile defense system. The summit also highlights the G-7's importance as an international security linchpin, despite criticism of its actions in this area.

site_title: Economists eye growth, labour data to track MAS's next move
summary: Singapore's central bank, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), is expected to closely monitor growth and labour market data to inform its next policy move. Despite better-than-expected inflation data in April, MAS has not revised its inflation forecast, suggesting that the central bank may have already factored in the improvements. Economists expect sequential growth and jobs data to be more important in the October policy decision, potentially ruling out another easing of monetary policy.

site_title: China's 'Fedex' takes backdoor route to 43.3b yuan Shenzhen listing
summary: China's SF Holdings, a major courier company, has agreed to a 43.3 billion yuan deal with metals company Maanshan Dingtai Rare Earth & New Materials Ltd, allowing SF to list on the Shenzhen stock market through an asset swap and new share accord. The deal, subject to regulatory approvals, will give SF control over the new business, with founder and chairman Wang Wei at the helm. This is SF's largest backdoor listing, following similar moves by smaller peers and comes as Chinese regulators tighten scrutiny of such deals.

site_title: Biotech firm, Swiss partner to offer healthier white bread
summary: Biotech firm Holista Colltech Ltd has partnered with Swiss supplier Veripan AG to develop low glycemic index (GI) white bread, Panatura GI. The new bread has a GI reading of 53, the lowest achieved in clean-label white bread, and aims to reduce the risk of diabetes. The companies plan to produce the bread in Singapore, which they see as a hub for research and development, and may expand to other low GI foods such as noodles and rice.

site_title: Get ready for the wine world's richest, glitziest weekend
summary: Auction Napa Valley, a three-day charity event, is set to take place in June with over 318 auction lots, featuring exclusive wine experiences, unique items, and high-end bidding opportunities. The event aims to meet expectations set by last year's $15.8 million haul, with this year's goal exceeding $16 million. The auction will include rare wine collections, exclusive dinners with winemakers, and unique experiences, with minimum bids ranging from $10,000 to $800,000. The event supports Napa County charities and has donated over $145 million since its inception.

site_title: Manhunt mounted after millions stolen in Japan heist
summary: A coordinated heist involving an international gang of 100 people has stolen 1.4 billion yen (S$17.6 million) from 1,400 convenience store ATMs in Japan. Armed with fake credit card details from South Africa's Standard Bank, the thieves made a series of withdrawals in under three hours, evading the usual daily withdrawal limit of 100,000 yen. Japanese police are analyzing footage of ATM security cameras and working with South African authorities, with no suspects in custody. The heist is believed to be one of the largest in Japan's history.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: KOP Limited reported a narrowed net loss of S$1.8 million in the fourth quarter, up from S$21.1 million a year ago, due to revenue surging 84% to S$6.7 million. Memstar Technology is in talks to recover a US$5 million deposit from a failed reverse takeover. OSIM International suspended trading after its founder and CEO raised his stake to 96.03%. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed, while Creative Technology warned of potential revenue shortfall.

site_title: Ryanair sees slower profit growth as airfares fall
summary: Ryanair forecasts slower profit growth this year due to lower airfares, with net profit expected to rise 13% in the year through March. The airline's ticket prices are expected to fall 7% in fiscal 2017, with further declines in the second half of the year. Fuel savings will contribute to reduced costs, but the impact on passenger prices is uncertain. Ryanair's earnings growth will slow due to the recent terror attacks and air-traffic control strikes, prompting airlines to cut ticket prices.

site_title: New payment options for Chinese, Japanese visitors to Singapore
summary: Singapore has expanded payment options for Chinese and Japanese visitors with two new partnerships. The Japanese credit card firm JCB has partnered with Nets to give JCB cardholders access to 91,000 Nets acceptance points, while Resorts World Sentosa has partnered with Alipay, the world's largest third-party payment platform, to offer Chinese tourists a "smart tourism" experience. These partnerships aim to increase market share and enhance visitor experiences, with joint travel packages and promotions to be rolled out for Alipay users.

site_title: Concord Energy to build second oil terminal in Fujairah
summary: Concord Energy, a Singapore-based energy trader, plans to build a second oil terminal in Fujairah, UAE, with a capacity of 1.1 million cubic meters. The terminal, expected to be commissioned in mid-2018, will be a joint venture with a national oil company and will be built adjacent to the existing Fujairah Oil Terminal. The new terminal will cater to the growing demand for gasoline storage in Fujairah, which is expected to be boosted by the lifting of sanctions in Iran, allowing for increased gasoline blending operations.

site_title: Innovation is a shared responsibility
summary: Singapore's 2016 budget emphasizes innovation and growth beyond its shores, urging businesses to innovate and upskill their workforce to drive the economy forward. Despite challenges, the government has introduced programs and funds to mitigate risks, such as the Capability Development Grant and Global Company Partnership. The budget highlights the potential of expanding into Southeast Asia, with its large and growing domestic markets, and low setup and labor costs. To succeed, businesses must take calculated risks, learn from failures, and involve all levels of the organization in the innovation and internationalization journey.

site_title: UK would lose at least 500,000 jobs after Brexit vote: Osborne
summary: Britain would lose at least 500,000 jobs within two years of a vote to leave the European Union, according to finance minister George Osborne. A "Brexit" vote would also push up inflation sharply, with workers' earnings adjusted for inflation expected to be almost 3% lower, equivalent to a pay cut of almost £800 per year.

site_title: Britain's Ken Loach wins Cannes gold with moving austerity tale
summary: British director Ken Loach won the Palme d'Or at Cannes for his drama "I, Daniel Blake," a moving tale about poverty in austerity-hit Europe. This marked Loach's second Palme d'Or win in a decade, beating out favorites like Maren Ade's "Toni Erdmann" and Jim Jarmusch's "Paterson." The award highlights Loach's continued ability to shed light on social issues, particularly those affecting the downtrodden.

site_title: NUS rises to No 12 in FT customised executive education ranking
summary: The National University of Singapore (NUS) Business School has risen four spots to 12th in the Financial Times' 2016 ranking of customised executive education programs. The ranking is based on data from companies and business schools. This move reflects NUS' growing reputation in providing high-quality executive education programs.

site_title: Marketing key to SMEs going regional
summary: Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) can capitalize on the growing opportunities in the Asia-Pacific region by adopting a marketing communication strategy that stands out in foreign markets. Governments in the region are providing infrastructure to encourage SMEs to venture abroad, but they only account for 30% of exports. Understanding the local market, including its culture and communication modalities, is essential for SMEs to succeed. For example, in the Philippines, celebrity endorsements are crucial, while in Indonesia, digital and online advertising are key. In Malaysia, out-of-home advertising is preferred. A clear marketing strategy involves identifying the target audience, understanding their needs, and creating a product or service that meets those needs.

site_title: Virtual reality can be economies' way out of productivity slump: Deutsche Bank
summary: Deutsche Bank suggests that virtual reality, along with robotics, Internet of Things, cloud computing, and big data, could be a way to boost productivity and lift economies out of a slump. The technology has the potential to automate factory processes and address labor shortages, particularly in industries with aging workforces. Several countries, including Japan, South Korea, and the US, are already deploying these technologies with positive results. However, the success of these innovations depends on legislation and management of labor-saving devices, with countries like Singapore and Taiwan offering lessons for others.

site_title: EU extends grace period to Thailand to stop illegal fishing
summary: The European Union has extended a six-month grace period for Thailand to address illegal fishing practices, giving the country another chance to meet EU standards. Thailand was initially warned with a "yellow card" in 2015, but has since introduced new licensing and monitoring systems, tightened regulations, and increased checks on vessels to prevent labor abuses and human trafficking. The EU has declined to comment on the extension, citing confidentiality. This reprieve is seen as a positive step for Thailand's seafood industry, which employs over 300,000 people.

site_title: 1MDB bonds backed by Abu Dhabi fund gain 1.9%
summary: Malaysia's 1Malaysia Development Bhd bonds backed by Abu Dhabi's International Petroleum Investment Co (IPIC) have rallied 1.9% in May, contrasting with notes supported by the Malaysian government, which slumped 6.4%. The divergence reflects investor concerns about the Malaysian government's backing amid an economy forecast to expand at the slowest pace in seven years. The fund has defaulted on interest payments and faces cross-defaults on several debt obligations.

site_title: China's cash-strapped local governments looking to boost funds
summary: China's local governments face fiscal challenges due to a tax overhaul and revenue shortfalls. Proposals include redistributing sales-tax revenue, allowing provinces to apply new levies on housing, and turning over pension commitments to Beijing. The Ministry of Finance is overhauling the tax system. Local economies, particularly in the north-east rust-belt provinces, rely on land sales, which may worsen long-term housing problems. Despite initial uncertainty, regional and local governments' fiscal and economic positions are expected to improve as the real estate market and macro economy stabilize.

site_title: Uber deal shows divide in labour's drive for role in 'gig economy'
summary: The International Association of Machinists and Aerospace Workers has reached an agreement to represent New York Uber drivers, but the deal falls short of actual union representation. This has revealed divisions among labour advocates on how to address the gig economy's classification of workers as independent contractors. The move shows a divide within the US labour movement on how to address the issue, with some advocating for greater union involvement in the industry.

site_title: CCT to buy partners' stake in CapitaGreen
summary: Capitaland Commercial Trust (CCT) proposes to buy the remaining 60% stake in Grade-A office building CapitaGreen for approximately S$393 million, valuing the entire building at S$1.6 billion or S$2,276 per square foot. The acquisition is constrained by terms of a call option, despite falling office prices. Analysts question the timing, but the manager attributes it to the terms of the call option.

images.alt_text: CCT's manager said it did not want to risk broader market uncertainties by delaying the acquisition. And waiting until the building yields higher may further raise the valuation of the property and the acquisition cost.

site_title: Don't fret over Brexit; UK is better on its own
summary: The UK's decision to potentially leave the EU, or "Brexit," will not significantly impact its trade or economy, according to Gerry Ball. Despite EU concerns, major investments such as Mapletree's £500 million investment in the UK and ICBC's purchase of a London gold vault indicate London's continued importance in global trade. Ball cites Singapore's successful experience of breaking away from larger trading blocs and thriving on its own, suggesting that the UK can do the same, potentially even better, if it establishes a stable political and economic environment.

site_title: Hong Leong seen awarding more hotel contracts here to Marriott
summary: The Hong Leong Group, a member of City Developments Ltd, is reportedly awarding hotel management contracts to Marriott International for two new properties in Singapore: a 200-room Edition hotel on Cuscaden Road and potentially the 360-room Studio M Hotel on Mohamed Sultan Road, which could be rebranded as Aloft. This would mark the introduction of new hotel brands to Singapore and give the Hong Leong Group leverage to negotiate for more favorable fees from Marriott.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Periodic regulatory updates needed for TWC stocks
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has strengthened corporate governance by providing more targeted information in its Trade with Caution (TWC) notices and setting up independent committees. However, critics argue that improvements in other areas are needed to address concerns about the exchange's dual role. Shareholders of companies with suspended shares, such as LionGold and Asiasons, are still waiting for updates on the regulatory front, which is essential for informed investment decisions. The SGX should provide periodic updates on the status of these stocks, particularly if investigations are ongoing.

site_title: Cuts in oil supply renew bets on price rally
summary: Oil prices are on the rise due to supply disruptions in Nigeria, Libya, and Canada. Nigerian crude output has plummeted to a 27-year low, while Libyan exports have halted due to competing administrations. In Canada, wildfires have threatened oil-sand mines, leading to a production deficit earlier than expected. Speculators' net-long position in US crude has climbed by the most contracts since March, indicating a potential price rally. WTI futures are heading for a fourth-straight monthly gain, the longest rally in five years.

images.alt_text: The Canadian wildfire doubled to an area more than five times bigger than New York City in about a week, threatening oil-sand mines.

site_title: Brexit shock will cause severe unemployment, recession: UK Treasury
summary: The UK Treasury has predicted that a Brexit vote would lead to severe economic consequences, including a recession, unemployment rising by at least 500,000, and GDP shrinking by 3.6%. The forecast assumes a bilateral trade agreement with the EU and predicts inflation would increase by over two percentage points, with sterling falling by 12% and house prices decreasing by 10%. A more severe scenario, driven by increased uncertainty and volatility, could lead to an even deeper recession and unemployment rising by 800,000.

site_title: Fed's Bullard: rates too low for too long could be risky
summary: US Federal Reserve President James Bullard expressed concerns that keeping interest rates too low for too long could lead to financial instability. He noted a relatively tight labor market and potential upward pressure on inflation, supporting the idea of a rate hike. Market expectations for a rate rise have increased, with a June or July hike now considered "probably good" by Bullard. The Fed is considering a data-dependent "slow normalization" of rates, with a gradual increase over several years if the economy evolves as expected.

site_title: Middle East franchisee for Jones the Grocer buys global rights for brand
summary: Jones the Grocer's global rights have been bought by JTG Holdings, the Middle East master franchisee, for an undisclosed amount. L Capital Asia, a private equity firm backed by LVMH, has taken a minority stake in JTG Holdings and a master franchise right in various North Asian and South-east Asian markets. CEO Yunib Siddiqui stated that JTG Holdings remains committed to supporting existing and new franchisees, with the new development expected to bring better focus and new global opportunities.

images.alt_text: Ravi Thakran says the new owners of the brand will do full justice to exploiting its true potential.

site_title: Slow response to past crashes could hinder EgyptAir search, experts say
summary: A three-year search for the black box of EgyptAir Flight 804, which crashed with 66 people on board, is facing technical constraints due to a slow regulatory response to earlier disasters. The search teams have 30 days to locate the flight recorders before the batteries die, but the life of the underwater beacons has been trebled to 90 days only in 2018, too late to aid in the search. Experts blame the delay on bureaucracy, lack of resources, and a tussle between regulators, airlines, and manufacturers over safety spending.

site_title: Oil falls as Iran firm on export rise, US rigs decline slower
summary: Oil prices fell for a fourth consecutive session, with Brent crude down 44 cents at $48.28 a barrel, as investor focus shifted to global supply. Iran insisted on a rise in oil exports, while US drillers slowed the reduction in rigs. Global supply concerns outweighed concerns about unplanned oil outages, and analysts forecast lower prices due to shale productivity gains and increased production.

site_title: BP set to sanction Tangguh Train 3 project; subcontracts expected soon
summary: BP is set to sanction its $12 billion Tangguh Train 3 project in Indonesia's West Papua province by mid-year, with bids for two key contracts expected soon. Italian oilfield services provider Saipem is reportedly the single largest winner in the project tenders, with a bid for the onshore engineering, procurement, and construction contract. Saipem's consortium is also in line to secure a second EPCIC contract for offshore platforms. The project is expected to stimulate demand for offshore support and supply vessels in Indonesia, with BP targeting to fix a five-year offshore drilling contract in December 2016.

site_title: AXA becomes first major insurer to cut tobacco ties
summary: AXA, a global insurer, has become the first major insurer to cut ties with the tobacco industry, selling 1.8 billion euros worth of investments in the sector. The decision, made as a "responsible health insurer and investor," aims to support efforts to curb smoking-related deaths, estimated to kill one billion people worldwide in the 21st century. This move follows AXA's previous divestment from the coal sector and its commitment to tripling environmentally friendly investments by 2020.

site_title: Eu Yan Sang seeks early redemption of bonds
summary: Eu Yan Sang, a traditional Chinese medicine group, is seeking approval from debt holders to amend the conditions of its outstanding 4.5% notes due this year. The company aims to include the option to redeem all remaining notes (S$23.6 million) with at least five business days' notice, at 100.5% of principal. This move is part of Eu Yan Sang's efforts to address its existing debt, as the group is currently the subject of a privatization bid.

site_title: US: Wall St opens flat as focus turns to Fed speakers
summary: US stocks opened flat on Monday as investors awaited Federal Reserve speeches for clues on the timing of the next interest rate increase. Fed speakers, including Chair Janet Yellen, will provide clarity on the pace of rate hikes. San Francisco Fed President John Williams suggested two-to-three rate hikes this year, while St Louis Federal Reserve President James Bullard noted a tight labor market may put upward pressure on inflation. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.1%, while the Nasdaq Composite rose 0.17%.

site_title: Oil discoveries sink to lowest since 1952: Morgan Stanley
summary: Oil discoveries in 2015 fell to their lowest since 1952, reaching 2.8 billion barrels globally, according to Morgan Stanley. This decline, combined with reduced exploration budgets, creates a gap for meeting future demand. Despite a decrease in exploration spending, analysts warn that the industry will need ongoing investment to build capacity over the next 25 years, potentially exceeding current spending levels.

site_title: VietJet orders 100 Boeing 737 MAX planes
summary: VietJet, a South-east Asia low-cost carrier, has ordered 100 Boeing 737 MAX 200 jets worth $11.3 billion at list prices, making it one of the region's fastest-growing airlines. The deal, signed during US President Barack Obama's visit to Vietnam in 2016, marks a significant order for Boeing. This order represents a coup for Boeing, as VietJet previously operated Airbus A320 planes. The agreement signifies VietJet's commitment to expanding its fleet and further establishing itself as a major player in the South-east Asian aviation market.

site_title: LendingClub climbs after Singapore investors increase holdings
summary: LendingClub shares rose 6.8% after a Singapore-based investor, Tianqiao Chen's group, disclosed a stake of up to 11.7% in the marketplace lender. The group paid $148.7 million for shares and options, potentially making them the largest shareholder. Following the surprise resignation of CEO Renaud Laplanche, LendingClub has seen significant losses for the year. The company's stock price has pared losses, bringing the year's decline to 61%. LendingClub has expressed interest in continuing dialogue with the Shanda group, which may engage in a review of the company's business and operations.

site_title: KOP Limited narrows loss in Q4
summary: KOP Limited reported a narrower loss of S$1.8 million in Q4, compared to a loss of S$21.1 million a year ago. Revenue surged 84% to S$6.7 million, driven by the handover of completed properties and assignment of distribution rights. Administrative expenses decreased 67% to S$7.9 million, contributing to the improved financial performance. For the full year, KOP's net profit plummeted to S$346,000, with revenue rising 32% to S$24.5 million. The company will focus on existing businesses and expand cautiously in uncertain economic conditions.

site_title: Eurozone consumer confidence rises for second month in May
summary: Eurozone consumer confidence rose for the second consecutive month in May, reaching its highest level since January, according to a European Commission flash estimate. The consumer morale increased to -7.0 points from -9.3 in April, beating the average forecast of -9.0. Meanwhile, consumer sentiment in the European Union as a whole rose by 1.1 points to -5.7.

site_title: Bail-in level for eurozone banks to be set case-by-case: EU Commission
summary: The European Commission has adopted a regulation clarifying that there will be no harmonized minimum level of banks' assets that can be wiped out by regulators when a lender is wound down. This move slightly softens requirements for banks, relieving them from the possibility of having to hold at least 8% of their liabilities and own funds. The new EU rules, operational since this year, require banks to hold assets that can be wiped out in case of a banking rescue.

images.alt_text: The European Commission adopted on Monday a regulation clarifying that there will no harmonised minimum level of banks' assets that can be wiped out by regulators when a lender is wound down, a move that slightly softens requirements for banks.

site_title: Investor groups call for new probe of VW scandal
summary: Three investor groups, including DSW and Deminor, are calling for a new, independent investigation into Volkswagen's emissions scandal, citing concerns that internal probes may not be transparent enough. The groups, which represent a combined 0.013% of VW's voting shares, want to allow shareholders to vote on launching such an investigation at the company's annual general meeting. VW has set aside 16.2 billion euros to cover vehicle refits and legal costs, and has established a Special Committee on Diesel Engines to investigate the scandal.

site_title: NTU in tie-up to develop helicopter manufacturing and technology
summary: NTU in Singapore has partnered with Leonardo-Finmeccanica to develop helicopter manufacturing and technology through a research collaboration. The partnership aims to advance aerospace technology by sharing knowledge, conducting scientific research, and enhancing engineering and industrial capabilities. The joint projects will focus on lightweight composite materials and aerodynamics research, potentially improving flight performance. The collaboration will benefit NTU faculties and students, while boosting Leonardo-Finmeccanica's edge in advanced helicopter technologies.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Nissan likely to send former tech chief to lead reform at Mitsubishi: sources
summary: Nissan is likely to appoint Mitsuhiko Yamashita, its former global tech chief, as Mitsubishi Motors' tech chief as part of a planned $2.2 billion investment. Yamashita, who held a similar position at Nissan from 2005-2014, would lead reforms at Mitsubishi, which is reeling from a fuel economy scandal and a $3 billion market value hit. Nissan CEO Carlos Ghosn has stated that Mitsubishi will be led by a Nissan executive, prompting industry analysts to forecast a significant reshuffle at the top. An appointment is reportedly set for an emergency Mitsubishi board meeting on Wednesday.

site_title: Singapore shares close higher for the day
summary: Singapore stocks closed 0.1% higher on Monday, advancing 3.11 points to 2,766.93, amidst cautious trading over a potential June US rate hike. The Straits Times Index saw 197 gainers and 193 losers, with a total of 1.02 billion shares changing hands. The market's non-committal move was attributed to traders' uncertainty over the US rate hike.

site_title: Middle East franchisee buys global rights for Jones the Grocer
summary: A Middle East franchisee, JTG Holdings, has acquired global rights to the Jones the Grocer brand. L Capital Asia, a backer of the brand since 2012, has taken a minority stake in JTG Holdings. A subsidiary of L Capital Asia has also gained master franchise rights for various markets in North Asia, South-east Asia, Australia, and New Zealand. The new development aims to bring focus and new global opportunities to stakeholders in the business.

site_title: Asia industrial commodities drop as Japan, China demand concerns
summary: Asian industrial commodities, including steel, iron ore, and rubber, slumped on Monday due to concerns over China and Japan's economic health. Chinese steel and iron ore futures fell 6% and 5% respectively, while rubber futures dropped 5.3% and 4.5%. The decline is attributed to faltering domestic demand and increased steel production in response to price increases. The Shanghai Composite Index has dropped for five weeks in a row, underscoring concerns about China's economy.

site_title: US consumers buck investors' rush to self-driving cars: study
summary: US consumers remain resistant to self-driving cars, with 46% preferring no self-driving capability, according to a University of Michigan study. The majority (95%) want to maintain manual control over a self-driving vehicle, and three out of four respondents are "afraid" to ride in a self-driving car. This finding contradicts the rush by investors and automakers to invest in self-driving technology, with companies like General Motors and Alphabet's Google leading the charge. The study's results mirror previous surveys, highlighting limited consumer demand for self-driving cars.

site_title: Russia goes it alone with first Eurobond since sanctions imposed
summary: Russia is issuing its first Eurobond since sanctions were imposed in 2014, with the benchmark-sized sale of 10-year dollar-denominated notes priced between 4.65-4.9%. The bond sale comes after a rally in Russian assets pushed yields on outstanding debt to levels preceding the sanctions. Russia's VTB Group is acting as the sole organiser for the sale, with proceeds not directed to any activity that violates sanctions. The bond sale aims to raise $3.5 billion to finance Russia's budget shortfall, which has widened due to the country's recession and decline in oil prices.

site_title: FLASH: Singapore CPI in 18th month of contraction with April's 0.5% fall; core inflation up 0.8%
summary: Singapore's consumer prices fell 0.5% in April, marking the 18th consecutive month of contraction. Core inflation rose 0.8%, indicating a slight improvement in the country's economic situation.

site_title: India to boost Iran port project, links to Afghanistan
summary: India's Prime Minister Narendra Modi pledged up to $500 million to develop the Chabahar port in Iran, giving India trade access to Iran, Afghanistan, and central Asia.
