A two-year limit for negotiating terms on a member state's departure will be strictly enforced, with no guarantees of a free trade deal or favorable terms.

site_title: German doctors blast Lufthansa over Germanwings crash
summary: German doctors' association head blasts Lufthansa and regulators for allowing a pilot with severe depression to fly, contributing to the 2015 Germanwings crash that killed 150. Investigators found the pilot had a history of depression and suicidal tendencies, and Lufthansa knew about his health condition. The association's head, Andreas Lubitz, criticized the airline and regulators for failing to prevent the crash, calling it a "tragedy" that could have been avoided.

site_title: Lacking new ideas, G7 agrees on 'go-your-own-way' approach
summary: The G7 finance leaders' gathering in Japan agreed on a "go-your-own-way" approach to address global economic growth risks, due to differing fiscal situations among member countries. Japan backed away from coordinated fiscal action, while the US stated there was no "one-size-fits-all" policy solution. Countries with fiscal space can deploy more stimulus, while those without can't, according to US and Japanese officials. The agreement reflects the challenges in finding a unified response to economic growth concerns.

site_title: Boustead Projects' Q4 net profit falls 31%
summary: Boustead Projects Limited reported a 31% decline in Q4 net profit to S$5.38 million due to higher costs and associate company losses. Group revenue rose 22% to S$59.4 million, driven by 21% growth in design-and-build revenue. Despite similar revenue to 2014, net profit fell 7% to S$22.9 million. The company maintains its leadership position in the industrial real estate market and plans to explore M&A and investment opportunities to grow its business.

site_title: Apple boss to meet India's Modi and his gold iPhone
summary: Apple CEO Tim Cook is set to meet Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi in New Delhi, where he will discuss ways to boost sales in the country. Modi, known for taking selfies with his gold iPhone, has expressed his desire for Apple to manufacture phones in India to help the country become a manufacturing powerhouse. Cook will also be reminded to avoid upstaging Modi, who has been known to shove aside other leaders to be in the spotlight. The meeting aims to increase Apple's market share in India, where the company currently has only 2% of the market.

site_title: EgyptAir crash highlights how terror fears are shifting tourism
summary: An EgyptAir flight from Cairo to Paris crashed overnight, highlighting how terrorism fears are shifting tourism flows in Europe. Travelers are shunning Egypt, Turkey, and Tunisia after deadly attacks, with tourists flocking to safer destinations like Spain, Greece, and Portugal. "Geopolitical events have become an ever more important factor for tourism," said Steffen Wagner, head of transport and leisure at KPMG. The incident reawakens security concerns among travelers, underscoring the impact of terrorism on the tourism industry.

site_title: Shots fired in Uber, taxi clash in Johannesburg finance hub
summary: Shots were fired in Johannesburg's Sandton financial district as Uber drivers clashed with metered taxi operators. One taxi driver was arrested and his vehicle impounded, while three police officers were injured. The violence occurred outside a Gautrain station, where Citigroup and other major companies have offices. Uber service has been temporarily suspended in the area. This incident intensifies the dispute between Uber drivers and traditional taxi motorists, who object to competition from the ride-hailing service.

site_title: UK banks pulling out of pawn shops to cut risk: lawmaker
summary: UK banks may be restricting access to pawn shops to avoid anti-money laundering rules, according to a senior lawmaker. Chairman of the Treasury Select Committee, Andrew Tyrie, stated that banks are de-risking by cutting off services to individuals, firms, and charities, harming small businesses and thousands of individuals. This move is seen as a response to the anti-money laundering regulations. The Financial Conduct Authority has been informed about this issue, but no specific actions have been taken yet.

site_title: Goldman Sachs shareholders approve executive pay proposal
summary: Goldman Sachs shareholders approved executive pay plans, with over 66% voting in favor. CEO Lloyd Blankfein received $22.6 million in pay, his first decline in four years. The bank reported its worst results in four years, with revenue tumbling 40% in the first quarter. Despite this, Blankfein expressed optimism about the economy, citing signs of improvement, including rising interest rates and growing employment. The bank's board chairman, Blankfein, will remain in both roles.

images.alt_text: More than three-fifths of Goldman Sachs Group Inc shareholders voted in favor of executive pay plans on Friday at the bank's annual meeting in its Jersey City offices.

site_title: Fancy buying a million-dollar Ferrari - through a website?
summary: Luxglove, a Singapore-based e-commerce platform, is listing a vintage 1961 Ferrari 250 GTE for sale at a price of $1 million. This is believed to be the first classic car to be listed on an Asian e-commerce platform and one of the highest-priced items aside from property. The Ferrari is considered a rare and luxurious gift for someone who already has everything.

site_title: China: Stocks end up, but Shanghai index posts 5th week of losses
summary: China's Shanghai Composite Index posted a 5th consecutive week of losses, despite a 0.7% gain on Friday, as investor optimism over growth prospects faded. The decline was attributed to concerns about rising US interest rates and bad debts in China's state sector. The CSI300 index rose 0.5% on Friday, but the week's loss was 0.1%. Analysts suggest some investors are buying cheap blue-chip shares in anticipation of MSCI's inclusion of Chinese shares in its Emerging Markets Index next month.

site_title: Hong Kong kicks off talks to boost scrutiny on stock markets
summary: Hong Kong's Securities and Futures Commission has initiated discussions with brokerages on introducing rules requiring the disclosure of individual investor identities in equities trades. The proposed rules, which could take effect as early as next year, aim to boost scrutiny on the city's stock markets and align with global efforts to mitigate market volatility. However, some brokerages and banks have expressed concerns that such rules could expose their trading strategies and cause unease among investors.

site_title: Asia: Stocks end week on a positive, oil rebounds
summary: Asia's stocks ended the week on a positive note, with Tokyo and Sydney gaining 0.5% and Shanghai closing 0.7% higher. Oil prices rebounded, lifting energy and commodity firms, with Brent crude back above $49 a barrel. Investors weighed the impact of a possible US interest rate hike in June and a G7 meeting in Japan, where talks may highlight differences over global growth.

site_title: Fewer passengers ride Eurostar due to attacks
summary: The number of Eurostar passengers decreased by 6% in the first quarter of 2016 due to terror attacks in Paris and Brussels, with US and Asian travelers avoiding the service. Despite this, the company is optimistic about a recovery driven by the Euro 2016 football tournament in France. Sales fell to £201 million, a 6% decline compared to the same period last year.

site_title: Hong Kong shares up but trading thin amid US rate hike worries
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 0.8% to 19,852.20 points, driven by a strong IT sector, despite light trading volumes amid concerns of a US interest rate hike possibly in June or July. Investors also worry about China's economy losing momentum. The Hang Seng index rose 0.7% for the week. A Fed policymaker stated that markets underestimated the probability of policy tightening.

site_title: ST Engineering says legal proceeding over alleged losses on 2014 flight now defunct
summary: ST Engineering has announced that a legal proceeding over alleged losses on a 2014 flight is now defunct. The claim, filed by passenger families in the Court of Toulouse, France, was related to an Airbus AirAsia flight from Indonesia to Singapore. The claimants failed to register the writ of summons within the required time, rendering the proceeding defunct. ST Engineering previously stated that the claim had no merit, citing that neither the company nor its subsidiaries were providing line maintenance support to AirAsia at the time of the incident.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index ended lower on Friday, closing at 1,628.79 points down 4.97 points. Trading volume reached 1.71 billion lots valued at RM1.64 billion, with 365 gainers and 408 losers.

site_title: World Bank restarts Cambodia loans after five-year freeze
summary: The World Bank has approved $130 million in new loans for Cambodia, ending a five-year freeze following mass evictions at Phnom Penh's Boeung Kak lake. The loans will fund projects improving roads, water access, livelihoods, and healthcare. The move comes after strongman Prime Minister Hun Sen's government clashed with the World Bank over the evictions, displacing 4,000 families. Activists remain disappointed, calling for justice and suitable homes for the evicted families, amid ongoing land conflicts in Cambodia.

site_title: China approves sweeping plan to clean up online finance industry: sources
summary: China's government has approved a plan to clean up the online finance industry, including rules to limit P2P lending firms, which have been linked to recent fraud scandals. The plan requires P2P platforms to deposit client funds with a third-party bank and set up "firewalls" to manage transactions with affiliates. The government also aims to establish a centralized registration system and a unified platform for internet bank accounts. The plan is part of a broader effort to clean up the online finance sector, following high-profile fraud scandals, including the arrest of 21 officials of Ezubao, China's biggest P2P lending platform.

site_title: EU to make it easier to suspend visa-free travel amid immigration worries
summary: European Union interior ministers will back plans to make it easier and faster to suspend visa-free travel with third countries amid immigration concerns. The EU plans to upgrade a mechanism to allow for quicker suspension of visa-free travel for countries like Turkey, Ukraine, and Kosovo. The changes will apply to the Schengen zone and aim to address concerns about the scale of immigration into the bloc. The plan enjoys broad backing, with some EU states expressing anxiety about opening up to a mainly Muslim nation like Turkey.

site_title: Fullerton Health unit buys Indonesian managed healthcare firm Medilum
summary: Fullerton Health's subsidiary Global Assistance & Healthcare acquired Indonesian managed healthcare firm Medilum, providing managed healthcare and third-party administration services to over 1,400 healthcare providers. The acquisition combines Medilum's expertise with GAH's existing healthcare services, forming Indonesia's only complete, integrated corporate healthcare solutions company. This move aims to enhance Fullerton Health's presence in the Indonesian market, while the company is also planning to raise S$300 million through a listing on the Singapore Exchange.

site_title: Brexit Britain would be treated as an outsider: Juncker
summary: European Commission chief Jean-Claude Juncker warns that if Britain quits the European Union, it will be treated as an outsider, no longer considered a full member. This means the UK will not be given preferential treatment and will have to accept the consequences of its decision. The UK will have to accept being a third party in EU affairs, with its relations changing as a result. The warning comes ahead of the UK's referendum on June 23, where Britons will vote on whether to stay in the EU.

site_title: Egypt says wreckage found from missing EgyptAir Plane
summary: Egyptian authorities have found wreckage and personal items from the missing EgyptAir plane that vanished en route from Paris to Cairo with 66 people on board. The debris was discovered 290 kilometers north of Alexandria in the Mediterranean Sea. The search, which began since the plane disappeared early Thursday, is ongoing. Authorities are investigating possible causes, including a deliberate act or malfunction, and have not ruled out a terrorist attack. EgyptAir has offered condolences to the families of the victims and vowed to take necessary measures.

images.alt_text: Egyptian authorities said they found wreckage and belongings from the missing EgyptAir plane that vanished en route from Paris to Cairo with 66 people on board.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's domestic wholesale trade declined 22.6% in Q1 due to a decline in petroleum and petroleum products. Manulife US Reit made its debut on the SGX mainboard, trading between US$0.77 and US$0.825. Technics Oil & Gas filed a writ and injunction against Soilbuild Reit over unpaid rent. Fullerton Health's Indonesian subsidiary acquired PT JLT GESA, while UOL bought a London property for £98.75m. Keppel's offshore unit formed a joint venture with Rosneft and MHWirth. The STI rose 1.1% for the week, with Global Logistic Properties and Thai Beverage contributing to the gains.

site_title: Europe: Shares open higher, led by UniCredit
summary: European shares rose 0.9% in early trading, driven by gains in Asia and stronger oil prices, with UniCredit leading the gains on potential asset sales. The FTSEurofirst 300 index recovered from a 1.2% drop in the previous session. Miners and oil stocks surged, while Richemont fell 4.5% due to weak sales growth. UniCredit is assessing the sale of stakes in several banks, which could ease capital concerns.

site_title: Singapore sets up council for skills and industry transformation
summary: Singapore establishes a three-ministry council to develop and implement industry transformation maps, focusing on skills development, productivity, and innovation. The Council for Skills, Innovation, and Productivity will be chaired by Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam and comprise representatives from government, industry, and educational institutions. The council aims to drive economic growth through skills advancement, industry transformation, and a culture of lifelong learning, with a two-year term.

site_title: Oil eases as focus returns to oversupply
summary: Oil prices slipped on Friday, trading down 23 cents at $48.58 a barrel, as investors cashed in on recent gains and focused on swelling global inventories. Despite supply disruptions in countries like Nigeria, Canada, and Libya, analysts expect oil prices to come off recent highs, citing excess supply and large inventories. Russian Energy Minister Alexander Novak estimated supply to be in excess of demand by 1.5 million barrels per day. Some analysts predict oil prices could fall to the mid to high $30-a-barrel range, driven by a stronger dollar and ongoing inventory overhang.

images.alt_text: Oil prices slipped on Friday as investors cashed in on recent gains and focus shifted again to swelling global inventories that have cushioned impact from a series on unplanned supply outages.

site_title: Tokio Marine: sees insurance payout for Kumamoto quake around 5b yen
summary: Tokio Marine Holdings Inc estimates a 5 billion yen (S$62.7 million) insurance payout for damages from the April 14 earthquakes in southern Japan. The bulk of the payout is for corporate insurance to cover damaged factory buildings and equipment, excluding residential earthquake coverage reinsured by the government. The estimate does not include losses from landslides and production halts.

site_title: Dollar firm against euro, yen as G7 finance chiefs meet
summary: The dollar strengthened against the euro and yen as a G7 finance meeting began in northern Japan, with investors weighing the potential impact of a US interest rate hike in June. The dollar rose to 110.09 yen from 109.96 yen, while holding gains against the euro, amid hawkish minutes from the Federal Reserve's recent meeting and solid US economic data. The G7 meeting may highlight a divide among rich nations on how to boost global growth, with host Japan pushing for fiscal stimulus.

site_title: Morgan Stanley said to move 75 Shanghai jobs to Hong Kong, India
summary: Morgan Stanley plans to move about 75 jobs from its Shanghai operations team to India and Hong Kong, aiming to improve back-office efficiency. A third of the roles will be shifted to Hong Kong, with the rest going to India. The relocation, announced internally in March, is expected to be completed by the end of the year. The move will result in some job losses in China, but the bank will hire in India to compensate. The operations team will remain unchanged in terms of headcount.

site_title: Lacking new ideas, G7 to agree on 'go-your-own-way' approach
summary: G7 finance leaders are expected to agree on a "go-your-own-way" approach to address global economic growth risks, rejecting coordinated fiscal stimulus. Instead, they will focus on structural reforms and individual investment. Japan's hopes for coordinated fiscal action to spur global demand have been dashed. The risk of a British vote to exit the European Union (Brexit) will be discussed, and cyber-security will be a key topic, with policymakers recognizing the need for prompt action to enhance global financial transactions.

site_title: VW agrees to 4.8% pay raise for workers at German plants
summary: Volkswagen has agreed to a 4.8% pay raise for around 120,000 workers at its western German plants, following a collective wage-bargaining deal with the IG Metall labour union. The pay increase will be implemented in two stages, with a 2.8% raise on September 1, 2016, and a further 2% on August 1, 2017. The deal also includes a 200 euros pension contribution and an extended part-time working scheme until 2022. This marks the union's second pay raise of 2016, following a 4.8% increase for 3.8 million German workers in April.

site_title: Taiwan's Tsai calls for 'positive dialogue' with Beijing
summary: Taiwan's President Tsai Ing-wen called for "positive dialogue" with China in her inauguration speech, striking a conciliatory tone amidst an increasingly hostile Beijing. Tsai, who won a landslide victory, emphasized the importance of cross-strait communication and vowed to maintain the status quo, while also diversifying Taiwan's economy and defending its democratic culture. Despite Beijing's pressure to back its "one China" message, Tsai reiterated her opposition to the concept and committed to Taiwan's sovereignty.

site_title: 'Absolutely no indication' what caused EgyptAir crash: French minister
summary: EgyptAir Flight 804 crashed in the Mediterranean on May 19, 2016, killing all 66 people on board. French Foreign Minister Jean-Marc Ayrault stated there is "absolutely no indication" of the cause, contradicting Egypt's Aviation Minister who suspects a "terrorist" attack. A massive search operation was underway. The French government plans to meet with families of the victims on Saturday to provide information.

site_title: Some foreign investors target India's top bourse in rare shareholder backlash
summary: Foreign investors, owning 10.1% of India's National Stock Exchange (NSE), have accused the exchange of poor corporate governance, zero transparency, and lack of accountability. The investors, led by US-based Norwest Venture Partners, have been pushing for the NSE to list as soon as possible, but the exchange has been reluctant due to Indian law requiring it to list on another exchange. The dispute marks a rare instance of shareholder backlash in India, where governance problems are common. The investors have threatened to call for a replacement of management and board if their demands are not met.

site_title: Clinton's lead over Trump narrows in latest US poll
summary: Hillary Clinton's lead over Donald Trump in the US presidential election has narrowed to 6 percentage points, according to a CBS News/New York Times survey. Clinton now holds 47% support, while Trump has 41%. This marks a reversal from a 10-point lead Clinton held in a previous CBS News poll last month, following Trump's nomination as the Republican presidential candidate.

site_title: China official media blackout on Taiwan inauguration
summary: China's official media largely ignored the inauguration of Taiwan's new president Tsai Ing-Wen, who took office on Friday, signaling the end of an eight-year rapprochement with China. Mainland Chinese news outlets and social media platforms blocked searches for her name and "Taiwan". China views Taiwan as a renegade province awaiting reunification, and Beijing has been sending assertive messages since Tsai's election in January, warning against formal declaration of independence. The move is seen as a significant escalation in tensions between the two sides.

site_title: Hong Kong's SFC said to survey participants on investor codes
summary: Hong Kong's Securities and Futures Commission (SFC) is moving forward with a project to assign real-time investor identification codes, allowing regulators to track trades beyond brokers to individual investors. The system aims to enhance market oversight, detect manipulation, and deter rogue traders. A public consultation period is set for the second half of the year, with the system expected to be implemented at least a year later. The introduction of the system has raised concerns among some brokers, who worry it may damage the city's appeal to investors and increase costs for large traders.

site_title: Tokyo to get bigger skyscrapers with record developer debt
summary: Japan's largest real estate companies are borrowing record amounts of cheap cash to build massive skyscrapers in Tokyo, generating 10 trillion yen for the economy. Mitsubishi Estate Co plans to build a 61-floor, 390-meter tower, and Mitsui Fudosan Co and Sumitomo Realty & Development Co also have record debt piles. The Bank of Japan's negative-rate policy is boosting investment in domestic commercial property, but uncertainties in the market have increased due to the economy's weakness. Analysts warn of risks of overheating in the market, despite the developers' optimism about future profits.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher on weaker yen
summary: Tokyo stocks rose 0.54% on Friday, ending the week on a positive note, driven by a weaker yen that lifted exporters. The Nikkei 225 index closed at 16,736.35, while the Topix index gained 0.51%. This week's gains followed a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks ahead of GDP data, despite US-EU trade talks and tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Clinton calls Democratic race 'done,' says Trump unqualified
summary: Hillary Clinton declared the Democratic nomination race over, stating she will be the nominee and Donald Trump is unqualified to hold the nation's highest office. Clinton expressed confidence in her ability to secure the nomination, despite some Sanders supporters expressing doubts. Trump responded by calling Clinton "unfit to serve" and claiming she has "bad judgment." The Democratic Party is experiencing upheaval, with simmering divisions and concerns about violence at the national convention. Clinton's campaign is now focusing on defeating Trump, who is consolidating Republicans around him.

site_title: Hot stock: Manulife US Reit makes debut on SGX mainboard
summary: Manulife US Reit, a real estate investment trust, made its debut on the Singapore Exchange's mainboard on May 20, 2016, trading between US$0.77 and US$0.825 per unit. It closed at US$0.79, with 42 million units changing hands. The Canadian insurer priced its IPO at the top end of its indicative range at US$0.83 per unit.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks fall, president's speech awaited
summary: Taiwan's stocks fell on Friday, awaiting President Tsai Ing-wen's speech on her stance towards China. The TAIEX index dropped 0.2% in the first 30 minutes of trading, with the electronics and financial subindices also declining. The speech is expected to provide indications on how Tsai will address China's concerns over Taiwan's independence. The pro-independence Democratic Progressive Party won the presidential and parliamentary elections in January, and investors are watching for any move towards independence by the new president.

site_title: China's cabinet appoints new central bank deputy governor
summary: China's cabinet has appointed Zhang Tao as the new deputy governor of the People's Bank of China (PBOC), replacing Zhou Mubing, who will no longer hold the post of vice chairman of the China Banking Regulatory Commission (CBRC). The appointments were made without providing further details.

site_title: Vanishing Hong Kong housing packages strip bankers of peak views
summary: Hong Kong's luxury rental market is experiencing a downturn, with expat housing packages being significantly reduced or eliminated. The number of finance clients with corporate packages moving to Hong Kong has halved, and those who remain are downsizing to more affordable options. Luxury properties, once in high demand, are now struggling to find tenants, with some landlords offering discounts of up to 30% to fill vacant units. The decline in expat packages is attributed to the city's property correction, which has led to a 14% decline in housing prices and further declines predicted this year.

site_title: Seoul: Won bounces after sharp losses, stocks set for 4th weekly loss
summary: The South Korean won rebounded 0.3% to 1,187.7 per dollar after sharp losses fueled by expectations of a US interest rate hike. The won was on track for its fourth consecutive weekly loss. Meanwhile, South Korean shares remained directionless, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) up 0.1%. Foreign investors sold KOSPI shares, and tech firm LG Electronics Inc fell 3.7%, while LG Display Co Ltd gained 4.1%.

site_title: Taiwan's Tsai takes office as hostile Beijing looks on
summary: Taiwan's Tsai Ing-wen becomes the island's first female president, taking office with a landslide victory over the ruling Kuomintang. Tsai's campaign focused on restoring Taiwanese pride and sovereignty, resonating with voters who felt Ma Ying-jeou's eight-year rapprochement with Beijing went too far. Beijing wants Tsai to acknowledge the "one China" concept, but she has pledged to maintain the status quo and uphold Taiwan's democratic culture. Tsai's inauguration speech will be closely watched, with observers expecting her to avoid compromise on the "one China" issue.

site_title: Indonesia's financial minister revises down growth assumption in 2017 budget
summary: Indonesia's finance minister, Bambang Brodjonegoro, revised the country's 2017 growth assumption to 5.3-5.9% in the state budget, lower than the initial forecast of 5.5-5.9%. This change follows the central bank's trim of its 2016 growth outlook to 5.0-5.4% due to first-quarter growth coming in below forecast. Brodjonegoro remains optimistic about Indonesia's growth prospects, citing a 5.3% growth rate for 2016.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.2% up on Friday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 0.2% to 2,746.78 on Friday, driven by a temporary rebound in crude oil prices. About 31.1 million shares changed hands, with an average unit price of S$0.92 per share. This follows a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data and comes after a 0.4% increase on Thursday.

site_title: Japan lawmakers discuss big stimulus to offset 2017 tax hike
summary: Japan's lawmakers are discussing a big stimulus package to offset a planned 2017 sales-tax increase, which could go ahead as scheduled. Despite initial recommendations to delay the tax hike due to global financial market fluctuations and signs of economic resilience, some lawmakers propose to proceed with the 10% tax increase and address potential economic damage through an enlarged fiscal package. A senior Liberal Democratic Party legislator plans to submit a proposal for up to $376 billion in supplementary fiscal measures to support the economy.

site_title: China eyes PBOC veteran Zhang as next IMF deputy, Caixin reports
summary: China plans to nominate Zhang Tao, a central bank veteran, to replace IMF Deputy Managing Director Zhu Min when his term ends in July. Zhang, who was recently promoted to deputy governor of the People's Bank of China, has years of experience at multilateral development banks. China's nomination reflects its growing economic might and push for increased global use of the IMF's unit of account. Zhang's appointment would be the fifth of the central bank's deputy governors to hold a PhD, with his boss Governor Zhou Xiaochuan advocating for financial reforms and staff with international experience.

images.alt_text: China plans to nominate Zhang Tao, a central bank veteran with years of experience at multilateral development banks, to replace International Monetary Fund Deputy managing director Zhu Min (pictured), Caixin magazine reported.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks open lower
summary: Hong Kong and Shanghai stocks fell on Friday, tracking overnight losses in global markets amid expectations of a US interest rate hike. The Hang Seng Index dropped 0.11%, the Shanghai Composite Index fell 0.50%, and the Shenzhen Composite Index lost 0.82%. These declines follow a 5-day rally in Singapore stocks and come as investors await US GDP data and US-EU trade talks.

site_title: Stocks to watch: CDL, SembMarine, Technics Oil & Gas
summary: City Developments Limited (CDL) plans to deploy S$5 billion in overseas expansion over five years, targeting real-estate investments. Sembcorp Marine's subsidiary PT SMOE inaugurated a training centre in Batam to retain skilled workers. Technics Oil & Gas faces two new legal suits totaling close to S$5 million in loan repayments, following a newbuild order that fell through.

site_title: Taiwan swears in Tsai Ing-wen as first female president
summary: Taiwan's Tsai Ing-wen was sworn in as the country's first female president on May 20, 2016, after winning a landslide victory in January. The move signals the end of an eight-year rapprochement with China, with which Taiwan's relations have rapidly cooled. Tsai, a Beijing-sceptic, took the oath of office at the presidential palace, marking a significant shift in Taiwan's politics. The ceremony was attended by celebrating crowds and followed by a brass marching band parade.

site_title: Tesla raises US$1.46b in stock sale: IFR
summary: Tesla Motors Inc has raised US$1.46 billion in fresh capital from a stock sale of 6.8 million new common shares, priced at US$215 per share. The funding will help finance the expansion of electric vehicle production to 500,000 units per year by 2018.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Friday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 1.07 points to 1634.83 on Friday, driven by a higher volume of 27.45 million lots worth RM10.45 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 81 to 49, indicating a positive trading session.

site_title: Australia: Shares rebound, set for weekly gain; NZ more subdued
summary: Australian shares rebounded 0.5% on Friday, setting the market on track for a weekly gain. The S&P/ASX 200 index rose to 5,349.5, driven by gains in the mining sector and major banks. Key movers included BHP Billiton (1.6%) and Rio Tinto (2.0%). In contrast, New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index fell 0.2% for the week, led by declines in Ryman Healthcare and New Zealand Refining.

site_title: Suppliers question Tesla's goals for Model 3 output
summary: Tesla plans to accelerate production of its Model 3 to 100,000 units in 2017 and 400,000 units in 2018, two years earlier than planned, according to the company's CEO Elon Musk. However, suppliers question the feasibility of this goal, citing the complexity of the vehicle's design, limited supplier capacity, and high demand for machinery and tooling. Industry experts also express doubts, citing the lack of finalization of the Model 3 design and the need for significant investment in new production hires and in-house parts production.

images.alt_text: Tesla Motors Inc has surprised parts makers with plans to move up the launch of high-volume production of its Model 3 to 2018, two years earlier than planned - an acceleration that supplier executives and industry consultants said would be difficult to achieve and potentially costly.

site_title: S&P sees impact if Alaska unable to reach budget deal in special session
summary: Alaska's credit rating may face pressure if it fails to reach a budget deal during its special session, according to Standard and Poor's Global Ratings. The state's general obligation debt rating was lowered to AA-plus in January due to a structural deficit caused by declining oil-related tax revenue. Governor Bill Walker has announced a special session starting Monday to address a $3.5 billion budget deficit, which includes fiscal reforms. Failure to reach a deal may impact the state's credit rating.

site_title: Gap to close 75 Old Navy, Banana Republic stores globally
summary: Gap Inc. plans to close 75 Old Navy and Banana Republic stores globally, focusing on North America to revive its fortunes. The closures, including 53 Old Navy stores in Japan, are expected to result in a US$250 million annualized sales loss but save US$275 million in pretax costs. Gap's first-quarter sales fell 6% and net income declined 46.9%, leading the company to reaffirm its adjusted profit forecast for 2016 and focus on improving trends in the apparel retail environment.

site_title: Asia: Shares poised for weekly loss, Fed talk lifts dollar
summary: Asian shares are poised for a weekly loss, despite a 0.6% gain on Friday, as the dollar is expected to rise due to bets on a potential US Federal Reserve rate hike as early as next month. Japan's Nikkei index rose 0.2% for the week, while the MSCI Asia-Pacific index remains down 0.3% for the week and 4.2% for the year. The dollar's strength is attributed to market expectations of a Fed rate hike, which could impact global markets.

site_title: British stars from Cumberbatch to Knightley back staying in EU
summary: British celebrities including Benedict Cumberbatch, Keira Knightley, and Patrick Stewart have urged voters to stay in the European Union in a joint letter, citing the EU's role in boosting Britain's creative industries. The letter, signed by 282 people from various fields, argues that leaving the EU would be a leap into the unknown and severely weaken Britain's global creative success. The letter also references William Shakespeare and David Bowie to emphasize the importance of British creativity inspiring the world.

images.alt_text: British stars including Benedict Cumberbatch, Keira Knightley and Patrick Stewart urged voters to back staying in the European Union in a joint letter on Friday.

site_title: Oil prices rise as turmoil in Nigeria adds to global supply disruptions
summary: Oil prices rose globally due to supply disruptions in Nigeria, US shale bankruptcies, and Venezuela's economic crisis. Turmoil in Nigeria, including a blocked Exxon terminal, and Libyan internal conflict reduced output. US shale production fell, and wildfires in Canada cut 1 million barrels daily. Venezuela's oil output declined by 19% in the first quarter of 2016. Despite these disruptions, global oil inventories remained high, preventing supply shortfalls and sharper price spikes. Oil prices rose 0.59% and 0.81% for Brent and West Texas Intermediate crude, respectively.

site_title: Deutsche Bank internally probes dubious trades: WSJ
summary: Deutsche Bank is internally investigating a series of trades that may have generated millions of dollars in personal profits for current and former employees. The trades, which are set to close next year, are estimated to have resulted in $37 million in profits for six employees, with one individual, Colin Fan, potentially making $9 million on a $1 million investment. The bank has not commented on the matter.

site_title: Technics Oil & Gas files writ, injunction against Soilbuild Reit
summary: Technics Oil & Gas has filed a writ of summons and injunction against Soilbuild Business Space Reit, claiming unlawful conspiracy over a sale and leaseback transaction. The guarantor for Technics Offshore Engineering's tenancy is disputing the trustee's claim on a S$11.8 million bank guarantee, equivalent to 18 months' rent. Soilbuild Reit denies the claims and plans to vigorously defend against them.

site_title: 'Here's some fruit - now pay up,' say Thai debt collectors
summary: In Thailand, debt collectors use unconventional methods to collect bad debt, such as offering baskets of fruit to debtors' homes instead of traditional intimidation tactics. JMT Network Services, a leading consumer loan collector, has seen success with this approach, with dozens of firms emerging in the country since 1998. The firm's owner, Piya Pong-acha, believes a polite and non-confrontational approach is more effective in recuperating debt. This unique approach highlights the evolving nature of debt collection in Thailand.

site_title: Nera to sell payment solutions unit to Ingenico for S$88m
summary: Nera Telecommunications has agreed to sell its payment solutions unit to Ingenico Group for approximately S$88 million, with expected gains of S$71.5 million. The sale will allow Nera to focus on its core network solutions business and strengthen its balance sheet. The payment solutions unit accounted for 26% of Nera's total revenue and 21% of its total earnings in 2015. Ingenico, based in Paris, has the world's largest payment acceptance network.

site_title: Asia: Stocks set for fourth weekly drop on global growth concern
summary: Asian stocks are set for their fourth weekly decline, with the MSCI Asia Pacific Index down 0.1% as investors assess the impact of a potential US interest-rate increase on global growth. The regional benchmark index has fallen 0.4% this week, extending a slump that began in May. Concerns about a rate hike have weighed on markets, with traders now seeing a 28% chance of higher borrowing costs next month.

site_title: China's yuan off early highs, partly held back by US rate hike expectations
summary: China's yuan rose marginally against the dollar on Friday after the central bank set a stronger midpoint rate, but weakened at the close due to expectations of a US interest rate hike in June. The yuan closed 0.2% firmer for the week, despite bearish pressures. The People's Bank of China fixed the midpoint rate at 6.5510 per dollar, with spot yuan trading at 6.5454 per dollar. The introduction of foreign commercial banks for yuan trading in overseas settlements is expected to inject vigor into China's interbank market.

site_title: UOL buys London property for £98.75m
summary: Singapore property developer UOL Group has acquired a London property, 110 High Holborn, for £98.75 million (S$199 million) from UBS Central London Office Value Added Fund. The 10,900 sqm property, located near London's Holborn tube stop, consists of offices and retail space. UOL has paid a £9.7 million deposit and the balance is payable upon completion of the deal, scheduled for June 15.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open lower following Wall St losses
summary: Tokyo stocks opened lower on Friday, following losses on US and European markets. The Nikkei 225 index dropped 0.31% to 16,594.99, and the Topix index fell 0.34% to 1,331.97. A stronger yen dented exporters, contributing to the losses.

site_title: Keppel's offshore unit to form joint venture with Russia's Rosneft
summary: Keppel Corp's offshore and marine unit has formed a joint venture with Russia's Rosneft and Norwegian firm MHWirth. The Singapore incorporated company will establish a design and engineering centre in Russia, focusing on shallow water platforms projects for Rosneft and potentially other Russian and international customers.

images.alt_text: Conglomerate Keppel Corp's offshore and marine unit signed a shareholders' agreement with Russian oil firm Rosneft and Norwegian drilling equipment firm, MHWirth, to set up a Singapore incorporated joint venture company.

site_title: Dollar edges higher on rate hike talk; pound strengthens
summary: The US dollar rose 0.1% to US$1.1203 against the euro, driven by speculation of a potential interest rate hike in June. Meanwhile, the British pound strengthened to US$1.4609, boosted by a recent opinion poll showing 47% of voters favor staying in the EU. Sterling also reached its highest level since early February due to better-than-expected retail sales data.

site_title: Global growth tops agenda as G7 meeting kicks off in Japan
summary: Finance ministers and central bankers from the G7 meet in Japan to discuss global growth, amid a sharp divide on currency policy and fiscal stimulus. Japan seeks to promote its position on stimulating the global economy through fiscal stimulus, but this may put it at odds with other nations, including the US and Germany. The G7 aims to hammer out a strategy to prevent a global recession, while discussing other topics such as terrorist financing, offshore tax havens, and a debt relief deal for Greece.

site_title: China homebuilder Sunac says acquisition spree to continue
summary: China homebuilder Sunac is set to continue its acquisition spree due to rising land prices at government auctions, chairman Sun Hongbin said. The company is in talks for multiple projects in cities like Beijing and Shanghai, with prices considered "fairly reasonable" compared to open auctions. Sunac has spent $11.6 billion acquiring 46 projects in 15 months and is seeking reasonably priced land to replenish its stock. The company's cash flows remain "very safe," but land prices may become unsustainable if developers rely on them to make a profit.

site_title: Bitcoin exchange Coinbase to add ether currency to trading platform
summary: Coinbase, a leading bitcoin exchange, will add ether to its trading platform next Tuesday. The exchange, now rebranded as GDAX, will offer ether/dollar and ether/bitcoin currency pairs. Ether is the digital currency for the Ethereum platform, a blockchain that enables decentralized applications. This move expands Coinbase's offerings and reflects the growing adoption of ether and other digital currencies.

site_title: Alibaba insists it can help fight counterfeit brand goods
summary: Alibaba has reaffirmed its commitment to combating counterfeit brand-name products, despite being kicked out of an industry coalition last week. Alibaba president Michael Evans met with the International Anti Counterfeiting Coalition, saying the company is "uniquely positioned" to take on the global $500 billion counterfeit market. Evans received a lukewarm reception from the group, but Alibaba remains committed to working with brands to stop counterfeit goods. The company's online shopping platforms contain over a billion product listings, and it has pledged to collaborate with brands to combat counterfeiting.

site_title: Accident or terrorism, Egypt crash to set back economic recovery
summary: Egypt's economy is dealt another blow as an EgyptAir jet crashes into the Mediterranean, raising concerns about terrorism or mechanical failure. The crash, which killed all 66 people on board, occurs as the country aims to project an image of authority and security to revive growth. The incident further complicates Egypt's efforts to rebuild its economy, which has been struggling with a foreign-currency crunch, a decline in tourism revenues, and a widening current-account deficit.

site_title: Google's Android and Chrome operating systems get closer
summary: Google is integrating its Android mobile app store, Google Play, into Chrome OS, allowing Android apps to run on personal computers. The move is part of a convergence between Android and Chrome OS, with the goal of making devices more useful. Initially, the integration will be available on three Chromebook PCs, with plans to expand to other existing and new Chromebooks. The integration aims to bring popular Android apps, such as Skype, to Chromebooks, filling gaps in their functionality. Google's approach is to combine the best attributes of each operating system.

site_title: Clinton declares Trump a 'threat' to US democracy
summary: Hillary Clinton declared Donald Trump a 'threat' to US democracy, stating he is unqualified to be president. In an interview with CNN, Clinton emphasized the need for steadiness, strength, and smarts in the presidency. Her comments mark a hardening of her position on Trump, who she believes poses a dramatic threat to the country's democracy and economy. Clinton's remarks come ahead of the general election.

site_title: Zuckerberg explains trending method to conservatives
summary: Mark Zuckerberg held a meeting with conservative figures to address concerns about Facebook's trending news topics and alleged liberal bias. Zuckerberg explained the social network's algorithm, stating there's minimal human involvement and no bias. He also emphasized the platform's importance to conservatives, citing Donald Trump's large following and Fox News's high engagement. Attendees expressed concerns over other Facebook policies, but praised Zuckerberg's sincerity and willingness to address issues, calling for further work to restore trust.

site_title: Air-sea search intensifies for crashed EgyptAir plane
summary: An EgyptAir Airbus A320 crashed in the Mediterranean on May 18, 2016, killing all 66 people on board. The plane vanished from radar screens while flying from Paris to Cairo, with conflicting reports of wreckage being found. Egyptian President Abdel Fattah al-Sisi demanded an intensified search, with French President Francois Hollande confirming the plane had crashed. Authorities suspect a terrorist attack or technical failure, with the Islamic State (IS) group claiming responsibility for a similar bombing last October.

site_title: China demands end to US surveillance after aircraft intercept
summary: China has demanded the US cease surveillance activities near its territory after two Chinese fighter jets intercepted a US reconnaissance aircraft in the South China Sea. The incident occurred in international airspace, with the US aircraft conducting a routine patrol. China's Foreign Ministry called the US actions "serious endangering Chinese maritime security" and demanded an end to close reconnaissance activities. The encounter increases tensions in the region, which has been disputed by China, the US, and other countries.

images.alt_text: Beijing demanded an end to US surveillance near China on Thursday after two of its fighter jets carried out what the Pentagon said was an "unsafe"intercept of a US military reconnaissance aircraft over the South China Sea.

site_title: ECB has no plan to cut deposit rate at present
summary: The European Central Bank (ECB) has no plan to cut its deposit rate, currently at -0.40%, despite zero inflation in the euro zone. ECB executive board member Benoit Coeure stated that a further cut is "in principle possible" but not currently planned. The ECB has maintained its ultra-low rates and money printing policies, despite criticism from banks, investors, and German policymakers, who argue they are distorting financial markets and squeezing profits.

site_title: Search for MH370 likely to end by August
summary: The search for Malaysia Airlines' MH370 plane is expected to be completed by early August, with less than 15,000 square kilometers of the 120,000 sq km target zone remaining to be scoured off western Australia. The Australian Transport Safety Bureau (ATSB) head Martin Dolan said there's no indication the zone will be extended, but hopes of finding the Boeing 777, which vanished on March 8, 2014, with 239 people on board, are receding. The search has yielded no clues as to what happened aboard MH370, and the ATSB is working on a report exploring other possibilities, including the "rogue pilot" theory.

images.alt_text: The massive search for Malaysia Airlines plane MH370 in the remote southern Indian Ocean is expected to be completed by early August, the man leading the hunt said Friday.

site_title: A little care goes a long way
summary: A recent article emphasizes the importance of proper care and maintenance for high-end home products, such as sofas, pillows, and mattresses. It suggests that taking care of these items can significantly extend their lifespan. The article does not provide further details on the topic, but rather serves as a general reminder for consumers to prioritize product maintenance.

site_title: Netflix, Amazon face EU quota on European works
summary: The European Commission plans to require online video streaming services like Netflix and Amazon Prime to dedicate at least 20% of their catalogues to European content. The Audiovisual Media Services Directive aims to boost European film and TV production by ensuring "prominence" of EU works and potentially requiring non-EU streaming services to contribute financially to European productions. The proposal also includes stricter age barriers for YouTube and a ban on geoblocking.

site_title: Merkel's 480b euro clean power boon creates social problems
summary: Germany's guaranteed fees for clean power operators, totaling 480 billion euros over 20 years, may exacerbate social inequality. The policy benefits approximately 8 million people, but less than 10% of the population, sparking concerns about fairness. The fees will lead to increased power bills, making Germany's electricity prices the second-most expensive in the EU. German Chancellor Angela Merkel faces opposition from state premiers over her plans to introduce auctions for renewable power, threatening the country's renewable energy shift.

site_title: German economic upswing to continue at slower pace
summary: The German economy is expected to continue growing at a slower pace due to weaker trade. Despite strong domestic demand, exports from Europe's largest economy are likely to be impacted. The Finance Ministry reported a 11% rise in tax income to 100 billion euros from January to April, driven by rising employment and private consumption. The government attributes the slowdown to external factors, emphasizing the solid growth path of the German economy.

site_title: US: S&P 500 hits lowest since March as rate fears deepen
summary: The S&P 500 fell to its lowest level since March, closing at 2,040.04, amid concerns over potential US interest rate hikes by the Federal Reserve as early as June, which could choke inflation and hamper economic expansion. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.52% and the Nasdaq Composite dropped 0.56%. The decline was attributed to rising rate fears, with New York Fed President William Dudley stating the US economy could warrant a rate increase in June.

site_title: US, Britain, France, Germany back business with Iran
summary: Western powers, including the US, Britain, France, Germany, and the European Union, have urged foreign banks and businesses to conduct legal trade with Iran. In a joint statement, they assured companies that certain forms of trade are permitted under the Iran nuclear deal. The powers pledged not to stand in the way of permitted business activity with Iran, providing a boost to the country's economy.

site_title: French PM calls for end to labour protests marred by violence
summary: French Prime Minister Manuel Valls urged union leaders to call off protests against labour law reforms, citing waning turnout and increasing violence. Despite the prime minister's claims, hundreds of thousands of people participated in demonstrations, with 129,000 people taking to the streets nationwide. Violence has marred protests, with police facing clashes with masked youths hurling petrol bombs and paving stones. The government remains committed to reforming labour laws, despite protests and strikes, with over 1,300 arrests made during weeks of protests.

images.alt_text: France's prime minister urged union leaders on Thursday to call off protests against reforms to labour laws, saying turnout was waning but violence mounting as some people were hijacking legitimate protests to attack police.

site_title: Brazil stock exchange chairman takes Petrobras CEO job
summary: Brazil's state-controlled oil producer Petrobras has appointed Pedro Parente as its new CEO, replacing the third chief executive officer in less than two years. Parente, a veteran business executive, previously led BM&F Bovespa SA and has experience in energy management. He aims to help Petrobras reduce debt and navigate the fallout from corruption scandals. The company faces significant challenges, including asset disposal programs and debt refinancing, and may require government support if it fails to meet its asset sales targets. Parente's appointment has been praised by investors, who see it as a step towards restoring growth to Brazil's economy.

site_title: Gold slides to three-week low on Fed rate expectations
summary: Gold prices fell 1% to a three-week low on Thursday, extending a decline, due to expectations of a potential US interest rate hike by the Federal Reserve as early as next month. The Fed minutes indicated stronger second-quarter growth and firming inflation and employment, increasing the opportunity cost of holding non-yielding bullion. Silver and other precious metals also declined, with spot gold settling at $1,253.80 an ounce, its weakest since April 28.

site_title: Europe: Shares slip on US rate hike prospects; banks outperform
summary: European shares fell 1.2% on Thursday as weaker oil and metals prices pressured commodities stocks, while bank stocks outperformed due to expected US interest rate hikes. The FTSEurofirst 300 index declined, with copper prices extending losses due to a stronger dollar and concerns about US rate increases. Bayer was the top loser, falling 8% after making a bid for Monsanto, and travel and leisure stocks also declined following an Egyptair flight disappearance.

site_title: Apple unveils new store design in San Francisco
summary: Apple unveiled a new store design in San Francisco, aiming to recreate the experience of visiting its headquarters. The new design features socialization and collaboration spaces, following a decline in iPhone sales and revenue drop in 13 years. The makeover is part of Apple's efforts to adapt to an increasingly saturated market. The new design will roll out to more locations worldwide, offering customers a unique experience.

site_title: Dudley joins chorus of Fed officials seeing rate hikes soon
summary: US Federal Reserve President William Dudley said the economy may be strong enough to warrant an interest rate increase in June or July, echoing the views of other Fed officials. Dudley stated that investors' bets on a rate increase have shifted to July from September, with a 30% chance of a June hike. The Fed's next meeting is scheduled a week before the UK's vote on Brexit, which may influence the decision. The economy is near full employment, but concerns about inflation and the global slowdown may slow rate hikes.

site_title: Acra probing possible SingPost rule breaches
summary: Singapore's corporate watchdog, the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (ACRA), is investigating possible breaches of regulations at SingPost, a postal and e-commerce group. The investigation follows a joint special audit report that found former lead independent director Keith Tay may have breached the Companies Act for not declaring his interest in a 2013 acquisition. SingPost shares slid 3.5% to a two-and-a-half month low after the announcement. ACRA has requested the full special audit report, and the Singapore Exchange is reviewing the findings to determine the appropriate course of action.

site_title: Yoma's non-real estate businesses lift fourth-quarter profit
summary: Yoma Strategic Holdings reported a 8.9% increase in net profit for the fourth quarter, driven by growth in non-real estate businesses such as vehicle leasing, tourism, and KFC franchises. Revenue rose 65.8% to S$45.7 million. The company's real estate business showed a gradual improvement, with property accounting for more than half of revenue. Full-year net profit expanded 32.6% to S$37.19 million, with revenue edging up 0.8%. The company's diversification efforts are seen as key to its growth.

site_title: US pension fund sues five banks over agency bond rigging claims
summary: A US pension fund, Boston Retirement System, is suing five banks, including Bank of America and Deutsche Bank, over claims that traders conspired to manipulate trading in supranational, sub-sovereign and agency bonds, or SSAs. The suit alleges that traders fixed prices at which they bought and sold SSA bonds, harming investors. The probe follows inquiries by US and UK authorities into the market for SSAs, which has been the subject of billions of dollars in settlements over claims of rigging interest-rate benchmarks and currency markets.

site_title: Doing business with Iran still a maze of ambiguity, sanctions and exemptions
summary: The US Secretary of State John Kerry advises European banks to contact the Treasury Department's Office of Foreign Assets Control (OFAC) to determine the legality of doing business with Iran. Kerry stated that the rules are "clearly defined" and that OFAC is available to answer questions. This comes as US sanctions and exemptions on Iran remain ambiguous, making it challenging for companies to navigate the situation. Kerry's guidance aims to simplify the process and provide clarity for executives concerned about potential business deals with Iran.

site_title: City buzz
summary: In Singapore, various events and dining options are available. The Theatrical Sunday Champagne Brunch Affair at Edge, Pan Pacific Singapore, features a live Peking duck station, monjayaki station, and caviar bar. Overtime #3, a pop-up art gallery and music showcase, takes place at CATO, featuring DJ A:SHE and a roundtable discussion on unconventional labor. A charity sale at La Putri jeweler supports local eye charity iC2, while JAAN at Swissotel The Stamford offers a Spring menu. Additionally, a Peranakan feast at Grand Mercure Singapore Roxy celebrates the best of Peranakan cuisine.

site_title: GLP's revenue, earnings jump in Q4
summary: Global Logistic Properties (GLP) reported a 45.7% surge in net profit to US$152.7 million in its fiscal fourth quarter, driven by higher revenue and fair value gains from investment properties. Revenue expanded 19.4% to US$199.1 million year-over-year. The company also lowered its FY17 development start target due to oversupply in some Chinese cities.

site_title: FOMC minutes give traders excuse to sell
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) fell 1.3% on Thursday, closing at 2,740.11, after the release of the US Federal Reserve's April FOMC meeting minutes, which suggested a June interest rate hike is increasingly likely. Global Logistic Properties (GLP) and Thai Beverage slid after several days of strength, while Jumbo Group's shares remained unchanged. Traders took advantage of the FOMC minutes to resume short selling, with average market volume reaching S$1.05 billion.

site_title: Preparing for a comeback in oil prices
summary: Oil prices have been volatile, dropping to levels not seen since 2003 due to a surge in oil production from Opec and the removal of production quotas. Despite 10 consecutive quarters of oversupply, prices are expected to rebound from October this year, rising to $80 by 2018 and $105 by 2020. The industry is in its deepest downturn since the 1990s, with reduced exploration and production spending and significant job cuts. Companies should focus on investing in future projects, improving cost efficiency, and positioning themselves for the next upcycle.

site_title: Japan's gaming companies now bet on virtual reality startups
summary: Japanese gaming companies, such as Gumi Inc, are investing heavily in virtual reality (VR) startups, betting on the next tech boom. CEO Hironao Kunimitsu established a $50 million Venture Reality Fund to invest in early-stage VR companies, targeting tools for virtual-reality environments and hardware/software before mass adoption. Other Japanese peers, such as Gree Inc, are also investing in VR ventures, with investments surpassing $1.08 billion this year, according to CB Insights. The move is seen as a shift from mobile gaming to VR, with many companies predicting VR headset sales will top $20 billion by 2020.

images.alt_text: With mass adoption still years away, Mr Kunimitsu says there's ample opportunity to invest in the basic building blocks of VR technology.

site_title: Japanese politicians challenge Donald Trump to a debate
summary: Two Japanese politicians, Shintaro Ishihara and Shizuka Kamei, have challenged US presidential candidate Donald Trump to a debate on how to deal with Japan, China, and North Korea. Ishihara, former Tokyo governor, and Kamei, former government minister, want to dissuade Trump from withdrawing US forces from Japan and urge the US to help stop China's "collapse from within." They have not received a response yet, but warned that Trump's views could pose "grave risks" for US-Japan relations and global stability.

site_title: Tesla to offer up to US$1.7b in new stock to fund Model 3
summary: Tesla plans to offer up to $1.7 billion in new stock to finance the launch of its Model 3 electric sedan. The move comes after the market closed, causing Tesla shares to fall 2.2% to $206.59 per share. This is lower than the $242 per share price at which Tesla last issued new shares in August 2015. The new funding will help accelerate the production and launch of the Model 3, which is expected to be a key contributor to Tesla's growth.

site_title: Oil traders unfazed by recent supply shocks
summary: Oil traders remain unfazed by recent supply shocks, with ample inventories near record highs on ships and land. The Canadian wildfire has knocked out about 2 million barrels a day, but buyers are hesitant to lock down new crude supply due to the overhang of physical oil. Total US crude inventories are near their peak, and crude stocks in Europe have tested capacity. The overhang stems from two years of production exceeding demand, resulting in huge extra exports and unprecedented stocks.

images.alt_text: Oil traders from Houston to the North Sea are tapping plentiful storage onshore and offshore, evincing little sign of concern yet about mammoth supply losses from Canada to Nigeria that has knocked out about two million barrels a day (bpd) of output.

site_title: PM Lee: Visit to Russia 'significant', long overdue
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong concluded a three-day visit to Moscow, meeting with Russian PM Dmitry Medvedev. The visit marked a significant milestone, with Lee inviting Medvedev to Singapore and expressing interest in growing trade ties. The two countries have a long-standing relationship, with diplomatic ties established in 1968, two years after a trade agreement signed in 1966. Lee's visit highlights Singapore's commitment to strengthening its ties with Russia, a move seen as a strategic move in the region.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Two contrasting readings of Mishima's classic
summary: Two theatre directors, Chong Tze Chien and Shigeki Nakano, presented contrasting interpretations of Yukio Mishima's 1950s play The Damask Drum as part of the Esplanade's Super Japan festival. Chong's version remained faithful to Mishima's original text, incorporating additional writings by notable authors, while Nakano's interpretation offered a unique and layered exploration of love, desire, and the cruelty of beauty. Both directors aimed to enrich the classic play with diverse perspectives, resulting in thought-provoking and distinct performances.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Dearth of IPOs, not delistings, lies at the heart of market's woes
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) is facing a shortage of initial public offerings (IPOs), not delistings, as the main cause of the market's woes. Despite a decline in delistings since 2014, the number of new listings has fallen far below the replacement rate in 2015, with only 14 IPOs to 21 delistings. SGX must refresh its strategy to attract new listings, looking beyond its traditional hunting grounds and exploring incentives for foreign companies and funds to list in Singapore.

site_title: Guqin music through motion
summary: Singapore dancers collaborate with composer Joyce Beetuan Koh to create "Sounding Body," an experiment where movement generates guqin music. Dancers Matthew Goh, Melyn Chow, and Kong Wei Jie use motion sensors synced with computers to create unique sounds, manipulating their bodies to produce distinct guqin tones. The seven-segment piece explores new roles of dance and movement, strengthening dancers' musicality and sensitivity to musical scores. It runs from May 26-28 at Goodman Arts Centre.

images.alt_text: Dancers (from left) Matthew Goh, Melyn Chow and Kong Wei Jie are fitted with motion sensors which replicate the sounds of a guqin when they move.

site_title: Shunfu Ville sold for S$638m to Qingjian
summary: Shunfu Ville, a 358-unit HUDC estate, was sold to Qingjian Realty for S$638m, the largest collective sale since 2007. The sale price is lower than the reserve price of S$688m, and the site could yield over 1,000 units. The sale offers Qingjian a development pipeline similar to acquiring two or three government sites. However, some market watchers question whether this marks a revival of the enbloc market due to punitive measures on unsold units for developers.

site_title: BHP sees China steel demand to stay firm but not for iron ore
summary: BHP Billiton predicts China's steel demand will continue to grow until the middle of the next decade, driven by infrastructure spending on highways, railways, and airports. However, demand for iron ore is expected to fall as China turns to using more scrap in its steel production, with about 10% of its crude steel production coming from scrap last year. This shift towards environmentally-sustainable practices will lead to higher-quality raw materials like iron ore lumps being required, potentially driving up prices.

site_title: Caution abounds as US$ hovers at 7-week high
summary: The US dollar reached its highest levels in 7 weeks, stabilizing at a 7-week high after a perceived increase in chances of a US interest rate rise by September. Hedge funds have revived expectations of a US currency rally, driven by stronger data and a shift in money markets. However, caution prevails due to the US election year and market skepticism about the dollar's slide. Many investors remain cautious, preferring to bet against Asian currencies, and a broad-based dollar rally is seen as unlikely, driven instead by relative policy biases.

site_title: Clapton returns to blues roots on new album
summary: Eric Clapton releases his 23rd studio album, "I Still Do", revisiting blues roots and collaborating with producer Glyn Johns, who worked on his classic album "Slowhand". The album features original tracks "Spiral" and "Catch the Blues" and covers songs by blues greats, including Leroy Carr and Bob Dylan. Clapton, 71, has stated he prefers to return to the studio rather than put out a best-of compilation, saying the album is "fresh" and "me, at this moment".

images.alt_text: In his first album as a septuagenarian, guitar virtuoso Eric Clapton is revisiting the blues roots that shaped his distinctive sound.

site_title: Whistleblowing guide for accountants timely
summary: The International Ethics Standards Board for Accountants (IESBA) is set to issue new provisions guiding accountants on whistleblowing, following the Panama Papers scandal. The standard, expected to be issued in a few months, will provide clearer guidelines for accountants to report suspected non-compliance with laws and regulations. Non-auditors will be required to refer cases to higher internal levels of authority, while auditors will need to report issues to management and the board of directors or audit committees. The move aims to balance the need to uncover wrongdoing with the potential impact on business relationships and career prospects.

site_title: Philips opens first telehealth centre in S'pore for remote patient treatment
summary: Philips has opened Singapore's first telehealth centre, a 38,000 sqm facility equipped with cloud-based healthcare equipment, enabling hospitals to remotely treat patients at home. The centre can treat 5,000 patients and aims to reduce hospitalisation needs by optimising public health resources. Philips has partnered Eastern Health Alliance and Changi General Hospital since 2014 to develop a telehealth programme for heart patients, showing success in reducing hospital admissions. The centre will also provide training for healthcare technicians and practitioners.

site_title: Millennials show French banks they're falling behind in branch cuts
summary: Millennials in France are increasingly moving away from traditional banking services, with 26-year-old Jean-Baptiste Esmenjaud stating he hasn't set foot in a bank in over five years. This trend may push French banks to reduce branches, as they lag behind European peers in branch closures. Despite French banks' large branch networks, only 21% of clients visit branches several times a month, down from 52% in 2010. To adapt, banks will invest in new technology, with French banks expected to spend $15.3 billion on new technology in 2020.

site_title: New rules relax prospectus burden for retail bonds from quality issuers
summary: Singapore authorities have launched new frameworks to boost the retail bond market, allowing good-quality issuers to sell debt to mom-and-pop investors without a prospectus. The seasoning framework requires bonds to be sold to institutional investors and listed for at least six months before being sold to retail investors with a simplified product highlight sheet. The Exempt Bond Issuer Framework also allows issuers to offer bonds directly to retail investors without a prospectus if they meet stricter eligibility criteria. The move aims to widen the range of fixed income products and increase liquidity in the market.

site_title: SembMarine unit's Batam centre aims at retaining core skilled worker group
summary: SembCorp Marine's PT SMOE has inaugurated a training and learning centre in Batam, aiming to retain its core group of skilled workers for domestic and international projects. The 85-hectare yard has successfully delivered complex oil and gas projects, including those in Indonesia and Russia. The centre will partner with local institutions to provide relevant training for local employees, and the company plans to expand its workforce to over 9,000 by delivering more LNG module fabrication works. The centre will serve as a hub for sharing knowledge and exchanging ideas, enabling PT SMOE to sustain its competitive advantage in the industry.

site_title: QIA said to be in exclusive talks to buy Asia Square Tower 1
summary: Qatar Investment Authority (QIA) is in exclusive talks to buy Asia Square Tower 1 in Singapore for approximately S$3.35 billion, based on a price of S$2,700 per square foot of net lettable area. The 43-storey tower features 1.2 million sq ft of offices and 40,000 sq ft of retail space. The deal, if finalized, would be one of the largest property transactions in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: EgyptAir jet missing after mid-air plunge; floating objects found
summary: An EgyptAir Airbus 320 jet carrying 66 passengers and crew disappeared mid-air while flying from Paris to Cairo, plunging from 37,000 feet to 15,000 feet before vanishing from radar screens. Debris, including two lifevests and pieces of plastic, were found 230 miles south of Crete. Egyptian officials are cautious not to speculate, but the aviation minister suggests a terrorist attack is more likely than a technical failure. The cause remains unknown, and investigations are ongoing.

images.alt_text: Family members of passengers on the downed EgyptAir flight have been transported by bus to a gathering point at Cairo airport. The flight carried 30 Egyptian and 15 French nationals, along with citizens of 10 other countries.

site_title: Volvo rolls out 2 concept cars built on common Geely platform
summary: Volvo unveiled its first two concept cars based on the Compact Modular Architecture (CMA) platform, a common platform with Chinese owner Geely. The cars, a small car and an SUV, aim to secure a premium market foothold. Volvo seeks to boost sales and profit margins, which have improved over the past two years but still lag those of premium carmakers like Daimler. The CMA platform is part of Volvo's strategy to grow and establish itself in the premium market.

site_title: Motor-mouth Gervais is lost for words in latest outing
summary: Ricky Gervais' Netflix film "Special Correspondents" is a remake of the French farce "Envoyés très spéciaux" and stars Gervais alongside Eric Bana, Kevin Pollak, and Vera Farmiga. Despite being a remake of a well-known comedy, the film is surprisingly mild and lacks laughs, with Gervais' usual mean streak missing. The film follows two reporters who get stuck in New York and fabricate a story to gain media attention, but things spiral out of control. The film is panned for its cliched plot, thin characters, and pacing issues, earning a rating of C.

images.alt_text: Egoistic journalist Frank Bonneville (Eric Bana, left) is stranded in New York with loser radio sound engineer Ian Finch (Gervais) after the latter loses their passports and plane tickets.
Dylan Tan

site_title: Future looks good for Genting Hong Kong: group chairman
summary: Genting Hong Kong's cruise business is expected to deliver in the longer term, according to group chairman Lim Kok Thay, despite the company's 17.8% stake in Genting Hong Kong being difficult to dispose of. The stake is valued at US$0.29 per share, and the disposal mandate is set to expire in July. Lim believes the cruise business has the potential to grow compared to other segments, and the company is exploring ways to increase revenue, such as collateralising borrowings against the delivery of new ships.

site_title: Future Singapore to be more than just about economics: Halimah
summary: Speaker of Parliament Halimah Yacob stated that Singapore's future, 50 years from now, will be defined more by social terms than economic ones. Economic vibrancy is important, but life should be more than economics and GDP. Halimah emphasized the need to address social development factors, such as culture and values, to achieve the desired society. She also highlighted the importance of businesses competing based on quality and excellence, rather than just cost and price, to attract and retain customers. Halimah paid tribute to late founding prime minister Lee Kuan Yew, who transformed Singapore into a first-world economy through trustworthiness and honouring one's word.

site_title: Monsanto gets unsolicited takeover offer from Germany's Bayer
summary: Monsanto, the world's largest seed maker, received a non-binding takeover offer from Germany's Bayer AG, seeking to merge the companies and create the world's largest supplier of seeds and farm chemicals. The proposal, valued at potentially over $42 billion, comes as the seed and crop-chemicals industry faces consolidation due to low crop prices. Monsanto's board is reviewing the proposal, which would strengthen Bayer's seed business and help the company reduce its reliance on the agriculture industry.

site_title: Open season
summary: The OPEN, a pre-festival of the Singapore International Festival of Arts, features an eclectic selection of events, including fashion, music, and film. Fashion events include "Models Never Talk," a performance art piece featuring seven former top models recalling their experiences working with famous designers, and "Dances and Ceremonies: Spring/Summer 2017," a fashion show by Mexican designer Carla Fernandez. Music performances include a concert by Chinese-Muslim rock star Perhat Khaliq and Indonesian avant-garde rock band Senyawa. The OPEN also features an indie cinema program with 23 selected films, including "The Bacchus Lady" and "Tangerine."
