site_title: Genting HK confident about its 'risky' cruise market splash
summary: Genting Hong Kong (GHK) is optimistic about its "risky" cruise market splash, despite a decade-long delay in ship delivery. The company, which acquired German shipbuilders to expedite the process, is investing heavily in the market, with a focus on Asia, particularly China. GHK's chairman, Lim Kok Thay, believes the cruise industry is underserved and has room for growth, driven by increasing demand and limited shipyard capacity. The company expects its new ships to make waves in the market, with a sharp turn upwards in ticket sales and revenue.

site_title: Big bang for startup crowdfunding opens with a fizzle
summary: Everyday investors can now buy shares in private US startups, but the new "crowdfunding" market is off to a slow start. Only around 35 startups, including a distillery and donut store, were offering stakes on nine funding websites by Wednesday morning. The rule change, which took effect this week, allows anyone to invest in private US companies. Despite the potential for a "big bang," the market has been sluggish, with many startups struggling to attract investors.

site_title: Increasing fintech won't displace banks: Moody's
summary: Moody's Investors Service reports that fintech won't displace banks, despite the rise of financial technology firms. The ratings agency estimates 4,000 fintech-related startups globally, with $19 billion in venture capital investment. Banks retain competitive advantages, including large customer bases and regulatory experience. While fintech may shift the industry, a major competitive reversal is unlikely. The growth of fintech is driven by millennials, but it will take a few years for this generation to dominate financial services consumption. Banks will continue to work alongside and compete with fintech firms.

site_title: ST Telemedia buys 74% of Tata Comm's data centre business
summary: ST Telemedia acquired a 74% stake in Tata Communications' data centre business in India and Singapore, valued at approximately US$640 million. This deal ties ST Telemedia more closely with tech giant Amazon and allows the company to control 14 data centres in India and three in Singapore. The acquisition is expected to make ST Telemedia one of the largest homegrown data centre players in Asia, with a presence in the region's growing data centre market.

site_title: Agenda for G-7 meeting in Japan this weekend will be a packed one
summary: The G-7 finance minister and central bank governor meeting in Japan this weekend will focus on the threat of currency wars and volatile capital flows. As monetary policy normalizes, policymakers are concerned that currency fluctuations could lead to a financial crisis, potentially worse than the 1997 Asian financial crisis or 2008 global financial crisis. The meeting aims to strengthen the "Global Financial Safety Net" and address issues like infrastructure financing, tax havens, and money laundering, with Japan pushing for greater coordination among G-7 nations and institutions.

site_title: Nokia name to return after licence deal
summary: Nokia's mobile phone brand is set to return to the market after a 10-year licensing deal with HMD global Oy, a company backed by former Nokia executive Jean-Francois Baril. The deal allows HMD to create Nokia-branded smartphones and tablets, with Foxconn manufacturing the products. Nokia will receive royalties on sales, covering brand and intellectual property rights. The company had sold its mobile phone business to Microsoft in 2014 and now focuses on telecom network equipment. The partnership aims to leverage Nokia's strong brand recognition in developing markets, particularly Asia and South America.

site_title: CDL to home in on strategic investments in real-estate firms
summary: CDL plans to deploy S$5 billion in overseas investments and funds management over a five-year period. The group's CEO, Grant Kelley, aims to capitalize on the current price discount in equity markets by acquiring mature companies in key overseas markets, including Australia, China, Japan, the UK, and the US. With S$3.3 billion in cash reserves, CDL will focus on patient acquisitions, prioritizing strong governance and quality assets. The group may consider a smaller-scale PPS offering this year, shifting focus to overseas acquisitions, following a more volatile market.

site_title: Supply Chain Asia in tripartite deal to woo young professionals
summary: Supply Chain Asia (SCA) signed a tripartite Memorandum of Understanding (MOU) with the National Trades Union Congress (NTUC) and the Singapore Workforce Development Agency (WDA) to attract and train young professionals in the logistics and supply chain sector. This partnership aims to boost the sector and enhance the skills of its workforce. The MOU was witnessed by NTUC secretary-general Chan Chun Sing, marking a significant development for the industry.

Dairy Farm International (DFI) reported its biggest earnings decline in over a decade due to weak macro growth and added costs from expanding in Indonesia and Singapore. SATS Ltd's share price is trading near peak valuations, making its stock a sell due to moderating EPS growth.

site_title: Indonesian tin output seen falling to 14-year low
summary: Indonesian tin production is expected to reach a 14-year low of 60,000 tonnes this year due to weak prices and government regulations. The country's largest tin producer, PT Timah, accounts for about half of Indonesia's total output. The government has imposed restrictions on production, taxation, and quality standards, leading to a decline in smelter capacity and ore supplies. Industry estimates suggest a production range of 62,000-63,000 tonnes this year, a significant drop from 2015's 67,350 tonnes.

site_title: Seletar Airport to get new passenger terminal building
summary: Seletar Airport in Singapore is set to receive a new passenger terminal building by end-2018, aiming to improve handling capacity and enhance service offerings. The new 7,000 sq m terminal will accommodate turboprop operations, shifting them from Changi Airport and freeing up capacity for jet aircraft operations. The terminal will cater to both business aviation and commercial passengers with dedicated facilities. The upgrade aims to support growing general aviation activities and traffic growth at the airport, reinforcing Singapore's position as a vibrant aviation hub.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Temasek, CIC, KKR said to be in 2nd round of Yum China stake sale
summary: Temasek, China Investment Corp, and KKR & Co are in the second round of bidding for a 20% stake in Yum China, the Chinese unit of Yum Brands Inc. The stake, valued between $8 billion and $11 billion, is part of Yum's plan to spin off its 7,205 China restaurants by the end of 2016. The second round of bids is due by the end of the month, with some bidders keen to buy control of the China business. However, Yum is sticking to the minority stake sale plan for tax efficiency.

site_title: Make the best of your living space
summary: A home makeover should be welcoming and satisfying, while also being as fuss-free as possible. The article advises making the best of one's living space by sharing personal feedback on BT's products and services. Meanwhile, global news includes a low-profile property trust's data centre gambit, a decline in US weekly jobless claims, and China's efforts to aid employment amid trade tensions.

site_title: Parsing nebulous data into work of art
summary: The Big Bang Data exhibition, now in Asia, showcases artworks created from vast amounts of data, transforming it into immersive installations and art pieces. The exhibition features 25,000 stars representing active listed companies in the Asian time zone, with each star's size and glow determined by market capitalization and trading volume. The project, led by artists Lise Autogena and Joshua Portway, has undergone significant changes since its debut in 2000, incorporating new technologies and data sources. The exhibition raises questions about personal privacy and the impact of data on our lives, highlighting the need for responsible data management and usage.

site_title: Iswaran to deliver keynote at BT forum
summary: Minister for Trade and Industry S Iswaran will deliver the keynote address at The Business Times Leaders' Forum on May 31, replacing Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat. Iswaran will also participate in a panel discussion on Singapore's future ecosystem, co-chaired by the Committee on the Future Economy (CFE).

site_title: Japan fare's street cred
summary: The Super Japan Matsuri, a traditional outdoor Japanese street food celebration, was held at the Esplanade in Singapore as part of the Esplanade's Super Japan Festival. The event, which replicated a popular summer event in Japan, featured nine stalls selling Japanese food and games, as well as a chindonya show and craft workshops. The festival, which was the first of its kind organized by the Esplanade, aims to introduce a new element to the outdoor festival and provide an authentic experience of Japanese culture. It is part of a new programme that will be held once every three years, focusing on a different region and culture each time.

site_title: X-Men loses the plot with one sequel too many
summary: X-Men: Apocalypse, the 9th film in the franchise, has received criticism for its overstuffed plot and inability to save the series from digital demise. Despite Bryan Singer's return as writer and director, the film's attempt at fan service falls flat, resulting in a confusing and unmemorable experience. The movie's 2.5-hour runtime barely accommodates its numerous characters and story arcs, and even its action sequences fail to leave an impression. The film's poor reception is a stark contrast to its predecessors, leaving fans and critics alike feeling fatigued by the superhero genre.

site_title: Former BSI banker likely to face new charges
summary: Former BSI banker Yeo Jiawei is likely to face new charges in connection with 1Malaysia Development Berhad, following an ongoing probe into illicit transactions. Prosecutors are scrutinizing documents related to a $11.95 million transfer in 2013, which Yeo allegedly forged to facilitate the transfer. The prosecution seeks to deny Yeo bail, citing his role in complex, cross-border financial transactions. Yeo's lawyer argues that the prosecution already has sufficient evidence and should release him on bail to prepare his defense. A district court judge has ordered Yeo to be remanded until May 24.

site_title: JPMorgan says the biggest risk for Taiwan stocks is Apple, not China
summary: Taiwan's stock market is under pressure due to a slowdown in the global smartphone business, with Apple's first quarterly sales decline in 13 years being a major concern. JPMorgan Asset Management and BlackRock Inc say the bigger risk for Taiwan's US$841 billion stock market is the decline in the global smartphone market, rather than the ascension of independence-leaning President Tsai Ing-wen. Investors have pulled a net $2.2 billion from Taiwan's shares this quarter, with the Taiex Index falling 4.5% due to falling profits at technology companies, including Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co and Hon Hai Precision Industry Co.

site_title: Jump in foreign-held companies set up in Q1
summary: Foreign-held companies set a record in Singapore's Q1 2016 business formations, accounting for 37% of newly formed companies. This is a significant increase from the 24% in Q4 last year. Chinese, Indian, and Malaysian investors dominated, with registrations from countries such as the US, Australia, and Japan also rising. Despite a 4.23% drop in business formations compared to the previous quarter, the overall number of registrations increased by 8.7% compared to the same period in 2015.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Trade ties with China likely first key obstacle for new Taiwan leader
summary: Taiwan's new leader, Tsai Ing-Wen, is set to face an early test with China over a proposed "supervision law" that could paralyze trade between the two rivals. The bill, which requires government consent for talks with China, has angered China and the Taiwanese business community, which fears it will harm the economy. Tsai's Democratic Progressive Party (DPP) sees it as a way to add transparency to negotiations, while critics say it will stall relations with China, the island's largest export market. China has vowed to oppose the bill, and its leaders have not ruled out using force to bring Taiwan under their control.

site_title: Drop in US jobless claims bolsters hopes of economic rebound
summary: The US Labor Department reported a 16,000 decrease in initial unemployment claims to 278,000 for the week ended May 14, the largest drop since February. This decline, along with other economic data, suggests the economy is regaining speed after a first-quarter slump. Claims have been below 300,000 for 63 consecutive weeks, a threshold associated with a strong job market. The drop in claims bolsters hopes of an economic rebound, with the four-week moving average of claims rising 7,500 to 275,750.

site_title: Fed seriously considering June interest rate hike, meeting minutes show
summary: The US Federal Reserve is seriously considering raising interest rates in June, contrary to market expectations. Fed officials believe the economy is showing signs of a rebound from a weak winter, and most think it's likely to raise rates in June if conditions continue to strengthen. The Fed's April meeting minutes revealed that officials are thinking about a June increase, with some officials expressing frustration over market participants' assessments of the likelihood of a rate hike. However, the decision remains uncertain, and the Fed will continue to monitor economic data before making a final decision.

site_title: Group calls on US to speed up favorable regulations for autonomous cars
summary: A group called Securing America's Future Energy (Safe) has called on US policymakers to speed up regulations for autonomous cars, aiming for their commercialization "once they are as safe as today's cars." The report seeks federal rules pre-empting state standards, revising NHTSA regulations, and creating a federal program for addressing liabilities. Safe also aims to reduce the value of the federal electric vehicle tax credit and create a single office at the US Transportation Department to oversee autonomous vehicle deployment. The group's goals include boosting fuel efficiency standards, increasing US energy production, and reducing oil use by 2040.

site_title: Weighing the ups and downs of entering Iran
summary: Singaporean businesses face challenges in entering Iran, including lengthy visa applications and high transaction costs. Despite these hurdles, Singapore companies are still attracted to Iran's vast oil and gas reserves, with some signing bilateral agreements during South Korea's visit to the 2016 Iran oil show. Iran aims to boost efficiencies and scale its oil and gas value chain, but faces skepticism over its ability to meet its $100 billion foreign direct investment needs. Local content requirements and geopolitical risks also pose challenges, with some companies hesitant to enter the market due to concerns about business insurance and transfer of funds.

site_title: Drama lays bare struggles with autism
summary: A heart-wrenching play, "Falling," by Tracie Pang, tells the story of a family struggling to raise their severely autistic son, Josh. The play follows mother Tami, father Bill, and daughter Lisa as they navigate their son's unpredictable behavior and emotional struggles. With a realistic set and outstanding performances, particularly by Tan Kheng Hua and Adrian Pang, the play sheds light on the challenges of raising an autistic child. A live discussion follows each performance, raising awareness about autism and its impact on families.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Oil down over 2% as dollar soars on US rate hike fears
summary: Crude oil prices fell over 2% on Thursday as the dollar surged on US rate hike expectations. The US dollar index hit a near two-month high, making oil less attractive to holders of the euro and other currencies. Oil prices had rallied earlier in the week on supply outages, but the dollar's surge prompted investors to cash out of long positions. Brent futures fell $1.40 to $47.53 a barrel, and WTI fell $1.30 to $46.89 a barrel. Analysts say the dollar's surge may pause but not stop the recovery in crude prices.

site_title: Worry over defaults in First Sponsor's property financing business may prove unfounded
summary: First Sponsor Group's property financing business, which yields a 100% gross profit margin, has faced loan defaults of 87% of its loan portfolio. However, the defaults are expected to result in a windfall for the company, as the loans are secured by valuable collateral in first-tier Chinese cities. The company's strong balance sheet and low gearing ratio also suggest it can weather the defaults. Despite the challenges, analysts see potential re-rating catalysts, including the disposal of non-core assets and the low loan-to-value ratio, which could lead to a stock price re-evaluation.

site_title: Blue diamond sells for record US$50.6m
summary: A 14.62-carat blue diamond, known as the Oppenheimer Blue, was sold at a record US$50.6 million at an auction in Geneva, surpassing its pre-auction valuation of $38-45 million. The diamond, which is the largest Fancy Vivid Blue stone ever sold at auction, was purchased by an anonymous buyer. This sale follows a recent surge in the value of precious stones, with Sotheby's selling a 15.38-carat Fancy Vivid Pink diamond for US$31.6 million earlier in the week. The sale highlights the increasing investment in rare gems among ultra-rich individuals as a safeguard against market volatility.

site_title: EgyptAir plane fell 22,000 feet, swerved sharply twice: Greek minister
summary: An EgyptAir flight carrying 66 people lost contact over the eastern Mediterranean, 130 nautical miles from the Greek island of Karpathos, between Crete and Rhodes. The plane, flying from Paris to Cairo, made two sharp turns before disappearing from radar at around 10,000 feet. Despite a pilot's last communication with Greek controllers, there are no clear results from the search. Greece has dispatched search planes and a frigate, and is seeking satellite imagery from other countries to aid the investigation.

site_title: Making the most of the social media opportunity
summary: Singapore has become a leading social media society, with over three times the global average of users per capita. Businesses can reach millions through social media, but many are uncertain about its benefits and management. Social media enables businesses to listen to customers, understand their perceptions, and shape their message in real-time. However, there are risks, such as misinterpreting trends or failing to manage online conversations. Businesses must use "social intelligence" tools to analyze data and identify opportunities, and consider the broader implications of their messages to avoid failures, such as a fast food company's ill-fated tweet about a trending domestic violence message.

site_title: RIOgaleão launches revamped Tom Jobim International Airport following two billion real investment (Amended)
summary: Brazil's revamped Tom Jobim International Airport has been inaugurated after a two billion real (S$783 million) investment. The revamped airport features a new pier, improved facilities, and enhanced services. The project was undertaken by a consortium led by Odebrecht TransPort, Changi Airports International, and Infraero, with Changi Airport Group owning a 20.4% stake. The airport took over under a 25-year concession contract in August 2014.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower as rate hike looms
summary: US stocks opened lower on Thursday, falling 0.37% due to declining oil prices and concerns over the Federal Reserve's potential interest rate hike as early as next month. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 65.67 points to 17,460.95, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq composite also declined.

site_title: Jazz wunderkind
summary: Thirteen-year-old Indonesian-born jazz pianist Joey Alexander has garnered a standing ovation at the Grammys and released a debut album, "My Favorite Things." He received two Grammy nominations for Best Improvised Jazz Solo and Best Jazz Instrumental Album, a surprise for a 13-year-old. Alexander's music is inspired by various sources, including the city of New York and his family's support. He credits his father, a tour operator, for introducing him to jazz and continues to pursue his passion without considering an alternate career.

site_title: HSBC to close half of India branches in digital banking push
summary: HSBC plans to close nearly half of its 50 branches in India, focusing on digital banking to expand its consumer business. The move aims to improve earnings hurt by compliance costs, as part of CEO Stuart Gulliver's global network restructuring. HSBC remains committed to India, where it is also shutting its global private banking operations, and the country was the fourth-biggest contributor to group earnings in 2015.

site_title: W Hotel keen on downtown Singapore presence
summary: W Hotel Worldwide is exploring options for a second hotel in downtown Singapore, aiming to complement its existing property at Sentosa. Anthony Ingham, global brand leader, stated that the company is looking for the "right piece of land, right time and right partner" before making a decision. A downtown location could potentially be the flagship W hotel, but no further details have been announced.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: 2015 sets a vintage high-water mark
summary: The 2015 vintage is being hailed as a defining vintage, with ideal growing conditions and high-quality grapes across various wine regions, including Italy, Burgundy, and Bordeaux. The article highlights the exceptional quality of Bordeaux wines, particularly Chateaux Ausone, Vieux Chateau Certan, Le Pin, Figeac, Leoville Barton, and Langoa Barton. Prices for top Bordeaux wines are expected to be high, with the opening price of Chateau Pontet Canet at 75 euros per bottle. Overall, the 2015 vintage is considered a rare and exceptional year for wine production, with wines showcasing richness, power, complexity, balance, freshness, and class.

site_title: UBS to cut investment banking jobs in cost-savings plan: sources
summary: UBS Group AG is cutting investment banking jobs as part of a cost-saving plan to reduce revenue losses. At least a dozen London-based employees in the securities unit have lost their jobs, primarily in equities, debt capital markets, and leveraged finance. The move follows a 64% decline in first-quarter profit, partly due to a challenging revenue environment. The bank aims to achieve a net savings target of 2.1 billion francs. Global investment banks' second-quarter revenue is expected to decline 24%, with UBS' advisory and trading revenue expected to drop 28%.

site_title: Airplane lifejackets found in Egyptair search
summary: Greek authorities found aircraft debris, including two lifejackets, 230 miles south of Crete. The debris is believed to be from the missing EgyptAir aircraft that vanished from radar screens early Thursday. The search for the aircraft continues, but no further information on the cause of the disappearance has been released.

site_title: Update: EgyptAir flight crashes in Mediterranean with 66 on board
summary: An EgyptAir flight from Paris to Cairo carrying 66 people crashed in the Mediterranean on May 19, 2016, with possible wreckage spotted off a Greek island. The plane vanished from radar screens without sending a distress signal, raising fears of a repeat of the Islamic State's bombing of a Russian passenger plane in October 2015. Egyptian officials suspect a terrorist attack, while French authorities are investigating all possibilities. A search mission is underway, with French, Egyptian, and Greek aircraft and naval vessels participating.

site_title: Container shipping firms' costs soar on new fuel rules: OECD
summary: Container shipping firms face increased costs due to new sulphur emissions regulations, resulting in a $500 million annual increase. The regulations, implemented in 2015, require ships to use lower-sulphur fuel, leading to higher costs for the industry. The Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD) estimates that the global sulphur cap of 0.5% in 2020 could add $5 billion to $30 billion in annual costs, potentially transferring these costs to customers.

site_title: Two more lawsuits for Technics Oil & Gas as S$70.5m liftboat order falls through
summary: Technics Oil & Gas, a Singapore-based offshore marine player, is facing two more lawsuits related to loan repayments, totaling around S$5 million. The company's subsidiary, Technics Offshore Engineering Pte Ltd, has received writs of summons from two individuals claiming for repayment of loans with interest and legal costs. Additionally, a S$70.5 million liftboat order, previously announced in 2015, has fallen through due to non-fulfillment by the parties of a contract clause. The company will defend the legal actions and make further announcements as necessary.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysian shares ended the day lower, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index slipping 1.96 points to close at 1,633.76. A total of 1.39 billion lots worth RM1.80 billion were traded, with 355 gainers and 415 losers.

site_title: No weather issues at time of EgyptAir plane disappearance: Eurocontrol
summary: An EgyptAir plane with 66 people on board went missing on Thursday morning while flying from Paris to Cairo. Eurocontrol stated there were no weather issues at the time and in the vicinity of the disappearance. Egyptian, Greek, and French authorities are sending planes and boats to search for the missing plane. The cause of the disappearance is unknown.

site_title: Temasek says retail bond issue remains a possibility
summary: Temasek Holdings, a Singapore state investor, has expressed openness to a retail bond offering, pending new market rules. The Singapore Exchange has introduced a framework allowing retail investors to buy wholesale bonds initially offered to institutions, starting at S$1,000 denominations six months after listing on SGX. This move aims to expand access to investment opportunities for retail investors, following the announcement of new retail market rules by the central bank and exchange.

site_title: Singapore banks' group invites Swift to discuss cyber attacks
summary: Singapore's Association of Banks in Singapore (ABS) has invited Swift to discuss cyber attacks on banks in Bangladesh and Vietnam, which involved Swift's financial messaging service. The attacks, including a $81 million heist in Bangladesh, have prompted other central banks to urge banks to increase cyber security. ABS members have individually engaged Swift since the attacks emerged, and the meeting in June will focus on Swift's experience in managing the incidents. The FBI and private forensic experts are investigating the Bangladesh heist, which was followed by similar attacks in Vietnam.

site_title: Fed's Lacker sees strong June rate-hike case as risks dissipate
summary: Federal Reserve Bank of Richmond President Jeffrey Lacker stated that a June interest-rate increase is likely due to diminishing global risks, particularly those affecting China. Lacker expressed that the US economy is on track for improvement, contrary to market expectations. Following the release of the April Federal Open Market Committee minutes, odds of a June rate hike have increased to over 30%. Lacker also weighed in on the potential replacement of Fed Chair Janet Yellen, stating it would be problematic for a presidential candidate to dismiss a Fed chair based on party affiliation.

site_title: Singapore final GDP seen confirming growth stalled in Q1
summary: Singapore's first-quarter GDP is expected to confirm growth stalled at 0.0% in Q1, according to a Reuters poll of 11 economists. This would align with the government's advance estimate released in April. Year-on-year GDP growth is also expected to remain unchanged at 1.8%. The sluggish global demand poses risks to Asia's trade-reliant economies, particularly Singapore's.

site_title: Asia: Stocks mostly down, energy firms hit
summary: Asia stocks declined Thursday, with energy and commodity firms taking a hit, as investors reacted to the Federal Reserve's minutes suggesting a potential June interest rate hike. Energy shares fell 1.95-2.25% due to a stronger US dollar, while mining giants like BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto plummeted. Despite this, some banking-linked equities rose, and Singapore's STI index edged up 0.4% on Thursday.

site_title: Ex-BSI banker in 1MDB probe remanded for another week
summary: A Singaporean state court has granted prosecutors a one-week remand for former BSI Singapore banker Yeo Jiawei, who faces charges of money laundering, cheating, and obstructing justice in the 1MDB probe. Yeo, 33, has been remanded for a sixth time and is set to appear in court again next week. Prosecutors argue that a further remand is necessary to facilitate ongoing investigations, while Yeo's lawyer claims the prosecution already has all the evidence they need and should release him on bail.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Opec strategy working as Kuwait sees oil rising to US$50
summary: Kuwait's acting oil minister Anas Al-Saleh says Opec's strategy to defend market share rather than target a price is working, with oil prices expected to reach $50 a barrel by year-end. The strategy, which involves pumping to win customers, has been successful due to declining output from producers like US shale wells and growing demand. Kuwait plans to boost its oil production to 4 million barrels a day by 2020 and invest heavily in its industry, sticking to the market share strategy despite talks of an output cap failing in June.

site_title: EgyptAir flight from Paris feared crashed in Mediterranean
summary: An EgyptAir flight from Paris to Cairo with 66 people on board vanished from radar screens on May 19, 2016, with no distress call reported. The plane, which included 26 foreigners, crashed into the Mediterranean between Greek islands and the Egyptian coast, according to a Greek aviation source. A search and rescue mission was launched by Egypt and Greece, but no debris has been found yet. The cause of the disappearance is unknown, with EgyptAir stating "no theory can be ruled out" and French authorities calling a crisis meeting to investigate.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: ACRA investigates possible breaches at SingPost, the local corporate watchdog. Retail investors can now buy wholesale bonds on the Singapore Exchange, while the share of wholly foreign-held companies in Singapore increased to 37% in Q1 2016. A new passenger terminal building at Seletar Airport is set to be ready by end-2018. ST Telemedia agreed to buy a majority stake in Tata Communications' data centre business. Temasek and a consortium advanced to a second round of bidding for a minority stake in Yum China.

site_title: Turkey names new PM as Erdogan tightens grip
summary: Turkey's ruling party named Transport Minister Binali Yildirim as its new chairman, making him the country's new prime minister. Yildirim, a longtime ally of President Recep Tayyip Erdogan, will work closely with the president to implement changes to the constitution, potentially transforming Turkey into a presidential system. Yildirim is expected to prove a more pliable figure for Erdogan than his predecessor, Ahmet Davutoglu. The new prime minister's main tasks include negotiating a visa deal with the European Union and implementing Erdogan's "crazy" projects to create a "New Turkey."

site_title: Lufthansa CEO: Brexit could lead to lower travel demand
summary: Lufthansa CEO Carsten Spohr warned that a Brexit could lead to lower travel demand due to restricted economic growth. The UK's exit from the EU on June 23 may result in less demand from customers, according to Spohr. The airline is preparing for a potential crisis, but hopes it won't come to that. This prediction highlights the potential economic impact of Brexit on the airline industry and travel demand.

site_title: High food prices pose challenge to India's inflation target
summary: India's inflation target is challenged by rising food prices, which are expected to surge in the next three months due to thin supplies. Food inflation rose to 6.32% in April, breaking a recent slowing trend, and is a significant concern for the central bank. The country is struggling with its first back-to-back drought in nearly three decades, but expected good rains in the monsoon season may boost production and food supplies later in the year.

site_title: Incoming Taiwan govt likely to infuriate China from the word go
summary: Taiwan's new government, led by President Tsai Ing-wen, is set to pass a "supervision law" that requires legislative consent before, during, and after talks with China, potentially straining trade relations between the two. China has already condemned the bill, viewing self-ruled Taiwan as a breakaway province. The law aims to add transparency to negotiations, but business leaders fear it will harm the economy. The move is seen as a priority for the Democratic Progressive Party, which won elections in January on a platform opposed to China's growing economic influence.

site_title: Australia to stiffen underpayment fines after 7-Eleven scandal
summary: Australia plans to increase fines for underpayment of staff by tenfold, following a 2015 report on 7-Eleven franchisees threatening migrant workers with deportation if they complained of low pay. The government will also boost funding for the Fair Work Ombudsman by A$20 million, enhance its evidence gathering powers, and set up a taskforce to assist migrant workers. This move comes in response to the reported practice of underpaying workers as little as half the minimum wage.

images.alt_text: Australia unveiled plans on Thursday for a tenfold hike in fines for employers who underpay staff after 7-Eleven convenience store franchisees were accused of ripping off migrant workers, in what some experts believe is a widespread practice.

site_title: India's ruling party wins power in northeast, widens influence
summary: India's ruling party, the Bharatiya Janata Party (BJP), won power in the northeastern state of Assam, expanding its influence in the region. The BJP led in over 80 of the 126 seats, beating the main opposition Congress party. This victory helps Prime Minister Narendra Modi's right-wing nationalist government regain momentum after poll losses last year. The win marks a first for the BJP in Assam, a key state in India's volatile northeast.

site_title: China: Stocks edge down amid concern on interest rates, growth
summary: China's stocks edged down 0.2% on Thursday, marking near 3-1/2-month lows, amid concerns over interest rates and economic growth. Investors are cautious due to possible US interest rate hikes in June, following minutes from the Federal Reserve meeting. The State Council urged state-owned companies to restructure and cut capacity, leading to a mixed performance across sectors, with resource shares rising.

site_title: Technics Oil & Gas to 'vigorously defend action' after Soilbuild Reit's claims of unpaid rent
summary: Technics Oil & Gas has received a writ of summons from Soilbuild Reit claiming S$2.19 million in unpaid rent and S$11.8 million in continuing arrears for its premises. The oil and gas solutions provider has guaranteed its subsidiary's payments and plans to "vigorously defend the action." Technics Oil & Gas has engaged legal counsel and believes it has a good defense, despite a 2.9% decline in its stock price. The company is seeking to enforce the corporate guarantee and is expected to take legal action to resolve the dispute.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares slip as investors fear a US rate hike is coming
summary: Hong Kong stocks plummeted 0.7% to 19,694.33, the lowest close in 2-1/2 months, amid growing concerns of a US rate hike in June. Minutes from the Federal Reserve meeting showed officials felt the US economy was ready for a rate hike, putting pressure on the stock market. Energy shares led the decline, with almost all main sectors falling. Investors, already worried about China's economic health, became more cautious, with strategist Alex Fan stating that a US rate hike would exert pressure on the stock market.

site_title: Deep changes urged to avoid mass deaths from superbugs
summary: A report by the British government warns that 10 million people could die annually from 2050 due to antibiotic resistance unless drastic measures are taken. The Review on Antimicrobial Resistance recommends reducing antibiotic overuse, improving diagnoses, and investing in research to develop new antibiotics. The estimated cost of these measures is $40 billion over 10 years, significantly less than the potential cost of inaction. The report urges governments to take proactive action to address the growing threat of superbugs, which could lead to a return to the pre-antibiotic era.

site_title: UK retail sales bounce back in April despite clothing hit
summary: British retail sales rebounded in April, exceeding economists' forecasts with a 1.3% monthly growth, despite a decline in clothing sales due to cold weather. This rebound was largely attributed to a revision in March's figures, which showed a 0.5% decline rather than the initially reported 1.3%. The revised figures suggested that late data from large stores contributed to the correction.

site_title: European travel and leisure stocks fall after EgyptAir plane goes missing
summary: European travel and leisure stocks plummeted after EgyptAir reported a plane carrying over 60 passengers and crew missing. The sector underperformed the broader market, with shares in Thomas Cook, Accor, TUI, and InterContinental Hotels falling 1.8-3.7%. Airbus, Air France KLM, and Lufthansa also saw declines. Officials believe the Airbus A320 likely crashed into the Mediterranean Sea, sparking concerns about safety. The STOXX Europe 600 Travel and Leisure index fell 1.1%, its lowest performance since the COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Singapore shares close lower after FOMC minutes raise interest rate worries
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 1.3% to 2,740.11 after US Federal Reserve Open Markets Committee (FOMC) minutes raised interest rate worries, prompting traders to resume short selling. The STI had jumped 45 points on Tuesday, but the FOMC minutes suggested a June interest rate hike is likely, leading to a 37-point loss. Turnover was 1.2 billion units worth S$1.05 billion, with 132 rises and 269 falls. Global Logistic Properties (GLP) was a major loser, sliding S$0.06 to S$1.845 after reporting a 47.9% increase in FY16 profit.

site_title: Japan hopes to steer "frank" G7 debate on economy, tax evasion
summary: Japan is hosting a G7 finance meeting to discuss global economic uncertainties and tax evasion. Japanese Finance Minister Taro Aso aims to steer frank discussions on macro-economic policy, structural reform, and measures to combat tax evasion and money laundering. The meeting precedes a G7 leaders' summit where boosting global growth will be a priority. Japan has lobbied for coordinated fiscal action but faces resistance from Germany on fiscal discipline, while Tokyo and Washington disagree on yen exchange rates. The meeting may provide an opportunity for Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe to delay a planned sales tax hike.

site_title: Egyptian officials believe missing EgyptAir plane crashed into sea
summary: Egyptian officials believe a missing EgyptAir plane, carrying 66 people, probably crashed into the Mediterranean Sea. The Airbus A320 aircraft vanished from radar about 10 minutes after the last contact with the pilot. There was no distress call from the plane, and it disappeared while flying from Paris to Cairo on May 18, 2016.

site_title: IMF backs Saudi economic plan, fiscal policy
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has backed Saudi Arabia's economic reform plan, praising the kingdom's efforts to reduce its dependence on oil exports and cut spending to cope with a huge state budget deficit. The plan aims for a "bold and far-reaching transformation" of the Saudi Arabian economy, with the IMF welcoming the government's spending controls and changes to domestic energy prices. The IMF predicted the deficit would remain large this year, but said the government's financing of the deficit through a combination of financial reserves and debt was "appropriately adjusting" to the drop in oil prices.

site_title: Keppel Land beefs up hospitality business in Myanmar
summary: Keppel Land has expanded its hospitality business in Myanmar with the topping out of Junction City Tower in Yangon and the opening of an extension wing at Sedona Hotel Yangon. The developer holds a 40% stake in Junction City Tower, which has a net lettable area of 34,000 square meters. The new wing at Sedona Hotel Yangon will cater to business and leisure travelers with 431 rooms. This marks a significant growth in Keppel Land's hospitality arm, now boasting over 1,000 rooms in Myanmar, with the company remaining committed to the country's growth.

site_title: Sterling slips against firm US dollar, awaits UK retail sales data
summary: Sterling fell 0.1% to $1.4585 against the US dollar, reversing gains from the previous day. The drop comes ahead of UK retail sales data, which may impact the pound's value if it falls short of forecasts. A YouGov poll showed a 4-point lead for the "In" camp in the EU referendum, with 75% of betting odds favoring a Remain vote. The US dollar strengthened against major currencies following the release of Federal Reserve minutes, which rekindled expectations of a June interest rate hike.

images.alt_text: Sterling eased against a strong US dollar on Thursday, giving up some of its gains from Wednesday, when a poll showed support was growing for Britain to remain a member of the European Union.

site_title: Hanergy eyes home solar to move past US$19b collapse
summary: Hanergy Thin Film Power Group Ltd, a solar equipment maker, is developing new products and sales channels to distance itself from a US$19 billion market collapse and ongoing investigation by Hong Kong's stock market regulator. The company has signed agreements with over 1,300 dealers to sell residential solar power systems and plans to unveil a solar-powered car. Despite receiving 7,100 orders, Hanergy still faces challenges in the residential market due to land ownership and single-family house scarcity.

site_title: Retail investors can now buy wholesale bonds
summary: Retail investors in Singapore can now purchase wholesale bonds listed on the Singapore Exchange (SGX), with denominations as low as S$1,000. The bonds must meet specific criteria, including size, track record, and listing history. The new framework allows for re-taps without a prospectus, provided the six-month seasoning period is met. This move aims to increase accessibility to wholesale bonds for retail investors, while issuers must still meet certain requirements. The framework was introduced after a public consultation period in 2014.

images.alt_text: The framework will allow investors to buy wholesale bonds in denominations as small as S$1,000 if the bonds have been listed on SGX for at least six months.

site_title: China sets aside 27.64b yuan to finance steel, coal capacity cuts
summary: China's central government has allocated 27.64 billion yuan (S$5.84 billion) to finance capacity cuts in the steel and coal sectors. The funds will help pay for the relocation of 1.8 million laid-off workers and reward local authorities that exceed their closure targets. China aims to cut 100-150 million tonnes of crude steel and 500 million tonnes of coal production in the next 3-5 years to tackle capacity gluts. The funds will also support company and debt restructuring, as well as the liquidation of bankrupt assets.

site_title: French PM urges 'harsh' punishment over anti-police violence
summary: French Prime Minister Manuel Valls urged "harsh" punishment for those attacking police officers, following a violent protest in central Paris where a police vehicle was torched and two officers injured. Four suspects have been arrested, and a fifth is being held, in connection with the incident. Valls also called on protest organizers to prevent troublemakers from infiltrating demonstrations, which have seen over 350 security force members injured in recent weeks.

site_title: Australia, NZ: Australia shares extend losses, NZ falls more than 1%
summary: Australian shares fell 0.6% to 5,323.3, extending losses to nearly 1.5% over two days, weighed down by a stronger US dollar. New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index plummeted 1.1% to 6,903.6 points.

site_title: Temasek, CIC-KKR advance to second round of Yum China stake sale: sources
summary: Singapore's Temasek Holdings and a consortium including China Investment Corp and KKR & Co have advanced to a second round of bidding for a 20% minority stake in Yum China, the Chinese unit of Yum Brands. The second round of bids is due by the end of the month, with some bidders seeking control of the business. Yum Brands aims to spin off its 7,205 China restaurants by the end of 2016, amid pressure from activist investor Corvex Management. The entire China unit is valued between $8 billion and $11 billion.

site_title: ST Telemedia to buy majority stake in Tata Communications' data centre business
summary: ST Telemedia has agreed to buy a 74% stake in Tata Communications' data centre business in India and Singapore for an undisclosed amount. The business includes 14 data centres in India and three in Singapore. Tata Communications will retain a 26% stake. The acquisition is expected to enhance ST Telemedia's data centre capabilities in the region.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks open down
summary: Hong Kong and Shanghai stocks opened lower on May 19, 2016, following choppy trade on Wall Street and in Europe. The Hang Seng Index fell 0.6%, and the Shanghai Composite Index slipped 0.19%. Investors reacted to the increased likelihood of a US interest rate hike, which was more probable than initially thought.

site_title: China tells state firms to cut fat, improve competitiveness
summary: China's cabinet has ordered state firms to cut 20% of redundant management to improve competitiveness. The goal is to reduce management layers from five-nine levels to three-four levels in the next three years. This move aims to make state firms more market-based and efficient. By streamlining management, the government hopes to increase productivity and reduce costs, ultimately boosting the firms' competitiveness.

site_title: Oil prices extend pullback as dollar rises
summary: Oil prices retreated in Asia after a stronger US dollar, which makes dollar-priced oil more expensive, denting demand and hurting prices. The dollar rose after hawkish US Federal Reserve meeting minutes. Oil prices had previously surged due to production outages from wildfires in Canada's Fort McMurray area. A report showed a rise in US crude stockpiles, further contributing to the price pullback. The stronger dollar is expected to continue to impact oil prices, making dollar-priced oil more expensive.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks down ahead of Friday's inauguration of new president
summary: Taiwan's stocks declined on Thursday ahead of President Tsai Ing-wen's inauguration, driven by uncertainty over her stance on China, Taiwan's largest trading partner. Tsai's independence-leaning Democratic Progressive Party won a landslide victory in January. Investors fear Beijing may be dissatisfied with her words, potentially souring Taiwan's economic ties with China. The inauguration will be closely watched by investors on Friday.

site_title: DBS hires for potential Australian dollar covered bond
summary: DBS Bank has hired investment banks to arrange a covered bond investor update call, potentially leading to a transaction in Australian dollars. This would be DBS' first covered bond in Australian dollars, following its issuance of a US$1 billion three-year issue in Singapore last year. The covered bond is expected to be rated Aaa/AAA. The transaction is subject to market conditions.

images.alt_text: DBS Bank has hired Barclays, DBS, NAB, RBC Capital Markets and Westpac to arrange a covered bond investor update call on May 23.

site_title: China's desire for headline growth may hide longer-term risks
summary: China's economic growth target of 6.5-7% this year may mask longer-term risks, according to Moody's Investor Services. Despite unchanged growth forecast of 6.3%, increasing debt levels could lead to future problems. High leverage in China and emerging markets poses concerns, particularly if the US interest rate hikes, which could sap borrowers' ability to repay debts. Moody's warns that reliance on debt-fuelled stimulus could lead to a financial crisis and economic recession, and that emerging market corporate balance sheets are under pressure from debt payments and currency volatility.

site_title: Europe: Stocks slide at open
summary: European stocks declined at the start of trading on Thursday, following losses in Asia and on Wall Street. The Federal Reserve's minutes from its April policy meeting suggested a June interest rate hike, which tightened money conditions and strengthened the US dollar. The FTSE 100 index fell 0.7%, while the DAX 30 and CAC 40 indices also dropped 1% and 0.6%, respectively. Additionally, Bayer shares slid 7% after merger talks with Monsanto were announced.

site_title: Xiaomi sees China smartphone market peaking at 500 million units
summary: Xiaomi predicts China's smartphone market will peak at 500 million units annually, surpassing the current record of 438 million units in 2025. The company attributes its success to an online flash sales model that bypasses retail outlets and wireless carriers. Xiaomi's innovative approach enabled it to dominate China's market, and the company's chief financial officer, Shou Zi Chew, believes that 500 million is the natural ceiling for the market.

site_title: Hot stock: SingPost shares fall after regulatory probe
summary: SingPost shares plummeted 3.5% to a two-and-a-half month low after the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (ACRA) launched an investigation into possible breaches of the Companies Act. The company, which has significant shareholders including Singapore Telecommunications and Alibaba, was asked to furnish the ACRA with a special audit report on acquisitions. Only a summary of the report was released to the public, sparking concerns about the company's transparency. The decline comes ahead of Singapore's GDP data release and follows a five-day rally in the Singapore stock market.

site_title: Alanis Morissette says manager swindled millions
summary: Rocker Alanis Morissette has sued her former business manager, Jonathan Schwartz, for allegedly swindling her of $4.7 million from her savings between 2010 and 2014. Morissette claims Schwartz drained her assets, leading her to financial ruin, despite her instructions to live solely on her income and interest. The lawsuit also names GSO Business Management, where Schwartz was a partner, for failing to prevent the theft.

site_title: US$170b in Malaysia pensions cry out for more Islamic bonds
summary: Malaysia's Employees Provident Fund (EPF) is urging the government to increase the supply of Islamic bonds, or sukuk, to meet demand from the fund's planned Islamic retirement scheme. Currently, sukuk issuance accounts for 42% of government debt, with EPF aiming for 50% to expand the range of maturities and investor base. Boosting sukuk sales could also reduce arbitrage opportunities, with Islamic notes paying 3.99% compared to 3.84% on similar conventional securities.

site_title: Greece deploys ship, aircraft to search for EgyptAir plane
summary: Greece has deployed a ship and aircraft to search for the missing EgyptAir plane in the southern Mediterranean, approximately 130 nautical miles south of the island of Karpathos. A merchant ship's captain reported a "flame in the sky" in the area where the plane vanished from radar screens. Authorities are investigating the incident, but no further details have been released.

images.alt_text: Greece said it had deployed air assets and a frigate to an area in the southern Mediterranean where an EgyptAir aircraft vanished from radar screens early on Thursday.

site_title: DocuSign executive exodus raises questions at US$3b startup
summary: DocuSign, a US$3 billion startup, has lost four senior executives, including its operating chief, growth chief, product chief, and human resources chief, amid a search for its new CEO. The departures come as the company expands to over a dozen offices worldwide and adds customers in various industries. The company had already begun searching for its CEO, Keith Krach, who stepped down last year, and had identified a top candidate before he backed out for a better offer from another company. The exodus raises questions about the company's stability and future direction.

site_title: Taiwan's Ma sees unlikely comedy farewell video go viral
summary: Taiwan's outgoing President Ma Ying-jeou has released a comedy farewell video that has gone viral with over 5 million views, despite widespread criticism of his charisma. Ma's presidency was marred by his Beijing-friendly policies, which alienated the public and led to his plummeting support. His inability to connect with ordinary voters has been seen as a key factor in his fall from power. The video's unexpected humor has humanized Ma, but it's unclear if it will improve his legacy.

site_title: Media freedom still distant goal in Sudan: top editor
summary: Sudanese editor Osman Mirgani's newspaper, Al-Tayar, resumed printing after a five-month ban, but the risk of further suspension remains high due to the government's strict control over media freedom. The National Intelligence and Security Service (NISS) has confiscated print runs multiple times, and the country ranks near the bottom of a world press freedom index. Mirgani attributes the targeting to the newspaper's independent journalism and criticism of the government. Despite the challenges, Mirgani remains committed to his role as editor, stating that "real journalism" is essential for both the people and the government.

site_title: Seoul: Won, stocks end down as Fed keeps door open to June hike
summary: The South Korean won declined 0.8% to 1,191.7 against the US dollar after the US Federal Reserve indicated a possible rate hike in June. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) fell 0.5% to 1,946.78 points. This marks the second consecutive day of declines for both the won and shares, following the Fed's minutes.

site_title: Sydney housing stalls as election jitters sideline sellers
summary: Australia's housing market is experiencing a slump due to election uncertainty, with sellers choosing to sit on the sidelines. The market has seen a 20% decline in property listings and a 3.6% drop in new listings in Sydney. The main opposition Labour Party's pledge to end negative gearing has fueled concerns about the impact on the market. The election's outcome is uncertain, with a 51% to 49% lead for Labour in a recent poll. The government's tax proposals, including changes to superannuation contributions, are also contributing to the uncertainty, with some predicting a shift in investor demand towards property.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares end flat, energy stocks slump on oil price drop
summary: Tokyo shares closed flat on May 19, 2016, as investors weighed the likelihood of a US interest rate hike, while energy stocks plummeted after oil prices dropped to six-month lows. The Nikkei 225 index ticked up 0.01%, and the Topix index lost 0.14%.

site_title: Hong Kong launches fresh plan to fortify cyber security after Swift heist
summary: Hong Kong's central bank has launched the "Cybersecurity Fortification Initiative" to strengthen lenders' ability to protect their critical technology systems. The move follows recent global cyber attacks, including a $81 million heist in Bangladesh. The initiative aims to raise cybersecurity levels through a three-pronged approach and follows similar measures taken by other countries. The Hong Kong Monetary Authority will issue a formal circular to all banks requiring them to implement the initiative, which is seen as a response to the growing threat of cyber attacks in the financial community.

site_title: Update: EgyptAir flight from Paris to Cairo disappears from radar, search is underway
summary: An EgyptAir flight with 69 people on board, MS804, vanished from radar en route from Paris to Cairo on May 19, 2016. The plane, an Airbus A320-232, lost contact at 2:45 am local time, just inside Egyptian airspace. A search and rescue operation is underway. The flight's disappearance comes more than two years after Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370 vanished, and theories include mechanical failure, hijacking, or rogue pilot action.

site_title: New Zealand consumer confidence eases in May
summary: New Zealand consumer confidence eased slightly in May, reaching 116.2, according to the ANZ-Roy Morgan index. While still optimistic, this marks a slowdown from the previous month. ANZ chief economist Cameron Bagrie expects a 3% GDP growth for 2016 based on the Confidence Composite data.

site_title: Asia: Stocks, bonds drop with oil as Fed weighs June rate hike
summary: Asia's stocks, bonds, and currencies dropped as the Federal Reserve hinted at a June interest-rate hike, with the MSCI Asia Pacific Index falling to a six-week low. The US economy's strong performance has led to increased expectations of a rate hike, with the odds rising to 32% on Fed Funds futures. Commodities such as crude oil and zinc also declined, while the dollar strengthened against other currencies. The Fed's decision is seen as a response to the global economic slowdown and a push by Japan to stimulate its economy through fiscal spending.

site_title: Seoul: Won falls to near 9-wk low; stocks extend losses
summary: The South Korean won fell to its lowest level since mid-March at 1,189.6 per dollar, down 0.6% from Wednesday's close, amid signals of a potential US Federal Reserve interest rate hike in June. This led to losses for South Korean shares, with the Korea Composite Stock Price Index down 0.5% at 1,946.70. Investors are also watching upcoming global economic events, including an OPEC meeting and central bank policy meetings, which may impact currency and stock markets.

site_title: Australia, NZ: Australia shares dip after jobs data, NZ weak
summary: Australian shares slipped 0.6% on Thursday, following a second consecutive session of losses, led by energy and mining stocks. Domestic jobs data showed lower-than-expected employment growth. Meanwhile, New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index fell 0.46% as power companies led losses. Electronics retailer JB Hi-Fi jumped 4% after talks for a possible buyout, while James Hardie rose 6% on share buyback and positive earnings outlook.

site_title: Sharp spike in foreign-held companies setting up shop in Singapore
summary: Singapore saw a significant spike in foreign-held companies setting up shop, with a 37% increase in wholly foreign-held companies from 24% in October-December 2015 to 37% in January-March 2016. Local-owned companies dropped to 50%, while mixed-holding companies rose to 13%. The delay in the budget release and low interest rates from regional central banks contributed to this trend. Companies from various countries, including the US, China, and India, established subsidiaries in Singapore, with Indian and Chinese entrepreneurs leading investors.

site_title: FLASH: New passenger terminal building at Seletar Airport to be ready end-2018
summary: Singapore's Seletar Airport is set to receive a new passenger terminal building by the end of 2018, according to an earlier report from 2016.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index opened lower on Thursday, down 14.64 points to 1621.08. Volume was 12 million lots worth RM5.6 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 69 to 61.

site_title: Gold holds slump after Fed minutes point to possible June hike
summary: Gold prices slipped to a three-week low after the Federal Reserve hinted at a possible interest rate hike as early as June, according to minutes from its last meeting. The possibility raised odds of a rate hike to 32% from 4% earlier in the week. As investors gauge the impact of higher US borrowing costs on demand, gold retreated from a 15-month high, trading near US$1,260.18 an ounce.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Thursday on Fed rate rise talk
summary: Singapore stocks opened 0.2% lower on Thursday due to speculation of a US Federal Reserve interest rate hike in June, as released Fed meeting minutes suggested discussion of a potential hike. The Straits Times Index fell 6 points to 2,771.11. Losers outnumbered gainers 70 to 52, with Golden Agri-Resources being the most actively traded counter. The market reacted to the Fed's potential rate hike, causing a decline in Singapore stocks.

site_title: Philippine growth surges to three-year high on election spending
summary: The Philippine economy grew 6.9% in the first quarter, its fastest pace in almost three years, driven by election spending ahead of the May elections. The growth is expected to remain strong this year, fueled by remittances from Filipinos abroad and outsourcing industries. Incoming President Rodrigo Duterte plans to retain the economic priorities of the outgoing administration, which led to the nation's first investment-grade ratings. The economy is forecast to outperform in the region, with the central bank cutting its benchmark rate to a record-low of 3%.

images.alt_text: The Philippine economy grew at the fastest pace in almost three years last quarter, spurred by spending ahead of the May elections.

site_title: Google reveals use of 'thousands' of AI processors it designed
summary: Google has started using its custom-designed AI processors, called TensorFlow Processing Units, in its data centers, potentially disrupting traditional chip suppliers like Intel and Nvidia. Over the past year, Google has deployed "thousands" of these specialized chips, which are in addition to using standard central processing units and graphics processing units. The move aims to increase the performance of its artificial intelligence software, but Google maintains it still uses a mix of its own and other companies' chips.

site_title: Central Park re-opens secret sanctuary after 80 years
summary: New York's Central Park has reopened the Hallett Nature Sanctuary, a 4-acre woodland area that was hidden away for 80 years. The sanctuary, located near Fifth Avenue, was previously fenced off and allowed to overgrow. It has been reopened just in time for summer, providing a serene escape for the park's 43 million annual visitors. The area's reopening is a welcome addition to the park's natural offerings, offering a chance for New Yorkers to reconnect with nature in a previously inaccessible area.

site_title: Australian dollar drops to lowest since March after jobs data
summary: The Australian dollar fell to a two-and-a-half month low of US$0.7209 after mixed jobs data reinforced expectations of a potential interest rate cut. The drop was attributed to the mixed jobs data, which did not meet market expectations, and the Australian dollar is expected to target a major retracement level of US$0.7063 if it breaks below US$0.7212.

site_title: Australia's labour market resilient, keeps jobless rate low at 5.7%
summary: Australia's unemployment rate remained steady at 5.7% in April, with nearly 11,000 new jobs created. The jobless rate has been around 5.75% in recent months, and annual jobs growth was a healthy 2.1%. Full-time employment fell 9,300, while part-time jobs rose 20,200. The Australian dollar dropped to a two-and-a-half month low after the mixed jobs data, but bounced back to its original value. Despite slow wage growth, businesses' hiring intentions remained above long-run averages, indicating ongoing resilience in the labour market.

site_title: Brazil's Temer said to eye privatisations to plug budget gap
summary: Brazil's Acting President Michel Temer is studying the sale of state assets to shore up public accounts, including stakes in companies like Furnas Centrais Eletricas SA and Petrobras. The move aims to plug a near-record budget deficit and improve state-owned enterprise efficiency. A government task force will consider the sales, which could help reduce Brazil's budget gap. The news led to a 1.6% rally in Petrobras's preferred shares.

site_title: BOJ's ETF position risks becoming too big to exit, lawmaker says
summary: The Bank of Japan's massive ETF position, valued at 3.3 trillion yen (S$41.45 billion), poses a risk of becoming too big to exit, according to Democratic Party lawmaker Tsutomu Okubo. To manage liquidity and avoid large price distortions, Okubo suggests the central bank should drastically lower its presence in the stock market by stopping its annual ETF buying and reducing its ownership to 20-30%. This would prevent the BOJ from being unable to sell its holdings when needed, potentially leading to ETFs diverging from their theoretical prices.

site_title: Bayer makes preliminary offer to buy Monsanto
summary: Bayer has made a preliminary offer to acquire Monsanto, the world's largest seed company, in a deal that could be worth over $43 billion. The proposal comes amid a drive to consolidate the agricultural sector due to high inventories and low commodity prices. Monsanto's board is reviewing the proposal, which is subject to due diligence and regulatory approvals. The acquisition could raise US antitrust concerns due to the overlap in the seeds business, particularly in soybeans, cotton, and canola. Bayer's market value is $90 billion, and the deal would be larger than a recent acquisition by ChemChina.

images.alt_text: Monsanto Co, the world's biggest seed company, said on Wednesday it had received an unsolicited proposal to be acquired by German drug and chemicals maker Bayer AG, as high inventories and low prices for agricultural commodities spur a drive to consolidate the sector.

site_title: Two more people file claims to Prince's estate
summary: Two individuals, Brianna Nelson and an 11-year-old girl, have filed claims to Prince's estate, stating they are relatives of the late pop star. The claims are based on the fact that Prince's half-brother, Duane Nelson Sr, was omitted from a list of siblings in the original probate petition filed by Prince's sister, Tyka Nelson. If Prince left no will, his estate would be divided equally among his siblings and their nearest surviving descendants under Minnesota law. The claims come as a paternity claim by a federal prison inmate has cast doubt on Prince's estate.

site_title: Samsung Elec, Alibaba to team up on mobile payment systems
summary: Samsung Electronics and Alibaba Group Holding plan to announce a collaboration on mobile payment systems, allowing Samsung smartphone customers to use Alipay, a Chinese online payment platform. The tie-up was reported by South Korean media and has not been commented on by Samsung Electronics.

site_title: New passenger terminal building at Seletar Airport to be ready in end-2018
summary: The Civil Aviation Authority of Singapore and Changi Airport Group announced a tender for a new passenger terminal building at Seletar Airport. Construction is expected to begin in October 2016 and the new terminal is scheduled for completion by the end of 2018. The move aims to free up capacity at Changi Airport for jet aircraft operations, following the shift of turboprop aircraft operations from Seletar to the new terminal. This is part of the government's efforts to optimize the use of resources within the aviation system in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: US trade panel says TPP would have small positive effect on growth
summary: The US International Trade Commission (ITC) has released a report stating that the Trans-Pacific Partnership (TPP) would have a small positive effect on US growth, with a 0.15 percentage-point gain in gross domestic product by 2032, resulting in $42.7 billion in increased output and 128,000 more jobs. However, manufacturing output would be lower, and some sectors like auto parts and textiles would see reductions. The report contradicts Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump's claims that TPP would destroy US manufacturing jobs.

images.alt_text: The US International Trade Commission said on Wednesday that the sweeping pan-Pacific trade deal President Barack Obama wants Congress to approve before he leaves office would likely have only a small positive effect on US growth.

site_title: South Korea April producer price decline slows
summary: South Korea's producer prices fell at their slowest annual pace in 1.5 years in April, with a 3.1% decline from a year earlier, according to the Bank of Korea. This was the slowest annual pace of decline since December 2014. In monthly terms, the producer price index edged up by 0.2%, marking its fastest monthly gain since January 2014. The decline may be a welcome sign of easing deflationary pressures, potentially alleviating some economic concerns.

site_title: Oil extends drop as unexpected stockpile gain expands US glut
summary: US crude oil stockpiles unexpectedly increased by 1.3 million barrels last week, keeping supplies at their highest level in over eight decades. Oil futures slid 0.8% in New York, extending a decline for a second day, amid a surging US currency and concerns about a potential Federal Reserve rate hike in June. The global glut is easing, but oil prices may be capped by high inventories and producer hedging. West Texas Intermediate fell to $47.83 a barrel, while Brent lost 39 US cents to $48.54 a barrel.

site_title: Ringgit drops to two-month low as minutes boost US rate bets
summary: Malaysia's ringgit plummeted to a two-month low due to speculation of a US interest rate hike as soon as next month, following the Federal Reserve's minutes release. The US dollar surged, and US Treasuries fell, as Fed officials indicated a likely rate increase if the economy continues to improve. Malaysia's central bank is expected to hold interest rates for an 11th consecutive meeting. The decline in the ringgit is attributed to increased bets on US rate hikes, which could impact the country's economy.

site_title: For European banks, US assurances on Iran come with asterisks
summary: US Secretary of State John Kerry assures European banks that doing business with Iran is permissible, citing the US Treasury Department's Office of Foreign Assets Control (OFAC) as the authority to clarify sanctions. However, sanctions lawyers argue that OFAC's recommendations are often vague and noncommittal, creating uncertainty for companies. Despite lifted sanctions, US banks are still forbidden from doing business with Iran, and firms are reluctant to restart or launch relationships with Iran, Cuba, and Myanmar due to the ambiguity.

site_title: Suzuki says improper mileage tests used on 2.1 million cars
summary: Suzuki Motor Corp admitted to using improper fuel-economy testing methods on about 2.1 million vehicles sold in Japan, making it the second automaker to do so. The company used a tunnel to test fuel efficiency due to wind concerns at its proving grounds. However, proper testing showed the earlier results were within an acceptable range of deviation, meaning no revisions are needed. All 16 models currently sold in Japan were reviewed, but the issue does not affect vehicles sold overseas.

images.alt_text: Suzuki Motor Corp said it used fuel-economy testing methods that weren't compliant with Japan regulations on about 2.1 million vehicles sold locally, making it the second automaker in the country to admit having conducted improper checks.

site_title: Malaysia slowdown is test for new governor as some eye rate cut
summary: Malaysia's central bank, Bank Negara Malaysia, is expected to keep its benchmark interest rate unchanged at 3.25% despite a slowing economy and currency volatility. The rate of loan growth has eased, and the economy is forecast to expand at the slowest pace in seven years in 2016. Some economists, including those at Standard Chartered and Mizuho Bank, predict a rate cut to stimulate the economy, citing a difficult global environment and deteriorating growth conditions. The new governor, Muhammad Ibrahim, must balance the need for stimulus with maintaining monetary stability.

images.alt_text: In his first interest-rate meeting as governor of Malaysia's central bank, Muhammad Ibrahim must grapple with how to provide more stimulus to a slowing economy facing currency volatility and political tensions.

site_title: China central bank sets yuan midpoint at 3-1/2 month low after bullish Fed minutes
summary: China's central bank set the yuan/dollar midpoint rate at 6.5531, a 3-1/2 month low, following the US Federal Reserve's bullish minutes on a potential June interest rate hike. The dollar strengthened in Asian morning trading, reaching multi-week highs, amid expectations of a rate hike. The move weakened the yuan, which had partially factored in the dollar's global strength.

site_title: New Zealand April job ads rise: survey
summary: New Zealand's job advertisements rose 1.7% in April from the previous month, according to a survey by ANZ Bank, with a 4.6% increase on a year-over-year basis. This suggests a strong labor market, with economist Sharon Zollner stating that wage growth is likely to accelerate.

site_title: Asia: Stocks swing after Fed minutes, Japan gains on weaker yen
summary: Asian stocks fluctuated after minutes of the Federal Reserve's April meeting showed policy makers discussed raising interest rates as early as June. The yen weakened, boosting Japanese shares, while US stocks rose slightly. The MSCI Asia Pacific Index was little changed, and other regional markets also saw small gains or losses. The Fed's statement highlighted policy uncertainty, with traders now expecting a one-in-three chance of a rate hike next month.

site_title: Canada's Trudeau apologises after physical altercation in parliament
summary: Canada's Prime Minister Justin Trudeau apologized in Parliament after a physical altercation with opposition leaders. Trudeau rushed across the floor to hurry a legislator to his seat, was accused of elbowing another in the chest, and got into a shouting match with an opposition leader. The incident, which was caught on video, was an unusual outburst for the normally composed Trudeau. He apologized for the physical contact, stating it was "unadvisable" and "unacceptable" in the House of Commons.

site_title: KFC, balloons lift Yoma's Q4 earnings
summary: Yoma Strategic Holdings reported an 8.9% increase in its fourth-quarter net profit to S$8.89 million, driven by a 65.8% leap in revenue to S$45.7 million. The company's non-real estate businesses and its KFC franchise outlets in Myanmar contributed to the earnings growth. The real estate business also showed a gradual improvement following the transition of the Myanmar government after the 2015 election. Earnings per share and net asset value per share remained unchanged.

site_title: Chinese investor buys Aston Villa for reported £60m
summary: Chinese investor Dr. Tony Jiantong Xia has purchased Aston Villa Football Club for a reported £60 million, ending US-based owner Randy Lerner's two-year attempt to sell the club. Xia, who owns Recon Group, aims to return Villa to the Premier League's top six and establish a massive fan base in China. Villa is currently in the Championship, a two-tier system, after a dismal season under managerless leadership. Former Leicester boss Nigel Pearson and ex-Chelsea chief Roberto Di Matteo are reportedly leading candidates to become the new manager.

site_title: Mitsubishi Motors' scandal was an accident waiting to happen
summary: Mitsubishi Motors' president Tetsuro Aikawa resigned amid a scandal involving overstating fuel economy and improperly testing vehicles since 1991. The company lost 35% of its market value, and Nissan Motor Co will buy over one-third of Mitsubishi Motors, gaining control over major decisions. The scandal highlights Mitsubishi's troubled corporate culture, which former employees attribute to an insular environment that failed to absorb lessons from past scandals. Nissan will send its engineers to oversee Mitsubishi Motors, and a root-and-branch overhaul is required to break the company's chain of debilitating scandals.

site_title: US trade panel opens patent probe into Volkswagen hybrid vehicles
summary: The US International Trade Commission has launched an investigation into whether Volkswagen AG and its subsidiaries infringed on hybrid electric vehicle patents owned by Paice LLC. Paice claims it shared its patented technology with Volkswagen from 2001 to 2004, but the company ended the collaboration and shifted focus to diesel technology. A ruling against Volkswagen could hinder its hybrid vehicle strategy, which has been impacted by the company's emissions scandal. Paice is seeking an import and sale ban on Volkswagen, Audi, and Porsche hybrid vehicles in the US market.

site_title: ACRA investigating possible Companies Act breaches at SingPost
summary: The Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (ACRA) is investigating possible breaches of the Companies Act at Singapore Post (SingPost) following a joint special audit report. The report found former director Keith Tay was "arguably in breach of section 156(1) of the Companies Act" for not declaring his interest in the 2013 acquisition of Famous Holdings. Tay also breached fiduciary duties related to the deal and SingPost's acquisition of Famous Pacific Shipping (NZ) in 2015.

site_title: Chinese people most welcoming to refugees: Amnesty index
summary: Amnesty International's Refugees Welcome Index ranked China, Germany, and Britain as the world's most welcoming countries to refugees. In China, 46% of people said they would take refugees into their homes, while in Britain, 29% would do so. In contrast, Russia was ranked as the least welcoming, with 61% saying they would refuse refugees access to their country. The survey of over 27,000 people found that one in 10 people worldwide would be prepared to welcome refugees into their homes, but governments' responses are "badly out of touch" with their citizens' views.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares push higher in opening trade on weaker yen
summary: Tokyo shares rose 0.98% in opening trade, driven by a weaker yen, which boosted exporters. The Nikkei 225 index reached 16,807.46 and the Topix index advanced 0.82% to 1,349.30.
