summary: Singapore Reits' core-DPUs grew 0.8% year-on-year in Q1 2016, with organic growth challenging due to falling occupancy and rent reversions. Hotel Properties' first-quarter topline dipped 9.6% due to lower contributions from a development and hotel closures. Analysts maintain neutral views on S-Reits, citing low interest rates and suppressed yields, while recommending Mapletree Industrial Trust and Ascendas Reit for top picks. Meanwhile, property stocks are expected to remain range-bound due to policy concerns and developer stock discounts.

site_title: Is there room for co-living in S'pore?
summary: Co-living spaces, a concept inspired by millennial-generation values of openness, collaboration, and social networking, are being explored in Singapore despite initial hesitation due to cultural and economic factors. Despite two failed attempts, startups such as Shopback and XFERS are showing interest in co-living, citing its benefits for productivity and social innovation. For co-living to thrive in Singapore, rent must be cheap, and the space must be designed with aesthetics, flexibility, and services in mind. Corporates may also be attracted to customizable schemes for short-term projects, but there is currently no sign of co-living emerging as a trend for shared households.

site_title: Temasek raises healthcare investments, adds more ADRs of JD.com
summary: Temasek Holdings, a Singapore investment firm, has raised healthcare investments and added more American depositary receipts (ADRs) of JD.com. The firm bought ADRs of Beigene Ltd, Gilead Sciences Inc, Illumina Inc, and Regeneron Pharmaceuticals Inc, and added to its position in JD.com, increasing its holdings by 1.2 million shares. This move reflects Temasek's bets on industries benefiting from rising life expectancies and a growing middle class in emerging markets, with the healthcare industry expected to expand as populations age.

site_title: HSR fined, barred from en bloc deals for a year
summary: The Council for Estate Agencies (CEA) fined HSR International Realtors S$74,000 for two counts of acting for a client without declaring a conflict of interest. The agency is also barred from undertaking en bloc deals for one year, starting April 20, 2016, following an investigation into its management's approval of lead agent's incentive payments to four owners of Thomson View condo.

site_title: Government support for opportunity entrepreneurs vital
summary: Government support for opportunity entrepreneurs is crucial for driving economic growth. Opportunity entrepreneurs, who start businesses to exploit a potential opportunity, are more likely to grow their businesses, employ people, and introduce innovation. However, they make up only a small proportion of entrepreneurs, accounting for over 50% of net job creation in the UK between 2002 and 2008. Focusing on supporting these entrepreneurs could have a significant impact on economic development.

site_title: NTU launches research centre for 3D printing
summary: The Nanyang Technological University (NTU) in Singapore has launched the Singapore Centre for 3D Printing, a research centre dedicated to collaborating with the construction, maritime, and aerospace sectors. The centre aims to develop industry standards for 3D printing and reduce materials wastage and manufacturing lead times. Supported by the National Research Foundation (NRF) with a funding of S$42 million over 10 years, the centre will focus on these growth areas for Singapore's economy, enabling the creation of complex parts and new manufacturing technologies.

images.alt_text: Prof Chua Chee Kai, executive director of the Singapore Centre for 3D Printing, says this form of manufacturing can get things made faster, cheaper and with less wastage.

site_title: South Korean wins Man Booker International Prize
summary: Han Kang, a 45-year-old South Korean author, won the Man Booker International Prize for her novel "The Vegetarian", sharing the £50,000 award with her translator Deborah Smith. This was the first time the prize was awarded jointly, as Smith had only taught herself Korean three years before translating the book. The novel, described as "lyrical and lacerating", tells the story of an ordinary woman's rejection of convention from three different perspectives, and was chosen unanimously by the panel of judges.

site_title: Afton opens its first greenfield plant in 35 years on Jurong Island (Amended)
summary: Afton Chemical, a US-based petroleum-additives maker, has opened its first greenfield plant in 35 years on Jurong Island in Singapore, investing US$300 million. The US$100 million facility produces customized lubricant components for Asia-Pacific and Middle East customers, with plans for a second phase to be completed in 2018. The plant aims to create unique solutions for lubricant companies and solidifies Singapore's position as a hub for the Asia-Pacific lubricant-additive market.

images.alt_text: American petroleum-additives maker Afton Chemical opened the first phase of its US$300m plant on Jurong Island on Tuesday.

site_title: Spring appoints 7 new accelerators for startups in emerging sectors
summary: SPRING Singapore has appointed seven new accelerators to grow high-potential startups in clean technology and advanced manufacturing and engineering sectors. The new accelerators include Enchant-VC, Green Meadows Accelerator, JCS Venture Lab, Jungle Ventures, TNB Ventures, TRIREC, and Wavemaker. This move aims to support and nurture startups in these emerging sectors, with Minister for Trade and Industry S Iswaran expressing his support for the initiative.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

site_title: Did regulatory slips 'enable' the 1MDB scandal?
summary: A regulatory slip-up may have enabled the 1MDB scandal, a massive financial controversy surrounding a Malaysian state-backed fund. 1MDB's debt ballooned 10 times to RM50 billion within six years, with several billion-dollar deals funded by debt and risks. If regulatory authorities had spotted the irregularities, the scandal could have been averted. The Malaysian finance ministry has accepted the resignation of 1MDB's board members, but true closure will take time and regulators must acknowledge their indecision and tardiness in acting.

site_title: Tech startups come up with some creative definitions for 'profitable'
summary: Tech startups are redefining "profitable" to suit their financial realities. Companies like SpoonRocket, Uber, and Lyft are focusing on contribution margin, excluding costs such as customer service, office rent, and marketing to drivers. This approach allows them to claim profitability, even if they're not generating enough revenue to cover expenses. The practice has become increasingly common, with other startups, including Instacart and TaskRabbit, using similar calculations to demonstrate financial maturity. This shift reflects the changing funding landscape, where venture capitalists are prioritizing profit over growth, and startups are adapting to remain viable.

site_title: Hedge funds reap big rewards from Russia
summary: Hedge funds have significantly outperformed traditional funds in emerging markets, with Russian assets gaining an average 29% since 2015. This is due to the volatility of Russia's markets, which have been closely tied to the price of oil. Despite the country's recession and sanctions, hedge funds have thrived, with some funds appreciating 17% this year. The performance is attributed to the use of riskier investment strategies, such as leverage and short-selling, which allow hedge funds to amplify returns and minimize losses.

site_title: Egypt investors using arbitrage to get US$
summary: Egyptian investors are using arbitrage to acquire US dollars, buying shares of Commercial International Bank Egypt in the local market and selling them in London for a 30% loss. This trade, driven by the country's tight foreign currency controls, has become increasingly popular among multinational companies and foreign investors. Despite the guaranteed losses, many are willing to take the risk to access dollars, which are in short supply in Egypt. The practice is expected to come to an end as the Egyptian Exchange approaches its regulatory limit on GDR trading, potentially limiting the market's ability to access dollars.

site_title: Election years have paralysing effect on industry
summary: US presidential election years have a paralysing effect on the corporate sector, with large investments being postponed and big deals put on hold. Research shows that during election years, particularly when there is significant uncertainty, industry becomes almost frozen. This trend is evident in reduced capital spending, stalled IPOs, and a volatile stock market. The final year of an incumbent's eight-year term, like this year, sees a significant decline in investment expenditures and average negative returns. The uncertainty surrounding the election may lead to a delay in economic activity, which could last even after the election is decided.

site_title: Top China official promises to 'listen' to Hong Kong
summary: China's top official, Zhang Dejiang, has promised to "listen" to Hong Kong's political demands during his three-day visit, amid growing concerns over the city's freedoms. This conciliatory move comes as Beijing's tightening grip on Hong Kong stirs resentment. Zhang's visit, the first by a senior official in four years, aims to address concerns and potentially ease tensions in the semi-autonomous territory.

site_title: Foiled Vietnam attack likely a test run for Bangladesh heist
summary: A hacking attempt on Vietnam's Tien Phong Commercial Joint Stock Bank was likely a test run for a $81 million cyber attack on Bangladesh's account at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, according to cybersecurity experts. The Vietnam attack targeted a third-party service used by the bank to connect to the Swift interbank messaging system, which may be vulnerable to outdated software. Experts warn that banks in developing countries are prime targets for such attacks due to their limited resources to build technological firewalls against hackers.

site_title: Aussie milk production seen falling as processors slash farm-gate prices
summary: Australian milk production is expected to fall during the 2016/17 season due to processors slashing farm-gate prices by up to 15% amid a global supply glut. The price cuts, made by major dairy exporters Fonterra and Murray Goulburn, have forced farmers to slaughter cattle, potentially reducing the national dairy herd by 1.74 million head. The move may alleviate some pressure on global milk prices, which have tumbled 60% since early 2014.

site_title: Foreign banks, funds turn to US municipal bonds
summary: Foreign banks and pension funds are shifting their investments to US municipal bonds due to negative interest rates in their home countries. These bonds, which finance local infrastructure projects, offer attractive yields and low credit risk, making them an attractive alternative to corporate debt. International buyers, including Asian and European investors, are contributing to a surge in municipal bond prices, with taxable bonds yielding 2.44% compared to Treasuries. This influx of foreign capital is expected to continue, driven by the US$3.7 trillion municipal market's low default rates and lack of volatility.

site_title: Nissan interest fuels US Mitsubishi dealers' hopes for more car models
summary: US Mitsubishi dealers are hopeful for a new era after Nissan's $2.2 billion investment, which could bring a fresh crop of models to boost sales. Despite struggling in the US, Mitsubishi has 0.6% market share, and dealers are optimistic about the potential of the Nissan partnership, which could calm concerns of asset stripping and dealership closures. Nissan plans to keep the brands intact and offer support to Mitsubishi, with chairman Ryan Gremore expecting a more detailed product strategy after due diligence.

site_title: NRF to put up S$85m VC funds jointly with CapitaLand, DeClout, Wilmar, YCH
summary: Singapore's National Research Foundation (NRF) is partnering four large local enterprises - CapitaLand, DeClout, Wilmar, and YCH - to jointly invest up to S$85 million in Singapore-based tech startups through the Early Stage Venture Fund scheme. The NRF will commit S$40 million, while the LLEs will contribute S$10-15 million each. The partnership aims to create value and jobs, and leverage the startups' innovative ideas and the corporates' resources to drive growth. This marks a new dimension in the LLEs' involvement in venture capital, expanding the ecosystem and creating opportunities for startups to scale up.

site_title: Japan's planned coal-fired power plants hazardous to health: Greenpeace
summary: Japan's planned coal-fired power plants are under attack from Greenpeace, which claims they could become a significant health hazard due to air pollutant emissions. The plants, with a total capacity of over 20 GW, are planned near large population centers, amplifying their potential health impact. Greenpeace urges the Japanese government to focus on developing renewable energy sources instead, citing the plants' potential to cause tens of thousands of premature deaths over their operating life.

site_title: China Everbright secures 208m yuan waste water project
summary: China Everbright Water Limited secured a 208 million yuan waste water project, upgrading the Qingdao Waste Water Treatment Plant to reduce chemical oxygen demand and pollutants. The project's waste water treatment capacity remains unchanged.

site_title: India car sales buck oil's gloomy trend
summary: India's car sales have bucked the global trend of declining oil prices, with a 12.4% year-over-year increase in April. This surge in car sales is attributed to a decrease in fuel prices, making vehicles more affordable for middle-class Indians. Anil Gaikwad, a 34-year-old engineer, bought his first car, citing a reduction in commuting time and a desire to park his motorcycle. This development is seen as a positive sign for the Indian automotive industry, which has been impacted by the decline in oil prices over the past two years.

site_title: Twitter adds BET Network's Debra Lee to board in video push
summary: Twitter Inc has added Debra Lee, CEO of BET Networks, to its board, becoming the first African-American on the company's board. Lee, 61, joins as part of Twitter's efforts to expand its user base through video services. The move comes after the company bolstered its board with the appointments of Hugh Johnston and Martha Lane Fox. Twitter aims to increase representation from the media industry to serve as a live video destination, with Lee's experience in television expected to help achieve this goal.

site_title: Pfizer's Anacor deal showcases new wave of eczema therapies
summary: Pfizer's acquisition of Anacor Pharmaceuticals Inc. marks a significant shift in the eczema treatment market, with the company's steroid-free topical ointment crisaborole and injectable therapy dupilumab showing promising results in late-stage trials. These treatments have greatly reduced eczema symptoms without side effects, positioning Pfizer to become a market leader with potential annual sales of over $9 billion. However, high costs may limit patient access, with dupilumab estimated to cost $25,000 per year.

site_title: BP exploration boss leaves after spending cuts
summary: BP's exploration boss, Richard Herbert, is leaving the company after nearly two years, following a decision to simplify the upstream executive team. Herbert, who led exploration activity to rebuild investor confidence after the 2010 US Gulf oil spill, oversaw a reduction in exploration spending due to low oil prices. Despite finding oil and gas in various regions, BP's reserves replacement ratio fell to 61% in 2015, the lowest in years, due to a lack of new discoveries and investment amid low oil prices.

site_title: US factory output boosted by machinery, auto production
summary: US factory output expanded in April, rising 0.3% as machinery and auto production increased, resisting global growth slowdown. This beat expectations and followed a 0.7% rise in overall industrial output, with utilities output rebounding from March's decline due to warmer weather.

images.alt_text: US factory output expanded in April as makers of machinery and cars posted solid increases in production, a sign that the country's manufacturing sector was resisting the downward pull from sputtering global growth.

site_title: Sao Paulo property prices seen staying low until at least next year
summary: Brazil's real estate market in Sao Paulo remains low until next year due to the country's recession, with property prices expected to stay near current levels. The market has been hit by two consecutive years of contraction, high unemployment, and inflation, resulting in a glut of new apartments and cancelled sales. Two major real-estate companies, Cyrela and Eztec, predict prices won't decline further but won't rise either, with inflation at 9% annually putting pressure on real estate values until the economy improves.

site_title: SIA Engineering Co inks a two-year contract with Tigerair Australia
summary: SIA Engineering Co. has signed a two-year contract with Tigerair Australia to provide heavy maintenance services for its A320-200 fleet starting May 2016. The services will be performed at SIAEC's facilities in Singapore and Clark, the Philippines. Tigerair Australia operates 14 A320-200 aircraft serving 11 destinations in Australia. This contract will be renewable for an additional year.

images.alt_text: SIA Engineering Company Limited (SIAEC) said that it has entered into a two-year contract (with an option to renew for an additional year) with Tigerair Australia to perform heavy maintenance services for its A320-200 fleet beginning May 2016.

site_title: Is it time to slay some sacred cows about financing growth?
summary: The Group of Seven (G-7) finance ministers and central bank governors are set to meet in Japan, potentially shifting the paradigm of combined fiscal and monetary policy. The gathering comes as global growth estimates continue to be revised downward, and conventional wisdom about the need for independent central banks is being questioned. Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has called for stepped-up fiscal stimulus, which may be financed by central banks, sparking debate about the role of central banks in stimulating economic activity. The meeting may lead to new paradigms for financing economic activity, potentially involving governments taking a more active role in spending and central banks facilitating this process.

site_title: Apple boss Cook to tap Indian software talent during maiden visit
summary: Apple CEO Tim Cook is set to announce plans to expand its Indian software development centre and build an accelerator programme for local start-ups during his maiden visit to the country. The move comes as India emerges as a significant growth market for the tech giant, with over 100 million smartphones sold last year. Cook's visit also includes meetings with Prime Minister Narendra Modi and industry partners, with the Indian government pushing for Apple to set up production facilities in the country.

site_title: Olam International to issue 5.5b yen in senior unsecured notes due in 2021
summary: Olam International Limited is issuing 5.5 billion yen (approximately $69 million) worth of fixed-rate senior unsecured notes due in 2021. The notes will bear a 1.427% annual interest rate, payable semi-annually. Proceeds will be used for working capital and general corporate purposes, including financing capital expenditure and potential acquisitions. DBS Bank Ltd acted as the sole manager for the issue, with the notes expected to be issued on May 24 and mature in five years.

site_title: Repayment demands pile up on Jason Holdings
summary: Troubled timber flooring provider Jason Holdings has received another repayment demand from ANZ's Singapore branch and five contractors, according to a recent filing with the Singapore Exchange. The company also had its tenancy at a dormitory in Kaki Bukit terminated by its landlord. These developments come as the company faces financial difficulties, with repayment demands and claims from contractors piling up. Jason Holdings' principal operating unit, Jason Parquet Specialist (Singapore), is also facing a significant challenge in meeting its financial obligations.

site_title: Malaysia says too early to conclude fraud in 1MDB-Abu Dhabi deal
summary: Malaysia's finance ministry stated it's too early to conclude if fraud occurred in the 1MDB-Abu Dhabi deal. 1MDB, under global investigation, had paid $3.5 billion to Aabar Investments PJS, which IPIC denied owning. The Malaysian finance ministry said 1MDB is reviewing and investigating to prove IPIC and Aabar Investments PJS' involvement.

images.alt_text: Malaysia said Tuesday it's too early to conclude if fraud had occurred in dealings between its troubled state company and an Abu Dhabi sovereign wealth fund.

site_title: AusGroup in breach of financial covenant under a trust deed
summary: AUSGROUP Limited breached a financial covenant under a trust deed for its S$110 million notes due to a decline in consolidated total equity to below A$160 million as of March 31. The company's note interest rate is 7.45% and matures this year. The breach is due to the group's consolidated total equity falling below the required minimum threshold.

site_title: Microsoft says UK should avoid Brexit and stay part of Europe
summary: Microsoft CEO Michel Van der Bel says the UK should remain in the European Union, citing the country's attractiveness to businesses due to its EU membership. The tech giant, with over 5,000 UK employees, believes staying in the EU supports investment and flexibility in doing business. This stance echoes those of Prime Minister David Cameron and other business leaders who argue leaving the EU would harm trade and immigration. The UK referendum on EU membership is set for June 23.

site_title: Syria's famous damask rose withered by war
summary: Syria's damask rose, a centuries-old flower used in perfumes and cosmetics, is withering due to five years of war. Farmers in the Damascus region have seen a significant decline in production, from 80 tonnes in 2010 to 20 tonnes this year, and a decrease in cultivated land by over half. The war has prevented access to rose fields and cancelled the annual rose festival, depriving the region of its main source of income. Experts attribute the decline to a combination of war and drought, with the rose's unique scent and quality making it a prized commodity, particularly from Damascus.

site_title: Objections to US-EU trade deal over secrecy surrounding talks
summary: Opponents of the US-EU Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) have shifted focus from trade issues to secrecy surrounding talks, with Greenpeace leaking documents that sparked concerns about the deal's impact on European citizens, agriculture, and environmental standards. European politicians, including Chancellor Angela Merkel and Economy Minister Sigmar Gabriel, have defended the treaty, but opponents argue that greater transparency is needed to address mistrust. The US and EU negotiators have dismissed the leaks as "misleading" and "flatly wrong," but the issue has become a contentious topic in both the US and Europe.

site_title: OCBC makes open call to app developers
summary: OCBC Bank launched its open API platform, becoming the first bank in South-east Asia to do so. The APIs, which are free and fully secured, allow third-party developers to embed OCBC's services, such as branch locators, credit card advisers, and forex rates, into their apps. This move is part of Singapore's smart nation ambitions and aims to promote an "open data" economy. The Monetary Authority of Singapore and other banks, including DBS and UOB, have also been using APIs to collaborate with fintechs and promote innovation.

site_title: Penny fever fades as blue chips bounce
summary: Singapore's blue chip stocks rebounded strongly on Tuesday, with the index gaining 45.05 points or 1.65% after nearly two weeks of relentless selling. The 2016 closing low of 2,539 on February 12 was avoided, and the index's display of strength was largely driven by short-covering. Despite this, the broad market still recorded more falls than rises, and the activity in penny speculatives was muted after trading restrictions were imposed on some stocks. Key banks and Thai Beverage also contributed to the index's gains, while DBS Group Research warned of potential downside risks in the market.

site_title: Eurozone banks face profitability shock, need to consolidate: ECB's Praet
summary: Eurozone banks face a severe profitability shock due to overcapacity, high costs, and excess bad loans, according to European Central Bank chief economist Peter Praet. Praet urged more consolidation in the sector to make it more competitive. The current situation is characterized by a smaller pool of earnings and clearly overcapacity in the sector, resulting from a lack of necessary consolidation.

site_title: US consumer prices post largest gain in three years
summary: US consumer prices rose 0.4% in April, the largest gain in three years, driven by increases in gasoline, rents, and medical care costs. The year-on-year increase in the Consumer Price Index (CPI) reached 1.1%, surpassing the Federal Reserve's 2% inflation target. The Fed is expected to raise interest rates later this year, with markets unlikely to see a hike before September. The data suggests steady inflation build-up, which could provide the Fed with ammunition to raise interest rates.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Yanlord Land Group has entered a joint venture to acquire a 351,338 sqm Tianjin land parcel for 2.37 billion yuan (S$497.5 million). DBS Bank launched an online service for small and medium enterprises to apply for banker's guarantees in five minutes. SIA Engineering Company signed a two-year contract with Tigerair Australia to perform heavy maintenance services for its A320-200 fleet. Olam International issued 5.5 billion yen fixed-rate senior unsecured notes due 2021. China Everbright Water secured the Qingdao Waste Water Treatment Upgrading Project worth 208 million yuan.

site_title: German Q2 growth solid but losing some momentum: Bundesbank
summary: Germany's Q2 growth is expected to remain solid but lose momentum, according to the Bundesbank. The country's economy grew 0.7% in the first quarter, its strongest rate since 2014, driven by a strong labor market and rising consumer spending. However, oil prices are not expected to fall, and consumer purchasing power may recede, potentially affecting exports. The bank's new 2016-2018 projections will be published in June.

site_title: Q&M's proposed acquisition of two companies has lapsed
summary: Q&M Dental Group's proposed acquisition of Orchard Scotts and De Pacific Dental Group has lapsed due to the expiration of the points of agreement (POA). The acquisition was first announced last year but no definitive agreements were entered within 12 months, leading to the POA's expiration. The two companies have clinics in Ang Mo Kio, Balestier, Jurong West, and Pasir Ris. Q&M has ended its interest in the acquisition, resulting in the lapse of the deal.

site_title: UK home-price growth accelerates to fastest pace in a year
summary: UK house prices accelerated to the fastest pace in a year, rising 9% annually in March, with London prices jumping 13%. The surge in demand, driven by landlords and investors before a tax increase took effect in April, has skewed the housing market. Mortgage loans gained 28% from a year earlier, while buy-to-let mortgages more than tripled. Experts expect prices may take a downward turn, but high employment, low interest rates, and decent purchasing power are expected to support buyer interest once the EU referendum uncertainty fades.

site_title: US corporates' biggest advantage over Europe is poised to snap
summary: US corporations' long-standing advantage over European peers is expected to narrow, according to Barclays analysts. Since the financial crisis, US companies have outperformed their European counterparts due to higher earnings growth, but strategists argue that European companies are poised to close the gap. They point to stabilizing pricing and aggressive cost-cutting efforts in Europe, while US companies face margin contraction due to labor shortages and rising labor costs. For Europe to outperform the US, earnings need to improve at a faster pace.

site_title: Addvalue Technologies proposes one-for-three rights issue
summary: Addvalue Technologies Ltd. is undertaking a renounceable non-underwritten rights issue of up to 395.79 million new shares at 3.5 Singapore cents apiece, representing a 49% discount to its weighted average price. The company plans to use the proceeds to reduce debt and for working capital. The proposed disposal of its subsidiary Addvalue Communications Pte Ltd is still pending further negotiations with a Chinese buyer.

site_title: One measure of US wage growth just hit a new post-recession high
summary: The median US worker experienced a 3.4% year-over-year wage growth as of April, setting a new post-recession high, according to the Federal Reserve Bank of Atlanta's wage growth tracker. This surpasses the average hourly earnings reported by the Bureau of Labour Statistics, which is affected by composition effects. The good news also indicates a reduction in American income inequality, particularly among lower-skilled workers, with college-educated workers experiencing slower wage growth. Experts suggest that the recent wage growth trend may benefit low-income Americans, with minimum wage hikes expected to lead to firmer wage growth.

site_title: Fitch Ratings downgrades Noble to 'BB+' with stable outlook
summary: Fitch Ratings downgraded Noble Group Limited's long-term issuer default rating to 'BB+' with a stable outlook, citing a shift towards shorter-term financing and a weakening debt maturity profile. The downgrade reflects Noble's asset-light business model and debt reduction efforts. The stable outlook is due to continuous improvements in its balance sheet and sufficient liquidity to cover working-capital needs. Noble's liquidity stands at US$1.86 billion, but is expected to decrease temporarily after debt repayment and will increase post-equity placement and asset sales.

images.alt_text: FITCH Ratings has downgraded the long-term issuer default rating of Hong Kong-based commodities trader Noble Group Limited to "BB+" from "BBB-" with stable outlook.

site_title: Lereno: Aborted acquisition called off on May 13, not May 16
summary: Lereno Bio-Chem has clarified that its acquisition of HTwo Education Holdings was called off on May 13, not May 16, due to expectations it couldn't be completed by June 28. The deal was mutually terminated. Lereno plans to quickly enter a new merger and acquisition deal, seeking new opportunities.

site_title: Palm oil gains as demand picks up ahead of Muslim festival
summary: Malaysia's palm oil futures rose 0.5% ahead of the Muslim festival of Ramadan, which begins in June, as demand for the tropical oil increased. The new contract for August delivery reached RM2,600 per tonne, driven by higher demand from Europe, Pakistan, and India. A stronger Malaysian ringgit, which typically makes palm oil more expensive for foreign buyers, was offset by market expectations of Ramadan demand. The export tax on crude palm oil was raised to 5.5% for June, but traders expect the impact to be minimal.

site_title: Yanlord in joint venture with 3 Chinese partners for mixed-use project in Tianjin
summary: Yanlord Land Group has entered into a joint venture with Chinese partners to acquire a 2.37 billion yuan (S$497.5 million) land parcel in Tianjin's Hong Qiao District for a mixed-use project. The 351,338 sq m site will feature high-end residential, commercial units, and educational facilities. This marks Yanlord's fifth project in Tianjin, as the company continues to expand its footprint in the Bohai Rim region, according to Chairman Zhong Sheng Jian.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares ended higher on Tuesday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 12.18 points to close at 1,633.39. The index saw 1.70 billion lots valued at RM1.72 billion, with 479 gainers and 341 losers.

site_title: US stocks dip despite strong Home Depot earnings
summary: US stocks opened lower on Tuesday, giving back some of the prior day's gains, after Home Depot shares dipped despite a 14.2% jump in first-quarter earnings to US$1.8 billion. The retailer raised its full-year forecast, but shares fell 1.3% as investors felt the "good news" was already priced in. The Dow Jones Industrial Average and S&P 500 lost 0.2% and 0.1% respectively, while the Nasdaq Composite Index shed less than 0.1%.

site_title: US housing starts, building permits increase in April
summary: US housing starts rose 6.6% in April to a 1.17 million-unit pace, exceeding expectations. Single-family starts increased 3.3% to 778,000 units, with the South seeing a 9.0% jump to its highest level since December 2007. Multi-family starts soared 13.9% to 394,000 units. Building permits also rose 3.6% to 1.12 million units, with single-family permits increasing 1.5% and multi-family permits advancing 8.0%. The data suggests the economy is regaining momentum early in the second quarter.

images.alt_text: US housing starts rose more than expected in April as builders ramped up the construction of single and multi-family homes, supporting views that the economy was regaining steam early in the second quarter.

site_title: Oil near six-month high as outages support
summary: Oil prices near a six-month high as supply outages support the market. Nigerian oil output has been cut by almost 40%, and a wildfire in Canada prompted the evacuation of 4,000 people from oil camps. Brent crude reached a six-month high of $49.47, while US crude traded at $48.05, its highest level since October. Analysts expect supply disruptions and declining output in some Opec nations to bring forward the expected rebalancing of the market in the second half of the year.

site_title: French president says won't back down on labour market reform
summary: French President Francois Hollande has ruled out withdrawing the labour market reform, despite weeks of street protests and a vote of no-confidence in the government. Hollande promised tougher action against protesters, including more arrests and bans on protesting, after over 1,000 people were arrested and 350 police officers were injured in violence. The Socialist government survived the vote, and Hollande vowed to push the reform through, despite opposition.

site_title: China state planner urges power, coal sector integration
summary: China's National Development and Reform Commission plans to integrate the power and coal sectors through mergers, long-term supply contracts, and joint investment projects. The goal is to bring together the two "pillar industries" often at odds, aiming to speed up structural reform and improve energy security. The plan encourages struggling coal firms to invest in the power sector and establishes a long-term strategic cooperation mechanism to coordinate supply and demand, control prices, and share risks. This move aims to reduce China's dependence on coal while improving the economic fortunes of the sector.

site_title: German conglomerate Bosch to launch second IoT cloud platform here
summary: German conglomerate Bosch is launching its second IoT cloud platform in Singapore by the end of the year, further solidifying its presence in the growing IoT sector. The company will also implement its first building monitoring project, utilizing sensors to optimize lift and washroom operating conditions. This move aims to establish Bosch as a major player in the IoT sector, transforming from a traditional manufacturing company to a technological solutions provider.

site_title: NTU launches new research centre for 3D printing
summary: NTU launched a new research centre for 3D printing, supported by the National Research Foundation at a funding of S$42 million over 10 years. The centre, part of Singapore's RIE 2020 Plan, aims to focus on construction, maritime, and aerospace sectors. It will collaborate with companies such as ST Engineering, Keppel, and Emerson Process Management to advance additive manufacturing technologies and develop new industry standards. The centre is expected to tap into new technologies and provide resources for companies to study and recommend industry standards.

site_title: OCBC first bank in South-east Asia to launch API platform
summary: OCBC Bank, the first bank in South-east Asia, launched its open API platform, providing sets of requirements for application communication. The platform, free for software developers, includes APIs for branch locators, ATMs, credit card advisers, and forex rates, without containing customer information. The move is part of Singapore's vision of an 'open data' economy and a smart financial centre, as stated by Praveen Raina, senior vice-president, group operations and technology.

site_title: Singapore shares close higher as STI rebounds 1.7%; penny activity fades
summary: Singapore's stock market rebounded 1.7% on Tuesday, with the STI index rising 45.05 points to 2,584, avoiding its 2016 closing low of 2,539. The index's gains were driven by blue chips, including Thai Beverage, which jumped 5.4% after a positive report from OCBC Investment Research. However, penny stocks were less active due to trading restrictions. Despite the rally, the broad market still recorded more falls than rises, with 156 falls and 268 rises excluding warrants.

site_title: Australia: Shares end up 0.7% on resources lift
summary: Australian shares rose 0.7% on Tuesday, driven by gains in steel, mining, and energy stocks. The S&P/ASX 200 index reached 5,395.90 points. Oil prices hit six-month highs due to supply concerns, contributing to the commodity-driven rally. This followed a 0.6% gain on Monday. New Zealand's benchmark index also rose 0.9%, marking a new record high.

site_title: China: Stocks slip on worries monetary stimulus to be tapered
summary: China's stocks slipped 0.3% on Tuesday due to concerns that Beijing may taper monetary stimulus as the economy struggles. The CSI300 index fell to 3,086.02, while the Shanghai Composite Index dropped to 2,843.68. President Xi Jinping announced plans to push forward supply-side reform and increase middle-income earners, but investors remained cautious.

site_title: Hong Kong residential plot sells within expected range
summary: A residential plot in Hong Kong's Tai Po district sold for HK$4.02 billion (S$709.34 million) after being put up for tender, within the expected price range. The 50-year land grant plot has an area of 28,685 square meters and a maximum gross floor area of 103,266 square meters. Billion Real Estate Holdings Ltd unit, King Future Ltd, won the tender, beating listed developers including Vanke Property Overseas Ltd and Sun Hung Kai Properties Ltd, amidst steady declines in Hong Kong home prices for the sixth consecutive month.

site_title: UK April inflation slips for first time since September as airfares fall
summary: British inflation slipped to 0.3% in April, its first decline since September 2015, due to a drop in airfares and lower clothing prices. The Office for National Statistics also reported a 9.0% rise in house prices, the largest in a year. The Bank of England expects inflation to remain below 1% until the end of the year and to undershoot its 2% target until 2018. Despite a short-term dip, economists expect the BoE to keep rates low due to a weakening global economy and uncertainty ahead of the EU referendum.

site_title: Indonesia turns to Singapore's Temasek as model for investment
summary: Indonesia is considering establishing a sovereign investment company modeled after Singapore's Temasek Holdings to drive development in the country. Finance Minister Bambang Brodjonegoro plans to create a holding company for state-owned entities to invest in Indonesian companies, potentially expanding to overseas assets. The move aims to boost economic growth and attract businesses, following President Joko Widodo's mandate to spur growth through public spending. The proposed fund would help address issues of foreign ownership in Indonesian companies, with state banks and energy firms considered as potential targets.

images.alt_text: Indonesia is turning to Singapore's Temasek Holdings as a model to create a sovereign investment company to drive development in Southeast Asia's biggest economy.

site_title: Philippine VIPs fly south to Duterte's new seat of power
summary: Philippine President-elect Rodrigo Duterte has named key allies to his administration, including veteran politician Manny Pinol as agriculture secretary and ER Ejercito as tourism head. Duterte's allies include billionaire Lucio Tan, rebel leader Ghadzali Jaafar, and boxer Manny Pacquiao, who shifted his support from early frontrunner Jejomar Binay. Duterte's administration is focused on filling top posts with loyalists who can help spread economic development in the southern Philippines. The region, typically known for violence and insurgencies, is now being recognized for its potential.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) rose 4.5% in April, outpacing March's 0.1% increase. The National Research Foundation (NRF) committed S$40 million in venture capital funds to four local enterprises. HSR International Realtors was fined S$74,000 for acting in a conflict of interest. BSI SA is investigating employees related to 1MDB. Hyflux launched a S$300 million perpetual capital securities offer at 6%. Fitch Ratings downgraded Noble Group to 'BB+' with a stable outlook. NTU launched a new research centre for 3D printing.

site_title: Unlock hidden hard drive on desktop with wearable Asus ROG Band
summary: Asus has released a high-end gaming desktop, the ROG GT51CA, featuring a wearable NFC band that unlocks a hidden 1TB hard drive. The system, powered by Intel Core i7 Skylake processors and Nvidia GeForce GTX Titan X graphics, supports 4K output and virtual reality games. A mid-range model with two Nvidia GTX 980 graphics cards is also available, priced at S$4,298. The desktop, available for pre-order from May 18 to June 30, comes with a free 4K ROG G-SYNC monitor.

images.alt_text: Asus's latest Republic of Gamers ROG GT51CA gaming desktop.

site_title: Europe: Stocks advance at open on Tuesday
summary: European stock markets rose at the start of trading on Tuesday, driven by rebounding oil prices. London's FTSE 100 index gained 0.5% to 6,184.42 points, while Frankfurt's DAX 30 index rose 0.6% to 10,019.79 points. The gains followed a public holiday in Frankfurt and were influenced by mining and healthcare stocks.

site_title: Marcos likely loss in Philippines setback for family revival
summary: Ferdinand Marcos Jr., the son of the former Philippine dictator, is trailing congresswoman Leni Robredo in the vice presidential election by over 200,000 votes with less than 1 million votes left to be counted. Marcos has refused to concede, but the likely defeat is a setback for the Marcos family's efforts to expand their political influence 30 years after the fall of his father's regime. Marcos vowed to ensure the "true will of the Filipino people" prevails in the election, despite trailing behind Robredo.

images.alt_text: The likely defeat of Ferdinand Marcos Jr in the race for Philippine vice president is a setback for efforts to expand the family's political influence 30 years after the fall of his father's dictatorship.

site_title: Seoul: Won ends up on risk sentiment, stocks unchanged
summary: The South Korean won strengthened by 0.5% to 1,173.7 won per US dollar, rebounding from a recent sharp decline, amid a boost in global investor risk appetite. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) closed nearly steady at 1,968.06 points. The move was largely driven by a strong Wall Street performance, but South Korean shares remained unchanged throughout the day.

site_title: Malaysia's policy rate seen steady as growth expected to improve
summary: Malaysia's central bank is expected to maintain its overnight policy rate at 3.25% on Thursday, despite a slow first-quarter economic growth of 4.2%, according to a Reuters poll of 11 economists. The rate has been unchanged since July 2014. The Bank Negara Malaysia is also expected to keep the statutory reserve requirement ratio at 3.5%. Economic growth is expected to improve in the coming quarters, driven by solid private consumption and a solid GDP growth rate. Inflationary pressure is cooling, with the annual consumer price index up 2.6% in March.

site_title: Australia delays 'backpacker tax' after backlash
summary: Australia has delayed the planned "backpacker tax" that would have required foreign travelers to pay 32.5 cents for every dollar earned, amid a backlash from farmers and the tourism industry. The tax, set to be introduced on July 1, was intended to boost government coffers by A$540 million over three years. The delay, announced by Assistant Treasurer Kelly O'Dwyer, is pending a ministerial review, and farmers and tourism operators have welcomed the reprieve, citing concerns that the tax would deter backpackers from visiting Australia.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares rise on Wall Street's gain, higher oil prices
summary: Hong Kong stocks rose 1.2% on Tuesday, driven by US and Asian market gains and higher oil prices. The Hang Seng index closed at 20,118.80, while the Hong Kong China Enterprises Index rose 1.4% to 8,425.78. US shares, including Apple, surged on Monday, fueling investor confidence. The rally was also influenced by higher oil prices, which boosted energy stocks.

site_title: Updated quick takes: Singapore's NODX contraction eases in April, but outlook still weak
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) declined 7.9% in April to S$13.3 billion, a softer pace than the 15.7% contraction in March. The decline was driven by a decrease in exports to top markets, with Taiwan, South Korea, and Indonesia being the largest contributors. Economists warn that the decline in NODX is a sign of persistent weakness in global demand, and may manifest in lower GDP growth figures. The outlook remains weak, with some experts predicting a 3.3% year-on-year contraction in 1H 2016 and a 1.8% GDP growth forecast for 2016.

site_title: DBS rolls out online banker's guarantee application for SMEs
summary: DBS Bank has launched an online banker's guarantee application service for small and medium enterprises (SMEs) in Singapore. The service allows SMEs to apply online and receive an indication of bank fees instantly. The bank is targeting over 1,000 SMEs to benefit from this service within a year. Until December 31, 2016, SMEs can receive a fee waiver of S$100 and free document delivery. This is described as a "first in Singapore" and aims to simplify the process of securing financial or performance obligations for SMEs.

site_title: Taiwan begins review of Chinese Tsinghua's chip stake deals in island
summary: Taiwan has begun reviewing Chinese state-backed Tsinghua Unigroup's proposals to buy stakes worth nearly US$1 billion in two domestic semiconductor companies, Powertech Technology Inc and ChipMOS Technologies Inc. The review process, led by Taiwan's Investment Commission, comes as the new government of President Tsai Ing-wen takes office, which has expressed concerns over Tsinghua's proposals. The chances of the proposals being approved have increased, with industry executives citing a reduced proposal value and fewer proposals submitted by Tsinghua. A final decision is expected in several months.

site_title: As Brexit vote looms, US banks review their European commitments
summary: US banks are reviewing their European commitments in anticipation of the UK's potential exit from the European Union. If Britain votes to leave, some US banks may be forced to reorganize their business in the bloc, potentially leading to a loss of market operations and a reevaluation of their commitment to the EU. The five largest US banks employ 40,000 people in London, primarily due to the EU "passporting" regime, which allows them to offer services across the bloc. A reorganization could result in significant costs, with some banks considering alternative outposts or locally capitalized subsidiaries in the EU.

site_title: Apple CEO Tim Cook visiting India, an important growth market
summary: Apple CEO Tim Cook is visiting India, a key growth market, with a focus on expanding the company's presence in the country. During his trip, Cook will unveil a digital maps development center in Hyderabad and introduce an iOS developer accelerator program. He is also seeking permission to open Apple Stores in India and will meet with Prime Minister Narendra Modi. India's growing middle class and increasing purchasing power make it an attractive market for Apple, with shipments of iPhones growing 56% in the first quarter of 2016.

site_title: UBS takes more positive view on Greek banks
summary: UBS has upgraded its view on Greek banks, turning more positive on the sector due to signs of progress in talks with Greece's lenders. The bank believes a deal on releasing new bailout funds and debt relief could lead to a 90% increase in Greek bank stocks. This optimistic view echoes Morgan Stanley's earlier assessment. Despite Athens' benchmark index being down 2% since 2016, UBS sees a fundamental investment case and valuations suggesting upside potential for Greek banks.

site_title: Yen ticks up ahead of G7 finance ministers' meeting
summary: The yen rose ahead of a G7 finance ministers' meeting in Japan, where currencies will be a major topic. Japanese officials have threatened to intervene in forex markets to tame the yen's surge to 18-month highs, but analysts believe this is unlikely due to diplomatic sensitivities. The US dollar edged down to 108.97 yen, while the euro and other currencies also declined. The yen's recent gains have given up, and analysts predict the US dollar will regain its strength in the second half of the year.

site_title: Emirates unit Dnata looking for acquisitions after record year
summary: Emirates' aviation services arm Dnata reported a record profit of 1 billion dirhams (S$372 million) for the fiscal year ending March 31. Dnata is seeking acquisition opportunities to integrate into the business without compromising quality and standards. The unit has 3.5 billion dirhams in cash assets and plans to return to the Iranian market through travel services with a local partner. Dnata aims to replicate last year's profit despite tough market conditions, with Emirates financing covered for the delivery of 36 planes in the current fiscal year.

site_title: China threats, popular hopes pour pressure on Taiwan's Tsai
summary: Taiwan's newly elected President Tsai Ing-wen faces pressure from both domestic and international forces as she navigates a delicate balance between national pride and Beijing's demands. Tsai's pro-independence stance and pledge to maintain the "status quo" with China have sparked concerns from China, which views Taiwan as part of its territory. Despite this, Tsai has vowed to diversify economic partnerships and seek a higher profile for Taiwan internationally, aiming to reduce its reliance on China and protect its sovereignty.

site_title: Singapore-Russia trade links can be improved: PM Lee
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong expressed his desire to boost trade between the two countries, stating that the current trade volume is not in proportion to the potential. The bilateral trade between Singapore and Russia has quadrupled in the last decade, reaching S$7.66 billion in 2015. Lee plans to negotiate a free trade agreement with the Eurasian Economic Union and meet Russian business leaders to discuss investment opportunities in Singapore. Major Russian companies already operate in Singapore, and Singaporean firms are active in Russia, with the two countries celebrating 50 years of diplomatic relations.

site_title: HSR fined, barred from en bloc deals for one year
summary: The Council for Estate Agencies (CEA) fined HSR International Realtors S$74,000 for breaching its duties as a real estate agent. HSR was barred from undertaking collective-sale work for one year after offering incentive payments to four subsidiary proprietors, a practice deemed a clear breach of its duties and deemed as bad faith. The decision stems from the en bloc attempt of Thomson View condominium, where HSR's actions led to a stop order and a court ruling that HSR had breached its duty of transparency.

site_title: Australia's central bank considered holding rates steady at May meeting
summary: Australia's central bank decided to cut interest rates to help return inflation to target over time, contrary to initial expectations. The decision was made at the May 3 policy review, with members persuaded that easing monetary policy would improve sustainable growth and inflation prospects. The Australian dollar rose to a session high of US$0.7368 after the announcement.

site_title: New Zealand's inflation expectations pick up for coming year: survey
summary: New Zealand's near-term inflation expectations rose to 1.22% for the coming year, up from 1.09% in the previous survey, according to a Reserve Bank of New Zealand survey. Two-year inflation expectations also increased to 1.64%. This marks a shift from previous expectations, indicating potential policy action by the RBNZ.

site_title: ANZ, contractors lodge claims against Jason Holdings
summary: ANZ's Singapore branch has sent letters of demand to Jason Holdings, Jason Parquet Specialist, and two executive directors, Jason Sim Chon Ang and Sim Choon Joo, over unpaid debts. The troubled timber flooring provider also faces eviction from a Kaki Bukit dormitory by the end of May. The company has received another letter of demand from a bank, adding to its mounting claims.

site_title: NRF awards S$40m venture capital funds to CapitaLand, DeClout, Wilmar, YCH
summary: The National Research Foundation (NRF) of Singapore has awarded S$40 million in venture capital funds to four local enterprises (CapitaLand, DeClout, Wilmar, and YCH) under its Early Stage Venture Fund scheme. The funds will be invested on a matching basis to support innovative Singapore-based technology startups, encouraging LLEs to engage in corporate venturing and providing startups with opportunities to scale up through networks, customer base, and resources.

site_title: Dollar edges down, Aussie soars on dovish RBA minutes
summary: The US dollar declined in Asian trading on May 17, 2016, while the Australian dollar surged after the Reserve Bank of Australia's (RBA) minutes revealed a less dovish stance on interest rate cuts. The RBA reduced the cash rate to a record low 1.75% and minutes showed policymakers were less concerned about economic growth. The Australian dollar was boosted by a rebound in crude oil futures, which reached a six-month high due to supply disruptions. The market reaction was also influenced by a more bullish assessment from Goldman Sachs.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Tuesday, with the Nikkei 225 index gaining 1.13% to 16,652.80. Shares in top automakers Toyota and Nissan rose, while energy shares jumped after oil prices surged to six-month highs. The broader Topix index advanced 1.07% to 1,335.85.

site_title: Sao Paulo real estate prices are near the bottom, builders say
summary: Real estate prices in Sao Paulo, Brazil's largest market, have hit a bottom and are expected to remain low until next year due to the country's recession. Builders, such as Cyrela Brazil Realty and Eztec Empreendimentos, report a glut of new apartments and tight credit, leading to discounts and canceled sales. The average price of a square meter in Sao Paulo has slowed to 0.8% growth, and prices are expected to remain under pressure until the economy improves.

site_title: Thailand bomb suspect breaks down, tells media, "I'm not an animal"
summary: A Thai court hearing for two suspects, Adem Karadag and Yusufu Mieraili, involved in the deadly 2016 Erawan Shrine bombing, took a dramatic turn when Karadag broke down in front of cameras, stating "I'm not an animal." Karadag and Mieraili, both ethnic Uighur Muslims from China, deny the charges against them. Analysts suspect the attack was linked to sympathizers of the Uighur minority in China, who were angered by Thailand's deportation of Uighurs to China. The trial is expected to involve over 250 witnesses and could last until the end of 2016.

site_title: Nasa launches near-space monitoring balloon from New Zealand
summary: NASA successfully launched a 532,000 cubic metre balloon from New Zealand's South Island Wanaka Airport on May 17, 2016, to conduct near-space scientific investigations. The balloon, which is expected to remain airborne for over 100 days, will circumnavigate the globe at an altitude of 33.5 km and be visible from the ground, particularly in the southern hemisphere's mid-latitudes. This marks the fifth attempt to launch the balloon, with previous bids thwarted by bad weather, and aims to provide inexpensive access to the near-space environment for science and technology.

site_title: China must never repeat Cultural Revolution: People's Daily
summary: China's ruling Communist Party's official People's Daily warned that the country must never repeat the Cultural Revolution, a decade-long period of chaos and violence from 1966-1976. The 50th anniversary of the movement's start was marked with no official commemorations, and the party's grip on the historical narrative remains tight. The newspaper emphasized the need to draw lessons from the Cultural Revolution to prevent a similar event from occurring again.

images.alt_text: China must learn from the tumultuous, decade-long Cultural Revolution and never allow such an event to happen again, the ruling Communist Party's official People's Daily said on the movement's anniversary.

site_title: Aussie gains 1% with less easing risk seen
summary: The Australian dollar surged 1% on Tuesday following minutes from the Reserve Bank of Australia's policy meeting, which indicated a lower likelihood of a rate cut. The Aussie reached a high of US$0.7358, rebounding from a 2-1/2-month low. Analysts believe the market is less likely of a rate cut in the near term, but a possible easing in June to a record low of 1.5% is still anticipated.

images.alt_text: The Australian dollar rallied one per cent on Tuesday after minutes of the Reserve Bank of Australia's (RBA) May policy meeting encouraged markets to pare back the chances of a cut in interest rates.

site_title: Coal spill risk to Australia's Great Barrier Reef: study
summary: A new study published in Nature Scientific Reports reveals that a major coal spill on Australia's Great Barrier Reef could kill colorful corals within two weeks and stunt the growth of fish and seagrass. Researchers found that fine coal particles had a "smothering" impact on corals, causing significant mortality and reduced growth rates in fish and seagrass. The study highlights the reef's vulnerability to coal spills, which could exacerbate existing problems caused by warming sea temperatures, farming run-off, and development.

site_title: China plans steps to slow exodus of processing trade exporters: commerce ministry
summary: China plans to slow the outflow of processing trade exporters by encouraging them to move to central and western regions with lower labor costs. The country will use differentiated policies, including reserving land and streamlining government approval processes, to achieve this goal. China's processing trade exports have declined for 14 consecutive months, with a 8.2% drop in April. The share of processing trade in China's total exports has decreased to 30% from a historical high of 53%. The goal is to slow the transfer of processing trade businesses abroad and keep them within China.

images.alt_text: China will take steps to stem the outflow of processing trade businesses to other countries by encouraging them to move to its central and western regions where labour costs are lower, a spokesman for the commerce ministry said on Tuesday.

site_title: Vietnam bank hackers tried to send money to Slovenia
summary: Vietnam's central bank reported a failed hacking attempt on Tien Phong Bank (TPBank) via the Swift messaging system in December, aiming to transfer 1.2 million euros (S$1.86 million) to a Slovenian bank. The attempt was detected by TPBank and no other Vietnamese lenders or the central bank were affected. Interpol was immediately informed of the incident. This is the only detected Swift hacking attempt in Vietnam, and the central bank assured that other Vietnamese lenders and the central bank were not affected.

site_title: Malaysia raises June crude palm oil export duty to 5.5%
summary: Malaysia is raising its crude palm oil export duty to 5.5% in June, up from 5% in May. The Southeast Asian nation calculated a reference price of 2,625.18 ringgit per tonne for June. The tax, which starts at 4.5% for prices below 2,250 ringgit, aims to increase revenue. This is the second time Malaysia has raised its tax on crude palm oil exports since May 2015, when it ended a duty-free policy.

site_title: BP struggles for Great Australian Bight drill approval
summary: BP's plan to drill in the Great Australian Bight for oil and gas has failed to win regulatory approval for the second time. The company applied for permission from the National Offshore Petroleum Safety and Environmental Management Authority (Nopsema) in October but was denied due to failing to meet strict environmental criteria. The project can be re-applied, but environmentalists are urging the project to be abandoned. BP plans to drill four exploration wells at a depth of up to 2,500 meters off the South Australian coast.

site_title: Virtual reality puts viewer in the movie at Cannes
summary: Virtual reality technology has secured a special slot at the Cannes film festival, where dozens of VR movies are being shown. Filmmakers are struggling to keep up with the rapid advancements in VR, requiring homemade cameras and innovative scriptwriting techniques. Notable films include "Invasion," an animated bunny fighting aliens, and "I, Philip," a VR film based on the true story of science fiction author Philip K. Dick. However, access to VR films remains limited due to high-end headset costs, and distribution challenges remain a significant hurdle for the emerging technology.

site_title: Hong Kong braces for first Post-Occupy Beijing visit
summary: Hong Kong is on high alert as National People's Congress Chairman Zhang Dejiang arrives for a three-day visit, amid growing tensions over Beijing's rule. The city has raised its alert level to "high" and deployed up to 6,000 police officers to secure the Hong Kong Convention and Exhibition Centre, where Zhang is scheduled to speak on President Xi Jinping's "One Belt, One Road" plan. The visit comes amidst a backdrop of escalating protests and a boycott by several lawmakers, who will meet Zhang to express their concerns over the city's autonomy.

site_title: Seoul: Won up on renewed risk demand, stocks edge down
summary: The South Korean won edged up 0.5% to 1,173.4 per dollar, recovering from two-day declines, due to strengthened US stocks and global oil prices boosting investor demand for riskier assets. However, the won's recovery may be halted if the US consumer price index signals an increased chance of a Federal Reserve rate increase. South Korean shares edged down 0.1%, with offshore investors taking profits and tech giant Samsung Electronics Co Ltd rising 0.6%.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Tuesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rising 0.170 points to 1619.48. The market saw a slight gain, with 94 gainers outnumbering 65 losers.

site_title: Asia: Stocks extend climb after Apple rally as oil, metals rise
summary: Asian stocks continued their climb, driven by a rebound in technology stocks and commodity prices. Apple's surge, led by Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway's $1.1 billion stake, boosted the US market. Oil prices rose, with West Texas Intermediate crude reaching a six-month high. Commodity prices also rose, including industrial metals and gold, righting global equities after a decline in May. Investors await the release of Federal Reserve minutes, which may influence US monetary policy, and other central banks' decisions.

site_title: ANZ to cut about 200 jobs in Australia as loan growth slows
summary: ANZ is cutting about 200 jobs in its Australian unit due to subdued economic conditions, low lending growth, and the need to simplify its business and improve productivity. The job cuts will mainly affect managerial and back-office roles in Melbourne. The lender also has an external hiring freeze in place.

site_title: Quick takes: Singapore's NODX contraction pace eases in April, but outlook still weak
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) fell 7.9% in April to S$13.3 billion, easing from a 15.7% contraction in March. The decline was led by Taiwan, South Korea, and Indonesia. Economists expect the outlook to remain weak, citing persistent cyclical and structural pressures on Asian trade, and the abating of growth momentum in China. The Monetary Authority of Singapore may ease monetary policy in October, but this is not the base case at this juncture.

site_title: Vietnam success foiling hack shows risk of Swift connection
summary: A Vietnamese bank, Tien Phong Commercial Joint Stock Bank, successfully foiled a hacking attempt that could have stolen over $1.55 million. The incident is believed to be a practice run for a larger cyber attack on Bangladesh's account at the Federal Reserve Bank of New York, which lost $81 million in February. Experts say the attack highlights vulnerabilities in the Swift interbank messaging system and the need for stronger cybersecurity measures, particularly in developing countries with limited resources.

site_title: ABN Amro's private banking arm taps veteran banker for South Asian services
summary: ABN Amro's private banking arm has appointed Amrit Uppal as managing director of its South Asian services and international team, based in Singapore. Uppal, with over 16 years of experience in private banking, joins from EFG Banking AG Singapore and previously worked for Barclays Wealth Asia and Credit Suisse in the UK. He reports to Lee Chang Tze, head of private banking for South-east Asia.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.5% up on Tuesday
summary: Singapore stocks rose 0.5% on Tuesday, driven by an overnight rebound on Wall Street, with the Straits Times Index reaching 2,748.47. The rally was fueled by a six-month high in crude oil prices. Trading volumes were moderate, with 65.4 million shares changing hands worth S$66.4 million.

site_title: Out of this world: 'Moon and Mars veggies' grow in Dutch greenhouse
summary: Researchers at a Dutch university have successfully grown vegetables in soils similar to those found on the Moon and Mars in a greenhouse. The experiment, which began in 2013, used NASA's simulated "space soil" to test plant growth. The results showed that plants grew well in the Martian soil, even flowering, but the safety of the vegetables for human consumption remains uncertain due to the presence of heavy metals. To address this, the researchers propose purifying the soil with other plant species that absorb toxins. The study aims to provide a solution for future human colonies on the Moon and Mars, but experts emphasize the need for further research on the effects of space conditions on plant growth and survival.

site_title: Australia, NZ: Resources and steel power shares higher
summary: Australian and New Zealand shares rose on Tuesday, with steel, mining, and energy stocks leading the gain. The S&P/NZX 50 index in New Zealand reached an all-time high, and the S&P/ASX 200 index in Australia rose 0.5%. Steel companies, including Bluescope Steel and Steel & Tube Holdings, surged, while iron ore producers like Fortescue Metals jumped 5.2%. Oil and gas producers also saw gains, while top miner BHP Billiton rose 3%. site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai chase Wall St rally at open
summary: Hong Kong and Shanghai stocks rallied for a second consecutive session on May 17, 2016, driven by a strong lead from Wall Street. The Hang Seng Index rose 0.52% to 19,987.24, while the Shanghai Composite Index added 0.09% to 2,853.54. Energy firms were boosted by further gains in oil prices. The rally followed a strong performance on Wall Street, where the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: Tokyo: Shares soar on Wall St rally, higher oil prices

site_title: MAS says banks should maintain high level of IT security
summary: Singapore's central bank, the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), has emphasized the importance of maintaining a high level of IT security for banks, particularly following recent cyber attacks using the Swift financial messaging system. The MAS expects financial institutions to implement strong controls in their IT systems, as outlined in the MAS Technology Risk Management Guidelines. This includes securing critical IT systems such as Swift.

site_title: CapitaLand to co-invest in early-stage venture fund for startups
summary: CapitaLand, a Singapore property developer, will co-invest in the Early Stage Venture Fund III Scheme with the National Research Foundation. The venture fund aims to invest in Singapore's technology startups, focusing on innovations that complement CapitaLand's business in design, construction, operations, and smart living solutions. The investment will support local startups and enhance CapitaLand's business capabilities.

site_title: BSI said to probe bank employees on 1MDB-related dealings
summary: BSI SA, a Swiss bank, is investigating employees and their dealings related to 1Malaysia Development Bhd (1MDB), a Malaysian state investment fund. The bank's manager, Kevin Swampillai, has been suspended pending investigation, although he hasn't been accused of wrongdoing. BSI's inquiry comes amid global probes into 1MDB's alleged use of funds to funnel money to politically-connected individuals. The bank had invested $2.32 billion in a Cayman Islands fund linked to 1MDB. The investigation is part of a broader examination of 1MDB's transactions, which have been linked to money laundering and cheating.

site_title: MH370 hunters must face failure, search chief tells Guardian
summary: The head of the Australian investigation team, Martin Dolan, says the chances of finding missing Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370 are fading, with a decreasing possibility of success. With 15,000 square kilometers left to search in a 120,000 square-kilometer area in the southern Indian Ocean, Dolan contemplates the possibility of not finding the aircraft. The Boeing 777 plane vanished on March 8, 2014, and there has been no trace of the 239 people on board, with bad weather potentially delaying the search by at least a month.

images.alt_text: The chances of finding missing Malaysia Airlines Flight MH370 are fading and searchers have to face possible failure, the head of the Australian investigation team told the Guardian newspaper.

site_title: Gold advances as Soros buys Barrick, Eton Park adds SPDR stake
summary: Billionaire George Soros and Eton Park Capital Management have joined investors buying gold, driving prices up for a third day. The metal has rallied 21% in 2016 as the Federal Reserve scales back interest-rate expectations. Hedge fund managers Paul Singer and Stan Druckenmiller are bullish, while John Paulson has retreated from gold for the second quarter. Holdings in gold-backed exchange-traded funds have increased to 62 metric tons, the highest since December 2013.

images.alt_text: Gold climbed for a third day as billionaire George Soros and Eton Park Capital Management joined the slew of investors piling into bullion.

site_title: China to tighten share suspension rules ahead of MSCI inclusion
summary: China plans to tighten rules on listed companies suspending and resuming trade by next week to prevent price manipulation and improve market order ahead of potential inclusion in the MSCI EM index. The revised rules will address issues such as arbitrary trading halts and long suspensions, which have affected market order and liquidity. The move aims to enhance China's reputation in global stock markets and comply with MSCI's passive tracking requirements.

site_title: Australian police raid properties connected to Islamic State sailing group
summary: Australian counter-terrorism police conducted raids across Melbourne, targeting properties connected to five men accused of planning to join Islamic State in Syria via a boat trip from Australia to Indonesia. The men, aged 21-31, were charged with preparing to engage in hostile activities and face a maximum penalty of life imprisonment. They were arrested after towing a 7m motor boat 3,000km from Melbourne to Cairns in northern Queensland.

site_title: China's staples turn into stock-market stars as economy worsens
summary: China's consumer staples stocks have surged 18% since January 28, outperforming the CSI 300 Index, as the economy worsens. Companies producing meat, animal feed, and alcohol have seen significant gains, with some reporting profits exceeding 30% growth. Despite weak industrial production, retail sales, and investment data, consumer staples are seen as more resilient due to secure earnings. Analysts attribute the outperformance to affordable prices and increasing consumption, with some warning that valuations may become unsustainable in the long term.

site_title: IS has lost nearly half the area it once claimed in Iraq: Pentagon
summary: The Islamic State (IS) group has lost nearly half the territory it once claimed in Iraq, with about 40% of its Iraqi holdings now under control of government forces. This loss is part of a broader trend of IS losing control of territory across Iraq and Syria. The Pentagon estimates that IS fighters have lost control of about 40% of the territory in Iraq and 10% in Syria.

site_title: Japan's upstream oil and gas investment to tumble in 2016/17
summary: Japan's upstream oil and gas investment is expected to decline by around 40% to 1.2 trillion yen ($15 billion) in 2016/17 due to low oil prices. This follows a 40% decline in 2014/15, with global upstream investment expected to fall by 18% in 2016, according to the International Energy Agency. The decline is attributed to the global oil price drop of 55% since 2014, prompting spending cuts on new wells and projects. This marks the first time upstream investment has fallen for two consecutive years since the 1980s.

site_title: G7 to discuss currencies, Japan seeks FX stability: Finance Minister Aso
summary: Japanese Finance Minister Taro Aso announced that G7 finance leaders will discuss currencies and stability in the foreign exchange market during their meeting in Sendai, Japan, on May 20-21. The focus will be on adopting monetary and structural policies tailored to each country's situation amidst global economic uncertainty. Aso emphasized the importance of maintaining stability in the foreign exchange market.

site_title: Temasek raises healthcare bets, adds more ADRs of JD.com
summary: Temasek Holdings, a Singapore investment firm, increased its healthcare bets in the first quarter by buying American depositary receipts of US drugmakers Beigene Ltd, Gilead Sciences Inc, Illumina Inc, and Regeneron Pharmaceuticals Inc. It also added to its position in JD.com Inc's ADRs, buying 1.2 million more shares. The firm's healthcare investments are expected to benefit from rising life expectancies and a growing middle class in emerging markets, with analysts noting the industry's expansion as populations age and developing nations can afford better treatment.

site_title: US dollar firms, higher yields support as markets ponder Fed outlook
summary: The US dollar strengthened against major currencies due to rising crude oil prices and US Treasury yields, with the yield on 10-year notes reaching 1.7533%. The dollar index remained near a three-week high, and the euro and yen also gained value. Despite a weaker-than-expected New York Empire State survey, dollar bulls remained optimistic due to low expectations for Fed policy changes, with only a 4% chance of a rate hike in June, according to FedWatch.

site_title: Sterling near 3-week lows, cost of hedging volatility soars
summary: Sterling rose from a three-week low against the US dollar on May 16, 2016, amid warnings of a potential Brexit's impact. Polls ahead of the June 23 referendum show the outcome still uncertain, with the "Remain" camp holding an eight-point lead. The cost of hedging against sharp falls in the coming two months soared, while bookmakers' odds on a Brexit widened to around 28%. Warnings about the potential impact of a vote to leave intensified, adding to market volatility.

site_title: Venezuela emergency decree boosts security powers
summary: Venezuela has implemented a state of emergency decree, granting President Nicolas Maduro's government sweeping security powers to tackle food shortages and public unrest. The 60-day decree allows the government and security forces to ignore constitutional safeguards, but opposition groups plan nationwide marches to test the decree's public-control measures. The move is seen as an attempt to quash efforts to call a referendum on removing Maduro from office, amid widespread discontent and economic crisis.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Eu Yan Sang, Cordlife, Lum Chang, firms linked to 2013 penny-stock crash
summary: A consortium led by a UOB-backed fund and Eu Yan Sang's CEO Richard Eu has launched a S$0.60 takeover bid for the traditional Chinese medicine retailer. Jeremy Yee, former CEO of Cordlife Group, has claimed he was forced to step down after being offered two options, contradicting the company's remarks. Lum Chang Holdings has tied up with Tien Wah Press Holdings to undertake a mixed-use development in Malaysia. Shares of companies linked to the 2013 penny-stock crash jumped amid heavy volumes, leaving traders mystified.

site_title: Moleskine vs Apple: Hemingway's notepad maker goes digital
summary: Moleskine, a luxury notepad maker, is facing a threat from Apple's introduction of the iPad Pro, which can be used for writing and drawing. In response, Moleskine has released the Smart Writing Set, a pen-and-notebook set that can be uploaded to a smartphone or tablet. The set costs $199, more profitable than classic paper notebooks. Despite this, Moleskine's total revenue is still a 30% jump from the previous year, with Apple's iPad sales reaching $23 billion last year. Moleskine's digital product range is growing, and the company has carved out a new reporting segment for it.

site_title: Japan's Ishihara: No truth to media report sales tax hike to be delayed
