summary: Japanese Economy Minister Nobuteru Ishihara denied a media report that the government would delay a sales tax hike scheduled for next year, stating he had no instructions from Prime Minister Shinzo Abe. Ishihara continued working on the government's annual growth strategy, contradicting a Nikkei business daily report that suggested delaying the tax increase to boost domestic demand.

site_title: Donald Trump to meet with Henry Kissinger
summary: US Republican presidential candidate Donald Trump is set to meet with former Secretary of State Henry Kissinger in New York, following weeks of telephone conversations. The meeting comes after Trump's foreign policy proposals were criticized by former Secretary of State James Baker, who claimed they would make the world less stable. The meeting between Trump and Kissinger, a top adviser to Presidents Nixon and Ford, has been reported by the Washington Post.

site_title: Singapore NODX rises 4.5% in April, up from March's 0.1%
summary: Singapore's non-oil domestic exports (NODX) rose 4.5% in April, up from March's 0.1%, but still fell 7.9% year-on-year. Shipments declined to most top 10 markets except EU and Hong Kong. Electronic NODX fell 7.4%, while non-electronic NODX declined 8.1%. Non-oil re-exports eased 2.8% in April, following a 3% fall in March. The decline was attributed to shipments to Taiwan, South Korea, and Indonesia.

site_title: Oracle co-CEO says it did not buy Sun Micro to sue Google
summary: Oracle co-CEO Safra Catz testified that the company acquired Sun Microsystems in 2009 to protect its products relying on Sun's software, not to sue Google over copyright infringement. Catz stated that Sun had a dispute with Google over Java, and Oracle acquired Sun to prevent a competitor from accessing this strategic software. The jury will now decide if Google's use of Java under fair-use provisions warrants US$9 billion in damages.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks pare early gains ahead of new govt, economy worries
summary: Taiwan's stocks remained flat on Tuesday, closing nearly unchanged at 8,065.32, as investors awaited the swearing-in of the new president and concerns about the trade-reliant economy. The main TAIEX index fell for the fourth consecutive session, with the electronics subindex rising 0.3% but the financials subindex unchanged. The uncertain outlook and economic worries weighed on the market, despite a positive start to the week in overseas markets.

site_title: Honours for De Niro, tears from legendary boxer Duran in Cannes
summary: Legendary boxer Roberto Duran was honored at a screening of the film "Hands of Stone" in Cannes, starring Robert De Niro. The film tells Duran's life story, including his rise to boxing stardom and his infamous "No Mas" incident. De Niro was also honored for his five-decade acting career, receiving a standing ovation and emotional tributes from Duran and other attendees. The film will be released internationally in August and September, and is directed by Jonathan Jakubowicz.

site_title: Hacker pleads guilty in US over press release insider scheme
summary: A Ukrainian man, Vadym Iermolovych, has pleaded guilty to hacking into services that distribute corporate news releases and using stolen information for insider trading, resulting in over $100 million in alleged illegal profit. He was part of a worldwide scheme with nine others, including traders and hackers, who hacked into over 150,000 news releases from February 2010 to August 2015. Iermolovych faces 5-1/2 to 6-1/4 years in prison for conspiracy to commit wire fraud, computer hacking, and aggravated identity theft.

site_title: Buffett's Berkshire invested US$1b in Apple
summary: Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway invested over $1 billion in Apple, marking a rare foray into the technology sector. The investment, made in the first quarter, boosted Apple shares by 3% despite concerns about the company's valuation. Berkshire's largest technology bet remains its $12 billion stake in IBM. The investment comes as Apple faces a declining market value and increasing competition.

images.alt_text: Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway Inc revealed a more than US$1 billion stake in Apple Inc, a rare foray into the technology sector that the billionaire has largely shunned, apart from a poorly performing investment in IBM.

site_title: Google merges skills to launch Spaces sharing app
summary: Google has launched a new app called Spaces, allowing users to easily share content and commentary on any topic. The app, available on Android and iOS devices, uses Google Search, YouTube, and Chrome, making it simple to find and share articles, videos, and images. Users can create a space with a single tap and invite others via messaging, email, or social networks. The app will be showcased at Google's annual developers conference, which will focus on virtual reality, artificial intelligence, and the Android operating system.

site_title: Takata declares nearly 14m US air bag inflators defective
summary: Takata Corp, a Japanese air bag manufacturer, has filed reports with US auto safety regulators declaring nearly 14 million air bag inflators defective. This is the first tranche of a 35-40 million recall expansion, announced earlier this month. The issue has linked to 13 deaths and over 100 injuries, with malfunctioning inflators capable of exploding with shrapnel. The recall is the largest in US auto safety history, and Takata has agreed to work with manufacturers to develop a recall plan for high-humidity areas.

site_title: Brazil's Temer wants proposal for pension reform within 30 days
summary: Brazilian interim President Michel Temer agreed to draft a pension reform proposal within 30 days, aiming to address a fiscal gap equivalent to 10% of last year's economic output. The proposal will include raising the minimum retirement age and possibly legalizing gambling to boost revenue. Temer's move seeks to restore confidence in the country's largest economy, which has been struggling with a burdensome pension system.

site_title: Hyflux launches offer of up to S$300m perpetuals at 6%
summary: Hyflux has launched an offer of up to S$300 million of perpetual capital securities (perps) paying 6% annually, with the option to reset the rate from May 2020. The company is offering S$230 million to the public, S$20 million to directors, and S$50 million to institutional investors. If oversubscribed, the total offer size could reach S$500 million. Distributions will be paid semi-annually, starting on Nov 27, 2016.

site_title: Olympics to give battered Brazil economy only limited boost: report
summary: Moody's report states the Rio Olympics will give Brazil's economy a limited boost, with a temporary increase in tax revenues and infrastructure improvements. Spending $7.1 billion on Olympics infrastructure will be equivalent to 12 cities' spending in 2014. However, the Games will not change Brazil's deepening recession, and construction spending is almost over. The Olympics are expected to benefit sectors such as broadcasters and car rental companies, but some projects, like the express bus system, have uncertain commercial prospects.

images.alt_text: The Rio Olympics in August will give Brazil's battered economy only a limited shot in the arm, Moody's ratings agency said Monday, as bad news mounted for the city's Olympic transportation network.

site_title: Alberta blaze nears Enbridge oil-sands terminal as flames spread
summary: Wildfires in northern Alberta, Canada, have spread to within a kilometre of an Enbridge oil-sands terminal, forcing crews to use bulldozers to keep the blaze away. Despite warm weather and wind, the flames are expected to be pushed away from the facility, allowing Enbridge mainlines to continue operating. The fires have been raging for over two weeks, with Alberta Premier Rachel Notley urging caution.

site_title: Oil prices hit 2016 peaks on talk of supply deficit
summary: Oil prices surged to six-and-a-half month peaks on May 16, 2016, due to a short-term supply deficit predicted by Goldman Sachs. The report cited production outages in Nigeria and increased demand as the main causes of the deficit. This unexpected shift led to a sudden increase in oil prices, with Goldman Sachs stating that the oil market had moved from near storage saturation to a deficit earlier than anticipated.

site_title: UK job vacancies fall on Brexit worries, higher minimum wage
summary: UK job vacancies fell 9% in April, with a 27% decline from last year, due to uncertainty over the EU referendum and the introduction of a higher minimum wage. The slump in recruitment began in March and accelerated in April, with the UK labour market slowing in recent months. Economists expect a Brexit to hurt the economy in the short-term, contributing to the decline.

site_title: There's reason to be cautious about BOC Aviation
summary: Investors should exercise caution when considering BOC Aviation's US$1.1 billion initial public offering due to the aircraft leasing industry's inherent risks, particularly in the Asian market. Despite BOC Aviation's diverse regional presence, the company's returns are lower than those of its peers, trading at 11 times its net income, compared to AerCap's 6.53 times earnings. The region's indebtedness and potential overcapacity also raise concerns, making it a less attractive investment opportunity.

site_title: US: Stocks lifted by oil rally, Buffett's Apple stake
summary: US stocks rose 1.0% on Monday, driven by a rally in oil prices and Warren Buffett's $1 billion stake in Apple. Oil prices reached new 2016 highs, while petroleum-linked shares surged. Most retailers also gained, with Home Depot and Wal-Mart advancing 1.7% ahead of earnings releases. The market's decline over the past three weeks may have attracted buyers, according to analysts.

site_title: Billionaire Soros cuts US stocks by 37%, buys gold miner
summary: Billionaire George Soros cut his US stock holdings by 37% in the first quarter, selling stakes in Level 3 Communications, Dow Chemical, and Endo International, and buying a $264 million stake in Barrick Gold Corp. Soros also acquired call options on gold, citing concerns over China's economy and potential global deflationary pressures. This move follows warnings from Soros that a hard landing in China is "practically unavoidable" and could boost US government bonds.

site_title: Japan likely to time further fiscal, monetary easing with G-7 meetings
summary: Japan is set to announce further fiscal and monetary easing at the upcoming G-7 meetings in Sendai, potentially paving the way for other G-7 members to increase stimulus. Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's government is unlikely to accept criticism of Abenomics, instead using the meetings to announce additional economic policies. The move comes as Japan's economy faces challenges, and Abe's government seeks to revitalize growth. The announcement may also influence global economic trends, particularly in the wake of the US's recent tariff announcements.

site_title: Gold falls from early gains as US equities turn higher
summary: Gold prices fell from early gains as US equities rose, reversing a 1% gain. Spot gold declined 0.05% to $1,272.50 an ounce, while US gold futures rose 0.1%. The drop was attributed to strong crude futures and US equity markets, which led to a decrease in interest in gold as an alternative asset. The decline was also influenced by a weaker US dollar and rising Treasury yields, following a six-month high in crude futures.

images.alt_text: Gold prices turned slightly negative on Monday, reversing gains of one per cent on pressure from strong crude futures and US equity markets.

site_title: US top envoy Kerry to visit Egypt's Sisi
summary: US Secretary of State John Kerry is set to visit Egypt's President Abdel-Fattah al-Sisi in Cairo amid a crackdown on political freedoms in the country. Kerry's talks will cover bilateral and regional issues, following criticism of the US government for authorizing arms sales to Egypt without proper checks. Egyptian authorities have recently jailed 152 protesters, raising concerns about an authoritarian assault on dissent. The visit comes as Egypt faces growing international pressure over human rights and democracy.

site_title: Housing scheme history repeats itself
summary: A housing scheme model similar to "land contracts" or "contracts for deeds" is resurging, where investors buy foreclosed homes by the thousands and sell them on contract. This model, popularized in the mid-20th century, victimized black home buyers by offering them alternative lending options with limited protections, resulting in them losing their investments. Rutgers historian Beryl Satter's 2009 book, "Family Properties," highlighted the issue, which is now being revisited as conventional lending becomes increasingly difficult for some buyers.

images.alt_text: The foreclosure crisis has created a vast stock of vacant homes, many of which have deteriorated through neglect.

site_title: SandRidge, Breitburn join wave of energy bankruptcy filings
summary: SandRidge Energy Inc and Breitburn Energy Partners LP filed for Chapter 11 bankruptcy protection on May 16, 2016, amidst the US energy price crash. Over 60 North American oil and gas producers have filed for bankruptcy since early 2015. SandRidge estimated $7 billion in assets and $4 billion in debt, while Breitburn listed $4.7 billion in assets and $3.4 billion in liabilities. The surge in bankruptcy filings highlights the significant impact of the energy price crash on US energy producers.

site_title: Consortium launches privatisation bid for Eu Yan Sang
summary: A consortium led by a UOB-backed fund and Temasek Holdings has launched a S$0.60 cash takeover bid for Eu Yan Sang International, aiming to delist the 16-year-old mainboard-listed traditional Chinese medicine retailer. The bid, filed with the Singapore Exchange, is being led by Eu Yan Sang's group CEO Richard Eu. The goal is to end Eu Yan Sang's mainboard listing, following a report by the Business Times last week.

site_title: Deutsche Bank names Thomas Piquemal to lead global M&A group
summary: Deutsche Bank has appointed Thomas Piquemal, 47, as head of global mergers and acquisitions and chairman of corporate and investment banking in France. Piquemal, formerly senior executive vice president at Electricite de France, will be based in Paris and report to Jeff Unwin. The move comes as Deutsche Bank ranks 11th globally in advising on deals this year, and 7th in Europe. Piquemal's experience includes advising on high-profile deals such as Anheuser-Busch's US$105 billion takeover of SABMiller.

images.alt_text: Deutsche Bank AG named Thomas Piquemal head of global mergers and acquisitions and chairman of corporate and investment banking in France.

site_title: Dubai airport a transit point for drugs traffic to Europe, says Italy
summary: Dubai International Airport has become a transit point for smugglers bringing high-value narcotics into Europe, according to Italian police. Two smugglers, one from Slovakia and one from Nigeria, were arrested at Rome's Fiumicino airport after arriving via Dubai, with seizures totaling around half a million dollars. The smugglers use Dubai's transit lounge, exploiting its tough anti-drug reputation, to mask their origin and avoid detection. The tactic involves creating an unsuspicious itinerary, allowing the smugglers to pass through without raising suspicion.

site_title: WDA gives a leg-up to mid-career PMETs keen to switch to wafer fab industry
summary: Singapore's Workforce Development Agency (WDA) has launched a professional conversion programme to help mid-career professionals (PMETs) transition to the wafer fabrication industry. The 6-12 month programme, supported by 70% of the trainee's salary, aims to provide training for PMETs to acquire new skills and expertise in a growing industry. Three major wafer fabrication firms have committed to hiring PMETs under the programme, with up to 70 local hires projected over the next 12 months.

site_title: Saudi Arabia's US$117 billion treasuries tally poses fresh puzzle
summary: Saudi Arabia's foreign reserves, valued at US$587 billion, include US$116.8 billion in US Treasuries as of March, according to the US Treasury Department. This represents about 20% of the country's foreign reserves and 10% of China and Japan's. The figure is lower than expected, sparking questions about the kingdom's remaining dollar-denominated investments, with strategists suggesting it may hold fewer dollar-denominated securities than anticipated, or park securities in custody or own other securities not reflected in the data.

site_title: World Bank weighs issuing bond to fight pandemics, CFO Levy says
summary: The World Bank is considering issuing "pandemic bonds" to provide emergency funding to countries affected by outbreaks such as Ebola. The debt, modeled after catastrophe bonds, would release funds if a virus is detected. The first issue would likely be around $200 million and last three to five years. The World Bank plans to present a proposal to G-7 leaders on May 26-27, seeking financial support to implement the plan. The move aims to address underinvestment in pandemic response and provide faster access to funds during outbreaks.

site_title: Vallianz bags OSV charter contracts worth up to US$210m
summary: Vallianz Holdings has secured contracts worth up to US$210 million to supply 13 offshore support vessels to an undisclosed national oil company in the Middle East. The vessels will be chartered for up to seven years, with deployment starting in the second half of 2016.

site_title: HK ups security for high-level China official visit
summary: Hong Kong authorities have increased security measures ahead of a high-level Chinese official visit, including gluing down paving stones and setting up barricades, in an effort to prevent protesters from using them as missiles. The visit by Zhang Dejiang, who chairs China's legislature, aims to ease tensions and gauge the political temperature, but activists have voiced fury over the clampdown. The visit comes as Beijing tightens its grip on Hong Kong, where a fledgling independence movement has angered China, and amid concerns over the erosion of freedoms in the semi-autonomous city.

site_title: Twitter to free room for links and photos: report
summary: Twitter plans to expand its 140-character limit to allow users to post links and photos without reducing the post length, potentially increasing user engagement. The change may occur by the end of May, according to a Bloomberg report. The move aims to accommodate the growing trend of sharing multimedia content, which could help boost user numbers and communication on the platform. Twitter's quarterly update showed a slight increase in monthly active users to 310 million. The company also announced the addition of BET Networks CEO Debra Lee to its board.

site_title: South Korea's Han Kang wins Man Booker International Prize
summary: South Korean author Han Kang won the Man Booker International Prize for her novel "The Vegetarian", sharing the £50,000 award with her translator Deborah Smith. The novel, described as "lyrical and lacerating", tells the story of a woman's rejection of convention from three perspectives. This is the first time the award has gone jointly to a translator, who had only taught herself Korean three years before translation. The award recognizes the growing popularity of translations in the English-language literary world.

site_title: Europe: Shares steady as miners rise but Eutelsat slumps
summary: European shares ended steady on Monday, recouping early losses, as mining stocks rose on firmer metals prices. The FTSEurofirst 300 index ended flat despite earlier falls of up to 0.6%. Telecom Italia rose 3% on cost-cutting plans, while Anglo American benefited from a Bank of America Merrill Lynch upgrade. Eutelsat slumped 6.8% after Morgan Stanley cut its rating to "underweight". The FTSEurofirst is down 9% for 2016, with global markets affected by concerns over China's economy.

site_title: Alberta wildfire near Enbridge crude oil tank farm: officials
summary: A massive wildfire near Fort McMurray, Alberta, is about 1 km away from Enbridge's Cheecham crude oil tank farm, but is under control. The fire, which has burned 285,000 hectares, is stable due to cooperative winds, but hot, dry conditions and lightning fires are expected to challenge firefighting efforts. Residents are still not allowed to return to their homes due to thousands of hotspots, and the air quality health index is at 38. No timeline has been set for residents to return, with Alberta Premier Rachel Notley hoping for more information by the end of the week.

site_title: Hedge funds continue to bet on silver even as rally fades
summary: Hedge funds have increased their bullish bets on silver to an all-time high, despite the metal's price rally showing signs of fatigue. Money managers added to their net-long positions in silver for the fourth time in five weeks, with 71,656 US futures and options contracts held as of May 10. The price surge is attributed to speculation on global growth and interest rate increases, but some investors are reassessing the outlook due to manufacturing growth concerns. The price of silver has risen 24% this year.

site_title: Container lines should learn from airline industry
summary: Container shipping companies are forming alliances to cut costs and better utilize spare capacity, mirroring the airline industry's strategy. The four major container-liner alliances are rapidly shifting, with Hapag-Lloyd joining an alliance with five Asian carriers, and the world's largest shipping companies forming partnerships like the 2M and Ocean alliances. However, the shift towards consolidation may not be beneficial for exporters who rely on low freight rates, and competition regulators should be on alert. This trend could lead to reduced competition and higher prices for goods, as seen in the US airline industry.

site_title: NTU launches project to enhance cyber security
summary: Nanyang Technological University (NTU) in Singapore has launched the Cyber Risk Management (CyRiM) Project to enhance the nation's cyber security amid escalating global incidents. The three-year initiative aims to help businesses and institutions defend against cyber attacks, promote research in cyber risk and insurance, and recommend policies to the Singapore government for advanced cyber risk protection. The project is a collaborative effort between NTU and industry players, aiming to improve the nation's cyber security landscape.

site_title: Italian establishment launches counter-bid for RCS Mediagroup
summary: Italy's corporate establishment has launched a 776 million-euro counter-bid for RCS Mediagroup, a publisher of Corriere della Sera, Italy's top-selling mainstream newspaper. The consortium, including investment bank Mediobanca and tyremaker Pirelli, aims to prevent the company from falling into the hands of media tycoon Urbano Cairo. The cash bid surpasses Cairo's all-share offer of 0.532 euros per share, and analysts expect the consortium's offer to prevail. The bid battle is seen as strategically significant to control Corriere della Sera, which could play a crucial role in Italy's upcoming referendum on Prime Minister Matteo Renzi's constitutional reform.

site_title: South China Sea dispute gets more complicated for Asean
summary: A Taiwan government-linked organisation has made a last-minute submission to the Permanent Court of Arbitration in The Hague, complicating the South China Sea dispute. The claim seeks a swath of the region as Taiwan's exclusive economic zone, potentially delaying the court's judgement on the Philippines' case. This move may be part of a party-to-party cooperation between Taiwan and China, with the goal of undermining the joint Asean position and allowing Beijing to pursue a bilateral approach to negotiations.

site_title: Protests cloud Brazil acting president's political honeymoon
summary: Brazil's acting President Michel Temer faces challenges in his first full week in power as street protests and controversy surround his government. Protests broke out in several cities, including Rio de Janeiro and Brasilia, and opposition leaders criticized the lack of female ministers in his cabinet. Temer's approval ratings are low, and he faces opposition from the left, unions, and social media. Despite his vow to unite the country, Temer's honeymoon period is clouded by controversy, with polls showing he is almost as unpopular as his predecessor, Dilma Rousseff.

site_title: Malaysia's Felda says palm output drops as El Nino bites
summary: Malaysia's Felda Global Ventures Berhad, the world's third largest palm plantations operator, reported a 17% drop in palm oil output due to dry conditions caused by El Nino. The decline is expected to boost crude palm oil prices by up to 20% by August. Felda's newly-appointed CEO, Zakaria Arshad, aims to get green certification for 15 processing mills by year-end, despite withdrawing from the Roundtable on Sustainable Palm Oil (RSPO) certification earlier this year.

site_title: Junta spending boosts Thai growth but risks remain
summary: Thailand's economy grew 3.2% in the first quarter driven by strong tourism and public spending. This marks a solid start despite the country's history of political instability and sluggish exports. Analysts warn that the growth is still shaky, and the economy's long-term prospects remain uncertain. The country's tourism sector, in particular, is seen as a key driver of growth, but the impact of external factors such as global trade tensions and economic shifts in the region will be closely watched. The Thai government's efforts to boost spending and stimulate growth will be crucial in determining the country's economic trajectory.

site_title: Striking Singapore death penalty film stirs emotions at Cannes
summary: Singaporean filmmaker Boo Junfeng's film "Apprentice," which premiered at the Cannes film festival, tells the story of the executioner trade from the hangman's perspective. The film, which took five years to make, explores the complex and often humane side of the death penalty through the eyes of a young prison guard who learns the trade from a seasoned executioner. Boo's approach aims to humanize the issue, rather than making a straightforward activist film, and has sparked debate among those who support the death penalty in Singapore.

site_title: PM Lee makes first bilateral visit to Russia
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong made his first bilateral visit to Russia, a four-day trip that includes meetings with Moscow leaders and a special summit in Sochi to mark 20 years of dialogue ties between Russia and ASEAN. This marks the first visit by a Singapore leader since Lee Kuan Yew in 1990.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen
PM Lee being greeted by President Vladimir Putin in September 2013 at a welcoming ceremony of the G20 Leaders' Summit in St Petersburg.

site_title: Private banking in region shifting to fee-based model: BOS
summary: Bank of Singapore Ltd (BOS), a private banking unit of Oversea-Chinese Banking Corp, expects the region's private banking industry to shift towards a fee-based model, replacing traditional commission-based practices. Clients prefer managed portfolios with consistent returns, especially in volatile global financial markets. BOS aims to increase managed portfolios to 40% of client assets, focusing on quality advice and transparency. The bank has already acquired Barclays wealth units in Singapore and Hong Kong for $320 million, and expects to complete the acquisition by the end of this year.

images.alt_text: Mr Shaari sees the trend towards fee-based advice continuing in Asia, adding it's possible that the proportion of BOS client assets in managed and discretionary portfolios will rise to 40% in future.

site_title: Sandberg's speech on resilience may form basis for second book
summary: Facebook COO Sheryl Sandberg shares her journey of resilience after her husband's death in a graduation speech at the University of California at Berkeley. She emphasizes that resilience is a skill that can be built, not innate, and encourages students to focus on gratitude and finding strength in their ability to overcome challenges. Sandberg's speech may be the basis for a potential second book on the subject, following her first book "Lean In".

site_title: Hyundai raids Bentley to turbo-charge Genesis luxury drive
summary: Hyundai Motor Co has hired Bentley's exterior designer, Sangyup Lee, as its head of design, to work with Luc Donckerwolke on the Genesis premium car brand. Lee, who also designed for General Motors and Volkswagen, aims to make Genesis a recognized global premium brand. Hyundai sees limited growth unless it breaks into new markets, particularly in premium cars and parts of South-east Asia. The move is part of Chung Euisun's plan to elevate Hyundai to an elite global corporate league alongside luxury brands.

site_title: Boeing, Oman fund among investors in BOC Aviation's US$1.1b IPO
summary: BOC Aviation Ltd, the aircraft leasing unit of Bank of China Ltd, raised US$1.1 billion in its initial public offering (IPO) in Hong Kong, attracting investors including Boeing Co, China Investment Corp, and the Silk Road Fund. The IPO is the second dedicated Asian air lessor to go public, following China Aircraft Leasing Group Holdings in 2014. The company aims to begin trading on June 1, with BOC Aviation management meeting investors through May 23.

site_title: Cordlife ex-CEO tells his side of the story
summary: Jeremy Yee, former CEO of Cordlife Group, has shared his side of the story after stepping down in March. He claims he was given two options: resign or face termination, with no opportunity to renegotiate his contract. Yee denies wanting to leave with full 10% profit entitlement, stating it was up to the remuneration committee to decide. He also disputes that he wanted to be paid the full sum, citing a supplemental deed that entitled him to profit sharing. Yee defends his track record, saying his performance speaks for itself, and accepts the board's discretion in his leadership.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel
Mr Yee ended weeks of silence after his sudden resignation, saying: "I believe my track record for the company speaks for itself."

site_title: China's Didi to consider IPO in US next year
summary: China's Didi Chuxing, the country's largest ride-hailing app, is reportedly considering an initial public offering (IPO) in New York next year. The timing depends on its battle with Uber in China. Didi has raised about $3 billion in funding, including a $1 billion investment from Apple, swelling its valuation to $26 billion. The company is on track to turn an operating profit "soon" and has expanded its reach to 14 million registered drivers in China. A successful IPO could make Didi the largest Chinese company to go public since Alibaba in 2014.

site_title: April new private home sales down 11.6%
summary: Private home sales in Singapore decreased by 11.6% in April, with 745 units sold. This marks a pull-back from the 8-month high in March. Notably, existing projects showed stronger demand than new launches, sparking mixed reactions from analysts. The decline in sales highlights a potential shift in market trends, with developers focusing on existing projects rather than new launches.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Brokerages raise target prices for Singapore Airlines and Thai Beverage, citing strong Q2 performance and low oil prices benefiting the airline. Jumbo Group's earnings per share are expected to rise 6% in FY16, while Thai Beverage's beer and spirits sales are expected to increase. NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer is 9.8 times oversubscribed, and Singapore stocks notch a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Penny stocks in play as blue-chip interest dips
summary: Blue-chip stocks have seen a decline in interest over the past few weeks, leading to a surge in speculative small caps, including Attilan, LionGold, and Blumont. Penny stocks such as ISR Capital have experienced significant gains, with ISR's shares rising 42.7% in six trading sessions. Brokers attribute the sudden interest to traders seeking to make money in low-priced counters, despite some companies being part of ongoing investigations.

site_title: UnionPay, DBS launch debit card
summary: UnionPay International and DBS have launched a debit card that allows Singapore consumers to make payments in China, expanding payment options for travelers. The card is set to be offered from June 3, and it will provide an alternative to UnionPay's dominance in the Chinese market. This move is expected to benefit Singapore consumers traveling to China, who previously had limited payment options.

site_title: Brexit could lead to downgrades for other EU countries: Fitch
summary: A British exit from the European Union could lead to downgrades in the credit ratings of other EU countries with close trade or financial ties to Britain, including Germany, France, and Spain. Ireland, Malta, Belgium, the Netherlands, Cyprus, and Luxembourg are most exposed due to their high exports to the UK, which account for at least 8% of their GDP. Fitch warns that widespread uncertainty could create economic and political risks, potentially leading to negative rating actions in the medium term.

site_title: Hines offering real estate portfolio for sale: report
summary: US real estate company Hines is selling a US$5.5 billion portfolio of properties, including a London office building leased to Morgan Stanley, as part of its global real estate investment trust. The portfolio, valued at about US$5.3 billion, includes 43 properties across the US, UK, Australia, Germany, Poland, France, and Russia. Hines has hired Lazard to advise on the sale, with no set timetable, amid declining US commercial real estate values. The sale comes as total return from London investment properties hit a 6-year low in February.

site_title: Creative leadership in SMEs is about nurturing out-of-the-box thinking
summary: A Greek philosopher once said that change is the only constant. In today's fast-paced business environment, small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) need creative leadership to navigate unpredictable waters. This involves bringing out the creativity in others and harnessing it as a driving force to power the organization forward. Effective creative leadership can transform an organization, solve problems, and create positive change. By cultivating an organizational culture that values creative thinking and problem-solving, SMEs can adapt to a changing environment and stay afloat, even in the face of adversity.

site_title: Chinese top foreign buyers of US homes in 2015
summary: Chinese nationals became the largest foreign buyers of US homes in 2015, investing over $93 billion in residential real estate and $17 billion in commercial property between 2010 and 2015. Their total investment of over $110 billion has helped the US real estate market recover from the 2006 crash and is expected to double to $218 billion by the end of the decade. Chinese buyers are concentrated in expensive US markets, paying an average of $832,000 per home, and their motivations include investing in rental and resale properties, as well as seeking safe offshore assets.

site_title: Southwest pilot tensions flare anew over arrival of B737 jets
summary: Southwest Airlines pilots, frustrated with four years of unsuccessful contract talks, have asked the carrier to guarantee it won't force them to fly the new Boeing 737 Max before a new agreement is reached. The pilots claim this would violate the Railway Labor Act's "status quo" provision, setting a standard for negotiations between airlines and labor. The 737 Max is scheduled to enter the market in the first half of 2017, and Southwest has maintained its delivery commitments. The pilots' union president, Jon Weaks, expressed doubts about the airline's willingness to negotiate an acceptable contract.

site_title: Stop using GDP as a punching bag
summary: The article argues against overhauling the Gross Domestic Product (GDP) as a measure of economic growth, citing concerns that it could be politicized and misunderstood. Critics claim that GDP is incomplete and misleading, but the author counters that it is a useful indicator of economic production, subdivided into segments such as consumer spending and business investment. The author notes that GDP has evolved over time to address limitations, including the shift from a manufacturing to a service economy, but acknowledges that it still has problems, such as undercounting non-market activities like healthcare and education. The article concludes that trying to modify or replace GDP to promote other goals, such as equality or environmentalism, is undesirable and should be debated openly.

site_title: Worst is over for platinum, palladium prices, say traders
summary: Platinum and palladium prices are expected to rise 20% by the end of 2016, with platinum reaching $1,153 an ounce and palladium reaching $660 an ounce, according to traders and analysts surveyed by Bloomberg. The metals have rallied from their lowest points in half a decade, driven by low US interest rates and growing demand from carmakers. Industry experts predict a bull market, with Impala Platinum Holdings forecasting deficits in the medium to long term due to increasing car emissions regulations.

site_title: Buffett's Berkshire invests in Apple
summary: Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway Inc has invested in Apple Inc, acquiring 9.81 million shares worth about $1.07 billion as of March 31. This investment comes after iPhone sales fell for the first time, with Berkshire betting on a stock price rebound. The investment amount is equivalent to about 0.2% of Berkshire's total market value. It is unclear whether Buffett or his portfolio managers made the investment.

site_title: Lum Chang in JV for mixed-use M'sia project
summary: Construction company Lum Chang Holdings (LCH) has formed a joint venture with Tien Wah Press Holdings Berhad (TWPH) to undertake a mixed-use development in Malaysia. LCH will acquire a 13,040 sq m piece of leasehold industrial land in Petaling Jaya for RM63.75 million, with the JV company Sterling Model Sdn Bhd owning and managing the project. The joint venture will fund the consideration through a combination of shareholder funding and external borrowings, with expected gains for TWPH of about RM29.5 million.

site_title: Squatters see new haven in Las Vegas
summary: Squatters in Las Vegas are taking over abandoned homes in struggling neighborhoods and upscale communities, bringing a trail of crime with them. The housing collapse eight years ago has left many properties vacant, providing a new haven for squatters. The issue highlights the ongoing impact of the housing collapse and the need for solutions to address homelessness and property abandonment.

images.alt_text: A shopping cart outside a vacant home in Las Vegas. Down-and-out gamblers and opportunists have their pick of thousands of empty, foreclosed homes in the city, and the problem seems to be worsening.

site_title: Vice-presidential picks will be key test for Clinton and Trump
summary: US presidential candidates Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump are considering their vice-presidential running mates, a key test for both campaigns. The selection process has become more prominent due to changes in US politics, with the vice-president's role gaining power and influence. Clinton and Trump will aim to choose candidates that won't "do harm" to their prospects, with potential picks including experienced politicians like Senator Tim Kaine and Senator Rob Portman. The vice-presidential selection has historically been influenced by factors like party balance and regional representation, but modern considerations are less relevant, with a focus on short-term political calculation and historical precedent.

images.alt_text: Supporters of Mrs Clinton and Mr Trump outside a campaign event in Williamson, West Virginia. It is likely that Mrs Clinton, who is 68, and Mr Trump, who is 69, will select candidates younger than themselves who could well be future presidential candidates.

site_title: MUFG sees full-year profit falling 11% amid negative rates
summary: MUFG, Japan's largest bank, expects a 11% decline in full-year profit due to negative interest rates and increasing bad-loan costs. The bank aims for a net income of 850 billion yen (S$11 billion) for the year ending March 2017, lower than analysts' estimates of 982 billion yen.

site_title: Pan Ocean Q1 net profit falls 40%; tonnage oversupply, slow demand expected to continue
summary: Pan Ocean Co Ltd, a South Korean bulk carrier, reported a 39.6% decline in Q1 net profit to US$61.4 million, citing tonnage oversupply and slow demand. Despite a 3.6% increase in sales to US$376.6 million, costs of sales rose 11.5%, resulting in an operating profit of US$32.3 million. The company expects the market situation to remain similar to 2015, with a chronic oversupply of tonnages and slow demand.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: OCBC optimistic about growing loans to SMEs
summary: OCBC Bank is optimistic about growing loans to small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) in Singapore, despite moderating economic expansion globally. The bank's head of emerging business, Eric Ong, expects a boost from government-led projects in infrastructure and healthcare. SMEs are increasingly keen to tap into government-led schemes, such as the venture debt programme, to boost workforce efficiency and productivity. OCBC has chosen to offer venture capital loans to companies without requiring them to be backed by venture capitalists. The bank aims to provide up to S$500 million in venture debt loans to SMEs by March 2018.

images.alt_text: William Maurice, director of Solar-DrivenAsia, with his relationship manager who assisted him with his microloan application.
OCBC's head of emerging business Eric Ong

site_title: China's record daily steel output in April bodes ill for world rivals
summary: China's record daily steel output in April reached 2.314 million tonnes, exceeding the previous best set in June 2014. This surge in production, driven by higher prices, poses a threat to the global steel industry, which is already struggling with a deluge of exports from China. Analysts predict that Chinese mills will continue to prioritize exports over domestic demand, exacerbating oversupply risks.

site_title: From local to global - lifting a brand overseas
summary: ClearSK, a Singapore-based medi-aesthetic and wellness company, has expanded its operations to Shanghai, China, marking its first overseas venture. Founded by medical expert Shiau Ee Leng and business manager Daniel Then, the company aims to tap into China's vast market, which is about four to five times larger than Singapore's. ClearSK leverages the Singapore brand's reliability and trustworthiness to establish itself in the Chinese market, with plans to grow further through joint ventures and franchisee-doctor concepts. The company's expansion is supported by government resources, including grants from the Customer-Centric Initiative and Market Readiness Assistance.

images.alt_text: ClearSK's founders hail from vastly different backgrounds. While Dr Shiau (left) used to be a general practitioner, Mr Then (right) first worked in the public sector, before moving to the private sector where he took on the role of chief financial officer in an SGX-listed company.

site_title: German discount retail chain Aldi opts for customer-friendly design
summary: Aldi, Germany's discount supermarket chain, is updating its image with a new "Future Store" concept featuring cozy wood panelling, natural light, and a cafe area offering fair trade coffee and chilled beverages. The move, aimed at capturing changing consumer tastes and rising competition, will be rolled out in nearly 1,900 locations over the next three years. Despite the initial costs, Aldi expects long-term economic returns from the renovation, which will also introduce benches for senior citizens and baby-changing tables.

site_title: Demand for SGD bonds still hot; S$4.3b orders for 2 deals made
summary: Demand for Singapore dollar (SGD) bonds remains strong, with two new deals attracting combined orders of S$4.3 billion, leading to lower pricing. Manulife Financial Corp's 10-year SGD bond priced at 3.85% and Mapletree Logistics Trust's perpetual bond priced at 4.18%. The surge in demand is driven by investors seeking debt investments amid a "lower-for-longer" interest rate outlook and a rally in the SGD. This has resulted in SGD bonds outperforming equities, with the Singapore Fixed Income index reaching a new high.

site_title: Boeing's 787 Dreamliner remains popular but faces new challenge: slowing sales
summary: Boeing's 787 Dreamliner, a high-tech plane, faces a new challenge: slowing sales. The company needs to sell dozens of 787s to recover nearly $30 billion in production costs. Despite its popularity, sales have fallen 51% since 2013 due to industry-wide sales slump, Airbus's cheaper A330, and low fuel prices. Boeing aims to book 120 orders this year to meet its target, but leasing companies are hesitant to order the 787 due to oversupply. The company is working to make the aircraft less expensive to build and has cut its workforce to improve return on investment.

site_title: Eight Asia-Pac budget carrier rivals turn allies with new grouping
summary: Eight Asia-Pacific budget carriers, including AirAsia, Scoot, and Jetstar, have formed the Value Alliance, the first cross-border pact among low-cost carriers. The alliance aims to boost connecting traffic and simplify booking across 160 destinations with a common booking platform. By pooling resources, the carriers hope to increase sales and make travel easier for passengers. The partnership is seen as a strategic move to increase market share and competitiveness in the rapidly growing Asia-Pacific air travel market.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Shaken by the India-Mauritius tax quake
summary: India has signed a protocol with Mauritius amending the 33-year-old tax treaty, effective April 1, 2017, which will grant taxing rights on capital gains to India from sales of Indian shares by Mauritius residents. Investments made before April 1, 2017, are grandfathered, and special rules apply during a transition period until March 31, 2019. This move aims to curb treaty abuse and round-tripping of funds, while providing certainty to investors. The change may impact India's largest investor, Mauritius, and could lead to renegotiation of the India-Singapore tax treaty, which may also be affected by the shift in taxing rights.

site_title: RBS shows banks' tech nightmare as Scottish branches spur delay
summary: Royal Bank of Scotland (RBS) is struggling to divest its Williams & Glyn unit, which was sold as a condition of its EU bailout in 2009. The unit's technology systems, created over decades, are causing delays and spiraling costs, with the bank spending £50 million a month to separate the 6 branches in Scotland from the rest of the unit. The EU deadline to divest the unit is at risk, and the delay may harm the prospects for a sale, with RBS warning it may miss the 2017 deadline and facing significant financial losses.

site_title: Philips eyes windfall of almost 1b euros in May 27 IPO
summary: Dutch electronics giant Philips is set to raise almost 1 billion euros in its initial public offering (IPO) on May 27, with 37.5 million shares expected to be released at a price range of 18.50-22.50 euros. The IPO is part of Philips' plan to focus on medical equipment, which now accounts for over 40% of sales, after selling its lighting business in 2014. The company expects to raise between 694 million and 970 million euros, with net proceeds going to Royal Philips.

site_title: European vote against China market status not 'constructive': Beijing
summary: China's foreign minister described a European Parliament vote against granting China market economy status as "not at all constructive". The designation would have made it harder for Brussels to fight Beijing over alleged unfair trading practices. China joined the WTO in 2001 and argues that accession protocols dictate it will automatically switch to market economy status by December, 15 years later.

site_title: The 2016 gender gap: Is Trump playing the man's card?
summary: US presidential candidate Donald Trump's support may favor him in the 2016 election due to the gender gap. Despite making abusive comments about women, Trump's unfavorability ratings among female voters are only 70%, and women tend to vote more than men. Trump's supporters believe that married white women and white men, particularly those with lower education, may vote for him, potentially widening the gender gap. This could benefit Trump, as Clinton's main problem is with white voters in general and white men in particular, who have historically voted for Republican candidates.

site_title: Some key issues that S'pore's petrochemical sector needs to address
summary: Singapore's petrochemical sector has benefited from low crude oil prices, with margins improving 158% in South-east Asia as of April 2016. Integration has helped oil majors like ExxonMobil and Shell maintain profitability. New plants have been started, including a metallocene polyethylene plant by Prime Evolue, but the sector faces headwinds, including a potential rebound in oil prices and shrinking demand growth from China. The sector must address broader issues to achieve sustainable growth, with a conference on the topic scheduled for May 19-20.

site_title: China credit tap back on, but comes with risks, analysts warn
summary: China's credit tap surged by over 25% in the first quarter, with new loans reaching a 5-year high. The move aims to prop up growth, but analysts warn it may lead to a debt crisis and delay reform. This is a repeat of the 2008-2009 credit binge, which had severe consequences. The short-term solution may not be effective, and policymakers face growing pressure to address the issue as China's GDP growth is expected to slow.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Limited's proposed listing of Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust (FLT) on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) has been given the go-ahead. The Reit will hold a portfolio of Australian industrial assets. Mapletree Logistics Trust plans to issue S$250 million of fixed-rate perpetual securities for general corporate funding purposes. Cosco Corporation (Singapore) has delayed the delivery of a jack-up drilling rig to KS Drilling Pte Ltd to December 31, 2017. Xpress Holdings has signed a non-binding MOU to invest S$1 million in Amplify Me Pte Ltd for a 70% equity stake.

site_title: Yen erases early gains on Japan intervention talks
summary: Japan's yen fell on Monday as the country prepared to host a G-7 meeting, erasing early gains made on disappointing Chinese data. Vice-Finance Minister Masatsugu Asakawa indicated Japan's willingness to intervene in the market to deal with excessive exchange rate moves. Investors trimmed yen positions, expecting potential easing of monetary policy to bolster inflation and growth, with some analysts predicting the dollar/yen could move above 110 in May. Japan's first-quarter GDP data, due on May 18, will be closely watched.

site_title: China Web giants look to hip-hop, wingsuits in virtual reality spending
summary: China's web giants Alibaba, Tencent, and Baidu are investing heavily in virtual reality, allocating $1.1 billion to fuel a domestic market expected to grow 36 times in four years to $11.5 billion. The companies are positioning themselves as middlemen, partnering with startups and developers to create content and hardware. This strategy aims to capitalize on China's vast virtual reality market, which is expected to reach 55 billion yuan by 2020. The companies are also exploring applications such as immersive video and online gaming.

site_title: Thai Airways Q1 profit up by a third, fuel costs down
summary: Thai Airways International reported a 32% increase in quarterly net profit to 6 billion baht (S$232.43 million) for the January-March quarter, driven by a drop in fuel expenses. The airline's operating profit rose 63% to 7.2 billion baht, despite a 3.8% decline in passenger yield due to intense competition. The airline aims to reduce operating costs and boost revenue through cost-cutting and restructuring efforts. Thai Airways plans to take delivery of 2 Airbus A350-900XWB planes and sell 14 decommissioned aircraft in 2016.

site_title: Overseas utilities a new growth engine for Sembcorp?
summary: Sembcorp Industries' utilities division is emerging as a growth engine for the company, driven by its expansion into overseas markets. The division now accounts for 70% of the group's net profit, up from 52% last year. Sembcorp has secured over 3,800 megawatts of new power projects and 1.3 million cubic meters of water a day through 16 projects over the next three years. However, analysts differ in their views, citing risks such as regulatory and currency risks, as well as the potential for teething problems in new markets.

site_title: French abstract artist Francois Morellet, 90, dies
summary: Francois Morellet, a French abstract artist, died at 90 on May 11, 2016, at his home in Cholet, France. Known for his use of unorthodox materials and mathematical concepts in his work, Morellet was a prominent figure in postwar abstract art. He was featured in numerous exhibitions, including the 1965 "The Responsive Eye" at the Museum of Modern Art and a 2011 retrospective at the Pompidou Centre in Paris. Morellet's work often incorporated lines, shapes, and chance, and he was a pioneer of the Groupe de Recherche d'Art Visuel, which emphasized public participation in art.

site_title: Oil prices rise on Nigeria outages and Goldman forecast
summary: Oil prices surged over 2% to their highest since November 2015 due to supply disruptions in Nigeria and a shift in Goldman Sachs' forecast, with Brent crude futures trading at $49.05 per barrel. The disruptions, combined with sustained demand and declining production, pushed oil production below consumption levels for the first time in two years, starting to deplete the massive stockpiles that had previously driven prices down by 70%. Goldman expects the market to flip back into a surplus in the first half of 2017.

site_title: China media is silent 50 years after Cultural Revolution
summary: China's official media remained largely silent on the 50th anniversary of the Cultural Revolution, a tumultuous decade that left the country in chaos. The People's Daily and Global Times published limited coverage, with the Global Times discussing the popularity of Cultural Revolution memorabilia without providing political context. The Communist Party has officially disavowed the movement, attributing its failures to Mao Zedong and restricting discussion to maintain the legitimacy of its rule. Users discussing the anniversary on Weibo were censored, with many commenting on the need for further investigation and discussion of the period's impact.

site_title: Iswaran to co-chair Committee on Future Economy as Heng remains hospitalised
summary: Singapore's Committee on the Future Economy (CFE) has appointed Minister for Industry S Iswaran as co-chair, replacing Heng Swee Keat, who remains hospitalized due to a stroke. Iswaran's appointment takes effect immediately. Chan Chun Sing has been appointed as the committee's deputy chairman. The CFE, tasked with charting Singapore's next economic phase, will continue its work with Iswaran's co-chairship, despite Heng's prolonged recovery.

images.alt_text: Mr Iswaran, previously deputy chairman of the 30-member Committee, will now be its co-chair.

site_title: Mapletree Logistics Trust to issue S$250m of perpetual securities
summary: Mapletree Logistics Trust (MLT) plans to issue S$250 million of fixed-rate perpetual securities, with DBS Bank and OCBC appointed as joint lead managers. The net proceeds will be used for general corporate funding purposes, including potential acquisitions and asset enhancement initiatives.

site_title: US: Oil, Apple push Wall St higher
summary: US stocks rose on Monday, driven by a surge in oil prices and gains from tech giant Apple, which rose 1.6% after Warren Buffett's Berkshire Hathaway reported a stake worth about $1 billion. The Dow Jones industrial average was up 58.07 points, or 0.33%, at 17,593.39, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite also gained. Oil prices jumped 3% to their highest since November 2015, driven by growing Nigerian output disruptions and a shift to a deficit in the market.

site_title: Eldorado to exit China with US$600m sale; shares gain
summary: Eldorado Gold Corp, the largest foreign gold producer in China, agreed to sell its remaining Chinese assets to Yintai Resources Co for US$600 million. The sale will focus Eldorado's efforts on developing mines in Europe. The deal is expected to close in the second half, and Eldorado will use the proceeds to grow its business. The company's shares rose 3.6% following the announcement. This sale marks the latest effort by Eldorado to exit China, following the sale of its Jinfeng mine stake for US$300 million last month.

site_title: Acer enters VR realm where PC makers fear to tread
summary: Acer partners with Swedish games maker Starbreeze to produce a virtual-reality headset, dubbed StarVR, through a joint venture. The companies aim to design, manufacture, and sell the headset, which could be a significant move for Acer, a struggling PC maker. The joint venture's success or failure remains uncertain, but the partnership could be a game-changer for Acer's business.

site_title: Trump's Beijing bashing misses China's own rust belt upheaval
summary: US presidential candidate Donald Trump's criticism of China's economic policies may be misplaced, as the country's own industrial Northeast is facing job losses and economic decline. China's steel industry is struggling with overcapacity, with 500,000 jobs at risk, and the nation's air quality is among the worst in the world. Trump's rhetoric ignores this reality, which is affecting cities like Xingtai, where steel factory wages have dropped 15% and workers are delaying life plans due to lack of employment opportunities. China's financial system and industrial policy are seen as the root cause of the problem.

images.alt_text: The pain inflicted on steelmakers across the globe by the double whammy of overcapacity and slowing demand in the world's No 2 economy is also inflicting pain at home. Steel mills are being shuttered in places from Xingtai to Tonghua (above) in China's Jilin province.
In the early post-war era, Johnstown was an industrial powerhouse, churning out the steel that helped build railroads, bridges and skyscrapers across a rapidly growing America. No more.

site_title: HSBC axes 850 IT jobs in Britain in first big wave of planned cuts
summary: HSBC is cutting 850 IT jobs in Britain, the first wave of 8,000 planned redundancies by the end of next year, as part of a three-year restructuring plan to improve earnings. Most affected employees were informed on Monday, with all jobs expected to be eliminated by the end of the year. The bank aims to consolidate IT and back office operations, with more cuts expected in the coming months.

site_title: Goldman ups oil price forecast as global supply flips to deficit
summary: Goldman Sachs has raised its US crude oil price forecast to $50 a barrel for the second half of 2016 due to a global supply deficit caused by unexpected production disruptions and sustained demand. This marks a sudden halt to the market surplus, contrary to the bank's previous estimate of $45 a barrel in March. The change in forecast is attributed to the decline in production and sustained demand, indicating a shift in the global oil market.

site_title: Iswaran to co-chair Committee on the Future Economy in view of Heng Swee Keat's illness: PMO
summary: Singapore's Committee on the Future Economy (CFE) has been restructured due to Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat's illness. Minister for Industry S Iswaran will co-chair the committee, while Chan Chun Sing will take over as deputy chairman. The appointments are effective immediately, with the committee's work slated to conclude by the end of the year. Heng Swee Keat, 54, remains in the intensive care unit following a stroke. The changes come as the committee charts Singapore's next phase of economic transition.

site_title: Catalist-listed Ntegrator secures S$11 million of contracts for current fiscal year
summary: Catalist-listed Ntegrator International Ltd secured S$11 million in contracts for the current fiscal year, with five new deals awarded under a frame contract signed in 2015. The contracts include high-performance battery supplies to Viettel, Vietnam's largest mobile network operator, and pipeline installation and maintenance services. All five contracts are expected to contribute positively to the company's performance for the financial year ending Dec 31, 2016, subject to timely completion and effective cost management. This marks the fourth and fifth series of orders awarded to Ntegrator under the frame contract.

site_title: German state refused to clear VW management but relented: source
summary: Lower Saxony, a 20% shareholder in Volkswagen, initially opposed endorsing the company's top management but relented after Chairman Hans Dieter Poetsch's plea, fearing a vote of no-confidence would harm VW's recovery efforts. The decision came as the company faces a $10 billion deal with the US government and civil law suits over emissions scandal. Lower Saxony's backing, along with that of major shareholders, is crucial for VW's management. A vote against the management board would have risked further destabilizing the company, which employs over 120,000 people in the region.

site_title: Chinese executive 'confesses' to 5.2b yuan fraud
summary: A Chinese executive, Xu Qin, has confessed to a 5.2 billion yuan ($1.1 billion) fraud involving Zhongjin Asset Management, which owes over 25,000 investors. Xu, described as the "controller," was among 35 executives arrested last week. The scam, which cost investors hundreds of millions of dollars, was uncovered by state-run Dragon Television. Xu's arrest and confession come after a thorough investigation into the scheme, which has raised concerns about financial stability in China.

site_title: China slowdown shows debt addiction will be tough to shake
summary: China's economy slowed to 6.88% growth in April, down from 7.11% in March, as new credit slowed and industrial production was dragged down by weak steel and coal output. The slowdown highlights the challenges of cutting capacity and curbing credit excesses without stalling the economy. Despite a sharp swing in fortunes, the economy remains reliant on debt, with property and government-backed building programs driving growth. Policymakers are applying the brakes on a key growth driver while vowing to cut capacity from industries mired by deflation and oversupply.

site_title: Traders puzzled by rally in stocks linked to 2013 penny crash
summary: A number of penny stocks linked to the 2013 penny stock crash in Singapore saw their share prices surge, leaving traders puzzled. Attilan Group, formerly Asiasons Capital, tripled in value to 1.5 Singapore cents after 193.4 million shares were traded. Other affected stocks include Blumont and LionGold, drawing trading queries from the Singapore Exchange. The sudden rally has raised questions about who is behind the buying, with no clear explanation provided.

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint Limited receives eligibility-to-list letter from SGX for new Reit
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Limited (FCL) received an eligibility-to-list letter from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) for the proposed listing of a new real estate investment trust (Reit) named Frasers Logistics & Industrial Trust (FLT). The Reit will hold a portfolio of Australian industrial assets. However, FCL emphasized that no decision has been made on whether the transaction will proceed, and there is currently no certainty that the company will go ahead with the offering.

site_title: ICBC's president Yi Huiman poised to replace Jiang as chairman
summary: ICBC's president Yi Huiman is set to replace Chairman Jiang Jianqing, who is retiring after 16 years, according to the bank's internal announcement. Yi, 51, will become chairman and Communist Party secretary, taking over at a time of slowing economic growth and rising bad loans. ICBC's net income may drop 2.7% this year, the first decline since its IPO in 2006. Yi, the son of a Shanghai doctor, has held various positions at ICBC, including president since 2013.

site_title: Lum Chang Holdings unit in JV with Malaysian company for mixed-use project
summary: Lum Chang Holdings has formed a joint venture with Malaysian company Tien Wah Press Holdings Berhad to develop a mixed-use project in Petaling Jaya, Malaysia. The JV company, Sterling Model Sdn Bhd, will acquire a 13,040 sq m leasehold industrial land for RM63.75 million. The project will have an issued and paid-up share capital of RM10 million. This acquisition is seen as a prime investment opportunity to consolidate Lum Chang's property and development portfolio in Malaysia.

site_title: Cosco unit delays delivery of another jack-up rig
summary: Cosco Corporation (Singapore) has delayed the delivery of a jack-up drilling rig by its Nantong unit to December 31, 2017, citing unfavorable market conditions. The delivery was initially set for April 30, 2016. The company has agreed to further extend the delivery date with KS Drilling Pte Ltd. The delay affects one of two rigs to be delivered under a building contract. Cosco Corp has not disclosed the financial impact of the delay and has left the door open for the parties to negotiate a compromise solution.

site_title: Qatari wealth fund said to create US$100b unit in overhaul
summary: Qatar's sovereign wealth fund is undergoing its largest overhaul since 2014, grouping $100 billion of investments into a new unit called Qatar Investments. The Qatar Holding name, synonymous with high-profile deals, will be replaced by the QIA name on international investments. Ahmed Al-Rumaihi, a former Qatari diplomat, will head the new unit, which will have a single person in charge for greater oversight. The fund will rely on asset sales or dividend income for new investments, and no new money will be allocated this year.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 7.05 points to close at 1,621.21 on Monday, with 1.70 billion lots valued at RM1.69 billion traded. The market saw 250 gainers and 539 losers. This news is unrelated to the provided articles.

site_title: Hanjin, Hyundai Merchant post losses amid efforts to revamp debt
summary: South Korea's two largest container carriers, Hanjin Shipping Co and Hyundai Merchant Marine Co, reported significant losses for the first quarter due to excess capacity and slowing economic growth. Hanjin posted a net loss of 261.4 billion won, while Hyundai Merchant Marine reported a net loss of 276.3 billion won. The companies are revamping their debt as part of an industry overhaul and are in negotiations to cut charter rates and get bondholders to participate in a debt restructuring plan. South Korea is taking active steps to help the shipping and shipbuilding industries reduce debt and weather a global slump.

site_title: Singapore shares close mixed as pennies take over led by ISR, Liongold, Blumont
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index rose 1.15 points to 2,736.06, despite a dip in interest in blue chips. Speculative small caps, including penny stocks, led the market's attention. ISR Capital's shares surged 1,850% to S$0.117, while LionGold and Blumont also saw significant gains. The penny surge is attributed to traders seeking opportunities in low-priced counters amid weakness in blue chips.

site_title: Pan Ocean Q1 net profit falls 40%; expects tonnage over-supply, slow demand to continue
summary: Pan Ocean Co Ltd reported a 39.6% decline in Q1 net profit to US$61.4 million, down from US$101.6 million a year ago. The company attributed the drop to a "waiver from debt" due to a debt-equity swap. Despite a 3.6% increase in sales to US$376.6 million, costs of sales rose 11.5% and operating profit fell 42% to US$32.3 million. Pan Ocean expects the market to remain oversupplied and slow, with tonnage scrapping potentially alleviating supply-demand imbalance.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: A consortium led by Tower Capital and Temasek Holdings launched a bid to take Eu Yan Sang International private, while developers in Singapore sold 745 private homes in April, down 11.6% from March. Budget airlines formed the Asia Pacific's first alliance, and Bank of Singapore expects the region's private-banking industry to shift to a fee-based model. Cosco Corporation delayed the delivery of a jack-up rig, and CWT confirmed exclusive talks for a potential sale to HNA Group.

site_title: No let up in demand for SGD bonds; 2 deals on Monday draw S$4.3 billion orders
summary: Demand for Singapore dollar bonds remains strong, with two new deals drawing orders of S$4.3 billion on Monday, a decrease in pricing due to investor fears of lower interest rates. Canadian insurer Manulife's 10-year deal priced at 3.85% attracted S$3.5 billion in orders, while Mapletree Logistics Trust's perpetual bond priced at 4.18% drew US$800 million in orders. The strong demand has led to a year-to-date return of 3.96% for the Singapore Fixed Income index, outperforming the Straits Times Index by 9.09%.

site_title: British business sees Brexit effect as growth forecasts cut
summary: Britain's largest business lobby, the Confederation of British Industry (CBI), cut its UK economy growth forecasts to 2% this year and next, citing a "dark cloud of uncertainty" from the Brexit referendum. The IMF warned that the world economy is at risk of stagnation, and Bank of England Governor Mark Carney said leaving the EU could trigger a recession. The CBI's revised forecast is in line with the BOE's projections, but slower than initially thought.

site_title: Europe: Shares open lower, H&M drops as sales disappoint
summary: European shares fell 0.7% in early trading on Monday, with H&M and Prudential Plc among the top losers after disappointing sales growth figures. H&M dropped 1.5% despite reporting a 5% sales increase in April, below analyst expectations. Telecom Italia rose 2.8% after nearly tripling its cost-cutting target. The FTSEurofirst 300 index is down 0.7% as thin volumes are expected due to the German market closure.

site_title: Oil advances as Goldman forecasts deficit amid increasing demand
summary: Oil prices surged as Goldman Sachs forecasted a deficit in the market earlier than expected, citing strong demand and falling production. The market shifted into deficit in May, with Chinese refineries processing record crude rates. Oil prices rose 1.7% in New York and London, with West Texas Intermediate increasing to $47 a barrel. Goldman raised its price estimates and projected a return to surplus early next year, citing a gradual decline in inventories and growing low-cost production.

site_title: China internet titans look to hip-hop, wingsuits in VR spending
summary: China's internet titans Alibaba, Tencent, and Baidu are investing heavily in virtual reality (VR) spending, with a focus on employing startups and opening platforms to developers. Unlike overseas competitors, they are not building headsets, instead positioning themselves as middlemen. This approach has led to a US$1.1 billion global VR spending spree, with hip-hop dancers, military marchers, and winged suit performers becoming central players in the industry. The Chinese companies' strategy is expected to fuel the growth of VR content and hardware, with a dominant headset yet to emerge.

site_title: Japan vows to cooperate in French Olympic probe
summary: Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe vowed to cooperate with a French probe into $2 million allegedly paid to help Tokyo secure the 2020 Olympics. The payment was linked to Papa Massata Diack, son of ex-world athletics chief Lamine Diack, who denies receiving the money. Japan's Olympic chief insisted the payment was a "legitimate consultant's fee," while the top government spokesman described the bid as "clean." The investigation follows allegations of corruption and money laundering in the bid process.

site_title: China's economy to help stabilise cross-border capital flows: regulator
summary: China's foreign exchange regulator stated that the country's economy will stabilize cross-border capital flows in the near term. Capital outflow pressure eased in April, with commercial banks selling US$23.7 billion of foreign exchange, down from US$36.4 billion in March. This decrease indicates that domestic companies are paying foreign debts at a slower pace, with companies less willing to hold foreign exchange. The easing of capital outflow pressure is seen as a positive sign for China's economy.

site_title: Japan's MUFG forecasts profit to fall 10.7% this year, missing analyst estimates
summary: Japan's Mitsubishi UFJ Financial Group (MUFG) forecasts a 10.7% profit decline this year, missing analyst estimates. The bank attributed the decline to weak domestic lending and bad loan costs. Despite this, MUFG is expected to be less affected by domestic factors due to its significant overseas interests. The bank forecast a profit of 850 billion yen for the year through March 2017, down from the 1.037 trillion yen average of analyst estimates.

site_title: Goldman surprised by sudden oil-market turn as glut vanishes
summary: Goldman Sachs has revised its US crude price forecast to $50 a barrel for the second half of 2016, citing a sudden shift to a deficit in the global oil market. Supply disruptions and sustained demand have led to a halt in the market surplus, prompting the bank to raise its forecast. The market is expected to remain in deficit through the second half of 2016, with a return to surplus in early 2017. Goldman also predicts oil prices will rise to $60 by the end of 2017.

site_title: Cheap and available: Asian low-cost carriers head for the altar
summary: Asia's low-cost carriers form the world's largest airline alliance, the Value Alliance, with eight airlines, including Scoot and Nok Airlines, to sell tickets and services across their routes. The alliance aims to increase revenue but faces challenges in coordinating schedules and generating extra revenue. Industry experts say the move may signal a step towards mergers in Asia's saturated low-cost carrier market, where hundreds of aircraft have flooded the region in the past decade.

site_title: Oracle's Catz becomes top-paid female executive with US$57m
summary: Oracle's CEO Safra Catz became the highest-paid female US executive in 2015 with a $56.9 million pay package, surpassing Alphabet's CFO Ruth Porat ($41.1 million) and General Motors' Mary Barra ($36.3 million). The top 17 women executives in the Bloomberg Pay Index, 15 of whom are executive officers, tend to have higher compensation due to their companies' revenue. The challenge lies in increasing the number of women in top executive positions.

images.alt_text: Safra Catz emerged as the highest-paid US female executive in fiscal 2015 when she became co-chief executive officer of Oracle Corp.

site_title: Islamic finance preps rules for charitable funds
summary: Islamic finance institutions are set to unveil guidelines for Muslim charitable institutions, aiming to improve asset management and efficiency. The guidelines, which include core principles for zakat, are expected to be released at a United Nations summit in Istanbul. This move follows criticism of poorly managed Islamic endowments and alms-giving, which hold billions of dollars in assets globally. The guidelines are seen as a step towards promoting better governance and transparency in the industry.

site_title: Chevron Thailand says to cut 800 staff, cut costs by US$500m
summary: Chevron Thailand plans to cut 800 staff and reduce costs by US$500 million in 2016 due to lower global energy prices and weaker demand. The cuts, effective August 1, aim to help the company continue operations in Thailand and achieve the cost savings goal. Chevron's president, Pairoj Kaweeyanun, stated that the staff reductions will help the company weather the current economic challenges.

site_title: Australia: Shares gain, healthcare shines; NZ pauses near record high
summary: Australian shares rose 0.6% on Monday, driven by gains in healthcare stocks. The S&P/ASX 200 index ended at 5,358.90, while New Zealand's benchmark S&P/NZX 50 index held near a recent record high, finishing at 6,914.13.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks end up, shrug off disappointing China data
summary: Hong Kong shares rose 0.8% on Monday, driven by gains in most Asian markets, despite disappointing Chinese data that raised concerns over the country's economic recovery. The Hang Seng index ended at 19,883.95 points. The market has dropped for three weeks on fears that China's economic activity may be fizzling out.

site_title: Crystal Jade to open outlet at Yangon International Airport
summary: Crystal Jade to open its first outlet at Yangon International Airport's Terminal 2 in the third quarter of 2016, following a franchise agreement with Crystal Jade Management (Vietnam) Pte Ltd. The move aims to tap into Myanmar's growing demand for Chinese cuisine, with plans to also open a Crystal Jade Palace restaurant at the Sedona Hotel Yangon later in the year. This expansion is part of Singapore Myanmar Investco Limited's strategy to capitalize on the country's food and beverage market, which has seen significant growth following recent reforms.

site_title: Singapore Airlines' low-cost carriers, others start alliance
summary: Singapore Airlines' low-cost carriers, including Scoot and Tiger Airways, have formed the Asia Pacific region's first alliance with other budget airlines. The Value Alliance, comprising eight carriers, aims to boost network usage and offer passengers a single booking platform. The alliance, launched in May 2016, is the world's largest of budget carriers, covering over 160 destinations with 174 aircraft. Analysts see the move as a positive step for low-cost carriers, allowing them to expand their networks despite the challenge of joining traditional alliances.

site_title: US, South Korea, Japan to hold drills on North Korean missiles
summary: The US, Japan, and South Korea will hold joint military exercises in late June to track North Korean missiles. The drills will involve Aegis destroyers near Hawaii and come as the US encourages its allies to increase cooperation. This follows the signing of an intelligence-sharing pact in 2014 and comes amid North Korea's continued ballistic missile tests. The US is also in talks with South Korea on deploying its Thaad missile defense system, which has raised concerns in China. The exercises show progress in defense cooperation among the nations.
