site_title: Police commissioner demands inquiry into Man United fake bomb 'fiasco'
summary: Police Commissioner Tony Lloyd demanded an inquiry into a fake bomb left behind during a training exercise at Manchester United's Old Trafford stadium, forcing the abandonment of a Premier League match against Bournemouth. The realistic-looking device was accidentally left in a toilet, causing the evacuation of 75,000 fans and a 24-year-old Premier League match abandonment record. Lloyd criticized the incident, stating it was "unacceptable" and wasted police and army resources, while Manchester United executive vice chairman Ed Woodward vowed to investigate the incident fully.

site_title: China: Stocks post modest gains despite disappointing economic data
summary: China's stocks rose 0.7-0.8% on Monday, rebounding from four-week lows amid reports of a potential crackdown on fundraising and mergers and acquisitions. The securities regulator denied these reports, stating it would continue to support M&As by qualified companies. Disappointing April economic data showed slower-than-expected growth in investment, factory output, and retail sales, but traders had already priced in the impact. The CSI300 index rose to 3,095.31 points, and the Shanghai Composite Index gained to 2,850.86 points, with all main sectors showing gains.

site_title: Donald Trump says unlikely to have a good relationship with British PM Cameron
summary: US presidential candidate Donald Trump stated that he is unlikely to have a good relationship with British Prime Minister David Cameron due to Cameron's criticism of Trump's Muslim ban proposal. Trump also expressed skepticism about Britain's EU membership, calling it "bureaucratic" and "difficult." The comments come after Cameron criticized Trump, stating he would unite the UK against him if Trump visited.

site_title: Central bankers' wisdom faulted as gold holdings surge 25%
summary: Central bankers' predictions of interest rate hikes have been called into question as gold holdings surge 25%, reaching a seven-year high. Investors are seeking safe-haven assets amid concerns over negative rates in Europe and Japan, and potential US rate hikes. Gold prices have risen 21% this year, with demand reaching its second-highest level ever in the first quarter. Billionaires such as Paul Singer and Stan Druckenmiller are backing the gold rally, while some bullion bears have had to adjust their forecasts.

images.alt_text: The great gold rush of 2016 is gathering pace. Holdings in exchange-traded funds have now surged by a quarter, with investors taking advantage of lower prices over the past two weeks to enlarge stakes on rising concern about central bank policy making worldwide.

site_title: Opportunities for mid-career PMETs to join wafer fabrication industry
summary: Singapore has launched a professional conversion programme for wafer fabrication, targeting mid-career professionals, managers, executives and technicians (PMETs) looking to switch industries. The programme aims to address the ongoing demand for local PMETs in the wafer fabrication industry. This move is seen as an effort to support the restructuring of the economy and provide opportunities for skilled workers to transition into the industry.

site_title: Philips lighting unit IPO could raise as much as 970m euros
summary: Royal Philips NV plans to raise up to 970 million euros from the initial public offering of its lighting unit, valuing the business at 3.38 billion euros. The company will sell 37.5 million shares at a range of 18.50-22.50 euros per share. Separating the lighting business will allow Philips to focus on its healthcare market. The IPO could come as early as May 27, with the company expecting to raise 844-970 million euros, depending on the exercise of an over allotment option.

site_title: China's record daily steel output bodes ill for world rivals
summary: China's record daily steel output in April, 2.314 million tons, suggests an oversupply of the metal in the global market, threatening world rivals. The country's top steel producer, Hebei Iron & Steel Group Co, plans to cut 5.02 million tons of capacity, but analysts predict exports may continue to rise, adding to supply risks. China's overseas sales have already increased 7.6% year-over-year, and the nation is exporting its steel surplus as domestic growth slows, sparking trade tensions and affecting global steel prices.

site_title: Apple's Cook visits Beijing after China woes, Didi deal
summary: Apple CEO Tim Cook visited Beijing on May 16, 2016, following a $1 billion deal with ride-hailing app Didi Chuxing. The visit aimed to reinvigorate Apple's sales in China, where the company has faced recent problems, including weakening smartphone sales and a trademark dispute. Cook met with Didi's president Jean Liu and executives from other app companies, including Meituan-Dianping. The meeting was seen as an effort to better understand the Chinese market and prepare for Didi's planned US IPO in 2018.

images.alt_text: Apple Inc Chief Executive Tim Cook visited Beijing on Monday, days after announcing a US$1 billion deal with ride-hailing app Didi Chuxing, and as the US firm tries to reinvigorate sales in China, its second-largest market after the United States.

site_title: Seoul: Won finishes at 1-month low, stocks wobble
summary: South Korea's won fell to a one-month low of 1,179.7 to the US dollar, down 0.7% from Friday's close. Weak Chinese economic data boosted global risk aversion, affecting the won. South Korean shares remained nearly unchanged, closing at 1,967.91 points.

site_title: Vietnam's central bank probes hacking attempt on Tien Phong
summary: The State Bank of Vietnam is investigating a hacking attempt on Tien Phong Commercial Joint Stock Bank, where a fraudulent transfer request was made for over 1 million euros. The attack allegedly used malware installed in a third-party software used to connect to the Swift interbank messaging system. The bank has stopped using the service and now uses its own technology with stronger security. The incident occurred in the fourth quarter of last year and did not result in any losses for Tien Phong. The central bank will provide more information on the incident later.

site_title: China to let more cities build metro systems: Economic Information Daily
summary: China plans to relax minimum population requirements for cities to build metro systems, allowing cities with a population of over 1.5 million to build subway projects. This move aims to support the slowing economy by encouraging investment-led growth. The previous requirement of 3 million population and 10 billion yuan annual revenue will be dropped. China's transport ministry plans to invest 4.7 trillion yuan in transport infrastructure projects over the next three years, with 26 cities already having built metro systems and 39 having projects approved.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close higher after sales tax delay report
summary: Tokyo stocks closed higher on Monday following a report that Japan's government may delay a planned sales tax rise to avoid damaging the country's fragile economy. The Nikkei 225 index gained 0.33% and the Topix index ticked up 0.11%. The delay is seen as a positive move for the market, which has been cautious due to economic uncertainty. The news has boosted investor confidence, leading to a higher closing price.

site_title: Konecranes buys Terex unit for US$1.3b after merger dropped
summary: Konecranes Oyj has agreed to acquire Terex Corp's lifting-gear business for approximately US$1.3 billion. The deal marks the end of a full merger between the two companies after China's Zoomlion Heavy Industry Science & Technology Co emerged as a rival suitor. Konecranes will pay US$820 million in cash and 19.6 million shares, with Terex retaining a 25% stake in the Finnish firm. The transaction replaces a US$4.2 billion merger deal that was abandoned due to the bidding war with Zoomlion.

site_title: Pavement glued down in Hong Kong for China official visit
summary: Hong Kong authorities have glued down paving stones in central Hong Kong to prevent protesters from using them as missiles ahead of a high-level Chinese visit. The measures include barricades and a no-protest security zone, sparking fury among activists who feel their rights are being restricted. Beijing's tightening grip on the semi-autonomous city has fueled concerns over eroding freedoms, following the disappearance of five Hong Kong booksellers and the arrest of a pro-democracy activist linked to a plot to disrupt a Chinese official's visit.

site_title: Five urban sustainability research projects get S$14m in funding
summary: The Ministry of National Development (MND) and National Research Foundation (NRF) Singapore awarded S$14 million in funding to five urban sustainability research projects under the Land and Liveability National Innovation Challenge (L2 NIC). The projects, which received 26 submissions, aimed to improve living environments and push the frontier of living space development. The funded projects underwent a rigorous evaluation process and were selected for their potential to use technology to enhance urban sustainability.

site_title: Developer sales of private homes slip to 745 units in April
summary: Singapore developers sold 745 private homes in April 2016, down 11.6% from March and 36.2% from April 2015. This includes 1,291 homes when including executive condominiums, down from March's 1,328. The figures are based on data submissions by developers and were released by the Urban Redevelopment Authority.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Philippine central bank to move to interest rate corridor system starting June 3
summary: The Philippine central bank will transition to an interest rate corridor (IRC) system starting June 3, aiming to improve monetary policy transmission. The IRC framework sets the overnight lending rate as the ceiling and the special deposit account rate as the floor, with the key overnight borrowing rate in the middle. The BSP is expected to cut the overnight borrowing rate to 3.5% and the lending rate to 4.5%, while keeping the special deposit account rate at 2.5%. This move is part of a broader effort to guide market rates and stimulate economic growth.

site_title: Malaysia's Felda says 2016 palm output to drop 17% as El Nino bites
summary: Malaysia's Felda Global Ventures Berhad, the world's third-largest palm plantations operator, expects a 17% drop in palm oil output in 2016 due to dry conditions from the El Nino weather pattern. This decline is expected to boost crude palm oil prices by up to 20% by August, reaching between 2,600 and 2,800 ringgit per tonne. The El Nino effect is also expected to impact Southeast Asia's harvests, leading to a broader decline in global palm oil supplies.

site_title: About US$36b of planned India coal plants could be scrapped
summary: India's plan to build 80 gigawatts of coal-fired power plants worth $72 billion may be scrapped due to insufficient electricity demand. The country's coal output has been declining, and idle capacity accounts for about a fifth of its total power generation. Officials are rethinking the goal of doubling annual coal production to 1 billion tons by 2020, citing concerns that the economy remains below its potential. The Coal Ministry is reassessing the demand and exploring alternative solutions to address the issue.

site_title: China says Taiwan fraud suspects deported from Malaysia 'confess'
summary: China says 32 Taiwanese fraud suspects deported from Malaysia have confessed and will be tried on the mainland. The suspects, part of a telecom fraud ring targeting Chinese victims, will undergo proceedings under the mainland judiciary. Taiwan has lodged formal complaints, insisting its nationals face investigation and trial on the island. The deportations are seen as a means of exerting pressure on Taiwan's new president, Tsai Ing Wen, who has a more sceptical approach to relations with Beijing.

site_title: Deutsche sees Rousseff ouster boosting Petrobras, Brazil bank debt
summary: Brazil's Senate voted to impeach President Dilma Rousseff, who faces trial on budgetary rule-breaking charges. Vice President Michel Temer is expected to implement business-friendly policies, potentially boosting bonds in state-controlled oil producer Petrobras and Brazilian banks. Analysts at Deutsche Bank believe Temer's administration could lead to a more market-friendly framework, stabilizing the currency, and stimulating economic growth. However, execution risks remain high, with a lower bar set for the new administration.

site_title: CWT confirms major shareholders in exclusive talks for potential sale to HNA
summary: CWT's controlling shareholders have entered into exclusive negotiations with a unit of HNA Group, a Chinese conglomerate, for a potential sale of their interests. The shareholders, who hold 31.9% of CWT, have been looking to sell since July 2015 and have enlisted Credit Suisse and DBS Bank to advise them. The deal could lead to a general offer for the company under Singapore's takeover rules if a buyer acquires 30% or more of the shares.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open slightly lower on Monday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Monday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 0.630 points to 1628.520. Despite this, volume was high at 35.02 million lots worth RM10.9 million. Gainers outnumbered losers 62-58.

site_title: Yen slips after initial rise on China growth worries
summary: The yen initially rose against the dollar due to disappointing Chinese economic data, but later eased as Tokyo shares strengthened from strong US data. The dollar recovered from its losses and stood at 108.90 yen, up 0.2% on the day. Analysts expect Japan's first-quarter GDP data on May 18 to impact the yen, with a weak result potentially boosting safe-haven demand. The dollar is expected to clear resistance at 109.47 yen, a key level that could signal a bullish dollar set-up.

site_title: US dollar rises after climbing to six-week high on retail spending
summary: The US dollar rose to a six-week high against major currencies, including the yen and euro, after the largest increase in consumer spending in a year. The Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index increased 0.1% as traders speculated about a potential Federal Reserve interest-rate hike this year. Futures traders assign a 4% chance of a rate hike in June and 53% for the year. The US dollar's rise is attributed to the Fed's expected repricing, which should lead to a stronger dollar, albeit with less market enthusiasm compared to previous rate hikes.

site_title: China's tourism investment to hit 2t yuan by 2020
summary: China's tourism investment is expected to reach 2 trillion yuan by 2020, doubling from 1.25 trillion yuan in 2016, according to the China National Tourism Administration. The sector saw a 42% increase in investment to 1 trillion yuan in 2015. Private sector investment accounted for 57% of the total, with areas like online travel services, rural tourism, and sports tourism expected to drive growth. The tourism body sees huge potential for investment in the sector, with hopes that it will propel economic growth amid weaknesses in other areas.

site_title: Oil prices rise on Nigeria, Venezuela disruptions
summary: Oil prices rose due to disruptions in Nigeria and Venezuela, with International Brent crude futures up 28 US cents, or 0.6%, to US$48.11 per barrel. Nigeria's Qua Iboe crude stream was suspended and other producers faced sabotage, cutting output to its lowest in decades. Venezuela's oil production has fallen by at least 188,000 barrels per day, while US crude production has also declined. Rising Opec output and a stronger dollar capped gains, however, as analysts attributed price increases to falling supplies from producers.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars near recent lows on China, iron ore
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars reached recent lows due to soft Chinese economic data and sliding iron ore prices. The Australian dollar dropped to its lowest in two-and-a-half months, while the New Zealand dollar edged down. The losses were attributed to concerns about China's economy stabilizing, with Chinese investment, factory output, and retail sales missing forecasts. The Aussie has tumbled 4% this month, largely after the Reserve Bank of Australia cut rates to a record low.

images.alt_text: The Australian dollar slumped to multi-month lows against major currencies on Monday after soft Chinese economic data and sliding iron ore prices knocked the wind out of commodity currencies.

site_title: Indonesia posts US$670m trade surplus in April
summary: Indonesia posted a trade surplus of $670 million in April, exceeding forecasts, driven by a 14.62% decline in imports to $10.78 billion and a 12.65% decline in exports to $11.45 billion. Low commodity prices have impacted exports, while the decline in imports has improved the trade balance and reduced the current account deficit. This marks the 19th consecutive month of declining exports.

images.alt_text: Indonesia's trade surplus increased in April due to a larger-than-expected drop in imports, the statistics bureau said on Monday.

site_title: Diamond magnate's rare stone goes under the hammer in Geneva
summary: A 14.62-carat blue diamond, "The Oppenheimer Blue," owned by architect Philip Oppenheimer, is set to be auctioned off in Geneva. Christie's has valued the stone at $38-45 million, potentially breaking a record set by Sotheby's last November. The diamond, part of a 280-lot collection, is the largest ever sold in the Fancy Vivid Blue category and is owned by a Hong Kong billionaire who recently purchased a $48.4 million diamond. The auction is part of Geneva's Magnificent Jewels week.

site_title: South Korea says Nissan manipulated emissions, plans fine and recall
summary: South Korea has accused Nissan of manipulating emissions on its Qashqai SUV, citing a "defeat device" that turns off emissions management during regular driving conditions. The government plans to fine Nissan 330 million won (S$385,000) and order a recall of 814 affected vehicles. Nissan denies any wrongdoing, stating it has never manipulated vehicles or used defeat devices. The move follows similar allegations against Volkswagen AG in November.

site_title: Japan's Nikkei leads gains in Asia on tax hopes
summary: Japan's Nikkei stock market led gains in Asia on Monday, following a report that Prime Minister Shinzo Abe plans to delay a planned sales tax hike. The news boosted investor confidence, with Tokyo's Nikkei rising 1% and a weaker yen providing additional support. The delay is seen as crucial to support economic growth, which is still recovering from a recession. Other Asian markets, such as Hong Kong and Sydney, also rose, while Shanghai retreated due to weak Chinese economic data.

site_title: China slowdown shows debt addiction will be tough to shake
summary: China's economy slowed to 6.88% growth in April, down from 7.11% in March, as weak steel and coal output dragged on industrial production. Retail and investment readings also disappointed, with new credit moderating in April after a surge in March. China's central bank reassured that monetary policy will continue to support the economy, but economists warn that the economy remains overly reliant on debt, and when credit moderates, so too does the economy. Policy makers are applying the brakes on a key growth driver, while vowing to cut capacity from industries mired by deflation and oversupply.

site_title: Yen slips on sales tax delay report
summary: The yen slipped on Monday amid speculation that Japan will delay raising its sales tax to 10% in 2017, potentially boosting the economy. The planned tax rise, which was first introduced in 2014, was blamed for stalling a recovery and pushing Japan into recession. A lacklustre string of Chinese data also weighed on emerging currencies. The news came after Nikkei business daily reported that Prime Minister Shinzo Abe wanted to delay the tax rise.

site_title: Singapore shares open 0.3% lower on Monday
summary: Singapore stocks opened 0.3% lower on Monday, with the Straits Times Index at 2,727.67, following weak economic data from China. About 56.3 million shares changed hands, with Attilan rising S$0.002 to S$0.007. Losers outnumbered gainers 72 to 51, marking a weak start to the week.

site_title: Fonterra promises early dividend to struggling dairy farmers
summary: Fonterra, the world's largest dairy exporter, announced an early dividend payment to its 10,500 New Zealand farmer-shareholders, aiming to support struggling dairy farmers. The NZ$0.10 per share dividend will be paid in June, following a two-year revenue drop of NZ$7 billion. Fonterra reported a 3% drop in milk collection due to low global prices, and its Australian suppliers will receive financial support measures. The company's total forecast annual dividend remains NZ$0.40 cents per share.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks rise at start despite Wall Street drop
summary: Tokyo stocks rose modestly at the start of the day, with the Nikkei 225 index increasing 0.30% to 16,461.59, despite a negative lead from Wall Street. The broader Topix index also rose 0.09%. The market's gains were attributed to bargain-hunting.

site_title: Philippine central bank to move to interest rate corridor system on June 3
summary: The Philippine central bank will transition to an interest rate corridor (IRC) system on June 3, aiming to steer market rates close to the policy rate of 4.0% and make monetary policy transmission more effective. The decision comes as the country expects strong economic growth despite a leadership change. The benchmark interest rate has remained steady since September 2014.

site_title: Gold advances as investors extend fund-buying spree to 14 days
summary: Gold prices rose 0.4% to $1,278.06 per ounce, marking a 14th consecutive day of buying, the longest streak since March 7. The metal has rallied 20% in 2016 as investors sought a safe haven from equity turmoil and uncertainty over global growth. Holdings in exchange-traded funds (ETFs) increased 7.6 metric tons to 1,822.35 tons, the highest since December 2013. Analysts attribute the surge to speculation about a potential move in the gold price to the upside.

site_title: Seoul: Won down on weak China data, stocks shrug off early dip
summary: The South Korean won declined 0.6% to 1,178.6 against the US dollar, driven by weaker-than-expected Chinese economic indicators and positive US data. Despite this, South Korean shares rose nearly steady at 1,967.94 points, thanks to foreign buying. The construction industry sub-index underperformed, while market heavyweight Naver Corp rose 2.4%. The won's decline is attributed to the possibility of a US Federal Reserve June rate hike and concerns over a slowdown in global economic growth and a stable Chinese yuan.

site_title: Striking Singapore death penalty film stirs emotions at Cannes
summary: Singaporean filmmaker Boo Junfeng's film "Apprentice" premieres at Cannes, shedding light on the country's death penalty through the perspective of an executioner. The film tells the story of a young man who learns the executioner's trade from his own father, exploring the complex relationship between the two. After meeting a "humane" executioner, Boo rethought his approach, aiming for human truth rather than activism. The film highlights the humanity behind the death penalty issue, sparking a nuanced discussion in a country where 95% of the population supports the practice.

site_title: Brazil's biggest economic problem is confidence: finance minister
summary: Brazil's finance minister, Henrique Meirelles, stated that the country's biggest economic problem is "confidence." The interim government needs to reorder government finances to reverse Brazil's worst economic downturn in decades. However, spending on social programs will not be cut. Interim President Michel Temer took office after Dilma Rousseff was suspended for irregularities in the government budget.

site_title: Darco Water Technologies wins S$11.5m contracts
summary: Darco Water Technologies secured S$11.5 million contracts in China and Malaysia. One contract was for the expansion of a wastewater treatment project in Zhejiang province, China, while others were for wastewater treatment projects in Malaysia involving the construction of an ammoniacal nitrogen wastewater treatment system.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks rebound, HTC soars on share buyback plan
summary: Taiwan's stocks rebounded 0.1% on Monday, with HTC's 5% surge on a share buyback plan. The electronics subindex rose 0.2%, while the financials subindex fell 0.1%. Foreign investors sold a net T$14 billion in Taiwan shares on Friday, taking their net selling to T$89 billion for the month. The Taiwan dollar softened to T$32.654 per U.S. dollar. The TAIEX index closed at 8,059.58, a level not seen since late January.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares rise at open
summary: Hong Kong's Hang Seng Index rose 0.59% to 19,836.36, following a broad regional advance. This comes after sharp losses last week. In contrast, the Shanghai Composite Index dropped 0.37% and the Shenzhen Composite Index fell 0.30%.

site_title: BOC Aviation draws Boeing, sovereign funds to US$1.1 billion IPO
summary: BOC Aviation, Asia's largest aircraft lessor, raised $1.1 billion in its initial public offering in Hong Kong, attracting investors including Boeing, China Investment Corp, and Silk Road Fund. The company's shares were priced at HK$42 apiece, with cornerstone investors taking up 52% of the base offering. The IPO aims to tap into the growing demand for aircraft leasing in Asia, driven by strong economic growth in China and India, and is expected to begin trading on June 1.

site_title: Asia: Stocks rise from one-month low as Japanese equities rally
summary: Asian stocks rose, rebounding from a one-month low, after Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe announced he would delay a planned sales tax increase. The MSCI Asia Pacific Index climbed 0.4% and Japan's Topix index jumped 0.7%. The news boosted equities, with economists predicting the delay would be bullish for stocks. However, China's retail sales, industrial production, and fixed-asset investment data missed estimates, highlighting policy makers' challenges. Japan is set to report GDP data on Wednesday, with economists predicting the country narrowly avoided a recession in the first quarter.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Eu Yan Sang, CWT, Oxley
summary: A consortium led by a private equity fund, Temasek Holdings, and Eu Yan Sang's CEO Richard Eu has launched a S$0.60 per share takeover bid for Eu Yan Sang International. CWT's controlling shareholders have signed an exclusivity agreement to negotiate a sale to China conglomerate HNA Group, which could trigger a general offer. Oxley Holdings plans to enter the Australian market and is considering Sydney's Bays Precinct for a flagship project.

site_title: Watch out Nike, China's sports brands are coming back: Gadfly editorial
summary: China's sports brands are experiencing a resurgence, thanks to efforts to shift to a consumption-oriented economy. After a tough three years, domestic brands are now leaner and ready to compete, driven by store cutbacks, online sales growth, and a government-backed campaign to encourage healthy living. This comes as Nike and Adidas face challenges from the ongoing US-China trade tensions and tariffs, with many companies adapting to the changing landscape by reviving their running shoe lines. China's sports brands are poised to challenge global giants like Nike and Adidas.

site_title: Vallianz bags up to US$210m in new charter contracts
summary: Vallianz Holdings, an offshore services provider, has secured new charter contracts worth up to US$210 million, taking its order book to a record US$1.2 billion. The contracts are for 13 offshore support vessels to be chartered by a national oil company in the Middle East for up to seven years. CEO Ling Yong Wah stated that Vallianz is bidding for contracts worth US$1.5 billion in the Middle East region.

site_title: Why China's private sector needs a "high degree of attention"
summary: China's private sector is facing a slowdown, with private-sector fixed-asset investment growing just 5.2% in January to April, its weakest pace since 2012. This decline is concerning policymakers, who rely on the private sector for investment, innovation, and productivity growth. The sector's slowdown could restrain stable growth and requires a high degree of attention. Private surveys show downward pressure on wages as factories shed workers, and companies are struggling to find profitable projects. The government has promised "strong measures" to halt the slowdown, but critics argue that private firms are being foisted with weak assets and poor returns.

site_title: Eu Yan Sang's Q3 profit hit by weaker revenue, higher expenses
summary: Eu Yan Sang International reported a 94% decline in Q3 net profit to S$286,000 due to weaker revenue and higher expenses. Revenue slipped 6% to S$103.87 million, mainly due to a decline in Malaysian market revenue and foreign exchange losses. The company attributed positive growth in Singapore and Australia, but warned of a continued slowdown in private consumption in Malaysia and Hong Kong. Eu Yan Sang proposed an interim dividend of 2.5 cents per share.

site_title: More take up HDB's Lease Buyback Scheme after enhancements
summary: The Housing and Development Board (HDB) in Singapore has seen an increase in households participating in its Lease Buyback Scheme, with 541 households taking it up in the past year. The scheme, introduced in 2009, allows elderly flat owners to sell part of their lease back to the HDB for retirement income. The household income ceiling has been raised from S$3,000 to S$12,000, and flat owners can now choose the length of lease to be retained. The scheme has been updated to cover more households, including four-room flat owners.

site_title: Chinese pouring billions into US real estate: study
summary: Chinese nationals became the largest foreign buyers of US homes last year, investing over $110 billion in real estate, with their five-year total reaching $110 billion. This surge has helped the US real estate market recover from the 2006 crash. Chinese buyers are concentrated in expensive markets like New York, Los Angeles, and San Francisco, paying an average of $832,000 per home. The majority of their investments are private wealth, not corporate, and are driven by a desire to diversify assets and preserve wealth amidst China's economic concerns.

site_title: New Zealand's service sector expansion speeds up in April
summary: New Zealand's services sector experienced its strongest monthly expansion in 2016, with the Bank of New Zealand-Business NZ's seasonally adjusted performance of services index rising 2.6 points to 57.7 in April. This growth, combined with a rise in manufacturing activity, suggests the economy is growing at a better-than-average pace as it enters the June quarter, according to senior economist Craig Ebert.

site_title: Consortium launches privatisation bid for Eu Yan Sang
summary: A consortium led by Tower Capital, Temasek Holdings unit Blanca Investments, and Eu Yan Sang's CEO Richard Eu has launched a bid to take the traditional Chinese medicine firm private. The offer price is S$0.60 per share, valuing the company at S$269 million. The consortium needs to control more than 50% of the company to complete the deal, currently holding around 30.656%. The offer is final and excludes an interim dividend, with irrevocable undertakings from major shareholders to accept the offer.

site_title: Bangladeshi probe panel's chief says Swift responsible for cyber theft
summary: A Bangladesh government-appointed panel has found Swift, the international banking payments network, responsible for a number of mistakes that made it easy for hackers to steal US$81 million from the country's central bank. The panel's head, Mohammed Farashuddin, stated that Swift connected its network to the central bank's new real-time gross settlement system, which made it vulnerable to the hackers. Swift had previously denied allegations of fault, but the panel's findings suggest the network's security measures were inadequate.

site_title: Bank of Singapore sees Asia rich shift to paying fees for advice
summary: Bank of Singapore, a private banking unit of Oversea-Chinese Banking Corp, expects Asia's wealthy clients to shift towards paying fees for advice instead of traditional commission-based models. CEO Bahren Shaari notes that clients prefer consistent returns from fee-based managed portfolios, particularly in volatile markets. The bank's client assets under management are expected to grow to US$73 billion, with 17% of assets now in discretionary portfolios charged a fixed fee. Shaari predicts a continued trend towards fee-based advice, potentially increasing to 40% in the future, with a focus on the quality of advice provided.

images.alt_text: "The whole industry is moving into advisory," said Bank of Singapore chief executive officer Bahren Shaari, speaking about private banking in Asia.

site_title: 17 French ex-ministers vow to end silence over sex harassment
summary: Seventeen French former ministers, including Christine Lagarde, have vowed to end the silence surrounding sex harassment in politics, following an investigation into multiple claims against a former deputy parliamentary speaker. The women, from across the political spectrum, promised to systematically denounce sexist remarks and behavior, urging parties to support victims and help them gain justice. The move comes after finance minister Michel Sapin admitted to inappropriately touching a female journalist, and as the judicial arsenal exists but laws are not sufficiently applied.

site_title: Thai Q1 GDP grows 0.9% q-o-q, beats forecast
summary: Thailand's economy expanded 0.9% in the first quarter from the previous three months, beating forecasts. This growth was driven by higher government spending and tourism, with annual growth at 3.2%. The national planning agency reported the figures on Monday, exceeding the 2.8% median forecast. This positive economic news contrasts with other regional developments, such as China's slowing GDP growth and the UK's shrinking economy.

site_title: Cheap cash-rich companies on SGX: Opportunity or trap?
summary: A recent article examines the concept of buying stocks that are undervalued by various metrics, such as the price-to-book ratio. However, it warns that this strategy can be "foolhardy" and often leads to investors' downfall. The article highlights the example of Warren Buffett's 1989 shareholder letter, where he described bargain-hunting as a "siren song" that can lure investors to their doom. The article suggests that investors should be cautious when evaluating cheap stocks and consider multiple factors before making a purchase.

site_title: Philippines' Duterte wants friendly ties with China
summary: Philippines' newly elected President Rodrigo Duterte announced plans to establish friendly relations with China, despite a long-standing territorial dispute in the South China Sea. Duterte confirmed he would meet with China's ambassador and expressed openness to direct talks. He also signaled a shift from the previous administration's approach, which relied on multilateral forums to raise the issue. Duterte's stance is seen as a departure from the policies of his predecessor, Benigno Aquino, who refused to engage in direct talks with China.

site_title: Fiscal constraints mean BOJ likely to keep helicopter grounded
summary: The Bank of Japan is unlikely to implement "helicopter money" due to fiscal constraints and a law prohibiting the central bank from directly underwriting public debt. Despite Governor Haruhiko Kuroda's dismissal of the idea as "impossible," officials and associates suggest he may be hinting at its possibility. Japan's huge debt pile and concerns over market trust make helicopter money a risky bet, with lawmakers and policymakers hesitant to revise the law and allow the BOJ to explicitly underwrite public debt.

site_title: Norway's wealth fund to sue Volkswagen over emissions scandal
summary: Norway's sovereign wealth fund, the world's largest, plans to join class-action lawsuits against Volkswagen AG over the emissions scandal. The fund aims to safeguard its $850 billion holding in the company, which admitted to using software to cheat exhaust emissions tests. The move comes after Volkswagen reached a $10 billion deal with the US government to buy back or fix diesel cars. The fund previously suffered a 4.9 billion crown loss due to the scandal, and has also turned its attention to US oil companies to report on climate change risks.

site_title: China April slowdown shows debt addiction will be tough to shake
summary: China's April GDP growth slowed to 6.88% from 7.11% in March, driven by weak steel and coal output, disappointing retail and investment readings, and a slump in new credit. The slowdown underscores China's reliance on debt, which remains a challenge for policymakers seeking to curb excesses in recovering sectors. Despite a reassurance from the central bank that monetary policy will continue to support the economy, economists warn that the pass-through to stronger activity remains muted, and the economy remains vulnerable to debt-dependent drivers of property and government-backed programs.

site_title: Corporate earnings surprise in US, Europe isn't what it seems
summary: US and European companies have reported strong earnings, with 75% of S&P 500 companies beating analyst estimates. However, aggregated earnings and sales growth in Europe declined 27% and 9% respectively, while only three industries experienced positive revenue and profit growth. Despite these deteriorating fundamentals, corporate bond spreads remain unchanged, and investors are not reflecting the warning signs of potential defaults among junk-rated US companies. S&P Global Ratings expects a jump in defaults among US junk-rated companies in the coming year.

site_title: Senior IMF official visits Iran
summary: IMF's first deputy managing director David Lipton visited Iran for a two-day discussion on economic developments, following the lifting of sanctions linked to the country's nuclear program. The visit aims to explore Iran's economic growth and policy initiatives. The IMF currently provides statistical and technical assistance to Iran and expects the sanctions lifting to increase oil production and exports, and lower costs for trade and financial transactions, with projected real GDP growth of 4-5.5% in 2016-17.

site_title: Google faces record 3b euro EU antitrust fine: Telegraph
summary: Google is set to face a record 3 billion euro EU antitrust fine for promoting its shopping service in Internet searches at the expense of rival services. The European Commission has accused Google of manipulating search results to favor itself and harm rivals. The fine, which has not yet been finalized, could be a maximum of 6 billion euros, or 10% of Google's annual sales. The company will also be banned from continuing to manipulate search results. The fine is the largest antitrust fine to date, surpassing Intel's 1.1 billion euro fine in 2009.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Oxley Holdings Ltd plans to enter the Australian market with a flagship project in Sydney's Bays Precinct, potentially collaborating with Brookfield Multiplex. The company is considering the Fish Market site at Pyrmont among other redevelopment sites. No further details were provided on the project's timeline or budget.

site_title: UK business lobby cuts growth forecast, wage and retail outlook soft
summary: The UK business lobby, the Confederation of British Industry, cut its economic growth forecasts to 2% for this year and next, citing uncertainty over the EU referendum. This is below the long-run average and lower than previous forecasts. The Bank of England also reduced its growth forecast to 2% for this year, warning of a possible recession if Britain votes to leave the EU. Retailers and pay experts point to a subdued outlook, with retailers seeing a 4.7% decline in shoppers on the high street and average pay rises expected at 1.7% over the next 12 months.

site_title: Real estate crowdfunding sites mushroom on the Internet
summary: Real estate crowdfunding sites have proliferated online, with over 125 platforms in the US, according to Jason Best. Investors poured $484 million into real estate projects last year, more than three times the amount in 2014. However, only one in five platforms has passed scrutiny for transparency and investor protection. New SEC rules, set to take effect on May 16, will allow non-accredited individuals to invest on crowdfunding platforms, potentially fueling growth in the field.

site_title: Retailers to set market mood this week
summary: US retailers, including Target, will report earnings this week, facing concerns about consumer habits amidst the rise of online stores. The retail sector has been a cornerstone of American capitalism since the late 19th century, but the promises of the Internet are now being fulfilled, causing investors to recoil. If retailers cannot assuage these concerns, the dour mood may persist, potentially affecting the market.

site_title: Oil slips on stronger US$ but gains on week
summary: Oil prices slipped on Friday due to a stronger US dollar and investor selling, but still ended the week higher. Nigeria's oil production fell to its lowest in two decades, while Canadian oil sands output was slashed by wildfires. The US dollar reached a two-week high, weighing on greenback-denominated commodities. Despite this, oil prices rose for the week due to production cuts and supply disruptions.

site_title: London's office market resists Brexit flight risk
summary: London's office market remains in high demand despite the uncertainty surrounding Brexit, with first quarter rental data showing little damage to space requirements. London is still Europe's most sought-after office market, and rival cities such as Frankfurt and Paris have not seen a significant increase in demand. The London office market's resilience suggests that the impact of Brexit on the financial sector has been minimal, at least in the short term.

site_title: In S'pore's automation drive, execution is key
summary: The Singapore government's automation push is expected to be crucial in the country's economic future, but its execution will be key to its success. With over $400 million allocated for the Automation Support Package and $450 million for the National Robotics Programme, the government must ensure that funds are used efficiently to implement new schemes. Analysts warn that a phased approach and focus on jobs that are physically strenuous, such as logistics and warehousing, will be essential to mitigate the impact of automation on the workforce.

site_title: 1995: Nick Leeson brings down Barings
summary: Nick Leeson, a Singapore-based derivatives trader, brought down Britain's oldest bank, Barings, in 1995 with estimated losses of US$1.6 billion due to bets on the Japanese stock market and government bonds. After fleeing Singapore, Leeson was caught, extradited, and sentenced to 6.5 years in prison for cheating and forgery. The collapse of Barings led to the term "Rogue Trader" entering global corporate history. Meanwhile, tycoons Ng Teng Fong and Quek Leng Chan battled for control of Yeo Hiap Seng, with Ng emerging victorious.

site_title: Hedge funds keep betting on silver even as rally starts to fade
summary: Hedge funds increased their bullish bets on silver to an all-time high, adding to their net-long positions in the fourth week in five. Despite the price surge showing signs of fatigue, with futures posting two consecutive weekly declines, money managers remain optimistic. The rally has been driven by speculation on global growth risks and lower borrowing costs, but some investors are reassessing the outlook due to signs of manufacturing growth stalling. Despite this, Bank of America Merrill Lynch raised its price forecast by 8% to $16.47 for 2016, citing a shift in fundamentals.

site_title: Obama's pivot to Asia staggers as trade deal stalls in Congress
summary: President Barack Obama's pivot to Asia, aimed at countering Chinese expansion in the Pacific, is struggling as a key trade deal with 11 Pacific-Rim nations is in danger of being rejected by the US Congress. Despite efforts to strengthen relationships with regional allies, China's territorial claims and belligerence have increased, making the situation in Asia "clearly worse" than it was eight years ago. The Trans-Pacific Partnership, a cornerstone of Obama's Asia-Pacific strategy, faces opposition from both Republicans and Democrats, threatening to undo his foreign policy accomplishments.

images.alt_text: Mr Obama's pivot to Asia, as it's come to be known, became formal in November 2011 when he traveled to Hawaii, Australia and Indonesia to announce strengthened economic and military cooperation with US allies in the region.

site_title: Japan startup spins profitable future for synthetic spider silk
summary: Japanese startup Spiber Inc. has developed a super-strong, synthetic spider silk material, which will be used in North Face's $1,000 "Moon Parka" jacket. The material, made from genetically engineered microorganisms, is stronger than steel and more elastic than nylon, with lower carbon emissions. Spiber plans to expand its use in various products, including underwear and industrial applications. The company's president, Kazuhide Sekiyama, aims to revolutionize the production of various industrial products using protein-based materials, with the goal of reducing the planet's environmental impact.

images.alt_text: Spiber's Mr Sekiyama holding a tube containing synthetic spider silk. The company uses genetically altered micro- organisms to mass produce a silk-protein material called "Qmonos", meaning spider's web in Japanese.

site_title: Hines said to offer US$5.5b real estate
summary: Hines, a US real estate company, is offering a US$5.5 billion portfolio of properties, including a London office building leased to Morgan Stanley, for sale. The company, which manages $89.1 billion in assets, has hired Lazard to advise on the sale. The properties, valued at about $5.3 billion, are spread across the US, UK, Australia, Germany, Poland, France, and Russia. This move comes as US commercial real estate values have fallen for the second consecutive month, with total returns from London investment properties at 1.54% in the three months through March.

site_title: Facebook's Zuckerberg to meet conservatives on political bias flap
summary: Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg will meet with 12 conservative thought leaders on Wednesday to address allegations of political bias on the platform. The meeting comes after a former employee claimed workers omitted conservative stories from the company's trending list. The invitees include media personalities Glenn Beck and Dana Perino. The meeting aims to address concerns about Facebook's handling of conservative content and provide transparency into the company's content moderation practices.

site_title: CWT's controlling shareholders in exclusive talks on sale to China's HNA
summary: Singapore's CWT, a diversified logistics company, is in exclusive talks with China's HNA Group for a potential sale of the company's shares. The controlling shareholders, controlling 58.9% of the company, have signed an agreement to negotiate the sale. A deal could trigger a general offer for the remaining shares, with HNA being the most interested party. The pricing and structure of the sale are still to be negotiated, and the exclusivity period is unclear.

site_title: Biofuels plant in Hawaii first to be certified as sustainable
summary: A biodiesel plant in Hawaii has become the first US-based facility to receive certification for sustainability from the Sustainable Biodiesel Alliance. The plant, owned by Pacific Biodiesel, uses local waste products to produce nearly 13,000 gallons of biodiesel daily. The certification aims to provide consumers with information to make environmentally conscious choices. The plant's use of local waste and minimal environmental impact sets it apart from other biodiesel production methods, which have been criticized for contributing to deforestation and greenhouse gas emissions.

site_title: New North Sea beckons oil producers off Canada's east coast
summary: Major oil companies, including Exxon Mobil and Chevron, are investing C$1.2 billion in auctions off Canada's east coast, with the potential to double exploration in the area. The change in a decades-old shipping law has opened the area to more vessels, and 13 new parcels will be auctioned in November. The province expects to offer up to 2% more area annually, and exploration blocks may hold 12 billion barrels of oil, comparable to Norway's North Sea. Despite low oil prices, the government hopes the new opportunities will boost the economy.

site_title: When technology meets infrastructure
summary: A recent panel discussion in Singapore explored the intersection of new-age technology and age-old infrastructure, highlighting how technology is changing infrastructure needs. Experts noted that while technology can be disruptive, it cannot replace the need for infrastructure in certain areas, such as water supply and healthcare. Technology has already disrupted traditional infrastructure in some instances, with countries abandoning plans for cables and telephone lines in favor of satellite technology and mobile phones. To harness technology effectively, governments and companies must work together to create infrastructure at a more efficient pace and on a more cost-efficient basis.

site_title: Smart yet down-to-earth cooking
summary: Mo'mor Izakaya, a restaurant in Singapore, has finally found its niche after three failed attempts by Swiss Butchery to create a dining space in a cramped basement. The eatery serves smart yet down-to-earth cooking, with a focus on generic Western cuisine and Japanese ingredients. Standout dishes include soft-shell crabs, grilled hamachi collar, and Japanese squid, all made with attention to detail and quality ingredients. The restaurant's affordable set lunches and casual atmosphere make it a popular spot, despite the food not being outstanding. Rating: 7/10.

site_title: MNCs must enable Asian managers to secure top positions
summary: Multinational companies (MNCs) must adapt their talent management strategies to support Asian managers in securing top positions. A recent study by Odgers Berndtson found that Asian executives are just as qualified and capable as their Western counterparts, yet tend to remain below their skill level. To address this, MNCs should consider creative approaches to placements, such as short-term assignments and interim replacements, and prioritize early career planning and development. Exposing high-potential employees to senior executives and creating opportunities for growth and exposure can also help overcome cultural and communication differences.

site_title: US$ rally has legs, says Goldman Sachs
summary: The US dollar has continued its two-week rally, with Goldman Sachs predicting the currency will strengthen to 120 yen in six months and 125 yen in one year. The Bloomberg Dollar Spot Index rose 0.9% last week, driven by the Federal Reserve's expected interest rate hikes. The dollar's gains have led to a shift in market sentiment, with hedge funds and speculators reducing bets on dollar weakness. Goldman Sachs' chief currency strategist, Robin Brooks, believes the dollar's rally has legs, citing scope for greenback strength versus the yen and other major currencies.

site_title: More take up HDB's Lease Buyback Scheme after enhancements
summary: Singapore's Lease Buyback Scheme has seen an increase in take-up, with 541 households participating in the past year, bringing the total to 1,506. The scheme, introduced in 2009, allows elderly flat owners to sell part of their lease back to the Housing Board for retirement income.

site_title: China's steelmakers push output to record high after price rally
summary: China's steelmakers produced a record 2.314 million tonnes in April, surpassing the previous best set in June 2014. The daily rate was 0.5% higher than the previous year, with output rising to 69.42 million tonnes. The increase is attributed to rising prices and the best profits this decade, with steel prices rebounding after five years of losses. However, prices have since receded, and regulators have moved to cool the market frenzy, sparking concerns about the sustainability of the price surges.

site_title: BOE chief denies overstepping mark with Brexit warning
summary: BOE Governor Mark Carney denied overstepping his mark by warning of potential economic costs of Brexit, despite criticism from "Out" campaigners. Carney said he has a responsibility to explain risks and mitigate them, and that ignoring them wouldn't reduce them. The BOE warned of slower growth, higher inflation, and recession if the UK leaves the EU, but Carney assured households can still service their debts, albeit at a cost to consumer demand.

site_title: Uber drivers criticise US$100m settlement, say lawyer sold out
summary: Uber drivers are criticizing a $100 million settlement, saying lawyer Shannon Liss-Riordan sold out by accepting a payout less than 10% of drivers' claims. Liss-Riordan claims she did the best she could in a hard-fought case, but critics say she prioritized lawyer fees over drivers' interests. The settlement, which covers 385,000 drivers, includes a sliding payment scale and allows drivers to post signs about tips. A judge is set to approve the settlement on June 2, but critics argue it's a "sweetheart deal" for Uber.

images.alt_text: The lawyer who struck a US$100 million deal with Uber Technologies Inc is being accused of greed by some of the drivers covered by the accord who want her bumped.

site_title: Can Buffett-backed bid help Yahoo grow?
summary: Warren Buffett is backing a consortium, led by Quicken Loans founder Dan Gilbert, in a bid to purchase Yahoo's internet assets. Buffett is helping to finance the offer, a rare move into digital media for the investor. Analysts say Buffett's history of investing in struggling companies with a large consumer base could work in Yahoo's favor, as the company has struggled to compete with Google and Facebook. If successful, the investment could be a significant turnaround for Yahoo, which is auctioning off its internet business and cutting 15% of its workforce.

images.alt_text: In Media General's case, Mr Buffett bought many of its newspapers and provided nearly US$450 million in debt relief.

site_title: Foreign firms struggling despite India easing red tape
summary: Foreign firms continue to struggle with India's complex regulatory environment, despite efforts by Prime Minister Narendra Modi to ease red tape. High-profile disputes over taxes and market access have led to billions of dollars in backdated tax bills and threats of asset seizure. The country ranks 130 out of 189 on the World Bank's Ease of Doing Business index, with varying regulations across states and a much-reviled 2012 retrospective tax law still in place. Despite India's growing economy, nationalist tendencies and protectionist policies have hindered investment and trade, with major companies like Vodafone and Monsanto facing challenges.

site_title: Verstappen makes F1 history as Mercedes crash out
summary: Max Verstappen made history as the youngest F1 winner at 18 years old, beating Kimi Raikkonen by 0.616 seconds in the Spanish Grand Prix. Mercedes drivers Lewis Hamilton and Nico Rosberg crashed out on the opening lap, ending their team's hopes of extending their winning streak. Verstappen's impressive debut performance earned praise from his team, Red Bull, and his father, Jos, who called it the best day of his life.

site_title: Does 'sell in May and go away' hold sway?
summary: A saying in the stock market, "sell in May and go away," has been observed in recent weeks, with some investors cashing out in anticipation of market volatility. However, historical data suggests that selling in May may not yield significant benefits, with the S&P 500 index showing a 1.83% average rise between May and October. The saying, which advises investors to stay out of markets from May to September and re-enter in October, has some merit but is not foolproof, as 2015 saw selling accelerate despite buying again in September.

site_title: CWT shareholders in exclusive talks for potential sale to China's HNA
summary: CWT's controlling shareholders, holding 58.9% of shares, are in exclusive talks with China's HNA Group to sell their stakes. The deal could trigger a general offer for CWT if HNA's shareholding exceeds 30%. HNA has been the most advanced party in negotiations, and an official announcement is expected soon. The pricing and structure of the sale must still be negotiated, and the exclusivity period is unclear. The sale could impact CWT's market capitalization of S$1.3 billion, currently at S$2.12 per share.

site_title: This US$5.5b Swedish hedge fund doesn't care about political risk
summary: A Swedish hedge fund, Informed Portfolio Management (IPM), is ignoring potential risks from Brexit and political turmoil in various countries, focusing instead on fundamental analysis and relative bets. The US$5.5 billion fund has made successful bets on the Russian rouble and Brazilian real, and its simulations show a minor impact from a Brexit. IPM's CEO, Stefan Nydahl, believes that short-term price movements are irrelevant and that fundamental factors drive investment decisions, resulting in a 14.6% return on its Systemic Macro portfolio this year.

site_title: Till wrinkles do us part: introducing the brotox groom
summary: Men are increasingly seeking pre-wedding cosmetic treatments, known as "brotox," to enhance their appearance before the big day. Many grooms, groomsmen, and even fathers-in-law are opting for procedures such as Botox, Kybella, and SculpSure to reduce wrinkles, fat, and unwanted hair. The trend is attributed to the growing acceptance of men taking care of their appearance and the influence of the gay community. The American Society for Aesthetic Plastic Surgery reported a 63% increase in male procedures over a five-year period, with over 1.2 million procedures performed in 2015.

site_title: Indonesia reviewing collaboration with S'pore on haze and forest fires
summary: Indonesia is reviewing its bilateral cooperation with Singapore in the environment and forestry field, including haze and forest fires. Minister of the Environment and Forestry Siti Nurbaya stated that existing collaborations would be terminated if they don't meet Indonesia's criteria, while planned collaborations are also being put on hold. The review process aims to ensure Indonesia's environmental laws and regulations are upheld. Singapore's Ministry of the Environment and Water Resources has not commented on the review, but Indonesia will notify them of any terminated or scrapped collaborations.

site_title: China asks UK for advice on super-regulator
summary: China has asked the UK for advice on creating a financial super-regulator to improve oversight and reduce systemic risk following the 2015 stock market crash. The talks highlight China's growing willingness to seek outside help in regulating its financial infrastructure. Beijing has sent delegations to London to study the UK regulatory framework, and UK government representatives have visited Beijing to discuss financial and regulatory issues. The proposed super-regulator would consolidate supervisory powers over banking, mutual funds, insurance, and securities, with options including reporting to the central bank or the State Council.

images.alt_text: Weaknesses in Chinese regulation were exposed last summer when China's stock markets lost a third of their value in a month, having soared 150 per cent in the previous 12 months.

site_title: Buying surges after 2 weeks of low purchases
summary: Buying activity surged on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) in the second week of May, with 13 firms recording 29 acquisitions worth S$2.5 million. The rebound in buying activity follows two weeks of low purchases. In contrast, sales remained low with one firm posting two disposals worth S$0.042 million. The surge in buying activity was driven by significant purchases by GSH Corporation, Sing Investments & Finance, Heeton Holdings, and Overseas Education, among others. The buys were made after the companies announced improved financial results or rebounded in share prices.

site_title: Indonesia environment ministry reviewing bilateral cooperation with Singapore
summary: Indonesia's Minister of the Environment and Forestry, Dr Siti Nurbaya, is reviewing bilateral cooperation with Singapore in the environment and forestry field. The review process aims to terminate existing collaborations that no longer meet Indonesia's criteria. This move follows a court warrant issued by Singapore's National Environment Agency against an Indonesian company for failing to provide information on its efforts to mitigate fires and prevent haze. The review process will assess all bilateral collaborations, including those planned for the future.

site_title: TSA proposes measures to cut US airport gridlock
summary: The Transportation Security Administration (TSA) has proposed measures to reduce wait times at US airport checkpoints, amid growing frustration from passengers. Homeland Security Secretary Jeh Johnson authorized steps including overtime for screeners, faster hiring, and increased use of bomb-sniffing dogs. However, Johnson noted that these measures will not eliminate waiting times, which can still take an hour or more. The TSA aims to improve the passenger experience, but the issue of gridlock remains a challenge.

site_title: Being global but thinking locally
summary: Hewlett Packard Enterprise (HPE) is redefining its focus on customer-centricity, with Managing Director (MD) LOH Khai Peng emphasizing the company's commitment to creating innovative solutions that address customer needs. Since its split from HP in 2015, HPE has shifted its focus to high-tech manufacturing and sales, marketing, and professional consulting services. The company has also developed intellectual property for cloud, analytics, and mobility solutions, and has established a regional headquarters in Singapore. HPE's four key transformation areas - hybrid infrastructure, digital enterprise security, analytics, and data-driven organization - are aligned with Singapore's Smart Nation aspirations.

site_title: What do comparisons between US stock, bond yields reveal?
summary: The S&P 500 Index's price-earnings ratio is near its highest levels since the Internet bubble, but stocks remain cheap compared to bonds. A comparison between the index's per-share earnings and the yield on the 10-year Treasury note, known as the Fed Model, shows that stocks are less expensive than any time during the 2002-2007 bull market. The average payout by S&P 500 companies is 2.18%, nearly 7 times wider than its smallest point in 2007, providing a floor for the market and supporting bull cases.

site_title: Spring to be 'administering agency' against errant retailers
summary: Singapore's Ministry of Trade and Industry (MTI) has proposed two key amendments to the Consumer Protection (Fair Trading) Act, aiming to strengthen measures against errant retailers and protect consumers. The proposed changes will appoint Spring Singapore as an administering agency with investigation and enforcement powers, and allow the courts to impose additional measures, such as publicizing errant retailers' status and requiring them to notify consumers. The measures are targeted at persistent errant retailers and will enable tougher action to be taken against them.

site_title: Eu Yan Sang Q3 profit dented by forex losses, closing of F&B operations in China
summary: Eu Yan Sang International Ltd reported a 94.8% decline in Q3 net profit to S$286,000 due to a 6% drop in operating revenue, foreign exchange losses, and expenses from closing F&B operations in China. Revenue slipped to S$103.87 million, mainly due to a decline in Malaysian market revenue and the weakening Malaysian ringgit. The group attributed the decline to weak macroeconomic conditions in Hong Kong and Malaysia.

images.alt_text: Eu Yan Sang International Ltd reported a slump in net profit to S$286,000 for the third quarter ended March 31 from S$5.45 million, as it suffered decline in operating revenue, foreign exchange losses and expenses related to cessation of F&B operations in China.

site_title: US: Wall Street drops at end of tough week for retailers
summary: US stocks fell on Friday, closing down 0.85% to 2,046.61, as a decline in oil prices and gloomy quarterly reports from Nordstrom and JC Penney overshadowed upbeat April retail sales data. Consumer stocks, which have been under pressure this week, fell again, with Nordstrom and JC Penney losing 13.42% and 2.82%, respectively. The Dow Jones industrial average dropped 1.05% and the Nasdaq Composite fell 0.41%.

site_title: Fifa compliance chief quits, saying corruption fight threatened
summary: Fifa's head of audit and compliance, Domenico Scala, quit due to changes at the top of the organization that he believes will undermine efforts to eliminate corruption. Scala cited a vote allowing the ruling council to dismiss members of independent advisory bodies as a threat to their independence. Scala's resignation comes after a disagreement with new President Gianni Infantino over a $2 million annual pay offer. Scala's departure has been accepted by Fifa, which claims his claims are "baseless."

site_title: How internal auditors can be more effective
summary: A recent NUS-ISCA study highlights the need for internal auditors to improve in three areas: risk-based audits, judicious outsourcing, and ensuring independence. Audit committees, managing conflicting expectations from various stakeholders, require an effective internal audit function to perform optimally. The study's respondents, mostly AC chairmen of large and small listed companies, believe that improving internal auditor effectiveness can be achieved through these three key areas, ultimately supporting the AC's optimal performance.

site_title: Taking bilateral exchanges to a new level
summary: The Singapore-Australia Comprehensive Strategic Partnership (CSP) package aims to deepen economic, social, and defense ties between the two countries. Key benefits include increased investment, trade, and cultural exchange. Singapore companies can focus on joint development of Australia's Northern areas, while Australian companies can tap into Singapore's hub for equity and renewable energy investments. The agreement also promotes freer movement for people, goods, and services, and enhances university degree recognition, professional qualifications, and innovation. The pact is expected to boost bilateral trade, tourism, and talent mobility, ultimately strengthening regional ties and cooperation.

site_title: Fed's Williams sees good outlook, 2-3 rate hikes this year
summary: US Federal Reserve Bank President John Williams sees a "definitely good" economic outlook, suggesting 2-3 rate hikes this year. The Fed has kept rates on hold since December, citing concerns over a slowdown in China and Europe. Williams believes delaying rate hikes would force the Fed to move more quickly in 2017, but markets do not expect rate hikes until December. The Fed's balance sheet reduction is still in the future, with a possible start in the background.

site_title: Fifa compliance chief quits in protest at changes
summary: FIFA's head of audit and compliance, Domenico Scala, quit in protest of changes made by new president Gianni Infantino, which he believes will imperil efforts to eliminate corruption. Scala stated that allowing the ruling council to dismiss independent advisory body members would leave them vulnerable to manipulation. Scala had been with the organization for four years and made the decision to leave after a vote on Friday. The changes were made at the first congress under Infantino's leadership. Scala's departure raises concerns about the integrity of FIFA's anti-corruption efforts.

site_title: Facebook launches probe into report of political bias
summary: Facebook is investigating allegations of political bias after an unnamed former employee claimed workers omitted conservative stories from the trending list. Chairman Mark Zuckerberg stated that Facebook has found no evidence to support the claim, but will continue to investigate. The company will invite "leading conservatives" to share their points of view and has revealed its guidelines for selecting and displaying news. Facebook has over 1 billion daily active users and denies discriminating against any political origin. The company will take additional steps if evidence of bias is found.

site_title: China complains to WTO that US fails to implement tariff ruling
summary: China has filed a complaint with the World Trade Organization (WTO) against the US for failing to implement a ruling against punitive tariffs on Chinese goods. The US imposed duties on solar panels, wind towers, and steel pipe in 2012, but the deadline for implementation expired in April. China claims the US is disregarding WTO rules and harming Chinese industries. This comes as trade tensions between the two countries continue to escalate, with the US also lodging a complaint against China's duties on US broiler chicken exports.

site_title: Teenage sensation Verstappen wins maiden Grand Prix in Spain
summary: Max Verstappen, an 18-year-old Dutch driver, won his maiden Formula One Grand Prix in Spain, becoming the youngest ever winner. The victory came after a spectacular first lap crash that eliminated both Mercedes cars. Verstappen showed composure under pressure, resisting all attacks to claim the win in his 24th F1 race, breaking Sebastian Vettel's record as the youngest Red Bull driver to win a Grand Prix.

images.alt_text: Red Bull F1 driver Max Verstappen (L) of The Netherlands celebrates with Ferrari F1 driver Kimi Raikkonen of Finland after winning Spanish Grand Prix. REUTERS

site_title: China's economy loses momentum in April, clouding policy outlook
summary: China's economy showed signs of slowing growth in April, with industrial production increasing 6% and retail sales missing analyst forecasts. Fixed-asset investment rose 10.5%, but new credit growth fell short of expectations. Top leaders signaled a shift away from debt-fueled growth, emphasizing the need for deleveraging and upgrading industrial capabilities. Economists warn that risks to growth and inflation remain on the downside, and policy easing and reforms may be necessary to generate a sustained recovery. China's central bank reassured investors that monetary policy will continue to support the economy.

site_title: New York Fed defends fund transfer after Bangladesh heist
summary: The Federal Reserve Bank of New York has defended its procedures for wiring funds after a cyber heist at the Bangladesh central bank, which resulted in the theft of $81 million. In response to criticism, a letter from the New York Fed stated that the correct procedures were followed in approving five transfers of money and blocking 30. The letter attributed the heist to the hackers' ability to bypass the automated systems' manual review process, which relies on the SWIFT messaging network's authentication process. The New York Fed's procedures will be reviewed to prevent similar incidents in the future.

site_title: Cyber-city rises from the desert in Israel
summary: A cyber-city is rising in Beersheba, Israel, cementing the country's position as a major digital power. The development will concentrate top talent from the military, academia, and business, with a cyber emergency response team and a military cyberdefenders' headquarters nearby. Israel is at the forefront of cyber-offence, developing stealthy computer weapons, and has a unique ability to organise itself to defeat cyberthreats due to its size, history, and culture. The country aims to be feared in the region and is working closely with the US on cyber-activities, despite occasional disagreements.

images.alt_text: In global private investment into cybersecurity firms, Israel is second only to the US, with half a billion dollars flowing to the sector annually.

site_title: Anti-counterfeit group suspends Alibaba after a month
summary: The International AntiCounterfeiting Coalition (IACC) suspended Alibaba's membership after a month, citing conflicts of interest involving President Bob Barchiesi and complaints from some members. The IACC board acknowledged a "weakness in our corporate governance procedures" and will review its governance. Alibaba, a major e-commerce platform, was initially welcomed as a member but raised concerns about its image as a haven for counterfeit products. The company will continue to work with the IACC to combat counterfeits, despite being suspended.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary:
Here's a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. Creative Technology warned of below-target H2 revenue and similar operating losses as in H1. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran, is OCBC's incoming CEO, replacing Helen Wong. Singapore stocks rallied for a 5-day run ahead of GDP data, with affluents needing around $1.39 million to retire comfortably.

site_title: Warren Buffett backs Gilbert's Yahoo bid
summary: Warren Buffett has backed a consortium, led by Quicken Loans founder Dan Gilbert, in the auction for Yahoo's internet assets. The consortium is in the second round of bidding and is competing against other parties. Buffett made no immediate comment on the matter. The bidding process for Yahoo's assets is confidential, and the company has not responded to a request for comment. This development marks a significant shift in the bidding process, with Buffett's involvement likely to add weight to the consortium's bid.

site_title: Japan to push for new G-7 model for financing global growth
summary: Japan is hosting a G-7 meeting in Sendai, where finance ministers and central bank governors will consider new financing models to restore the position of advanced nations as a driving force behind the global economy. The meeting aims to focus on central bank-financed spending on projects rather than monetary handouts. The G-7 nations, including the US, Japan, and European countries, will discuss ways to promote global growth amidst a slowdown in China and other emerging economies. The meeting is seen as an opportunity for Japan to reassert itself as a key player in global economic affairs.

site_title: Ukraine wins Eurovision Song Contest
summary: Ukraine's Jamala wins the Eurovision Song Contest with her song "1944", scoring 534 points and outperforming Russia's Sergey Lazarev and Australia's Dami Im. The song tells the story of the deportation of Crimean Tatars during World War II, sparking controversy over its perceived criticism of Russia's annexation of Crimea. Ukraine's President Petro Poroshenko congratulated Jamala on her victory, and the contest saw a record-breaking 197 million viewers worldwide, solidifying its status as a global phenomenon.

site_title: G7 to take steps on global steel glut
summary: The G7 nations are set to take steps to address a global steel glut, blaming overcapacity at Chinese steel producers. The issue has led to closures of steel mills in countries like Australia and the UK. China's steel output hit a record high earlier this year, prompting calls for urgent action from the US, EU, and others. China plans to shed 150 million tonnes of domestic crude steel capacity in five years. The G7 draft text urges coordinated actions to eliminate subsidies and support, and encourages adjustment to address the issue.

site_title: Oil slips on stronger dollar; gains on the week on supply outages
summary: Oil prices slipped on Friday due to a stronger dollar and investor profit-taking, but ended the week higher after supply outages in Nigeria and Canada. Brent crude futures fell 25 cents to $47.83 a barrel, while US crude ended 49 cents lower at $46.21. Despite a 5.2% weekly gain for Brent and a 3.4% weekly rise for US crude, the market sentiment remains biased to the upside, supported by growing views of a rebalancing pattern in the global oil complex.

site_title: Hollywood takes notice as Korean films surf K-culture wave
summary: South Korean films are gaining international recognition, with three films premiering at the 2016 Cannes Film Festival. Director Park Chan-Wook's period drama "The Handmaiden" is competing for the Palme d'Or, while other Korean films, including "The Wailing" and "Train to Busan", are showing in out-of-competition sections. This marks a growing cinematic clout for Korean cinema, with Hollywood taking notice of its accomplishments. Korean directors, such as Park Chan-Wook, Kim Jee-Woon, and Bong Joon-Ho, have been hired to helm English-language movies, showcasing their unique style and creativity.

site_title: Scandal-hit VW gives staff 3,950-euro bonus
summary: Volkswagen announced a 3,950-euro bonus for its 2015 staff, despite suffering losses due to the emissions-cheating scandal. The bonus, less than the 2014 payout, comes after criticism over top executives' bonuses, which were frozen 30% for nine directors. The company has set aside 16.2 billion euros in provisions for the scandal, which led to a 1.58 billion euro loss. VW employs 600,000 people globally and has committed to recognizing staff's "strong commitment" despite the difficult situation.

images.alt_text: German auto giant Volkswagen announced Friday it is giving its staff a 3,950-euro bonus for 2015, despite suffering huge losses due to an emissions-cheating scandal which sent shockwaves through the industry.

site_title: China orders banks to clear hurdles slowing private sector lending
summary: China's Banking Regulatory Commission has ordered local banks to investigate and clear bottlenecks slowing private sector lending. The directive requires financial institutions to report their implementation results by May 20. The move aims to address issues such as insufficient lending support to small and micro-businesses, and reduce costs for short-term credit products. The CBRC also calls for banks to examine risk in their loan guarantee businesses, in line with central government directives to promote private investment's stable and sustainable growth.

site_title: Govt urges BBC to become 'more distinctive'
summary: The UK government has urged the BBC to become more distinctive and avoid aping its commercial rivals, subjecting the 94-year-old broadcaster to external regulation for the first time. The reforms will replace the BBC Trust with a new board and hand external regulation to Ofcom, with the government naming six members and the BBC appointing the majority.
