The reforms aim to address criticism of the BBC's bloated and wasteful nature, with external regulation and transparency measures to be introduced, including publishing salaries over £450,000 and value for money audits.

site_title: Digital currency firm co-founder gets 10 years in prison in US case
summary: A US District Judge sentenced co-founder Vladamir Kats of digital currency firm Liberty Reserve to 10 years in prison for money laundering and operating an unlicensed money transmitting business. Kats agreed to help prosecute his ex-partner, Arthur Budovsky, who received a 20-year prison term for similar charges. Kats also forfeited $6.5 million and pleaded guilty to money laundering and operating an unlicensed money transmitting business in 2013. Liberty Reserve processed over $8 billion in transactions, helping launder proceeds from various crimes.

site_title: Forex gains, better margins boost Golden Agri in Q1
summary: Golden Agri-Resources reported a net profit of US$94 million for Q1 2016, driven by currency and tax gains and better downstream margins. However, an accounting change reduced its book value by US$5 billion, causing its net asset value to more than halve. The company expects to focus on upstream yield improvement and integrating recently-acquired downstream assets, with total 2016 capital expenditure projected at US$180 million.

site_title: Obama tells schools to allow transgender bathroom access
summary: President Barack Obama's administration issued a letter to schools, stating they must allow students to use bathrooms of their choosing based on their gender identity. The guidance, issued by the Justice and Education Departments, comes amid a heated battle over transgender rights. Schools that disagree with the administration's interpretation could face lawsuits or reduced federal aid. Attorney General Loretta Lynch described the policies as "unjust" and emphasized that there is no room for discrimination in schools, including against transgender students. The move follows a federal court battle in North Carolina over a state law requiring transgender people to use public restrooms based on their birth certificate.

images.alt_text: President Barack Obama's administration fired the latest salvo Friday in a heated battle over the rights of transgender Americans, telling schools they must allow students to use bathrooms of their choosing.

site_title: Tech optimist
summary: Chairman of PricewaterhouseCoopers Dennis Nally believes technology will have a transformative effect on economies and businesses, but warns that institutions that do not adapt quickly will be left behind. He cites examples of companies like Airbnb, retail, and supply chain management that have leveraged technology to improve efficiency and responsiveness to consumers. Nally also notes that accounting firms, like PwC, need to evolve to deliver services that incorporate big data and technology tools. However, he acknowledges that the profession faces challenges in achieving consistency in accounting and reporting standards across borders, and that auditors have a critical responsibility to provide more holistic guidance to investors.

site_title: Japan's Abe to delay sales tax hike
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe has decided to delay a planned sales tax hike from 8% to 10% set for April, following further consideration and talks with fellow Group of Seven leaders. Economists had predicted the delay due to weak consumption, wage growth, and a stronger yen. The delay is seen as a move to boost economic growth and support businesses, but the exact date of the revised hike has not been announced.

site_title: China central bank says no change to money policy after April loans miss expectations
summary: China's central bank stated that its monetary policy stance remains "prudent" despite a disappointing April loan release, with banks cutting back on new loans by 555.6 billion yuan. However, the bank attributed this to seasonal and technical factors, and noted that new loans in April were actually higher than expected when including local government bond issuance. The bank stated that current financial support to the real economy remains strong, with no change to monetary policy.

images.alt_text: China's central bank said it has not changed its "prudent" monetary policy stance despite a disappointing release of April data showing banks had cut back sharply on new loans.

site_title: Pfizer blocks its drugs from use in lethal injections
summary: Pfizer has blocked its drugs from use in lethal injections, citing strong objection to their use in capital punishment. The move follows similar actions by over 20 US and European drugmakers, effectively shutting off the last open market source of execution drugs. Pfizer's distribution restriction applies to products that have been part of or considered for lethal injection protocols. The company's action aims to prevent its products from being used in executions, aligning with the stance of other major pharmaceutical companies.

site_title: Europe: Shares rally after US data but Eutelsat plunges
summary: European shares rose 0.6% after strong US retail sales data, lifting markets despite earlier losses. The pan-European FTSEurofirst 300 index rebounded from negative territory. In contrast, satellite company Eutelsat plummeted nearly 30% after slashing its outlook. The US retail sales data showed a year-high increase, suggesting the world's largest economy is regaining momentum.

site_title: Association of Banks fends off ransomware attack
summary: The Association of Banks in Singapore (ABS) successfully defended against a ransomware attack, which was likely infiltrated through an employee's email. The malware, a type of ransomware, was detected and contained, and the ABS's director, Ong-Ang Ai Boon, attributed the incident to the "crooks" being "a few steps ahead" of regulations. The incident comes as ransomware attacks on the rise in Singapore, with the government's Singapore Computer Emergency Response Team warning users of the risks and advising to update anti-virus software regularly.

site_title: Short-lived rally for Kim Heng on Iran foray
summary: Kim Heng Offshore & Marine Holdings' planned foray into Iran sparked a short-lived rally, with its shares opening at S$0.094 before closing 11.2% lower at S$0.079. The company announced a non-binding memorandum of understanding with Iran Marine Fund, estimating up to S$622 million in value over 10 years. Analysts noted the preliminary nature of the agreement and potential regulatory hurdles, but highlighted the partnership's potential to secure projects in the oil and gas-rich country.

site_title: Trump taps climate change skeptic as energy adviser, pushes back on taxes
summary: Donald Trump has selected climate change skeptic and US Republican Representative Kevin Cramer as his energy adviser, despite criticism from environmental groups and Hillary Clinton's campaign. Cramer's white paper on energy policy will emphasize the dangers of foreign ownership of US energy assets, taxes, and over-regulation. Trump also pushed back on calls to release his income tax returns, saying it's "none of your business." The move is seen as a significant shift in Trump's energy policy, contrasting with Clinton's plan to shift the country to 50% clean energy by 2030.

site_title: Global network exploited again in bank breach
summary: Thieves have breached the SWIFT messaging system, stealing $81 million from the central bank of Bangladesh in February. The attack appears to be part of a broader online assault on global banking. The incident is the second breach involving SWIFT, with new details emerging. The lender involved has not been identified. Investigators are still working to solve the heist, which is believed to be linked to a broader cybercrime operation targeting financial institutions worldwide.

site_title: Houston developers know how to build apartments
summary: Houston and Dallas developers are building a higher percentage of multi-unit dwellings than any other US metropolitan area except New York. Despite criticism of higher-density development, demand for apartments is evident, particularly in walkable neighborhoods and affordable housing. The cities' zoning-free approach to development, with minimal land-use rules, allows for a high volume of apartment construction. This is in contrast to cities like San Francisco and Los Angeles, which face geographical limits and stricter regulations, limiting their ability to build apartments.

site_title: Lagarde issues yet another bleak warning if UK chooses Brexit
summary: IMF managing director Christine Lagarde has issued a bleak warning that the UK could plunge into a "severe" crisis if it chooses to leave the European Union. The IMF report predicts that Britain's economy would be depressed below 2% this year and rebound to 2.25% if it stays in the EU. A vote for exit would lead to financial market volatility, output hit, and heightened uncertainty. The report also warns that London's status as a global financial center could be eroded and the UK's reliance on external financing could exacerbate these risks.

site_title: HK economy contracts in Q1
summary: Hong Kong's economy unexpectedly contracted in Q1 with a 0.4% decline in GDP from the previous quarter, the lowest growth in 10 years. Falling retail sales and a weakening property market contributed to the decline. Retail sales fell for a 13th consecutive month, with Chinese tourists expected to drop 3.2% and average spending to decline 4%. Economists predict minimal growth for the next 5-6 months, with some revising their GDP growth forecasts downward.

site_title: Hapag-Lloyd, Asian lines form new alliance
summary: Hapag-Lloyd, Germany's top container shipping line, has formed a new vessel-sharing alliance with five Asian carriers, including Kawasaki Kisen Kaisha and Mitsui OSK Lines, to compete against market leaders Maersk Line and Mediterranean Shipping Co. The alliance, called "The Alliance," controls 18% of the world's container shipping fleet and has a combined capacity of 3.5 million standard twenty-foot containers. The partnership aims to increase its capacity to over 4 million TEU, but experts question its ability to survive due to the size of Maersk and Chinese shipping lines.

site_title: VW getting ready to move on recovery plan in US: sales chief
summary: Volkswagen aims to reach a final settlement with US authorities by June 21 to move forward with a recovery plan. The plan includes launching new crossover and electric vehicles, such as a mid-sized SUV and an all-new family of electric cars, to meet growing demand for green cars in the US. VW hopes to expand its electric vehicle offerings and restore its image after the "Dieselgate" scandal, which has seen US sales fall 11% this year. Analysts expect a recovery in US sales, with estimates predicting 490,906 vehicles sold in 2022.

site_title: ST Engg's Q1 earnings down 15.2%
summary: ST Engineering's Q1 earnings fell 15.2% to S$110.2 million due to lower profit from its land systems and marine sectors, but revenue rose 7.7% to S$1.63 billion driven by higher sales from the aerospace and electronics divisions. Earnings per share dropped 15.35% to 3.53 Singapore cents. The company announced S$948 million worth of new contracts and ended the quarter with an order book of S$11.5 billion and a cash reserve of S$1.5 billion.

site_title: Foxconn founder tells Sharp staff layoffs needed to begin revival
summary: Foxconn founder Terry Gou has written to Sharp Corp staff that layoffs are necessary to turn around the ailing Japanese company. Gou has pledged that wages will rise and profit-sharing will be reinstated, but notes that costs must be reduced. Sharp has reported tripled annual losses, and Foxconn has a $3.5 billion stake in the company. Staff cuts could total 3,000 in Japan, with more when global operations are included. Foxconn's vice-chairman, Tai Jeng-wu, has been appointed CEO of Sharp, and the company aims to finalize the stake sale by the end of June.

site_title: Heng Swee Keat will remain in ICU 'for some time': PM Lee
summary: Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat remains in stable condition but will stay in ICU "for some time", according to Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong. This comes as concerns over his health grew.

site_title: EPL's heroes and villains
summary: Leicester City captain Wes Morgan lifted the English Premier League trophy, marking the Foxes' first championship win in the most-watched football league in the world. The season was unusual, with top teams Chelsea, Arsenal, Manchester City, and Manchester United failing to meet expectations. Meanwhile, Liverpool's 26-year wait for a top-flight championship continues. The Foxes' historic victory came after a season of unpredictability, leaving fans and pundits stunned.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: US retail giants feel pain as online shopping hits
summary: US retail giants Macy's and Gap are facing challenges due to the growing market share of online retailers like Amazon. Despite a strong economy with low unemployment, conventional retailers are experiencing declining profits as consumers shift to online shopping. Online retail sales rose 8.1% in the first four months of 2016, compared to 1.9% growth in clothing stores. Retailers are struggling to understand the trend, with Macy's CFO stating they see the same economic data but are experiencing a decline in customer spending.

site_title: Passion investing a better bet in 2015
summary: Investing in objects of passion, such as classic cars, wine, and art, yielded higher returns in 2015 compared to traditional investments like stocks and real estate, according to The Wealth Report 2016. This finding suggests that emotional investment decisions may be more lucrative than rational ones. The report's findings highlight the potential benefits of investing in personal interests and hobbies.

site_title: How to buy a house without an on-site visit
summary: A growing number of homebuyers are making offers on houses without physically visiting the property, with 21% of Redfin survey respondents reporting this practice. To facilitate such purchases, experts recommend using video tours, trusting a reliable agent, and conducting online neighborhood reconnaissance. Agents use tools like FaceTime, Skype, and dedicated apps to provide immersive tours, while also relying on online platforms like Houzz and Pinterest to gather information. By leveraging technology and thorough research, homebuyers can successfully purchase a home without an on-site visit.

site_title: When speed is vital
summary: A sudden loss of nerve function due to inadequate blood flow to the brain, known as a stroke, can be prevented or minimized with early treatment. The most effective treatment is administering clot-busting drugs or mechanical devices within three hours of stroke onset, with a 4.5-hour window for improved outcomes. Imaging techniques, such as non-contrast computed tomography (NCCT) and computed tomographic angiography (CTA), help diagnose and guide treatment. The use of clot-busting drugs, such as alteplase, has shown improved outcomes, with 35% of patients achieving excellent recovery.

site_title: Olam's Q1 earnings treble to S$113.6m
summary: Olam International's Q1 earnings tripled to S$113.6 million, driven by lower bond buyback charges and a 10.2% revenue increase to S$4.8 billion. The company's finance costs decreased by 41.5% due to bond buyback initiatives. However, free cash flow was negative S$156 million due to a large acquisition in Nigeria. Despite this, Olam aims to achieve positive free cash flow by 2016, and its net gearing remains within target.

site_title: Wake-up call for hedge fund investors
summary: Major US insurance firms are reevaluating their investments in hedge funds following steep losses in the last quarter, resulting in billions of dollars in damages to their earnings. Industry leaders, including American International Group and MetLife, plan to cut their hedge fund exposure significantly. Critics argue that hedge funds failed to deliver on their promises of high returns with lower risk, and their high fees are increasingly unsustainable. With over 10,000 hedge funds managing nearly $3 trillion in assets, the industry's complexity and lack of transparency have contributed to the losses.

site_title: Final form of SIA-United tie-up yet to materialise: SIA CEO
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) CEO Goh Choon Phong said the final form of a potential codeshare alliance with United Airlines is yet to be decided. The partnership aims to help SIA fend off competitors with low yields, particularly in the US market. Despite a significant increase in net profit for the fourth quarter, SIA shares fell due to concerns over yield declines. The airline is monitoring Virgin Australia's situation and may consider acquiring its stake to prevent a competitor from claiming it.

site_title: P&G non-profit arm purifies its 10 billionth litre of potable water
summary: Procter & Gamble's non-profit arm has purified its 10 billionth litre of potable water through its Children's Safe Drinking Water programme, launched in 2004 in Pakistan. The goal is to provide 15 billion litres by 2020, enough to "save one life every hour". The programme aims to manufacture and distribute water purification sachets to needy children and families in disaster-impacted areas and developing nations with no access to potable water.

images.alt_text: CLEANER WATER: Kirk Wagar, US Ambassador to Singapore (left) and Magesvaran Suranjan, president of P&G Asia Pacific, demonstrating the purification ability of the sachet on a vat of dirty water.

site_title: It's good times for Ontario's wine industry
summary: Ontario's wine industry is experiencing a surge in popularity, driven by cheaper currency and looser liquor regulations. Canadian wine exports increased 137% in 2014, with the region of Niagara-on-the-Lake producing premium grapes like cabernet sauvignon and chardonnay. Companies like Peller Estates and Diamond Estates are seeing increased demand from Asia, particularly for ice wine and red table wines. The provincial government's loosening of liquor laws is also expected to boost sales, with grocery stores set to stock Ontario wine for the first time.

site_title: Sake paradise
summary: Noriyoshi Nagai, president and CEO of Nagai Sake, has determined that aging sake at -2 degrees Celsius allows it to mature for up to 10 years, while -5 degrees Celsius extends its aging time to 20 years. Nagai Sake's top-tier Nagai Style range accounts for 8% of its total production. Nagai Style sakes are served in wine glasses, but their full flavor is experienced in small sake cups. The company's rarest sake, Nigori, is produced in limited quantities and has a unique, unfiltered taste.

site_title: SPH launches new print technology
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) has launched a new print technology called Variable Print, allowing advertisers to create multiple messages for a single ad in the same edition of a newspaper without stopping the presses. This technology accepts various message types, such as text, images, and barcodes, and enables personalization and targeted messaging. Carlsberg, the official sponsor of Uefa Euro 2016, is using Variable Print in a promotional campaign featuring four football teams, reaching 393,000 readers daily. The technology aims to enhance consumer engagement and measurable success for advertisers.

site_title: April retail sales post largest gain in a year
summary: US retail sales in April recorded a 1.3% gain, the largest increase in a year, driven by car sales rising 3.2% and online retail sales jumping 2.1%. This uptick suggests the economy is regaining momentum after growth stalled in the first quarter. Core retail sales, excluding cars and food services, rose 0.9%, a welcome reprieve for a sector struggling with tepid demand. The increase in retail sales is a positive sign for economic growth, which expanded at a 1.4% pace in the fourth quarter.

site_title: Mundipharma investing S$100m over 5 years in Tuas plant
summary: Mundipharma is investing S$100 million in Singapore over five years, with a focus on setting up a 7,300 sq ft consumer health hub in Tuas. The facility, operational by January 2018, will manufacture and distribute Betadine antiseptics, conduct R&D, and house six production lines producing about a billion applications annually. The investment aims to support emerging markets businesses, with 70% of regional volume to be produced in the facility. The hub will enable rapid response to regional health crises and seek new solutions.

site_title: Malaysia grows at slowest pace in over 6 years
summary: Malaysia's economy grew at its slowest pace in over six years, with a 4.2% increase in the first quarter of 2016. Weakened exports and private investment contributed to the slowdown. The International Monetary Fund has lowered its forecast for global expansion, citing a risk of stagnation. The Malaysian central bank has kept interest rates steady, despite accelerating inflation, and expects growth to improve in the second half of the year. The government projects a 4% to 4.5% growth rate for 2016.

site_title: STI ends week 4 points up despite Friday's fall
summary: The Straits Times Index ended the week 4 points up despite a 10.48-point drop on Friday, closing at 2,734.91. The local stock market saw a significant decline in trading volume, with 982 million units worth S$1.04 billion traded. The market has been affected by deflationary pressures, with a decrease in money supply and a rise in falls (249) versus rises (140) throughout the day.

site_title: When the parts add up
summary: LG, a South Korean tech giant, has built the world's first mass-market modular smartphone, the LG G5, allowing users to upgrade individual parts rather than replacing the entire device. This innovation aims to provide more flexibility and functionality to smartphones, offering a more affordable alternative to traditional incremental upgrades. The modular design enables users to upgrade specific parts, such as batteries or cameras, without having to purchase a new device, potentially reducing electronic waste.

images.alt_text: WORTHWHILE INVESTMENT LG's hardware-based DAC can be fitted on to the phone and comes with a housing that contains a second USB-C port, so that you can use this module with other phones in the market.
MORE LIKE A CAMERA: When the Cam Plus is inserted into the G5, the bump in the rear, which also houses an additional 1,200 mAh battery, acts as a cradle that provides a better phone/camera grip.

site_title: Tranquil Gunma
summary: Gunma, a Japanese prefecture, is a serene getaway from Tokyo's city life, offering fresh air, hot springs, and picturesque scenery. Visitors can relax at onsen resorts like Bettei Senjyuan and Ryokan Tanigawa, which feature private baths with natural hot springs. The area is also home to 100 mountains, 12 cities, and numerous towns and villages, with plenty of opportunities for outdoor activities like fruit picking, hiking, and exploring temples and villages. Recommended accommodations include Yutorian ryokan and Ryokan Tanigawa, and local eateries like Soba Watanabe and Kura Cafe serve delicious soba noodles and sake-infused dishes.

images.alt_text: CHARMING: View of cherry blossoms and Mt Tanigawa from Bettei Senjyuan onsen.
CHARMING: The village complex in Kawaba has many cafes, restaurants and ice cream bars but its main attraction is a farmer's market which offers a huge array of local specialties.
CHARMING: Gunma is famous for its apple orchards and especially for its super sweet honey apples.
ENJOY: Kichijyoji Temple is situated in lush gardens bursting into bloom.
ENJOY: Train enthusiasts can take a ride on Hotel Sl's steam locomotive, which chugs along the hotel grounds back and forth for 150 metres.
ENJOY: Two versions of home made soba - the familiar regular buckwheat noodle and a thinner, beige-hued version that is lighter, chewier and refreshing.

site_title: Singapore gets first case of Zika
summary: Singapore has reported its first case of the Zika virus, a 48-year-old male permanent resident who traveled to Sao Paulo, Brazil, in March. He developed symptoms and is currently under treatment and isolation at Tan Tock Seng Hospital's CDC. The patient is recovering well and will be discharged once tested negative for the virus. The Ministry of Health and National Environment Agency are screening household members and urging residents in nearby areas to take precautions and seek medical attention if symptoms appear.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Iran's revival unlikely to change Opec stance
summary: Iran's oil production has risen to its highest level since 2011, according to the International Energy Agency (IEA). With crude oil prices near their highest since November, analysts believe there is no immediate need for OPEC countries to agree to cap output. Iran's increased production, combined with supply disruptions in Nigeria, Libya, and Venezuela, has reduced the "urgency" for OPEC to limit production when they meet next on June 2. This suggests that Iran's revival is unlikely to change OPEC's stance on production levels.

site_title: Brands take up more shop space - online
summary: Brands in Singapore are expanding their online presence by setting up branded stores on established e-commerce marketplaces such as Qoo10 and Lazada. This move aims to tap into the growing online consumer market, with the Asia-Pacific region expected to become the largest e-commerce market in the world within the next five years. Brands can offer local warranties, after-sales support, and mobile apps, while leveraging the marketplaces' existing resources. Companies like Samsung, Lenovo, and Philips have started selling their products online, and smaller businesses are also leveraging the existing platforms to reach customers.

site_title: Can your company survive in the future?
summary: Leaders must adapt to emerging trends and disruptions to survive in the future workplace, known as Workforce 2020. The changing composition of the workforce, technological advancements, and new ways of working will shape the future of work. Five generations will work together, with Millennials taking on more senior leadership positions, leading to a greater emphasis on creating meaningful work experiences. Companies must invest in making the experience of employees better, with a focus on emotional, intellectual, physical, cultural, and technological aspects. Technology will continue to disrupt some roles, but also enable innovation and productivity in others. Companies must be adaptable, agile, and committed to change to thrive in an unpredictable world.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: ComfortDelGro Corporation is recommended for a buy by RHB Research. The Asia region is expected to drive and benefit from dollar asset diversification. Meanwhile, Ant, backed by Jack Ma, plans to add Circle's stablecoin to its global network. Retail investors are anticipated to drive significant growth in Asia and Europe's ETF market, according to Amundi. The S&P 500 has reached a record high, with some speculating that the worst of the trade war may be behind us. Productivity gains are seen as crucial for wealth creation, while de-dollarisation and shifting safe havens continue to shape market trends.

site_title: More boxes to tick for bankers taking firms public
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has introduced tougher due-diligence guidelines for banks bringing companies to the market, requiring more in-depth scrutiny. The Association of Banks in Singapore (ABS) has set new standards to boost oversight, amid efforts to enhance the listing process. The move aims to improve transparency and protect investors.

site_title: Setting sights on turning hands into keyboards
summary: Tap Systems, founded by Ran Poliakine, has developed a foam strap that translates 31 finger taps into letters and numbers, allowing users to type anywhere and on anything using Bluetooth connectivity. The technology, which has an accuracy level of 99%, aims to replace voice-based systems and eliminate the need for carrying a keyboard. The company plans to offer the strap to the visually impaired and plans consumer testing before shipping, with potential applications in virtual reality, augmented reality, and wearable devices.

site_title: Facebook reveals its policy on news content
summary: Facebook has released internal editorial guidelines detailing its process for selecting content for the "Trending Topics" section on its platform. The guidelines emphasize the role of both human editors and algorithms in curating content, with editors given leeway to exercise their influence at various points in the process. The move comes amid criticism of the company's alleged political bias, with some accusing Facebook of suppressing conservative content. Despite denying these claims, Facebook's stance has been questioned by lawmakers and news organizations, highlighting the tension between the use of human editors and algorithms in content curation.

site_title: Fine art of green fingers
summary: Landscape designer James Basson, founder of Scape Design, will participate in the Singapore Garden Festival (SGF) for the second time, showcasing a Mediterranean garden with locally sourced plants and minimal maintenance. Basson, a strong advocate of dry gardening, aims to create a garden that fits into its natural surroundings, using materials such as plastic rocks and European oak. He has won several awards, including a gold medal for his fantasy garden "Tartarus" in 2014, and will bring plants from the south of France, which are adjusting to the local climate, to minimize maintenance.

images.alt_text: Tay Suan Chiang

site_title: S'pore agri trader buys Canadian processing plant
summary: Agrocorp International, a Singaporean agri-commodity trading company, is buying Veikle Grain, a grain handling plant in Cut Knife, Saskatchewan, Canada for S$10 million. The plant processes specialty crops, mainly pulses, for the Chinese and South Asian market. This acquisition expands Agrocorp's presence in Canada and further diversifies its revenue streams.

site_title: Call for proposals on grid-scale energy storage
summary: Singapore is testing-bedding a utility-scale energy storage system to integrate renewable energy sources and enhance grid resilience. The Energy Market Authority and Singapore Power issued a request for proposal for a test-bed system with a capacity of 6 megawatts, to be deployed at three substations using various energy storage technologies. The goal is to assess performance in managing intermittent power from renewables and peak shaving, with the potential to lower costs, enhance reliability, and contribute to a sustainable future. The collaboration is one of the world's first to consider hot and humid conditions in Singapore.

site_title: Wheels of fortune
summary: The Toyota Fortuner, a seven-seat SUV, has been revamped with a new level of luxury. Introduced 11 years after its first generation, the second-generation model is sold out until next year, a rare feat for a vehicle with its price point. The new Fortuner features a sleeker design, improved suspension, and a more refined interior with luxury features such as black dashboard, tan leather upholstery, and electric seats. The vehicle's 2.7-liter petrol engine is paired with a six-speed automatic transmission, and it boasts a spacious interior, safe features, and a commanding driving position.

site_title: Be prepared for lower returns on your investments for retirement
summary: Investors may face lower returns on their retirement investments due to a slowing global economy, declining corporate profits, and low interest rates. The McKinsey Global Institute predicts 4.0-6.5% real returns for US and European equities over the next 20 years, and 0-2.0% real returns for US and European bonds. To mitigate this, investors can construct or re-evaluate their financial plans, invest in low-cost, diversified portfolios, and utilize CPF accounts to earn better yields. Understanding how CPF accounts and the retirement scheme CPF LIFE work can also help investors make the most of their retirement savings.

images.alt_text: MAKING YOUR MONEY WORK HARDER: In a low-interest-rate, low-inflation and low-yield environment, taking the time to understand and thereby maximise the risk-free interest rates from CPF and CPF LIFE should enable you to retire more comfortably than if you did not.

site_title: US: Wall St little changed on strong retail sales data
summary: US stocks remained little changed at the open on Friday, offsetting a drop in oil prices with strong April retail sales data, indicating an economy recovery. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.09%, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite declined 0.12% and 0.14%, respectively. The strong retail sales data suggests an economy recovery is gaining traction, but the US stock market was largely influenced by oil price movements.

site_title: China Everbright Water registers flattish profit in Q1
summary: China Everbright Water reported a 1% year-on-year increase in net profit to HK$106.1 million for Q1 FY2016, driven by a 51% rise in revenue. Construction revenue increased 145% due to ongoing wastewater treatment projects. The company plans to expand organically and through acquisitions, optimize management, and increase technology research and development investment.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Car sales expected to cushion retail sales till year-end
summary: Singapore's retail sales rose 5.1% in March, boosted by a 41.3% increase in car sales. However, excluding motor sales, retail sales declined 2.2% year-on-year. Economists attribute the softening to weak discretionary goods and services sales, which indicate a lack of consumer confidence. With an increase in certificates of entitlements set to be released in the coming months, car sales are expected to continue propelling retail sales numbers. Despite this, overall retail sales remain moribund, with a fourth consecutive month of softening sales.

images.alt_text: Retail sales are still moribund following the latest March data, so hopes are increasingly being pinned on car buyers propping up figures for the rest of the year.

site_title: S'pore and the 'Sterling Raj'
summary: Singapore's diversification of its reserves from sterling, with reserves amounting to S$1,251.6 million, contrary to British estimates of 90% in sterling. The government decided not to devalue its currency, despite a 14.3% devaluation of sterling. Singapore's budget surpluses over the years were consistently underestimated, revealing the extent of the country's reserve diversification. The British government questioned Singapore's loyalty and cooperation as a Sterling Area member, and an exchange of letters between Roy Jenkins and Dr Goh ensued.

site_title: Genting Singapore Q1 gain battered by bad debt, softer gaming revenue
summary: Genting Singapore reported a 83% decline in Q1 net profit to S$10.84 million, largely due to weaker gaming revenue from its Singapore integrated resort and increased impairments on trade receivables. Turnover fell 5% to S$608.01 million, with a 9% drop in Singapore IR gaming revenue. The company attributed the decline to caution in its VIP gaming business and a focus on growing the foreign premium mass market. Construction of Resorts World Jeju in South Korea is progressing well, with a soft opening planned for the fourth quarter of 2017.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Thai Beverage posted a 30% year-on-year rise in net profit to 8.56 billion baht for the first quarter, driven by higher profits from spirits, beer, and food businesses. Revenue increased 21% to 55.18 billion baht, primarily due to sales revenue growth in these businesses. United Engineers has entered into share purchase agreements to divest non-core businesses, with book values estimated at around S$8.8 million and S$22.1 million.

site_title: In search of growth, Goldman Sachs turns to debt
summary: Goldman Sachs is hosting its first leveraged finance conference to strengthen its position in debt underwriting and seek new growth opportunities. The event aims to convince clients to use Goldman for debt financing over competitors like JPMorgan Chase. As strict regulations and market volatility pressure its bond trading unit, Goldman is exploring other sources of profit in leveraged finance, advising private equity firms on deals and financing smaller transactions. Despite increasing revenue in debt underwriting, analysts question whether Goldman can compete with larger banks for large clients.

site_title: Luxury home sales fall in London, NY
summary: Luxury home sales globally rose 8% last year, slowing from a 16% jump in 2014, according to a Christie's International Real Estate survey. In contrast, sales declined in Manhattan, Hong Kong, and central London, while increasing in Auckland (63%), Toronto (48%), Paris (21%), and Jackson Hole (45%). Economic unrest, soaring prices, and exchange-rate shifts have damaged buyers' appetite for gateway cities, but investors see opportunities in cheaper locations with room for growth.

site_title: US business inventories post largest gain in nine months
summary: US business inventories rose 0.4% in March, the largest gain in nine months, following a 0.1% dip in February. Automobile stocks surged 2.3%, the biggest increase since 2013, suggesting a possible revision to the first-quarter's weak economic growth estimate. The inventory-to-sales ratio for motor vehicles reached 2.30 in March, the highest since 2009. This increase indicates a potential boost to economic growth, which may be revised upward in the coming weeks.

site_title: Perennial's Q1 profit buoyed by fair value gain
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings reported a net profit of S$8.47 million in the first quarter, a 148% increase from the same period last year, driven by a fair value gain from the revaluation of its Chengdu East High Speed Railway Integrated Development Plot D2. Group revenue rose 9% to S$29.49 million, with key contributors including CHIJMES and TripleOne Somerset in Singapore, and Perennial Qingyang Mall in China. The company has received approvals for asset enhancement works and strata-sale at TripleOne Somerset and AXA Tower, with a total cost not expected to exceed S$150 million.

site_title: France, Germany urge tighter trade defence in face of China steel
summary: France and Germany urged EU members to tighten trade defenses to protect against cheap Chinese steel imports, citing Tata Steel's decision to sell its British operations. The European Commission proposed an overhaul of the EU's trade defense system in 2013 but failed to secure approval. France and Germany proposed speeding up investigations, allowing duties to be imposed after 7 months, and increasing the ability to apply tariffs retrospectively. The EU is set to decide by December whether to grant China "market economy status," which could make it harder to impose anti-dumping duties.

site_title: India's trade deficit narrows for fourth straight month in April
summary: India's trade deficit narrowed for the fourth consecutive month in April, reaching US$4.84 billion, as plummeting imports (down 23.10%) offset a 6.74% decline in exports to US$20.57 billion. Imports of oil and gold declined significantly. This marks the fourth straight month of narrowing trade deficit.

site_title: Heng Swee Keat in stable condition but will remain in ICU 'for some time': PM Lee
summary: Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat remains in stable condition but will remain in ICU "for some time" after suffering a stroke caused by an aneurysm. Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong confirmed this in a Facebook post, stating that Heng is receiving good care at the National Neuroscience Institute. Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam will cover Heng's duties until his recovery.

site_title: Humble tofu powering Indonesian homes with clean energy
summary: In Indonesia's tofu-producing region, three men are now churning out not only traditional tofu but also clean energy. They have developed a system to harness the methane produced by the tofu-making process, which is then piped into homes, providing a cheap and renewable source of energy. This innovative approach has the potential to power homes across the island, offering a sustainable solution for the community. The production of clean energy from tofu is a unique example of repurposing waste into a valuable resource.

images.alt_text: TOFU MAKERS GO GREEN: A woman frying tofu. Around 150 small tofu businesses in Kalisari village are benefiting from a pioneering green scheme that converts wastewater from their production floors into a clean-burning biogas.

site_title: Men's essentials
summary: Biotherm Homme, a premium skincare brand, has partnered with David Beckham to develop a men's grooming line. The partnership, announced earlier this week, aims to create a men's skincare range that aligns with Beckham's ambitions. The retired footballer expressed his excitement about collaborating with Biotherm, stating that the brand shares his ambition and is looking forward to showcasing their joint efforts soon.

site_title: Consumer sentiment in US jumps to highest level in a year
summary: US consumer confidence surged to a 12-month high in May, reaching 95.8, driven by the strongest views on inflation-adjusted income gains in a decade. This marked the highest level since June 2021. Lower-income and younger households led the advance in expectations, with all Americans projecting real incomes would rise by the most in 10 years. The improvement in consumer sentiment is seen as a welcome sign of an impending shift towards spending and away from savings, potentially helping the economy recover from a first-quarter slowdown.

site_title: KrisEnergy explores recapitalisation options
summary: KrisEnergy, a Singapore-based oil-and-gas exploration firm, is exploring recapitalization options due to a US$18.3 million loss in the first quarter, citing the deepest oil downturn in three decades. Revenue rose to US$33.1 million, but the average realized price for oil and liquids fell 60.8% to US$20.85. The company must raise at least US$150 million by June 30 to meet its debt obligations. KrisEnergy's shares fell 5.8% to close at 16.3 Singapore cents on Friday.

site_title: Football: Fifa picks Fatma Samoura as first female secretary general
summary: Fifa has named Senegalese diplomat Fatma Samoura as its first female secretary general, a historic appointment that marks a significant step towards diversity and gender equality. Samoura, 54, brings 21 years of experience from the United Nations, and will take the post by mid-June after undergoing an eligibility check. Fifa president Gianni Infantino described her as a "great person" with experience managing big organizations, and praised her fresh perspective, saying she will "bring a fresh wind" to the organization.

site_title: US's Lew: G7 needs to reinforce pledges against currency devaluations
summary: US Treasury Secretary Jacob Lew emphasized the need for the Group of Seven economies to reinforce their pledge to avoid competitive currency devaluations, warning it could lead to a chain reaction. Lew also defended the dollar's current strength, attributing it to the US economy's growth, and urged other economies to strengthen to equilibrate exchange rates. He also stressed the need for debt relief for Greece, particularly as debt repayment deadlines approach, and urged caution in negotiations, especially during the Brexit vote.

site_title: OKH Global posts S$2.97m profit for Q3
summary: OKH Global posted a net profit of S$2.97 million for the third quarter, reversing a S$1.63 million net loss from the same period last year. Group revenue more than tripled to S$82.4 million, driven by a commercial property achieving a temporary occupation permit. Construction services revenue plummeted to S$9,000, while property investment revenue rose 25.2%. The firm's shares closed 0.4 cents lower.

site_title: Latest Earnings
summary: NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer was oversubscribed 9.8 times. Creative Technology warned of potential H2 revenue below target and similar operating loss as H1. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10b upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a graft case involving 285 trillion rupiah. Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran, is set to become OCBC's incoming CEO. MAS and PBOC are expanding cooperation on green and transition finance. Singapore stocks experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data release.

site_title: Fantastico Lusso
summary: Ferrari unveiled the GTC4Lusso at its Japan premiere, marking a significant redesign of its four-seater, shooting brake coupe. The new model, named after classic Ferrari beauties, boasts over 90% new components, including the latest V12 engine. The Ferrari GTC4Lusso is a luxurious and powerful replacement for the FF model, reflecting the Italian sports car manufacturer's evolution.

site_title: General Motors' Opel unit in hot seat over emissions
summary: Opel, a subsidiary of General Motors, is under scrutiny from Germany's transport ministry over allegations of irregularities in emissions values of its diesel models. Tests revealed "hitherto unknown devices" that deactivate filtration systems in the Astra and Zafira models, causing emissions to exceed norms. The ministry demands explanations for the reports, which were published by Der Spiegel and Monitor on ARD public television. This raises concerns about the environmental impact and potential regulatory consequences for Opel and General Motors.

site_title: India announces new trademark, patent policy amid global pressure
summary: India has announced a new intellectual property policy aimed at speeding up the online registration of patents and trademarks, resisting pressure from the US and other Western countries to amend its patent laws. The policy will regulate intellectual property rights through the Department of Industrial Promotion and Policy, with the goal of promoting innovation and effective enforcement mechanisms. Despite being on the US "Priority Watch List" for inadequate IPR protection, India remains committed to the Trade-Related Aspects of Intellectual Property Rights (TRIPS) agreement and will retain its right to issue compulsory licenses under "emergency" conditions.

site_title: Perennial Real Estate's Q1 profit surges 150% on fair-value gain
summary: Perennial Real Estate Holdings reported a 150% surge in Q1 net profit to S$8.47 million, driven by a fair-value gain of S$7.5 million from revaluing a property in Chengdu, China. Group revenue rose 9% to S$29.49 million. The company's developments, including TripleOne Somerset in Singapore, are on track for asset enhancement works and strata-sale, with costs not expected to exceed S$150 million. Construction works are progressing steadily in China.

site_title: Hong Leong Asia racks up loss in Q1
summary: Hong Leong Asia reported a net loss of S$16.48 million in the first quarter of 2016, down from a profit of S$4.69 million a year ago. Revenue declined 12.6% to S$948.52 million due to lower revenue from most business units, except air-conditioning systems. The company expects weak performance from its China-based business units in the second quarter, citing a challenging business environment and uncertain economy. Loss per share was 4.41 Singapore cents, compared to earnings per share of 1.25 Singapore cents in the same period last year.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: US producer prices rise modestly in April
summary: US producer prices rose 0.2% in April, driven by a 0.2% increase in energy prices, while services edged up 0.1%. The core PPI, excluding food, energy, and trade services, rose 0.3% last month. The moderate inflation increase is attributed to the lingering effects of the dollar's surge and oil price plunge. Despite this, inflation remains restrained, and economists expect a moderate increase in inflation in the coming months.

site_title: Branching out
summary: Singapore's homegrown F&B groups are expanding beyond their home turf, with several making waves in the region. The Les Amis Group recently opened restaurants in the Philippines and Indonesia, while the Timbre Group launched a new concept in Kuala Lumpur. Australian chef Frederic Colin's first overseas outpost, Bistrot Gavroche, opened in Sydney, offering no-frills classical French cuisine. Other F&B groups, such as Zest, Joe & Dough, and Series of Intentions, are also planning to expand abroad, with some already having successful ventures in Southeast Asia. These expansions aim to capitalize on the "fast casual" trend and create a total of 300 global outlets by 2020.

site_title: Modern art
summary: Nagai Sake, a Japanese brewery, combines art and technology to create unique sake varieties, including sparkling, vintage, and dessert sakes. Founded by Noriyoshi Nagai, the sixth-generation owner, the brewery produces three premium sake brands: Tanigawadake, Mizubasho, and Nagai Style. Nagai Sake uses traditional techniques, such as temperature control and the five senses, to create distinctive sakes, including a sparkling sake made using the traditional method champenoise. The brewery's focus on matching sake and food aims to enhance the drinking experience.

images.alt_text: COMBINING WINE- AND SAKE-MAKING: After a decade of experimentation with wine maturation techniques, Mr Nagai realised that temperature makes a difference to the taste of sake.
TOP-TIER RICE WINE, PRISTINE WATER: Dinner was served over an irori or sunken hearth in Nagai Sake's restaurant, which is designed by Mr Nagai, a trained architect.
TOP-TIER RICE WINE, PRISTINE WATER: Mr Nagai at a water pipe outside Nagai Sake brewery. The water is soft and mildly sweet and is used to wash and brew the rice.

site_title: United Engineers to divest stake in UES Holdings
summary: United Engineers (UE) has agreed to sell 62 million shares in UES Holdings (UESH) to Giant Maze for S$16 million, subject to UESH's business restructuring. UE also divested interests in UE Envirotech, UE Asia Pacific (Beijing) Co, and Hengyang City Songmu Water Co for S$30 million. The book values of the shares being sold will be around S$8.8 million and S$22.1 million, respectively.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Football: Fifa set to name first woman as secretary general
summary: FIFA is set to name its first female secretary general, a non-European woman, for the first time in the organization's history. The announcement is expected to be made during a congress in Mexico City. Gianni Infantino, the new FIFA president, indicated that the appointment would be made in summer, but the timing may be accelerated. The move comes after the sacking of former secretary general Jerome Valcke, who was banned from football for 12 years due to misconduct. Germany's Markus Kattner has been serving as interim secretary general since January.

site_title: Wheelock Properties' Q1 earnings fall 9.1% to S$11.1m (Amended)
summary: Wheelock Properties reported a 9.1% decrease in Q1 earnings to S$11.1 million, primarily due to lower unit sales and rental income. Revenue fell 7.5% to S$91.8 million. The company has sold 96% of The Panorama units and is targeting completion of its Ang Mo Kio project by 2017. Ongoing marketing efforts and contributions from rental income from Wheelock Place and Scotts Square Retail are expected to support the group's recurring income.

site_title: Oil falls as dollar strengthens but traders eye Nigerian outages
summary: Oil prices fell on Friday, ending a three-day bull run, due to a strong US dollar weighing on greenback-denominated commodities. The dollar hit a two-week high, lifting expectations of another US Federal Reserve rate hike. Oil production in Nigeria, the lowest in 22 years, cushioned losses after a pipeline outage reduced output to 1.65 million barrels per day. The US West Texas Intermediate crude futures traded down 61 cents, while global benchmark Brent crude futures fell 45 cents to $47.63 a barrel.

site_title: Thai Beverage reports 30 per cent jump in Q1 profit
summary: Thai Beverage Public Co reported a 30% year-on-year increase in net profit to 8.56 billion baht (S$332.73 million) for Q1 2016, driven by higher profits from its spirits, beer, food, and non-alcoholic beverages businesses. Revenue rose 21% to 55.18 billion baht, with earnings per share increasing to 0.34 baht from 0.26 baht last year.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: For Apple, US$1b is small price for firmer China foothold
summary: Apple has invested $1 billion in China's largest ride-hailing service, Didi, to accelerate growth in the world's most populous country and earn goodwill with Beijing. The deal, announced in 22 days, aims to help Apple secure a firmer foothold in the Chinese market, where the company is struggling with a slump in smartphone sales. The partnership also represents Apple's first public investment in the auto industry, and analysts see it as a strategic move to stay in China's good graces and potentially pave the way for an Apple-branded car.

site_title: Opec says oil glut 'may ease' by 2017 as non-cartel supply drops
summary: Opec reported that the global crude glut may ease by 2017 due to a 740,000 barrel-per-day drop in non-Opec supply. Non-Opec countries are expected to lower their crude supply, mainly driven by lower expectations for Chinese oil production. The forecast aligns with the International Energy Agency's prediction of a shrinking worldwide oversupply. Despite a more positive outlook, Opec warned that the oversupply remains and global oil inventories are at record highs, with prices still below $100 a barrel.

site_title: Euro-area growth revised down slightly despite Germany
summary: The euro-area economy grew 0.5% in the first quarter, slightly less than the initial estimate of 0.6%. Germany, the region's largest economy, drove the growth, surpassing forecasts. This marks the fastest momentum in a year, indicating a strong start to the year despite the downward revision. Despite this, the growth rate remains a positive sign for the euro region.

site_title: Singapore has first imported case of Zika virus
summary: Singapore has reported its first imported case of the Zika virus, a 48-year-old male permanent resident who recently traveled to Brazil. The patient was admitted to a hospital, isolated, and tested positive for the virus. The Ministry of Health and National Environment Agency are screening the patient's household members and alerting residents in the affected area to seek medical attention if they develop symptoms. Residents are also urged to cooperate with vector control operations to prevent mosquito breeding and to monitor their health for 14 days after returning from affected areas.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Jumbo posts 49.4% rise in Q2 profit
summary: Jumbo Group reported a 49.4% year-on-year increase in Q2 profit to S$5.83 million, driven by cooperative ventures and a fully-owned subsidiary. Revenue rose 18.5% to S$39.63 million, while earnings per share increased to 0.9 Singapore cents. For the six months, net profit rose 42% to S$7.91 million. CEO Ang Kiam Meng attributed the growth to leveraging competitive strengths despite a challenging macro environment, with the China operations showing promising potential.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Seoul: Won, stocks close down on BOK's policy decision
summary: The South Korean won closed down 0.8% at 1,171.4 to the US dollar following the Bank of Korea's decision to hold interest rates for May. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) also fell 0.5% at 1,966.99 points due to foreign investors selling KOSPI shares worth 141.4 billion won. The market is bracing for a potential interest rate cut in June, increasing uncertainty about the won's future movement.

site_title: IMF says Brexit would lead to cycle of weak growth, hit house and share prices
summary: The International Monetary Fund warns that a Brexit would lead to a cycle of weaker economic growth, lower house prices, and financial market volatility. The IMF predicts a protracted period of uncertainty, exacerbating Britain's current account deficit and potentially causing a self-reinforcing cycle of economic contraction and depressed asset prices. The Fund estimates it could take years for Britain to renegotiate trade deals, hitting investment and economic sentiment.

images.alt_text: The International Monetary Fund said Britain risks falling into a self-reinforcing cycle of weaker economic growth and lower house and share prices if voters opt to leave the European Union next month.

site_title: Genting Singapore's Q1 earnings plunge 83% to S$10.8m
summary: Genting Singapore's Q1 earnings plummeted 83% to S$10.84 million due to weaker gaming revenue from its Singapore integrated resort and a drop in other operating income. Turnover fell 5% year-over-year to S$608.01 million. The company cited caution with its VIP gaming business and a strong performance in its mass gaming market segment. Earnings per share dropped to 0.09 Singapore cent, and shares ended at S$0.785, down 1.5 Singapore cents.

site_title: Straits Trading chalks up big jump in Q1 FY2016 bottom line
summary: Straits Trading Company reported a significant jump in net profit for Q1 FY2016, reaching S$22.56 million, up from S$2.44 million the previous year. Lower expenses and higher share of associates' results contributed to the increase. Revenue slipped 3.5% year-over-year to S$140.53 million, while earnings per share rose to 5.5 Singapore cents. Executive chairman Chew Gek Khim attributed the progress to transformative initiatives, promising to continue building sustainable value for shareholders.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Golden Agri makes restated Q1 profit but accounting change wipes out US$5b equity
summary: Indonesian palm oil producer Golden Agri-Resources reported a net profit of $94 million in Q1, excluding currency movements and accounting changes. However, an accounting change wiped out $5 billion in equity. Revenue fell 4% to $1.49 billion, while Ebitda fell 24% to $76 million. The company's downstream segment saw a 179% increase in Ebitda, driven by higher margins. Foreign-exchange gains and a net tax credit also boosted the bottom line.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end lower
summary: Malaysia's stocks ended lower on Friday, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index dropping 20.72 points to close at 1,628.26. The index saw a significant decline despite 1.83 billion lots valued at RM2.81 billion being traded.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: The Association of Banks in Singapore (ABS) has raised the standards for due diligence guidelines for companies seeking to list on the Singapore Exchange (SGX). This move aims to improve transparency and accountability. Meanwhile, Vietnam expressed surprise over the US Trump administration's tariff announcement and is seeking a lower rate. The Asian garment industry is bracing for higher US tariffs, while Malaysia is set to seize RM3 billion of assets from Daim Zainuddin. China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers, and the UK economy has shrunk for the second consecutive month.

site_title: Q&M Dental's Q1 profit rises 28% to S$3.7m
summary: Q&M Dental Group reported a 28% increase in Q1 net profit to S$3.7 million, driven by a 28% rise in revenue from its dental and medical clinics. The increase was partly offset by higher expenses. Earnings per share for Q1 2016 reached 0.47 Singapore cents, with revenue growth attributed to existing and new dental outlets in Singapore, as well as acquisitions.

site_title: US April retail sales post largest gain in a year
summary: US retail sales in April posted the largest gain in a year, rising 1.3% as Americans stepped up purchases of automobiles and other goods, suggesting the economy is regaining momentum. This is the largest gain since March 2015, exceeding economists' forecasts of a 0.8% increase. Core retail sales, excluding automobiles, gasoline, and food services, also rose 0.9% after an upwardly revised 0.2% gain in March. The increase is a welcome reprieve for the retail sector, which has struggled with tepid demand, and suggests economic growth is picking up after a 0.5% annualized rate in the first quarter.

site_title: Swiber deeper into the red with US$2.56m Q1 loss
summary: Swiber Holdings, an offshore engineering services provider, reported a net loss of US$2.56 million in its first quarter, a 2.4% increase from the previous year's loss of US$2.5 million. Revenue rose 16% to US$191.34 million, driven by new contracts secured despite depressed market conditions.

images.alt_text: Higher tax expenses dragged offshore engineering services provider Swiber Holdings deeper into the red in its first quarter.

site_title: Shanghai-Hong Kong stock link draws more institutions
summary: Global institutional investors are increasingly participating in the Shanghai-Hong Kong Stock Connect, driven by improved trading and settlement services. The scheme, launched in 2014, had faced criticism for being used by retail investors and hedge funds, but recent reforms have addressed settlement issues. As a result, European funds and other institutions are now actively engaging with the platform, which is expected to accelerate reforms and the rollout of a Shenzhen link. This increased institutional participation bodes well for China's stock markets, which are facing low turnover.

site_title: Midas's Q1 bottom line hit by higher income-tax expense
summary: MIDAS Holdings reported an 8.6% year-on-year drop in net profit for Q1 2016 to 9.99 million yuan, driven by a higher income-tax expense. Revenue decreased 5.3% to 303.52 million yuan, with the aluminium alloy extruded products division reporting lower revenue. Earnings per share fell to 0.8 RMB fen from 0.9 RMB fen.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai end week down
summary: Hong Kong and Shanghai shares closed lower on Friday, extending losses from the previous day. The Hang Seng Index fell 0.99% to 19,719.29, while the Shanghai Composite Index dropped 0.31% to 2,827.11. The week's losses were attributed to traders' anticipation of Chinese economic data release over the weekend.

site_title: Singapore shares close lower on Friday, flat for the week
summary: Singapore shares declined 10.48 points to 2,734.91 on Friday, despite a four-point gain for the week, as oil prices rebounded above US$40 per barrel. The Straits Times Index (STI) definition of deflation, where declining prices lead to a vicious spiral of negatives, seems to be unfolding in the local stock market, with a meagre trading volume of 982 million units worth S$1.04 billion. Banks, particularly those exposed to the oil sector, have been hit hard, with concerns over asset quality and earnings impacting their weight in the STI.

site_title: Tat Hong expects losses for Q4 and FY2016
summary: Tat Hong Holdings expects losses for its Q4 and FY2016 due to costs from exiting an Indonesian business, foreign-exchange losses, and non-cash impairment charges. The group reported a net loss of S$6.7 million in its third quarter. Tat Hong has been struggling with oversupply in the cranes market and is considering a potential takeover offer. The company's shares closed 0.5 Singapore cents lower at 51 Singapore cents on the day of the announcement. Financial statements for FY2016 will be released on or around May 27.

site_title: Tokyo 2020 payments were 'legitimate': Japan Olympic chief
summary: Japan's Olympic chief, Tsunekazu Takeda, denied allegations of corruption in the country's 2020 Games bid, stating that payments reported by British media were "legitimate consultant's fees" for professional services. The payments, totaling 2.8 million Singapore dollars, are being probed by French investigators, but Japanese officials say they have no cause for suspicion. The government will question officials involved in the bid to confirm facts, but remains confident that no wrongdoing occurred.

site_title: Soon you won't have to be rich to back a startup
summary: New crowdfunding rules taking effect Monday in the US will allow anyone to invest in startups, regardless of their wealth or income, as long as founders submit annual financial reports to the SEC. The change overrides the current requirement that investors must be "accredited," meaning they make at least $200,000 a year and have a net worth of $1 million or more. Startups can now raise up to $1 million through online crowdfunding portals, providing more opportunities for people to invest in startups without needing to be wealthy.

site_title: European stocks drop at open
summary: European stock markets declined at the start of trading on Friday, with London's FTSE 100 index falling 0.6% to 6,069.68 points, and the eurozone's Frankfurt DAX 30 index dropping 0.7% to 9,794.83 points. This marked a downbeat end to the week, following a 0.4% gain for Singapore's STI on Thursday.

site_title: China April new loans down sharply, money growth also below forecast
summary: China's banks significantly reduced new loans in April, extending 555.6 billion yuan, below market expectations and less than half the March amount. The central bank reported a 12.8% year-over-year growth in M2 money supply, lower than forecast. Outstanding yuan loans grew 14.4% annually. The move is seen as a cautious response to the cooling economy, with analysts warning of a financial crisis if debt risks are not curbed. China's government is trying to arrest a prolonged slowdown, with outstanding total social financing up 13.1% year-on-year.

site_title: Singapore April exports seen shrinking for 2nd month on slow global growth
summary: Singapore's exports are expected to have shrunk for a second month in April, with non-oil domestic exports forecast to decline 7.9% from a year earlier, according to a Reuters survey of 12 economists. Overseas sales tumbled 15.6% in March, mainly due to shipments to China, the US, and Europe. Despite a 4.0% month-on-month increase in non-oil domestic exports, analysts say this is not a sustainable stabilisation. Local factories' activity contracted for a 10th consecutive month in April, with a manufacturing index reaching its highest level since June.

site_title: Singapore retailers see 5.1% y-o-y increase in March sales (Amended)
summary: Singapore's retail sales in March increased 5.1% year-over-year, beating a consensus estimate of 3.6%. Motor vehicle sales rose 41.3% and non-discretionary items such as medical goods and toiletries also saw significant increases. However, excluding car sales, retail sales fell 2.2% year-over-year. The sale of food and beverages was the strongest increase at 13.3%, while optical goods and books saw the steepest fall at 8.4%.

site_title: German unions, employers agree 4.8% wage hike for metalworking sector
summary: German unions and employers agreed on a 4.8% pay hike for the metalworking sector, affecting 3.8 million workers. The one-off payment of 150 euros will be followed by 2.8% and 2% pay rises in July and April 2017, respectively. This pilot agreement for North Rhine-Westphalia will serve as a benchmark for the rest of the country.

site_title: Atlantic Navigation bags US$236m vessel charters
summary: Atlantic Navigation Holdings secured long-term charters worth US$236 million for 10 offshore supply vessels, including five newbuilds. The charters, for a Middle Eastern national oil company, will commence in 2016 and 2017, supporting operations in the Arabian Gulf. The deal is expected to positively impact the company's net tangible asset and earnings per share for the 2016 financial year, following a net loss of US$1.06 million in Q1 FY2016.

site_title: Honda full-year profit tumbles on airbag scandal
summary: Honda's full-year profit dropped 32.4% to 344.5 billion yen due to the exploding airbag crisis at key supplier Takata, leading to a global recall of tens of millions of inflators. The crisis resulted in 13 deaths and 29 million recalled airbags in the US. Honda attributed the decline to "quality-related costs" linked to the airbag crisis, with operating profit dropping 24.9% and annual sales rising 9.6%. Despite this, Honda expects a 13.2% increase in net profit for the current fiscal year.

images.alt_text: Honda Motor said Friday its full-year net profit dropped by a third, pressured by the exploding airbag crisis at key supplier Takata that has led to a worldwide recall.

site_title: Investors dump stocks at fastest rate since Aug 2011: BAML
summary: Investors have dumped stocks at the fastest rate since August 2011, with global equity funds posting a net outflow of $7.4 billion over the past five weeks. The European equity funds saw the largest outflow in 14 weeks, and emerging market equity funds experienced their largest outflow in four months. In contrast, fixed income funds drew in $3.5 billion, while money market funds and precious metals attracted significant inflows. The 'risk off' sentiment is attributed to uneven economic growth and policymakers' inability to support activity.

site_title: German economy grows at fastest in two years on domestic demand
summary: Germany's economy grew at its fastest pace in two years, expanding 0.7% in the first quarter of 2016, driven by domestic spending. This beats economists' estimates and marks a cyclical recovery in the euro area. Record-low unemployment has supported consumer demand, while European Central Bank stimulus has contributed to the growth. The economy expanded 1.6% from a year ago.

site_title: China says hopes US, Vietnam ties benefit regional peace
summary: China expressed hope that the US lifting its 30-year-old arms embargo on Vietnam will benefit regional peace, following the US administration's consideration of the move. China's Foreign Ministry spokesman, Lu Kang, stated that Beijing is "happy to see Vietnam develop normal relations with the relevant country" and that this relationship can contribute to regional stability. The arms embargo, which was eased in 2014, is seen as a major step forward in ties between the two countries, which have improved since the normalization of relations 21 years ago.

site_title: SPH launches new print technology
summary: SPH launches SPH Variable Print, a new print technology in South-east Asia, allowing for multiple messages in the same edition on the same day. Carlsberg partners The New Paper to engage readers before the Uefa Euro 2016 tournament. The technology is expected to attract more advertisers, maximizing its potential.

site_title: UK construction output slides in Q1, March worse than forecast
summary: The UK construction sector declined 1.1% in Q1, with a 3.6% drop in March, the worst month-on-month figure since December 2012. Housebuilding was the only sector to show growth, while infrastructure was the biggest drag. The decline is attributed to uncertainty surrounding the EU referendum and global weakness. Construction output fell 4.5% compared to Q1 2015, with economists expecting a 2.7% decline. The sector's reliance on the services sector to drive economic growth is highlighted, with the services sector showing a 0.4% slowdown in Q1.

images.alt_text: British construction sector declined sharply in the first quarter, adding to signs the economy struggled against global weakness and uncertainty about June's European Union referendum, data showed Friday.

site_title: Ringgit drops for third week before GDP, current-account reports
summary: Malaysia's ringgit is poised for its third consecutive weekly loss before reports on the country's economic growth and current-account surplus. The currency has dropped 0.8% this week, reaching 4.0360 per dollar, amid concerns over slowing global growth and domestic economic moderation. The current-account surplus narrowed to 6.8 billion ringgit in the first quarter, and GDP growth slowed to 4% from 4.5%. The ringgit's decline is attributed to speculation on reduced demand for exports and concerns over 1Malaysia Development Bhd's debt repayments.

site_title: Asia: Stocks slide, Apple suppliers track losses in tech giant
summary: Asia stocks declined on Friday, following losses in New York and Europe, with Apple suppliers experiencing significant losses. Oil prices retreated after the International Energy Agency predicted a global supply glut would ease in the second half of 2016. Nissan's stock soared almost five percent after announcing a $2.2 billion stake in scandal-hit Mitsubishi.

site_title: Mundipharma sets up Betadine consumer health hub in Singapore (Amended)
summary: Mundipharma has announced plans to set up a new Betadine consumer health hub in Singapore, combining research and development, manufacturing, and distribution. The 7,300 square foot facility, expected to be operational by January 2018, will be the group's first consumer and over-the-counter facility in emerging markets and the largest for Betadine. The hub will be located in Tuas and will support the company's expansion in the region.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei ends 4-day winning streak but secures gains for week
summary: Japanese stocks fell 1.4% on Friday, ending a four-day winning streak, due to profit-taking and concerns over a stronger yen's impact on corporate profits. The Nikkei share average closed at 16,412.21, up 1.9% for the week. Rakuten Inc shares plummeted 5.4% after reporting a 17.3% year-on-year drop in net profit for the January-March quarter.

site_title: World's oldest person dies in New York City, aged 116
summary: Susannah Mushatt Jones, the world's oldest living person at 116 years old, died in New York City, surpassing Emma Morano-Martinuzzi as the oldest verified person. Born in Alabama in 1899, Jones lived a life of modest means, working as a housekeeper and childcare provider, and attributing her longevity to lots of sleep and a healthy lifestyle. Jones' death makes her the oldest person to have lived, surpassing Jeanne Calment of France, who died at 122 years and 164 days in 1997.

site_title: Japan to investigate Olympic payment claim
summary: Japan plans to investigate officials involved in the 2020 Tokyo Olympics bid after French prosecutors launched a probe into an alleged illicit payment of $2 million to a son of Lamine Diack, a disgraced former world athletics supremo. The payment was allegedly made to win support for Tokyo's bid. Japanese officials, including Sports Minister Toshiaki Endo, are confident that no wrongdoing occurred, but the government will speak to officials from the Tokyo metropolitan government and the Japanese Olympic Committee to confirm facts.

site_title: Oil prices take breather but uptrend likely to continue
summary: Oil prices fell in Asia on Friday, taking a breather from a recent price rally, as investors awaited the International Energy Agency's forecast on crude oversupply. The IEA reported that demand is expected to grow at a "solid" rate this year, boosted by India's needs, and that the oil surplus will shrink dramatically later in the year. Analysts believe the uptrend is likely to continue, with a rebalancing of supply and demand expected sooner rather than later.

site_title: China: Stocks fall for 4th straight week amid economic worries
summary: China's stocks fell for the fourth consecutive week, closing at their lowest level in two months, amid concerns that economic growth may be slowing. The Shanghai Composite Index dropped 0.3% to 2,827.11 points, and the CSI300 index fell 0.5%. Investor confidence waned after a People's Daily article described China's economic trend as "L-shaped," implying little growth momentum. The article also suggested Beijing will be cautious with monetary policies, supporting data showing China's fiscal expenditures rose only 4.5% in April. Main sectors, including consumer and transportation shares, led the decline.

site_title: Hapag-Lloyd, five Asian shipping lines said to form new alliance
summary: Hapag-Lloyd AG, Germany's top container shipping line, and five Asian carriers, including Kawasaki Kisen Kaisha Ltd, Mitsui OSK Lines Ltd, Nippon Yusen KK, Hanjin Shipping Co, and Yang Ming Marine Transport Corp, are forming a new alliance. The move comes amid a glut in capacity, depressed freight rates, and increased competition from market leaders AP Moeller-Maersk A/S and Mediterranean Shipping Co. The alliance is expected to make the announcement on Friday, but industry experts express skepticism about its ability to survive due to the size and strength of its competitors.

site_title: Dutch government looks to float insurer ASR this quarter
summary: The Dutch government plans to float insurer ASR on the stock market with an initial public offering (IPO) before the end of the quarter. ASR, the country's fourth-largest insurer, has a book value of 3.57 billion euros. The state will initially retain a significant portion of shares but plans to sell the rest over time. CEO Jos Baeten expressed optimism about the insurer's future, citing a 25% rise in operating profit and a solvency rating of 185% under Europe's Solvency II regime.

site_title: Malaysia to hold by-elections in test of Najib after Sarawak win
summary: Malaysia will hold by-elections on June 18 to fill two vacant parliamentary seats, following the deaths of two lawmakers in a helicopter crash. The by-elections in Sungai Besar and Kuala Kangsar are seen as a test of Prime Minister Najib Razak's popularity amid funding scandals and financial troubles. Najib's ruling party, Barisan Nasional, secured a bigger majority in the Sarawak state election, but voters on the peninsula may be more critical of his performance. The outcome of the by-elections will be closely watched for signs of support for Najib, who faces economic growth slowdowns and debt-ridden state funds.

site_title: China to boost energy storage 10-fold to cut power waste: industry
summary: China aims to boost its power storage capacity by 10-fold to 14.5 gigawatts by 2020 to reduce power waste from renewable energy projects. The country, the world's second-largest wind and solar power producer, currently has 105 megawatts of storage capacity, representing just 1.7% of total generation capacity in 2015. Industry leaders expect storage technologies, such as pumped storage hydropower and lithium ion batteries, to play a key role in improving the use of renewables. The government has set no target for energy storage, but industry experts call for more government support to make the technology financially viable.

site_title: Humble tofu powering Indonesian homes with clean energy
summary: In Indonesia's Kalisari village, 150 small tofu businesses are harnessing wastewater from their production floors into clean-burning biogas, providing a cheap and renewable energy source for residents. The biogas is piped directly into household stoves, replacing traditional fossil fuels and reducing costs by three times. Experts say this innovative approach holds potential for widespread adoption, with the government aiming to increase renewable energy to 25% of the country's energy mix by 2025.
