site_title: Workers set to push ahead with strike at major Argentina grains port
summary: Workers at Argentina's Rosario grains export hub will proceed with a strike on Friday, demanding higher salaries, including a 45-per-cent increase in the minimum regional wage. The strike, set to begin at midnight, comes after the labor ministry asked workers to call off the action. The strike affects 80% of Argentina's grains exports, with multinational companies like Bunge Ltd and Cargill involved. The dispute is amid soaring inflation in Argentina, with the government targeting an inflation rate of 25% this year. The strike is indefinite, with a union meeting to be held on Friday.

site_title: Singapore Air closely watching developments at Virgin Australia
summary: Singapore Airlines is closely monitoring developments at Virgin Australia, following Air New Zealand's consideration of exiting the airline. Singapore Airlines' CEO Goh Choon Phong stated the airline is watching the situation, without commenting on speculation. Virgin Australia's shares rose 1.8% after the news, valuing the airline at A$989 million. The airline is almost equally owned by Air New Zealand, Etihad Airways, and Singapore Airlines, with Air New Zealand owning 26% of Virgin Australia.

site_title: South Africa's central bank probe blames Abil's collapse on former management
summary: South Africa's central bank probe into the 2014 collapse of African Bank Investments (Abil) has blamed former management for negligently chasing growth and lacking banking experience. The report found that the bank's aggressive lending practices, ignoring risks such as a weak economy and labour unrest, led to the collapse. The probe also found that the bank's business was conducted negligently, but no evidence of intent to defraud depositors. Abil's failure raised questions about levels of disclosure and regulators' monitoring of lending practices, leading to a US$1.6 billion bailout.

site_title: ST Electronics and SUTD launch first joint cybersecurity laboratory
summary: Singapore Technologies (ST) Electronics and the Singapore University of Technology and Design (SUTD) launched a $44.3 million joint cybersecurity laboratory, the first under the Corporate Laboratory@University Scheme, to research and develop new cybersecurity solutions. The laboratory, located at SUTD's Changi campus, aims to address current and future cyber threats. It is supported by the National Research Foundation and is a collaborative effort between the two institutions to advance cybersecurity research and development in Singapore.

site_title: Yen edges up, markets eye Bank of Japan stimulus
summary: The yen strengthened against the US dollar, despite the Bank of Japan's chief Haruhiko Kuroda's pledge to unleash more stimulus measures to boost the economy. Kuroda stated that the central bank doesn't have to wait to implement additional monetary easing, potentially weakening the yen. This comes amid a recent rally in the currency threatening Japan Inc's profits. Markets will closely watch the central bank's next move, as the yen's value is seen as a key indicator of the country's economic health.

images.alt_text: The yen edged higher Friday even as the Bank of Japan's chief repeated a pledge that he was ready to unleash more stimulus measures to boost the sagging economy.

site_title: Australian dollar set for 4th straight week of losses
summary: The Australian dollar dropped to an 11-week trough, reaching a low of US$0.7286, after a slide in commodities and unwinding of long positions. The currency has tumbled more than five US cents since its April peak, setting the stage for a fourth consecutive week of losses. Markets expect another quarter of a percent rate cut by the Reserve Bank of Australia later this year, with the New Zealand dollar also under pressure, dipping to US$0.6800.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Friday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Friday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 5.320 points to 1643.660. Volume was 59.8 million lots worth RM23.7 million, with 91 gainers and 64 losers.

site_title: Gold eyes worst week since March on dollar strength
summary: Gold prices rose on Friday, edging higher after a 1% loss in the prior session, amid a firmer US dollar. The dollar's strength, driven by the Boston Federal Reserve's suggestion of interest rate hikes, made dollar-denominated assets like gold less appealing. This is gold's worst week since March, with a potential for further losses.

site_title: Singapore says helping French with Olympic payment probe
summary: Singapore's anti-corruption agency is assisting French authorities in investigating possible fraud in Japan's Olympic bid. The probe centers on US$2 million paid to Papa Missata Diack, son of a former athletics supremo, which was allegedly linked to Tokyo's 2020 Olympics bid. The Corrupt Practices Investigation Bureau (CPIB) confirmed it is working with the French authorities, but declined to comment further due to ongoing investigation. Japan has also announced it will question Tokyo 2020 Olympic officials.

site_title: ST Engineering's Q1 earnings down 15%, affected by land systems and marine segments
summary: ST Engineering reported a 15.2% drop in net profit to S$110.2 million for Q1 2016, due to lower earnings from its land systems and marine sectors. Revenue rose 7.7% to S$1.63 billion, driven by contributions from the aerospace and electronics sectors. The company attributed the decline to unfavorable product mix and poor performance of shipbuilding from local and US operations.

site_title: Australia, NZ: Australia shares down, NZ steady as focus turns to US data
summary: Australia's S&P/ASX 200 index fell 0.6% on Friday, weighed down by losses in major miners and banks. New Zealand's S&P/NZX 50 index held steady, under a record high set earlier in the week. Caution ahead of US retail sales data kept investors cautious, with analysts expecting an encouraging outcome to reinforce the Federal Reserve's view of a moderate US economy. Global miners BHP Billiton and Rio Tinto declined over 2%, while APN News & Media jumped 12% after a successful capital raising.

site_title: Rupiah drops to six-week low on outlook for slower global growth
summary: Indonesia's rupiah plummeted to a six-week low due to concerns over slowing global growth and a potential US interest-rate increase. The currency fell 0.1% to 13,310 per dollar, with investors cutting their holdings of Indonesian bonds by $313 million this month. Weakening demand for the nation's exports and waning risk appetite led to the decline. The rupiah has declined 0.5% this week, with Indonesian 10-year bonds rising three basis points to 7.80%.

images.alt_text: Indonesia's rupiah fell to a six-week low as concern global growth is slowing and the prospect of a US interest-rate increase damped demand for higher-yielding assets.

site_title: China environment ministry given powers to inspect provinces: paper
summary: China's environment ministry has been given the power to send inspection teams to provinces and regions to root out local polluters. The Ministry of Environmental Protection will become the second national authority to have this power, after the Central Commission for Discipline Inspection. The move aims to strengthen enforcement and address the challenge of pollution, with 14 provinces set to be inspected after the completion of inspections in Hebei province. The ministry has already imposed total fines of 115.7 million yuan and closed or suspended 301 polluting projects.

site_title: Facebook CEO investigates allegations of bias in news choice
summary: Facebook CEO Mark Zuckerberg is investigating allegations of bias in the way the company highlights important news on its social network. The investigation follows a report suggesting that Facebook contractors suppressed stories with conservative viewpoints. Zuckerberg stated that the company found no evidence to support the report, but will take steps to address any issues if the probe uncovers problems. The company released guidelines showing that human input and company rules determine trending news topics, contradicting earlier statements that the system was mostly machine-based.

site_title: China, US should manage South China Sea differences constructively: Chinese general
summary: China and the US should manage their differences over the South China Sea constructively, according to General Fang Fenghui, a Chinese military official. The two nations discussed the issue in a video link-up, with General Fang urging restraint and General Joseph Dunford calling for an effective mechanism to maintain stability in the South China Sea. The tensions arise from China's large-scale land reclamation and the US's increased patrols, with both sides accusing each other of militarizing the disputed waters. The two sides agreed to refrain from actions detrimental to relations and work towards a peaceful solution.

site_title: Chow Tai Fook shares hit month-low as profit to miss estimates
summary: Chow Tai Fook Jewellery Group Ltd reported a 50% decline in full-year profit, citing weak Chinese consumer demand and hedging losses on gold loans. The company's shares fell to a month-low of 3% in Hong Kong trading, with analysts expecting a 36% decrease in net income. The decline is attributed to China's economic slowdown and anti-corruption campaigns, affecting luxury retailers in Hong Kong and Macau. The company's near-term focus is on recovering consumer sentiment in Greater China.

site_title: Tennis: Australia's Tomic snubs Rio Olympics
summary: Australian tennis star Bernard Tomic has announced he will not represent the country at the Rio Olympics due to a busy playing schedule. Tomic cited his personal circumstances and commitment to his tennis career as the reason for his decision, following a warning from the Australian Olympic Committee over his on-court behavior. This move comes after Tomic and fellow Australian Nick Kyrgios faced criticism for their attitude and behavior, with Tomic also withdrawing from a tournament in Mexico to play instead.

site_title: Update: Malaysia's economy grows 4.2% y-o-y in Q1, slowest in 6.5 years
summary: Malaysia's economy expanded 4.2% in Q1, its slowest growth in 6.5 years, due to weak exports and domestic demand. The current account surplus narrowed to 5 billion ringgit in the first three months of the year. The central bank projects growth to improve in the second half driven by higher production in the manufacturing sector. The ringgit has seen some recovery, strengthening 10% in Q1, but remains the worst performing Asian currency in the second quarter.

site_title: Seoul: Won down as BOK seen easing next month; stocks falter
summary: South Korea's won fell 0.4% against the dollar to 1,167.4 as of Friday morning, amid expectations the central bank will cut interest rates next month. The Bank of Korea (BOK) held rates steady for the 11th consecutive month, but analysts believe a rate cut is likely in June due to economic data and hawkish comments from US Federal Reserve officials. South Korean shares also dropped, with the Kospi index falling 0.5% and Samsung Electronics down 2.0%.

site_title: Apple invests US$1b in Chinese ride-hailing service Didi Chuxing
summary: Apple has invested US$1 billion in Chinese ride-hailing service Didi Chuxing, its second-largest market, as part of a strategic move to better understand the Chinese market. The investment gives Apple a sizeable stake in Didi Chuxing, a rival to Uber Technologies Inc in China. Apple CEO Tim Cook sees opportunities for collaboration between the two companies and is focused on the in-car experience with its CarPlay system. Despite slowing economic growth in China, Cook remains confident in the market and believes the investment will deliver a strong return for Apple's invested capital.

site_title: Singapore Air rivals squeeze for passengers amid yield drop
summary: Singapore Airlines is facing a yield drop amid increasing competition from rivals, with yields reaching a six-year low of 10.6 Singapore cents per passenger in the year ended March. The airline's net income dropped to S$804 million, a quarter of Emirates' net income in the same period. To combat this, Singapore Airlines is investing over $10 billion in new aircraft and forming alliances with carriers in Asia and beyond, but its stock price has declined 4.1% following the announcement.

site_title: Chinese tycoons, party officials' data leaked on Twitter
summary: A Twitter account, "shenfenzheng," leaked sensitive information on dozens of Chinese Communist Party officials and business leaders, including ID cards and residential addresses, sparking concerns about China's ability to police information within its borders. The leak, which included information on prominent figures such as Alibaba Group chairman Jack Ma and Xiaomi Corp co-founder Lei Jun, was attributed to the intention of exposing how sensitive information can be easily procured through black-market channels. The incident highlights China's vulnerability to information security breaches despite its strict internet controls.

images.alt_text: Personal information on dozens of Chinese Communist Party officials and captains of industry from Jack Ma to Wang Jianlin may have been exposed on Twitter in one of the country's biggest online leaks of sensitive information.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks rise in opening deals as Nissan soars
summary: Tokyo stocks rose on Friday, driven by a surge in Nissan shares, which jumped over 5% after reporting full-year earnings. The benchmark Nikkei 225 index gained 0.36%, while the Topix index rose 0.25%. Despite a weak lead from Wall Street, the market opened on a positive note.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks hit fresh 3-mth low; Hon Hai jumps
summary: Taiwan's stocks hit a fresh 3-month low, with the main TAIEX index falling 0.4% to 8,072.91. Heavyweights like Taiwan Semiconductor Manufacturing Co. traded lower, while Hon Hai Precision rose 1.4% after announcing a dividend payment. Asian shares also declined, with MSCI's broadest index down 0.3% for a potential weekly loss of 0.4%. The Taiwan dollar softened to T$32.611 per US dollar.

site_title: Duterte has investors spellbound with Philippines metamorphosis
summary: Philippine President Rodrigo Duterte is reinvigorating financial markets with his business-friendly transformation, causing the peso to gain 0.5% this month and become the second-best performer in emerging markets worldwide. The currency's strength is attributed to Duterte's commitment to eliminating corruption in the tax system and his openness to foreign ownership of businesses. The peso's decline before the election was "excessive," and equities are also gaining, with the nation's benchmark stock index being the world's fifth-best performer this month.

site_title: Islamic Development Bank to elect new president next week
summary: The Islamic Development Bank (IDB) will elect a new president next week, replacing long-serving president Ahmad Mohamed Ali, who led the AAA-rated IDB since 1975. Saudi Arabia's former Haj Minister Bandar Hajjar has been nominated for the post, backed by outgoing IDB president. Hajjar's candidacy could be a test for Iran, the IDB's third-largest shareholder, amid tensions with Saudi Arabia. The IDB, with a US$150 billion authorized capital, focuses on economic development projects in 56 member countries, including energy, transportation, and water and sanitation.

site_title: Croesus Retail Trust's Q1 DPU dips on larger unit base after rights issue
summary: Croesus Retail Trust reported a distribution per unit (DPU) of 1.86 Singapore cents for its third quarter, down from 1.9 cents a year ago due to a larger unit base. The decline was caused by a rights issue in November 2015 that added over 114 million new units. Adjusted for the increased unit base, DPU would have risen 19.2%.

site_title: Petrobras earnings slide continues in Brazil
summary: Brazil's state oil company Petrobras reported a Q1 loss of $318 million, extending its streak in the red after its worst year in history. The company cited rising interest payments and falling production and sales. Petrobras is also dealing with a massive fraud scheme involving executives and contractors, and the company is cutting back investments and expenses to get its books back in order. The scandal has contributed to the impeachment of President Dilma Rousseff, who was chair of the Petrobras board during the period under investigation.

site_title: ABS boosts due diligence guidelines for SGX listings
summary: The Association of Banks in Singapore (ABS) has revised its due diligence guidelines for companies seeking to list on the Singapore Exchange (SGX). The updated guidelines now include on-site visits to material production facilities and properties, as well as checks on reasons behind management and director resignations, and restrictions on cash remittances from overseas subsidiaries. The changes aim to enhance the scrutiny of listed companies, particularly those with significant assets and operations. The revised guidelines are expected to increase the standard for due diligence and provide investors with more comprehensive information about listed companies.

site_title: Croesus Retail Trust buys two Japanese malls for 6.1b yen
summary: Croesus Retail Trust (CRT) has acquired two Japanese malls, Mallage Saga and Feeeal Asahikawa, for 6.11 billion yen (S$74.5 million), representing an 8.8% discount to their valuation. The acquisition is funded through equity, bonds, and notes, and is expected to increase CRT's total portfolio value to 106.5 billion yen. This will also lead to a 2.2% increase in the pro forma distribution per unit (DPU) to approximately 7.83 Singapore cents for the FY2015 period.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower on Friday
summary: Singapore shares opened 0.6% lower on Friday, with the Straits Times Index down 16.46 points to 2,728.93. Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam will cover Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat's duties while he recovers from a stroke. The move is expected to provide stability and steady market sentiment. Globally, US stocks ended mixed, while Tokyo stocks rose despite a weak lead from Wall Street.

site_title: South Korea central bank keeps policy rate on hold for 11th mth, as expected
summary: South Korea's central bank, the Bank of Korea, kept interest rates at 1.5% for the 11th consecutive month, as expected. The decision was made to assess the ongoing economic recovery and corporate restructuring in the shipping and shipbuilding sectors. Twenty-four out of 26 analysts polled by Reuters predicted the rate would remain unchanged, following the addition of four new board members. Governor Lee Ju Yeol is scheduled to hold a news conference later.

site_title: Nvidia forecast shows gamers keep spending on expensive gear
summary: Nvidia forecasts sales of $1.35 billion in the second fiscal quarter, beating analysts' estimates, driven by gaming enthusiasts' enthusiasm for the latest technology. The company's gaming-related revenue surged 17% to $687 million, while sales of chips for data centres grew 63% to $143 million. Nvidia expects this growth to continue, with its data centre division potentially becoming the largest end market. The company's net income rose to $196 million, or 33 cents a share, driven by increased spending on high-end gaming gear.

site_title: KrisEnergy slips into US$18.3m Q1 net loss
summary: KrisEnergy reported a net loss of US$18.3 million for Q1 2016, compared to a net profit of US$46.2 million in the same period last year. The loss was mainly due to higher non-cash depreciation and amortization expenses. Revenue increased to US$33.1 million, driven by higher crude oil and gas sales, despite depressed benchmark oil prices. Loss per share was 1.2 US cents, compared to earnings per share of 4.4 US cents last year.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Shares extend losses in early trade
summary: Shares in Hong Kong and Shanghai extended losses on Friday, following weak leads from New York and Europe. The Hang Seng Index in Hong Kong fell 0.36%, while the Shanghai Composite Index eased 0.26%. The Shenzhen Composite Index also declined 0.33%. The losses come after a weak start to the day, with traders brushing off new Trump threats.

site_title: Olam's Q1 net profit triples on lower exceptional charges from bond buybacks
summary: Olam International reported a 300% increase in Q1 net profit to S$113.6 million due to lower exceptional charges from bond buybacks. Revenue rose 10.2% to S$4.76 billion, while operational profit after taxes and minority interests fell 5.5% to S$126.1 million. Earnings per share rose to 3.95 Singapore cents, up from 1.32 cents a year ago. The company attributed the decline in operational profit to lower contributions from certain businesses and higher depreciation costs.

site_title: Challenge to Australia's Senate voting reforms in boost for PM Turnbull
summary: The Australian High Court rejected a challenge to Senate voting reforms, which make it harder for smaller parties to enter parliament. The reforms, passed in March, are a boost for Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull ahead of elections on July 2. The reforms aim to limit the influence of independent and minor party senators who have stalled key government policies, including changes to healthcare and welfare. The decision clears the path for Turnbull's government to implement its agenda, despite a challenging economic outlook and criticism of its immigration policy.

images.alt_text: Australia's High Court rejected a challenge to reforms to Senate voting on Friday in a boost for Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull ahead of elections on July 2.

site_title: Japan, US preparing summit meeting around May 25: govt
summary: Japan and the US are preparing to hold a summit meeting around May 25, with Prime Minister Shinzo Abe and President Barack Obama expected to discuss global economy, North Korea, and the South China Sea. The meeting is set ahead of a Group of Seven summit in western Japan on May 26 and 27, where they will likely address these issues.

site_title: Alibaba, SoftBank team up for cloud computing service in Japan
summary: Alibaba and SoftBank have formed a cloud computing service venture in Japan, targeting Japanese customers. The joint venture, SB Cloud Corp, will open a new data center to provide services such as data storage and processing. This move expands Alibaba's cloud business, which has almost tripled revenue to over 1 billion yuan in the March quarter, and is expected to account for over $1 billion of Alibaba's revenue by 2018. The venture aims to compete with Amazon in the global cloud market, valued at $120 billion.

site_title: Brazil's Temer calls for unity, confidence for Brazil recovery
summary: Brazil's interim President Michel Temer urged unity and confidence as he steers the country toward market-friendly policies amid a deep economic recession and corruption scandal. Following the Senate's suspension and trial of his predecessor, Dilma Rousseff, Temer vowed to enact business-friendly policies while maintaining social programs. He faces the challenge of reducing a massive budget deficit and cutting bloated public spending. Temer's government is expected to announce austerity measures, including pension reform, and has named a respected former central bank governor as finance minister. The trial could last up to six months, and Rousseff has vowed to fight the charges.

site_title: US dollar holds gains, US data awaited for fresh incentive
summary: The US dollar maintained its gains against the yen and euro on Friday, awaiting US data that could influence the currency's tone. The dollar rose 0.6% overnight and is on track to rise 1.8% for the week, despite a Bank of Japan monetary policy decision that had previously caused the yen to rally. US Treasury yields rose after Boston Federal Reserve President Eric Rosengren suggested the Fed may raise interest rates if the economy shows signs of strength. Key US data, including April retail sales and the producer price index, will be released later in the day.

site_title: Asia: Stocks retreat amid earnings as technology shares decline
summary: Asian stocks declined 0.2% as technology shares fell amid disappointing corporate earnings and concerns over global economic growth. The MSCI Asia Pacific Index retreated from a week's gain, with Apple's decline to its lowest since June 2014 contributing to the downturn. Investment directors expressed uncertainty over central bank efforts to boost growth, citing a faltering bullish momentum in equities.

site_title: Sim Lian posts earnings, revenue slump in Q3
summary: Sim Lian Group reported a 82% drop in net profit to S$16.4 million in Q3 2016, a 74% decline in revenue to S$163.3 million, and a 81% drop in earnings per share to 1.63 Singapore cents. The decline was attributed to reduced contribution from completed development properties.

site_title: Fed's George says interest rates are too low
summary: Kansas City Fed President Esther George stated that the Federal Reserve's interest rates are too low, posing risks of excessive debt for companies. George, who has dissented on rate hikes in the past, believes a gradual adjustment is necessary. She warned that keeping rates low for too long can lead to debt growth and disruption. This contradicts the Fed's general agreement to raise rates gradually. The Fed has maintained interest rates steady since December, with investors anticipating one rate increase this year.

site_title: Some Obamacare funding deemed illegal by DC federal judge
summary: A DC federal judge ruled that a key Obamacare program is unconstitutional due to unappropriated funds. The program aimed to reduce consumers' out-of-pocket medical bills. The ruling, which is on hold pending appeal, could lead to higher co-payments, deductibles, and costs for low-income Obamacare customers. This decision is a victory for the Republican-led House of Representatives, which challenged the provision in 2014.

site_title: Ghosn eyes salvage job with 237b yen Mitsubishi Motors stake
summary: Carlos Ghosn, who saved Nissan 16 years ago, is taking on a new role with Mitsubishi Motors Corp. Nissan agreed to buy a 34% stake in the company for approximately 237.4 billion yen ($3 billion). The investment aims to stabilize Mitsubishi Motors, whose market value fell 40% after it admitted to overstating fuel economy and improper testing since 1991. This move could serve as a crucial lifeline to the struggling automaker, providing much-needed capital to revive its business.

site_title: Foxconn to cut Sharp jobs after review of 'subpar' performance
summary: Foxconn Technology Group chairman Terry Gou announced plans to cut jobs at Sharp Corp after reviewing the company's "subpar" performance. Sharp posted its second straight annual loss, with a "level of inefficiency" throughout its operations cited as the reason for the workforce reduction. Gou promised to reward employees who contribute to rebuilding the iconic brand, but warned of "very regrettable" job losses.

site_title: Swift says second bank hit by malware attack
summary: Swift, a global financial messaging network, reported a second malware attack similar to the February US$81 million cyberheist at the Bangladesh central bank. The attackers demonstrated a deep understanding of specific operational controls, potentially aided by malicious insiders or cyber attacks. The targeted bank was not named, but Swift warned of a similar threat to its system, highlighting the need for enhanced security measures to prevent future cyberheists.

site_title: Jack Treynor, who pioneered modern investment theory, dies at 86
summary: Jack Treynor, a pioneer of modern investment theory and discoverer of the capital asset pricing model, died on May 11 at 86. The model, a cornerstone of finance, codifies the role of risk in expected investment returns. Treynor, who spent his last years in California, occasionally contributed to financial journals. He is recognized as one of the key figures in shaping the field of quantitative finance.

site_title: Twitter suspends rapper Azealia Banks after racist abuse
summary: Twitter suspended rapper Azealia Banks after she launched racist attacks on former One Direction member Zayn Malik, accusing him of copying her style. The US artist's Twitter account was temporarily removed for "abusive tweets and behavior." Banks had previously made headlines for provocative online remarks, including homophobic language and denunciations of Australian audiences. Her suspension follows a festival in London canceling her appearance and numerous Twitter users calling for her removal.

site_title: Gold slips after best day since April as US dollar strengthens
summary: Gold prices fell 0.6% to $1,269.76 an ounce, after a 15-month high last week, due to a strengthening US dollar. The decline came as some buyers cashed in gains after the metal's biggest daily rise this month. US jobs data was downbeat, but a brief rebound occurred after the US dollar strengthened. Analysts attribute the weakness to the dollar's strength and the approaching $1,300 level.

site_title: Facebook guidelines show trending news relies on human judgment
summary: Facebook's trending news feature relies heavily on human judgment, contradicting earlier claims of a machine-based system. Documents released by the social network show that human editors can insert news topics and prioritize them against 10 news organizations to determine legitimacy. The company denies allegations of suppressing conservative viewpoints, stating it does not discriminate against sources based on their political origin. However, the documents suggest Facebook's system is more human than advertised, making it susceptible to biases and criticism, similar to other news organizations.

site_title: UK hails progress, defends tax havens at corruption summit
summary: UK Prime Minister David Cameron defended Britain's tax havens at an international summit on combating corruption, despite criticism over the lack of transparency. Over 40 countries signed a declaration to pursue and punish corrupt individuals, with several nations agreeing to create public registers of company ownership and recover stolen assets. Cameron announced plans for a new international centre to coordinate asset recovery and a public register of company owners, but campaigners expressed disappointment that it did not extend to Britain's overseas territories.

site_title: Clinton joins crowd calling for an overhaul of Fed governance
summary: Hillary Clinton calls for an overhaul of the Federal Reserve's governance structure, arguing it should be more representative of America as a whole. The proposal includes getting bankers off regional Fed bank boards and selecting directors from small businesses and non-profit organizations. This comes as Democrats criticize the central bank, with lawmakers and the Fed Up coalition backing Clinton's position. Some Fed officials, including Richmond Fed president Jeffrey Lacker, push back against the idea, citing the importance of monetary policy independence.

site_title: Australia's Origin appoints Macquarie for potential gas demerger: sources
summary: Australia's energy retailer Origin Energy has appointed Macquarie Capital to advise on a potential spin-off of its gas production businesses, including a US$25 billion liquefied natural gas (LNG) plant. The move aims to shift debt to the gas production business, protect Origin's investment-grade credit rating, and provide shareholders with more value. The spin-off would also help to separate Origin's debt-saddled Asia Pacific LNG business.

site_title: Brazil's Rousseff suspended to face impeachment trial
summary: Brazilian President Dilma Rousseff was suspended Thursday to face an impeachment trial, ceding power to Vice President Michel Temer. Rousseff was suspended for six months pending judgment on charges of breaking budget accounting laws, with a two-thirds majority vote needed to force her from office for good. Temer has named a new cabinet to calm markets and steer the country out of its worst recession in decades, but opponents have condemned the move as a throw-back to an era of white male dominance. Rousseff has denounced the move as a "coup" and vowed to mobilize her supporters during the trial.

site_title: British PM apologises for calling imam IS supporter
summary: British Prime Minister David Cameron apologized to Imam Sulaiman Ghani for wrongly branding him a supporter of the Islamic State group, after making the accusation in parliament. Cameron stated that Ghani's support was for an "Islamic state," not the terrorist organization, and apologized for any misunderstanding. The apology was made after Defence Secretary Michael Fallon echoed the comments in a radio interview, sparking criticism and potential legal action against Ghani. The incident occurred in the run-up to the London mayoral election won by Labour candidate Sadiq Khan.

site_title: China Inc misses best shot to repay US$430b as yuan drops
summary: China's companies face a challenging time to repay their US$430 billion in dollar debt due to the yuan's decline, which is rallying after its worst quarter since 2010. The yuan's drop threatens to drive up costs for companies seeking to repay US currency borrowings or hedge exposure. Economists predict a 2.6% decline in the yuan for the rest of the year, making it harder for companies to repay their debt, which has already seen eight issuers defaulting in 2016.

images.alt_text: The best time for China Inc to repay its dollar debt may be coming to an end.

site_title: US gives Tunisia military hardware to bolster security
summary: The US has delivered military hardware to Tunisia, including light aircraft, jeeps, and communications systems, worth $20 million, to help the North African country combat terrorism and secure its borders. The equipment was handed over at a ceremony attended by US officials and Tunisian Defence Minister Farhat Horchani. The move aims to bolster Tunisia's military capabilities and provide advanced surveillance capabilities to detect potential threats along its border with Libya, where the Islamic State group has a presence.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Olam, ST Engineering, Croesus Retail Trust, KrisEnergy
summary: Olam International reported a tripling in net profit to S$113.6 million for its first quarter, driven by lower exceptional charges. ST Engineering posted a 15.2% drop in net profit to S$110.2 million, while KrisEnergy swung to a net loss of US$18.3 million due to higher depreciation expenses. Croesus Retail Trust reported a distribution per unit of 1.86 Singapore cents, down from 1.9 cents a year ago, due to a larger unit base.

images.alt_text: ST Engineering on Friday posted a 15.2 per cent drop in net profit to S$110.2 million for the first quarter ended March 31, 2015.

site_title: Pope Francis mulls opening door to female deacons in Church
summary: Pope Francis has announced plans to set up a commission to study the possibility of women serving as deacons in the Catholic Church, a move seen as a potential step towards greater female representation. The commission will examine the role of women in the early centuries of the Church and whether they could be ordained as deacons, a rank below priest. While Pope Francis has not ruled out the possibility of women becoming priests, he has stated that women will not be allowed to celebrate the Eucharist. The move is seen as a significant step forward for the Church and has been welcomed by progressive groups.

site_title: Philippines' cash-strapped cops cheer new crime-buster president
summary: Philippines' police force, severely underfunded, elected a new president, Rodrigo Duterte, who campaigned on a single-issue platform of crushing crime, corruption, and drug abuse. Duterte, former mayor of Davao, promises to raise policing standards, following a 22-year tenure in the city, where he implemented a 911 emergency service. The country faces a high rate of methamphetamine use, with 2.1% of 16- to 64-year-olds using the substance, prompting popular alarm. Duterte's unpolished message tapped into public concern, as the police force struggles to provide basic services due to lack of funding.

site_title: US: Wall Street mixed as Apple tumbles to two-year low
summary: US stocks ended mixed on Thursday, with the S&P 500 and Dow Jones virtually flat. Apple tumbled to a two-year low, 2.35% down, amid worries over slowing iPhone demand. Despite this, gains in telecommunications and consumer staples helped offset losses. The Nasdaq Composite fell 0.49%. The Federal Reserve indicated a possible interest rate hike if data points to an improving economy.

site_title: Apple falls below US$90 to 2-year low
summary: Apple shares fell 3.3% to $89.47, ceding the world's largest company title to Google, and are down 14% since the start of the year. The decline is attributed to disappointing fiscal Q2 earnings, lower iPhone sales, and concerns over the pace of iPhone sales. Analysts at UBS cut their Apple share price outlook to $115 from $120, citing lower sales forecasts. This marks Apple's lowest price in nearly two years, with its market valuation now at $494 billion, down from a peak of $132.54 last year.

site_title: Pakistan to get US$510m tranche of IMF loan: officials
summary: Pakistan has received a $510 million tranche of a three-year IMF loan, bringing the total to $6.6 billion. The loan was granted after a review of Pakistan's economic performance, which showed robust growth despite challenges. The IMF expects Pakistan's real GDP growth to reach 4.5% in FY 2015/16 and 4.7% in FY 2016/17. The country has met all quantitative performance criteria, including a budget deficit target and floor for the central bank's net international reserves. This is part of a bailout package required to address Pakistan's energy crisis.

site_title: Yen weakens vs dollar on talk of more policy easing
summary: The Japanese yen fell to a two-week low against the dollar on May 12, 2016, amid speculation of potential policy easing by the Bank of Japan. Prominent academic Takatoshi Ito suggested the BOJ may expand stimulus in June or July, while Governor Haruhiko Kuroda stated the bank would take further easing steps if necessary. The dollar rose 0.6% to 109.06 yen, with some analysts predicting a reversal in the yen's value to 120-125 yen in the second half of the year.

site_title: Brazil's institutions 'durable' enough to withstand crisis: US
summary: The US expressed confidence in Brazil's institutions, stating they are "sufficiently mature and durable to withstand the political turmoil" following President Dilma Rousseff's suspension from office. The Brazilian Senate voted 55-22 to suspend Rousseff for six months to face impeachment, effectively ending 13 years of leftist rule. Vice President Michel Temer took over, naming a business-friendly cabinet. The US intends to respect Brazil's institutions and procedures, despite the crisis.

images.alt_text: The United States expressed confidence in Brazil Thursday, saying it was strong enough to withstand political turmoil in the wake of President Dilma Rousseff's suspension from office to face an impeachment trial.

site_title: Oil price falls from 2016 high
summary: Oil prices fell to a 2016 high, closing at $45.98 a barrel, after profit-taking and a forecast by the International Energy Agency that the global supply glut would "shrink dramatically" this year. The news came after a surprise drop in US crude reserves and a shutdown of 1.2 million oil barrels a day in Canada due to wildfires. Analysts attributed the price surge to a sharp drop in the supply glut and strong demand in the US, which led to a 25-cent drop in oil prices.

site_title: Intel said to plan US$2.75b bond sale for refinancing
summary: Intel plans to sell $2.75 billion in bonds to refinance debt due this year and 2017, according to a regulatory filing. The bonds may yield 1.55-1.6% above comparable government debt, down from initial discussions of 1.7%. Bank of America and JPMorgan Chase are managing the sale, which has received an A+ grade from S&P Global Ratings. This is part of a larger trend of US blue-chip companies issuing bonds in anticipation of low borrowing costs and a summer slowdown.

site_title: Can this real estate gimmick save the world?
summary: Steve Wynn plans to replace a golf course with a 38-acre man-made lake behind two Las Vegas hotels, featuring a 10-storey mountain accessible by zip line and electric ferry, and nightly fireworks. This project is part of Crystal Lagoon's ambitious plans to create luxury lakes and resorts globally.

images.alt_text: Mr Wynn intends to replace a golf course in Las Vegas with a huge Crystal Lagoons man-made lake.

site_title: Hacker arrested for attempted extortion of Brazil interim president's wife
summary: Brazilian police arrested three individuals, including a hacker, his wife, and sister-in-law, for hacking into the internet account of Vice President Michel Temer's wife, Marcela Temer. The hackers stole intimate photographs and attempted to extort money. The arrests were made on Wednesday. This incident occurred after Vice President Temer took office, following President Dilma Rousseff's suspension.

site_title: Tears, a final kiss and 'sad' Rousseff quits presidency
summary: Brazilian President Dilma Rousseff stepped down on May 12, 2016, after a Senate impeachment vote that she described as a "coup." Rousseff, 75, was escorted from the presidential palace, where she addressed the nation and thanked supporters for their loyalty. She will serve a six-month suspension pending judgment on charges related to budget manipulation. Rousseff's vice president, Michel Temer, will take over as president. The impeachment marked a significant shift in Brazilian politics, with many recognizing the wrongdoing of lawmakers who voted to remove Rousseff, despite her own corruption allegations.

images.alt_text: Tears flowed when Dilma Rousseff addressed the nation for a last time Thursday before driving away from Brazil's presidential palace to the chanting of supporters.

site_title: Europe: Shares weighed down by disappointing earnings; Bayer falls
summary: European stocks fell 0.55% on Thursday, weighed down by disappointing earnings updates, including Aegon's 11.4% drop and Credit Agricole's 4.9% decline. Bayer and BASF dropped 4.8% and 2.1%, respectively, after reports they may be interested in buying Monsanto. Despite this, some stocks rose, including KBC 4.6% and Zurich Insurance 6.6%, while RWE rose 6.8% after beating earnings expectations.

site_title: Choosing the perfect bed frame
summary: Choosing the perfect bed frame is crucial for quality sleep. Investing in a suitable bed frame offers ample support and can enhance overall well-being. When selecting a bed frame, consider factors such as material, style, and size to ensure it meets individual needs. A proper bed frame can also increase the lifespan of a mattress and improve sleep quality. By prioritizing a suitable bed frame, individuals can rejuvenate their body and mind, leading to improved overall health and well-being.

site_title: Latest SGX 'hollowing out' is different - and troubling
summary: The Singapore stock market is experiencing a "hollowing out" effect, where undervalued companies are being taken private by major shareholders or corporate predators, leaving the market worse off in the long run. This phenomenon is not new, but the current round of takeovers is different due to the lack of new listings and the shift in motivations from external parties to incumbent shareholders seeking to escape poor liquidity and undervaluation. The absence of fresh names on the exchange and the diminishing prestige of being a listed company are major concerns, making it challenging for the authorities to address the issue.

site_title: Trump, Republican leaders hold 'positive' talks in Washington
summary: US Presidential candidate Donald Trump met with Republican leaders, including House Speaker Paul Ryan, in Washington, marking a "positive step" toward unifying the party behind his White House run. Despite differences, Trump and Ryan stressed the need to defeat Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton in November. Trump's meeting with other Republican leaders, including RNC chairman Reince Priebus, was seen as a crucial test of his ability to unite the party. Ryan withheld his endorsement, but expressed optimism about the meeting, saying it was a "first very encouraging meeting" that could help bridge gaps within the party.

site_title: Chilean cabbies block traffic in protest against Uber
summary: Thousands of Chilean taxi drivers blocked traffic in protest against Uber, citing unfair competition and strict regulations. The protesters, who decorated their taxis with the Chilean flag, blocked several blocks along Santiago's main avenue, causing traffic jams. The government has deemed Uber illegal, but Congress must pass a law to address the issue. A court had previously dismissed a lawsuit against the government for not suspending Uber. The taxi drivers union claims their efforts show they are not wrong, with the head of the union saying "We never thought we would attract so many people and co-workers."

images.alt_text: Thousands of Chilean taxi drivers honked their horns and blocked traffic Thursday in a protest against ridesharing service Uber.

site_title: Kim Heng, first mover in Iran, to help develop its marine sector
summary: Kim Heng Offshore & Marine Holdings, a Singapore-listed company, has partnered with the Iran Marine Fund to develop Iran's marine industries. The agreement aims to manufacture platform supply vessels, offshore cranes, and chemical tankers. Kim Heng set up an office in Tehran and appointed a local representative. Despite the potential for growth, analysts caution that the country's bureaucracy and infrastructure deficiencies may hinder progress, and Singapore companies may face unfair competition from Chinese suppliers.

site_title: Meirelles, Brazil finance minister to calm markets
summary: Henrique Meirelles, Brazil's new finance minister, has been tasked with rescuing the country's economy from its worst crisis in decades. Meirelles, a 70-year-old conservative, previously headed the Brazilian central bank from 2003 to 2011. He will focus on tackling the country's worst recession in 25 years, which contracted 3.8% last year and is forecast to continue this year. Meirelles will need to help implement unpopular spending cuts and reforms to bolster public finances, a task his predecessor, Dilma Rousseff, failed to accomplish.

site_title: S'pore brands lag those of Asean neighbours in local market share
summary: Singaporean brands lag behind their South-east Asian counterparts in terms of market penetration, with less than 20% of total market share. A recent survey by Nielsen Company found that local brands in Indonesia capture over half the market, while Thai brands are winning consumer hearts, with a 34% share growth from 2012 to 2014. Singaporeans prefer global brands for beauty and electronics, citing quality and innovative products as key factors, but local brands have an advantage in fresh foods due to concerns about perishability.

site_title: Najib's stepson used 1MDB funds to buy US properties: WSJ
summary: Malaysian Prime Minister Najib Razak's stepson, Riza Aziz, allegedly used funds from state investment company 1MDB to buy US properties worth $50 million. The funds originated from at least $238 million transferred via an intermediary to Red Granite Capital, a company wholly-owned by Riza. The US Federal Bureau of Investigation is investigating the deals, which also involve a Hollywood production company backed by Riza. Najib's family has been entangled in various alleged links to 1MDB funds amid ongoing global probes into money laundering and embezzlement.

site_title: Cisco told to pay US$23.5m over hacker-security patents
summary: Cisco Systems Inc. has been ordered to pay over US$23.5 million to a nonprofit research centre for infringing on network-surveillance patents designed to identify hacking attacks on computer systems. The jury in Delaware federal court ruled that Cisco used technology owned by SRI International without permission. The patented technology allows computers to automatically detect and record suspicious activity on networks. SRI International initially sought over US$50 million in damages. Cisco's unauthorized use of the technology was deemed a patent infringement, with the jury rejecting Cisco's arguments that the patents were not valid.

site_title: Food companies need to collaborate more and set industry benchmarks
summary: Singapore's food industry, worth S$7.7 billion annually, faces a challenge in maintaining trust among consumers due to food scandals and recalls. To address this, the industry needs to collaborate and set industry benchmarks, promoting transparency and traceability throughout the supply chain. The government is encouraging collaboration through initiatives such as the 30 Collaborative Industry Projects (CIP) and leveraging technology to enhance food safety and quality. By doing so, Singaporean food companies can build a strong reputation and gain a competitive edge in the global market.

site_title: Goldman Sachs gets query over Panama Papers
summary: Goldman Sachs has been asked by New York's Department of Financial Services to provide information about shell companies established through a Panamanian law firm, Mossack Fonseca. The request comes after a similar inquiry to 13 other banks and is not an accusation of wrongdoing. The DFS is investigating the banks' interactions with Mossack Fonseca and whether any employees had dealings with the law firm or the shell companies. The investigation follows the release of the Panama Papers, which identified global banks that used the law firm to set up shell companies for anonymous clients.

site_title: Hyundai, Kia said to make low-cost SUVs to battle China rivals
summary: Hyundai Motor and Kia Motors plan to launch three low-cost SUVs in China by next year, a shift to compete with Chinese rivals. The move comes after the South Korean carmakers' market share in China slid to a seven-year low. Hyundai will build compact and subcompact SUVs, while Kia will follow with its own subcompact and mid-sized SUVs. The companies aim to reduce costs by using Chinese suppliers and local engineering, but some experts warn that introducing low-end SUVs could undermine the Korean carmakers' quality and brand image.

site_title: Opec meeting to focus on dialogue
summary: Kuwait's acting oil minister Anas al-Saleh said OPEC's June 2 meeting in Vienna will focus on dialogue rather than coordinated action to stabilize oil markets. The meeting follows a failed attempt to agree on measures to reduce oil production in April, where Saudi Arabia and Iran couldn't agree on deal terms. Recent price increases to $47.50 per barrel are justified by decreased production, with other regions such as the Americas, Asia, and Africa experiencing sharp declines. The meeting aims to determine further action based on increased dialogue among OPEC members.

site_title: SGX starts half-yearly updates on long-suspended companies
summary: The Singapore Exchange (SGX) has begun publishing half-yearly updates on long-suspended companies, aiming to boost transparency and improve the admissions process. The updates cover 20 suspended companies, with 11 exploring trading resumptions or reverse takeovers. The median suspension length is under three years, with the longest suspension dating back to 2009. The move is also seen as a learning tool for rejected IPO applicants, and improvements to the admissions process are expected to be announced jointly with the Association of Banks.

site_title: Two men charged with insider trading offences
summary: Two Singapore men, Tay Yeow Kee and Cheng Hong Wee Eddy, have been charged with insider trading offences for buying and selling shares of Qualitas Medical Group and Leeden in 2011. The men face six counts each, with neither entering a plea. The charges come as Singapore boosts its efforts to police market misconduct. This is part of a broader crackdown on insider trading and market manipulation, which has been a focus for the city-state since a 2013 penny-stock rout. The men's lawyer has stated plans to challenge the charges.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Pan-United Corporation's shares closed at S$0.625 on May 12, 2016, surpassing the target price of S$0.49. The company was deemed fully valued.

site_title: 1MDB execs approved fund transfer to Jho Low associate
summary: Singapore's state court documents reveal that 1MDB executives authorized a $11.95 million transfer to a firm beneficially owned by Eric Tan, a close associate of Malaysian tycoon Jho Low. The transfer was done through a fund overseen by 1MDB's finance executive Terence Geh and approved by SRC International's managing director Nik Faisal Ariff Kamil. The move is part of the ongoing probe into 1MDB's financial dealings, with Singapore investigators working around the clock to uncover the source of funds. The case against BSI's former wealth manager Yeo Jiawei has been updated with a new charge of forgery, further implicating the 1MDB scandal.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Shah of Iran's art collection to go on show in Berlin
summary: The former Shah of Iran's extensive modern art collection will be exhibited in Berlin from December 2023 to February 2024. The nearly 300-piece collection, featuring works by Picasso, Miro, Warhol, Pollock, Rothko, and Bacon, will be showcased at the Prussian Cultural Heritage Foundation. This is the first time the collection, assembled under the patronage of Shah Mohammad Reza Pahlavi's wife Farah, has been displayed outside of Iran since the 1979 Islamic revolution. The exhibition is seen as a sign of Iran's "cultural and social opening up" and will also include works by contemporary Iranian artists.

site_title: Roxy Pacific plans upscale Maldives resort
summary: Roxy Pacific Holdings Limited has finalized plans to create an upscale Noku-branded resort in the Maldives after acquiring Zitahli Kuda-Funafaru for US$31 million. The resort, set to open in Q1 2017, will undergo extensive renovations. This marks Roxy Pacific's second Noku property and its first in the Maldives, following the successful launch of a Kyoto, Japan property in November last year. The resort features 50 villas, a full-service spa, and various amenities.

site_title: Yen drama likely to enter new phase at G-7 meeting
summary: Japan is expected to enter a new phase in addressing the volatility of the yen at the upcoming G-7 meeting of finance ministers and central bank governors. Japan seeks to gain understanding from its G-7 partners on the need for concerted intervention to stabilize yen fluctuations and prevent the currency from rising to levels that could undermine Japan's economic recovery. The yen has been moving erratically, with recent comments from the Bank of Japan's governor and a professor close to him contributing to its decline.

site_title: ComfortDelGro raises Q1 profit by 8.6% to S$73.4m
summary: ComfortDelGro reported a 8.6% increase in Q1 net profit to S$73.4 million, driven by growth in bus and taxi businesses, as well as rail and driving centre businesses. Group revenue rose 3.3% to S$995.6 million, offset by decreases in automotive engineering services and bus station businesses.

site_title: Security bug SAP patched draws US govt alert
summary: A US security alert has been issued over a vulnerability in SAP software, which can still give attackers remote control over older systems if not patched. SAP fixed the issue six years ago but left the decision to customers on whether to apply the fix, which can destabilize their systems. Dozens of companies have been exposed to the security gaps, and a larger number of SAP customers remain vulnerable, with some 36 enterprises found to have signs of unauthorised access.

site_title: S'pore prime land 'exorbitant': CityDev
summary: Singapore's second-largest developer, City Developments Ltd, has described prime land prices in the city-state as exorbitant, citing the S$383m price paid for its Gramercy Park project site in 2006. Despite a decline in profit and revenue, the company expects prices to rise further, with interest in the property remaining positive during regional roadshows. The developer's comments reflect the ongoing challenges of securing prime land in Singapore, where the government has imposed curbs to cool the market and prevent overheating.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Hotel Properties Limited reported a slight increase in net profit to S$14.34 million for Q1 2016, while revenue fell due to lower contributions from the Tomlinson Heights condominium development and resorts in the Maldives. Hyflux saw a 30% increase in net profit to S$7.3 million, driven by a four-fold growth in revenue from its TuasOne waste-to-energy project and Qurayyat Independent Water Project in Oman. EZION Holdings reported a 62% drop in net profit to US$15.5 million, while Nam Cheong suffered a net loss of RM40.1 million. FJ Benjamin made a net loss of S$5.1 million for the third quarter.

site_title: Oil glut to 'shrink dramatically': IEA
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) predicts a "dramatic" reduction in the global oil glut later this year, driven by Canada's wildfire disruption and India's soaring demand. Despite a "solid" growth rate in global demand, oil prices are expected to remain low due to abundant stocks. Iran's increased oil production and exports, particularly after lifting sanctions, also contributed to the expected market balance. The IEA forecasts a 1.2 million barrel per day increase in global oil stocks, with a reduction of 200,000 barrels per day in the second half of the year.

site_title: Senate votes to oust Rousseff, ushering in new govt
summary: Brazil's Senate voted 55-22 to suspend President Dilma Rousseff, ushering in a new government amid months of turmoil in the recession-wracked country. Rousseff faces an impeachment trial in the Senate after being accused of illegally doctoring fiscal accounts to mask a budget deficit. The marathon 21-hour session marks a significant shift in Brazilian politics, with Rousseff's suspension paving the way for a new government.

site_title: Startup uHoo develops air quality monitor with extra sensors
summary: Singapore startup uHoo has successfully raised US$31,888 for its indoor air quality monitor, uHoo Premium, which tracks 8 sensors including particulate matter and chemicals. The device is priced at US$149 and aims to provide users with data on long-term air quality and track foreign elements. The company, co-founded by Dustin Jefferson Onghanseng and Brian Lin, has completed research and development and plans to start production with the US$50,000 Indiegogo target by the end of the year, with initial sales expected to begin soon.

site_title: Yen drops to 2-week low on stimulus talk
summary: The yen fell to a two-week low due to speculation that the Bank of Japan may expand its monetary stimulus as early as next month. Prominent academic Takatoshi Ito suggested the BOJ will likely take further easing steps, and Governor Haruhiko Kuroda warned of large downside risks to Japan's economy. The US dollar rose 0.9% to 109.40 yen, while sterling rose to a six-day high against the US dollar after the Bank of England kept interest rates on hold.

site_title: Stories of desperation, told in words and images
summary: Comic artist Adrian Tomine's latest book, "Killing and Dying", is a collection of six graphic stories set in middle- and working-class America. The stories explore the struggles of ordinary people, often due to external circumstances or their own flaws. Tomine uses minimalist illustrations and precise dialogue to convey complex emotions and themes, blurring the line between text and image. His unique style has elevated the graphic novel form, allowing it to tell stories in ways prose novels cannot, and has been praised for its nuanced portrayal of human struggles.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Hard truths about getting on a company's board
summary: Business executives seeking to join a company board should not ask for the opportunity, but rather be invited. A board of directors has three key responsibilities: hiring and firing the CEO, validating strategy, and ensuring proper execution and risk management. To be effective, a director must possess intelligence, self-confidence, integrity, experience, drive, and interpersonal skills. They must also be ready to contribute from day one, bringing unique skills and perspectives to the board. The reality is that becoming an independent board director is a challenging and competitive process, with only a few candidates being invited to join a company board.

site_title: Comfortable spaces to relax in
summary: A recent article emphasizes the importance of having a comfortable space to relax at home. It suggests that investing in a key piece of furniture can provide optimum comfort, regardless of the home's size. The article provides two ways to achieve comfort at home, but does not delve into specific details. It appears to be a brief introduction to the topic rather than a comprehensive guide.

site_title: An Indian art show with a difference
summary: A contemporary Indian art exhibition, "Discover the Dream," is being held in Singapore, featuring works by seven artists from Baroda, known for producing India's best contemporary artists. The exhibition, curated by Rukshaan Krishna, brings together artists who incorporate traditional techniques or subjects into modern works. The artists include Ramgopal Kumawat, Ambu Rathwa, Soumen Das, Ajay Sharma, Kundan Mondal, Harisha Chennangod, and Sanjay Barot, showcasing a range of styles and themes.

site_title: Aided by 3D printing, precision-engineering sector set to transform
summary: Singapore's precision-engineering sector is set to transform with the help of 3D printing, a technology known as additive manufacturing. Applied Materials, the world's largest chipmaking equipment maker, has partnered with a Singapore research agency to develop new additive-manufacturing technologies. This collaboration aims to change the way the company operates in the future, marking a significant shift for the sector.

site_title: Plane lessor Doric preparing to take back five A380s from SIA
summary: Doric, an aircraft-leasing firm, is preparing to take back five Airbus A380s from Singapore Airlines starting next year. This move would be the first test of second-hand demand for the world's biggest jetliner. Doric is exploring refurbishment options and highlighting the planes' availability to potential users, including tier-one airlines like British Airways. Leasing the planes could save Singapore Airlines $432.6 million and offer attractive rental rates. The move may also pave the way for a second-hand market for A380s, which could benefit low-cost Asian airlines and Airbus.

site_title: Pacific Radiance slips into the red in Q1
summary: Pacific Radiance, a Singapore-based offshore and marine player, reported a Q1 loss of US$6.76 million, reversing from a profit of US$2.53 million last year due to a 42% decline in revenue. Revenue plummeted on weakened market conditions from a severe drop in oil prices, with a 61% decline in subsea business revenue and a 40% decline in offshore support services revenue. The company expects to launch a ship-repair yard in mid-2016 to control fleet maintenance.

site_title: Macy's cuts profit forecast, stocks plunge
summary: Macy's Inc cut its profit forecast and posted disappointing first-quarter revenue, citing slow foot traffic at shopping malls and a decline in consumer spending. The company's shares plummeted 15% to $31.38, and other retailers like Wal-Mart, Target, and Nike also fell. Analysts expect Ralph Lauren, Kohl's, and Nordstrom to provide insight into the retail industry's health, with some warning of low demand and potential cost-cutting measures. Macy's now expects full-year earnings of $3.15-$3.40 per share, down from an earlier projection of $3.80-$3.90 per share.

site_title: ETF inflows push Q1 gold demand to 7-year high
summary: Global gold demand rose 21% in the first quarter of 2016, reaching a 7-year high, driven by $13.8 billion in inflows into gold exchange-traded funds (ETFs). Investment demand accounted for 617.6 tonnes, valued at $23.5 billion, while jewellery demand fell 19% due to strikes in India and a slowdown in China. Central banks maintained their gold buying streak, and technology demand declined. The World Gold Council expects gold demand to remain healthy in 2016 due to ongoing market uncertainty and unconventional monetary policies.

images.alt_text: The increase of 21 per cent brought total gold demand in the quarter to 1,289.8 tonnes, up from 1,070.4 tonnes in the same period last year.

site_title: Platinum prices to bottom out, supply shortfalls to return in 2016: report
summary: Platinum prices are expected to bottom out in 2016, with a return to supply shortfalls predicted to hold the metal at an average US$1,005 an ounce. The market was oversupplied by 54,000 ounces last year, driven by a surge in mine output in South Africa, but is expected to return to a deficit this year. Demand for platinum edged up, with autocatalyst demand rising 2% and retail investment more than tripling, while jewellery demand eased 4%.

site_title: UOL Q1 profit up on higher property development revenue
summary: UOL Group reported a 4% increase in net profit to S$77.08 million for the first quarter ended March 31, 2016, driven by higher revenue from ongoing and new property development projects, including Riverbank@Fernvale and Seventy Saint Patrick's. Revenue rose 39% to S$330.12 million. The group plans to launch a Shanghai project this quarter and a Clementi condo next year.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Horror homage could afford a couple more scares
summary: Singapore's first Hollywood horror film, The Faith of Anna Waters, fails to deliver scares despite its ambitious attempt to cover various horror films. Writer-director Kelvin Tong's over-reliance on homages results in a disjointed plot, while the lack of chills affects lead actress Elizabeth Rice and Matthew Settle. The only memorable scene features child star Adina Herz in an exorcism scene, but her character's make-up and antics feel too familiar. The film's potential is lost due to poor storytelling and a reliance on generic horror tropes, resulting in a disappointing experience.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Ascendas Hospitality Trust's Q4 DPS rises 4%
summary: Ascendas Hospitality Trust reported a 4% increase in fourth-quarter distribution per stapled security (DPS) to 1.3 Singapore cents, driven by improved margins in Australia and China and proceeds from the sale of the Pullman Cairns International hotel. Net property income grew 3.5% to S$23.42 million, despite a 3% decline in gross revenue. The trust attributed the decline to weaker hotel markets in Singapore and Australia.

site_title: Lower fuel costs, fine refund propel SIA's Q4 profit to S$225m
summary: Singapore Airlines (SIA) posted a net profit of S$224.7 million for the fourth quarter, driven by lower fuel costs and a S$117 million refund of a competition-related fine. Despite lower yields, the airline's operating profit rose to S$153.2 million. The company expects challenges in the cargo market amid economic slowdown in China and increased capacity. SIA's new A350-900 fleet is expected to enhance competitiveness, and the airline plans to cut its cargo fleet size to seven aircraft by March next year.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: FLASH: Heng Swee Keat remains in ICU, DPM Tharman to cover as Finance Minister
summary: Singapore's Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat remains hospitalized in the ICU, and Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam will cover his duties as Finance Minister.

site_title: What's keeping shoppers away from retail malls in Singapore
summary: Singapore's retail industry is struggling due to high rents, manpower issues, and weak consumer sentiment, leading to a rise in retail vacancy rates in downtown malls. Online shopping and competition from suburban malls are also contributing to the decline. However, a recent study found Singapore to be among the top 10 luxury retail destinations in Asia-Pacific cities, suggesting that the fundamentals for high-end brands remain intact. To adapt, retailers and mall operators must shift towards "omni-channel" retailing, offering online and physical shopping experiences.

site_title: A robust line-up at this coffee fest
summary: The first Singapore Coffee Festival will take place from June 9 to 12, featuring various activities such as Lab Sessions, seminars, and forums on coffee-making skills, finance, photography, and more. The event aims to elevate the appreciation of quality coffee and its cultivation, comparable to artisanal products like wine. Over 100 exhibitors, including specialty cafes and local kopi connoisseurs, will participate. The festival is expected to attract 15,000 visitors and include fringe activities such as local music acts, seminars on socially conscious living, and food options.

site_title: Immersive theatre
summary:
Here is a 100-word or less summary of the article content:

Singapore's arts scene is witnessing a surge in immersive theatre experiences, with various groups and event organizers creating multi-sensory events that combine drama, food, fantasy, and technology. The Doghouse, a Danish VR film installation, was showcased at Pala, an indie arts platform, while an escape room event, Journey to the End and Back, took place at Haw Par Villa. A pop-up event, If We Dream Too Long, combined literature, food, and immersive theatre, and another event, Electro Ball, blended art, theatre, dining, and music at The Black Swan.

site_title: Delicious black comedy with bite
summary: Jason Bateman's film "The Family Fang" is a black comedy about a dysfunctional family of performance artists. The film, based on a 2011 novel, stars Bateman as Baxter, the son of Caleb (Christopher Walken) and Camille (Maryann Plunkett), who stage elaborate pranks and performances. When Baxter and his sister Annie (Nicole Kidman) return home after an injury, they discover their parents' mysterious disappearance, leading to a search that blurs the lines between reality and performance. The film features understated performances and a raw, emotional tone, with Walken stealing the show with his menacing and comedic portrayal.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: HK property market is in 'free fall', says head of US hedge fund
summary: HK property market in 'free fall', says US hedge fund head Kyle Bass. Bass stated at a conference that Hong Kong's property market is in a worse position than before the 1997 crisis. He attributed the issue to reckless credit expansion in Asian emerging markets, specifically Malaysia and Thailand. Bass also warned that the credit expansion will unravel.

site_title: Nissan throws US$2.2b lifeline to scandal-hit Mitsubishi Motors
summary: Nissan has invested US$2.2 billion in Mitsubishi Motors, purchasing a one-third stake in the scandal-hit carmaker and becoming its top shareholder. The deal aims to help Mitsubishi address the fuel economy scandal and restore consumer trust. Nissan CEO Carlos Ghosn said the alliance promises growth opportunities and will help the company address challenges. Mitsubishi's shares surged 16% following the announcement, with the company's stock having plummeted 40% since the scandal broke last month.

site_title: Manulife US Reit comes with single ownership cap of 9.8%
summary: Manulife US Reit, the first US office Reit listed in Asia, has a unique feature - a single ownership cap of 9.8%. This limit prevents any unitholder from owning more than 9.8% of the outstanding units, with automatic forfeiture if exceeded. The rule is intended to safeguard the tax-efficient structure of the US Reit and is not expected to affect retail subscribers, who are unlikely to breach the threshold. Any takeover bidder is likely to take the Reit private due to tax inefficiencies.

site_title: Indonesia tells 78 parties mentioned in 'Panama Papers' to correct tax reports
summary: Indonesia's tax office has asked 78 individuals to correct their tax reports after finding discrepancies between their wealth reports and data from the "Panama Papers". The 1,010 individuals mentioned in the leaked data include 272 with tax identifications, with most denying offshore assets. The government aims to improve individual compliance, but a tax amnesty program has been delayed by Parliament. Indonesia is facing a revenue shortfall due to a decline in commodity-related income.

site_title: Tharman to cover as Finance Minister after Heng Swee Keat suffers stroke
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam will cover Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat's duties after Heng suffered a stroke, remaining under intensive care. Tharman, 59, previously held the Finance Minister position and will return to helm the ministry immediately. The move comes as Heng, 69, undergoes neurosurgery.

site_title: Forex gain pushes Vard back into the black
summary: Vard Holdings reported a net profit of 37 million Norwegian kroner (S$6.25 million) for the first quarter, reversing a net loss of 92 million kroner from the same period last year. The company's operating loss decreased to 5 million kroner, with revenue falling 34% to 2.02 billion kroner. A net foreign exchange gain of 68 million kroner boosted the bottom line, while the yard group's order book stood at 8.58 billion kroner. Vard acknowledged the challenges in the offshore oil and gas market and is working to secure delivery of its current order book.

site_title: Stretching a Hollywood budget in Singapore
summary: Filmmaker Kelvin Tong chose to shoot his horror film, The Faith of Anna Waters, in Singapore instead of the US due to budget constraints and familiarity with the local environment. Tong, who has made supernatural films before, wanted to explore the exorcism subgenre and drew inspiration from real-life cases in Singapore. Despite initial concerns, the film was completed without major issues, and Tong credited his local knowledge and production team for its success. The film, starring Matthew Settle and Elizabeth Rice, is Singapore's first Hollywood-style horror film.

site_title: Sell your old artworks on new website
summary: A new Singapore website, Fickle Walls, allows art collectors to sell their pre-loved artworks at a fair price without auction houses. The site, founded by Yuen Yee Foong, lists artworks for free if in good condition and charges 10-20% commission. It offers a platform for lower-priced works, typically below S$5,000, and provides local shipping. The site's launch has featured 26 paintings by notable artists, including Christine Mak and Tung Yue Nang, with prices ranging from S$190 to S$4,500.
