site_title: EBRD bank trims economic outlook
summary: The European Bank for Reconstruction and Development (EBRD) has revised its economic outlook for its 36-nation investment zone, citing ultra-low oil prices, market volatility, and international tensions. The bank now forecasts 1.4% average economic growth in 2016, down from its previous guidance of 1.6%. The downgrade reflects a decline in oil prices and reduced capital flows to emerging markets. Despite this, the EBRD expects 2.5% growth in 2017. The bank's president, Suma Chakrabarti, is set to be re-elected for a fourth term.

site_title: US$ eases after six straight gains
summary: The US dollar eased against a basket of currencies after six straight days of gains, with the yen and euro gaining ground. The dollar's retreat was attributed to a reluctance to drive it much weaker than US$1.15 to the euro and US$1.45 to the pound, as the US economy remains stronger than its peers. US debt yields continue to drop, weakening the dollar's argument for further gains. The US dollar index fell 0.3% to 94.015, marking a move away from a two-week high.

site_title: Campaigns for Britain to leave EU get biggest donations: watchdog
summary: Campaigns for Britain's EU exit received £8.2 million in donations, surpassing the "In" campaign's £2 million, over 81 days. Leave.EU, led by Peter Hargreaves, received the largest donation of £3.2 million. The Electoral Commission recorded donations from February 1 to April 21.

site_title: Cityneon places out 40 million shares
summary: Cityneon Holdings has announced a share placement of 40 million shares at S$0.55 per share, consisting of 20 million new shares and 20 million vendor shares. The new shares will be offered to strategic investor CMC Holdings and institutional investors to increase liquidity and institutionalize the investor base.

site_title: Best World's net profit jumps in Q1
summary: Best World International reported a net profit of S$5.96 million for Q1 2016, up from S$249,000 a year ago, driven by a 160% surge in revenue to S$35.23 million. The company also announced a sale and purchase agreement to acquire a property for S$10 million to set up a skincare manufacturing facility. Earnings per share increased to 2.71 Singapore cents, up from 0.11 cent previously.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: CDL Q1 profit slips 14.4% on subdued Singapore property development business
summary: CDL posted a 14.4% drop in Q1 net profit to S$105.34 million, largely due to subdued property development business and lower hotel operations. Revenue fell 11.2% to S$723.31 million. The group anticipates overseas development projects to contribute to profit from the second half of 2016. CDL also announced the acquisition of a UK office building redevelopment property for £37.4 million. Earnings per share fell to 11.6 Singapore cents, and net asset value per share dropped to S$9.85.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Indonesia's Asian Games preparations on track: OCA
summary: Indonesia's 2018 Asian Games preparations are on track, according to the Olympic Council of Asia. Despite concerns over venue readiness, Indonesian officials, including Minister of Public Works and Housing Basuki Hadimuljono, assured the OCA that all construction and renovation work would be completed on time. The athletes' village is expected to be ready by November 2017, and the renovation of a major Jakarta stadium should be completed by July 2017. Indonesia has a history of hosting major events with issues, but officials are confident they can deliver the games successfully.

site_title: UK oil industry seen risking strike on job cuts, shift changes
summary: The UK's North Sea oil industry is at risk of a strike due to job cuts and shift changes, which have led to declining morale among offshore workers. The Unite union claims the changes, including a three-week rotation, jeopardize safety. With 65,000 jobs lost since 2014, the industry faces escalating costs and dwindling profits. The last major strike in the industry occurred in 1988 following a fire on a rig. The industry's lobby group, Oil & Gas UK, expects further job losses this year, putting pressure on companies to address workers' concerns.

site_title: Competition will throw up best investors for Myanmar
summary: Myanmar, newly democratic, faces opportunities for foreign investment and private sector development, despite economic constraints. The country has abundant natural resources, unskilled labor, and a favorable location, but struggles with low productivity, inadequate infrastructure, and regulatory uncertainty. To attract investors, Myanmar needs to improve its institutions, infrastructure, and regulatory environment, and move towards political and societal maturity. This will take time, but the country's unique cultural and physical attractions, as well as its booming tourist industry, offer potential for long-term growth and development.

site_title: Probe finds James Monroe's real home
summary: A recent exploration at James Monroe's estate, Highland, in Charlottesville, Virginia, has revealed a larger foundation than previously thought, suggesting a mansion existed instead of the two-room cottage tourists had been visiting. The foundation, approximately 74 feet by 30 feet, was likely the site of Monroe's actual home, which may have burned down after he sold the property. This discovery contradicts decades of tour guides' accounts and sheds new light on the life of the 5th US president.

site_title: Nigeria oil output set to fall to 22-yr low on pipeline outage
summary: Nigeria's oil production is set to fall to a 22-year low due to a pipeline outage caused by an explosion in the Nembe Creek Trunk line. Royal Dutch Shell's local operation declared force majeure on Bonny Light crude exports, cutting output to below 1.5 million barrels per day. The outage, combined with attacks on oil pipelines in the Niger Delta, has pushed oil futures higher. This marks a significant decline from Nigeria's peak oil production of 2 million barrels per day in 2013. The impact is further exacerbated by low oil prices.

images.alt_text: Nigeria's oil production is set to fall to its lowest in more than two decades after Royal Dutch Shell's local operation said it had shut a major pipeline.

site_title: US stocks open lower as Disney, Macy's drag
summary: US stocks opened lower on Wednesday, weighed down by Disney's and Macy's poor results, with the Dow Jones industrial average down 0.35%, the S&P 500 down 0.21%, and the Nasdaq Composite down 0.24%.

site_title: Super Group's Q1 net profit dips 15%
summary: Super Group's Q1 net profit fell 15% to S$11.6 million, driven by lower sales and higher costs. Revenue declined 2% to S$119.4 million, mainly due to a 2% drop in branded consumer sales and a 3% decline in food ingredient sales. Despite a 2% increase in gross profit, operating profit dropped 5% to S$15.6 million due to higher expenses. Earnings per share decreased to 1.04 Singapore cents, and the company's shares closed 0.5 cents lower at 91.5 cents.

site_title: Weak smartphone market, lack of property contribution drag down UE Q1 net profit
summary: United Engineers (UE) reported a 72% drop in Q1 net profit to S$6.9 million, down from S$25 million last year, due to lower revenue recognition from the Eight Riversuites development and Multi-Fineline Electronix (MFlex), which made a loss in the first quarter. Revenue decreased by 35% to S$333.6 million from S$515.3 million last year. The decline was attributed to a slow smartphone market.

site_title: Hong Kong's 'Superman' Li mulls Plan B after O2 deal rejected
summary: Hong Kong billionaire Li Ka-shing's proposed acquisition of UK mobile carrier O2 has been rejected by European Union regulators due to concerns over competition and price increases. The setback comes after a similar deal in Italy was also rejected. Li's company, CK Hutchison Holdings, is now considering alternative plans, including merging its 3 Italia business with VimpelCom's Wind Telecomunicazioni in Italy, but regulators have expressed concerns about the potential impact on mobile pricing. Li may consider exiting the mobile-phone business in the UK and Italy or taking a wait-and-watch approach.

images.alt_text: Hong Kong's "Superman" is facing more kryptonite as he tries to expand his European mobile-phone carrier holdings.

site_title: OECD indicator flags improving outlook in emerging countries
summary: The OECD's monthly leading economic indicator shows signs of improvement in emerging countries, with Brazil and Russia experiencing stable growth and China stabilizing. The indicator, which tracks turning points in the global economy, also suggests easing growth in the US and UK, while the eurozone economy remains stable. The overall OECD reading edged down to 99.6 in March, indicating a slowdown in the US but overall economic stability.

site_title: Ezra subsidiaries land new contract awards, letters of intent worth US$40 million
summary: Ezra Holdings' subsidiaries, EMAS Offshore and EMAS Energy, have secured new contract awards and letters of intent worth US$40 million since Q3 FY2016. EMAS Energy will support an oil major in the Gulf of Thailand, while EMAS Offshore has secured charter contracts in South-east Asia and West Africa. The company's group CEO, Lionel Lee, stated that the recent joint venture transaction and strengthened structure position Ezra for future growth.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 8.74 points to close at 1,644.58, driven by gains in some 467 stocks while 359 lost value. Total traded lots valued at RM1.89 billion were executed.

site_title: Global Palm Resources swings into the red in Q1
summary: Global Palm Resources, an Indonesian palm oil producer, reported a net loss of 2.6 billion rupiah in Q1, down from a net profit of 12.7 billion rupiah in the same period last year. Revenue fell 3% to 86.12 billion rupiah due to lower crude palm oil prices. The firm attributed the decline to volatile crude palm oil prices and rising food requirements from emerging markets, despite strong demand for palm oil from various industries.

site_title: South Beach hotel to be rebranded as JW Marriott Singapore
summary: The 654-room South Beach hotel in Singapore is set to be rebranded as JW Marriott Singapore after City Developments Ltd announced the change in its first quarter results statement. The hotel, which began trading last September, is operated by Marriott International, Inc, following a joint venture with Malaysia's IOI Group. The rebranding marks a significant change for the hotel, which is part of CDL's efforts to expand its luxury hospitality offerings.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's bond market surged as interest rates dropped, with two bank issues securing S$2 billion in orders by early afternoon. Meanwhile, a US tariff announcement on Vietnam caught the country off guard, prompting a call for a lower rate. The Asian garment industry also faces higher US tariffs. In other news, Malaysia is set to seize RM3 billion of assets from Daim Zainuddin, and China's GDP growth is expected to slow, putting pressure on policymakers.

site_title: Haw Par's Q1 profit grows 26.8% to S$17 million
summary: Haw Par Corp's first-quarter net profit rose 26.8% to S$17.1 million, driven by stronger healthcare sales and gains from financial asset disposal. Revenue increased 14.9% to S$52.3 million, with healthcare sales up 17.8% and property revenue improving 4.9%. However, the leisure segment reported a small operating profit due to reduced depreciation. The company expects a challenging business environment, citing softening retail sectors and volatile equity markets.

site_title: Singapore shares close lower as banks, Wilmar drag STI lower
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell 8.28 points to 2,732.87 on Wednesday, marking its 12th loss in 13 sessions, a 7.7% decline. Banks, including OCBC, DBS, and UOB, contributed to the decline, while Wilmar International's shares dropped 3.5% due to a mixed earnings report. The market remains cautious, with traders avoiding stocks and seeking safe havens like bonds.

site_title: Manulife Reit said poised to price US$470m IPO at top end
summary: Manulife US Reit, backed by three US office buildings, is set to price its US$470 million IPO at the top end of its marketed range of 82-83 cents per unit, according to people with knowledge of the matter. This would be Singapore's first IPO above US$100 million since 2015. The trust's cornerstone investors include private banking clients of Credit Suisse and DBS Group Holdings Ltd. The listing is expected to boost Singapore's stock exchange, which had the smallest haul of IPOs among the region's four largest markets in 2015.

site_title: Yanlord's Q1 profit jumps to 260 million yuan
summary: Yanlord Land Group's net profit rose to 260.14 million yuan in the first quarter of 2016, a multiple of its 15.46 million yuan profit in the same period last year. Revenue nearly tripled to 2.85 billion yuan. Chairman and CEO Zhong Sheng Jian attributed the growth to healthy home buyer demand in China and robust pre-sale deliveries, capitalizing on the favorable market environment.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares end lower on China economy doubts
summary: Hong Kong shares fell 0.9% on Wednesday, as investors questioned the sustainability of China's recent economic recovery. The Hang Seng index dropped to 20,055.29 points, with most sectors declining but consumer and materials shares rising over 1%. Mixed April data, weak factory surveys, and surging debt levels have fueled doubts about the recovery's legs, despite strong March data.

site_title: SBS Transit's Q1 profit surges 70% on lower fuel costs
summary: SBS Transit reported a 69.5% surge in Q1 net profit to S$8.08 million, driven by lower fuel and electricity costs. Revenue rose 6.6% to S$263 million, boosted by higher ridership on Downtown Line 2. Fuel and electricity costs fell 31.5%, while staff costs increased due to new hires and higher repair costs. Total operating costs rose 5% despite a slower pace than revenue growth.

site_title: OECD and IEA ponder divorce after years of friction: document
summary: The International Energy Agency (IEA) is considering a possible divorce from its parent body, the Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development (OECD), due to years of friction and disagreements over cooperation with China. The OECD has proposed a separation, citing IEA resistance to OECD rules, particularly regarding China. A separation could complicate funding and governance, but the OECD has offered to assist the IEA during the transition. Member states may prefer to maintain the current status of the IEA rather than making it an independent body or a department of the OECD.

site_title: US wants Japan to refrain from FX action: PM Abe's aide
summary: US policymakers have urged Japan to refrain from intentionally weakening the yen through currency intervention. Japanese financial authorities face a tough decision, with limited options to contain a strong yen, according to Koichi Hamada, a key economic adviser to Prime Minister Shinzo Abe. If Japan intervenes, it may anger the US, but failing to do so could lead to unwelcome yen rises. The yen has risen to an 18-month high against the dollar, with US Treasury monitoring Japan's currency policy. Japan plans to intervene if the yen strengthens to 90-95 per dollar.

site_title: Punters rap nameless Chinese official for stock slump
summary: China's stock market plummeted by nearly 3% after an "authoritative person" quoted in the official newspaper of China's Communist Party warned of excessive credit growth leading to a recession. The article, published in the People's Daily, contradicted previous policies and sparked criticism of anonymous officials' influence on the market. Investors lost over $211 billion in value, with some describing the article as a "blow" to the market and a "blow to investor optimism." The People's Daily did not respond to comments, fueling concerns about the role of official media in shaping market sentiment.

site_title: Cordlife Group posts S$2m loss on fair value changes
summary: Cordlife Group posted a net loss of S$2 million for the three months ended March 31, 2016, reversing a year-ago net profit of S$18.1 million, primarily due to fair value changes. This resulted in a loss per share of 0.79 Singapore cent, compared to a year-ago earnings per share of seven Singapore cents.

site_title: UK's Heathrow says will limit environmental impact of new runway
summary: Heathrow Airport has announced plans to limit the environmental impact of a new runway, including complying with an extended ban on night flights and meeting European air quality rules. The airport, which has been campaigning for 25 years, will operate at reduced hours and meet 11 conditions set by the Airports Commission. This move aims to win over opponents, including local residents and environmentalists. The proposal is part of a larger effort to address concerns about air quality and noise pollution. A decision on the project is expected by the end of July.

site_title: Thai central bank holds key rate, sees higher risks to growth
summary: Thailand's central bank kept its key interest rate at 1.50% on Wednesday, as expected, citing a conducive monetary policy for economic recovery. The economy is expected to expand at a rate close to the previous assessment, but face greater downside risks. Deflation has ended, with annual headline consumer prices rising for the first time in 16 months. The bank is cautious about cutting the policy rate, citing its inability to boost consumption and investment. The Bank of Thailand forecasts economic growth of 3.1% this year, despite uncertainty from the upcoming constitutional referendum.

site_title: UK factory output records biggest annual fall since 2013
summary: British factory output recorded its biggest annual fall in nearly three years, with a 1.9% decline in March compared to the same period last year, according to the Office for National Statistics. The decline was driven by shutdowns in the steel industry due to global overcapacity. Industrial output rose 0.3% in March but was 0.2% lower than a year earlier, with a quarterly decline of 0.4%. The Bank of England is expected to keep interest rates on hold as the UK economy slows down due to the global economic slowdown and the approach of the EU referendum.

site_title: Panama, Lebanon among recent joiners of global tax info sharing deal: OECD
summary: Panama and Lebanon have joined around 100 countries in a global tax information sharing deal, aiming to tackle tax evasion. The agreement, already in the works, was prompted by a major tax scandal in Panama after a leak of confidential documents showed their failure to cooperate. Automatic tax information exchanges are expected to start in September 2018. The Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) has emphasized the need for countries to implement the standards and exchange information to combat tax evasion.

site_title: Grab, AXA introduce usage-based insurance for private-hire car drivers
summary: Grab and AXA Insurance Singapore launched AXA Pay-As-You-Grab (PAYG), a usage-based commercial motor insurance for private-hire car drivers. The policy pays a flat rate of 70% of the base premium, plus an additional $0.06 per km driven on Grab rides, capped at 100% of the base premium. This reduces cost barriers for new drivers and aims to grow the supply pool of part-time drivers, particularly those driving less than 10 hours weekly, who currently make up over 40% of GrabCar drivers.

site_title: Toyota sees first profit drop in five years on yen strength
summary: Toyota Motor Corp. reported a possible 35% decline in annual net income to 1.5 trillion yen ($18.9 billion) due to the strengthening yen, which had previously boosted earnings. The forecast trailed analysts' estimates. The company's President, Akio Toyoda, has overseen three years of record profits, but now faces challenges from production disruptions and US demand growth stalls. Toyota aims to recover and maintain sales ahead of Volkswagen AG.

site_title: China: Stocks close up on consumer, healthcare bets
summary: China stocks rose 0.5% to 3,082.81, and the Shanghai Composite Index gained 0.2% to 2,837.04, as buyers snapped up consumer and healthcare stocks. The recovery comes after recent heavy losses, with the CSI300 index closing modestly higher.

site_title: China will meet economic growth goal this year: vice premier
summary: China's vice premier, Zhang Gaoli, stated that the country's economy will meet its 6.5-7% GDP growth target for 2016 despite facing downward pressure. The M2 money supply slowed in April, but the Chinese economy remains resilient, according to Zhang. China is not resorting to large-scale stimulus and aims to reduce leverage through bankruptcies. The global economic recovery is weak, but China's economy is expected to continue growing, according to Zhang's comments.

site_title: Australia: Shares hit 9-month high, NZ climbs back to record
summary: Australian shares reached a 9-month high, with the S&P/ASX 200 index rising 29.51 points to 5,372.30. New Zealand stocks also rebounded, reaching a record high of 6,944.34. The gains were driven by solid performances from mining giant BHP Billiton.

site_title: South Korea finance minister says yuan-won market in Shanghai to be established in June
summary: South Korea's Finance Minister Yoo Il-ho announced plans to establish a direct yuan-won market in Shanghai by June, following the opening of a similar market in Seoul in 2014. The market aims to increase trade payments in both currencies and reduce exchange rate risks. A meeting between South Korea and China's finance ministers is scheduled for May 27 in Seoul.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks close flat as rally fizzles
summary: Tokyo stocks closed flat on Wednesday, edging up 0.08% to 16,579.01, as a rally fizzled due to a stronger yen and dipping oil prices. The broader Topix index lost 0.04%.

site_title: Europe: Stocks diverge at open
summary: European stock markets diverged at the start of trading on Wednesday, with London's FTSE 100 index falling 0.2% and Frankfurt's DAX 30 index rising 0.1%. The divergence followed large gains in the previous session. Asia equities mostly rose, driven by renewed confidence after last week's sharp sell-offs. World stocks benefited from an upturn in Chinese inflation and possible progress on Greece's bailout.

site_title: Japan to announce action plan to curb tax evasion at G7: sources
summary: Japan plans to unveil an action plan to curb tax evasion at the G7 summit on May 26-27, following the leak of the Panama Papers revealing financial arrangements of wealthy politicians and business leaders. The plan aims to address global tax evasion and money laundering, building on efforts by governments worldwide to investigate financial wrongdoing by the elite. Japan will provide a more detailed roadmap when it hosts the G7 summit.

site_title: "Dim Sum" bond issuers tip toe into expensive market
summary: Dim sum bond issuers in China are cautiously returning to the offshore yuan bond market, with 52.8 billion yuan (S$11.07 billion) worth of bonds maturing in the second quarter, a 45% increase from last year. However, rising default risks and investors' wariness of the Chinese currency are expected to keep borrowing costs high, with issuers seeking higher premiums. Chinese issuers are tentatively dipping back into the market, with some firms opting to refinance debt onshore due to Beijing's tighter foreign exchange curbs.

site_title: Queen caught on camera describing 'very rude' Chinese officials
summary: Queen Elizabeth II made unguarded remarks about China's state visit to the UK last year, describing the Chinese delegation as "very rude" to her ambassador. The Queen's comments were captured on camera at a garden party at Buckingham Palace. The remarks came during a week when Prime Minister David Cameron was also critical of China, calling some countries "fantastically corrupt". The Queen's exchange was seen as a rare glimpse into her private thoughts on the sensitive issue.

images.alt_text: Queen Elizabeth II was caught making unguarded remarks about China's state visit to the UK last year, saying its delegation had been "very rude" to her ambassador.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks pare early loss on foreign buying, won ends higher
summary: South Korean stocks closed 0.1% lower at 1,980.10 points, but pared earlier losses as foreign investors bought a net 70.2 billion won worth of Kospi shares. The won finished 0.4% higher at 1,167.6 to the dollar, reversing some of its early gains as US dollar demand increased.

site_title: Deutsche Boerse CEO touts LSE merger, saying 'size is everything'
summary: Deutsche Boerse's planned $30 billion merger with LSE Group is on track for completion late this year or early 2017, according to CEO Carsten Kengeter. Kengeter stated that the merger's success is crucial for exchange operators, emphasizing the importance of size in the industry. He dismissed concerns that Frankfurt may lose its importance as a financial center, saying that boosting the number of potential users is key.

site_title: Hong Kong Exchange's Q1 net income falls 9% to HK$1.43b
summary: Hong Kong Exchanges & Clearing's (HKEx) Q1 net income fell 9% to HK$1.43 billion due to lower trading turnover and higher costs. Revenue declined 2% to HK$2.75 billion. The exchange's shares have risen 15% from a 2016 low, driven by expectations of a possible China A shares inclusion and the launch of a Shenzhen-Hong Kong stock trading link. Operating expenses increased 19% due to additional headcount and higher costs, leading the exchange to take a more cautious approach on project timing.

site_title: StanChart hires new cyber security chief from Symantec
summary: Standard Chartered has hired Cheri McGuire, former Symantec Corp executive, as its new chief information security officer. McGuire will oversee the bank's information and cyber security governance. The move comes amid global efforts to combat cyber security threats, following high-profile hacking incidents, including the $81 million theft from a Bangladesh central bank account. McGuire replaces Andy Wicks, interim head of information security, and joins from a cyber security firm. The hire is part of the bank's efforts to enhance its cyber security measures in response to mounting concerns about banks' vulnerability to hacking.

site_title: Mitsubishi Motors fuel cheating on 'almost all' Japan models
summary: Mitsubishi Motors admitted to fuel cheating on almost every model sold in Japan over the past 25 years, with dozens of models affected, including sedans and SUVs. Re-testing found the company overstated fuel economy by over 15%. Four models and over 600,000 vehicles have been confirmed involved, with the number expected to rise. The scandal has plunged the automaker into crisis, affecting its financial forecasts and shares, which rose 2.27% after the announcement. Mitsubishi has scheduled a press briefing to discuss its internal investigation.

site_title: Asia: Markets mostly up on revived confidence
summary: Asia markets mostly rose on Wednesday following gains on Wall Street and Europe, driven by revived confidence and a jump in oil prices. Energy firms benefited from the surge in oil prices, while emerging market currencies advanced as investors sought riskier investments. Tokyo's Nikkei rose 0.3%, while Shanghai and Sydney also gained ground. However, Hong Kong slipped 0.8% due to concerns over China's debt levels.

site_title: French finance minister admits to "inappropriate" conduct towards female journalist
summary: French Finance Minister Michel Sapin admitted to behaving inappropriately towards a female journalist, stating he made a comment about her clothing and put his hand on her back during a trip to Davos in 2015. Sapin apologized to the journalist, saying there was no aggressive or sexual intent but the gesture was inappropriate. This comes amid a growing debate about sexual harassment in French politics, following the resignation of lawmaker Denis Baupin over allegations of harassment. Sapin's admission was seen as an effort to address the issue, but critics questioned the sincerity of his apology.

site_title: Takata posts third annual loss in past 4 years on recall costs
summary: Takata Corp, a Japanese auto parts maker, reported its third annual loss in four years due to increased costs from recalls of potentially deadly airbag inflators. The company's net loss for the year ended in March was 13.1 billion yen (S$164.9 million). US transport authorities have announced a recall of up to 40 million more airbags, on top of the 50 million already recalled globally. Takata forecasts a net profit of 13 billion yen for the current year, despite the expanding recall.

site_title: Singapore bond market sizzles as interest rates slide
summary: The Singapore bond market is experiencing a surge in activity as interest rates slide, with two bank issues on Wednesday clinching orders of over S$2 billion. The 10-year non-call 5 issue by Societe Generale and the Basel III perpetual non-call 5 perpetual by United Overseas Bank have drawn significant interest from investors, including funds and banks. Interest rates have stabilized, and the USD/SGD exchange rate has shown more stability, contributing to the market's recovery. The trend is expected to continue if the market holds up, with year-to-date SGD bond volumes up 16% to S$8.2 billion.

site_title: 1MDB bonds decline as deadline for another coupon payment looms
summary: Malaysia's 1Malaysia Development Bhd bonds fell to a two-week low ahead of a $52.4 million interest payment due on Wednesday. The bonds, which mature in 2022, have dropped 1.79 cents on the dollar this month to 100.54 cents. The company defaulted on a $50 million coupon payment last month amid a dispute with Abu Dhabi's IPIC, which co-guarantees the securities. Analysts say the payment is unlikely to be made, citing a lack of changes in the situation. The bond price decline reflects investor concerns over 1MDB's ability to meet its debt obligations.

site_title: Stats ChipPac CFO bemoans 'market neglect' in life after Temasek
summary: Stats ChipPac, Southeast Asia's largest semiconductor assembler, saw its bond prices drop 1.7 US cents after a Moody's rating downgrade due to liquidity pressure. The company's CFO, Woo Kwek Kiong, attributed the decline to "market neglect" despite backing from powerful shareholders, including the Ministry of Finance and China Development Bank. A $200 million infusion from parent Jiangsu Changjiang Electronics Technology Co is expected to be secured, preventing further downgrade.

site_title: Stuck with dangerous dollar dominance, world debt higher than before crash
summary: The world is experiencing alarming bouts of volatility in financial markets due to a fear of higher interest rates and the resulting increase in global debt, now higher than pre-2007-08 crash levels. The US dollar's dominance as the world's main reserve currency is a complicating factor, with the US central bank struggling to adjust monetary policy without transmitting a self-defeating shockwave worldwide. Experts warn that the dollar's role could exacerbate instability by allowing the US to run larger fiscal and current account deficits, and that a more pluralistic system with multiple reserve currencies is needed to address the issue.

site_title: BHP Billiton joins Rio in shifting focus to growth
summary: BHP Billiton has shifted its focus to growth, joining Rio Tinto in marking a change from four years of cost-cutting measures. The mining giant expects to sign off on copper and oil projects next year, with the Spence copper project in Chile now expected to cost less than $2.2 billion. BHP also plans to cut costs, targeting $3.6 billion in savings by June 2017. The company's cost-cutting efforts are seen as well-positioned to positively surprise peers, with UBS noting that BHP is well-positioned to benefit from improving market fundamentals.

site_title: China tech workers asleep on the job - with the boss' blessing
summary: China's tech industry is notorious for its long working hours, with some employees sleeping on the job to meet deadlines. A 40-year-old entrepreneur, Dai Xiang, has installed bunk beds in his office to accommodate workers who need to rest during the day. This practice is common among tech companies, where workers are forced to burn the midnight oil due to the fast-paced industry. Some employees even live at the office, citing the benefits of working long hours as worth the social cost, including missing family time and socializing.

site_title: Allianz confident of meeting targets after strong Q1
summary: Allianz, a German insurance giant, reported strong results in the first quarter, with net profit rising 20.5% to 2.2 billion euros. The company is confident of meeting its full-year targets, aiming for an operating profit of 10.5 billion euros. Despite a decline in underlying operating profit and revenues, the company attributed growth to non-operating gains and lower claims stemming from natural catastrophes in its property and casualty division.

site_title: Clear, crunchy and counterfeit: China's fake jellyfish
summary: China's police have seized a tonne of man-made "jellyfish" made from chemicals, adding to the country's fake food problem. The fake ingredient, popular in China, was found to have high aluminium content, posing health risks. The vendors sold over 10 tonnes before being caught, earning around $36,000. The incident highlights China's food safety scandals, with officials often turning a blind eye to ignore standards and regulations for profit.

site_title: Malaysia's central bank says confident government will honour debt obligations
summary: Malaysia's central bank governor, Muhammad Ibrahim, expressed confidence that the government will honour its debt obligations. The statement comes as 1Malaysia Development Berhad (1MDB) faces a deadline to make a coupon payment on a US$1.75 billion bond. The government's decision on the payment is seen as crucial in improving market sentiments. Despite a previous non-payment of a US$50.3 million coupon, Ibrahim believes the government will honour its debt obligations, citing the resolution of 1MDB as a positive factor.

site_title: New Zealand dollar rises in relief rally, Aussie friendless
summary: The New Zealand dollar rose to US$0.6810 after the Reserve Bank of New Zealand failed to curb the country's hot housing market in its six-monthly financial stability report. The RBNZ expressed concern but stopped short of tightening lending, prompting a relief rally. In contrast, the Australian dollar struggled due to sliding iron ore prices.

site_title: Eight in 10 Singaporeans plan to maintain travel expenditure in 2016: survey
summary: A survey by Wyndham Rewards found that 81% of Singaporeans plan to maintain their travel expenditure in 2016, despite concerns about the economy. 68% said they would be more cost-conscious, but 36% are willing to spend half or more of their discretionary budget on travel. 44% plan a once-in-a-lifetime international trip, while a third intend to travel domestically in 2016.

images.alt_text: Singaporeans are still willing to spend on travel, despite fears of a softening economy, a study by Wyndham Hotel Group's loyalty division, Wyndham Rewards, shows.

site_title: US dollar gives back gains after rise to two-week highs, yen firms
summary: The US dollar fell 0.2% to 94.126, moving away from its two-week high of 94.356 after investors locked in gains following intervention warnings from Japanese officials. The dollar index remained above a 15-month trough of 91.919 set on May 3.

site_title: S&P positive on Indonesia economy reforms, finance minister says
summary: Indonesia's finance minister, Bambang Brodjonegoro, said S&P Global Ratings expressed positive views on the country's reform efforts during a visit to Jakarta. The company may raise Indonesia's sovereign rating, potentially enabling more funds to invest in the country. This move could boost Indonesia's bonds and currency. S&P's decision follows its previous statement in December that it may raise Indonesia to investment grade within a year.

site_title: Volkswagen's other speciality: curry sausage
summary: Volkswagen, known for its Beetle camper van and engine-rigging scandal, has a lesser-known specialty: curry sausage. The pork sausage, smothered in spiced ketchup and topped with curry powder, has been a workman's favorite for decades and is produced in large quantities at the company's headquarters in Wolfsburg. The sausage is a beloved snack among employees, and VW offers it in canteens worldwide, including the US, India, and China. The company's master butcher, Francesco Lo Presti, has been perfecting the recipe for over 15 years, and the sausage is now listed as an official VW component.

site_title: Singapore and Liaoning ink 16 projects at Singapore-Liaoning Economic and Trade Council meeting
summary: Singapore and Liaoning province in China signed 16 projects worth various amounts at the 9th Singapore-Liaoning Economic and Trade Council meeting. The projects include high-tech manufacturing and modern services, with almost half being small and medium-sized enterprise (SME) projects. The meeting was co-chaired by Singapore's Minister for Social and Family Development and Liaoning's Governor, and marked a significant increase in trade and investment ties between the two nations. The agreements are expected to boost Liaoning's economic development and position it as a key hub for North-east Asia cooperation.

images.alt_text: Mindy Tan

Singapore and Liaoning have inked 16 projects spanning high-technology manufacturing and modern services at the ninth Singapore-Liaoning Economic and Trade Council (SLETC) meeting which was co-chaired by Minister for Social and Family Development Tan Chuan-Jin and Liaoning Governor Chen Qiufa.

site_title: China's yuan edges up in line with midpoint, US dollar moves
summary: China's yuan edged up on Wednesday, firming in line with the central bank's midpoint and the US dollar's movements. The market remained quiet with no major market-moving news expected. The yuan's fluctuation is expected to continue in line with the midpoint and inversely to the dollar's global performance. This follows a period of volatility in global markets.

site_title: India's bid to bring home tycoon Mallya rebuffed; to keep trying
summary: India's attempt to bring back debt-strapped tycoon Vijay Mallya from Britain has failed. Despite revoking his diplomatic passport, the British government has told India that Mallya does not require a valid passport to remain in the country. The UK has offered assistance, including mutual legal assistance or extradition, as Mallya faces allegations of financial wrongdoing. Mallya has denied charges and offered a settlement to his creditors, which they have refused to consider. India will continue to seek his repatriation to face his creditors.

site_title: Japan PM could make final decision on sales tax after G7 summit: LDP lawmaker
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe may make a final decision on a planned sales tax increase from 8% to 10% in April 2017, following the G7 summit. The decision rests with Abe, amid speculation that he could postpone the tax hike due to the stagnant economy. LDP lawmakers plan to submit their own economic proposal to Abe next week, potentially influencing his decision.

site_title: Ahead of inauguration, China says Taiwan to blame for any crisis
summary: China has warned that Taiwan's new government, led by pro-independence President Tsai Ing-wen, will be to blame for any crisis with China that arises after its inauguration. Tensions have risen since the DPP's landslide victory in January, driven by rising anti-China sentiment. Beijing's comments add pressure ahead of Tsai's inauguration, following a period of rapprochement under the outgoing Nationalist government.

site_title: Temer: the man poised to be Brazil's next president
summary: Brazil's Vice-President Michel Temer is set to become the country's next president after the Senate opens an impeachment trial against President Dilma Rousseff on Thursday. Temer, a 75-year-old constitutional scholar, has lined up a business-friendly cabinet and plans to pivot away from left-leaning policy to tackle the country's economic recession. However, he faces a tall task in restoring stability, with popularity ratings as low as 2% and many of his allies implicated in corruption.

site_title: Aircraft lessor BOC Aviation to launch US$1.1b HK IPO on Monday: IFR
summary: BOC Aviation, a Singapore-based aircraft leasing company, plans to launch a US$1.1 billion initial public offering (IPO) in Hong Kong on Monday, with a fixed price listing. The company will sell new shares to raise funds for aircraft purchases and working capital, with 50% of the shares to be bought by cornerstone investors. This is a rare fixed-price flotation, with most IPOs setting an indicative range before deciding on the final pricing.

site_title: Three more signs smartphone downturn going from bad to worse
summary: Asian suppliers' earnings reports signal a worsening smartphone market, contradicting investor hopes for improvement after Apple's shaky earnings report. Three suppliers released back-to-back reports, indicating a decline in the industry. This suggests smartphone makers and other companies will face challenges ahead, despite potential long-term growth. The reports are a warning sign for investors and the broader tech industry, highlighting the ongoing decline in smartphone sales.

site_title: Australian regulator to sever its swaps benchmark relationship
summary: The Australian Financial Markets Association (AFMA) plans to sever its 30-year relationship with the bank bill swap rate (BBSW) due to ongoing rigging allegations and a complex benchmark setting process. This decision reflects a global shift towards more robust benchmarks with stronger defences against manipulation. The move comes as the country's financial watchdog pushes ahead with litigation against two major banks over alleged benchmark rigging. The exit marks a significant shift in the benchmark-setting process in Australia.

site_title: Oil declines as US stockpile gains counter Nigeria disruption
summary: Oil prices declined as US crude stockpiles rose, counteracting supply disruptions in Nigeria. US inventories increased by 3.45 million barrels last week, the highest level since 1929. Royal Dutch Shell and Chevron are evacuating workers from the Niger Delta due to deteriorating security. Oil prices have rebounded after a slump earlier this year, with West Texas Intermediate falling 0.7% to $44.34 a barrel. The market has rallied amid US production cuts, with prices gaining 70% from a low in February.

site_title: Philippine exports extend fall for 12th month in March
summary: Philippine exports dropped 15.1% in March to $4.61 billion, the 12th consecutive month of decline, mainly due to weak demand in the US and China. Seven of the country's top 10 exports declined, with electronics exports rising only 1%. Total exports in the first quarter fell 8.4%. Economists expect the Philippine economy to grow 6.2-6.3% in the first quarter, with government spending on infrastructure projects offsetting trade weakness.

site_title: Australia holds five suspected of plotting sailing trip to join Islamic State
summary: Australian police have detained five men suspected of planning to sail to Indonesia and the Philippines to join Islamic State in Syria. The men, aged 21-33, were held after towing a 7m boat from Melbourne to Cairns in Queensland. They face up to a decade in prison under Australia's tough new security powers. The detentions come as Australia has been on high alert for attacks by home-grown radicals, and approximately 100 people have left the country to fight alongside Islamic State in Syria.

site_title: Hyperloop One raises funds, to test futuristic transport system this year
summary: Hyperloop One, a Los Angeles company, has secured $80 million in funding to test its futuristic transportation system by the end of this year. The hyperloop, which can reach speeds of up to 750 miles per hour, would use maglev technology to levitate pods and reduce friction. CEO Rob Lloyd aims to dispel criticism that the technology is unproven, likening it to the emergence of the US railroad system. The company plans to conduct a full system test and is considering locations for its first system, with potential applications in ports and cargo transportation.

site_title: Disney closes Infinity unit in retreat from video games
summary: Disney closes its Infinity video-game business, citing a $147 million charge for severance costs and writing off its investment. The company will shut its Salt Lake City studio and lay off 300 employees, ending its efforts to develop games on its own. Instead, Disney will rely on licensed games, such as those from Electronic Arts. This decision comes as a surprise to analysts and marks a loss for Disney's "toys to life" games, which were pioneered by Activision Blizzard's Skylanders franchise.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open flat on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened flat on Wednesday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index up 0.230 points to 1636.440. Volume reached 50.9 million lots worth RM11.7 million, with 112 gainers outnumbering 47 losers.

site_title: BOJ appoints Eiji Maeda new executive director of international affairs
summary: The Bank of Japan appointed Eiji Maeda as its new executive director of international affairs, replacing his previous role as chief economist. Maeda's appointment comes amid concerns over the BOJ's monetary policies, particularly its quantitative easing and negative interest rates, which some argue favor Japan's exports by weakening the yen. The BOJ maintained its monetary policy steady last month, defying market expectations.

images.alt_text: The Bank of Japan said it appointed Eiji Maeda as the central bank's new executive director of international affairs, responsible for communicating with other central banks and arranging financial meetings.

site_title: Duel between Russia and Ukraine marks 60 years of Eurovision
summary: Eurovision marks its 60th birthday with a highly anticipated musical duel between Russia and Ukraine, two former rivals and allies. The competition aims to be a song contest free of politics, but tensions are high due to the ongoing conflict between the two nations. Ukraine's contestant Susana Jamaladinova's song "1944" has sparked controversy, with Russian officials and politicians claiming it is intended to denigrate Russia. Despite this, the song has been deemed acceptable by Eurovision's organisers. The competition will feature 26 artists from 42 countries, with France's Amir Haddad and Sweden's Mans Zelmerlow among the favourites to win.

site_title: Singapore shares open higher on Wednesday
summary: Singapore share prices opened 0.58% higher on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index rising 15.81 points to 2,756.96. The rally followed gains in the US and Tokyo, driven by a rebound in commodities. This is the fifth consecutive day of gains for Singapore stocks, ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Update: Clinton loses to Sanders in coal state of West Virginia
summary: US Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton lost to Bernie Sanders in the West Virginia primary, a setback that may signal trouble for her with working-class voters in the US Rust Belt. Despite this, Clinton remains heavily favored to become the Democratic candidate in the November election. The loss may impact her chances in key states such as Ohio and Pennsylvania, where she will face Republican candidate Donald Trump in the general election.

site_title: Australia, NZ: Australia shares hit nine-month highs, NZ climbs back to a record
summary: Australia's S&P/ASX 200 index rose 0.6% to a nine-month high of 5,375.6, driven by gains in mining giant BHP Billiton. New Zealand's S&P/NZX 50 index also climbed, reaching a record high of 6,953.9, after a late April fall. Investors were encouraged by Wall Street's best one-day gain in two months and positive outlooks from BHP Billiton and CSR. Only 12 stocks in the index were in negative territory, with the big four banks showing mixed results.

site_title: New Zealand central bank says "increasingly concerned" about soaring house prices
summary: New Zealand's central bank Governor Graeme Wheeler expressed concern over the nation's overheated housing market, citing record-high home prices in April. The RBNZ may slow further monetary easing due to housing inflation, with analysts expecting a cautious approach. The central bank will consider macro-prudential tools to curb lending, including debt-to-income speed limits, and will analyze data before introducing new measures. Housing prices rose 1.4% in April, with sales volumes increasing 12.8% seasonally. The concern is not limited to Auckland, with house price pressures building up elsewhere in the country.

site_title: US probes contracts between drugmakers, pharmacy benefit managers
summary: The US Attorney's Office for the Southern District of New York is investigating contracts between US drugmakers and pharmacy benefit managers (PBMs), seeking information about their relationships over the past decade. Companies such as Johnson & Johnson, Merck & Co, and Endo International have received civil investigative demands, while Express Scripts Holding Co and CVS Health have not commented. The probe follows a $390 million settlement by Novartis AG last year, and comes amid scrutiny of the sector over kickbacks and billing practices. The investigation aims to address the rising cost of new medications and the practices of PBMs.

site_title: Trump wins West Virginia, Sanders takes early lead
summary: US presidential hopefuls Donald Trump and Bernie Sanders secured victories in the West Virginia primary. Trump won the Republican contest, securing 34 delegates, while Sanders took the lead in the Democratic primary, ahead of Hillary Clinton. Clinton is close to securing the 2,383 delegates needed to win the nomination. Trump is now 1,237 delegates away from clinching the Republican nomination.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks rally at open
summary: Hong Kong and Shanghai stocks rallied at the open on Wednesday, with the Hang Seng Index up 0.52% and the Shanghai Composite Index up 0.39%. This follows a rally in New York and Europe and a rise in oil prices. The Shenzhen Composite Index also gained 0.55%. The gains come despite uncertainty surrounding US trade policies and the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic.

site_title: Asia: Shares set to extend US rally as copper rises; kiwi gains
summary: Global stocks are set to extend their US rally as commodity prices recover, with copper rising and oil holding above $44 a barrel. New Zealand's dollar rebounds from a six-week low, while Japan's Nikkei 225 futures signal gains of at least 0.1%. The rebound follows a selloff last week that erased over $1 trillion in value amid concerns over global growth and the effectiveness of central-bank stimulus.

site_title: Football: Man Utd bus 'smashed up' before West Ham game
summary: Manchester United's team bus was pelted with cans and bottles by fans before the team's last game at West Ham's Boleyn Ground, delaying kick-off for 45 minutes. The bus sustained gaping holes in its protective glass windows. Two people were injured in the incident, which involved chanting fans and smoke bombs. Authorities launched an investigation into the incident, which occurred near the stadium. The game eventually took place, with Manchester United winning 3-1.

images.alt_text: English football authorities launched an investigation after fans pelted Manchester United's team bus with cans and bottles, injuring two people and delaying the last ever game at West Ham's Boleyn Ground.

site_title: Goldman raises gold forecast while retaining bearish outlook
summary: Goldman Sachs raised its gold forecast to $1,200, $1,180, and $1,150 an ounce for 3, 6, and 12 months, respectively. The bank cut its US Federal Reserve rate hike expectations to 50 basis points from 100 basis points. Despite the revision, Goldman remains bearish on gold's prospects due to limited upside risks and potential catalysts for moderation, including a more hawkish Fed and dollar appreciation. Gold has surged 20% this year and currently trades around $1,270.

site_title: Tokyo: Stocks open higher following US gains
summary: Tokyo stocks opened higher on Wednesday, following US gains. The Nikkei-225 index rose 171.53 points, or 1.04%, to 16,736.72, while the Topix index gained 13.05 points, or 0.98%, to 1,347.95. The gains were attributed to an upturn in Chinese inflation and a rebound in commodities, particularly oil prices.

site_title: Seoul: Stocks edge down amid market uncertainty, won recovers
summary: South Korean stocks eased 0.5% on Wednesday amid market uncertainty, despite a recovering won. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (KOSPI) fell to 1,973.37 points. Analysts await comments from Federal Reserve officials and South Korea's central bank decision on interest rates this week for clues on future policy moves. Foreigners sold 35 billion won worth of KOSPI shares, while electronics manufacturer LG Electronics Inc fell 3.7% and web portal operator Naver Corp fell 2.1%. The won strengthened against the greenback as global oil prices and equities rose overnight.

site_title: Multiple stabbings in Massachusetts town, 2 killed, attacker shot dead
summary: A suspect stabbed at least four people, killing two, in Massachusetts, before an off-duty security officer shot him to death. The stabbings occurred at a home and a shopping mall, with the suspect driving a car into the glass entrance of a Macy's store. Police said there was no nexus to terrorism, and the motive remains under investigation. The attack was reported in Taunton, south of Boston, with no ongoing threat to the public.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks track regional markets higher; TSMC, Hon Hai inch up
summary: Taiwan's main stock index rose 0.4% to 8,187.87, following regional markets higher. Heavyweights TSMC and Hon Hai Precision, the world's top contract chip maker and world's biggest electronics component maker, respectively, saw shares increase 0.7% and 0.3%. The electronics subindex rose 0.5% and the financials subindex gained 0.2%. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to T$32.509 per US dollar.

site_title: Loyz welcomes new controlling shareholder, announces board and management changes
summary: Loyz Energy welcomes Wave Link LP as a new controlling shareholder, acquiring 9.85% stake in the company. Wave Link's investment focus on the oil and gas sector is driven by Loyz's proven reserves and low production costs. Strategic board and management changes have been made, including the appointment of new CEO Jeffrey Pang and chairman William Teo. Pang aims to improve cash flows and boost production, with plans to divest non-core assets and focus on strategic options to create value for shareholders.

site_title: Big oil unexpectedly backs newest non-fossil fuels
summary: Big oil companies are investing in non-fossil fuels, with Exxon Mobil partnering with a carbon-dioxide emissions capture company, Total SA buying a battery maker, and Enbridge Inc investing in offshore wind farms. This marks a shift towards diversification as crude prices struggle to recover and growth projections for renewables soar. Oil giants are recognizing the need to invest in low-carbon sources of energy to thrive in the long term, with investments totaling over $10 billion in ethanol and other biofuels between 2005 and 2013.

images.alt_text: Big oil is dipping a few more toes into clean energy.

site_title: Condo rents flat, rental volume slumps 10% in April: SRX Property
summary: Singapore condominium and apartment rental volumes slumped 10% in April, according to SRX Property. Rents remained flat in the city area, rose 0.1% in the city fringe, and decreased 0.1% in the suburbs. Year-over-year, rents dropped 5.4% from April 2015 and 16.1% from their peak in January 2013. Public housing rents also fell 0.6% in April, down 4.3% from April 2015 and 9.9% from their peak in August 2013.

images.alt_text: Rentals of private condominiums and apartments were flat in April, compared with March.

site_title: Blockbusters boost Disney profits but cable revenues fall
summary: Disney's second-quarter earnings rose 1.7% to $2.1 billion, driven by strong ticket sales from Star Wars and Zootopia, but cable revenues fell 2% to $4.0 billion. Analysts worry about the impact of mobile media and streaming on ESPN, a key cable television business. Disney's shares fell 6.4% to $99.81 after the earnings release. Despite this, the company's operating earnings in the studio entertainment business rose 27% to $542 million.

site_title: NZ central bank says risks to financial stability increasing
summary: New Zealand's central bank, the Reserve Bank of New Zealand, has reported that risks to financial stability have increased in the past six months. The outlook for the global economy has deteriorated, dairy prices remain low, and housing market imbalances continue to rise. The bank is closely monitoring developments and may consider further financial policy measures to assess the situation.

site_title: Oxley's placement of 4-year 5.15% bonds oversubscribed within one day
summary: Oxley Holdings' retail bond offering of 4-year, 5.15% bonds was oversubscribed within one day, with valid applications exceeding S$25 million. The placement received S$25 million in principal amount, reallocated from the public offer of up to S$125 million. The bonds are expected to be issued on May 18 and start trading on the Singapore Exchange on May 19.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Loyz Energy, Oxley, SingPost, Fraser and Neave, Wilmar
summary: Loyz Energy welcomed a new controlling shareholder, Wave Link LP, with a 16.7% stake, after an existing shareholder Jit Sun Investments acquired 9.85% stake. Oxley Holdings' retail bond offering was oversubscribed on its first day, with S$25 million reallocated from the public offer to the placement. SingPost reported a 196.4% jump in net profit to S$105.38 million in the first quarter. Fraser and Neave's second-quarter net profit slumped 54.1% due to a reclassification of profits from its brewery business in Myanmar. Wilmar International's net profit grew 3.2% to US$239.4 million despite a drop in revenue.

site_title: Half US$370b in coal assets globally may be useless: Gadfly commentary
summary: A significant portion of the US$370 billion in coal assets globally may become economically useless due to the rapidly shifting climate. With each of the last 11 months being the hottest on record, the world is approaching a 400 parts per million carbon dioxide level, potentially leading to 2°C temperature increases. This shift may render coal assets, such as mines and infrastructure, uneconomical. The increasing cost of coal production and the decline in demand due to climate change could lead to significant financial losses for coal companies.

site_title: Hong Kong ETF shows global traders just don't like city's stocks
summary: Hong Kong stocks are experiencing a surge in outflows from the iShares MSCI Hong Kong ETF, with a net US$142 million pulled out in May. This marks the 11th straight month of net outflows and the longest decline on record. Despite the underlying stock index falling 2.6% in May, investors have been net sellers even in months when the index rallied. The decline is attributed to concerns over China's slowdown, a dysfunctional political system, and a predicted 20% decline in house prices.

images.alt_text: Whether Hong Kong stocks rally or slump, investors in the biggest US exchange-traded fund tracking the equities just want out.

site_title: UFC parent in talks to sell the business: ESPN
summary: UFC parent Zuffa LLC is in advanced talks to sell the business, with a winning bid expected to value the company between $3.5 billion and $4 billion. At least four bidders have submitted offers, with Chinese conglomerate Dalian Wanda Group leading the way. The company is owned by brothers Lorenzo and Frank Fertitta, who founded Zuffa in 2001. The sale would mark a significant change for the mixed martial arts promotion company, which has been a major player in the sports industry. The deal's outcome is pending.

site_title: Data shows Zika virus stays longer in urine than blood: US CDC
summary: The US Centers for Disease Control and Prevention (CDC) updated its diagnostic testing guidelines for the Zika virus, recommending urine testing be conducted less than 14 days after symptoms start, as the virus can last longer in urine than blood. This change comes as the World Health Organization declared the Zika outbreak an international health emergency in February. Zika infections in pregnant women have been linked to microcephaly and other debilitating disorders. The CDC's updated guidelines provide adequate evidence of infection through either blood or urine testing.

site_title: Sharon Osbourne confirms Ozzy split, looks to new chapter
summary: Sharon Osbourne has confirmed her split from husband Ozzy Osbourne after 33 years of marriage. The metal icon, 67, has denied any relapse to past substance abuse issues, sparking speculation of an affair. Sharon, 63, said she's "getting to the last chapter" of her life and plans to carefully consider her future, citing Beyonce's album Lemonade as an inspiration. The Osbournes' marriage was featured in an MTV reality show, and Sharon will continue to manage Ozzy's career and their joint home, but has left the Los Angeles mansion.

site_title: RBNZ assessing whether more housing market restrictions needed
summary: New Zealand's central bank, the Reserve Bank of New Zealand (RBNZ), is closely monitoring the nation's booming housing market to decide whether further restrictions are needed. The housing market has seen a 12% national price rise in April, with Auckland prices increasing 1.5% and Wellington prices 2.9% over the same period. The RBNZ is concerned about imbalances in the market, which could pose a risk to lenders and the financial system if property prices collapse. Governor Graeme Wheeler has already cut the official cash rate to a record-low 2.25% to curb demand.

site_title: French minister eyes shale import ban as US LNG exports build
summary: France's Energy Minister Segolene Royal considers banning imports of US shale gas due to environmental risks. The US is increasing LNG exports to Europe, including to companies like Engie and Total, which have contracts with Cheniere Energy. If the ban is implemented, French contract holders could swap their cargoes with other countries, such as Spain, or switch to conventional liquefied gas. Cheniere's Sabine Pass liquefaction plant is expected to start shipping to France in 2018 under a five-year contract.

site_title: Vale looking at selling US$10b of its core assets, CEO says
summary: Vale SA, the world's largest iron-ore producer, is considering selling US$10 billion of its core assets by the end of 2017 to reduce its debt load. CEO Murilo Ferreira announced the plan, following a US$8.57 billion fourth-quarter net loss, as the company seeks to cut debt amid sluggish demand. Vale aims to raise US$4 billion to US$5 billion this year through the sale of non-core businesses, including energy assets and iron-ore carriers. The company's efforts to slash debt have been complicated by plans to start production at its US$14 billion S11D project in northern Brazil.

site_title: Ted Cruz rules out third-party presidential bid
summary: Ted Cruz ruled out a third-party presidential bid against Donald Trump, stating he has no interest in mounting a rival campaign. Cruz acknowledged disappointment over his loss, but emphasized the need for a wake-up call to Washington DC. He suspended his campaign after Trump's win in Indiana and will return to the US Senate. Cruz refused to endorse Trump, leaving it to the voters to determine their support, and vowed to continue promoting the conservative movement.

site_title: People uprooted within states by conflict hits record in 2015: aid group
summary: A record 40.8 million people were displaced within their own countries by conflict and violence in 2015, with Yemen recording the most cases of newly displaced people, at 2.2 million. This number is twice that of people who have become refugees by crossing international borders. The Internal Displacement Monitoring Centre attributed the increase to Saudi-led air strikes, economic blockades, and natural disasters. The UN refugee agency estimates the total number of forcibly displaced people worldwide may have surpassed 60 million in 2015, driven by the Syrian war and other conflicts.

site_title: Health service plans poorly, raising costs, UK lawmakers say
summary: UK lawmakers say the National Health Service in England risks raising costs and forcing patients to wait longer due to "poor workforce planning," leaving it reliant on temporary agency staff. The shortfall of 50,000 nurses and doctors is attributed to unrealistic efficiency targets. The government's seven-day-a-week NHS policy is also criticized for lacking a clear funding plan. The Public Accounts Committee recommends considering workforce implications for new health policies and calls for a report on the seven-day NHS by December. This could lead to longer waiting times and increased costs for patients.

site_title: US: Stocks jump as commodities rebound; Brazil assets advance
summary: US stocks surged, jumping 222 points, as commodities rebounded, easing bearish sentiment. The Dow Jones Industrial Average rose 1.3% for its largest gain since March 11. The S&P 500 advanced 1.3% and European shares climbed to a three-week high. Commodities, including crude, nickel, and zinc, rebounded after a selloff, driven by optimism on global growth and emerging markets. Brazil's real and assets advanced, with the process to oust President Dilma Rousseff appearing back on track.

site_title: Saudi gives Spanish firms more time to finish high-speed railway
summary: Saudi Arabia has given a Spanish consortium 14 months to complete the high-speed railway linking Mecca and Medina, pushing the opening to the first quarter of 2018. The project, worth 6.7 billion euros, has faced technical difficulties and disagreements among consortium members over costs and responsibilities. The extension comes after Spanish firms complained of delays in receiving payments from Saudi Arabia, which is facing a budget squeeze due to low oil prices. The project's completion will improve transport connections between Islam's holiest cities during the annual hajj pilgrimage.

site_title: Facebook denies anti-conservative bias, censorship
summary: Facebook has denied allegations of anti-conservative bias and censorship, following a report from Gizmodo that a former news curator claimed the company omitted articles from conservative outlets from its trending news sidebar. Facebook's vice president of search, Tom Stocky, stated that the company's algorithm determines popularity and is audited by review team members to ensure neutrality and consistency. The company emphasized that it encourages robust political discussion from all sides and does not prioritize one viewpoint over another. Facebook also denied manipulating the #BlackLivesMatter hashtag to make it a trending topic.

site_title: Uber and union agree to form drivers guild in New York city
summary: Uber has agreed to form a guild for 35,000 drivers in New York City, allowing them to negotiate with the ride-hailing company. The guild, affiliated with the International Association of Machinists District 15, will have limited power to resolve disputes and will not be able to collectively bargain. The agreement includes monthly meetings with drivers and access to discounted benefits, but drivers have expressed concerns about issues such as low fares, tips, and deactivation policies. The arrangement may set a model for other states, with the American Federation of Labor and Congress of Industrial Organizations calling it a "tone-setter for the rest of the country."

site_title: Yen down as Japanese officials talk forex intervention
summary: The Japanese yen retreated on Tuesday after Finance Minister Taro Aso reiterated warnings about intervening in the foreign exchange market to counter a surge in the yen's value. The comments followed similar warnings from Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, prompting investors to pare exposure to the yen. The British pound climbed against the dollar and euro ahead of the Bank of England meeting, while the dollar and euro charged higher against the yen. The risk of actual intervention remains low, but the comments have had a temporary impact on the yen's value.

site_title: Canadian towns scramble to take precautions against wildfire
summary: Canadian towns in northern Alberta are taking precautions against wildfires amid hot weather and dry vegetation. A wildfire forced 88,000 residents to evacuate Fort McMurray, growing to 229,000 hectares. Communities are clearing dead wood, pruning trees, and banning open fires. Some towns are installing sprinklers and enforcing vehicle bans. Experts warn that the risk is not limited to Fort McMurray, with nearly every town in the forest at risk. The buildup of dead organic matter and dry conditions have increased the risk of wildfires.

site_title: French government to face no-confidence vote over labour law
summary: France's Socialist government will face a no-confidence vote on Thursday after bypassing parliament and passing a labour reform bill amid massive street protests. The bill, which makes it easier for employers to hire and fire workers, has sparked opposition from within the government and among parliamentarians. Two right-wing parties have filed a no-confidence motion, requiring 226 of 288 votes to topple the government. The move is seen as a desperate attempt by President Francois Hollande, facing a re-election bid with a 13% approval rating, to pass a key piece of legislation.

site_title: 'Fantastically corrupt' nations join London summit
summary: British Prime Minister David Cameron will push for global action on corruption at a London summit attended by leaders of Nigeria and Afghanistan, amid public outrage over the Panama Papers leaks. The summit aims to tackle money laundering, anonymous companies, and offshore tax havens. Despite some watered-down language, campaigners hope for concrete action, with Transparency International urging governments to "expose corruption wherever it is found."

site_title: Parties at centre of US$81m cyber heist pledge cooperation
summary: US$81 million was stolen from a Bangladesh central bank account at the New York Fed in a cyber heist. Federal Reserve Bank of New York President William Dudley, Bangladesh Bank governor Fazle Kabir, and representatives from global messaging network Swift met in Basel, Switzerland, to discuss the incident. They pledged cooperation to recover the funds and bring the perpetrators to justice. The parties agreed to pursue jointly common goals, including recovering the stolen funds and protecting the global financial system from cyber attacks. Investigations by the US Federal Bureau of Investigation and Bangladesh police are ongoing.

site_title: US beer icon Budweiser to rename itself 'America', for a while
summary: US beer brand Budweiser is temporarily renaming itself 'America' for the 2016 presidential election campaign, starting May 23 and running to November 8. The rebranding aims to inspire drinkers to celebrate America and Budweiser's shared values of freedom and authenticity. The move is part of a summer-long campaign, "America is in Your Hands," which encourages people to embrace the country's optimism. The change will not be permanent and is an unconventional move for the brand, owned by Belgium-based AB InBev.

site_title: Nasa says 1,284 new planets found by Kepler telescope
summary: NASA announced the discovery of 1,284 new planets outside our solar system using the Kepler space telescope, more than doubling the number of known exoplanets. The new planets include nearly 550 rocky planets like Earth, with nine orbiting in their star's habitable zone, increasing the total to 21 potentially harboring life. The discovery confirms that exoplanets may be more common than stars, and highlights the need for future missions to explore the conditions of these planets and determine if life exists.

site_title: Brazil's Rousseff undone by hubris, economic missteps
summary: Brazil's President Dilma Rousseff will be stripped of office if the Senate votes to put her on trial for breaking budgetary laws, amid the country's worst recession since the 1930s. Rousseff faces no allegations of personal enrichment but is accused of obstructing a corruption investigation at state-run oil company Petrobras, where she chaired the board from 2003 to 2010. Her stubbornness, economic mismanagement, and self-isolation are cited as key factors in her downfall, with many Brazilians turning against her due to the recession and Petrobras scandal.

site_title: French presidential hopeful Juppe says would scrap 35-hour week, wealth tax
summary: French presidential hopeful Alain Juppe announced plans to scrap France's 35-hour working week and wealth tax if elected in 2017. Juppe aims to cut public spending by 80-100 billion euros and reduce payroll and corporate taxes. He also plans to increase the retirement age to 65 and cap welfare subsidies. Juppe's economic platform is seen as a key factor in his election chances, but his past unpopular prime minister role may impact his image. This move is seen as a departure from his previous stance, which was met with strikes and protests in the 1990s.

site_title: Fullerton Health to raise S$300m in proposed SGX listing
summary: Fullerton Health, a Singapore-based regional healthcare provider, plans to raise S$300 million through a listing on the Singapore Exchange (SGX). The company, which owns 200 clinics and facilities and has 8,000 associate units, has a pro forma market capitalization of S$1.5 billion. The IPO is expected to be priced in line with or at a premium to competitors, with about a third of shares going to global cornerstone investors. The proceeds will be used to fund regional expansion.

site_title: Marriott's bid for Starwood challenged in suit by hotel owners
summary: Marriott International Inc. faces a lawsuit from hotel owners in Chicago and New York, who claim the acquisition of Starwood Hotels & Resorts Inc. would violate exclusivity agreements. The lawsuit, filed in New York state court, seeks to block the deal, which would create the world's largest hotel operator by room count. The owners argue that the merger would unfairly eat into their business, particularly at the Sheraton Grand Chicago and Westin Times Square. The deal, valued at $12.9 billion, is scheduled to close mid-year.

site_title: It's Hillary's presidential race to lose this year
summary: A recent opinion poll suggests Hillary Clinton has a significant lead over Donald Trump in the presidential election, with many experts believing she has a better-than-50% chance of winning. However, some analysts point to the "Hillary Effect," a phenomenon where voters, particularly women, may be reluctant to admit to pollsters that they support Clinton due to her reputation for being a strong female candidate. Trump's poor approval ratings, especially among women, Hispanics, and African Americans, also pose a challenge for his campaign.

site_title: Bangladesh executes top Islamist leader for war crimes: minister
summary: Bangladesh executed Motiur Rahman Nizami, the leader of the Jamaat-e-Islami party, for war crimes committed during the country's 1971 war of independence with Pakistan. The execution, carried out just days after a court dismissed his final appeal, has sparked fears of violence in the volatile Muslim-majority nation. Nizami was the fifth and highest-ranked opposition leader to be executed for war crimes, despite global criticism of the trials. The move has been met with celebrations from secular protesters, while the Islamist party has called a nationwide strike in protest.

site_title: Gold near 2-week low on firm dollar, equities
summary: Gold prices fell to a near two-week low on Tuesday, reaching US$1,257.25 an ounce, amid a firm dollar and higher equities. The decline was partly due to a weaker-than-expected US jobs report in April, which eased expectations for near-term interest rate hikes. Spot gold rose 0.3% to US$1,267.30 an ounce, still up 19% in 2016. Analysts attribute the decline to a risk-off mode, with investors favoring assets like equities over gold.

site_title: Europe: Pandora, Credit Suisse lift European shares, Athens outperforms
summary: European shares rose 0.9% on Tuesday, lifted by Greek debt talks progress and strong earnings reports. Pandora surged 11% after beating expectations, while Credit Suisse gained 5% after a smaller-than-expected loss. Greek shares rose 3.1% to their highest level this year. The FTSEurofirst 300 index ended at its highest level since 2014, with nearly 70% of European companies having announced earnings results, 60% of which met or beat analyst forecasts.

site_title: Brexit is the only way to curb immigration, half of Britons say
summary: A poll by Ipsos Mori found that over half of Britons believe the only way to curb immigration is for the UK to vote to leave the European Union in the June 23 referendum. 63% of undecided voters and 95% of those backing "leave" agree. Halting EU immigration is a central plank of the "Leave" campaign's case for quitting the bloc.

images.alt_text: More than half of Britons think the only way to curb immigration is for the UK to vote to leave the European Union in the June 23 referendum, according to a poll by Ipsos Mori.

site_title: Oil prices rebound sharply
summary: Oil prices rebounded sharply on Tuesday, with US benchmark West Texas Intermediate rising 87 cents to $44.31 a barrel and Brent North Sea crude adding $1.43 to $45.06 a barrel. The rebound came after the previous day's heavy losses triggered by concerns over wildfires in Canada's Alberta region. The gains were likely due to receding concerns and a decrease in bearish market sentiment.

images.alt_text: The oil market climbed Tuesday, rebounding from the previous day's heavy losses that were triggered by receding concerns over wildfires in Canada's crude-producing Alberta region.

site_title: Latest MAS easing move 'appropriate': IMF
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has praised the Monetary Authority of Singapore's (MAS) recent easing of monetary policy, stating it is "appropriate" given the current economic conditions. The IMF expects Singapore's growth to slow to 1.8% in 2016 before improving to 2.5% in 2017.
