summary: A new production of Romeo & Juliet has been staged in a futuristic dystopia, updating the classic tale to a grey industrial backdrop with interlaced staircases and a focus on social class struggle. Thomas Pang stars as Romeo, a member of the wealthy Montagues, while Cheryl Tan plays Juliet, a rebellious Capulet. The production combines South-east Asian and British punk influences, with a focus on the intense emotions and violence that arise from the families' long-standing feud. This modern take on the classic love story explores the loss of innocence and the dangers of unchecked power.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: GoGoVan raises eight-figure Series C funding
summary: Hong Kong-based GoGoVan, backed by Singapore's Centurion Private Equity, has raised an eight-figure Series C funding round led by New Horizon Capital. The funding will support the development of "business-centric" products, including LaaS (logistics as a service), aimed at optimizing logistics costs for traditional logistics businesses. GoGoVan plans to use the capital to further develop its products, including a new delivery management feature. The round values the company at approximately US$250 million, following a Series B+ round in June.

site_title: ECB scrapping 500-euro banknotes
summary: The European Central Bank announced it will stop producing and issuing 500-euro banknotes by the end of 2018, citing concerns that the large denomination was favored by criminals for money laundering and terrorist financing. The decision comes after a Harvard University study found that the note's anonymity and portability made it a preferred payment mechanism for those pursuing illicit activities. Existing 500-euro notes will remain legal tender and can be exchanged at national central banks for an unlimited period.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary: Brokerages maintain buy ratings on Jumbo Group, Wilmar International, and Sembcorp Industries, citing improved market conditions and potential for profitability. Jumbo's China operations show promising signs, while Wilmar benefits from a structurally improved oilseeds market and favorable weather patterns. Sembcorp Industries' utilities segment sees upside potential, despite downside risk from the marine business. Target prices range from S$0.58 for Jumbo to S$4.25 for Wilmar.

site_title: China's commodities market frenzy cools
summary: China's commodities market frenzy has cooled, with trading volumes at three major exchanges returning to pre-peak levels. Trading volumes have dropped to US$114 billion, down from a record 1.7 trillion yuan (US$261 billion) in April. The slowdown follows the implementation of transaction fees and margins to limit speculation. Prices of some commodities, such as steel and coking coal, have still risen but have not collapsed, with steel futures up 15% and coking coal up 18% since their peaks. Regulators' efforts to monitor and regulate the market appear to have prevented a market collapse.

site_title: Focusing on erosion of local culture, changing identities
summary: Artist Steve Lawler, known as Mojoko, has showcased his latest solo exhibition "Mystery Island" at SPRMRKT in Singapore, focusing on the erosion of local culture and changing identities of Asians. The show features silkscreened works on ceramics, antique frames, and limited-edition prints, exploring contemporary topics such as deforestation. Lawler's work blends pop culture, B-grade movies, and Asian influences, reflecting his mixed cultural background. The exhibition runs until May 10 and marks a shift towards more mainstream gallery shows for the artist, who has gained international recognition through his guerrilla art scene.

images.alt_text: Witchmaster General (left) is inspired by the greedy harvesting of palm oil and Temple of Dhoom (right) is inspired by the rapid changing of identity in Asia. The works are screenprinted onto ceramic plates and framed in 17th and 18th-century antique frames respectively.
Lawler's works currently on show at SPRMRKT cafe have taken on a blue-and-white veneer

site_title: Whole-economy PMI slumps to 49.4 in April
summary: Singapore's whole-economy PMI plummeted to 49.4 in April, the first contraction in almost a year, signaling a renewed decline in the health of the private sector. The index, compiled by Markit, fell from March's 52.0 reading, with output growth slowing to a "marginal pace" due to weaker foreign demand and softer market conditions. Experts warn of potential global growth slowdown, citing IMF and World Bank revisions, and suggest new stimulus measures may be needed to counteract sluggish growth.

site_title: Jump in ST Engineering share price prompts SGX query
summary: ST Engineering's share price surged over 5% in morning trading, prompting a query from the Singapore Exchange (SGX). The stock closed at S$3.24, up 18 cents, and outperformed the Straits Times Index. ST Engineering attributed the unusual price movement to the divestment of an overseas subsidiary, stating it won't have a material impact on earnings. Analysts OCBC Research downgraded their 'buy' call to 'hold' citing valuations above its three-year mean, but noted strong contract wins in electronics and aerospace.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Alibaba investors seek catalyst for shares
summary: Alibaba's shares have lost over a third of their value since peaking at $120 following its record 2014 IPO, despite revenue growth of at least 20% and beating earnings expectations every quarter. The company's struggles are attributed to a slowing China economy and deceleration in online transactions. Investors are awaiting a catalyst for the stock, such as a resurgence in revenue growth, to push it higher. Analysts suggest Alibaba needs to demonstrate expanding growth or accelerating margins to regain investor confidence, with a focus on the impact of its acquisition spree and growth in Southeast Asian markets.

site_title: Gucci zeal to protect brand extends into the hereafter
summary: Gucci has taken action against six Hong Kong stores selling paper replicas of its products as funeral offerings, citing trademark infringement. The replicas, made by Chinese manufacturers, were sold at a fraction of the price of real Gucci items, with some shops offering paper versions of Italian sports cars and smartphones. Despite the stores' compliance with Gucci's request, the incident highlights the challenges of enforcing intellectual property rights in a city with a strong blend of Eastern and Western cultures.

images.alt_text: At specialty shops across Hong Kong, the bereaved can choose from an impressive array of goods to send to their departed loved ones, including Italian sports cars, smartphones, six-packs of beer, cigarettes, dress shirts and sports jackets.

site_title: Canadian oil output cut as wildfire disrupts operations, forces evacuation
summary: A wildfire in northern Alberta, Canada, forced the evacuation of nearly 900 more people, bringing the total to 80,000, as it destroyed homes and disrupted oil-sands operations. The provincial government evacuated two communities and Fort McMurray First Nation due to changing weather patterns. The reduced Canadian oil output, the world's fourth-largest crude producer, helped lift benchmark oil prices.

site_title: Another round of tasteless humour
summary: The article reviews Bad Neighbours 2, a comedy film directed by Nicholas Stoller. The movie follows Mac and Kelly as they try to evict their new neighbors, a sorority led by Chloe Grace Moretz's character. The film is criticized for its patchy humor, ageist and sexist jokes, and self-indulgent plot. Zac Efron is praised for his comedic performance, but the film's overall quality is deemed mediocre, earning a C+ rating.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: May's first COE bidding exercise ends mixed
summary: Singapore's first COE bidding exercise for May ended with mixed results, with passenger-car premiums rising (Cat A: S$589 to S$47,889, Cat B: S$1,408 to S$51,010) but other categories falling (Cat C: S$700 to S$42,302, Cat D: S$199 to S$6,302, Cat E: S$501 to S$49,000). The increases were expected despite a 14.7% boost in the total number of COEs for the next three months.

images.alt_text: The first certificate of entitlement (COE) bidding exercise for May ended mixed, with passenger-car premiums rising but those for the other categories falling.

site_title: HDB resale volumes in April hit 3-year high as prices stabilise
summary: HDB resale volumes in Singapore reached a 3-year high in April, with 1,828 flats sold, a 10.3% increase from March and 13.5% higher than last year. Prices moderated by 0.1% from a month ago, with 5-room flats experiencing a 0.9% decline, while 3-room and executive flats rose 0.6% and 0.1% respectively. The trend is expected to continue as buyers remain conservative and sellers adjust price expectations to minimize market time.

site_title: Classic beauty Jane Seymour flails in her Asian debut
summary: Jane Seymour, 65, makes her Asian stage debut in The British Theatre Playhouse's production of The Vortex at Raffles Hotel's Jubilee Theatre. However, her performance as the ageing socialite Florence Lancaster is met with disappointment. Seymour delivers her lines loudly and imperiously, lacking nuance, and fails to convince in the complex role. Despite her trim figure, Seymour's interpretation of Florence is shallow, leaving the audience to guess the character's motivations. The play, written by Noel Coward in 1924, explores the decline of a socialite, but Seymour's performance falls short.

images.alt_text: Helmi Yusof

site_title: Expanding the scope of mentoring those at risk
summary: Beautiful People, a 10-year-old mentoring program for at-risk teenage girls, has expanded to include teenage boys with the launch of the "Heroes' Journey" program. The organization, founded by Melissa Kwee, initially worked with girls but responded to a request from boys at a residential rehabilitation home, seeking to include the male component in their family philosophy. The program aims to nurture responsible men who care for women in their lives, with the long-term benefits of mentoring support kicking in after the teenagers leave their institutions.

site_title: Singaporeana remixed
summary: Singapore is reviving its vintage music scene with a focus on heritage, as seen in the upcoming Getai Soul 2016 festival, which features indie headliners and regional stars alongside Cantonese opera, getai, and Teochew puppetry. The event aims to capture the "old world charm" of Singapore's past and provide an alternative to international music festivals. Meanwhile, the Keong Saik Carnival, set to take place later this month, will celebrate local music history with a lineup of indie artistes and regional acts. The festival's success could pave the way for a resurgence in interest in Singapore's music heritage.

site_title: Roxy's Q1 profit dives; group to launch six projects in 2016/17
summary: Roxy-Pacific Holdings' first-quarter net profit shrank 79% to S$9.89 million, with revenue easing 48% to S$102.98 million. The group expects to be profitable in 2016 and has six new development projects set to launch in 2016-17. The group's net asset value per share rose to 39.37 cents, while net debt to adjusted net asset value increased to 0.67 times. Despite a decline in earnings, Roxy-Pacific remains optimistic about its future prospects and plans to expand its hospitality business.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: City buzz
summary: The 26th European Union Film Festival in Singapore will run from May 10 to 22, showcasing the best of contemporary European cinema. The festival's line-up includes award-winning films such as "The Tribe" and "Admiral", as well as lesser-known works. The festival also collaborates with a local film school, Ngee Ann Polytechnic's School of Film and Media Studies. Meanwhile, a career fair focused on women's career development will take place on May 6, with employers from various companies participating. Additionally, a contemporary dance showcase, Sides 2016, will be held on May 13 and 14, featuring emerging choreographers.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Labour set to recapture London after bitter mayoral campaign
summary: Labour candidate Sadiq Khan is set to become the first Muslim to be elected mayor of London, defeating Conservative Zac Goldsmith in a campaign marred by accusations of anti-Semitism and extremism. Khan has a big lead in opinion polls, despite criticisms from Goldsmith, who accused him of sharing platforms with radical Muslim speakers. The expected victory may be a lone bright spot for Labour, which is expected to lose seats in some traditional strongholds.

site_title: Tharman 'troubled' by SDP's politics of populism
summary: Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam expressed concern over the Singapore Democratic Party's (SDP) "politics of spreading fear and alarm, and the politics of populism." He emphasized that such politics is not suitable for Singapore, where a healthy opposition is still allowed. Tharman made these comments during the People's Action Party's (PAP) final rally for the Bukit Batok by-election.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: EU financial-transaction tax plan in doldrums as Belgium heads towards exit
summary: Belgium's finance minister, Johan Van Overtveldt, signals his country's potential exit from the EU's financial-transaction tax plan, citing concerns that it would drive business away. The tax, which aims to raise revenue and limit market speculation, needs the backing of at least nine nations to proceed. With Estonia having already pulled out and Italy wavering, the initiative is hanging in the balance. The EU's inability to secure a deal highlights the challenges to deeper European integration.

site_title: Ad agencies' new challengers expose lack of tech wizardry
summary: Consulting firms like Accenture, Deloitte, and IBM are emerging as digital marketing challengers to traditional ad agencies, exposing their lack of tech wizardry. These firms excel in online marketing, app development, and e-commerce, threatening the creative edge of agencies like WPP, Publicis, and Omnicom. As ad dollars shift to the web, the line between marketing and technology is blurring, favoring the nerds over the traditional ad agencies. Accenture, in particular, is expanding its digital marketing division, employing 20,000 people and growing its business to $3 billion, putting pressure on agencies to up their game in software and analytics.

site_title: Panama Canal expansion exposes US infrastructure, carriers' woes
summary: The US$5.2 billion Panama Canal expansion, set to debut next month, is expected to make US East Coast ports more competitive for cargo ships. However, those hopes are fading due to unprepared ports, a freighter glut, and a wobbly global economy. The wider, deeper canal will allow larger ships to pass through, but many East Coast ports lack the infrastructure to handle them, potentially stymying gains for carriers and cargo owners. The expansion's impact on the US economy remains uncertain, with many factors contributing to the delay.

site_title: Yen weakens slightly; investors not heeding intervention signal
summary: The yen weakened 0.2% against the dollar for a third consecutive day, reaching an 18-month peak, despite Japan's Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's warning that the government would intervene if necessary. Investors remain cautious, awaiting the US payrolls report on Friday, and are instead taking on more risk, with the Swiss franc hitting an eight-week low against the euro. The dollar index rose 0.5% as the euro fell 0.5%.

site_title: A surfeit of riches
summary: A recent dinner featuring wines from renowned Domaines and vintages fell short of expectations, with some bottles failing to meet their full potential. The Krug Champagne Vintage 1996 and Chambolle-Musigny 1er cru Les Amoureuses 2007 stood out as exceptional, while others, such as Montrachet 1996 and Chateau Petrus 1978, were disappointing. The main issue was the wine's provenance, with some bottles possibly having undergone significant stress during transportation, potentially affecting their flavor and quality. The experience highlights the importance of verifying a wine's origin and history to ensure authenticity.

site_title: Big data breaches found at major email services: specialist
summary: A massive data breach involving 272.3 million stolen online accounts has been discovered, including 57 million Mail.ru accounts, 40 million Yahoo Mail credentials, 33 million Microsoft Hotmail accounts, and 9 million Gmail accounts. The stolen data is being traded in Russia's criminal underworld, posing a significant risk of financial theft and reputational damage. The breach is one of the largest to be uncovered since cyber attacks on major US banks and retailers two years ago, and it highlights the need for users to regularly change their passwords and implement robust security measures.

site_title: A bridge for Israeli startups
summary: IZMUS, a Singapore-based company, has signed a Memorandum of Intent with Infocomm Investments to create a bridge for Israeli startups to expand into Asia, leveraging Singapore's networking and investment opportunities. The partnership aims to bring "relevant and viable" Israeli startups to Singapore for investment and market access. The move is expected to promote the exchange of ideas and technologies between Singapore and Israel, aligning with Singapore's plan to become a Smart Nation.

site_title: StarHub Q1 profit up 25.9% despite 4.4% dip in revenue
summary: StarHub reported a 25.9% increase in net profit to S$92.8 million in Q1 2016, driven by a 9.1% drop in operating expenses. Revenue fell 4.4% to S$590.9 million, primarily due to lower equipment sales. Despite this, service revenue grew, with broadband and enterprise fixed services contributing to the increase. The telco expects 2016 service revenue to grow in the "low single-digit range" and maintains its annual cash dividend of 20 Singapore cents apiece.

site_title: The devil is in the details in this 'New England fable'
summary: The film "The Witch" is a period horror drama set in 17th-century New England, directed by Robert Eggers. The story follows a banished man and his family as they settle in a remote plot of land, where they experience strange events, including the disappearance of their newborn and children. The film keeps the audience guessing about the supernatural force behind the events or if it's a family member. With its slow-burning tension, period authenticity, and eerie atmosphere, "The Witch" has become a cult classic, earning praise from fans of the horror genre and even the Satanic Temple.

images.alt_text: Dylan Tan

site_title: Singapore launches personal data platform to speed up e-govt transactions
summary: Singapore has launched MyInfo, a consent-based platform allowing citizens and businesses to access and share personal data for e-government transactions. This move aims to make transactions faster and easier, with the goal of transforming government service delivery. By 2018, most SingPass-authenticated e-services will be linked to the MyInfo platform, which currently includes 10 services across six agencies. The platform aims to put citizens and businesses "in charge" and increase transparency and efficiency in government services.

site_title: STI's losing streak extends into 9th day
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) closed at 2,767.81 on May 5, 2016, with a 5.26-point loss, marking its ninth consecutive day of decline, a 6.5% loss since April 21. The index fell despite a firm European opening and a 90-point rise in Dow futures. The decline was attributed to concerns over the asset quality of local banks, with Moody's Investors Service predicting deteriorating asset quality and rising pressure on profitability.

site_title: Keppel completes US$100m acquisition of LeTourneau
summary: Keppel Offshore & Marine has completed the US$100 million acquisition of Cameron International Corporation's offshore product division, which includes LeTourneau jack-up rig designs and aftersales services. The acquisition expands Keppel's jack-up rig designs to over 26 and provides a full suite of end-to-end solutions. The move complements Keppel's existing capabilities and enables faster servicing of LeTourneau rigs for their owners, expediting their return to work. The acquisition is part of Keppel's strategy to invest in new capabilities during the market downturn.

site_title: S-Class up your stay
summary: Mercedes-Benz has partnered with Capri by Fraser in Changi City to launch Mercedes-Benz Living @ Fraser, a luxury stay experience. The nine-terrace suites feature high-end amenities, including Burmeister sound systems and Swarovski chandeliers, at a cost of over S$200,000 each. Guests can enjoy an airport transfer in a Mercedes-Benz S- or E-Class, expedited check-in, and exclusive use of Mercedes-Benz Trek Bicycles. The target demographic is millennials working in the region, and the collaboration has seen success, with plans to expand to cities like Sydney, Beijing, and Barcelona next year.

site_title: The challenge of retail in Asia
summary: Asian retail faces significant challenges, with growing costs, e-commerce, and economic uncertainties hindering established and new brands. European brands that initiated retail expansion 50-60 years ago have a competitive advantage due to their long history and investment in retail infrastructure. In contrast, Asian brands struggle to penetrate the market, with short leases, high rents, and limited financial control. Developing a retail culture requires significant investments, and Asian companies are at a disadvantage due to the lack of a strong multi-brand channel, making it difficult to test products and adjust without financial risks.

site_title: Causeway comedy
summary: Malaysian comedians Joanne Kam, Kumar, and Gurmit Singh will reunite on the Resorts World Theatre stage in Laugh Die You - The Karaoke, a raunchy stand-up show combining stand-up routines, dance sets, and live music. The fourth instalment in the Laugh Die You series has been a sell-out success in Malaysia, selling almost 12,000 tickets in the past eight months. The show will feature fireworks, verbal sparring between the queens, and a friendly rivalry between Singapore and Malaysia over food.

site_title: EC e-applications not translating to sales
summary: Singapore's executive condominium (EC) projects saw strong interest in e-applications, but actual launch sales have been disappointing, with half of the 14 launched since 2014 falling short of a 20% conversion rate. This trend may indicate a potential supply overhang, which could take 1-3 years for the market to digest. Industry players are questioning the reliability of e-applications as a gauge of demand, and a 20-30% conversion rate is considered reasonable in today's market.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Keppel Corp's commercial representative in Brazil, Zwi Skornicki, is under investigation for possible offenses in cartel activities and fraud. A report by the Brazilian Public Prosecutor's Office found evidence of such crimes, but charges have not been filed against Skornicki. Keppel has stated it will take necessary steps to eradicate any illegal conduct. Meanwhile, Tiger Airways has posted a fourth-quarter profit, propelling the airline to full-year profitability after four years of losses, and Creative Technology has reversed into the black for the third quarter after a patent settlement.

site_title: A different spirit of the law in OSIM takeover
summary: A Singaporean corporate law issue has emerged in the OSIM takeover, where founder Ron Sim's ability to acquire the remaining shares of his company without resistance from minority shareholders has raised concerns about fairness. The law, under Section 215 of the Companies Act, allows an offeror to exercise compulsory acquisition once it reaches 90% of shares it didn't own, but this threshold may be too low for founders who hold a significant stake. A proposed change to exclude "associates" from the threshold has been rejected by the Ministry of Finance, citing concerns about uncertainty and the need for efficiency in the financial market.

site_title: DRB-Hicom calls off sale of The Verge
summary: DRB-Hicom has called off the sale of The Verge mall in Singapore due to the buyer's inability to fulfill its contractual obligations on the agreed completion date. The buyer, a Singapore-incorporated vehicle controlled by Keith Tang, failed to meet the requirements. This marks the end of the proposed sale, which was announced over four months ago.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Q1 Manulife profit up 45% on interest rates, Asian insurance
summary: Manulife Financial Corp reported a 45% gain in first-quarter profit to US$812 million, driven by interest-rate movements and record insurance sales in Asia. The company's stock rose 0.4% to US$14.07. Market-related gains, including the impact of interest rates, "more than offset depressed oil and gas prices," according to CEO Donald Guloien.

site_title: Keppel's commercial rep in Brazil hasn't been charged for fraud, illegal cartel activities
summary: Keppel Corporation's commercial representative in Brazil, Zwi Skornicki, won't face charges for alleged fraud and cartel activities, despite evidence of such crimes. The Brazilian Public Prosecutor's Office found no basis for filing charges against Skornicki. Keppel maintains its zero-tolerance stance against bribery and corruption and will investigate any misconduct. Skornicki, along with seven others, has been charged with corruption, criminal conspiracy, and money laundering.

site_title: A return to his comedic roots
summary: Aussie actor Eric Bana is set to star in the Netflix movie Special Correspondents, a comedy written and directed by Ricky Gervais. Bana, known for his serious roles in Troy and Chopper, has returned to his comedic roots and praises Gervais as a great collaborator. The film follows a radio journalist and his colleague as they fake frontline war reports from a hideout in Queens. Bana has expressed his enthusiasm for the project and credits Netflix for allowing directors and actors to pursue their visions without interference. The film is Bana's first for an on-demand service, and he has stated that he will never take on a musical role.

site_title: Whole Foods profit tops estimates
summary: Whole Foods Market Inc. reported quarterly earnings of 44 cents per share, beating analyst estimates, as cost-cutting measures helped cushion the blow of slowing sales growth. The company reported a 1.3% sales gain to $3.7 billion and reduced expenses to lower prices and compete with larger supermarket rivals. However, comparable-store sales dropped 3% last quarter and 1.8% in the previous quarter, leading to a lowered full-year sales forecast.

site_title: M&C's Q1 net profit falls on challenging hospitality markets
summary: MILLENNIUM & Copthorne Hotels plc (M&C) reported a net profit of £6 million for Q1 2016, down from £8 million a year ago, due to challenging hospitality markets. Revenue rose 1.6% to £192 million, driven by property income and favourable foreign-exchange movements. However, core hotel revenue fell 2.9% to £165 million, impacted by refurbishment work and terrorism concerns. The group chairman warned of an uncertain outlook, citing structural changes in the industry and increased competition.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Frasers Centrepoint Trust to enter Australian market wombat-style
summary: Frasers Centrepoint Trust (FCT) plans to enter the Australian market, leveraging its sponsor Frasers Centrepoint Limited's presence in the country. CEO Chew Tuan Chiong likened the strategy to allowing wombats to stay on Australian farmland, highlighting the challenges of entry but the potential for a foothold. FCT's expansion comes after its parent group established a significant presence in Australia through the acquisition of Australand Property Group. The move is seen as an opportunity to tap into the Australian retail market, which has limited opportunities for buyouts in Singapore.

images.alt_text: "With the help from the rest of the group, we are able to back our way into Australia slowly and find a foothold," says Dr Chew

site_title: Frasers Hospitality Trust raises S$100m in maiden perps issue, prices at 4.45%
summary: Frasers Hospitality Trust raised S$100 million from its maiden perpetual securities issuance at 4.45% fixed distribution rate, exceeding S$500 million in orders. Institutional investors accounted for 35% of total orders. The proceeds will be used for potential acquisitions, working capital, and general corporate purposes.

site_title: Fannie Mae to pay Treasury US$919m after reporting profit
summary: Fannie Mae reported a first-quarter profit of $1.1 billion, driven by fees for guaranteeing loans against default and credit-related income. The company will pay the US Treasury Department $919 million in dividends after meeting a net worth threshold. Revenue from net interest and fees was $5 billion, partially offset by $2.8 billion in derivatives losses due to declining interest rates. The payment is made under Fannie Mae's US conservatorship agreement, which requires the company to maintain a minimum net worth.

site_title: YuuZoo Q1 net profit nearly trebles on stronger revenue
summary: YuuZoo Corporation reported a net profit of S$12.8 million for the first quarter of 2016, nearly tripling from S$4.3 million in the same period last year. Revenue surged to S$45 million from S$13.1 million, driven by stronger e-commerce revenue and franchise sales. The company's strong Q1 performance is attributed to its growing online presence and expanding business operations.

site_title: Ford invests US$182.2m in software company Pivotal
summary: Ford Motor Co has invested US$182.2 million in Pivotal Software, a cloud-software company, to boost its own software capabilities and speed up software-development times. The investment is part of a US$253 million funding round and will help Ford develop its technology platforms for connected and self-driving cars. Ford and Pivotal will jointly open labs in the US and Europe, and the deal underscores the pressure carmakers face to invest in technology.

site_title: Auto parts maker Magna raises 2016 sales forecast
summary: Canadian auto parts maker Magna International Inc raised its 2016 sales forecast for the second time, citing strong vehicle sales in North America and Europe, particularly in the US due to low gasoline prices. The company reported a 14.5% increase in sales to $8.90 billion and a 8% increase in net income to $492 million. Magna forecasts 2016 sales of $35.5 billion-$37.2 billion, higher than its previous forecast. The company's shares rose 2.7% following the announcement.

site_title: US consumer comfort slumps to weakest level since Dec
summary: US consumer confidence fell to its weakest level since mid-December, dropping to 42 in the week ended May 1. The decline mirrors the Conference Board and University of Michigan confidence gauges, which have also deteriorated this year due to financial-market turmoil, weak economic growth, and election-year uncertainty. A stronger labor market and wage gains could help boost confidence, but for now, Americans remain pessimistic about the economy and their finances.

site_title: Affordable homes on NYC housing authority land
summary: The de Blasio administration plans to lease public housing land in Brooklyn and the Bronx to build nearly 500 affordable apartments for low-income tenants, mostly elderly. Three private developers will construct three buildings, each up to 16 floors, with amenities and services like rooftop gardens, community centers, and social services. The buildings will charge below-market rents, with public housing residents getting preference for 25% of the apartments. Construction is expected to start next year and last two years, generating up to $200 million in fees from developers over 10 years.

images.alt_text: The Brooklyn borough of New York. The housing projects will have rooftop gardens, arts and technology programmes, community centres, preschool education and social services.

site_title: Roxy-Pacific Q1 net profit shrinks 79% to S$9.9m as revenue drops
summary: Roxy-Pacific Holdings reported a 79% decline in Q1 net profit to S$9.89 million, largely due to a 48% drop in revenue from a completed development project. Earnings per share fell to 0.83 cents, while net asset value per share rose to 39.37 cents. Despite the decline, the group expects to be profitable in 2016.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Bahrain unveils business reforms to draw investors
summary: Bahrain unveiled business reforms to attract investors, aiming to be the fastest in the Gulf Cooperation Council to start a business. The measures will simplify commercial registration and licensing procedures for local and foreign investors. Crown Prince Salman bin Hamad Al Khalifa described the initiative as part of a package of business reforms, the largest seen in over 40 years. The goal is to increase investment in the island kingdom.

site_title: Singtel chairman Simon Israel to chair SingPost board too
summary: Singtel chairman Simon Israel will chair SingPost's board, replacing outgoing chairman Lim Ho Kee, effective May 11. Israel, 63, has received regulatory approvals for the appointment and has stated his priorities include completing a corporate governance review and appointing a new Group CEO. He will also review the board's composition. Israel's appointment was confirmed by a report earlier this week and follows Lim Ho Kee's decision not to seek re-election as a director.

site_title: Creative Technology reverses into black in Q3 on gain from lawsuit settlement
summary: Creative Technology reported a net profit of US$4.04 million for the third quarter, reversing a net loss of US$11.7 million from the same period last year. The gain was largely due to a US$12.5 million settlement in a patent lawsuit. Despite this, the company expects to report an operating loss in the second half of the year, with revenue potentially below target.

site_title: Alibaba sales surge as Chinese consumers defy economic gloom
summary: Alibaba Group Holding posted a 39% surge in revenue, reaching $3.7 billion in the March quarter, as Chinese consumers defied economic gloom through promotions. The company's platforms sold $461 billion worth of goods, with mobile advertising and overseas expansion contributing to the growth. Net income rose 85% to 5.3 billion yuan, while active users jumped 21% to 423 million. The marketing push underpinned a 41% jump in revenue on Alibaba's Chinese retail e-commerce platforms.

site_title: Malaysian helicopter goes missing with six aboard: reports
summary: A Malaysian helicopter carrying six people, including Deputy Minister Noriah Kasnon and parliament member Wan Mohammad Khairil Anuar Wan Ahmad, went missing over the Borneo island state of Sarawak on Thursday. Contact was lost during a short flight from the state's interior to its capital Kuching. Authorities have launched a search and rescue mission in the rugged state, where state polls are being closely scrutinized for signs of a voter backlash against the national ruling coalition. The purpose of their travel is unclear, but the ruling coalition is widely expected to retain control of resource-rich Sarawak.

site_title: ST Kinetics to divest stake in China subsidiary for 200m yuan
summary: ST Engineering's subsidiary ST Kinetics is divesting its 60% stake in Guizhou Jonyang Kinetics for 200 million yuan (S$43 million). The land systems arm has been reviewing its specialty vehicle business in China and decided to exit the excavator business due to market conditions. The divestment is pending regulatory approval and is not expected to impact ST Engineering's financial results.

site_title: Rolls-Royce to cut 300 more management posts as profit stutters
summary: Rolls-Royce Holdings Plc plans to eliminate up to 300 management positions, cutting 20-25% of its 2,000 management roles, as part of its cost-cutting drive amid stuttering earnings. The company, which has already cut 200 senior positions, will inform employees of the next steps by the end of the first half and reach a decision on the number of jobs to go by then. The move aims to boost the company's profitability and counteract its disappointing first-half earnings.

site_title: US bullet train proposals shun public funds, favor private cash
summary: US bullet train proposals are shifting away from public funding, instead relying on private cash from investors and foreign train makers. Companies in Texas, Minnesota, and Nevada plan to use partnerships with Japanese or Chinese firms to finance projects. This approach avoids the delays and challenges associated with public funding, allowing for quicker and potentially cheaper construction. Experts remain skeptical about the feasibility of private financing for initial construction costs, but supporters argue that investors can expect solid returns from ticket sales and high-end real estate developments.

site_title: New telco operator joins the fray in Singapore
summary: A new telco operator, Circles.Life, a consumer brand of Liberty Wireless, has entered Singapore's telecommunications market with a base plan starting at S$28 per month, offering innovative data-centric plans with no contract. The company aims to target 15-20% of Singapore's population and will sell mobile phones online at retail prices with interest-free instalment schemes. Circles.Life will offer pay-as-you-go rates for talktime and SMS use, unlimited messaging and calls using WhatsApp, and free roaming, along with bonus data.

site_title: EDP to invest US$1.6b a year, retain core market focus
summary: EDP, a Lisbon-based utility, plans to invest $1.6 billion annually from 2016 to 2020 in onshore wind energy, increasing installed capacity by 20% to 30 gigawatts. The company's clean energy arm, EDP Renovaveis, will invest $5.49 billion in the US, Europe, Brazil, and Mexico, adding 700 megawatts of installations per year. EDP will focus on its core markets, with renewables expected to rise to 76% of its capacity by 2020.

site_title: India regulator may allow insurance to buy banks' AT1 bonds
summary: The Insurance Regulatory Development Authority of India is considering allowing insurance companies to buy hybrid additional Tier 1 bonds issued by banks. The regulator will make a final decision within a month. This move aims to increase investments in the infrastructure sector. However, the regulator has no plans to ease a rule restricting insurance companies from buying bonds of companies rated below "AA."

site_title: Oxley sparkles in Q3, thanks to projects and one-time gain
summary: Oxley Holdings reported a 329% surge in net profit attributable to shareholders to S$51.2 million in Q3 2016, driven by revenue recognition from eight projects and a S$25.7 million gain on a Japanese investment disposal. Revenue climbed 33% year-on-year to S$202.6 million. The company's shares closed at S$0.445, up 1.5 cents. This significant increase is attributed to the success of its projects and one-time gains.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah

site_title: Thailand's top paint producer said to weigh US$400 million IPO
summary: Thailand's top paint producer, TOA Group, is considering a US$400 million initial public offering (IPO) for its paints and chemicals business. The company, controlled by the Tangkaravakoon family, aims to raise funds to expand its operations in the growing Asian Pacific market. A listing on the Thai stock exchange is expected to take place next year, following a trend of successful IPOs in Thailand, which have raised US$2.5 billion over the past year.

site_title: Saudis raise oil pricing for Asia by most since April 2015
summary: Saudi Arabia raised its oil pricing for June sales to Asia by $1.10 a barrel, the largest increase since April 2015, amid expectations of recovering demand and a global market rebalancing. The move comes as unplanned supply outages and disruptions curb a global glut. Benchmark prices have rallied over 60% since mid-February, rebounding from a historic crash. The price hike is seen as a sign of Saudi Arabia's confidence in demand recovery, which is expected to continue as the global market rebalances.

site_title: A-Reit's Q4 DPU fell 8.1 % to 3.41 Singapore cents on S$9m performance fees
summary: A-Reit's Q4 distribution per unit (DPU) fell 8.1% to 3.41 Singapore cents due to S$9m performance fees, despite a 22.4% rise in net property income to S$143.47m. Gross revenue climbed 17.4% to S$204.04m. The company's estimated DPU would have increased by 1.3% without the performance fees.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Saudi allows Binladin Group tenders after layoffs
summary: Saudi authorities have allowed Binladin Group to tender for public building projects despite the layoffs of 77,000 foreign workers. The decision may aid the struggling construction giant, which faced scrutiny after a crane collapse in Mecca last September, killing over 100 people. The company's economic difficulties are attributed to the suspension from new public contracts following the incident. Several projects, including the King Abdelaziz Airport, will resume, according to local media reports.

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore's private sector experienced a slight deterioration in operating conditions in April, with the Nikkei Singapore PMI falling to 49.4 from March's 52.0. The city-state launched MyInfo, a consent-based platform for e-government transactions, and a diamond exchange backed by Temasek Holdings began trading. PayPal launched an incubation program for financial technology startups. Meanwhile, the Straits Times Index closed lower for the ninth straight day, down 5.26 points at 2,767.81.

site_title: Singapore files three new charges against ex-BSI banker in 1MDB probe
summary: Singapore prosecutors have charged former BSI banker Yeo Jiawei with three new crimes related to the 1MDB probe. Yeo, who has been held in custody for 21 days, is accused of cheating his employer, money laundering, and attempting to pervert the course of justice. The charges bring the total to six, with Yeo facing allegations of receiving secret profits of US$4 million and taking "extraordinary steps" to cover his involvement in illicit transactions. Yeo's lawyer argued that other BSI employees were also being investigated, but should not be held in remand.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: China awards 4th telecom license to state-owned broadcaster
summary: China awarded a 4th telecom license to state-owned China Broadcasting Network Company, creating a fourth player in the market dominated by three big companies. The basic telecom services license allows the broadcaster to provide nationwide Internet data and telecommunication services. This move makes China Broadcasting Network the country's fourth telecom service operator, joining China Mobile, China Unicom Hong Kong Ltd, and China Telecom.

site_title: Morrisons makes progress with recovery plan
summary: Morrisons, Britain's fourth-largest grocer, has made progress with its recovery plan under new CEO David Potts. The company has achieved stability, cut prices, improved store standards, and tailored products to local tastes. Morrisons has posted two consecutive quarters of positive like-for-like sales and is on track for profit growth in its 2016-17 year, with analysts forecasting an underlying pretax profit of £318 million. The company's sales at stores open over a year rose 0.7% in the first quarter, ahead of forecasts, driven by online sales growth.

site_title: CWT's profit falls 19% on poor commodities performance
summary: CWT Limited reported a 19% decline in net profit to S$23.7 million in the first quarter, due to lower commodity prices and trading volumes. Revenue fell 14% to S$1.88 billion, with the logistics business showing improvement but the commodity market unit's profit weighed down by unrealised mark-to-market losses. The company's construction of the CWT integrated logistics hub is on track to be completed by mid-2026.

site_title: Hi-P International narrows Q1 loss to S$12.4m
summary: Hi-P International reported a Q1 net loss of S$12.4 million, narrower than S$13.8 million in the same period last year, driven by a four-fold surge in gross profit to S$16.7 million. Despite higher expenses, including finance costs and a net forex loss of S$6.9 million, the company plans to focus on cost controls, business development, and capacity utilization to improve its financial performance.

site_title: US:Wall St opens higher as rising oil boosts energy stocks
summary: US stocks opened higher on Thursday as oil prices rose for the first time this week, boosting energy shares. The Dow Jones industrial average increased 38.39 points, or 0.22%, to 17,689.65, while the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite rose 5.14 and 9.25 points, respectively. Oil prices jumped 3% due to concerns of a near-term shortage in supply caused by a wildfire near Canada's oil sands region and escalating tensions in Libya.

site_title: Trump's deportation plan could slice 2% off US GDP: study
summary: A study by the American Action Forum estimates that Donald Trump's deportation plan could reduce the US GDP by 2% due to the loss of private sector output, amounting to $381.5 billion to $623.2 billion. Approximately 6.8 million undocumented immigrants, who are employed, would be removed, potentially leaving millions of jobs unfilled. The study's findings add to concerns about Trump's policy proposals, which also include tearing up trade agreements and building a border wall.

site_title: Shell to Maersk count on Qatar to provide cleaner fuels at sea
summary: Shell and Maersk are collaborating with Qatar to develop liquefied natural gas as a maritime fuel to curb pollution. The partnership aims to create a new market for cleaner-burning fuels at sea. United Arab Shipping Co has also signed an accord with Shell, investing $2.3 billion in LNG-capable ships since 2014. The move is expected to reduce pollution from shipping and create a new market for cleaner fuels.

site_title: Ex-BSI banker Yeo faces three more charges in 1MDB-linked probe
summary: Singapore authorities charged former BSI SA private banker Yeo Jiawei with three more crimes related to the 1MDB probe, bringing the total to six charges. Yeo faces charges of cheating, perverting justice, and money laundering, with a total benefit of US$500,000. The charges follow previous accusations of cheating his former employer and attempting to pervert justice.

site_title: Insurer Beazley's Q1 buoyed by specialty lines
summary: Lloyd's of London insurer Beazley Plc reported a 7% rise in first-quarter gross written premiums to US$583 million, driven by strong growth in its specialty lines. Specialty lines saw a 15% increase to US$261 million, while marine insurance premiums fell 7% and life, accident, and health jumped 33%. The insurer expects a better-than-average first-half combined ratio if the trend continues. Shares rose 1.8% following the strong quarterly results.

site_title: Shanghai: Stock slightly up but trading remains light on growth concerns
summary: China stocks rose slightly on Thursday, with the CSI300 index up 0.1% and the Shanghai Composite Index gaining 0.2%, but trading volume remained near four-month lows. The market's recovery appears to be losing momentum, with a private survey showing services sector activity expanded in April but at a slower pace. Transportation shares rose after China's central government unveiled plans to promote airline transportation.

site_title: GoGoVan bags Series C funding from New Horizon Capital, SPH, Alibaba fund
summary: Hong Kong-based GoGoVan, a delivery van startup, has raised Series C funding led by New Horizon Capital and Singapore Press Holdings, with participation from Alibaba's Hong Kong Entrepreneurs Fund and existing investors. The undisclosed amount will be used to develop "business-centric products" and advance engineering capabilities. CEO Steven Lam plans to optimize logistics costs with innovative technology and create a new business model, Logistics As A Service (LaaS), to serve diversified business logistics needs.

site_title: China firm wins deal to build Cambodia's first oil refinery: Xinhua
summary: China's engineering unit, CNPCNE, has won a US$620 million contract to build Cambodia's first oil refinery in Preah Sihanouk province. The refinery, set to be completed by 2018, will have a capacity of 40,000 barrels per day and will help reduce Cambodia's reliance on fuel imports. The project, valued at US$3 billion, is a joint venture between CNPCNE and the Cambodian Petrochemical Company.

site_title: Hong Kong: Shares slip as global growth worries return
summary: Hong Kong shares slipped for the fourth consecutive day, falling 0.4% to 20,449.82, amid worries about global economic growth. The decline was influenced by weak job and worker productivity data on Wall Street, which saw major share indexes fall. Most sectors declined, with industrial and property shares among the biggest losers. The decline in Hong Kong shares mirrors global market trends, as investors become increasingly cautious about the economic outlook.

site_title: StarHub's Q1 profit up almost 26%, revenue down 4.4%
summary: StarHub reported a 26% increase in net profit to S$92.8 million for Q1 2016, driven by higher broadband and enterprise fixed services revenue. Revenue fell 4.4% to S$590.0 million due to lower equipment sales and mobile service revenue. The telco proposed an interim dividend of five Singapore cents per share, maintaining its annual cash dividend of 20 Singapore cents.

site_title: Singapore shares close lower as STI sinks for 9th straight day
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) in Singapore fell for the 9th consecutive day, closing at 2,767.81 with a net loss of 5.26 points. The loss since April 21 has been 193 points, or 6.5% of its value. Turnover was 986 million units worth S$1 billion, with 172 rises versus 177 falls. This marks the longest losing streak for the index since its inception.

site_title: Alibaba's finance arm says hires ex-Goldman banker Douglas Feagin
summary: Alibaba's finance arm, Ant Financial Services Group, has appointed ex-Goldman Sachs banker Douglas Feagin as senior vice president of international business, effective June 15, 2016. Feagin brings experience in international finance from his time as a senior partner at Goldman Sachs, where he worked with clients from various sectors across the US, Latin America, and Asia. This move is seen as a strategic appointment to enhance Ant's international presence and expertise in finance.

site_title: Car COE premiums up; other categories down
summary: COE premiums for passenger cars rose, with Category A increasing to S$47,889 and Category B to S$51,010, while Category E decreased to S$49,000. Goods vehicles and motorcycles also saw lower premiums, sliding to S$42,302 and S$6,302 respectively. The increases were attributed to strong orders collected at the recent TheCars@Expo.

site_title: Malaysia: Stocks end the day lower
summary: Malaysian shares ended the day lower, with the Kuala Lumpur Composite Index falling 12.49 points to 1,645.090. The trading volume of 1.39 billion lots valued at RM1.62 billion saw losers outnumber gainers 415 to 332.

site_title: Asia: Stocks decline for seventh day as growth concerns linger
summary: Asian stocks declined for a seventh consecutive day, with the MSCI Asia Pacific excluding Japan Index dropping 0.3% to its lowest level since April 8. The decline was fueled by concerns over global economic growth, weak company earnings, and the prospect of an interest-rate increase by the US Federal Reserve. Investors are struggling to reconcile valuations with risks, with some, such as billionaire Stan Druckenmiller, predicting the end of the bull market in stocks.

site_title: Ford China monthly sales drop most in a year in April amid slowing economy
summary: Ford China's vehicle sales dropped 11% in April, the largest decline in a year, due to the slowing economy. This is the largest decline in comparable monthly sales since Ford began reporting retail data in May last year. Despite a 7% increase in the first four months of the year, Ford's sales continue to struggle, extending an uneven start to 2016. The company's plant in Chongqing will idle for maintenance, but production plans remain unchanged.

site_title: Sri Lanka suspends MPs after worst brawl in 12 years
summary: Sri Lanka's parliament voted unanimously to suspend two MPs for one week after the worst brawl in 12 years. The brawl, sparked by former army chief Sarath Fonseka's claim that a 2006 bombing in Colombo was an inside job, left one MP hospitalized with a black eye and several others with minor injuries. Fonseka, now a government legislator, accused former president Mahinda Rajapakse's brother Gotabhaya of orchestrating the bombing. The incident was the worst in parliament since 2004.

site_title: Malaysia fund said to offer £200m London office for sale
summary: Malaysia's Gatehouse Bank Plc, a fund that invests on behalf of the country's 18 million Muslims, plans to sell its London office building at 10 Queen Street Place for about £200 million. The building, purchased in 2012 for £165 million, has been hired by Savills Plc to find a buyer. This sale follows other UK real estate deals by Malaysia's state investment funds, which aim to repatriate capital to prop up the country's stock and currency markets.

site_title: Europe: Stock markets steady at open
summary: Europe's main stock markets remained steady at the start of trading on Thursday, following two days of losses due to concerns over slowing global growth. The FTSE 100 index rose 0.2%, while the DAX 30 index also gained 0.2%. Asian stocks fell, following a negative lead from Wall Street. Markets are awaiting key US jobs data on Friday, which may impact global growth concerns.

site_title: Tiger Airways ends 4 years of losses as S$7.9m Q4 profit fuels turnaround
summary: Tiger Airways, a low-cost carrier, reported a fourth-quarter profit of S$7.9 million, ending four years of losses. The company's net profit for the full fiscal 2016 was S$282,000, a significant turnaround from a S$264.2 million loss in 2015. Revenue improved 4.1% to S$179.3 million, while fuel costs fell 31.1%. Tiger Airways will be delisted pending a delisting date after being taken over by Singapore Airlines. The company's board expressed satisfaction with the results, indicating a largely achieved turnaround.

site_title: World food prices rise slightly in April: FAO
summary: World food prices rose slightly in April, increasing to 151.8 points from 149.5 points in the previous month, according to the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO). The gains were driven by rises in vegetable oil and cereals prices, offsetting declines in dairy and sugar prices. FAO forecasts world cereals output in 2016-17 to be 2.526 billion tonnes, with wheat output expected to reach 716.9 million tonnes. Food prices on international markets were 10% lower than a year ago.

site_title: Islamic Development Bank to return to ringgit sukuk market
summary: The Islamic Development Bank (IDB) plans to return to the Malaysian ringgit sukuk market this year after a three-year hiatus, with the potential for a private or public placement of up to RM400 million. The move comes as the IDB aims to expand its financing activities and increase its sukuk issuance, with the bank having raised a total of RM700 million via three sukuk transactions since 2008. The deal would be the fourth ringgit-denominated sukuk from the AAA-rated IDB, alongside governments of Malaysia, Indonesia, and Qatar.

site_title: Rolls-Royce revamp on track as earnings to revive in second half
summary: Rolls-Royce Holdings Plc reported trading in line with expectations for the first half of 2016, with earnings expected to be weighted towards the second half. The company aims to be "close to breakeven" in the first six months, with cost-cutting measures and increased deliveries of larger turbines expected to improve performance. CEO Warren East reiterated that 2016 will be a "challenging year" due to weaker demand at its marine unit, but the company remains on track to deliver targeted cost savings and restructuring plans.

site_title: New British daily newspaper folds after 10 weeks
summary: Britain's first new national daily newspaper in 30 years, The New Day, has folded just over two months after its launch due to low circulation numbers. Despite a target of selling 200,000 copies a day, sales fell to around 40,000. The newspaper's owners, Trinity Mirror, cited disappointing sales figures as the reason for the closure, stating they had "tried everything" to make it work financially. The New Day aimed to offer upbeat content with no political bias, targeting 35- to 55-year-olds and especially women, but ultimately failed to meet expectations.

site_title: Philippine central bank: No strong need to change policy settings
summary: The Philippine central bank's governor, Amando Tetangco, stated that there is no strong need to change policy settings due to steady inflation rates. The annual inflation rate remained at 1.1% in April, the same as in March, supporting the central bank's view that inflation should be manageable. The central bank's key rate has been 4% since September 2014 and will be reviewed on May 12, following the presidential election.

images.alt_text: The Philippine central bank does not see a strong need to change policy settings, its governor said on Thursday, after data showed annual inflation held steady in April.

site_title: China ICBC's chairman set to retire: media
summary: China's Industrial and Commercial Bank of China Ltd (ICBC) chairman Jiang Jianqing, 63, is set to retire after leading the bank for 16 years. Jiang led ICBC through a non-performing loan crisis in 2004 and a record-breaking US$19.1 billion IPO in 2006. The exact timing of his departure and successor are unclear, but an internal meeting revealed the move. Jiang's tenure was marked by significant growth and transformation for ICBC, one of China's largest banks.

images.alt_text: Jiang Jianqing, chairman of Industrial and Commercial Bank of China Ltd (ICBC) , is poised to retire, the China Business News reported on Thursday.

site_title: Britain's economy slows to near-stall speed before EU referendum: Markit
summary: Britain's economy slowed in April, with services growth reaching its lowest rate in over three years, according to a survey by Markit. This could lead to a stall in overall economic growth, with some economists predicting a 0.1% growth rate in the second quarter. Uncertainty about the EU referendum and global economic weakness are major concerns, with companies citing consumers as the main drivers of the slowdown. A vote to leave the EU may prompt the Bank of England to cut interest rates, but a vote for Brexit could weaken the pound, adding to inflation.

site_title: Oil gains second day as US production slides most in 8 months
summary: Oil prices rose 2.3% in New York as US production fell 113,000 barrels a day to 8.83 million a day, the lowest since September 2014. The decline in US output is seen as a positive trend by analysts, with prices potentially reaching $48 to $50. Brent crude also gained 1.9% to $45.47 a barrel. The Organization of Petroleum Exporting Countries is without a proposal to revive production limits at its June meeting.

site_title: Australian Treasurer appoints Philip Lowe as next central bank governor
summary: Australian Treasurer Scott Morrison has appointed Philip Lowe, the current Deputy Governor of the Reserve Bank of Australia, as the next central bank governor. Lowe, who has served since 2012, will replace retiring Governor Glenn Stevens in September. His appointment is seen as a safe choice, bringing over three decades of experience to the role.

site_title: Malaysia's scandal-hit Najib seeks big win in Borneo state polls
summary: Malaysia's Prime Minister Najib Razak is seeking a landslide victory in the state polls of Sarawak, where his ally, Chief Minister Adenan Satem, is expected to win. Najib has made big pledges and taken his campaign to remote villages, hoping to show he still has the confidence of the people after the 1MDB scandal. Analysts say the ruling Barisan Nasional coalition is likely to comfortably win, but critics accuse Najib of trying to "hijack" the polls. The outcome will be seen as a moral booster for Najib and the ruling party.

site_title: EU transaction-tax plan on brink as Belgium inches toward exit
summary: Belgium's finance minister, Johan Van Overtveldt, signals his country may pull out of plans for a European Union financial-transaction tax, potentially leaving the initiative on the brink of collapse. The tax aims to raise revenue and limit market speculation, but concerns over its impact on business and government finances have led to opposition from several countries, including Belgium, Estonia, and Slovenia. The EU needs the backing of at least nine nations to proceed with the plan, which has been stalled since December's failed negotiations.

site_title: Australia, NZ: Australia shares steady as NAB rallies, NZ edges up
summary: Australian shares finished steady, edging up 7.96 points or 0.15% to 5279.10, after a 1.5% drop on Wednesday. New Zealand's S&P/NZX 50 index rose 0.76% or 51.98 points to 6876.48. National Australia Bank's encouraging results boosted shares, while weak mining stocks weighed on the market.

site_title: Olympics: China eyes consolidation at Rio, excellence at Tokyo
summary: China aims to consolidate its Olympic strengths at the 2016 Rio Games and strive for a leading position at the 2020 Tokyo Olympics. The country's sports ministry unveiled a five-year plan to strengthen international competitiveness, focusing on maintaining existing advantages and results positions. China's government has warned that its obsession with winning gold medals has caused problems like corruption and must be ditched. Hosting the 2022 Winter Olympics in Beijing and Zhangjiakou is expected to raise China's influence in international sports and spur winter sports development.

site_title: Palm oil stockpiles in Malaysia seen falling to 14-month low
summary: Malaysia's palm oil stockpiles likely hit a 14-month low in April, falling 3.7% to 1.82 million metric tons, according to a Bloomberg survey. This marks the fifth consecutive decline, the longest streak since June 2013. Production rose 9% to 1.33 million tons, while exports fell 6% to 1.25 million tons, amid concerns over El Nino weather conditions that may continue to impact production. Official data will be released by the Malaysian Palm Oil Board on May 10.

site_title: US dollar up as US data, Japan intervention talk follow rate comments
summary: The US dollar strengthened against the yen in Asia, reaching 107.08 yen, following upbeat US data and speculation of a Japanese intervention. This came after two US central bank regional heads hinted at a potential interest rate hike next month. Despite the gains, the dollar remains down 13% from the start of the year due to ongoing pressure from the Bank of Japan's stimulus decision. The dollar also rose against most emerging market currencies, including the South Korean won and Indonesian rupiah.

site_title: NZ speeds up foreign investment process, raises fees
summary: New Zealand has announced plans to speed up the approval process for inward foreign investment, addressing concerns that the vetting process is taking too long. Finance Minister Bill English stated that exemptions will be introduced for certain types of investments, without providing details. This move aims to address complaints from investors, similar to Australia, which has seen increased interest from Chinese investors in recent years. The changes are expected to simplify the process and reduce delays.

images.alt_text: "We've heard concerns from investors that the rationale for screening certain investment types is unclear and decisions by the OIO are taking too long," Finance Minister Bill English said in a statement, referring to New Zealand's Overseas Investment Office.

site_title: IDA boost for Israeli start-ups looking to expand to South-east Asia
summary: Israeli start-ups in medical technology, digital health, clean technology, and cyber security can leverage IZMUS to expand into South-east Asia, starting with Singapore. IZMUS has signed a Memorandum of Intent with Infocomm Investments to help startups tap the region. Interested companies will undergo a screening process with a bilateral advisory board, selecting the most innovative technologies. This initiative aims to foster growth and innovation in the region, particularly in the tech industry.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Hot stock: ST Engineering jumps 5% in trading on Thursday morning, prompting SGX query
summary: ST Engineering shares surged 5% in early trading on Thursday, reaching an intra-day high of S$3.22, prompting a query from the Singapore Exchange (SGX) about the unusual price movements. The stock was among the top five gainers on the Exchange, despite the Straits Times Index down 0.52%. The SGX asked ST Engineering if it knew of any information that could explain the trading, which was outperforming the market.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Dollar shortage leaves ATMs empty, Zimbabweans without cash
summary: Zimbabwe is facing a severe dollar shortage, leaving ATMs empty and threatening company failures. The shortage is attributed to the country's struggling economy, which has shrunk by half since 2009. President Robert Mugabe's government is struggling to resuscitate the economy, with 90% of the population out of formal employment. The issue is related to Zimbabwe's balance of payments, according to the CEO of Agricultural Bank of Zimbabwe Ltd. The shortage has caused long lines outside banks, with residents unable to access cash for basic necessities like school fees and groceries.

site_title: CityDev's M&C posts weaker Q1 net profit due to challenging hospitality markets
summary: MILLENNIUM & Copthorne Hotels plc (M&C), a London-listed hotel arm of City Developments, posted a net profit of £6 million for the first quarter of 2016, down from £8 million a year ago. Revenue rose to £192 million, driven by higher property income and a weaker pound, but hotel revenue fell 2.9% due to challenging hospitality markets. Group revenue per available room decreased 2.6% and 4.7% in constant currency, citing political and economic uncertainty, industry consolidation, and the growth of 'sharing economy' lodging.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan
Millennium & Copthorne Hotels plc (M&C) on Thursday posted a net profit of £6 million (S$11.8 million) for the first quarter of 2016, down from £8 million a year ago.

site_title: BHP, Vale shares slide on Brazil mining lawsuit
summary: BHP Billiton shares fell 1.92% to A$18.43 after Brazilian prosecutors filed a $43.4 billion lawsuit over a mine accident that killed 19 people and caused environmental damage. The lawsuit affects BHP's co-owner, Vale, which also saw its stock tumble 5.34% in Sao Paulo on Wednesday. The lawsuit's large size took traders aback, contributing to the decline.

images.alt_text: Shares in Anglo-Australian mining giant BHP Billiton fell further Thursday after Brazilian prosecutors filed a US$43.4 billion lawsuit over a mine accident that killed 19 people and wreaked environmental havoc.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars limp off lows, helped by data
summary: The Australian dollar rose to US$0.7489 after data showed a narrowing trade deficit in March, beating forecasts. The country's exports jumped 4% and retail sales surprised with a 0.4% gain. The New Zealand dollar also rose to US$0.6893, despite the Reserve Bank of Australia's easing and sliding dairy prices. Analysts expect the currencies to trade within specific ranges, with the Aussie expected to consolidate ahead of US payrolls data.

site_title: London home prices see parents jeopardise finances to help kids
summary: London home prices have reached record highs, forcing parents to jeopardize their finances to help their children buy apartments. According to a report by Legal & General Group, parents are giving half of their net wealth to their children as gifts or loans to secure deposits. This trend, known as the "Bank of Mom and Dad," is putting parents' financial stability at risk. With the median gross salary in London remaining unchanged, home prices are outpacing incomes, making it difficult for first-time buyers to enter the market.

site_title: Britain's largest broadband provider BT to invest £6b on fibre, 4G upgrades
summary: Britain's largest broadband provider BT plans to invest £6 billion in fibre and 4G upgrades over the next three years, aiming to improve connectivity nationwide. The company reported a 6% rise in full-year earnings, with core earnings reaching £6.58 billion. Revenue increased by 6% to £18.91 billion, driven by the addition of mobile operator EE at the end of January. The investment is part of BT's efforts to expand its services and meet growing demand for high-speed internet and mobile connectivity.

site_title: Big data breaches found at major email services according to experts
summary: Hundreds of millions of hacked usernames and passwords, including those of Mail.ru, Google, Yahoo, and Microsoft, are being traded in Russia's criminal underworld. According to Alex Holden, founder of Hold Security, 272.3 million stolen accounts were discovered, one of the largest breaches since cyber attacks on major US banks and retailers two years ago. Experts warn that this could lead to widespread identity theft and other cybercrimes.

site_title: US judge says Clinton may have to testify in email lawsuit
summary: US District Judge Emmet Sullivan ordered Hillary Clinton to potentially testify in a lawsuit related to her private email server. The case, brought by Judicial Watch, seeks access to records related to a Clinton aide's employment. Clinton's former top aides will give testimonies over the next eight weeks, which may require Clinton to be deposed. The lawsuit seeks information on the creation and operation of the private server and whether the State Department conducted an adequate search for emails.

site_title: Goldman cuts Hong Kong property seeing 20% drop in home prices
summary: Goldman Sachs has downgraded Hong Kong's property sector to neutral, predicting a 20% decline in home prices due to rising interest rates and limited government loosening measures. The bank cut its rating on several property companies, including New World Development and Hysan Development, and added Cheung Kong Property Holdings as a buy. The Hang Seng Properties Index fell 0.6% to a one-month low, with the office segment being the most defensive and retail remaining weak. Goldman predicts developers will shift focus to building investment properties for rent.

site_title: Oil prices up as Canada wildfires threaten crude output
summary: Oil prices rose in Asia due to wildfires in Canada's Alberta oil sands region, threatening crude output. The wildfires prompted oil companies to reduce operations and evacuate non-essential employees, while a decline in US crude production also boosted prices. US benchmark West Texas Intermediate rose 2.19% to $44.74 a barrel, and Brent crude climbed 1.79% to $45.42 a barrel. Analysts believe the Canada wildfires and US production decline will help ease the global supply glut, leading to a potential market rebalancing over the next few quarters.

site_title: Takata survival gets harder as deaths climb amid wider recalls
summary: Takata Corp faces increasing pressure as two more deaths in Malaysia are linked to ruptured air bag inflators, raising the total number of fatalities to 13. The Japanese supplier must replace up to 40 million additional air bags in the US, more than doubling the previous recall. The company's market value has plummeted 75% in the past year, and it's seeking a financial lifeline to survive. With 69 million inflators now recalled, the costs are estimated to be around $4.75 billion, and the company may need to exit the inflator business to survive.

site_title: North Korea readies for party congress, nuclear test fears persist
summary: North Korea is set to hold its most important ruling party gathering in nearly 40 years, with leader Kim Jong-Un expected to deliver a keynote address. The congress aims to cement Kim's status as supreme leader and legitimize his "byungjin" policy of pursuing nuclear weapons and economic development. Despite no clear signs of an imminent nuclear test, concerns persist, with South Korean officials believing the North is ready to conduct a test at any moment. The event will also elect a new central committee and select the party politburo, with significant personnel changes predicted.

site_title: South Korea to add oil storage as traders eye China teapots
summary: South Korea plans to add 3.5-5 million barrels of crude storage capacity in the second half of 2016 to supply China's independent refineries, known as "teapots." The country's state-run explorer, Korea National Oil Corp, aims to complete onshore tanks and an underground cavern to meet the growing demand. The move comes as China's inbound crude shipments reached a record high, and independent processors are expected to buy more crude from overseas due to eased import rules.

site_title: Operating conditions deteriorate across Singapore private sector in April: Nikkei Singapore PMI
summary: Singapore's private sector saw a slight deterioration in operating conditions in April, with the Nikkei Singapore PMI falling to 49.4 from March's 52.0. Output growth slowed to a marginal pace, driven by a drop in new orders and softer market conditions. Companies also recorded falls in purchasing activity and employment, with stocks of inputs declining markedly. This suggests that new stimulus measures may be needed to counteract sluggish growth, and weak inflationary pressures provide room for such measures.

site_title: China's military deploys its first corruption inspectors
summary: China's military has deployed dedicated teams of corruption inspectors for the first time, following a practice established for civilian departments as part of President Xi Jinping's anti-corruption campaign. The move comes after dozens of officers, including two former vice-chairmen, were investigated and accused of corruption. The inspectors, who completed a two-day training, will be organized into 10 teams to investigate corruption in various military units nationwide. The move aims to strengthen the armed forces and prevent corruption from compromising national security, with President Xi emphasizing the importance of the inspectors' role in cleaning up the military.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks extend fall on uncertain economic, political outlook
summary: Taiwan's stocks fell 0.5% on Thursday, reaching near three-month lows, due to uncertainty over weak economic data and the inauguration of new President Tsai Ing-wen later this month. The main Taiex index closed at 8,148.09. Asian shares slipped for a seventh consecutive session amid concerns about global growth and deflation. The Taiwan dollar softened against the US dollar. A Reuters poll predicted Taiwan's exports contracted for the 15th straight month in April, ahead of the island's trade data release on Monday.

site_title: Presidential frontrunner Duterte facing coup rumours in Philippines
summary: Philippine presidential frontrunner Rodrigo Duterte is facing coup rumours after his anti-establishment rise to favouritism, with opponents warning he's a dictator in the making. Duterte enjoys a double-digit lead ahead of Monday's election, but has made enemies with vows to support communist rebels and threaten the government. His promises have sparked concerns of military unrest, with warnings of a potential coup if he wins. Duterte's tumultuous rise has reignited fears of a return to authoritarian rule in the Philippines, which has struggled with democracy since the 1986 overthrow of dictator Ferdinand Marcos.

site_title: Jail no barrier to political career in Philippines
summary: In the Philippines, several politicians accused or convicted of major crimes are running for office in national elections. Sajid Ampatuan, who spent five years in jail for his alleged role in the 2009 "Maguindanao Massacre," is running for mayor despite his father's conviction for mass murder. Other candidates include two ex-presidents, Gloria Arroyo and Joseph Estrada, who are facing corruption and vote fraud charges. Despite being convicted or on trial, these candidates are allowed to run for office due to a loophole in the law that requires them to be "convicted with finality" to be disqualified.

site_title: Asia: Stocks fall seventh day as global growth concerns linger
summary: Asian stocks fell for a seventh consecutive day, the longest losing streak in almost five months, amid global economic growth concerns. The MSCI Asia Pacific excluding Japan Index declined 0.4% due to weak company earnings and lackluster manufacturing and employment data. The US payrolls report on Friday is expected to further impact investors' assessment of monetary policy. Gold is seen as a safe-haven investment, with billionaire Stan Druckenmiller allocating to it, citing the exhaustion of the bull market in stocks.

site_title: Brazil's empty factories may be Blackstone's buying opportunity
summary: Blackstone Group LP, the world's largest private-equity property investor, sees opportunities in Brazil's industrial and logistics assets due to the country's economic and political uncertainties. With over 4,000 factories ceasing operations last year and a further 3.9% contraction expected this year, Blackstone believes that investment in warehouses and logistics facilities can be a "really interesting and compelling opportunity." Despite high vacancies, institutional investors are attracted to modern, state-of-the-art properties, and prices are not trading at distressed levels due to low leverage levels and a recovering market.

site_title: Epic wildfire threatens to engulf Canadian city as 88,000 flee
summary: A massive wildfire in Alberta, Canada, has forced the evacuation of 88,000 people from the city of Fort McMurray, destroying 1,600 structures and burning 18,500 acres of land since its eruption on Sunday. Authorities warn that the fire has the potential to destroy much of the town, with only 80% of houses in one neighborhood remaining intact. The province has declared a state of emergency, and the military has offered to deploy air force planes to assist in the relief efforts.

site_title: Gold holds three-day decline as investors weigh Fed rate outlook
summary: Gold prices declined for a third consecutive day as investors weighed the Federal Reserve's interest rate outlook ahead of Friday's payroll data. The metal fell to $1,279.75 per ounce, down from its peak of $1,300 earlier in the week.
