Despite a 21% year-to-date gain, gold prices retreated after speculation about a slow interest rate hike amid global growth concerns and low lending rates in the euro area and Japan.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Thursday
summary: Malaysia's shares opened lower on Thursday, with the FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index down 6.660 points to 1653.050. Volume was 44.2 million lots worth RM12.7 million, with 81 gainers and 64 losers.

site_title: Australian retail prices nearly flat in Q1, trade deficit narrows
summary: Australian retail prices remained flat in Q1, with inflation slowing to 0.1% in March, the lowest since 2014. Retail sales grew 0.4% in March and 0.5% when adjusted for inflation. Food prices were flat, the lowest reading in three years, due to discount wars between supermarkets. The country's trade deficit narrowed to $2.2 billion in March, driven by a 4% rise in exports. The Reserve Bank of Australia cut interest rates to an all-time low of 1.75% due to low inflation.

site_title: PayPal launches inaugural incubation programme in Singapore
summary: PayPal is launching a nine-month incubation program in Singapore targeting financial technology and technology start-ups. The program offers coaching, mentorship, networking opportunities, and venture capital connections, along with a co-working space. This is the second country in the Asia-Pacific to run the program, following India, where most of the 10 startups have received funding or strategic exits. The program aims to foster innovation and collaboration among start-ups in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Uber assembles international insights in policy board
summary: Uber has introduced a newly formed policy board with international experts, including former EU vice president Neelie Kroes, to navigate regulatory challenges worldwide. The board, formed in response to the ride-sharing service's growing global presence, includes representatives from the US, Australia, India, and Saudi Arabia, among others. The board aims to provide "candid advice and insights" on Uber's business and regulatory issues, as the company faces resistance from traditional taxi drivers and bans in some places due to safety and tax concerns.

site_title: Australia faces challenges in curbing spending: Moody's
summary: Moody's has warned Australia will face challenges in achieving fiscal consolidation due to subdued economic growth and large spending obligations. The ratings agency expects Australia's debt burden to rise, constraining fiscal space to buffer potential negative economic shocks. This highlights difficulties in curbing spending, particularly in the face of successive budget revisions towards more persistent deficits.

site_title: South Korea, Indonesia, Thailand: Market closed on Thursday
summary: Financial markets in Indonesia, South Korea, and Thailand are closed on Thursday for public holidays. Meanwhile, Singapore stocks have extended a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with the STI up 0.4% on Thursday. In the US, the S&P 500 and Nasdaq edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty, with investors staying positive despite split Fed views. Additionally, Airalo, an eSIM platform, has raised $220 million in funding, lifting its valuation past $1 billion.

site_title: Yahoo takes hit with loss of AT&T contract
summary: Yahoo's internet business took a hit after losing a 15-year contract with AT&T to manage the portal and search services. The US$100 million annual revenue deal will be handled by Synacor, ending Yahoo's involvement in 2017. The loss is a blow to Yahoo, which is trying to sell the company as part of a spin-off of Alibaba holdings. The struggling internet pioneer reported a net loss of $99 million in the first quarter, with revenues slumping 12% compared to the same period last year.

site_title: Philippines' April inflation steady at 1.1%
summary: Philippines' annual inflation remained steady at 1.1% in April, matching the central bank's forecast of 0.7-1.5%. Core inflation and consumer prices also remained unchanged. This steady inflation rate supports the central bank's decision to keep interest rates on hold when it meets next week. The central bank aims for a 2-4% inflation target for 2016 and 2017.

site_title: Brazil says almost 1,300 hit by Zika-linked microcephaly
summary: Brazil reported 1,271 cases of Zika-linked microcephaly, resulting in 57 baby deaths and 178 suspected deaths. The Health Ministry also identified 3,580 suspected cases and 2,492 ruled out as false alarms. The Zika virus, linked to microcephaly and adult-onset neurological problems, has no vaccine or treatment and is largely contained to Latin America and the Caribbean.

site_title: Stocks to watch: Sembcorp Industries, First Ship Lease Trust, POSH
summary: Sembcorp Industries reported a 25% year-on-year decline in net profit to S$107 million due to oil-and-gas exposure and higher finance costs. First Ship Lease Trust's net profit fell 55.1% to US$2.3 million, while PACC Offshore Services Holdings (POSH) saw a significant increase in net profit to US$4.5 million, driven by revenue growth from its offshore accommodation business division.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Packer cuts Macau stake, stoking Crown buyout speculation
summary: Crown Resorts, a gaming company controlled by billionaire James Packer, sold US$800 million worth of shares in its Macau venture, reducing its stake to 27% from 34%. The move raises speculation that Packer may be increasing his firepower for a potential buyout of Australian casino assets. Packer will resign as co-chairman of Melco Crown Entertainment and become deputy chairman. The stock sale provides Packer with more options and could lead to a potential return to shareholders.

site_title: HDB resale volumes up 10.3% in April as prices continue to slide
summary: HDB resale volumes rose 10.3% in April, with 1,828 flats sold, exceeding the record high since 2013 cooling measures. Resale prices moderated 0.1% overall, with five-room flats dropping 0.9%, while three-room and executive flats rose 0.6% and 0.1% respectively. Prices have fallen 11.1% from the 2013 peak and 0.2% from last year, with resale volumes still half the May 2010 peak.

site_title: China to invest 77b yuan in aviation infrastructure in 2016: Xinhua
summary: China plans to invest 77 billion yuan (S$16.16 billion) in aviation infrastructure in 2016, focusing on airports, with 11 key construction projects and 52 upgrades. The Civil Aviation Administration of China (CAAC) aims to boost the general aviation sector, which has become a hot spot for industrial upgrading and social concern. China's cabinet also announced support for the aviation industry, including opening up low-altitude air space, to foster the growth of the sector.

site_title: Aeropostale clears early hurdle by securing bankruptcy loan
summary: Aeropostale secured a US$100 million interim financing package from Crystal Financial LLC, overcoming the first hurdle in its bankruptcy reorganization plans. The move was approved by US bankruptcy judge Sean Lane despite opposition from Aeropostale's senior lender, Sycamore Partners, which deemed the plans "illusory" and predicted liquidation unless a buyer emerges in two to four weeks.

site_title: Australian banks signal end of era of dividend growth
summary: Australia's major banks, including Westpac, ANZ, and National Australia Bank, have signaled an end to the era of dividend growth after seven years, citing record-low margins and tougher capital requirements. ANZ cut dividends for the first time in seven years, while Westpac and National Australia Bank kept their dividends unchanged. The move is expected to impact investors, particularly the US$1.5 trillion pension industry, which may see lower returns in the future.

site_title: Temasek unit backs startup diamond exchange as trade kicks off
summary: Temasek Holdings' venture-capital unit Vertex Venture Holdings backs Singapore's first diamond exchange, the Singapore Diamond Investment Exchange, which began trading on May 5, 2016. The exchange allows electronic trading of single stones and baskets of investment-grade diamonds, providing a transparent price-discovery mechanism. This shift marks a departure from the centuries-old manual and bilateral trading system. Investors can now trade diamonds as an asset class, with trading hours from 2:30 pm to 6:30 pm in Singapore. The exchange is regulation-ready and backed by other early investors, including Jim Rogers and Hsieh Fu Hua.

site_title: Honda says two more deaths in Malaysia linked to Takata airbags
summary: Honda reports two additional deaths in Malaysia linked to Takata airbags, bringing the global total to 13. The fatalities occurred in crashes involving ruptured driver-side airbag inflators made by Takata in Malaysia's Sabah and Kedah states. US regulators have ordered Takata to replace up to 40 million additional airbags in the US due to moisture seeping into the inflators. Honda is working with Malaysian authorities to notify owners of affected vehicles and arrange recalls.

site_title: Alibaba investors seek catalyst for shares as China slows
summary: Alibaba Group Holding's shares have declined 6.6% this year despite revenue growth, as the company struggles to recapture its pre-IPO value due to a slowing China economy. Alibaba's shares have lost more than a third of their value since peaking at US$120 in 2014. The company's reliance on Chinese consumer spending poses a challenge, and investors are looking for a catalyst, such as a resurgence in revenue growth or progress in faster-growing South East Asia markets, to push the stock higher.

site_title: Australia new homes sales rebound in March: industry survey
summary: Australia's new homes sales surged 8.9% in March, a seven-month high, according to an industry survey. Detached homes sales rose 7% and multi-unit sector sales increased 16.3%. The Housing Industry Association attributes this growth to strong consumer spending and house building, as well as a recent interest rate cut by the Reserve Bank of Australia. This positive trend is expected to continue in 2016, indicating a strong signal for the residential construction sector.

images.alt_text: Sales of new homes in Australia surged to a seven-month high in March, an industry survey showed on Thursday, a positive sign for consumer spending and house building.

site_title: California raises age to purchase tobacco to 21
summary: California has raised the age to purchase tobacco products to 21, banning the sale of vaping products to minors and imposing fines of up to $5,000 on companies that violate the law. The move aims to reduce tobacco use among teens, citing an alarming rise in e-cigarette use. The state will also expand anti-smoking programs and regulate electronic cigarettes like traditional tobacco products. The measures, part of a package signed into law by Governor Jerry Brown, aim to curb tobacco use and promote public health.

site_title: China ordering investment firms, online lenders to shut offices to head off social unrest
summary: China is ordering investment firms and online lenders to shut their offices amid growing failures and social unrest. Authorities are taking measures to curb the growth of peer-to-peer online lenders, wealth-management firms, and other shadow banking operations, which have collapsed or are at risk of collapse. The government has suspended the registration of new companies with finance-related names and is requiring local governments to monitor and report on finance industry-related tenants. The crackdown aims to prevent potential instability and social unrest, particularly ahead of the G-20 summit in September.

images.alt_text: China's authorities, seeking to forestall potential social unrest due to growing failures of investment firms and online lenders, are ordering many to break leases and close their storefronts on busy streets - lest they become magnets for protesters.

site_title: Singapore launches platform to make e-government transactions faster
summary: Singapore has launched the MYINFO platform to simplify e-government transactions by allowing citizens to provide personal data once to the government, reducing the need for repeated submissions. The platform, available for 10 e-services, aims to increase efficiency and convenience. By 2018, most SingPass-authenticated e-services will be linked to the MYINFO platform, and the government plans to expand its use to secured commercial transactions. Users can register for a MYINFO profile at www.myinfo.gov.sg using their SingPass accounts. This move aims to remove inconvenience and friction in e-government transactions.

images.alt_text: Myinfo, a consent-based platform that seeks to make e-Government transactions - such as applications for public housing flats, the Baby Bonus scheme or polytechnic admissions - faster and easier for citizens, was officially launched on Thursday.

site_title: Big three in credit ratings still dominate business
summary: US regulators have failed to loosen the grip of the big three credit rating agencies, Moody's Investors Service, S&P Global Ratings, and Fitch Ratings, on the bond rating business. Despite post-crisis reforms, the big three still dominate the market, employing over 88% of analysts. Investors remain wedded to their ratings, making it difficult for smaller firms like DBRS to gain a share. Legislation aimed at reducing reliance on ratings has had little effect, and market participants say it will take a long time for the smaller agencies to carve out business.

site_title: As Trump becomes presumptive nominee, China urges objectivity
summary: China urged US citizens to take a rational and objective view of the US-China relationship following Donald Trump's election as Republican nominee, amid concerns over his proposed tariffs and trade deficit comparisons. China's foreign ministry spokesman stated that the relationship is mutually beneficial and win-win, while Chinese officials have generally avoided criticizing Trump directly. However, some officials, like finance minister Lou Jiwei, have made indirect criticism of Trump's tariffs proposal.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Shares suffer fresh losses at open
summary: Hong Kong shares fell 0.79% at open, extending losses from a sell-off in New York and Europe. The Hang Seng Index dropped to 20,363.86, while the Shanghai Composite Index slipped 0.14% to 2,987.02. The Shenzhen Composite Index eased 0.17% to 1,925.32. This follows a previous day's losses, with global markets impacted by sell-offs in the US and Europe.

site_title: Shell to Maersk count on Qatar to provide cleaner fuels at sea
summary: Shipping companies Maersk and United Arab Shipping Co are testing liquefied natural gas to power their vessels, aiming to curb pollution and create a new market for the cleaner-burning fuel. Qatar and Royal Dutch Shell Plc have agreed to work together to develop LNG as a maritime fuel, with Qatar investing US$2.3 billion in LNG-capable ships since 2014. This partnership is seen as a priority for Qatar, the world's second-largest LNG supplier, and Shell, the largest LNG-trading company, to find new customers in an oversupplied market.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower again on Thursday
summary: The Straits Times Index (STI) in Singapore fell 0.75% or 20.93 points to 2,752.14 in early trading on Thursday, May 5, 2016, due to weaker performances in the US and Europe. The top gainers included Jardine Matheson, ST Engineering, and SATS, while top losers were Venture Corp, DBS, and UOB.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: F&N to beef up capacity in Malaysia with over S$70m investment
summary: F&N, a subsidiary of Fraser and Neave Holdings Bhd, plans to invest over S$70 million in Malaysia to boost capacity and drive business growth. The investments will include an aseptic bottle line, warehouse facility, and ultra-high temperature processing line. The total asset value in Malaysia is expected to increase to RM1.9 billion.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Canada PM: Important to have firms like Bombardier creating jobs
summary: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau emphasized the importance of companies like Bombardier creating jobs in Canada. During a press conference, Trudeau stated that the goal is to create conditions for long-term success, leading to a thriving aerospace industry. Trudeau is currently discussing an aid package with Bombardier, aiming to secure good jobs and a vibrant industry.

site_title: Hong Kong cracks down on illegal money flows from China trade
summary: Hong Kong has launched a crackdown on fake trade invoicing, a method used to channel billions of dollars of illicit capital out of China. The move aims to combat a surge in capital outflows following China's stock market crash and yuan devaluation. Hong Kong's customs and financial sectors are increasing scrutiny of trade financing operations, conducting raids on warehouses, and conducting random checks on shipments. The crackdown reflects concerns about billions of dollars in illicit cash, with some estimates suggesting that up to 10% of exports from Hong Kong to China may be falsified.

site_title: Bangladesh Bank officials say to meet NY Fed, Swift; seek to recover stolen money
summary: Bangladesh's central bank chief, Fazle Kabir, will meet with the head of the Federal Reserve Bank of New York and a Swift executive in Basel, Switzerland, to seek the recovery of $81 million stolen by hackers in a February cyber heist. The Bangladesh Bank officials believe both the New York Fed and Swift bear responsibility for the heist, which was facilitated by the global financial messaging service Swift. The meeting is seen as a step towards recovering the stolen funds, but a potential lawsuit may face difficulties due to contracts requiring only "due care" to prevent such a hack.

site_title: S&P downgrades Halliburton, affirms Baker Hughes
summary: S&P Global downgraded Halliburton to A- due to the termination of a merger agreement with Baker Hughes, citing high debt levels and potential financial weakening. Halliburton will pay a $3.5 billion termination fee. The rating agency also placed the ratings on watch negative, warning of further downgrades.

site_title: Hong Kong's 'prince of toys' playing up to high-tech tastes
summary: Hong Kong billionaire Francis Choi's son Karson is revamping the family's toy empire, Early Light International Holdings, by incorporating high-tech features into toys. The company, which supplies top brands, aims to diversify into high-margin areas like electronics and medical products through remote-controlling toys via smartphone apps. The move is part of a broader strategy to rejuvenate the business and capitalize on growing demand for tech-enabled toys.

site_title: HLH clarifies erroneous announcement on SGX StockFacts portal
summary: HLH Group has clarified that an erroneous announcement on the SGX StockFacts portal in February stated the company had cancelled its acquisition of a land parcel in Cambodia. The land is actually being developed into a freehold residential project called D'Seaview. The announcements were removed after the company requested, and SGX has apologized for the error.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Trump faces task of uniting party around White House bid; Kasich bows out
summary: Donald Trump's Republican presidential nomination bid has become more unified after John Kasich's withdrawal. Kasich, the last challenger, dropped out of the race, leaving Trump as the presumptive nominee. Trump now faces the task of uniting a fractured party behind his White House bid. Kasich's campaign cancellation and scheduled statement in Ohio signify his decision to suspend his campaign. This move clears the path for Trump to focus on uniting the party for the general election.

site_title: Stubborn Shanghai residents hold a line drawn in rubble
summary: In Shanghai's Guangfuli neighborhood, a 16-year standoff between residents and a developer has resulted in a stalemate. Hundreds of people refuse to leave their ramshackle homes, which are worth millions, due to a dispute over land ownership. Residents claim they inherited the properties from their work units, while the developer argues they do not have a property right certificate. The local authority wants to demolish the neighborhood, but the residents are unwilling to budge, highlighting China's unresolved property rights issue.

site_title: Strong US services sector data buoys economic outlook
summary: The US services sector expanded in April, driven by new orders and employment growth, bolstering economic growth views. The Institute for Supply Management's non-manufacturing index rose to 55.7, indicating expansion. Services industry activity was fueled by a surge in new orders and employment, but private employers hired the fewest workers in three years in April. Economists expect the economy to rebound in the second quarter, with a possible interest rate hike in June.

site_title: Ralph Lauren CEO shakes up management in growth push
summary: Ralph Lauren CEO Stefan Larsson is shaking up management to boost growth, which has been sluggish due to mall traffic decline and a strong US dollar. Valerie Hermann is promoted to global brand president for luxury, women's collections, and accessories, while Christine Beauchamp is leaving the company in mid-May. Larsson aims to cut $110 million in annual costs and restore sales, which were forecasted to rise only 1% this year. The company expects one-time charges of $120-150 million as part of the reorganization effort.

site_title: Qatar said in talks for St Regis NYC, San Francisco hotels
summary: Qatar's investment authority is in talks to buy the St Regis hotels in New York and San Francisco from Starwood Hotels & Resorts for approximately US$1 billion. This deal comes as Starwood prepares to be acquired by Marriott International next quarter, aiming to sell its remaining US real estate. The Qatar Investment Authority has invested around US$38 billion in global property, including hotels, and plans to invest US$35 billion in the US over the next five years.

site_title: TripAdvisor revenue falls as referral revenue drops
summary: TripAdvisor Inc. reported a 3% decline in quarterly revenue, missing analyst estimates, due to a drop in referral revenue. The company's hotel booking feature, introduced in 2014, led to a 13.3% decline in referral revenue to $189 million. This was largely offset by growth in hotel bookings on its websites, as the feature was rolled out globally in the first quarter. TripAdvisor's profit also fell more than expected.

site_title: Selfie gone wrong fells 126-year-old statue of Portuguese king
summary: A 126-year-old statue of 16th-century Portuguese King Dom Sebastiao in Lisbon, Portugal, was damaged when a young man accidentally toppled it while taking a selfie. The statue, completed in 1890, stood outside the Rossio railway station and was a protected monument. The man, who hasn't been identified, tried to flee but was caught by police. He will face a judge later. The incident has sparked concern over the safety of historic monuments in tourist areas.

site_title: Canada PM pledges support as thousands flee monster wildfire
summary: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau pledged support for Fort McMurray, Alberta, after a monster wildfire forced the evacuation of tens of thousands of residents. No casualties have been reported, but 80% of residences in the suburb of Beacon Hill have been destroyed. Trudeau offered "total support" to Alberta Premier Rachel Notley, and oil companies reduced operations to facilitate the evacuation. The fire, fueled by drought and high winds, has left residents without access to their homes, with authorities urging them not to return.

images.alt_text: Canadian Prime Minister Justin Trudeau pledged support for the city of Fort McMurray Wednesday after tens of thousands of residents were forced to flee a monster wildfire sweeping through Alberta's oil sands region.

site_title: Judge convicts head of Mitsubishi Motors representative in Brazil
summary: A Brazilian judge convicted Robert de Macedo, president of Mitsubishi Motors's distributor and assembler in Brazil, for fomenting corruption and money laundering in a bribery scheme. Macedo was sentenced to four years and two months in jail for hiring lobbyists off the books. The "Operation Zealots" investigation, focusing on bribes to lawmakers, ensured measures favored by the auto industry were passed during the governments of President Dilma Rousseff and Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva. The company's former president and several lobbyists were also sentenced.

site_title: IMF warns Denmark of risk for exports if Britain quits EU
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) has warned Denmark that its exports to the UK would likely suffer if Britain votes to leave the European Union at the June referendum. Denmark's exports to the UK are significant, with Great Britain being its third-largest market after Germany and Sweden. The IMF's head, David Hofman, stated that a Brexit would have a prolonged period of uncertainty, affecting trade flows and international financial markets. This could have a negative impact on Denmark's economy, which has been experiencing slow growth.

site_title: Tokyo: Markets closed for holiday on Thursday
summary: Japanese financial markets are closed on Thursday for a public holiday. Meanwhile, in Singapore, stocks notched a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data, with the STI up 0.4% on Thursday. In other news, eSIM platform Airalo raised US$220 million in funding, lifting its valuation past US$1 billion, and US stocks edged to fresh records despite tariff uncertainty.

site_title: London mayoral front-runner hopes to unite city
summary: London mayoral candidate Sadiq Khan vowed to unite the city's communities if elected, amid a divisive campaign against him from Conservative rival Zac Goldsmith. Khan, a 45-year-old Muslim and Labour candidate, leads Goldsmith by 12-14 points in final polls. Khan's campaign focuses on addressing housing costs and bringing communities together, differing from Goldsmith's attacks on his ties to Islamic extremists. If elected, Khan will be the first Muslim mayor of an EU capital.

site_title: In U-turn, Britain to let in more Syrian child refugees
summary: Britain has announced a U-turn, allowing a limited number of child refugees from Syria to enter the country. The decision, made by Prime Minister David Cameron, comes after a parliamentary vote next week on a proposal by Alf Dubs, a member of the House of Lords, to increase the number of child refugees accepted. Around 95,000 unaccompanied children applied for asylum in Europe last year, and lone Syrian children who registered in Greece, Italy, or France before March 20 will be considered for entry. The exact number of children to be accepted has not been disclosed.

site_title: Addiction specialist rushed to see Prince before death
summary: Addiction specialist Howard Kornfeld, who treats opioid addiction, rushed to see Prince at his Minnesota compound on April 22, but arrived too late. Kornfeld had cleared his schedule after Prince's representatives contacted him, and his son, a medical student, had visited Prince the previous day. The specialist had hoped to stabilize Prince and convince him to seek treatment at his clinic in California. Prince was found unconscious, and an autopsy was conducted, but the cause of death remains unknown, with no evidence of trauma or suicide.

site_title: YouTube said to plan 'Unplugged' online TV service for 2017
summary: YouTube is planning a paid subscription service called 'Unplugged' that would stream cable TV channels over the internet, set to debut in 2017. The project involves major media companies, including Comcast, Viacom, and Fox, but rights have yet to be secured. YouTube has already overhauled its technical architecture to support the service. The company has discussed the plans with media executives, but no agreements have been reached. The Unplugged service would offer users a bundle of channels, marking a significant shift for the online video giant.

site_title: Oil prices drift as US crude output falls
summary: US oil output fell by 100,000 barrels a day, its lowest level since September 2014, amid low import prices and producers cutting back. Oil prices drifted sideways, with US WTI crude finishing at $43.78 a barrel, up 13 cents from Tuesday, and London Brent crude dropping 35 cents to $44.62. US crude and gasoline stockpiles increased, a bearish signal for the market, but a major wildfire in Alberta, Canada, threatened production from the oil sands region, supporting US prices.

site_title: Europe: Shares led down by Dialog and BHP; Athens outperforms
summary: European stocks fell 1.2% to 1,302.72 points, their lowest closing level in nearly four weeks, due to declines in Dialog Semiconductor and BHP Billiton. Greek stocks rose 1.1% despite a bear market outlook. Mining stocks were pressured by weak copper prices, while bank stocks such as Societe Generale rose after announcing cost cuts. The decline was attributed to concerns about a slowdown in China and a lawsuit filed against BHP Billiton in Brazil.

site_title: Dollar rallies again as US services sector picks up
summary: The US dollar rose for a second straight day as data showed stronger growth in the services sector, including employment, and a shrinking trade deficit. The dollar increased 0.2% against the euro and 0.4% against the yen. A positive employment component in the ISM services sector index was seen as a boost for the dollar, but a disappointing ADP private sector jobs survey raised concerns about a potential June rate hike and its impact on the dollar.

site_title: Developers eye Bangkok's historic Chinatown
summary: Bangkok's historic Chinatown is set to undergo significant changes with the construction of a new metro service, which will transform the area into a property goldmine. The proposed metro station, expected to open in 2018, will link the riverside district to downtown Bangkok. Residents, including 92-year-old Thanuan Amnueilap, fear eviction as developers and the Bangkok governor's charity close in, with land prices soaring over 20% in the past five years. The community is fighting to preserve the area's historic value, with preservationists arguing that nearly 7,000 buildings need protection, despite the government only listing 26 as heritage sites.

site_title: Witching Hour Studios hits Kickstarter target
summary: Witching Hour Studios, a Singapore-based video game start-up, successfully funded its upcoming game, Masquerada: Songs And Shadows, on Kickstarter, surpassing its £45,000 goal. The game, a role-playing game mixing action and traditional elements, features a star-studded voice cast, including Jennifer Hale and Matthew Mercer. The studio plans to use the additional funds to improve the game's aesthetics, despite it being complete. The game is set for release in the third quarter of 2016.

site_title: Bacteria hampers mosquitoes' ability to spread Zika: study
summary: Researchers have discovered that a bacterium called Wolbachia can reduce mosquitoes' ability to spread the Zika virus. In a study in Brazil, mosquitoes carrying Wolbachia were given the Zika virus and found to have fewer viral particles and inactive virus in their saliva. This suggests that releasing Wolbachia-infected mosquitoes in the field could slow the spread of Zika. However, the bacteria does not eliminate transmission entirely, and a combination of approaches, including vaccines and insecticides, is needed to curb the outbreak.

site_title: ECB scraps 500-euro note
summary: The European Central Bank announced it will stop producing and issuing 500-euro banknotes by the end of 2018, citing concerns that the violet-colored bills facilitate illicit activities such as money laundering and terrorist financing. The decision comes after a Harvard University study found that the 500-euro note is prized by criminals for its anonymity and ease of transport. Existing bills will remain legal tender, and those in circulation can be exchanged at national central banks for an unlimited period.

site_title: Corruption twist boosts Brazil's 'president in waiting'
summary: Brazil's President Dilma Rousseff faces growing corruption allegations, potentially weakening her grip on power. A leaked document reveals chief prosecutor Rodrigo Janot's request to investigate Rousseff, ex-president Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva, and other allies on corruption charges linked to Petrobras. The move comes as the Senate prepares to vote on impeaching Rousseff on unrelated charges, with Vice President Michel Temer poised to take over if she is suspended. The corruption probe has already led to dozens of arrests and convictions, with Temer surprisingly not being included on Janot's list.

site_title: Fox profit down despite Deadpool boost
summary: 21st Century Fox reported a 14% drop in net profit to $841 million in the first quarter, despite a boost from the film Deadpool, which grossed over $760 million at the box office. Revenues rose 6% to $7.23 billion, driven by growth in cable network programming and advertising. The company credited the results to the demonstrated value of its brands and creative content, with executives noting that the outstanding content will drive businesses forward in the evolving media marketplace.

site_title: Tesla accelerates to hit target of making 500,000 cars
summary: Tesla accelerates its production timeline to hit its target of 500,000 cars by 2018, two years ahead of schedule, driven by strong demand for its Model 3 electric vehicle. The company plans to deliver 80,000-90,000 vehicles this year and expects Model 3 deliveries to begin late next year at a price of around $35,000. Tesla's revenue increased 45% to $1.6 billion in the past quarter, with net loss narrowing 34% to $75 million.

site_title: Effects of BOJ's monetary easing will show in time: Kuroda
summary: Bank of Japan (BOJ) governor Haruhiko Kuroda defended the central bank's monetary policy, citing overall positive effects on the Japanese economy despite 15 years of deflation. Kuroda stated that the benefits of negative interest rates will show in "within a few months," and the BOJ's policies are aimed at achieving price stability at 2%. He noted that the quantitative and qualitative easing (QQE) introduced in 2013 has had the intended impact, with a significant decline in the yield curve and a positive effect on the real economy.

site_title: NYC art auction season to kick off, break a taboo
summary: The NYC art auction season is set to begin, featuring over 1,500 artworks expected to fetch over $1 billion. The season's opening auction at Christie's will include a provocative statue of Hitler by artist Maurizio Cattelan, which is expected to sell for $10-15 million. This taboo-smashing piece is part of a five-day auction schedule, which will also include paintings by Jean-Michel Basquiat and Cy Twombly.

site_title: Target gets tough with vendors to speed up supply chain
summary: Target Corp is cracking down on suppliers to speed up its supply chain and compete with rivals like Wal-Mart and Amazon. The retailer plans to tighten warehouse delivery deadlines, hike fines for late deliveries, and impose penalties of up to $10,000 for inaccurate product information. This overhaul aims to improve efficiency and reduce costs, ultimately benefiting Target's bottom line.

site_title: Seven big banks settle US rate-rigging lawsuit for US$324m
summary: Seven major US banks, including Bank of America, Barclays, Citigroup, and JPMorgan Chase, have agreed to pay a total of US$324 million to settle a lawsuit accusing them of rigging a key interest rate benchmark. The settlement resolves antitrust claims against these banks, which are among the world's largest. The US derivatives market, valued at US$553 trillion, relies on this benchmark. The agreement requires court approval and resolves claims against the seven banks, resolving the antitrust lawsuit.

site_title: SingPost special audit report should reveal full methodology
summary: A special audit report by Singapore Post (SingPost) has raised concerns over the company's corporate governance practices, particularly in the evaluation and approval of mergers and acquisitions. The report found that SingPost director Keith Tay breached his duties as a director, despite not appearing to have influenced transactions. The audit's limitations, including reliance on interviews and minutes of meetings, have been criticized, and regulators are urged to take further action. The report's findings have sparked calls for improved corporate governance practices within the company.

site_title: China weakens yuan fix by most since August devaluation
summary: China's central bank fixed the yuan nearly 0.60% weaker against the US dollar, the biggest downward move since August 2015, as it seeks to make trading more market-oriented. The fix was set at 6.4943 to one US dollar, weakening 0.59% from the previous day. The move comes amid global growth worries and a strong US dollar, with analysts saying it's in line with the US currency's rise. China aims to maintain control over the currency, allowing it to rise or fall 2% on either side of the daily fix.

site_title: Trade deficit shrinks as imports fall 3.6%
summary: The US trade deficit narrowed 13.9% to $40.4 billion in March, the smallest since February 2015, due to a 3.6% decline in imports, the largest in seven years. This outpaced a decline in exports. The Commerce Department reported the data on Wednesday.

images.alt_text: Imported merchandise declined 3.6 per cent, the most since February 2009, as American companies strived to get inventories in line with weaker first-quarter demand. At the same time, shipments overseas fell for the fifth time in six months.

site_title: Janet Jackson expecting first child at 49
summary: Janet Jackson, 49, is expecting her first child, according to reports. The pop superstar, who turned 50 on May 16, halted a global tour last month and revealed plans for a family with husband Wissam Al Mana. Jackson was reportedly in her second trimester and had been seeing a fertility specialist. While natural pregnancies are less common in her age group, in vitro fertilizations can extend the age range. A representative for Jackson did not immediately respond to a request for comment.

site_title: Wall Street values Tesla Motors at US$620,000 per car
summary: Tesla Motors' market capitalization is around $31 billion, equivalent to $620,000 per car, making it one of the world's most-shorted companies. Analysts question the firm's ability to generate profit and positive cash flow in 2016, citing concerns over rapidly increasing production costs and operational setbacks. Despite CEO Elon Musk's promise to turn the company's first net profit by the fourth quarter, investors expect even more aggressive growth, with some predicting a valuation that is "priced to perfection."

site_title: US: Stocks tumble on weak jobs data
summary: US stocks fell for the second day in a row on Wednesday, with the Dow Jones shedding 0.6% and the S&P 500 and Nasdaq Composite Indexes also declining. The ADP report showed a modest 156,000 jobs added in April, below analyst expectations, raising worries about Friday's jobs report. Airlines and tech companies were particularly affected, with US airlines dropping over 3% and Priceline plummeting 7.5%. Despite the weakness, some companies, such as CBS and Medivation, rose on positive earnings reports.

site_title: Microsoft steps ups rivalry with Google, Box with new sharing software
summary: Microsoft is releasing new software to boost its rivalry with Google, Box, and Dropbox, focusing on cloud computing and file-sharing. The company is updating SharePoint, introducing phone apps, and offering free migrations to its Office cloud software. The new software aims to expand Microsoft's $3 billion annual business and modernize its traditional product, which has fallen behind cloud rivals. Analysts predict that the update will inject fresh life into the existing user base and persuade more customers to switch to the cloud version of SharePoint.

site_title: Turnbull to call for elections to be held on July 2
summary: Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull announced plans to call an election on July 2, aiming to capitalize on a budget plan focusing on jobs and growth. The conservative government delivered the spending plan on Tuesday, which effectively launched its election campaign. Turnbull plans to dissolve parliament due to a political deadlock over industrial relations, hoping to win back voters disaffected with his government's policy inaction and rejuvenate his bid for re-election.

site_title: Singapore's 1MDB probe appears centred on its Cayman investments
summary: Singapore's authorities are investigating "complex and layered transactions" with "cross-border elements" involving shell companies in the 1MDB case. This probe appears to be centered on investments in the Cayman Islands. Prosecutors, led by Tan Ken Hwee, are looking into corrupt transactions involving Kelvin Ang Wee Keng, who was charged in the ongoing probe. The investigation highlights the international scope of the 1MDB scandal, which has raised concerns about money laundering and corruption.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: More undecided about using a property agent
summary: A survey by the Council for Estate Agencies (CEA) found that 3 in 10 consumers are undecided about using a property agent for future transactions, up from 25% in 2012. The survey also revealed that consumers between 21 and 39 years old are more uncertain about engaging a property agent. Minister of State for National Development Koh Poh Koon noted that estate agents must add value to their services to retain their position in the industry. To address this, OrangeTee launched a "Property Agents Bank" search engine, which allows customers to endorse the good services of agents through reviews.

site_title: First Ship Lease Trust Q1 profit dives on loss from disposal of vessels
summary: First Ship Lease Trust's net profit fell 55.1% to US$2.3 million in Q1 2016 due to a US$4.2 million loss from the disposal of two vessels. Despite this, the trust reported a 35.5% increase in operating profit to US$9.1 million, driven by a 7.6% growth in revenue. The trust retains all income available for distribution, with US$5.4 million in income. Its gearing improved to 53.1% and outstanding debt fell 14.1% to US$263.6 million.

site_title: Trump the 'presumptive' GOP nominee as Cruz crashes
summary: Donald Trump emerged as the presumptive Republican nominee for the 2016 presidential election after winning the Indiana primary, effectively ending Ted Cruz's campaign. Trump, known for his unorthodox approach, now focuses on the likely Democratic opponent, Hillary Clinton. His victory marks a significant shift in the US presidential race.

images.alt_text: Mr Trump thumped Mr Cruz by about 53.3 per cent to 36.6, with Mr Kasich an Indiana footnote at 7.6 per cent

site_title: Average DPU of 5 industrial Reits for January-March quarter down 3.5%
summary: The average distribution per unit (DPU) for five Singapore industrial real estate investment trusts (Reits) declined 3.5% to 2.1 Singapore cents in the January-March quarter, due to a supply of industrial space outstripping demand. Viva Industrial Trust saw the largest year-on-year decline, while Mapletree Industrial Trust posted the highest increase in DPU. The Reits reported a 7.9% gain in net property income and a 2.8% year-to-date price gain, with dividends boosting total returns to 5%.

site_title: Getting past 'new normal' slow economic growth
summary: The world economy is facing a "new normal" of slower growth, with the World Bank downgrading its medium-term projections. Economists point to demand-side constraints, supply-side factors, and the impact of low GDP growth on inequality. Theories such as secular stagnation, the rise of inequality, and the concentration of income at the top contribute to this slowdown. However, there is hope for growth in developing and emerging economies, and the author believes that technological progress, including artificial intelligence, can lead to higher expected returns and more investment. Ultimately, political choices will determine whether growth benefits all or exacerbates inequality.

site_title: Recall of Takata air bags in US could grow by 35 million: source
summary: The US regulator is expected to announce a recall of at least 35 million additional Takata air bags, bringing the total to 63 million, potentially affecting nearly 1-in-4 of 250 million US vehicles. The recall focuses on air bags without a drying agent, which can become unstable over time or when exposed to moisture, causing them to explode. The expansion is an admission by Takata that its use of ammonium nitrate, a cheap but potent compound, poses a safety risk.

site_title: Keeping a close watch on the new economy and its discontents
summary: Globalization, technological advancements, and shifting corporate power dynamics pose significant challenges to job security and benefits. As companies seek to stay competitive, workers are at risk of losing jobs to cheaper labor markets and upstart industries. Governments and businesses are exploring solutions, including education and training programs, to enhance productivity and adaptability. Ultimately, workers must find ways to upskill and remain employable, while employers must balance profit maximization with the need to restore worker confidence and security.

site_title: Aeropostale files for bankruptcy
summary: Aeropostale, a teen-clothing chain, has filed for bankruptcy protection in the US Bankruptcy Court for the Southern District of New York. The company, which has struggled to adapt to online competition and changing tastes, intends to re-emerge as a standalone enterprise with a smaller store base within the next six months. Aeropostale has closed hundreds of stores and secured $160 million in debtor-in-possession financing to meet financial commitments. The company also plans to close 113 US locations and all its Canadian stores as part of its restructuring efforts.

site_title: Euro zone business surveys suggest slow but steady growth in Q2
summary: The euro zone is expected to experience steady but slow economic growth in Q2, according to Euro zone business surveys. The final composite Purchasing Managers' Index from Markit showed a reading of 53.0, indicating expansion but not a particularly dynamic one. Retail sales fell 0.5% in March, and the European Central Bank's stimulus program has yet to boost inflation, which remains below the target of 2%. Policymakers are cautiously optimistic about the economy, but warn of high external and internal risks, with subdued inflation expected this year.

site_title: AIIB chief says bank will be lean even as it scales up operations
summary: The Asian Infrastructure Investment Bank (AIIB) aims to maintain a lean operation despite scaling up its activities, according to its president Jin Liqun. The bank's core principle is to be cost-effective, reducing funding costs for borrowing countries. Jin revealed that international investors have shown enthusiasm for investing in AIIB bonds and debt instruments, and the bank plans to tap into the Chinese and international capital markets. The AIIB will prioritize financially sustainable, environmentally friendly, and socially acceptable projects, and its operations will initially focus on a few key sectors and countries before expanding to achieve a balanced portfolio.

images.alt_text: Mr Jin said the majority of the AIIB's borrowing countries would be Asian, but since it has, among its members, emerging market economies from Africa, eastern Europe and Latin America, the bank's geographical coverage would range beyond Asia.

site_title: Brokers' take
summary:

ARA Asset Management's share price is undervalued due to lack of news, with a potential for growth in 2016. The companies' dividend yields are also highlighted, with LMIRT's at 10.1% and ARA's at 8.3% based on its DPU forecast.

site_title: Corporate digest
summary: Nera Telecommunications reported a 33.4% decrease in profit after tax to S$2.03 million for the first quarter of 2016, with revenue falling 11% to S$37.5 million. Zhongmin Baihui Retail Group saw a 10% drop in net profit to 20.4 million yuan (S$4.3 million) for the same period. Abterra Ltd entered an option agreement to sell office units for S$9.24 million, incurring a pre-tax loss of about S$3.76 million.

site_title: Pfizer approaches Medivation about potential takeover: sources
summary: Pfizer Inc has approached Medivation Inc, a US cancer drug maker, to express interest in an acquisition, potentially rivaling a US$9.3 billion offer by Sanofi SA. This comes after Medivation rejected Sanofi's offer of US$52.50 per share, citing it as too low. Medivation's shares closed at US$57.52 on Tuesday. Pfizer's approach raises the possibility of a new bid for Medivation.

site_title: Amazon, Facebook lead tech firms in reporting results based on GAAP
summary: Amazon and Facebook, two of the largest tech firms, have started reporting their financial results based on Generally Accepted Accounting Principles (GAAP), a shift that could significantly impact their reported profits and market valuations. This change is a response to pressure from regulators and investors, who have criticized the industry's use of non-GAAP numbers to hide the cost of stock-based compensation. The move is expected to make Amazon's stock price more realistic, trading at 122 times projected profit, compared to 63 times previously.

site_title: Indian parliament accepts Mallya's resignation
summary: The Indian parliament has accepted Vijay Mallya's resignation from the Rajya Sabha, the upper house of parliament, after he resubmitted his letter in line with procedures. The resignation was initially rejected due to procedural issues, but Mallya's second letter was deemed genuine and unconditional. An ethics panel recommended the expulsion of the former billionaire, citing misconduct and unpaid loans totaling over $1 billion. The Enforcement Directorate has obtained a non-bailable warrant against Mallya, and the government has revoked his passport, seeking Britain's cooperation in deporting him.

site_title: Citigroup set to bring voice recognition technology to Asia
summary: Citigroup plans to introduce voice recognition technology to its retail customers in Asia, aiming to have at least one million users within the next 12 months. The technology will speed up transactions and eliminate the need for cumbersome passwords, cutting the average identity validation time to 15 seconds. The rollout will begin in Singapore, followed by Australia, Hong Kong, India, and Taiwan. This move is part of Citigroup's digital transformation strategy, which also includes the introduction of voice recognition technology in the US. Other major banks in Asia, such as HSBC and Standard Chartered, are also exploring similar voice recognition services.

site_title: Chopard siblings pay S$25m for Tong Building space
summary: The Chopard siblings have acquired a 13th-floor office space at the 19-level Tong Building in Orchard Road, Singapore, for S$25.5 million, working out to S$3,713 per square foot. The purchase is a significant deal, with the siblings paying a premium for the freehold strata area. This acquisition is part of their expansion plans, further solidifying their presence in the luxury watch and jewelry market in Singapore.

images.alt_text: Kalpana Rashiwala

site_title: Blackstone said to be in talks to buy Sime Darby's Australian assets
summary: Blackstone Group LP is in talks to acquire industrial property assets in Australia valued at approximately A$250 million (S$253.6 million) from Sime Darby Bhd. The New York-based private equity firm is discussing the acquisition of up to five industrial buildings in Australia. The deal, if finalized, would involve industrial properties valued at A$250 million. Details of the negotiations remain private.

site_title: Shopee offers partial shipping coverage and classes for sellers
summary: Garena, a Singapore-based internet company, announced plans to accelerate Shopee's growth with US$170 million in funding. The company aims to make Shopee a leading player in Southeast Asia's e-commerce market. Shopee introduced "Shopee Free Shipping" and "Shopee University" to attract users and improve seller management skills. The initiatives include reimbursing shipping costs for registered sellers and offering free classes to help sellers improve their e-commerce management skills.

images.alt_text: Garena, a Singapore-based Internet company and South-east Asia's largest unicorn (privately valued at US$3.75 billion), on Wednesday made clear its ambition for its mobile-first e-commerce platform Shopee to be a leading player in the region.

site_title: Palm oil protest urges boycott at London Stock Exchange
summary: Indigenous and civil society leaders from Indonesia, Peru, Colombia, and Liberia gathered in London to urge a boycott of firms involved in palm oil production linked to human rights violations and land seizures. They presented a petition to the London Stock Exchange, calling for investors, consumers, and governments to ensure palm oil used in the EU comes from sustainable sources. The EU is the third-largest importer of palm oil, used in various everyday goods.

site_title: Dalian Wanda Group's unit may seek backdoor listing
summary: Dalian Wanda Commercial Properties, a unit of Chinese tycoon Wang Jianlin's Dalian Wanda Group, may seek a "backdoor listing" on the Shanghai Stock Exchange if it fails to get regulatory approval for an initial public offering (IPO). The company has been disappointed with its Hong Kong-listed shares' performance and offered to make interest payments to investors if it isn't listed on Shanghai within two years. A backdoor listing could allow Dalian Wanda Commercial to tap the mainland China share market more quickly, as two previous IPO applications were rejected in 2010 and 2014.

site_title: Unsold unit costs add to squeeze on developers in sluggish market
summary: Malaysian developers face a squeeze due to sluggish sales, with unsold units mounting and associated costs adding to their burden. Unsold stock has doubled, with top developers potentially holding RM5 billion worth of unsold units. Developers must pay bridging finance charges, maintenance fees, and ancillary charges, which have increased due to a 6% GST and weaker ringgit. To move unsold stock, developers are offering incentives, such as low downpayment, rebates, and waived fees, and have resorted to creative schemes, including referral rewards and easy payment plans.

site_title: Google, Fiat Chrysler to collaborate on driverless car project
summary: Google has partnered with Fiat Chrysler to expand its testing of autonomous vehicles by installing its technology in a fleet of Chrysler Pacifica hybrid minivans. The collaboration marks a significant shift in Google's approach to self-driving cars, allowing the company to work with a traditional carmaker. Fiat Chrysler will design and engineer the minivans, while Google will integrate sensors and computer systems. The deal aims to accelerate Google's efforts to develop fully self-driving cars, which could improve road safety and accessibility.

site_title: SouFun seeks to switch listing from US to China
summary: SouFun Holdings Ltd, China's largest real estate web portal, plans to switch its stock listing from the US to the Shanghai stock exchange via an asset and share swap with storage-battery manufacturer Chongqing Wanli New Energy Co. The proposal is pending regulatory approval. The move aims to increase valuation, as China-listed stocks trade at an average 139.4 times 2015 earnings, compared to 28.4 times for Hong Kong and 40.2 times for US-listed companies. SouFun's valuation would be 40 times its expected 800 million yuan profit in 2016, based on Wanli's share price.

site_title: As sales slow, US, EU steel makers call for fair trade
summary: US and EU steel makers are calling for fair trade as sales slow due to Chinese discounting, with some politicians, like Donald Trump and Bernie Sanders, criticizing free trade. China's manufacturers, including steelmakers, have been offering rock-bottom prices to maintain sales. The World Trade Organization (WTO) provision that allows countries to use proxy countries to determine production costs expires in December, complicating China's efforts to have its market economy status acknowledged. The dispute has created a global lobbying push, with the US, Europe, and China engaging in a trade standoff.

images.alt_text: The steel industry sits at the crux of a major debate playing out across the world economy, one that could soon be intensified by a looming change in the global trade rules.

site_title: Yen, euro slip from long-term highs against US$
summary: The yen and euro retreated from long-term highs against the US dollar as markets awaited US jobs releases by the end of the week. The euro rose to near 96, sparking speculation that the European Central Bank may intervene to talk the currency down. This followed a 9.8 times oversubscription of NTT DC Reit's Singapore public offer.

site_title: As Chanel glitz comes to Havana, Cubans watch from afar
summary: French fashion house Chanel staged its first Latin American catwalk show in Havana on Tuesday, with international celebrities and Cuban bigwigs in attendance. Karl Lagerfeld showcased his latest collection, infused with Caribbean island styles and colors. However, ordinary Cubans were unable to attend, with the event being restricted due to the country's economic and social restrictions. The show marked Chanel's entry into the Latin American market, highlighting the luxury brand's growing global presence.

site_title: Raffles Medical: succession planning question
summary: Raffles Medical Group, a Singapore-based private healthcare provider, is celebrating its 40th anniversary, prompting a succession planning question. Executive Chairman and Co-Founder Loo Choon Yong, 66, is seen as the glue holding the organization together. While the company has been renewing its next-generation leaders, there is no clear frontrunner to succeed him. Analysts believe investors are relatively comfortable with the group's prospects, but a clear succession plan is needed for long-term sustainability.

site_title: Lombard Odier's Asian fund shines amid volatility
summary: Lombard Odier's Asian fund has outperformed despite regional economic concerns, with a 55% total return since 2008. Sales of convertible bonds in South-east Asia have declined due to stuttering economic growth and debt defaults. The fund's success is attributed to the outperformance of underlying stocks, boosting hybrid notes from regional companies.

site_title: Rotary to set up centre of excellence for PCM sector
summary: Rotary Engineering, a Singapore-based oil and gas infrastructure services provider, plans to establish a centre of excellence for process, construction and maintenance (PCM) sector. The centre aims to improve productivity and regionalise services through mechanisation and talent development. Over three years, the centre will develop initiatives to upgrade automation equipment and enhance employee training. Rotary's chairman and managing director, Roger Chia Kim Piow, emphasized the importance of improving the PCM sector to support Singapore's energy and chemicals sector.

site_title: IE S'pore enhances financing support for commodities trading
summary: Singapore's trade promotion agency, IE Singapore, has enhanced its structured commodity financing (SCF) scheme under its Global Trader Programme to support the trading community. The enhanced scheme will include streaming financing, merger and acquisition advisory services, and consolidation, management, and distribution of funds for designated investments. Additionally, IE Singapore is developing a training programme for mid-career professionals to help them secure jobs in the international trading sector with skills in areas such as supply chain management and risk management.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Riding the Dubai property roller coaster
summary: Dubai's property market has experienced a decade-long rollercoaster, with prices peaking in 2008 and later plummeting due to the global financial crisis. Although prices have stabilized recently, experts predict a further decline of 5-10% in 2016. Overseas demand, particularly from Indians, British, and Pakistani buyers, has driven prices up, but a weakening currency and economic slowdown have reduced demand. Analysts believe the market has reached a "soft landing" and prices will stabilize by the end of 2016, with potential for a recovery in 2017.

site_title: Bankruptcy wave in US oil industry nears size of telecom bust
summary: A wave of US oil industry bankruptcies is nearing the size of the telecom bust in 2002-2003, with 59 companies filing for creditor protection. The number of energy bankruptcies is closing in on 68 filings, with 15 oil and gas companies filing in the first quarter. The US oil industry is not halfway through its wave of bankruptcies, according to experts. The industry's valuation has plummeted 60% since 2014, erasing $1.02 trillion from US energy company valuations.

site_title: Indonesia's recovery hopes intact despite dismal Q1
summary: Indonesia reported a lower-than-expected 4.92% growth in the first quarter of 2016, below the median 5.05% in a Reuters poll. Despite this, economists still expect the country to grow over 5% in 2016. The economy's growth weakened for the fifth straight year in 2015 due to poor commodity prices, contracting exports, and waning consumption. However, the government's efforts to boost spending and manufacturing have helped to maintain momentum, with consumption and government-led investment showing stability. Economists expect the recovery to continue, driven by domestic demand.

site_title: Angela Lee's ready for the fight of her life
summary: Singaporean MMA fighter Angela Lee, 19, will face 29-year-old Japanese veteran Mei Yamaguchi for the atomweight women's title at One Championship's "Ascent to Power" event. Lee, nicknamed "Unstoppable," has won all five fights by submission, aiming to finish the fight quickly. Yamaguchi boasts a record of 15 wins, eight losses, and a draw. The event, taking place in Singapore, is expected to be a highly anticipated and game-changing championship match.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: Why Britain must leave a centralising EU
summary: The article argues that Britain must leave the European Union to preserve its sovereignty and cultural identity. The author believes the EU's ambition to become a state undermines the UK's representative democracy and history. The author criticizes the EU's austerity policies, which have led to economic hardship in Greece and contributed to the rise of far-right parties across Europe. The author suggests that the UK will still maintain close cooperation with the EU in areas like defense and crime, and that the UK's economy will thrive outside the EU, particularly with the Commonwealth.

site_title: Will Singapore shareholders get their say on pay?
summary: Singapore may adopt "Say-On-Pay" for listed companies, allowing shareholders to vote on executive compensation. Global advisory firm Willis Towers Watson suggests this could be an inevitable development, driven by global trends and domestic needs. However, the approach has had mixed results worldwide, with some countries experiencing controlled inflation and others raising pay levels. Singapore currently uses a "comply or explain" approach, which has been criticized for lacking teeth. Adoption of Say-On-Pay is not necessary at present, but it may become inevitable in the future, with advisory votes likely to be introduced first.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah

site_title: Defaults loom as China stares at 3.7t yuan bond maturities
summary: China is facing a record 3.7 trillion yuan ($773 billion) of local bond maturities through year-end, with yields shooting up at the fastest pace in over a year. Issuance has fallen 43% due to deteriorating investor sentiment, heightening the risk of defaults. The country's corporate borrowers, particularly those in cash-strapped industries, need buoyant markets to refinance, but policymakers are becoming more tolerant of corporate failures as the economy slows. Defaults have already occurred this year, with at least seven companies renegeing on obligations, and more are expected.

site_title: More opportunities for PMETs to switch to ICT jobs
summary: Singapore has introduced eight new ICT conversion programmes to support professionals, managers, executives and technicians (PMETs) in switching to ICT jobs or upgrading their skills. The Professional Conversion Programmes (PCP) scheme, funded by the Singapore Workforce Development Agency (WDA), will support 250 job seekers and switchers with a 70% subsidy of up to $2,000. The programmes cover core areas of ICT, including cyber security, software development, and network administration, and aim to match job seekers with prospective employers.

images.alt_text: Manpower Minister Lim Swee Say announced the addition to the Professional Conversion Programmes (PCP) scheme at the first Adapt and Grow career fair, organised by the Singapore Workforce Development Agency (WDA), on Wednesday.

site_title: Voters must assess if plans are worth supporting: Murali
summary: In Singapore's Bukit Batok by-election, PAP candidate Murali Pillai has proposed plans to set up a mobile clinic, job placement scheme, and eldercare centre, aiming to woo voters. The 48-year-old lawyer believes voters must assess whether these plans are worth supporting. Meanwhile, SDP chief Chee Soon Juan has called for tightening Singapore's immigration policy in response to recent radicalization cases, prompting Home Affairs Minister K Shanmugam to criticize Dr Chee's remarks as lacking understanding of the issue. The by-election is set to conclude on Saturday.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: The primaries are over: it's the Donald vs Hillary
summary: Donald Trump is now the presumptive Republican presidential nominee, amassing 996 delegates after winning the Indiana primary. His main rival, Senator Ted Cruz, withdrew from the race after losing the Indiana vote, and Cruz's vice-presidential pick, Carly Fiorina, failed to attract support. Trump's campaign gained momentum, with the New Yorker lining up Indiana sports legends as supporters. The outcome of the Republican nomination is now mathematically impossible for Cruz, who will not attend the Cleveland convention. Meanwhile, Hillary Clinton is the presumptive Democratic nominee, and Bernie Sanders remains in the Democratic primary despite low chances of winning.

site_title: Abterra plans to sell two Suntec office units at S$3.8 million loss
summary: Abterra Ltd plans to sell two office units at Suntec Tower 1 for S$9.24 million, incurring a pre-tax loss of about S$3.76 million. The units, held for rental income, have been vacant for 2.5 months. Sale proceeds will be used to reduce bank borrowings and go towards working capital, with the goal of improving the company's financial position.

site_title: Recognising the economic value of intellectual property
summary: Singapore's commitment to research and development has led to a surge in intellectual property filings, with a 5% increase in patent filings and 9% increase in trademark filings in 2016. The government has set aside US$19 billion for the Research, Innovation and Enterprise (RIE) 2020 Plan, which includes a S$1.5 billion top-up to the National Research Fund. The government has also introduced targeted measures, such as the Productivity and Innovation Credit (PIC) scheme, to encourage IP acquisitions and commercialization. The government aims to build an IP-orientated culture among companies and support the development of innovative disruptors.

site_title: Sembcorp Industries Q1 profit down 25%
summary: Sembcorp Industries reported a 25% decline in Q1 profit to S$107 million, driven by higher borrowing costs and weaker operations from its marine arm. The company's share of net profit from SembMarine fell 48% to S$33.5 million, while its utilities business contributed 72% to the group's net profit. The company attributed the decline to the volatile oil and gas industry, with SembMarine expecting a protracted down cycle.

site_title: Malaysia dissolves 1MDB advisory board headed by Najib
summary: Malaysia's finance ministry dissolved the 1Malaysia Development Berhad (1MDB) advisory board, led by Prime Minister Najib Razak, in an apparent move to scale down the state fund amid scandals and money-laundering investigations in multiple countries, including the US, Switzerland, and Singapore. The board's dissolution allows the ministry to take over its remaining assets and transfer ownership of subsidiaries and land assets to the ministry. The move comes as Najib faces calls to step down over 1MDB's financial mismanagement.

site_title: POSH turns in stronger Q1 performance
summary: POSH, an offshore marine services provider, reported a stronger Q1 performance with a net profit of US$4.5 million, up from US$21,000 a year ago, driven by a 2% revenue increase to US$58.7 million. The Offshore Accommodation business division saw revenue more than double year-on-year. Despite challenging market conditions, the company plans to diversify and reduce costs, while seeking growth opportunities in new markets.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah

site_title: Once Asia's most promising leaders, Modi and Jokowi eye a rebound
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi and Indonesian President Joko Widodo, once considered Asia's most promising leaders, are seeking to revive momentum for reform plans derailed by recent election victories. Modi has seen some success, particularly with market-based energy pricing and an inflation target, but faces challenges in passing key reforms. Jokowi, on the other hand, has started to find his footing, with the economy picking up and infrastructure projects moving forward. While both leaders have potential, it's unclear who will ultimately succeed in driving growth and reform in their countries.

site_title: US ISM services index rises more than forecast to 55.7 in April
summary: The US Institute for Supply Management (ISM) services index rose to 55.7 in April, exceeding expectations of 54.7, indicating expansion in the service sector. The business activity index fell to 58.8, while the employment index rose to 53.0, and new orders climbed to 59.9. The reading above 50 signifies growth, and the prices paid index rose to 53.4. This suggests a moderate expansion in the US economy's service sector in April.

site_title: Europe's air safety agency to study aircraft-drone collision risk
summary: Europe's air safety agency, EASA, will study the risk of collision between drones and aircraft. A task force of manufacturers will examine vulnerabilities and review incidents. The study will analyze existing research and findings will be published in July. EASA has already developed regulations for drone usage, including operating in visual line of sight and registering drones. The agency aims to minimize the risk of accidents as private drone use grows, particularly near airports.

site_title: ICE says no bid for London Stock Exchange
summary: US-based global markets operator Intercontinental Exchange (ICE) has decided not to make an offer for the London Stock Exchange, citing insufficient engagement to confirm potential market and shareholder benefits. ICE had initially considered a bid in early March, but now has no current intention to pursue a deal. The decision comes as the London Stock Exchange Group has agreed to merge with Deutsche Boerse, creating one of the world's largest exchanges.

site_title: US private sector job growth slows in April: ADP
summary: US private sector job growth slowed in April, with 156,000 jobs added, below economists' expectations and the weakest gain in three years. This is the smallest increase since April 2013. The ADP National Employment Report, released on Wednesday, showed a revision down to 194,000 jobs in March. The US Labour Department's non-farm payrolls report, to be released on Friday, is expected to show a 193,000 job gain.

site_title: US to boost airport staffing to manage long security lines
summary: The US government plans to boost airport staffing to manage long security lines, a concern for airlines and travelers ahead of the summer tourism season. The Transportation Security Administration (TSA) will add officers at high-passenger volume airports and ramp up pre-screening enrollment efforts. The move comes after a series of high-profile attacks, including the Brussels airport bombing in March. The TSA will also seek additional funding to pay for officers' overtime, amid concerns that security hassles could deter travelers.

site_title: M&A decline from 2015 records may indicate stock vulnerability
summary: Global merger and acquisition (M&A) activity has declined sharply from record levels in 2015, with dollar value of deals down 22% and number of deals down 13% in the first half of 2016. This decline may indicate broader weakness in the US economy and vulnerability for US stocks, as companies become less optimistic about the future and less willing to spend their cash or exchange their stock. The decline in M&A activity follows a sharp decline in stock prices at the beginning of the year, making it harder for parties to agree on a fair price.

site_title: Germany revises up 2016 total tax estimate by 5b euros
summary: Germany has revised its 2016 tax estimate upwards by 5 billion euros, citing an economic upswing and record-high employment. The revised estimate puts total tax take at 691.2 billion euros. Finance Minister Wolfgang Schaeuble stated that the revised estimate shows the government is in a stronger position to deal with current challenges without new debts. However, there is no fiscal leeway for additional spending.

images.alt_text: Germany has raised its tax revenue estimates for this year by 5.0 billion euros (S$7.69 billion), Finance Minster Wolfgang Schaeuble said on Wednesday, citing an economic upswing and record-high employment.

site_title: SingPost special audit findings may lead to regulatory action
summary: A special audit report on Singapore Post's corporate governance has found disclosure failures and alleged breaches of fiduciary duties by director Keith Tay, potentially leading to regulatory action. Regulators, including the Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS), have stated they will take action if needed. The report highlights weak controls and lapses at the board, with some suggesting the entire board should share responsibility for these issues.

site_title: Biggest jump for palm in nearly 5 months on short-covering, weak ringgit
summary: Malaysian palm oil futures rose 3% to RM2,616 per tonne, marking their sharpest jump in nearly five months, as traders covered short positions after losses and a weakened ringgit. The price increase was attributed to the market being oversold and the weak ringgit making palm oil cheaper for foreign currency holders. This jump follows a 4.8% loss in palm oil prices last month, weighed down by poor export demand.

site_title: StanChart chairman defends bonuses against investor criticism
summary: Standard Chartered chairman John Peace defended the bank's bonuses against investor criticism, stating that cutting bonuses would lead to staff exodus. Despite a 48% decline in shares since 2015, the bank's overall incentive pool was only reduced by a fifth. Peace argued that bonuses are necessary for the bank's survival, and some investors, including Royal London Asset Management, have vowed to vote against the bank's new pay policies.

site_title: US crude stockpiles rise more than expected in week: EIA
summary: US crude stockpiles rose by 2.8 million barrels in the last week, exceeding analysts' expectations of a 1.7 million barrel increase. Gasoline stocks also saw a surprise rise, while distillate inventories fell. Crude stocks at the Cushing, Oklahoma, delivery hub rose by 243,000 barrels. This data from the Energy Information Administration marks a significant shift in the US energy market, with implications for oil prices and global demand.

site_title: US: Wall St opens lower as weak pvt jobs data weighs
summary: US stocks opened lower for the second straight day on Wednesday, weighed down by weak private jobs data. The Dow Jones industrial average fell 0.34% to 17,691.29, the S&P 500 lost 0.44% to 2,054.36, and the Nasdaq composite dropped 0.59% to 4,735.18. The data added to concerns about a slowdown in the global economy, sparking concerns about a potential slowdown in the US economy.

site_title: Apple loses China trademark case for "iPhone" on leather goods
summary: Apple has lost a Chinese court case over the "iPhone" trademark on leather goods, allowing local firm Xintong Tiandi to continue using the phrase. A Beijing court ruled in favor of Xintong Tiandi, stating Apple couldn't prove the "iPhone" brand was well-known in China before 2009. Apple expressed disappointment and plans to request a retrial with the Supreme People's Court. This is the latest in Apple's intellectual property disputes in China, where the company has faced challenges in its second-largest market.

site_title: US crude oil exports in March reached 508,000 bpd: US Census Bureau
summary: US crude oil exports rose to nearly 508,000 barrels per day in March, up from 374,000 bpd in February, according to the US Census Bureau. Exports went to Canada, Curacao, Israel, Italy, Japan, the Marshall Islands, the Netherlands, and Nicaragua. The US Census Bureau's data is released earlier than the closely watched US Energy Information Administration trade figures.

site_title: Emerging market downgrades likely to gather pace says S&P
summary: Standard and Poor's (S&P) warns that emerging market sovereign downgrades are likely to gather pace, with nine of the top 20 emerging market economies already having negative outlooks on their S&P ratings. Contingent liabilities, or costs of bailing out state-owned firms or damaged banks, pose new risks to EM sovereign ratings, particularly in countries with high levels of government-related debt, such as China, Brazil, and Mexico. S&P expects the negative bias in rating outlooks to continue and gather pace, citing the rapid surge in GRE debt and EM credit growth as key factors.

site_title: Sinopipe CEO to step down after insider trading at Sinomem
summary: Sinopipe Holdings CEO Pu Weidong is set to step down after being found guilty of insider trading in Sinomem shares. The Monetary Authority of Singapore (MAS) took civil penalty action against Pu Weidong and Triumpus Assets Management Pte Ltd, resulting in a S$316,000 fine. Pu Weidong, who was Sinomem's CFO in 2009, traded shares based on confidential price-sensitive information. He will not serve as a company director or be involved in management for a year.
