Trading in Sinopipe shares has been suspended since 2012.

site_title: FDI confidence in S'pore up again
summary: Singapore has surged in the A T Kearney annual Foreign Investment Confidence Index, rising from 15th in 2015 to 10th in 2016, amid growing interest from Asia-Pacific and IT firms. This marks the biggest jump in the global management consulting firm's rankings. The increase in confidence is seen as a positive sign for the country's economy, particularly in a time of slowing world trade.

site_title: Brussels Airport queues disappear after security checks eased
summary: Brussels Airport has returned to normal operations after easing security checks following complaints about lengthy queues and missed flights. The airport reopened part of the departure hall on Monday, increasing flights to about 80% of full capacity. However, queues were initially so long that passengers waited two to three hours to enter the building. The measures are seen as a response to the airport's slow recovery after the March 22 suicide attacks that killed 16 people.

site_title: Fifa ethics committee opens proceedings against CONCACAF's Webb
summary: Fifa's ethics committee has opened formal proceedings against former CONCACAF head Jeffrey Webb, a lifelong ban from all football-related activities is recommended. Webb was arrested in Zurich in May as part of a US investigation into corruption in soccer. The ethics committee's adjudicatory chamber received a final report on April 26, 2016, following an investigatory report. The US probe has rocked the sport's governing body, with other officials also implicated in bribery and kick-back-related offences.

site_title: First Ship Lease Trust's Q1 profit falls 55% to US$2.3m on losses from sale of vessels
summary: First Ship Lease Trust reported a 55.1% decline in Q1 net profit to US$2.3 million due to losses from selling vessels. Operating profit rose 35.5% to US$9.1 million, driven by a 7.6% increase in revenue. Despite the losses, the trust's managers remain optimistic, citing a "strong charter book" and diversified fleet. All earnings will be retained, with no distribution planned for the quarter.

site_title: PACC Offshore reports stronger earnings in Q1
summary: PACC Offshore Services Holdings (POSH) reported a net profit of US$4.4 million for Q1 2016, an improvement from the year-ago period's US$21,000. The company's joint ventures, particularly POSH Terasea, contributed to the better performance. POSH shares closed down 0.5 Singapore cent at 36.5 Singapore cents. The company's Q1 earnings marked a significant turnaround from a tough December quarter.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah

site_title: Oil rises near US$46 as Canada fire supports with US stocks in focus
summary: Oil prices rose near US$46 a barrel as a Canadian wildfire in the oil sands region reduced production, easing concerns about excess global supplies. Brent crude rose 92 cents to US$45.89, while US crude gained US$1.17 to US$44.82. The Canadian province of Alberta evacuated the population of Fort McMurray due to the wildfire, prompting some companies to cut output. The increased supply and reduced production supported oil prices, with Brent crude reaching a 2016 high of US$48.50 on Friday.

site_title: US productivity falls in Q1, compensation increases
summary: US nonfarm productivity fell 1.0% in Q1, marking the second quarterly decline, while labour-related costs rose at their fastest pace since 2014. This decline in productivity, along with a 0.5% growth in GDP, contributes to the divergence between a robust labour market and lacklustre economic growth. Hours worked rose 1.5% and unit labour costs increased 4.1%, the quickest pace since 2014.

site_title: Malaysia to dissolve Najib-led 1MDB advisory board amid probes
summary: Malaysia's government will dissolve the advisory board of state-owned investment company 1MDB, led by Prime Minister Najib Razak, amid global investigations into money laundering and embezzlement allegations. The board's resignation was accepted by the Minister of Finance, and Arul Kanda will remain as president until further notice. The decision comes after 1MDB defaulted on a US$1.75 billion bond and amid a dispute with IPIC, a co-guarantor of the bonds. The government has denied any wrongdoing, but will appoint new board members to reflect 1MDB's limited business profile.

site_title: Market pounded by same old worries
summary: The Straits Times Index fell for the eighth consecutive session, losing 38.13 points or 1.4% to 2,773.07. The decline was led by Singtel, Wilmar, and OCBC, with global growth worries, monetary stimulus concerns, and oil market volatility cited as reasons. The market's heavy turnover, surpassing the S$1 billion average of the past week, was also a contributing factor. The decline was echoed in Hong Kong's Hang Seng, which fell 0.7%, and the June contract on the Dow Jones Industrial Average, which lost about 20 points.

site_title: Fines and bad loans big drag on bank profitability: EU watchdog
summary: The European Union's banking watchdog, the European Banking Authority, says bad loans and fines for misconduct will hold back European banks' profitability for longer than expected, citing a trillion euros of bad loans on EU bank balance sheets. Chairman Andrea Enria notes that banks cleared of bad loans can lend more, and big fines are another major drag on profitability. Regulators are shifting focus from ensuring strong capitalization to banks' ability to lend, and Enria suggests maintaining a role for internal risk models to avoid throwing away valuable expertise.

site_title: Etihad says 31 passengers injured in Indonesia turbulence
summary: An Etihad Airways flight from Abu Dhabi to Jakarta experienced severe turbulence, injuring 31 passengers. The Airbus A330-200 landed safely, with 22 receiving minor treatment at the airport and 9 being taken to a local hospital. The incident occurred 45 minutes prior to landing, causing damage to cabin storage areas.

site_title: AnnAik's subsidiary to build and operate wastewater treatment plant in China
summary: AnnAik's subsidiary, ChangXing LiJiaXiang New Era Wastewater Treatment Co, has been awarded additional service concession rights to construct and operate a wastewater treatment plant in LiJiaXiang town, China. The project is expected to be completed by October this year, with 30-year concession rights starting from the plant's commercial operation. The company is investing up to 20 million yuan (S$4.2 million) in the project, funded by internal resources and bank borrowings, with no expected impact on the group's net tangible assets or earnings per share for the 2016 and 2017 financial years.

site_title: US trade deficit shrinks as goods imports hit five-year low
summary: The US trade deficit fell 13.9% to $40.4 billion in March, the smallest since February 2015, as imports of goods hit a five-year low. Exports also fell, but the decline was less severe. The decrease in the trade deficit may boost first-quarter economic growth estimates and suggests that some of the drag on exports is fading. The dollar's weakening 3.8% against major trading partners could improve US competitiveness, but weak imports may signal slackening domestic demand.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares end higher
summary: Malaysia's Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 6.14 points to close at 1,657.58, driven by 483 gainers and 342 losers in trading of 1.7 billion lots valued at RM2.13 billion.

site_title: Singapore probing complex transactions involving 'many shell companies' in 1MDB case
summary: Singapore authorities are investigating complex transactions involving multiple shell companies in the 1MDB case, a massive probe into Malaysia's state-backed firm. Prosecutors are analyzing cross-border transactions and working around the clock to unravel the money trail. Kelvin Ang Wee Keng, 34, has been charged with corrupt transactions, and his further remand was granted. Ang's dealings with ex-private banker Yeo Jiawei and other individuals implicated in improper dealings are being scrutinized, with progress made in the investigations. The probe is expected to be finalized within the next six days.

images.alt_text: Anita Gabriel

site_title: Daily Debrief: What Happened Today
summary: Singapore authorities are investigating complex transactions involving multiple shell companies in the 1MDB case. The country will soon select a US$1 billion tender for military utility helicopters. IEV Holdings secured five new contracts worth US$2.9 million. Malaysia dissolved the 1MDB advisory board amid global probes. China cut the yuan currency fix by 0.60% in its largest move since devaluation. US presidential candidate Donald Trump won the Indiana primary, boosting his claim to be the presumptive Republican nominee. The Straits Times Index (STI) dropped for the 8th consecutive session.

site_title: Carpet maker SMJ plans to expand into property as 'complementary' business
summary: SMJ International, a carpet maker, plans to expand into property investment and management as a complementary business. The move aims to broaden its income stream and revenue. The company considers opportunities in the property and hospitality industry, which could complement its carpet making and installation business. A diversification is expected to improve its prospects.

site_title: CVC Capital said to poach top HSBC Southeast Asia dealmaker
summary: CVC Capital Partners, a European buyout firm, has hired Alvin Lim, HSBC's most senior Southeast Asia dealmaker, to focus on investments in Singapore and Malaysia. Lim will join CVC Capital next month, following the departure of Fock Wai Hoong to General Atlantic. This move comes as CVC Capital has been active in Southeast Asia, with US$1.5 billion in deals over the past five years. Lim's hire is seen as a strategic move to strengthen the firm's presence in the region.

images.alt_text: CVC Capital Partners, the biggest European buyout firm, has hired HSBC Holdings Plc's most senior Southeast Asia dealmaker Alvin Lim, people with knowledge of the matter said.

site_title: Zhongmin Baihui's sales hurt by long winter, profit drops 10%
summary: Zhongmin Baihui Retail Group reported a 10% drop in net profit for the first quarter of 2016, with a net profit of 20.4 million yuan, due to seasonal sales pressure from the extended winter. Revenues slipped 1% to 229.9 million yuan. The company's shares had crashed after a warning from the Singapore Exchange in February, citing a small group of connected individuals responsible for 90% of the shares' buying volume.

images.alt_text: Michelle Quah

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks fall to 3-week low amid growth, deflation worries
summary: Hong Kong shares fell to a three-week low, closing at 20,525.86, amid concerns over global growth and deflation. The Hang Seng index dropped 0.7% and the China Enterprises Index fell 0.6%. HSBC Holdings Plc dropped 2.5% despite sticking to its dividend promise. The decline was attributed to sluggish trading in Asian markets, with energy, raw material, and financial shares leading the main indexes lower.

site_title: Sembcorp Industries posts 25% fall in Q1 profit, sees protracted oil & gas downcycle
summary: Sembcorp Industries reported a 25% drop in Q1 profit to S$107 million, primarily due to a 6.9% decrease in gross profit. Weaker operations linked to rig building projects contributed to the decline. The company expects a more protracted downcycle in the oil-and-gas industry, unlike previous cycles. This marks a significant challenge for the industry, with finance costs also increasing.

site_title: Oil edges up as Canadian wildfire reduces oil sands production
summary: Oil prices edged up as a Canadian wildfire near the oil sands region reduced production, with Brent crude futures trading at $45.07 per barrel. The wildfire in Alberta forced evacuations and impacted output at some facilities. Despite this, overall markets were weighed down by slowing economic growth in Asia and the US.

site_title: IE Singapore enhances structured commodity financing scheme
summary: IE Singapore has enhanced its structured commodity financing (SCF) scheme, allowing trading companies to leverage on innovative financing solutions, excess cash flow, and low-cost investment opportunities. The enhanced SCF scheme includes streaming financing, merger and acquisition advisory services, and fund management. Additionally, IE Singapore is launching a training programme for mid-career professionals to develop talent for the international trading sector, in partnership with the Singapore Workforce Development Agency and other institutions.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: China's Lenovo plans to invest US$500m in tech-startup fund
summary: Lenovo Group Ltd plans to invest US$500 million in Lenovo Capital, a technology start-up fund focused on sectors like artificial intelligence, robot, and cloud computing. The fund will be funded and managed by Lenovo Group, building on its existing investments in over 30 companies in areas such as mobile games, security, and smart home devices. This investment aims to further diversify Lenovo's portfolio and drive innovation in emerging technologies.

images.alt_text: Lenovo Group Ltd, the world's largest personal computer maker, plans to invest US$500 million in a technology start-up fund, the Beijing-based company said on Wednesday.

site_title: French services resume growing in April as companies cut prices: PMI
summary: France's service sector businesses returned to growth in April, with the purchasing managers index for services rising to 50.6 from 49.9 in March, driven by the fastest growth in new business since November as companies cut prices amid tough competition. This offset a slowdown in manufacturing activity, which was at its weakest pace in a year due to weakened demand despite price cuts.

site_title: China: Shanghai stock index flat, nearing key resistance level
summary: China's Shanghai stock index closed flat, near a key resistance level of 3,000, as manufacturing activity showed signs of subsidence. The CSI300 index fell 0.1% to 3,209.46, while the Shanghai Composite Index remained flat at 2,991.27 points. Volumes have remained low due to a lack of conviction in China's economic recovery, and the market's recent rebound appears to have lost steam. Most sectors declined, with resource shares among the biggest decliners.

site_title: Indonesia's Bumi Resources Minerals says nearing sale of stake in mine
summary: Indonesian miner PT Bumi Resources Minerals Tbk is nearing the sale of its stake in the operator of the country's second-biggest copper and gold mine, Newmont Nusa Tenggara. The sale, aimed at paying down debt, is being conducted by several suitors, including prominent businessman Arifin Panigoro, who has expressed interest in buying control. Financial terms are still under discussion, with a court-ordered freeze on a local company's 17.8% stake potentially complicating the process.

site_title: Europe: Stocks hover near 3-week low, Dialog and BHP slump
summary: European stocks hovered near a three-week low on May 4, 2016, with Dialog Semiconductor and BHP Billiton among the worst performers. Dialog shares plummeted 9% after reporting a 58% drop in underlying operating profit. Mining stocks fell due to weak copper prices, with BHP Billiton declining 6%. However, French bank Societe Generale rose 3.6% after pledging further cost cuts, lifting its rivals BNP Paribas and Credit Agricole.

site_title: PIMCO says buying emerging markets; likes rouble, Mexican peso
summary: PIMCO is shifting its focus to emerging markets, citing improving landscapes and potential gains in assets such as the Russian rouble and Mexican peso. The asset manager's head of asset allocation, Geraldine Sundstrom, believes commodity prices are bottoming out, Chinese growth is stabilizing, and the dollar's uptrend has ended. PIMCO is redeploying capital to emerging markets where it can find value, particularly in high-yielding currencies and local bonds with attractive yield curves.

site_title: Anonymous attack Greek central bank, warns others
summary: Greek central bank's website was disrupted by Anonymous in a cyber attack lasting a few minutes, with the group claiming it marks the start of a 30-day campaign against central bank sites worldwide. The attack was successfully contained by the bank's security systems. This is not the first time Anonymous has targeted a central bank, with the group reviving its "Operation Icarus" campaign.

site_title: Fortescue sees stable iron ore price as China curbs speculation
summary: Fortescue Metals Group CEO Nev Power expects iron ore prices to stabilize as China curbs speculation. Iron ore prices have surged 45% this year, driven by market speculation on platforms like the Dalian Commodity Exchange. China's Securities Regulatory Commission has urged domestic exchanges to curb excessive speculation, and the Chinese government aims to encourage market forces while preventing market volatility. Fortescue welcomes China's efforts to cool the markets, anticipating a stable iron ore price.

site_title: India court tells tobacco industry to adopt strict warnings
summary: India's Supreme Court ordered cigarette manufacturers to comply with new rules requiring 85% health warnings on packets, amid controversy over the directives. The rules, which mandate bigger warnings since April 1, were challenged by the tobacco industry, arguing they are too harsh. The court transferred petitions to a different court, instructing manufacturers to comply with the government's rules, despite industry claims of difficulty in implementation and potential job losses. The move aims to deter smokers, with up to 900,000 Indians dying annually from tobacco use.

site_title: India rejects Apple's plan to import used iPhones
summary: India has rejected Apple's plan to import used iPhones, citing rules against importing used electronics and concerns about dumping or recycling hazardous materials. The proposal, which would have allowed Apple to sell refurbished iPhones at a discount, was opposed by domestic phone makers who claim it would breach India's anti-dumping rules. The decision is a blow to Apple's efforts to revive sales of its flagship smartphones in the country, where the average smartphone sells for less than $150.

site_title: Nera posts 33% fall in Q1 profit
summary: NERA Telecommunications reported a 33.4% decrease in Q1 profit to S$2.03 million, down from S$3.05 million last year. Revenue fell 11% to S$37.5 million, primarily due to lower sales from the infocomm segment. Turnover from the infocomm segment declined 24.4% due to lower sales of network equipment and point-of-sales terminals in Thailand.

site_title: China fines Hitachi, CRRC unit for failing to declare joint venture
summary: China's commerce ministry fined Japan's Hitachi Ltd and a CRRC unit 150,000 yuan each for failing to declare a joint venture set up in 2013. The joint venture, involving Hitachi and Beijing CNR, was set up to bid on rail traffic signal contracts. The ministry also fined Bombardier and China's New United Group for failing to declare a joint venture set up in 2015. The fines are part of China's efforts to enforce anti-monopoly laws and ensure companies comply with reporting requirements.

site_title: China plans to streamline procedures for cross-border gold trade
summary: China is simplifying procedures for cross-border gold trade, allowing companies with frequent imports and exports to apply for a single permit for up to 12 shipments. The trial takes effect June 1 in six cities, reducing paperwork and speeding up gold imports. This move aims to boost gold consumption, as demand exceeds domestic supply, and the central bank continues to diversify its foreign-exchange reserves. The streamlined process is expected to reduce the time and cost associated with importing gold, potentially increasing imports and supporting the country's largest gold producer and consumer.

site_title: Eurozone businesses trudged into the second quarter: PMI
summary: Eurozone businesses experienced slow but steady growth in the second quarter, with the PMI index at 53.0, below March's 53.1. This suggests the European Central Bank's stimulus program is supporting activity, but not yet boosting inflation. The economy grew 1.5% annually and 0.6% quarter-on-quarter in the January-March period. However, inflation fell below zero for the seventh consecutive month, and growth is expected to be slower than initially thought, with subdued inflation forecast for the year.

site_title: Royal Dutch Shell profit slides on lower oil prices
summary: Royal Dutch Shell reported a 89% drop in net profit for the first quarter to $484 million, citing lower oil prices. The company attributed the decline to a 58% decrease in profit after stripping out exceptional costs and changes to oil stockpiles. Shell plans to invest less than expected, with capital investment reduced to $30 billion, a 36% decrease from the combined investment in 2014. The company's CEO stated that the acquisition of BG Group is off to a strong start and will likely result in accelerated delivery of synergies at a lower cost.

site_title: Singapore shares close lower with STI down for 8th straight session
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) fell for the 8th consecutive session, dropping 38.13 points or 1.4% to 2,773.07. The main losers were Singtel, Wilmar, and OCBC. Heavy turnover of 898 million units worth S$1.23 billion was seen, with 102 rises versus 276 falls. The decline was attributed to concerns over global growth, monetary stimulus, and US interest rates. The Hang Seng in Hong Kong also fell 0.7%, while the Dow Jones futures lost 20 points.

site_title: Slowing growth, inflation worries hurt Asia FX; ringgit leads
summary: Emerging Asian currencies slid on Wednesday due to concerns over slowing global growth and inflation, with the Malaysian ringgit hitting a five-week low. The Philippine peso touched a two-month trough and the Indonesian rupiah eased as economic growth disappointed. South Korea's won fell to its weakest in nearly three weeks. Analysts expect regional units to depreciate further as the dollar strengthens, with the won expected to lead the weakness. The ringgit lost 1.5% to 3.9850 per dollar, its weakest since March 30.

site_title: German private sector growth slows in April to 11-month low: PMI
summary: Germany's private sector growth slowed in April to its lowest level in nearly a year, with Markit's PMI falling to 53.6 from 54.0 in March. Despite this, the economy remains robust, with the manufacturing industry showing a three-month high in April. The slowdown in services was the weakest in a year, but job creation continued. The German economy is expected to grow at a slower pace in the second quarter, but the government predicts the same rate of expansion for 2016.

site_title: Societe Generale unveils fresh cost cuts, confident on 2016
summary: Societe Generale has pledged additional cost cuts of 220 million euros (US$253 million) to reassure investors about its diversified business model. The bank aims to reach a total of 500 million euros in cost savings by next year, primarily by exiting or restructuring non-profitable activities. Despite a weak start to the year, Societe Generale's net income rose 6.5% to 924 million euros in the first quarter, driven by lower loan loss provisions and stronger demand for loans in its international retail and financial services division.

site_title: Australia: Miners lead shares lower in profit-taking spree
summary: Australian shares dropped 1.55% on Wednesday, with resources leading the decline, amid concerns of further metal price falls and a court case against mining giant BHP Billiton. The S&P/ASX 200 index fell 82.74 points to 5271.10, while New Zealand's benchmark lost 0.27%. BHP shares plummeted 9% following a 155 billion-real civil lawsuit filed in Brazil over a tailings dam collapse.

site_title: Maersk Q1 profit beats forecast, keeps full-year outlook
summary: Maersk reported a Q1 net profit of US$224 million, exceeding analysts' forecast of US$55.6 million. The company maintained its full-year outlook for an underlying profit below last year's US$3.1 billion. Higher container volumes and increased oil production contributed to the profit. Maersk's results were supported by a strong quarter, but the company's outlook remains cautious.

site_title: Glencore reports lower commodity output after production cuts
summary: Glencore reported lower commodity output, including a 4% decrease in copper production for the first quarter, due to production cuts amid low prices. The company maintained its full-year production guidance, except for oil, where output is expected to be 0.3 million barrels less than previously forecast. The decision reflects a shift in focus from exploration to production to manage costs.

images.alt_text: Commodity miner and trader Glencore on Wednesday reported a fall in output of copper, zinc, lead, coal and oil following a decision to cut production because of low prices.

site_title: Indian parliament rejects tycoon's resignation
summary: India's upper house of parliament rejected billionaire Vijay Mallya's resignation, citing a letter that did not conform to procedures and lacked an original signature. Mallya, who owes over $1 billion in unpaid loans, is under investigation by a parliamentary ethics committee. He has had his passport revoked and is wanted by Indian authorities for deportation to Britain, where he claims to have no plans to leave and wants to reach a settlement with Indian banks. The government's decision may hinder Mallya's efforts to avoid prosecution.

site_title: US binge on African oil could bring rush of exports to Europe
summary: US crude oil imports from West Africa have surged to 13 million barrels in April, surpassing a two-year high, as the US lifted its decades-long ban on oil exports. This increased flow is undercutting US oil prices, threatening to send cargoes east and weaken the UK North Sea Brent benchmark. The rise in US gasoline production, driven by seasonal demand, has also encouraged US refiners to export oil, making it more attractive to buyers elsewhere. This may lead to higher US exports and higher prices in Europe.

site_title: LG launches new range of home appliances
summary: LG has launched a new range of home appliances, including the Twin Wash machine that handles two washing loads simultaneously and the Styler, a steam machine that sanitizes clothes and removes wrinkles. The company is also releasing larger size refrigerators with over 600 liters of storage capacity and a new door-in-door compartment for better temperature control. Prices for the Twin Wash machine start at S$2,999, while the refrigerators begin at S$4,999, with all products available from June 2016.

images.alt_text: The LG Twin Wash machine combines a full-size 21 kg front-loading washer with a 3.5 kg mini washer, which allows users to select two different wash cycles for their laundry.
The LG Styler is a steam machine that sanitises clothes, and can hold up to three items and one pair of pants at any one time.
LG is also launching a series of larger size refrigerators that come with over 600 litres of storage capacity.

site_title: Spain's April services PMI shows expansion continues, but employment growth slows
summary: Spain's service sector expanded in April, but at a slower pace than the previous month, according to a survey by Markit. The Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) stood at 55.1, down from 55.3 in March. Employment growth slowed, with new business and hiring at the weakest pace in over a year, attributed to political uncertainty ahead of June's parliamentary election. This marks two-and-a-half years of growth above the 50 line separating expansion from contraction.

site_title: Seoul: Won finishes near 3-week low, stocks down
summary: The South Korean won dropped to its lowest level in near three weeks, falling 1.2% to 1,154.3 to the dollar due to weak Chinese factory activity reports and a slump in global equities. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) closed down 0.5% at 1,976.71 points. Foreign investors bought 171.8 billion won worth of Kospi shares, but the overall market was down.

site_title: Petrobras sells Argentina, Chile assets for US$1.38b
summary: Petrobras sold US$1.38 billion in assets in Argentina and Chile to Pampa Energia SA and Southern Cross Group. The sale includes a 67.2% stake in Petrobras Argentina for US$892 million and all of Petrobras Chile Distribution Ltda for US$490 million. The sale comes amid Petrobras' struggles with record losses of US$9.6 billion last year and estimated US$2 billion in bribery losses over a decade.

site_title: Adidas to seek buyer for main golf business
summary: Adidas has decided to seek a buyer for its main golf brand TaylorMade, citing the sport's declining popularity in the US. The decision follows a strategic review of its golf business, which also includes Adams and Ashworth brands. Adidas will focus on selling golf footwear and clothing under its main Adidas brand and negotiate the sale of TaylorMade, Adams, and Ashworth.

site_title: Drama about drugs kingpin 'El Chapo' in development: media
summary: A drama series about Mexican drug lord Joaquin "El Chapo" Guzman is in development, with the showrunner of Netflix's "Narcos" behind the project. "#Cartel" will explore the emergence of drug gangs using social media, and the true story of El Chapo, who was captured in January after months on the run. The series will also delve into the risks of online bragging and the consequences of El Chapo's actions, including two extradition demands by courts in California and Texas.

site_title: Volvo Cars swings to Q1 profit as new models boost margins
summary: Volvo Cars, owned by Geely, reported a Q1 profit of 3.1 billion Swedish crowns (S$520.5 million), reversing a year-ago loss of 11 million. The profit was driven by new up-market models that boosted margins to a level comparable to global rivals. This marks a significant improvement for the Gothenburg-based carmaker, which was previously struggling. Volvo's new models have set a benchmark for the company's competitive position in the global market.

site_title: Siemens speeds cost-cutting, beats Q2 profit forecasts
summary: Siemens has accelerated its cost-cutting program, beating Q2 profit forecasts and increasing its savings target for the year to 850-950 million euros. The Munich-based company reiterated its full-year targets of an industrial profit margin of 10-11% and earnings per share of 6.00-6.40 euros. This move follows the company's efforts to reduce costs and maintain its competitive edge in the industry.

site_title: Developers zero-in on Bangkok's historic Chinatown
summary: Developers are focusing on Bangkok's historic Chinatown, a district yet to be heavily commercialized, with a new metro service set to transform the area. The influx of new residents will likely increase property values, turning the chaotic but charming neighborhood into a lucrative investment opportunity.

site_title: Apple loses fight to keep 'iphone' label off Chinese wallets
summary: Apple Inc. lost a court case in Beijing, allowing a Chinese accessories maker, Xintong Tiandi Technology, to use the "iphone" label for a range of luxury leather goods. The ruling affirmed that Xintong has the right to use the name, despite Apple retaining the trademark for mobile devices. This is the second time Apple has lost exclusive use of a brand name in China, the world's largest mobile market.

site_title: Obama faces looming trade row with China
summary: US President Barack Obama is facing a trade row with China, with Beijing demanding the US treat it as a "market economy" to lower tariffs on Chinese exports. The issue has sparked a fresh debate ahead of Obama's farewell visit to China in September. Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton has criticized the move, while Republican candidate Donald Trump has vowed to take a tougher stance. The dispute could complicate Obama's farewell visit and raise tensions between the two countries, with China threatening to retaliate if its demands are not met.

site_title: Asia: Stocks fall sixth day on global growth concern after rally
summary: Asian stocks fell for a sixth consecutive day, the longest losing streak since February, amid concerns over lackluster global economic growth and a decline in commodity shares. The MSCI Asia Pacific ex Japan Index dropped 0.9% as crude oil traded below US$44 a barrel. BHP Billiton Ltd slumped 7.8% in Sydney, with equity market sentiment reportedly "rolling over globally."

site_title: Microsoft ups rivalry with Google, Box with new sharing software
summary: Microsoft has released new software to boost its rivalry with Google, Box, and Dropbox, aiming to expand its $3 billion annual business. The new SharePoint, phone apps, and OneDrive updates provide improved mobile integration and file-sharing features. The software maker is also offering free migrations for customers to switch to OneDrive from Box or Google Drive. Microsoft's goal is to modernize SharePoint and persuade more customers to switch to the cloud version, currently used by 40% of customers. The updates will also utilize Microsoft's Office graph technology to suggest relevant content.

site_title: Asia: Markets chase Wall St down as global fears return
summary: Asia's stock markets plummeted on Wednesday as global fears over the economy returned, following sharp losses on Wall Street and in Europe. The sell-off was fueled by disappointing data from China, Europe, and the US, which raised concerns about a nascent recovery. Asian markets, including Hong Kong, Singapore, and Sydney, fell between 0.6-1.3% as traders sought safe investments. The Australian dollar plummeted over 1% amid concerns over the global economy, while the US dollar rallied against other currencies.

site_title: China cuts yuan fix in biggest move since devaluation
summary: China's central bank fixed the yuan currency 0.60% weaker against the US dollar, the largest move since devaluing the unit in August 2015. The People's Bank of China set the value of the yuan at 6.4943 to US$1.0, weakening 0.59% from the previous day's fix. The move is seen as part of efforts to make trading more market-oriented and follows a 0.56% increase in the yuan-dollar exchange rate last week. Analysts say the weaker fix is in line with the strength of the US dollar, which rose against most of its peers due to global growth worries.

site_title: South Korea: Won drops, stocks edge down on China data, holiday
summary: South Korea's won dropped to a near three-week low due to weak Chinese data and a decline in global equities, sapping investor appetite for risk. The won fell 1.2% to 1,154.2 per dollar, while the Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) was down 0.6%. Investors are also cautious ahead of a holiday long-weekend in South Korea, with foreign investors expected to be net buyers but trading thin.

site_title: Brazil prosecutor seeks obstruction of justice probe against Rousseff: reports
summary: Brazil's top prosecutor, Rodrigo Janot, has asked the Supreme Court to open an investigation into alleged obstruction of justice by President Dilma Rousseff and her predecessor Luiz Inacio Lula da Silva. Rousseff allegedly colluded with Lula to obstruct a judge investigating corruption at state oil company Petrobras. This could lead to Lula's prosecution and gain him limited immunity. The move also puts pressure on Rousseff, who faces impeachment charges and could be suspended from office next week. The Supreme Court is set to rule on Lula's nomination to a post in Rousseff's government.

site_title: The 3.7t yuan debt wall that points to more defaults in China
summary: Chinese debt investors are turning bearish ahead of a record 3.7 trillion yuan (S$770.8 billion) in local bond maturities through year-end. Yields rose at the fastest pace in over a year, and issuance tumbled 43% as borrowers canceled 143 billion yuan of planned debt sales. Defaults are expected, with at least seven companies reneging on obligations this year, and government-run banks may step in to help weaker borrowers. Policy makers are becoming more tolerant of corporate failures as the economy slows, raising concerns about refinancing risk and the potential for smaller companies to fail.

site_title: Aeropostale files for bankruptcy in latest retailer meltdown
summary: Aeropostale, a teen-clothing chain, filed for bankruptcy protection in the US Bankruptcy Court for the Southern District of New York, citing years of losses and struggles to adapt to competition from online merchants. The company has closed over 215 stores since 2013 and intends to emerge from Chapter 11 within the next six months with a smaller store base. Aeropostale secured US$160 million in debtor-in-possession financing and plans to continue its sale process, which could be completed within the same timeframe.

site_title: Tough-talking mayor keeps poll lead a week before Philippine elections
summary: Philippine presidential candidate Rodrigo Duterte maintained a double-digit lead in the latest opinion poll, with 33% support, just five days before elections. Despite allegations of undeclared millions of pesos in a bank, Duterte's strong anti-crime platform resonated with voters across economic and geographical lines. Manuel Roxas rose to second place, while Senator Grace Poe fell to third. The poll's results reflect Duterte's popularity among frustrated Filipinos, but also highlight a dip in support in Manila due to the bank allegations.

site_title: WhatsApp blockage ends in Brazil: Facebook
summary: A Brazilian court has lifted a 72-hour blockage of WhatsApp, ending a shutdown imposed on the messaging service for failing to surrender user data in a drug trafficking investigation. WhatsApp, owned by Facebook, had appealed against the shutdown, which was initially rejected. The company's CEO, Mark Zuckerberg, expressed relief and encouraged users to make their voices heard at an upcoming event to prevent such blockages in Brazil. The shutdown had angered users reliant on the free app, where cell phone fees for texting and calls are among the highest in the world.

site_title: Germany's reputable Berenberg Bank in spotlight over Panama Papers scandal
summary: Berenberg Bank, a German private bank, is under scrutiny for its alleged involvement in the Panama Papers scandal. Despite its reputation for discretion, the bank's involvement in offshore tax evasion schemes has raised questions about its integrity. This marks a significant departure from the bank's history of maintaining an "impeccable image" and avoiding scandals like those faced by Deutsche Bank and Commerzbank. The bank's reputation is now being challenged, and its squeaky clean image may not be as untarnished as initially thought.

site_title: Days are numbered for 500-euro banknote
summary: The European Central Bank is set to decide on abolishing the 500-euro banknote, which is associated with money laundering and terrorist financing. The note, valued at more than its face value, is used by criminals for anonymous transactions. France and the EU Commission support restrictions on high-denomination notes, but Germany opposes the move, fearing it could lead to the abolition of cash altogether. Experts argue that abolishing the note may not effectively combat crime, as most money laundering is done through other means.

site_title: AB InBev suffers weak start to year after Brazil slump
summary: AB InBev, the world's top brewer, reported lower-than-expected earnings in the first quarter due to a challenging quarter in Brazil, where its beer volumes fell by 10%. The brewer's core profit rose 2.5% to $3.46 billion, despite a weaker Brazilian real and Mexican peso. AB InBev maintained its forecast for revenue per litre growth, driven by strong volume increases in Mexico and the US, and a rise in revenue in Brazil. The company still expects to close its $100-billion-plus takeover of SABMiller in the second half of the year.

images.alt_text: Anheuser-Busch InBev, the world's top brewer set to buy number two SABMiller, reported lower than expected earnings in the first three months after one of its most challenging quarters in crisis-hit Brazil in years.

site_title: Air France-KLM posts stronger-than-expected Q1 rebound
summary: Air France-KLM reported a stronger-than-expected Q1 recovery, with earnings before interest, tax, depreciation, and amortisation (EBITDA) reaching 266 million euros. The carrier reduced its operating loss to 99 million euros, despite geopolitical risks and overcapacity concerns. Revenue grew 0.4% to 5.605 billion euros, beating analyst forecasts. The company reaffirmed its year-end targets, with the new CEO recently appointed.

images.alt_text: Air France-KLM posted a stronger-than-expected recovery in the first quarter due in part to low oil prices, but warned of geopolitical risks and airline overcapacity while reaffirming its targets for the year.

site_title: Australia dollar slips to seven-week low on RBA cut, commodities fall
summary: The Australian dollar fell to a seven-week low on Wednesday after the Reserve Bank of Australia cut interest rates to a record low of 1.75% and sliding commodity prices. The currency dropped to US$0.7489, its lowest since mid-March, and is expected to fall further to US$0.7335. The RBA's rate cut is seen as a yield play, with economists predicting another rate cut to 1.50% in August. Commodity prices, particularly iron ore, also fell, contributing to the decline.

site_title: Australia new vehicle sales a record for April: VFACTS
summary: Australian new vehicle sales reached a record high in April with 87,571 vehicles sold, a 7.2% increase from the previous year. Demand for SUVs and light commercial vehicles was strong, with sales up 7.1% and 14.1% respectively. Passenger vehicle sales also increased by 4.7%. Toyota maintained its lead in market share with 18.9%, followed by Hyundai, Mazda, Ford, and Holden. The strong sales suggest consumers' confidence in spending on big-ticket items, contrasting with soft retail sales.

site_title: Australia PM Turnbull says will call election for July 2
summary: Australian Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull announced plans to call an election for July 2, stating he would make the call within the next week. The election will be held between May 11 and July 2.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open lower on Wednesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index fell 6.13 points to 1644.77 on Wednesday, with losers outnumbering gainers 96 to 65. The market saw 38.8 million lots traded worth RM28.2 million.

site_title: Gold falls for third day as dollar rally damps investment demand
summary: Gold fell 0.5% to $1,281.57 an ounce for the third consecutive day due to a dollar rally, as investors became less interested in the metal as an alternative investment. The dollar's recovery on prospects of a US interest-rate increase next month reduced gold's appeal. Despite a 21% gain in 2016, gold prices have retreated from their January 2015 high. Investors expect a 12% chance of a rate hike next month, with Fed officials indicating a potential increase in June.

site_title: BHP hit by huge Brazil lawsuit, stock plunges
summary: BHP Billiton has been hit with a $43 billion lawsuit from Brazilian prosecutors over the Samarco disaster, which killed at least 17 people and polluted a large area of river basin in 2015. The lawsuit, filed by prosecutors, seeks compensation for social, environmental, and economic damages. The Australian mining giant's share price plummeted 7.38% in response to the news, following a previous settlement of $6.2 billion agreed with Brazilian authorities in March. BHP remains committed to rebuilding the community and restoring the environment affected by the disaster.

images.alt_text: Miners BHP Billiton and Vale have been hit with a US$43 billion lawsuit from Brazilian prosecutors over the Samarco disaster, it was announced Wednesday, sending the Australian resources giant's share price sharply lower.

site_title: Brokers' Take: RHB raises target price on SMRT, cites positive long-term outlook
summary: RHB raised its target price on SMRT Corp to S$2.25, citing a positive long-term outlook due to impending rail reforms. Analysts expect the reforms to reduce debt burden and enable the division to earn a 5% operating margin. However, near-term earnings may remain subdued due to ongoing losses at SMRT's train business, high maintenance costs, and potential government-imposed penalties. The reforms are expected to be implemented in 2019, with estimated cash receipts of S$590 million by 2019.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Sanders' Indiana primary win slows Clinton's march to nomination
summary: Vermont Senator Bernie Sanders won the Indiana Democratic presidential primary, slowing Hillary Clinton's path to the nomination. Sanders' victory gave his campaign a boost as the campaign enters its final stage. Meanwhile, Donald Trump secured the Republican nomination with a decisive victory, forcing out Texas Senator Ted Cruz. The results marked a significant shift in the presidential race, with Sanders now in contention for the nomination.

site_title: Seven banks to pay US$324m to resolve ISDAfix claims
summary: Seven major US banks, including Bank of America, Barclays, and Citigroup, have agreed to pay a total of US$324 million to settle claims they conspired to rig the ISDAfix benchmark. The settlements follow a US District Judge's ruling that a conspiracy among the banks existed, allowing investors to pursue billions of dollars in losses. The banks, excluding four others still in the case, will provide cooperation and documents to aid the investigation.

images.alt_text: Seven banks including Bank of America Corp, Barclays Bank Plc and Citigroup Inc agreed to pay US$324 million to settle claims they conspired to rig the ISDAfix benchmark, which is used in the sale of interest-rate derivatives and other financial instruments.

site_title: Art buyers face scrutiny as New York kicks off tax probe
summary: New York Attorney General Eric Schneiderman has launched a tax probe into art buyers and dealers, with two settlements announced against Aby Rosen, a Manhattan developer with a half-billion dollar art collection, and Victoria Gelfand, a Gagosian Gallery director. Rosen agreed to pay $7 million in unpaid taxes on $80 million worth of art, while Gelfand agreed to pay $210,000 in unpaid taxes on 30 pieces of art. The settlements are part of a broader investigation into tax evasion and money laundering in the art world, with officials seeking to recover millions in lost tax revenue.

site_title: Ted Cruz ends White House bid, setting Trump on path to nomination
summary: Ted Cruz suspended his White House campaign after a crushing defeat in Indiana's primary, clearing the path for Donald Trump to secure the Republican nomination. Cruz stated that the path to victory had been foreclosed, citing the voters' choice. This leaves John Kasich as Trump's sole challenger. Cruz's withdrawal marks a significant development in the Republican presidential election.

site_title: Twitter makes following accounts easier with new Connect tab
summary: Twitter has launched a new Connect tab on its mobile app, making it easier for users to find accounts to follow. The tab suggests popular accounts in the area and those already followed, allowing users to automatically sync their address books to connect with friends and family. The feature is available on Apple iPhones and Android smartphones. This move aims to improve Twitter's interface and attract more users, as its growth has lagged behind social media rivals.

site_title: New Zealand unemployment rises on increase in labour participation
summary: New Zealand's unemployment rate rose to 5.7% in the first quarter, while the participation rate jumped to 69.0% and employment grew 1.2%. Despite this, the economy is performing well, with wages growing 0.4% quarterly. However, wages are not keeping pace with labour market growth, potentially dragging on inflation. The Reserve Bank of New Zealand forecasts annual inflation at 1.1% by end-2016, down from its previous projection of 1.6%. Economists expect the central bank to cut interest rates in June to address subdued wage inflation.

site_title: Hong Kong, Shanghai: Stocks down at open
summary: Hong Kong and Shanghai shares plummeted in early trading on May 4, 2016, due to global economic concerns. The Hang Seng Index fell 0.58% and the Shanghai Composite Index dropped 0.32%, while the Shenzhen Composite Index declined 0.36%. The losses mirrored heavy declines in New York and Europe, reflecting worries over the global economy.

site_title: IEV unit bags five new contracts worth US$2.9m
summary: IEV Holdings' subsidiary IEV International has secured five new contracts worth US$2.9 million for its marine growth control business unit, which supplies marine growth preventer products. The contracts, valued at 808 MGP products, will be installed on 13 offshore platforms in Asia and Northern Africa starting from Q2 2016. The "ocean-powered" MGP products are expected to boost structural capacity and prolong lifespan, positively impacting the company's net tangible assets per share and earnings per share for the current financial year.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Rich and powerful warn robots are coming for your jobs
summary: At the Milken Institute's Global Conference in Beverly Hills, California, experts warned that robots are increasingly taking over jobs, particularly low-wage and low-skill positions. The conference, attended by 3,500 invite-only participants, highlighted the benefits of automation, such as higher quality and fewer errors, but also acknowledged the potential for job displacement. Experts like Michael Chui from McKinsey Global Institute noted that while automation can enhance efficiency, it also reduces labor. The warning comes as technology continues to advance and transform various industries.

site_title: China arrests one of most-wanted telecoms fraud suspects: Xinhua
summary: China has arrested Wen Longjian, one of its top 10 most-wanted fraud suspects, accused of conspiring to swindle 35 million yuan (S$7.3 million) in a telecoms scam. Wen, 32, impersonated a company head on an instant messaging app and evaded arrest after a police operation froze bank accounts containing 28 million yuan. He was caught in China's southwestern province of Guangxi on Monday, according to the Ministry of Public Security.

site_title: Singapore shares open lower again on Wednesday
summary: Singapore shares opened lower on Wednesday, with the Straits Times Index dipping 0.7% to 2,791.50. Trading volume was high, with 39.3 million shares changing hands. The decline followed a similar trend on Wall Street, where stocks fell on Tuesday. Losers outnumbered gainers, with companies like Jardine Cycle & Carriage and UOB leading the losses, while gainers included Haw Par, Great Eastern, and DBS.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Hong Kong bank funds said frozen for some tangled in 1MDB probe
summary: Hong Kong authorities have frozen bank accounts belonging to unnamed individuals amid global investigations into 1MDB, a Malaysian state fund at the center of money laundering and embezzlement allegations. The freeze is linked to probes in countries such as Singapore and the US. Malaysia's central bank has fined 1MDB and ended its investigation, while the fund's chairman, Prime Minister Najib Razak, denies wrongdoing. Authorities in other countries, including Switzerland, are also examining claims of 1MDB's misuse. A total of US$4.2 billion of irregular transactions by the fund have been identified.

site_title: Apple gets Google X lab co-founder for health projects
summary: Apple has hired Yoky Matsuoka, a robotics expert and Google X lab co-founder, to work on health projects. Matsuoka, a MacArthur genius award winner, left her job at Google-owned Nest last year due to a "life-threatening illness." This move marks Apple's entry into the health technology space, with Matsuoka's expertise expected to drive innovation in the field.

site_title: New Zealand house prices rise 12% y-o-y in April as low rates tempt buyers
summary: New Zealand house prices rose 12% in the year to April, driven by record low interest rates. The 12% increase in the Quotable Value residential property price index surpasses the annual rate of 11.4% in March. This marks a 16.9% increase above the market's previous peak in 2007. The housing sector has seen home value increases in major and regional centers, fueled by confidence in the market.

site_title: Takata to announce recall of 35-40m US air bag inflators: sources
summary: Takata Corp is set to announce a recall of 35-40 million US air bag inflators, the largest and most complex auto safety recall in US history, as regulators pressure the Japanese manufacturer. The recall will cover frontal air bag inflators without a drying agent and will be phased in over several years. The move aims to address safety concerns linked to the inflators, which have been linked to multiple fatalities worldwide. The recall will more than double the existing recall of 18 million inflators.

site_title: Fed's Lockhart: Brexit could 'loom large' over June policy meeting
summary: Atlanta Federal Reserve President Dennis Lockhart expressed concerns that the UK's Brexit vote could "loom large" over the Fed's June policy meeting, citing heightened global uncertainty. Lockhart also warned of risks to the US economy, including slowing growth and tepid inflation, and noted that the economy's mixed signals make it difficult to determine whether to raise interest rates. Meanwhile, San Francisco Fed President John Williams expressed support for a June rate hike if the economy shows continued progress. The Fed's decision is expected to be influenced by the global slowdown and Brexit uncertainty.

site_title: Mercedes SUV gains help widen US sales lead over Lexus, BMW
summary: Mercedes-Benz led US luxury auto sales in April with 29,236 vehicles, surpassing Lexus and BMW. SUV sales drove the gain, with Mercedes' GLC and GLK models surging 45%. Lexus sales fell 7.4% and BMW sales declined 7.4% as well. The trend is expected to continue, with luxury SUVs fetching higher average prices and fuel efficiency playing a role in demand. Mercedes' lead over Lexus extended to over 5,000 vehicles through the first four months of the year.

site_title: Google to buy minivans for self-driving tests from Fiat Chrysler
summary: Google has agreed to buy 100 plug-in hybrid Chrysler Pacifica minivans from Fiat Chrysler Automobiles for its self-driving testing program. The deal marks the most advanced partnership between Silicon Valley and a carmaker, with FCA working directly with Google on the test models. The vehicles will not be sold to the public, and the partnership does not preclude either company from cooperating with others. This partnership aims to expand Google's self-driving vehicle testing capabilities.

site_title: Once Asia's most promising leaders, Modi and Jokowi eye rebound
summary: Indian Prime Minister Narendra Modi and Indonesian President Joko Widodo, known as Mr Jokowi, are seeking to revive momentum for reform plans that stalled after their election victories. Both leaders have faced challenges in implementing their agendas, with Modi struggling to pass a goods-and-services tax and Jokowi facing resistance from within his party and bureaucracy. Despite their differences, both countries have shown promise, with India's growth rate being the fastest among major economies and Indonesia's economy picking up after a six-year low. A key test for both leaders will be the impact of their policies on gross domestic product data due out this quarter.

images.alt_text: Two years back, they were the most promising leaders in Asia, set to revamp a pair of perennial underperformers that account for a fifth of the world's population.

site_title: Panama Papers showed vulnerability of whole system: Panama president
summary: Panamanian President Juan Carlos Varela stated that the Panama Papers scandal highlighted the vulnerabilities of global financial systems, emphasizing the need for increased transparency and information sharing among countries. Following intense international pressure, Panama signed a bilateral agreement with the US to share back account information, a step towards addressing tax evasion concerns. Varela urged the international community to engage in respectful dialogue to address these issues, as Panama aims to improve its financial transparency and avoid being labeled a tax haven.

site_title: Fed's Williams says wants June rate hike if growth meets forecast
summary: San Francisco Federal Reserve President John Williams stated that he would support a June interest-rate hike if the economy grows at 2% and inflation remains consistent with his forecast. He expects economic growth of 2% this year and inflation to reach 2% by the end of the year. This would be enough for Williams to support a rate hike, according to an interview on Bloomberg Radio.

site_title: Stocks to watch: SingPost, ARA Asset Management, Lippo Malls Indonesia Retail Trust
summary: SingPost director Keith Tay has resigned as lead independent director, following a corporate governance special audit report that found weak controls and inaccuracies in its records. Tay's failures were not intentional, but rather a result of carelessness in preparation. ARA Asset Management posted a 2% increase in net profit and a 10% rise in total revenue for its first quarter. Lippo Malls Indonesia Retail Trust reported a 5.1% increase in distribution per unit and a 7.8% rise in distributable income for the first quarter.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Canada's Fort McMurray wildfire forces evacuations, no impact on oil sands
summary: A wildfire in Fort McMurray, Alberta, Canada, has forced the evacuation of nearly 80,000 residents due to high temperatures and light winds. The 2650-hectare fire is burning approximately six kilometers southwest of the city, but is not close to oil sands facilities. Authorities have deemed the blaze difficult to control, but no impact on oil sands operations is expected.

images.alt_text: An uncontrolled wildfire burning near Fort McMurray in northern Alberta, the heart of Canada's oil sands region, has forced the evacuation of nearly all the city's 80,000 residents, local authorities said on Tuesday.

site_title: Singapore set to pick military helicopters as arms spending rises
summary: Singapore is set to pick a winner for a $1 billion tender for military utility helicopters, with Airbus and Finmeccanica shortlisted for the contract. The country is modernizing its air force and navy amid rising tensions in the region, with a defense budget expected to reach $10.72 billion in 2020. Singapore is also considering Joint Multi Mission Ships, tactical lift helicopters, and maritime patrol aircraft, with Lockheed F-35 Joint Strike Fighter and unmanned platforms under consideration. The country's defense ministry is pursuing various modernization projects to compensate for its small size and population.

images.alt_text: Singapore will soon pick the winner of a US$1 billion tender for military utility helicopters, the first of several lucrative deals the island nation is pursuing as it modernises its air force and navy amid rising tensions in the region.

site_title: Outfoxed!
summary: Leicester won the English Premier League (EPL) title in 2016, resulting in significant losses for bookmakers. This historic win marked a major upset, with Leicester finishing 5000-1 odds to win the title. The victory was celebrated by fans, but also led to substantial financial losses for bookmakers. The outcome was seen as a major upset, with Leicester's success attributed to their strong team performance and clever tactics.

site_title: US: Stocks fall as global growth fears weigh
summary: US stocks fell on Tuesday as global growth fears weighed on markets, with the Dow Jones Industrial Average losing 0.8% and the S&P 500 dropping 0.9%. Concerns about global growth were fueled by weak Chinese manufacturing data and downgraded eurozone growth projections. Oil and commodity prices also declined, contributing to the market's decline. Analysts attributed the decline to investor concerns about weakening global growth, with one expert stating that concerns are "at the forefront of investors' thinking right now."

site_title: Brazil prosecutors file 155b-real lawsuit against Vale, BHP for dam spill
summary: Brazilian federal prosecutors filed a 155 billion-real (S$58.87 billion) civil lawsuit against iron miner Samarco, its owners Vale SA and BHP Billiton, for a collapsed dam in November that killed 19 people and polluted a major river. The lawsuit, which also targets two states and the federal government, is based on a six-month investigation and demands an initial payment of 7.7 billion reais. This is separate from a previous settlement between the companies and the Brazilian government, in which they agreed to pay an estimated 20 billion reais for damage caused by the spill.

site_title: LMIR Trust posts 5.1% rise in Q1 DPU; stays upbeat on Indonesian retail
summary: LMIR Trust, a Singapore-based retail trust, reported a 5.1% increase in distribution per unit (DPU) in Q1, driven by a 7.8% rise in distributable income. The trust attributed the growth to higher rental income from its malls and limited supply of new retail spaces in Jakarta, due to a government moratorium on mall construction. Despite this, LMIR Trust remains optimistic about the Indonesian retail segment, citing higher disposable income, lower inflation, and emerging trends in lifestyle shopping malls.

site_title: Brazil judge rules to unblock Whatsapp
summary: A Brazilian judge has overturned a suspension of Facebook's WhatsApp messaging application, effectively unblocking the service. The block was ordered by a different judge on Monday, which had expired before the decision was made. The suspension affected around 100 million WhatsApp users.

site_title: Oil settles below US$44 in New York before US stockpile report
summary: Oil prices dropped below US$44 a barrel in New York ahead of a US government report showing increased nationwide crude supplies. Futures fell 2.5% for the third day, declining after reaching a five-month high. Analysts expect inventories to have risen 750,000 barrels last week, with some forecasting a drop. The global oversupply persists, with prices about 60% below their peak in mid-2014.

site_title: Australia's A$500 billion debt pile to test bond buyer appetite
summary: Australia's federal government debt is expected to increase by up to A$73 billion, reaching A$499.5 billion, in the next fiscal year, testing global investors' appetite for the country's bonds. The government's budget deficit is projected to remain high, with a A$37.1 billion underlying cash deficit in the next 12 months. Despite a projected path back to budget balance within five years, Australia's debt pile is set to reach A$640 billion by 2026-27, driven by increasing bond issuance and declining foreign ownership.

site_title: Japan finance minister ready to respond to stem yen's rise
summary: Japan's Finance Minister Taro Aso expressed concern over the yen's sharp rise, warning that one-sided movements could harm the economy. Aso stated that Japan will respond if necessary to stem the currency's firming, following G20 agreements. Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda also announced that the central bank will take additional steps to achieve its inflation target, which is currently not being met. The yen reached an 18-month high against the dollar after the BOJ's decision to hold off on expanding monetary stimulus.

site_title: US rule would shield failed banks from hedge funds in future crisis
summary: The Federal Reserve has proposed a rule requiring some investors to wait 48 hours before cutting ties with failing US banks in a future crisis, aiming to prevent chaotic market unraveling. This pause is a response to the 2008 financial crisis, where Lehman Brothers' failure led to panic in global markets. The rule is intended to give investors time to reassess their investments and prevent a rush to exit, thereby stabilizing the financial system.

site_title: China tech group invests in Israeli gesture recognition company
summary: China-based technology group Kuang-Chi has invested $20 million in Israeli gesture recognition company EyeSight Technologies. The investment aligns with Kuang-Chi's strategy of exploring ideas that connect humans with machines and the future of space exploration. Part of the investment will be used to fund joint initiatives in Hong Kong and China. EyeSight's software allows for gesture control, such as controlling TVs with a fingertip.

site_title: UK 'In' camp retains lead ahead of EU referendum: TNS poll
summary: The UK's "In" camp has maintained its lead in the EU referendum, with 39% of respondents supporting staying in the EU and 36% supporting leaving, according to a TNS online poll. This is the second consecutive week the "In" camp has held the lead, despite a visit from US President Barack Obama urging Britain to stay in the EU. The Remain campaign faces a challenge in getting younger voters to participate, with the poll's margin of error at plus or minus three percent.

site_title: South Korea April FX reserves rise to 9-month high on management gains
summary: South Korea's foreign exchange reserves rose to a 9-month high in April, reaching $372.48 billion, driven mainly by "management gains" according to the Bank of Korea. The appreciation of currencies such as the Japanese yen and sterling against the dollar contributed to the increase. This marks the second consecutive month of growth in reserves.

site_title: Europe: Slides in banks, miners drag Europe stocks lower for a 3rd day
summary: European stocks declined for a third consecutive day, with the Stoxx Europe 600 Index falling 1.7% due to weak earnings reports from miners and lenders. The euro's strength also weighed on exporters, with BMW's profit missing analyst predictions. The region's benchmark has extended its biggest weekly decline since February, with Spain's IBEX 35 Index and Italy's FTSE MIB Index being the worst performers. Analysts expect a volatile market until the end of June due to the Brexit vote uncertainty.

site_title: Investors boost gold assets in world's top ETF by most since 2011
summary: Investors are pouring into gold, with holdings in the SPDR Gold Shares ETF surging 20.8 metric tons on Monday, the largest one-day expansion since 2011. The fund saw $7.1 billion in new money, the most of any ETF tracked by Bloomberg, as investors sought liquid, convertible gold amid global economic worries. Bullion prices have rallied 22% this year, driven by a weaker dollar, lower interest rates, and concerns about China and the euro zone.

site_title: Amazon, web giants shift to reporting real cost of equity pay
summary: Amazon and Facebook are shifting to report the real cost of equity pay, a long-standing practice among tech companies. This change is in response to pressure from regulators and investors. By including equity-based pay costs, companies' reported profits and official forecasts will be affected, potentially slicing billions of dollars off their market valuations. The shift is seen as a more transparent and accountable approach, with companies like Amazon and Facebook being viewed as more responsible in their use of stock compensation. This move may have a broader impact on the industry, with some analysts predicting that Twitter may be most exposed.

images.alt_text: Amazon.com Inc started breaking out stock-based compensation in the results of its different businesses in the first quarter.

site_title: France hits out at US-EU trade pact
summary: France has threatened to veto the US-EU Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) pact, citing concerns over unregulated free trade that could undermine France's agriculture and culture. French officials say the talks are unlikely to progress without significant concessions from the US, and a leaked Greenpeace document has fueled opposition to the deal. The US remains optimistic about completing the pact this year, despite differences in positions, with a US Trade Representative spokesman saying the deal would reflect democratic values and make common-sense updates to the existing economic relationship.

site_title: A glimpse of BaselWorld 2016
summary: BaselWorld 2016 unveiled a plethora of trend-setting high-end timepieces. The event showcased innovative designs, cutting-edge materials, and technological advancements in the watchmaking industry. This year's BaselWorld set the stage for a year of exciting developments in the world of luxury timepieces.

site_title: US shale firm exits bankruptcy to find just-as-tough new chapter
summary: Magnum Hunter Resources Corp, a US shale oil and gas company, has emerged from bankruptcy after its founder Gary Evans and creditors agreed to convert the company's $1 billion debt into shares. The company, which filed for bankruptcy in December, has already provided a template for other cash-strapped drillers. Evans warns that even debt-free Magnum Hunter cannot survive if energy prices do not recover soon, citing the need for gas prices to rise to $2.50-$3.00 per million cubic feet equivalent to secure its future.

site_title: Wall Street values Tesla Motors at US$620,000 per car
summary: Tesla Motors' market capitalization is approximately $31 billion, equivalent to $620,000 per car, as of May 3, 2016. This valuation is significantly higher than General Motors' $48 billion market value, which translates to $4,800 per vehicle. The high valuation has raised concerns among investors, with Tesla's stock price rally ending in April. The company's CEO, Elon Musk, may not mention the stock price in the upcoming financial update, but it will be a key focus for investors.

site_title: Citigroup to bring voice recognition to Asia amid digital push
summary: Citigroup plans to roll out voice recognition technology to its Asian retail customers, aiming to have at least 1 million users within 12 months. The technology will speed up transactions and eliminate password reminders, cutting the average phone validation time to 15 seconds. The move is part of Citigroup's digital push, with 95% of its transactions in the region taking place outside the branch network. Other banks, including HSBC and Standard Chartered, are also exploring voice recognition services in Asia.

site_title: EC warns euro area about debt as it cuts inflation forecast
summary: The European Commission has warned euro area nations, particularly France, Spain, and Italy, to reduce debt and modernize labor markets to ensure strong and sustainable growth. The commission slashed its inflation forecast, predicting an average 0.2% inflation rate this year, below the European Central Bank's target. The euro area's GDP is expected to increase by 1.6% this year and 1.8% in 2017, but faces challenges from high public and private debt, financial sector vulnerabilities, and declining competitiveness.

site_title: Criminalisation can hit shipping's bottom line
summary: The International Chamber of Shipping (ICS) has strongly criticized the Spanish Supreme Court's decision in the Prestige case, which overturned the 2013 verdict acquitting the tanker's master of environmental damage charges. The ICS argues that the decision undermines the system of shared liability for oil spills and could lead to enormous claims against shipowners. The case highlights the issue of criminalization of seafarers and the need for a strategy to protect seafarers' rights and ensure fairness and justice in maritime law.

site_title: US warns Shkreli may face more charges in securities case
summary: US authorities warn that Martin Shkreli, founder of Turing Pharmaceuticals, may face additional charges in his securities fraud case. Shkreli, who is already charged with defrauding investors, may be charged with distributing stock in Retrophin and a 2013 private placement deal. Assistant US Attorney Winston Paes stated that a more expansive indictment could be filed next month. Shkreli's trial is currently being delayed as he awaits further developments in his case, with prosecutors seeking to add more charges to the existing ones.

site_title: Australian government delivers sombre election budget for "extraordinary times"
summary: Australia's conservative government presented a sombre election budget, focusing on job creation and growth in "extraordinary times". The Reserve Bank of Australia cut interest rates to a record low of 1.75% amid low inflation and global uncertainty. The budget effectively doubles as an unofficial election campaign, with Prime Minister Malcolm Turnbull planning to dissolve parliament due to a political deadlock.

site_title: US auto sales approach records as consumers defy global slump
summary: US auto sales have reached record levels as consumers defy a global slump, with several automakers reporting strong April sales. US sales are expected to continue, potentially supporting the US economy. Automakers are selling more expensive SUVs and pickups, indicating consumer confidence. Despite some downbeat results, overall industry projections indicate a strong month, with sales beating estimates and setting new records. The US auto market may be a lone bright spot in a sluggish global economy.

site_title: Takata sets aside 20.1b yen for air-bag recall costs
summary: Takata Corp has set aside 20.1 billion yen for air-bag recall costs, following reports of a potential expansion of US recalls. The auto parts supplier denies plans to expand recalls, citing discussions with the National Highway Traffic Safety Administration (NHTSA). Over 100 million vehicles worldwide may be affected, but NHTSA spokesman Bryan Thomas says there has been no decision on expanding the US recalls.

site_title: China manufacturing weakens in April: survey
summary: China's manufacturing sector weakened in April, with a Purchasing Managers' Index (PMI) of 49.4, down 0.3 points from the previous month. The sector has been struggling due to sagging global demand for Chinese products, with new export work falling for the fifth straight month. The government is under pressure to prevent further economic downturn, with analysts differing on the impact of recent data, which showed expansion in the official sector but weakness in private sector surveys.

site_title: No respite for Japan as yen soars to 18-month high
summary: The yen has reached an 18-month high against the US dollar, rising 12% this year, amid Japan's stagnant economy and the Reserve Bank of Australia's interest rate cut. Japanese officials, including Prime Minister Shinzo Abe, have expressed concerns about the currency's run-up. The US dollar has fallen to its lowest level since January 2015, and investors are seeking safe-haven currencies. The Bank of Japan is under pressure to intervene, with a sharp yen rise potentially prompting action, despite previous G-7 meetings frowning upon such interventions.

site_title: Ferrari raises 2016 forecast as sports car sales boost profit
summary: Ferrari raised its 2016 forecast after sales of new sports cars boosted profit by 11% in the first quarter. The company expects adjusted earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization to total at least 800 million euros, up from an earlier forecast of 770 million euros. Ferrari delivered 1,882 cars in the first quarter, a 15% increase, driven by its 8-cylinder models. Revenue rose 8.8% to 675 million euros, and the company now forecasts full-year revenue of about 3 billion euros.

site_title: IS kills US Navy SEAL in Iraq attack
summary: A US Navy SEAL was killed in an Islamic State (IS) attack in northern Iraq on Tuesday, as the group continued its efforts to "thwart the plan to liberate Mosul." The attack occurred at a peshmerga position north of the city, and the SEAL was killed by "direct fire" after IS forces penetrated the Kurdish defenses. The death brings the number of US coalition members killed by enemy fire in Iraq to at least three since IS overran the country in 2014. The US has deployed additional forces to Iraq, with over 4,000 troops now involved in the fight against IS.

site_title: More credible responses needed from S'pore firms accused of bribery abroad
summary: Allegations have been made about Singapore companies' involvement in bribery scandals overseas, prompting companies to deny any wrongdoing and claim zero tolerance for corruption. However, such denials are deemed unhelpful as they don't guarantee compliance with company codes of conduct. Investigations are needed to determine if employees or third parties have paid bribes.

site_title: Philips plans listing of lighting unit after failing to find buyer
summary: Philips is planning to list its historic lighting division in Amsterdam, potentially valuing it at up to 5.5 billion euros. The company failed to find a buyer after a six-month search and aims to sell at least 25% of shares initially. The listing could shift away from Philips' lighting heritage, which dates back to 1891, as the company focuses on its healthcare business. The division reported 547 million euros in profit in 2015 and plans to pay out a 40-50% annual dividend in cash.

site_title: China stock analysts' showing among world's worst amid rout
summary: China's stock market was the world's second-worst over the past year, with its Shanghai Composite Index losing over 30% since April 2015. Analysts covering Chinese equities performed poorly, with predictions off by bigger margins than those of analysts researching the world's 20 largest markets. The worst call among the index's biggest 25 companies was Citic Securities Co, which lost 54% of its value. Despite correctly forecasting a 5.3% loss for the past year, analysts' overall performance was marred by missed inflection points and unrealistic target prices.

site_title: Hie thee to Hong Kong
summary: Twelve Cupcakes and Page One have set up shop in Hong Kong, citing the city as key to their expansion strategy. Meanwhile, in Singapore, OCBC targets S$5 billion in loans to serial entrepreneurs by 2028. The bank's incoming CEO, Tan Teck Long, is a former DBS veteran.

site_title: Rise in China's home prices accelerates in April
summary: China's home prices accelerated in April, rising an average 9% from a year earlier, according to private surveys. In the biggest 10 cities, including Shenzhen and Shanghai, prices rose 14.4% from a year ago. Despite local authorities tightening housing measures, prices in Shanghai and Shenzhen rose 1.5% in April, easing from 2.5% in March. The increases are attributed to smaller cities posting price gains, while top-tier cities continue to boom.

site_title: The impact of short selling on insider trading
summary: Short selling, a practice where investors sell shares they don't own in anticipation of a price decline, can affect insider trading by creating competition for private information.
