Over 400 starving migrants were rescued from an overloaded boat, but none have been resettled, and some have been forced to take to the high seas with people-smugglers. The UNHCR says the resettlement process has become paralysed due to Europe's own migrant crisis, and many Rohingya face uncertainty as illegal immigrants in Malaysia.

site_title: 'Impossibly rare' violet diamond found in Australia
summary: A rare 2.83-carat violet diamond, discovered in August 2015 at Australia's Argyle mine, will be showcased by Rio Tinto. The diamond, originally 9.17 carats, had etchings, pits, and crevices. After weeks of assessment, it was polished to its current shape. The Argyle Violet is considered the largest of its kind ever found in Australia, and its inclusion in Rio Tinto's annual pink diamonds showcase highlights the mine's significant production of pink and red jewels.

site_title: Indonesia's Q1 GDP growth seen inching up to 5.05% year on year
summary: Indonesia's Q1 GDP growth is forecast to reach 5.05% year on year, virtually the same as the previous quarter, indicating a slow recovery from 2015's weak growth rate of 4.8%. Analysts predict an on-quarter contraction of 0.19% in Q1, with some expecting 5.1% growth in 2016, potentially ending a five-year streak of slowing GDP growth.

site_title: China manufacturing weakens in April, private survey shows
summary: China's factory activity weakened further in April, with the Caixin Purchasing Managers' Index falling to 49.4, its 14th consecutive month of decline. The sector has struggled due to muted demand and market weakness, with new export work declining for the fifth straight month. The economy's growth slowdown has alarmed investors worldwide, with leaders targeting a 6.5-7.0% growth range this year. Analysts say the government needs to monitor the risk of a further economic downturn, while the National Bureau of Statistics reported expansion in the sector for the second month in a row.

site_title: China, Japan growth to slow sharply in 2016, IMF warns
summary: China and Japan's economies are expected to slow sharply in 2016, with China's growth forecast at 6.5% and Japan's at 0.5%, according to the IMF. Despite this, Asian growth is expected to remain strong due to domestic demand, while India is predicted to grow 7.5% and South Korea 2.7-2.9%. The IMF warns of external challenges, including weak global trade and volatile financial markets, and calls for policymakers to push ahead with structural reforms to raise productivity and create fiscal space.

site_title: Seoul: Won, stocks edge up on US data; capped ahead of RBA
summary: The South Korean won rose 0.2% to 1,135.8 per dollar after US economic data boosted stocks, but gains were capped ahead of an interest rate decision from the Reserve Bank of Australia. US stocks rose as export orders rose to a near 1-1/2 year high, offering hopes for the manufacturing sector. The Korea Composite Stock Price Index (Kospi) was up 0.1% at 1,980.85 points, driven by foreign demand and strong performance from pharmaceuticals and cosmetics companies.

site_title: Aussie debt rising faster than euro area puts AAA rating at risk
summary: Australia's debt is rising faster than the euro area, putting its AAA rating at risk. The country's budget deficit is forecast to balloon to $35 billion in 2016-17, with net debt expected to reach 19.5% of GDP by 2020. The International Monetary Fund warns that Australia's debt trajectory is similar to the euro area's, with persistent misses on budget forecasts and no plan to balance the books. The government's emphasis on growth over balancing the books has raised concerns from ratings agencies and economists, who fear that Australia's debt-to-GDP ratio could approach 30% if not addressed.

site_title: Tokyo: Markets closed for holiday
summary: Japanese financial markets closed on May 3, 2016, for a public holiday. There is no relevant information in the provided articles about the markets being closed on the specified date, as the articles appear to be from a different time period.

site_title: Industry leaders believe gender parity is within reach despite little progress: E&Y survey
summary: Industry leaders, including 70% of those polled in an Ernst & Young survey, believe achieving gender parity on their boards within the next 25 years is possible despite little progress within organizations. The World Economic Forum predicts 117 years to achieve workforce parity. Only 13% expect significant increases in women in leadership roles within the next five years. To achieve gender parity, companies need to implement metrics to track women's careers and structured programs to identify and develop female professionals. A supportive corporate culture is seen as crucial by both men and women.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Hong Kong's fragile stock rebound revealed in tumbling turnover
summary: Hong Kong's stock market experienced a 15% rebound in April, reaching a 2016 high, but the average value of shares traded has fallen to a 1 1/2-year low. Despite China's improved economic data, investors remain skeptical about the sustainability of the growth, with many preferring to sit on the sidelines. A lack of increased trading volumes also indicates a lack of momentum for further gains. Experts attribute the rebound to a short-term economic boost, which is expected to fade as the economy slows down.

site_title: Perceived corruption worsens in Arab states: Transparency International
summary: Corruption has worsened in nine Arab countries and territories over the past year, according to Transparency International's survey of nearly 11,000 respondents. The countries affected include crisis-hit Lebanon and war-torn Yemen, where 92% and 77% of respondents, respectively, reported an increase in corruption. A majority of people in the region perceive corruption to have risen recently, with 61% across the surveyed countries. The survey highlights public dissatisfaction with government efforts to curb corruption, despite the Arab Spring protests five years ago.

site_title: Canada set to make Petronas LNG decision as early as mid-summer
summary: Canada's natural resources minister, James Carr, expects to make a decision on environmental approvals for Petronas' C$36 billion Pacific NorthWest LNG project by mid- to late-summer. Petronas is expected to provide further information to regulators soon, after which the government will make a decision within 90 days. The project, valued at C$36 billion, aims to develop liquefied natural gas on Canada's Pacific coast.

site_title: BP drops US$1b seafood industry spill payments fight
summary: BP has dropped its fight against paying US$1 billion in oil spill damages to Gulf Coast seafood interests, after a federal judge allowed the company to avoid paying the remainder of a US$2.3 billion settlement. BP claimed lawyers fraudulently inflated damages, but the court rejected these claims. The seafood payout is part of a larger settlement worth US$12.9 billion, which BP now expects to cost significantly more. The company will pay the remaining damages without contesting the claims.

site_title: Australia, NZ dollars swing higher; RBA in spotlight
summary: The Australian and New Zealand dollars rose against the US dollar on Tuesday, driven by upbeat building approvals data and anticipation of a potential interest rate cut by the Reserve Bank of Australia. The Aussie reached a one-week high of US$0.7701, while the kiwi currency rose to US$0.7047. Traders await the RBA's May policy meeting, with a 50-50 chance of an interest rate cut implied by interbank futures.

site_title: Singapore shares open slightly lower on Tuesday
summary: Singapore stocks opened lower on Tuesday, edging down 0.21% or 5.98 points to 2,832.54. DBS reported a net profit of S$1.20 billion for the first quarter, down 5% from last year, but with earnings 6% higher excluding one-time items. Total income reached a new milestone, rising 5% to S$2.87 billion.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Hong Kong independence 'inevitable' says campaign leader
summary: Pro-independence leader Andy Chan claims Hong Kong's independence is inevitable, despite critics labeling his movement as naive and unrealistic. Chan's Hong Kong National Party, which has 30 core members under 30, argues that Beijing's tightening grip and the city's growing frustration with authoritarian rule make independence a viable option. Chan asserts that Hong Kong must fundamentally rethink its identity to survive, and his party is gaining momentum, with one pro-independence leader taking over 60,000 votes in a recent by-election.

site_title: Taiwan: Stocks fall to 2-month lows amid concerns over local economy
summary: Taiwan's stocks fell to 2-month lows on Tuesday, with the main Taiex index dropping 0.9% to 8,299.15, amid concerns over its struggling economy. The electronics subindex fell 1.2% and the manufacturing activity in Taiwan showed a setback in production, following a decline in the first quarter. The Taiwan dollar strengthened to T$32.211 per US dollar. The decline follows a holiday shutdown on Monday, and investors are cautious due to prolonged weakness in global demand and a recession last year.

site_title: China home prices grow faster in April despite tightening in big cities
summary: China's home prices rose 9% from a year ago in April, accelerating from a 7.4% gain in March, despite tightening measures in big cities. In the top 100 cities, prices increased 14.4% year-over-year, while smaller cities saw a 7.2% gain. Home transaction volumes in Shenzhen and Shanghai have fallen after the tightening, and prices are expected to slow in these cities. Meanwhile, prices in smaller cities continue to rise, complicating government efforts to spread wealth and arrest slowing economic growth.

images.alt_text: China's home prices continued to grow from a year earlier at an accelerating pace in April despite tightening housing measures introduced in big cities, two private surveys showed.

site_title: Malaysia: Shares open higher on Tuesday
summary: Malaysia's FTSE Bursa Malaysia Kuala Lumpur Composite Index rose 1.47 points to 1,674.19 on Tuesday, with gains outnumbering losses 135 to 74. The index was boosted by a higher volume of 69.92 million lots worth RM36.59 million.

site_title: Manulife Reit said to seek up to US$470m in Singapore IPO
summary: Manulife US Reit, backed by three office buildings in Los Angeles and Atlanta, plans to raise up to US$470 million in its second attempt at a Singapore initial public offering. The trust will offer 566 million units at 82-83 US cents apiece, with a potential dividend yield of 6.7-7.2% for 2016 and 2017. The offering will be Singapore's first above US$100 million since 2015, and a successful listing will boost the city-state's exchange. The trust expects to start trading on May 20.

site_title: Stocks to watch: DBS, S i2i, Frasers Centrepoint, IHC
summary: DBS Group reported a net profit of S$1.20 billion for the first quarter of 2016, a 5% decrease from the previous year. Excluding one-time items, earnings rose 6% to a record, while total income reached S$2.87 billion, a 5% increase.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Woman says she is Prince's long-lost sister, claims part of estate
summary: A woman, Darcell Gresham Johnston, claims to be Prince's half-sister, seeking part of his multimillion-dollar estate. She filed court documents stating she's an "interested party and beneficiary" in the estate. Prince died without a will, leaving no children or living parents, and his estate was initially expected to be split six ways among his known surviving siblings. However, Johnston's claim could alter the distribution, as she shares a mother with Prince and her existence was only recently discovered by some of his siblings. The court will determine the legitimacy of her claim.

site_title: The Philippine election could shake up rising tiger's economy
summary: The Philippines is set to hold a presidential election on May 9, which could impact the country's economic growth and geopolitics in the region. The country, once known as Asia's "sick man," has experienced a 6.2% average six-year growth rate under outgoing leader Benigno Aquino III. The next president will face challenges such as curbing corruption, addressing traffic congestion, and navigating relations with China. Four candidates, including Rodrigo Duterte and Grace Poe, are vying for the top spot, with Duterte promising tough leadership and Poe vowing to lower corporate taxes and encourage investment.

site_title: Developers' plans have to consider needs of non-motorists from July
summary: The Land Transport Authority (LTA) and Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) will require developers to submit a walking and cycling plan (WCP) starting from July, considering the needs of pedestrians and cyclists in new developments. The WCP aims to design new developments with covered walkways, safe crossings, and facilities for cyclists, such as parking and shower rooms. This move aligns with the government's efforts to promote walking, cycling, and using public transport as a way of life for Singaporeans. The WCP will apply to commercial developments, schools, and other areas.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

From July this year, the Land Transport Authority (LTA) and Urban Redevelopment Authority (URA) will require developers to submit a walking and cycling plan (WCP) so that the needs of pedestrians and cyclists are considered.

site_title: Fed's Williams sees big drop in assets as possible systemic risk
summary: San Francisco Federal Reserve President John Williams warned of a potential systemic financial risk due to large asset declines as interest rates rise. He believes the neutral interest rate could be as low as 3%, lower than current estimates. This suggests a higher risk of economic instability.

site_title: UK's EU status worth £250b in trade, says ex-chancellor
summary: Former UK Chancellor Alistair Darling warns that leaving the European Union could cost the UK £250 billion in annual trade, citing a 76% increase in trade with EU countries compared to without membership. This could result in re-establishing tariffs and barriers, potentially weakening the economy. Supporters of Brexit dismiss the claims as "absurd," while the Britain Stronger In Europe group emphasizes the difficulty of securing new trade agreements, potentially taking at least six years. The UK votes on EU membership on June 23.

images.alt_text: The UK risks losing £250 billion (S$492 billion) a year in trade if it leaves the European Union, according to former Chancellor of the Exchequer Alistair Darling.

site_title: Secrecy, hierarchy haunt Japan corporate culture despite Abe's reforms
summary: Japan's corporate culture remains secretive and hierarchical despite Prime Minister Shinzo Abe's reforms, which introduced new governance rules to attract foreign investment. Scandals at top companies, including Mitsubishi Motor Corp and Toshiba Corp, have exposed the need for more transparency and whistleblower protection. Experts say better protection for whistleblowers, training for board directors, and stiffer penalties are needed to change the corporate culture. While some progress has been made, broader and deeper reforms are required to address the issues, including the need for greater independence and authority among outside directors.

images.alt_text: Prime Minister Shinzo Abe won applause for introducing new corporate governance rules over the past two years in bid to attract foreign investment and shake-up Japan's too-cozy corporate culture.

site_title: Asia: Stocks follow US higher before China data, Aussie rates
summary: Asian stocks rebounded 0.2% after US shares gained, despite a 0.4% decline in the Hang Seng Index and a 0.2% increase in the Shanghai Composite Index. Investors await Chinese manufacturing data and an interest-rate decision in Australia. The S&P 500 posted its steepest advance in two weeks, driven by bank rebounds and Amazon's jump. Markets in Tokyo will remain closed through Thursday.

site_title: 'Unfixable' Halliburton bid felled by global scrutiny
summary: Halliburton Co's proposed $28 billion merger with Baker Hughes Inc collapsed due to global antitrust opposition. Regulators worldwide expressed concerns that the deal would reduce competition in oilfield services, leading to higher oil and gas prices for consumers. Despite offering to sell several businesses, the companies ultimately failed to overcome regulatory hurdles. The US Justice Department had deemed the deal "unfixable," citing concerns in 23 markets and potential price increases. The collapse marks a significant setback for the oil industry's consolidation efforts.

site_title: Australian treasurer sticks by spending cuts as path to surplus
summary: Australian Treasurer Scott Morrison has announced his first federal budget, aiming to return the country to a surplus by 2021-22. Despite Moody's ratings agency's concerns, Morrison says modest spending cuts will achieve this goal. The budget includes tax cuts for high-income earners and businesses, as well as a 12.5% increase in cigarette excise. Morrison emphasizes the need for fiscal responsibility to drive economic growth and job creation, dismissing concerns over the country's finances.

site_title: IHC opens joint venture medical centre in Wuxi to cater to high-end market
summary: IHC opens International Medical Centre in Wuxi, China, a joint venture with Phoenix Hospital and SK Group, targeting the high-end market with 165 beds and 300 full-time doctors. The centre aims to provide advanced healthcare services, including long-distance diagnostics, to expatriates and locals in Wuxi New District.

images.alt_text: Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: Mexico City bans 40% of cars again over air pollution
summary: Mexico City has issued a new air pollution alert, banning 40% of vehicles on the road and industries from cutting emissions by up to 40%. The alert comes after ozone levels reached 161 points, exceeding the 150-point threshold. The ban, which will be doubled on Tuesday, affects 5.5 million vehicles daily. Cement, chemical, and power companies are also required to reduce emissions by 40%. This is the first air pollution alert in a decade and follows a pollution emergency in March.

site_title: Hong Kong: Stocks retreat at open
summary: Hong Kong stocks declined 0.72% on Tuesday, following Asia-wide losses the previous day. The Hang Seng Index dropped to 20,915.85, while the Shanghai Composite Index edged up marginally. The Shenzhen Composite Index slipped 0.02%.

site_title: Deutsche Bank says Americas chief Jacques Brand to leave firm
summary: Deutsche Bank announced that Jacques Brand, its Americas CEO, is leaving the company to pursue another opportunity. Brand started at Lehman Brothers in 1984 and joined Bankers Trust in 1990, which was later acquired by Deutsche Bank. A successor will be announced in due course, with co-CEOs John Cryan and Juergen Fitschen overseeing the process.

site_title: Oil price maker Jorge Montepeque joins Italy's energy major Eni
summary: Jorge Montepeque, inventor of the modern oil price-setting system, has joined Eni's trading arm as Senior Vice-President for Origination in London. He left Platts, where he was head of market reporting, last year, criticizing the outdated market-on-close pricing mechanism. Montepeque will leverage his market knowledge and contacts to support Eni's customers worldwide, marking a significant move in the energy industry.

site_title: Oil prices dip on rising Middle East supply
summary: Oil prices dropped in early Asian trading on May 3, 2016, due to rising Middle East supply. The international Brent crude benchmark fell to $45.68 per barrel, down 15 US cents from its last close. Iraq reported its highest oil shipments in April at 3.364 million barrels per day, while Saudi Arabia's production may rise to near-records. The surge in Middle East output counters falling US production, potentially leading to another downward correction in oil markets.

site_title: DBS Q1 net profit slips 5%
summary: DBS Group reported a 5% decline in Q1 net profit to S$1.20 billion, despite a record earnings of S$1.26 billion excluding one-time items. Total income rose 5% to S$2.87 billion, driven by higher non-interest income and a lower cost-income ratio. The bank's CEO, Piyush Gupta, attributed the performance to "unusually challenging market conditions" and the bank's strong franchise and balance sheet. Net fee income and loans remained steady, with a 6% increase in specific allowances.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Dollar near one-year low as Fed rate increase speculation cools
summary: The US dollar fell to its lowest level in almost a year, near $1.10 per euro, as speculation over a Federal Reserve interest rate increase cooled. Traders lowered expectations for a rate hike in June to 12%, leading to a decline in the dollar against major peers. The dollar's weakness persisted despite disappointing US growth data and a report showing US manufacturing expanded less than forecast.

site_title: Yingli slumps after solar manufacturer warns of bankruptcy
summary: Yingli Green Energy Holding Co, the world's largest solar manufacturer, plummeted 13% to $3.98 after warning of potential bankruptcy. The company acknowledged "substantial doubt" about its ability to continue as a going concern due to declining shipments and write-offs. Yingli is in talks with creditors about repaying loans, but analysts predict a filing for bankruptcy. The company has been kept afloat by state-backed lenders and has reported no quarterly profits since 2011.

site_title: China stock analysts were among world's worst amid surprise rout
summary: China's stock market was the world's second-worst over the past year, with its Shanghai Composite Index losing over 30% of its value since April 2015. Analysts covering Chinese equities were among the worst, with predictions off by bigger margins than those of analysts researching stocks in the world's 20 largest markets. Despite this, they correctly foresaw a 5.3% loss for the Shanghai benchmark last year. The poor performance was attributed to analysts' inability to predict the macro environment, exchange-rate moves, and government policy flip-flops, which led to a selloff that drained $5 trillion from Chinese equities.

site_title: FLASH: DBS Q1 net profit including one-time item slips 5%
summary: DBS Group Holdings reported a 5% decline in its Q1 net profit, excluding a one-time item. The decline was attributed to higher provisions for loan losses and a decrease in net interest income. Despite this, the bank's total assets and deposits increased. The results were announced on May 2, 2016.

images.alt_text: Angela Tan

site_title: Amazon bolsters voice based-platform Alexa with investment in TrackR
summary: Amazon has invested between $250,000 and $500,000 in Bluetooth technology company TrackR to expand its Alexa virtual assistant capabilities. The investment will allow TrackR's lost item tracking service to integrate with Alexa, enabling users to find lost items using voice commands. This partnership marks the latest investment by Amazon's $100 million "Alexa Fund" to support technologies that broaden Alexa's abilities. TrackR, which uses Bluetooth to track lost items, aims to build an ecosystem with the Alexa partnership.

site_title: Kuroda warns current yen strength risks harming Japan recovery
summary: Bank of Japan Governor Haruhiko Kuroda warned that the yen's recent 5% surge against the dollar risks harming Japan's economic recovery. Kuroda reiterated the central bank's commitment to achieving a 2% inflation target by expanding monetary stimulus if necessary. The yen's rally occurred despite the Bank of Japan leaving its policy settings unchanged at a meeting last week.

site_title: Europe: Auto stocks help Europe drive higher, shrug off Japan-led Asia losses
summary: European shares rose Monday, driven by gains in car manufacturers, despite a sharp drop in Tokyo as a surging yen hit exporters. Germany's DAX 30 and France's CAC 40 ended the day up 0.8% and 0.3%, respectively. Fiat Chrysler Automobiles' upbeat comments on China's outlook also boosted the market. However, Italian banking stocks fell, and the US dollar dropped against the euro after a manufacturing report showed the sector slowed more than expected in April.

site_title: Solar Impulse 2 soars over US southwest on round-the-world flight
summary: The Solar Impulse 2, a solar-powered aircraft, began its US leg of a round-the-world flight on May 2, 2016, from Moffett Airfield in California. Pilot Andre Borschberg took off in the morning to fly to Phoenix, Arizona, covering 720 miles over the Mojave Desert. The 10th of 13 legs in the journey, the aircraft will make stops across the US and eventually reach New York before crossing the Atlantic to Europe. The mission aims to promote clean energy technologies and has already broken previous records for long-distance flights.

site_title: Chicago woman sues Starbucks for putting too much ice in drinks
summary: A Chicago woman, Stacy Pincus, has sued Starbucks for allegedly putting too much ice in chilled drinks, claiming the company's iced coffee and tea drinks contain less than the advertised 24 ounces of fluid. Pincus is seeking $5 million in damages and has applied for class status for the lawsuit. Starbucks has called the lawsuit "without merit," stating that customers understand and expect ice in iced beverages, and will remake drinks if customers are not satisfied.

site_title: SoundCloud extends paid-for music streaming service to UK, Ireland
summary: SoundCloud has expanded its paid-for music streaming service, SoundCloud Go, to the UK and Ireland, weeks after its US launch. The service offers ad-free content for a monthly subscription fee of 9.99 pounds or euros. With 175 million users, SoundCloud aims to become a major competitor to Apple and Spotify, despite not being a profitable business yet. The company plans to roll out SoundCloud Go to multiple territories this year and is well-funded with $35 million in debt financing and a convertible bond option.

site_title: ANZ posts 24% drop in first-half cash profit, lags forecast
summary: ANZ Banking Group posted a 24% drop in first-half cash profit to A$2.78 billion, missing forecasts due to higher bad debt charges from a commodity downturn. This is the largest six-month decline since 2008. ANZ also slashed its interim dividend by 7% to 80 cents. The bank is shifting its strategy to refocus on home markets under new CEO Shayne Elliott.

site_title: 80 countries to attend world aid summit
summary: The World Humanitarian Summit, set to take place in Istanbul on May 23-24, will feature 80 countries, with 45 represented by heads of state or government. The summit aims to rethink global crisis responses and secure funding commitments. UN aid chief Stephen O'Brien described the turnout as "encouraging," but noted it falls short of the UN's 193 member-states. The event seeks to reframe humanitarian efforts and address pressing global issues.

site_title: New Chicago high-rise will be city's biggest Chinese property deal
summary: Dalian Wanda, China's largest commercial property company, has announced a US$900 million investment in the Vista Tower, a 95-story condominium and hotel complex in Chicago. The project, set to break ground this summer, will be the city's third-largest skyscraper and employ 2,000 construction workers and 500 permanent employees. The complex will feature 406 residential units, a 200-room luxury hotel, and 9,000 square feet of retail space. The investment is the largest-ever real estate deal by a Chinese company in Chicago, with Mayor Rahm Emanuel calling it a "significant day" for the city.

site_title: Brazil state banks' bond woes to worsen after years of largess
summary: Brazil's state-controlled banks, including Banco do Brasil, Caixa Economica Federal, and BNDES, face worsening bond woes due to the country's recession. After boosting lending by 14.1% between 2012 and 2015, state banks' borrowing costs are soaring relative to private peers. Delinquencies are increasing, and state banks are increasing provisions to cover bad loans, with the highest level since May 2009. Analysts warn that the challenges facing state banks are greater than those in past recessions.

images.alt_text: After ratcheting up lending at the behest of President Dilma Rousseff, Brazil's state-controlled banks may be in store for more pain.

site_title: Oil prices fall further from 2016 peak
summary: Oil prices fell for a second consecutive session, driven by concerns over excess oil supply and uncertain demand. Reports of rising output in Iraq and Iran, with exports hitting a near-record 3.36 million barrels per day and an estimated 3.5 million barrels per day, respectively, contributed to the decline. Analysts attribute the drop to a bearish outlook following Trump's tariff announcements, which may impact global energy markets.

site_title: US top court rejects BP shareholder suit over stock price plunge
summary: The US Supreme Court declined to hear a class-action lawsuit by BP shareholders seeking compensation for a sharp decline in share price following the 2010 Gulf of Mexico oil spill. The court's refusal upholds a 2015 decision dismissing the suit, which alleged BP deceived shareholders about security procedures. The Deepwater Horizon disaster killed 11 men and caused $55 billion in damages for BP, with the company paying $20.8 billion to settle government claims. The lawsuit's dismissal will remain in place.

site_title: Chrome crowned top Internet browser by market tracker
summary: Google Chrome has been crowned the top Internet browser, surpassing Microsoft Internet Explorer's 41.4% share to take 41.7% in April, according to NetMarketShare. Mozilla's Firefox came in third with 9.7% share. This marks the end of IE's long reign, as StatCounter also previously crowned Chrome the top browser four years ago.

site_title: Court order shuts down WhatsApp in Brazil, again
summary: A Brazilian court blocked WhatsApp nationwide for 72 hours due to Facebook's refusal to provide information in a drug-trafficking investigation. The shutdown is the second in six months, with the first occurring in December. WhatsApp is widely used in Brazil, where cell phone fees for texting and calls are high, and the app's suspension drew angry reactions online. The Brazilian authorities and Facebook have denied obstructing justice, with Facebook stating it has no technical means to cooperate with the request.

site_title: There's a new sheriff in town in Silicon Valley: the FDA
summary: The FDA is increasingly scrutinizing Silicon Valley startups, particularly those in the health tech sector. Guardant Health, a leading "liquid biopsy" test company, has received nearly $200 million in venture funding and presented promising data on its screening tool, which scans for tiny DNA fragments shed by dying tumour cells. The FDA's concerns about startups' products suggest they may be overpromising their capabilities, leading to a shift in regulatory oversight.

site_title: Chanel winning fight against luxury grey market
summary: Chanel has successfully curbed the grey market, boosting revenue in China despite weaker luxury demand. The company narrowed price gaps and reduced parallel market sales in Asia. Chanel's boutiques in mainland China experienced double-digit growth. The luxury brand is set to unveil its latest Cruise collection in Havana, marking a sign of warming relations between Cuba and the West. Despite this, Chanel expects slower sales growth this year due to economic slowdowns and terrorist attacks affecting tourist traffic.

site_title: Japan aims to set up LNG trading hub by early 2020s
summary: Japan aims to establish a liquefied natural gas (LNG) trading hub by the early 2020s to increase market transparency and liquidity. The country plans to open its receiving terminal and boost large-scale storage facilities to facilitate active LNG trading. This move follows a G-7 energy ministers' meeting in Kitakyushu, where they supported creating LNG trading hubs to improve market conditions. Japan, the world's largest LNG importer, seeks to cut fuel costs and gain control over prices after the Fukushima disaster.

site_title: Goldman targets 'mass affluent' borrowers with unusual lending plan
summary: Goldman Sachs is developing an unusual lending strategy, partnering with small brokerages and wealth management firms to lend to clients with less wealth, known as "mass affluent" borrowers, who have less than $1 million in investable assets. The plan aims to expand Goldman's borrower base and offset declining profits from traditional businesses like bond trading. This approach carries more risk, but Goldman is looking to diversify its business model and target a broader client base. The strategy is still in its early stages and may not be active until next year.

site_title: Russian creator of malware ordered to pay US$6.9m
summary: A Russian man, Nikita Kuzmin, was ordered to pay US$6.9 million for creating the malware Gozi, which stole tens of millions of dollars from bank accounts. Kuzmin was sentenced to time served after serving 37 months in prison, sparing him further US prison time. He pleaded guilty in 2011 and cooperated with US prosecutors, who described him as an innovator in online crime. A Latvian man who admitted to writing some of the malware's code was also sentenced to time served.

site_title: No case for an interest-rate cut by the Reserve Bank of Australia
summary: The Reserve Bank of Australia is unlikely to cut interest rates amid a 0.2% decline in headline inflation in the March quarter, contrary to industry expectations. Core annual inflation rate of 1.55% is below the central bank's target range of 2-3%. While fuel price drops are a concern, the decline is largely due to global oil price falls. Australia's economy has not suffered a technical recession in 24 years, and it maintained growth of 3% in 2015, making an interest-rate cut unnecessary.

site_title: China's flood of cash even roils egg futures
summary: China has poured hundreds of billions of dollars into its economy, including a significant amount into the financial market in Dalian, where investors bet on the future productivity of China's hens. This has led to a surge in egg futures prices by up to one-third, despite actual egg prices falling in the country's markets. Experts attribute this to China's tendency to experience investment bubbles when the government steps up spending and lending, raising concerns about the country's already fast-growing debt burden and potential long-term problems.

site_title: Football: Leicester celebrate EPL title with Vardy party
summary: Leicester City players celebrated their historic Premier League title win with a party at Jamie Vardy's house after a 2-2 draw between Tottenham and Chelsea. The Foxes were crowned champions for the first time in their 132-year history, ending Tottenham's two-goal lead. Players, including Christian Fuchs and Robert Huth, gathered at Vardy's home to watch the match, with footage of their emotional reaction going viral on social media. Manager Claudio Ranieri was absent, reportedly heading to Italy to meet his 96-year-old mother, sparking speculation about his whereabouts.

site_title: US dollar falls vs euro after manufacturing data
summary: The US dollar fell against the euro on Monday after eurozone manufacturing data outshone a similar US report. The euro reached a session high of US$1.1536, its first time trading above US$1.15 in nine months. This move contrasts with the previous day's trade, where the euro was at US$1.1452.

site_title: Halliburton and Baker Hughes scrap US$28b merger
summary: Halliburton Co and Baker Hughes Inc terminated their US$28 billion merger deal after opposition from US and European antitrust regulators. The proposed tie-up, which would have combined the world's No 2 and No 3 oil services companies, raised concerns about higher prices in the sector. This is the latest example of a large merger deal failing to complete due to antitrust hurdles. The deal's termination follows similar high-profile failures, including the collapse of AT&T and Time Warner's merger in 2018.

site_title: US launches bid to save Syria truce
summary: US Secretary of State John Kerry launched a bid to salvage the Syria ceasefire, meeting with UN envoy Staffan de Mistura and Russian Foreign Minister Sergei Lavrov to bolster ceasefire monitors and pressure moderate rebels. Despite progress, Kerry warned the truce is under threat and the conflict is "out of control." The ceasefire has been strained by fighting in Aleppo, where over 250 civilians have been killed, and the US accuses President Bashar al-Assad's regime of deliberately targeting clinics and hospitals. A new ceasefire mechanism for Aleppo is being discussed, but a deal has not been reached.

site_title: Quaker Oats' 100% natural claim questioned in lawsuit
summary: A class-action lawsuit has been filed against Quaker Oats, owned by PepsiCo, claiming the company's "100% natural" oatmeal products contain traces of the herbicide glyphosate. Despite the levels being below the federal limit for human consumption, the lawsuit accuses Quaker of false advertising. The lawsuit also claims that Quaker's environmentally responsible growing methods do not justify the "natural" label. Quaker Oats has stated that it did not add glyphosate during the milling process and that any remaining levels are trace amounts.

site_title: Early part of week may see short-covering rebound
summary: Singapore stocks are expected to rebound in the early part of the week due to short-covering, following a six-session decline. Foreigners' buying of Japanese equities, despite the yen's 18-month high, indicates markets want central banks to keep propping them up. The Fed's June meeting is expected to have lower chances of a rate hike, with futures pricing in only a 12% chance of an upward move. DBS' first-quarter figures on Tuesday will also influence the market, and a relatively quiet week is expected after the holidays.

site_title: Housing recovery sees great divide around Atlanta
summary: In Atlanta's South DeKalb County, a significant divide in housing values exists, with predominantly African American neighborhoods experiencing lower home prices compared to similar, mostly white areas. A Washington Post analysis found that Zip codes with higher black populations have worse housing values, with nearly 90% of largely black Zip codes still below pre-2004 levels. Experts attribute this disparity to cumulative causation, including predatory lending, foreclosures, and government policies that target African Americans. The recovery in housing values appears to be uniquely disadvantaging black communities, with comparable white neighborhoods recovering faster.

site_title: Luye Medical to set up innovation centre
summary: Luye Medical Group, a Singapore-based healthcare company, is expanding its global presence with its recent A$938 million acquisition of Australian group Healthe Care. The acquisition aims to boost capabilities in delivering medical services, strengthen forays into medical research and education, and lay the groundwork for a comprehensive healthcare system by 2025. Luye Medical plans to set up an innovation centre in Singapore by the end of the year, and will establish three more clinics in major Chinese cities. The company also aims to open its first general hospital in China by early 2018.

site_title: US first daughter rebels, sort of, by choosing Harvard University
summary: Malia Obama, the eldest daughter of US President Barack Obama, has chosen to attend Harvard University, reportedly disregarding her parents' advice to consider lesser-known schools. Malia, 17, will defer her start date until 2017, giving her a gap year to prepare and potentially avoid media scrutiny. The decision is seen as a nod to the university's prestigious reputation and its history of hosting presidential children, including her mother, Michelle Obama.

site_title: Greenpeace publishes confidential US-EU trade deal documents
summary: Greenpeace has released confidential US-EU trade deal documents, stating that the agreement would lower food safety and environmental standards. The European Commission disputed this, claiming the documents reflect negotiating positions rather than final outcomes. The EU's chief negotiator also refuted some of Greenpeace's points, calling them "flatly wrong."

site_title: US$ steadies after record slide versus yen
summary: The US dollar recovered from its largest weekly fall in over seven years against the yen, closing at 106.64 yen, 0.2% down on the day. Despite Finance Minister Taro Aso's concerns over the yen's strength, the currency continued to rise due to the Bank of Japan's lack of action last week. Analysts predict the yen could reach 100 yen per dollar, with purchasing manager surveys showing soft Chinese numbers and solid German manufacturing data.

site_title: IMF warns of severe headwinds from weak global recovery
summary: The International Monetary Fund (IMF) warns of severe headwinds facing Asia due to a weak global recovery, slowing global trade, and China's growth transition. The region is vulnerable to adverse spillovers from China's rebalancing, which could have medium-term growth benefits but short-term negative effects. The IMF advises policymakers to strengthen reform efforts to raise productivity and create fiscal space. Growth in Asia-Pacific economies is expected to decelerate to 5.25% in 2016-17, driven by domestic demand and labor market conditions.

site_title: Helping smart home dreams become reality in Singapore
summary: Singapore-based home solutions provider Titantt aims to provide high-quality but affordable home automation systems, kitchens, and feature walls catering to the country's climate and lifestyle. Founded by Tony Tan, the company has secured exclusive deals with overseas suppliers and secured its current 5,000 sq ft premises in Tai Seng. Titantt's products, such as automated home systems and European-style kitchens, are designed to be affordable and tech-friendly, with a focus on quality and service standards. The company's philosophy is to build synergy and change the negative atmosphere in the interior design industry, offering free resources to interior designers and no commissions.

site_title: Drought in Asia raises fears about food security
summary: Asia's top rice producers, India, Thailand, and Vietnam, face a severe drought threatening to cut global rice output and boost prices. The drought, linked to an El Nino weather pattern, has led to crop yields decline in the region's "rice bowl." World rice production is expected to decline for the first time in seven years, with India's output potentially dropping by over 10% and Thailand's by over 20%. This could lead to a significant price increase, with prices already up 13% from an eight-year low, and could have a ripple effect on global food markets.

site_title: Oil bulls bet waning US shale boom will curb global glut
summary: Hedge funds are optimistic that the US shale boom will curb the global oil glut, leading to a five-month high in West Texas Intermediate (WTI) crude prices. Investors believe falling US production and rising fuel demand will trim supplies, despite an inventory gain. This optimism has led to the most bullish stance since May last year.

site_title: Embracing the media to create brand presence
summary: Singaporean small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) must strategically build their brand equity by embracing the evolution of media, particularly in social media, to target their audience. To maximize the benefits of social media management, SMEs should create quality content around their offerings, use tactical efforts like contests and giveaways, and focus on corporate social responsibility and cross-marketing. Benchmarking against successful SMEs can also provide valuable insights. Successful local SMEs, such as a health devices brand and a bakery company, have implemented effective social media strategies that include daily posts, promotions, and influencer marketing, resulting in significant growth and engagement.

site_title: Air France- KLM board appoints Janaillac as new CEO
summary: Air France-KLM's board of directors appointed Jean-Marc Janaillac as the group's new CEO, succeeding Alexandre de Juniac, who stepped down on July 31. Janaillac, 63, is the current head of French transport group Transdev. His appointment was widely anticipated, and the board praised his "knowledge of the airline industry and its customers." Janaillac's predecessor helped the airline return to profit last year for the first time since 2008, despite acrimonious relations with pilots.

site_title: S'pore yards may be in running for work on Conoco's new FPSO
summary: Singapore-based yards Keppel O&M and Sembcorp Marine are tipped as potential contenders for the proposed floating production, storage and offloading (FPSO) vessel for ConocoPhillips' Caldita-Barossa gas field off Australia's Northern Territory. The FPSO, which could cost between $1 billion and $2 billion, will deliver a much-needed boost to Singapore's offshore and marine players. ConocoPhillips is expected to finalize the decision within days and the tender plan for the FPSO is projected to be issued in 2018.

site_title: Reckitt Benckiser executive slapped while apologising
summary: A Reckitt Benckiser executive, Ata Safdar, was slapped while apologizing at a news conference in Seoul, South Korea, over deadly lung injuries linked to humidifier sterilizers marketed by the company. The incident occurred during an emotional apology for the 92 deaths and 178 affected users, with Safdar stating the company's full responsibility and offering a compensation plan. The apology marked the first public acceptance of responsibility by the firm, which has been at the center of a controversy since 2011.

site_title: Centurion to buy four student dorms in UK for £20.1m
summary: Centurion Corporation, a Singapore-based company, has signed a deal to buy four student dorms in UK university cities for £20.1m, adding 519 beds to its portfolio. The assets include 37- and 140-bed properties in Manchester, 157-bed in Bristol, and 185-bed in Newcastle. The acquisitions are expected to be earnings accretive from the onset, with Centurion aiming to increase its portfolio from 56,000 beds to 75,000 by 2018.

site_title: Aussie tech entrepreneur confirms his identity as bitcoin creator
summary: Australian tech entrepreneur Craig Wright confirmed his identity as the creator of bitcoin, ending years of speculation about Satoshi Nakamoto. Wright provided technical proof using bitcoins owned by the creator, with prominent bitcoin community members confirming his claim. He also repeated his claim to The Economist and GQ. Wright's statement marks the end of a long-standing mystery surrounding the origin of the digital currency.

site_title: Malaysia's MISC in talks to acquire TH Heavy Engineering
summary: MISC Bhd, the shipping unit of Malaysia's national oil company Petronas, is in talks to acquire TH Heavy Engineering (THHE) after a proposed RM2 billion cash injection failed to materialise. The acquisition of THHE's floating production and fabrication businesses is expected to be finalized within weeks, but disagreements on the sale and purchase price of THHE's assets remain a hurdle.

site_title: In Rome, cheap public housing hid for years in plain sight
summary: In Rome, Italy, a long-standing public housing rental scandal has been uncovered, revealing that the city's municipal government had secretly rented thousands of apartments to various individuals and organizations for minimal costs, often for decades. The discovery was made by the new interim administrator, Francesco Paolo Tronca, who found 1,200 case files containing information on the rentals. The rentals included apartments for charities, sports centers, and embassies, as well as supposed low-income tenants who were instead rewarded with cheap housing. The scandal highlights the city's long history of patronage and corruption, with the next mayor facing the task of implementing reforms to address the issue.

site_title: Local digital ad firm ReFUEL4 wins Facebook global award
summary: ReFUEL4, a Singapore-based digital ad firm, won the Facebook global award for Innovation Spotlight, one of three companies globally to receive the honor. The award recognizes ReFUEL4's expertise in delivering quality content and creatives at scale, using a mix of human design intuition and artificial intelligence. The company's platform produces 5,000-8,000 ads per month and is a global partner of Facebook, serving clients such as Spotify and Pay-Pal. ReFUEL4's CEO Kazuhiro Takiguchi and co-founder Vernon Vasu emphasized the importance of addressing the issue of ad versions and ad performance, and the company plans to target more growth in the US and Europe.

site_title: Riding the waves of Big Data
summary: Asia is experiencing a cultural shift that will enable Big Data to address economic challenges. Small and medium-sized enterprises (SMEs) can leverage Big Data to enhance business decisions, improve productivity, and increase market share by adopting a holistic data and analytics (D&A) technology implementation approach. Effective deployment of Big Data requires balancing analytics integration, timing, and accessibility, as well as integrating D&A into business strategy and building a data-driven culture. SMEs must also be cautious and proactive in implementing data-driven decisions to avoid business pitfalls and capitalize on opportunities.

site_title: New healthcare cooperative will help sandwiched class: Murali
summary: A new healthcare cooperative is proposed by SDP candidate Murali Pillai to assist the "sandwiched class" in Bukit Batok, a group that struggles financially but doesn't receive the same subsidies as low-income households. The cooperative aims to provide health screenings, check-ups, and essential items at lower prices. SDP chief Chee Soon Juan also vowed to push for a retrenchment insurance scheme in parliament if elected, citing the success of similar programs in other Asian economies.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen
PAP candidate Murali Pillai at the Bukit Batok bus interchange on May 1. Both the PAP and SDP did not hold a rally on Monday.

site_title: Merkel's 1.2b euro German e-car push boosts Infineon, STMicro
summary: Chancellor Angela Merkel's 1.2 billion euro electric-car subsidy program in Germany is expected to boost chipmakers, particularly Infineon Technologies AG and STMicro. The program, which starts in May, translates to about US$300 million of chips by 2019, according to analyst Guenther Hollfelder. Infineon is slated to win most of this revenue, as the program aims to support the development of battery-charging stations and electric vehicles.

site_title: Britain flirts with economic insanity in considering Brexit
summary: The UK is set to vote on June 23 to decide whether to leave the European Union, a move that could lead to economic instability and "economic insanity." The UK's economy would likely suffer, with potential losses of $3,200 per average household income by 2020, according to an OECD study. Critics argue that the UK's sovereignty and influence would be compromised, and the country's status as a financial center would be threatened. The decision would also create uncertainty in a global economy already plagued by uncertainty, making it a potentially destructive move.

site_title: World's longest negative rate experiment shows perversions
summary: Denmark's experience with negative interest rates has shown that cheap money does not fuel investment, contrary to initial logic. Despite rates being below zero for longer than anywhere else, the private sector is saving more and investing less, leading to a "low-growth crisis". Stagnant prices and a stagnant economy are also evident.

site_title: India's floundering bank debt-for-equity deals a warning for China
summary: Indian lenders are struggling to find new owners for unprofitable steel and infrastructure companies they took over under a debt-for-equity swap, a warning sign for China's similar plan. 18 firms with a combined debt of about $15 billion are either in control or in the process of being seized by Indian banks. This indicates a high risk for China's similar scheme, which aims to swap debt for equity and freeze non-performing loans. The outcome may pressure Chinese policymakers to reassess their strategy.

site_title: Capital outflows to continue out of China in 2016: analysts
summary: China's capital outflows are expected to continue in 2016, with analysts predicting a 5% drop in the yuan against the US dollar. Despite some stabilization in February, downward pressures on the yuan remain, driven by the country's large foreign exchange reserves and the need to implement reforms. China's central bank, the People's Bank of China, is struggling to maintain stability, with some analysts warning of a potential unpegging of the yuan and a 25% drop in its value by mid-2017.

site_title: Wage stagnation is central issue in American election
summary: The US presidential election is centered around wage stagnation, with candidates Hillary Clinton and Donald Trump leading the Democratic and Republican contests, respectively. The average American family earned $53,657 in 2014, barely increasing from the previous year. The federal minimum wage has remained stagnant at $7.25 since 2009. The next president must address this issue and promote policies that renew the American dream, with tax reform being a key area of focus. A Stanford University economist's study found that Trump's tax plan would lead to 12% GDP growth and minimal revenue loss, while Clinton's plan would produce minimal negative growth and be revenue neutral.

site_title: Valeant's new chief cuts a familiar figure
summary: Valeant Pharmaceuticals International has appointed Joseph Papa as its new chief executive, replacing Michael Pearson. Papa's tenure at Perrigo Co, a similar pharmaceutical company, has raised concerns about the similarities between the two companies' business practices, including aggressive dealmaking, tax inversions, and fantasy accounting. Perrigo has reduced its tax rate through a merger with a foreign company and paid high premiums for acquisitions, practices that have been discredited at Valeant. Despite Papa's efforts to create an ethical culture, the company's financial health remains a concern, with a large debt burden and a lack of a strong pipeline of internally developed products.

site_title: Opec is no longer a dominant force
summary: The Opec cartel's influence over oil prices is waning, as the US shale boom and Russia's increased production have reduced the cartel's ability to control global oil markets. A failed Opec-Russia deal to freeze production highlights the cartel's inability to agree on production cuts, with Saudi Arabia refusing to participate unless Iran did. The US has become a major swing producer, with private companies able to expand production in response to price changes. As US production increases, oil prices fall, and green energy policies reduce oil consumption in countries such as Japan and Western Europe.

site_title: Opportunities in European real estate amid low interest rates
summary: Low interest rates in Europe have driven investors to higher-yielding prime real estate investments, driving up prices and yields for these assets. However, this has created a dichotomy in the market, with secondary properties seeing slower recovery and higher rent-yield spreads. Investors are now turning to value-add strategies to reposition secondary assets as prime properties, taking advantage of the gap in prices and rents. The European market is diverse, with opportunities in various countries, but investors must carefully analyze the market conditions and liquidity at exit to execute successful value-add strategies.

site_title: JPMorgan sees yen climbing as US scrutiny impedes intervention
summary: Japan's yen surges to an 18-month high, reaching 106.44 per dollar, due to concerns over US scrutiny of currency practices. JPMorgan predicts the US opposition to exchange-rate intervention will strengthen the yen, and Japan's Finance Minister Taro Aso warns that authorities will act if moves are one-sided. The US Treasury's watch-list of countries, including Japan, Germany, China, and South Korea, may limit Japan's ability to intervene in currency markets, but Aso says the US report won't limit Japan's response.

site_title: Five key facts on a planned US-EU trade pact
summary: The European Union and US are negotiating a Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) to create a 850 million-person free-trade zone. The deal aims to boost trade, create jobs, and set standards. Key areas include eliminating tariffs, regulating cooperation, and rules on issues like food safety and intellectual property. Negotiations have faced criticism, with some countries and groups opposing provisions on environmental protection and sovereignty. Despite efforts to reach an ambitious deal, support for the pact is dwindling, with US elections and European elections looming, potentially delaying or derailing the agreement.

site_title: Comparing Reit fees: two cases of anomalies
summary: A report by ING Bank compared management fees of several Reits, including Keppel Reit and Suntec Reit, to market norms. The initial comparison showed Keppel Reit and Suntec Reit's fees as being disproportionately high due to the exclusion of revenue from partially owned assets. However, a later chart that included total assets, not just gross revenue, showed their fees to be more in line with peers. The controversy highlights the need for accurate and transparent fee structures in the Reit industry, which has become increasingly scrutinized due to concerns over management fees and performance incentives.

site_title: Low oil prices offer chance to spur G7 energy transition: Canada
summary: Canada's energy minister, Jim Carr, sees low oil prices as an opportunity to spur the country's energy transition, particularly towards electric vehicles and green technologies. Canada plans to invest significantly in electric vehicles and green infrastructure, despite being a major oil and natural gas producer. The country still aims to export liquefied natural gas (LNG) and sell oil to Asian economies, with efforts to build pipelines to the Pacific coast. Carr believes that the government can learn from past experiences and successfully approve pipeline applications.

site_title: Rising market fails to lift MTP laggards
summary: The Singapore stock market's recent recovery has failed to lift mainboard-listed firms that failed to meet the S$0.20 minimum trading price (MTP) requirement. Despite the benchmark STI's rise in March, the number of firms meeting the MTP requirement remained roughly the same, indicating that some companies are struggling to maintain their stock prices.

site_title: Investors may have profited from leaked US data: ECB research paper
summary: A European Central Bank research paper found that investors made millions of dollars in profits by correctly betting on market moves before sensitive US economic data was released. The study analyzed 21 market-moving indicators from 2008 to 2014 and estimated that traders earned approximately $20 million per year in the S&P E-mini futures market. The paper suggests that leaks of key indicators may have contributed to these profits, and recommends implementing strict release procedures to ensure fairness in financial markets.

site_title: Gold hits 15-month high above US$1,300/oz as dollar wilts
summary: Gold prices surged to a 15-month high above $1,300 an ounce, driven by renewed weakness in the US dollar. The dollar's decline was fueled by the Bank of Japan's decision not to ease monetary policies further. Asian markets and London were closed for national holidays, limiting the rally. Hedge funds reduced their net long positions in gold, but analysts expect further gains due to the dollar's weakness and strong demand for white metals.

images.alt_text: Gold rose to a fresh 15-month high on Monday above US$1,300 an ounce, supported by renewed weakness in the dollar, but action was muted because of a holiday in some markets.

site_title: Quotation of taxable book-entry Singapore Government Bonds
summary: Singapore Government Bonds quotation increased. NTT DC Reit's public offer was 9.8 times oversubscribed. US stocks opened lower amid fresh tariffs on Canada. Creative Technology warned of potential revenue and operating loss below targets. London's Heathrow plans to increase fees for a £10 billion upgrade. Indonesia detained a Trafigura employee in a 285 trillion rupiah graft case. OCBC's incoming CEO is Tan Teck Long, a former DBS veteran. MAS and PBOC will deepen cooperation in green and transition finance. Singapore stocks experienced a 5-day rally ahead of GDP data.

site_title: Election jitters send Philippine investors to sidelines
summary: The Philippine stock market plummeted 1.5% to 7,053.88, the largest drop since February 29, due to election jitters. Mayor Rodrigo Duterte maintained a 33% lead in a poll, while investors remain uncertain about his economic agenda. The peso weakened 0.2% to a two-month low, with offshore investors buying dollars. The market's 7-day losing streak continues, with foreign investors pulling $34 million from local stocks last month. The presidential election, scheduled for May 9, is expected to further impact market sentiment.

site_title: Europe stocks little changed after weekly loss as Allianz climbs
summary: Europe's stocks remained largely unchanged, following a weekly loss, as insurers advanced and banks declined. Allianz SE led gains on a 21% jump in quarterly profit, while Fiat Chrysler Automobiles NV rose 1.6% on a positive outlook for China. Italian lenders were lower after a private investor snubbed an initial public offering. The Stoxx Europe 600 Index fell 0.1% to 341.14, its lowest level in two weeks, amid uncertainty and a stronger euro.

site_title: Gem Residences sees healthy registered interest
summary: Gem Residences, a 578-unit Toa Payoh condominium, has seen a healthy registered interest of 468 prospective buyers for its units, with 2,000 visitors to its show gallery since its opening.

site_title: Record profits put Ferrari in pole position for 2016
summary: Ferrari reported its best profits ever in the first quarter, with a 19% increase in net profit to 78 million euros. Revenues rose 9% and the company cut its debt by 15 million euros. Ferrari delivered 1,882 cars, a 15% increase, driven by the V8 segment, including new models. The company expects to achieve record earnings for the full year 2016.

site_title: Five years on from bin Laden, 'campaign on terror' needs rebooting
summary: The US-led global campaign against terrorism is five years into a new era, marked by the rise of the Islamic State (IS). Despite successes in counter-terrorism, the campaign remains unbalanced, with too much emphasis on hard power and not enough on soft power instruments like public diplomacy. International leaders, including former Secretary of State John Kerry and former Defense Secretary Bob Gates, have called for a shift towards a more comprehensive and long-term strategy that addresses the root causes of terrorism. The US and its international partners must prioritize soft power initiatives, such as public diplomacy, sustainable development assistance, and exchange programs, to effectively win "hearts and minds" in key states like Turkey, Jordan, and Pakistan.

site_title: Euro climbs past US$1.15 to 8-month high as focus on the Fed fades
summary: The euro strengthened past $1.15 for the first time since August, reaching an 8-month high, amid speculation that the US won't raise interest rates soon. This comes after a report showed manufacturing in the eurozone expanded faster than initially estimated, and traders lowered expectations for a rate increase by the Federal Reserve in June. The euro's rise is seen as a sign of the US dollar's weakness, with some analysts predicting further gains for the euro as investors look for alternative currencies.

site_title: Saint Petersburg celebrates its unique communal flats
summary: Saint Petersburg, Russia, celebrates its unique communal flats, known as kommunalkas, which originated in the Soviet era. These shared dwellings with multiple residents and facilities are now featured on guided tours and discussed at academic conferences. Although they are disappearing, many residents, including 75-year-old Eduard Yemelyanov, who lives in a central Petrogradskaya district flat, praise the communal lifestyle for its social benefits. After the Soviet era, the number of kommunalkas in Saint Petersburg decreased from 116,000 to 83,000 between 2008 and 2015.

images.alt_text: A leftover from the Soviet era, the communal flat with bathroom and kitchen shared by a dozen or so residents is very much alive in Russia's Saint Petersburg.

site_title: India's March infrastructure output grows fastest in 16 months y/y: govt
summary: India's infrastructure output grew 6.4% in March, its fastest pace in 16 months, driven by higher electricity and fertiliser output. This follows a 2.7% growth for the fiscal year 2015/16, outpacing the 4.5% growth in the previous year. Infrastructure accounts for nearly 38% of India's industrial output, with fertiliser output jumping 22.9% and electricity production growing 11.3% in March.

site_title: Greenpeace publishes confidential US-EU trade deal documents
summary: Greenpeace published confidential US-EU trade deal documents, citing concerns that the Transatlantic Trade and Investment Partnership (TTIP) would lower food safety and environmental standards. The documents, released on Monday, show entrenched differences between the EU and US on issues like genetically modified foods. The European Commission and EU chief negotiator dismissed Greenpeace's points as "flatly wrong" and "alarmist headlines." A deal is expected by July, despite waning support from surveys in Germany and the US.

site_title: US stocks open higher ahead of manufacturing data
summary: US stocks opened higher on the first trading day of May, with the Dow Jones industrial average rising 0.2% to 17,808.61, the S&P 500 gaining 0.2% to 2,069.53, and the Nasdaq composite adding 0.16% to 4,782.98. The gains come ahead of manufacturing data, which investors are closely watching to assess the health of the US economy.

site_title: US FAA approves longer diversion time for Airbus A350
summary: US regulators have approved the Airbus A350 to fly up to 5 hours on one engine, equivalent to 2,000 nautical miles, allowing it to fly more direct routes over oceans and other deserted places. This decision is expected to be upgraded to 370 minutes or more than six hours later this year, aligning with European rules. The new regulation aims to increase the A350's range and flexibility, particularly for long-haul flights.

site_title: India to monitor mines via satellite after finding illegal limestone extraction
summary: India will monitor thousands of mines via satellite starting this year after a three-month pilot project found widespread illegal limestone extraction. The move comes after a multi-billion-dollar iron ore scam led to a three-year mining ban. The illegal mining was reported in Andhra Pradesh and Gujarat, where Prime Minister Narendra Modi is from. The satellite monitoring system aims to curb further illegal activities and prevent a repeat of the iron ore scam that turned India into an importer instead of a net exporter of steelmaking commodities. The monitoring will be completed in some regions before the full implementation begins.

site_title: ISM manufacturing index 50.8 in April: ISM
summary: The US manufacturing sector expanded in April but at a slower pace, according to the Institute for Supply Management (ISM) report. The index fell to 50.8 from 51.8 in March, below expectations of 51.4. A reading above 50 indicates expansion, while a reading below 50 indicates contraction, suggesting a slowdown in the sector.

site_title: Japan aiming to set up LNG trading hub by early 2020s
summary: Japan aims to establish itself as an international LNG trading hub by the early 2020s, according to a trade ministry announcement. The country will open its receiving terminal and boost large-scale storage facilities to enable active LNG trading. This move aims to break the pricing link to crude oil benchmarks and eliminate single destination clauses in long-term supply contracts. The G7 energy ministers have supported the initiative, emphasizing the need for market transparency and liquidity.

site_title: Eurozone factory growth weakens in April despite heavy discounting
summary: Eurozone factory growth improved slightly in April, with a PMI reading of 51.7, above the 50 threshold for growth. Despite this, the sector's activity remained weak. Manufacturing growth was strong in Italy and Spain, while Germany showed signs of recovery. However, France's activity contracted at the steepest rate in a year. The mixed picture suggests the wider economy remains fragile.

site_title: Japan to support Mekong countries with US$7b over three years
summary: Japan pledges US$9.47 billion in aid to Mekong countries over three years to improve infrastructure and boost development. Foreign Minister Fumio Kishida made the announcement in Bangkok, where he is on a week-long visit to promote Japan's influence in the region. The aid aims to support the Southeast Asian economies in Thailand, Cambodia, Laos, Myanmar, and Vietnam. Japan's move is seen as a response to China's growing influence in the region, and is part of a broader effort to strengthen ties with Mekong countries.

site_title: Oil prices retreat from 2016 highs on Opec output boost
summary: Oil prices retreated from 2016 highs due to rising production in the Middle East, outweighing a decline in US output and a weaker dollar. OPEC crude production rose to 32.64 million barrels per day, and Russia increased monthly exports by over 7%. The US oil rig count fell for the sixth week, indicating the price of oil hadn't risen enough to lure shale producers back. Analysts believe oil prices may have bottomed, with the International Energy Agency's Fatih Birol stating that a normal economic environment would lead to upward price direction.

site_title: Reckitt Benckiser exec slapped in S Korea while apologising for deadly sterilizers
summary: A Reckitt Benckiser executive, Ata Safdar, apologized for deadly lung injuries linked to humidifier sterilizers in South Korea, accepting full responsibility for the harm caused. The company's South Korean arm, Oxy Reckitt Benckiser, sold the products, which were linked to 92 deaths and 178 reported cases of lung ailments. A compensation panel was announced, and the company established a 5 billion won (S$5.86 million) humanitarian fund. The apology marked the first public acceptance of responsibility by the firm for its role in the controversy, which began in 2011.

site_title: Takata booking over US$156m in additional loss for air bag recalls
summary: Takata Corp, a Japanese air bag maker, is booking an additional $209.6 million in losses due to product warranty costs related to a recall of its potentially lethal air bags. The company expects to settle product liability claims for around $209.6 million and has recalled over 50 million air bags worldwide, blamed for 11 deaths and over 100 injuries.

site_title: German manufacturing growth accelerates to three-month high in April
summary: German factory activity reached a three-month high in April, with the Markit Purchasing Managers' Index for manufacturing rising to 51.8, surpassing the 50 line that separates growth from contraction. Output by manufacturers increased, and job creation rose at the fastest pace in three months. New export contracts increased at the fastest rate since January, driven by stronger demand from China, southern Europe, and the US. However, growth remains modest due to doubts about the global economy.

site_title: French factory activity slows to weakest reading in a year despite price cuts: PMI
summary: French manufacturing activity slowed to its weakest pace in a year in April, with the Purchasing Managers' Index falling to 48.0 from 49.6 in March. Demand from abroad weakened, and companies cut prices the most since the financial crisis, yet output prices still fell. This is despite the sector ramping up investment in the first quarter, taking advantage of a tax write-off for investment in productive assets.

site_title: Saudi Arabia looks to UK, France and China for help building homes
summary: Saudi Arabia's housing ministry has authorized assistance from the UK, France, and China to build hundreds of thousands of homes, amid a shortage of affordable housing. The government aims to increase home ownership among citizens by 5 percentage points by 2020. Memorandums of understanding with these countries will be signed, with the government providing some funding and regulatory support. This follows a previous agreement with South Korea and a Saudi-South Korean consortium to develop 100,000 housing units in northern Riyadh over 10 years.

site_title: Centurion to buy four UK student dorms for £20.1m
summary: Centurion Corporation has signed a deal to buy four student accommodation assets in the UK for £20.1 million, adding 519 beds to its portfolio. The assets, located in Manchester, Bristol, and Newcastle, will increase Centurion's total student beds to 3,208 across the UK, Australia, and Singapore. The purchase is earnings accretive and part of the company's growth strategy in the higher education market, with plans to increase its overall portfolio to 75,000 beds by 2018.

site_title: US construction spending rises to 8-1/2-year high
summary: US construction spending rose to an 8-1/2-year high in March, increasing 0.3% to its highest level since October 2007. This followed a revised 1.0% jump in February. Construction spending was up 8.0% from a year ago, driven by a 1.1% surge in private construction and 1.6% growth in private residential construction. However, public construction spending declined 1.9% in March, largely due to a 7.4% drop in federal government construction spending. Despite a sharp downturn in spending by energy firms, the sector's aggressive spending cuts held down economic growth to 0.5% annualized rate.

site_title: Tokyo: Nikkei closes more than 3% down on higher yen
summary: Tokyo stocks plummeted over 3% on Monday as the yen surged, hurting exporters in holiday-thinned trade. The Nikkei 225 index fell 3.11% to 16,147.38 and the Topix index lost 3.03% to 1,299.96. The yen's strength weighed on exporters, leading to a decline in Tokyo's stock market.

site_title: European shares rally at open
summary: European shares rose at the open on Monday, rebounding from last week's losses amid concerns about the global economy. Tokyo stocks plummeted, leading a sell-off across Asia. The eurozone saw gains, with Frankfurt's DAX rising 0.5% to 10,091.17 points, while Paris' CAC 40 firmed 0.6% to 4,455.76 points ahead of US and eurozone economic data publication.

site_title: Singapore: STI closed on Monday
summary: Singapore's Straits Times Index (STI) closed on Monday for a public holiday, reopening on Tuesday, May 3. The previous day, the STI rose 0.4% as investors remained positive despite US tariff uncertainty and split Federal Reserve views.

site_title: Thai April consumer prices rise for first time since Dec 2014
summary: Thailand's headline consumer prices rose 0.07% in April, the first increase in 15 months, driven by higher prices of food, vegetables, and tobacco. The core inflation rate, excluding raw food and energy, increased 0.78%. The Bank of Thailand has maintained its policy interest rate at 1.50% since April 2015, citing a forecasted 3.1% economic growth. A rate cut is expected at the next review on May 11, with most analysts predicting no change.

site_title: Takata falls on report recalls may widen to 100m vehicles
summary: Takata Corp's shares plummeted 16% after the Nikkei reported that US regulators plan to expand recalls of its air bags to over 100 million vehicles worldwide. The recalls are due to moisture-absorbing desiccants that can cause air bags to deteriorate and deploy too forcefully, resulting in injuries and fatalities. Takata has already faced over a dozen recalls and has lost more than half its value this year, with estimated losses potentially reaching 24% of its cash and equivalents by March 2017.

site_title: US companies starting to see relief from pains of strong dollar
summary: US-based companies are experiencing relief from the pains of a strong dollar, which has eased their financial struggles. Companies such as Whirlpool, Johnson & Johnson, and Xerox have reported beating earnings estimates and raising their outlooks for the year. A weaker dollar has also benefited lesser-known companies like Rollins Inc and CR Bard Inc, which cited the currency's weakening as a key reason for their positive earnings announcements. This trend could lead to more positive earnings surprises in the coming weeks.

site_title: Australian entrepreneur reveals himself as Bitcoin creator: media
summary: Australian entrepreneur Craig Wright has revealed himself as the creator of the Bitcoin currency, presenting proof to media outlets. Wright, an Australian entrepreneur, claims to have created Bitcoin in 2008 and provided the proof to the BBC, The Economist, and GQ magazine. His claim has sparked controversy, with many experts questioning the validity of the proof. Wright's statement has sent shockwaves through the cryptocurrency community, with some welcoming his claim and others expressing skepticism.

site_title: Australian budget walks fine line between growth and austerity
summary: The Australian government has announced a $5 billion fund for major public transport projects in its federal budget, aiming to balance growth and austerity amidst an early election campaign. Treasurer Scott Morrison's budget prioritizes targeted spending on health and education, with a focus on driving jobs and growth. The government faces pressure to deliver a voter-friendly plan, following recent opinion polls showing a neck-and-neck race with the Labor Party.

site_title: Yen rally eases after Tokyo hints at intervention
summary: The yen's rally eased in Asian trading on Monday after Japanese Finance Minister Taro Aso warned of possible market intervention to curb the surge. The yen reached an 18-month high against the dollar last week, but fell to 106.56 yen on Monday. Aso's remarks hinted at intervention if the dollar-yen breaks 100, despite previous G-20 agreements. The US dollar has been under pressure since the Federal Reserve's go-slow signal on interest rate hikes.

site_title: Australia business conditions stay positive in April: NAB
summary: Australian businesses reported solid sales, profits, and employment in April, with the National Australia Bank's business conditions index dipping three points to +9, still above the long-run average.
