This incident has sparked a call for greater vigilance among global banks, underscoring the importance of protecting sensitive financial information.

site_title: Q1 profits disappoint, outlook dim: analysts
summary: Singapore-listed companies reported largely disappointing first-quarter earnings, with 277 companies posting a median 1% decline in net profit. The oil and gas sector underperformed, while the transportation and consumer discretionary sectors also missed expectations. Analysts attribute the poor performance to weak oil prices and project deferrals. The outlook for earnings remains dim, with consensus expecting a 0.96% decline in 2016 earnings per share. Despite this, some analysts see potential for bargain opportunities in the market, particularly in sectors exposed to the Asian recovery.

site_title: Quick takes: Public office holders see Heng Swee Keat as invaluable, hardworking
summary: Finance Minister Heng Swee Keat, 54, collapsed during a Cabinet meeting on Thursday due to a stroke and is currently undergoing treatment at Tan Tock Seng Hospital. Colleagues, including Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong and Deputy Prime Minister Tharman Shanmugaratnam, expressed hope for his speedy recovery and praised his hard work and dedication to his duties. Many also acknowledged the immense load he carried, including handling the Finance Ministry and various projects, and wished him a full recovery.

site_title: 'Chairman Kim' presides over mass parade in Pyongyang
summary: North Korea held a massive parade in Pyongyang to celebrate the conclusion of a ruling party congress, marking a formal coronation for supreme leader Kim Jong Un. The four-day congress marked the first gathering of the party's top decision-making body in over 35 years. Kim Jong Un presided over the event, praising his leadership and calling on the country to "single-mindedly and faithfully carry through" his ideology. The parade featured hundreds of thousands of participants waving floral bouquets and chanting "Long Live" in unison, showcasing the country's latest military hardware, including long-range ballistic missiles.

site_title: NZ manufacturing activity rises in April
summary: New Zealand's manufacturing activity rose in April, with the Bank of New Zealand-Business NZ's seasonally adjusted Performance of Manufacturing Index (PMI) increasing to 56.5 from 54.7. This marks the sector's highest monthly rise since January, indicating expansion. The sector has displayed above-average growth for many months, according to BNZ senior economist Doug Steel.

site_title: Staples-Office Depot merger collapses after block by judge
summary: US District Judge Emmet Sullivan blocked a $6.3 billion merger between Staples and Office Depot, citing concerns that the combined company would create an unrivaled giant in the office supply market, harming buyers. The Federal Trade Commission had argued that the merger would lead to higher prices and lower quality service for large businesses. The companies abandoned the deal after the judge's ruling, with Office Depot's CEO stating that the company would not appeal. The decision marks the second time the FTC has blocked a combination between Staples and Office Depot.

site_title: Oil market rebalancing outlook still intact: analysts
summary: Saudi Arabia's new oil minister is reinforcing the country's commitment to maintaining its market share, analysts say. Despite US oil production declining, the market consensus remains that oil supply and demand will rebalance by the end of the year or early next year. This stance supports the oil policy initiated in 2014, and Saudi Arabia is expected to continue its efforts to maintain its dominance in the global oil market.

site_title: CWT says major shareholder still in talks with various parties on "strategic review"
summary: CWT Ltd's controlling shareholder, C&P Holdings, is still in talks with various parties regarding a strategic review of the company's business and assets. The review, initiated in August, follows media reports suggesting Chinese conglomerate HNA Group is interested in acquiring CWT for approximately US$1 billion. C&P Holdings has engaged in preliminary discussions with interested parties, but the review is still ongoing.

site_title: Mesitis raises US$2.35m; FinLab unveils inaugural batch of startups
summary: Singapore-based fintech startup Mesitis has raised US$2.35 million in funding, with the funds to be invested in people and technology for its personal financial data aggregation platform Canopy. The company, which has over US$3.2 billion in assets under management, will use the funds to "come out of closed beta" in the third quarter of the year. Meanwhile, nine other startups have been selected for The FinLab's inaugural accelerator programme, receiving S$30,000 in funding.

images.alt_text: Janet Young, UOB's head of Group Channels and Digitalisation, with Alex Lin, head of IIPL, after signing their joint venture to set up The FinLab last year.
Mesitis founder Tanmai Sharma.

site_title: Heading for SGX this June could be a S$900m Frasers Reit (Amended)
summary: Frasers Centrepoint (FCL) is set to spin off its Australian logistics and industrial assets into a real estate investment trust (Reit), worth S$800-900 million, and list on the Singapore Exchange (SGX) in June, barring unforeseen circumstances. The Reit, called Frasers Logistics and Industrial Trust (FLT), will be led by DBS and Citi as global co-ordinators. FLT's assets will comprise mostly industrial and logistics properties, and investors can choose to take distributions in Australian dollars or Singapore dollars.

site_title: Challenger's Q1 net profit up 2% to S$3.76m
summary: CHALLENGER Technologies' net profit rose 2% to S$3.76 million in Q1 2016, driven by 8% revenue growth to S$90.39 million. The IT products and services business segment saw a 7.6% increase, while retail operations saw a decline. Two new stores are set to open in Q3, and the company aims to expand its online marketplace to offer a 24/7 shopping experience.

site_title: SPH deepens foray in content marketing with BrandInsider relaunch
summary: Singapore Press Holdings (SPH) has relaunched Content Studio as BrandInsider, a content marketing solution for advertisers. The move emphasizes SPH's shift from traditional online advertising to content marketing. BrandInsider offers customized solutions, audience analytics, and access to unique demographics. The relaunch marks a transition towards more tailored content for advertisers, following SPH's acquisition of a 34.7% stake in video-led content marketing company Brand New Media in March. The new BrandInsider team brings 10 years of editorial experience and aims to create impactful native content.

site_title: Malaysia's 1MDB says to engage bondholders following default
summary: Malaysia's 1MDB state fund has started engaging with bondholders after defaulting on a US$1.75 billion note due in 2022. The fund has appointed Alvarez & Marsal Asia Ltd as its financial adviser and D.F. King Ltd to register bondholders. 1MDB is committed to working with Abu Dhabi's International Petroleum Investment Company, which claims the fund never met payment obligations. The move comes after the fund's default last month, with the outcome uncertain.

site_title: RBS says preparing for Brexit uncertainty, eyes further cost cuts
summary: Royal Bank of Scotland (RBS) Chairman Howard Davies said the bank is preparing for potential economic instability following the UK's EU referendum on June 23. Despite uncertainty, RBS will support its customers regardless of the outcome. The bank is in the midst of a corporate restructuring and has not made a profit in eight years. CEO Ross McEwan warned of significant challenges ahead, but expects the heaviest restructuring to be complete by the end of 2016. RBS plans to reduce costs by an additional £800 million to achieve a more sustainable cost-to-income ratio.

site_title: Update: Indonesia's GDP grows more slowly than expected in Q1
summary: Indonesia's GDP grew 4.92% in the first quarter of 2016, slower than the expected 5.05% and the actual 5.04% in the previous quarter. The country's economic growth has been slowing since 2011, and the government aims to reach 7% growth by 2019. The central bank has cut interest rates three times in the first quarter to support growth, and the government has offered tax incentives to boost the manufacturing sector. The unemployment rate remains at 5.50% in February.

site_title: Europe to urgently assess risk of drones hitting planes
summary: European aviation safety authorities have set up a task force to assess the risk of drone collisions with aircraft after a rise in near-misses. The task force, led by the European Aviation Safety Agency (Easa), will examine the vulnerability of aircraft windshields, engines, and airframes to drone impacts. This comes after a British Airways plane was suspected of hitting a drone near Heathrow airport, although the incident was later disputed. The task force will publish its results at the end of July, with representatives from aircraft and engine manufacturers participating.

site_title: Trump Indiana win boosts his claim to be presumptive nominee
summary: Donald Trump won the Republican presidential primary in Indiana, securing at least 45 of the 57 delegates at stake, bolstering his claim to be the presumptive nominee before the national convention in July. The victory dealt a blow to Ted Cruz's effort to stop Trump, and the Democratic primary between Hillary Clinton and Bernie Sanders remained too close to call. Trump's massive win in Indiana, coupled with his earlier victories in five northeastern states, has made it increasingly difficult for Cruz and Ohio Governor John Kasich to stop him from securing the nomination.

site_title: HSBC Q1 net profit falls 18% to US$4.3b
summary: HSBC's net profit fell 18% to US$4.3 billion in the first quarter, impacted by "extreme levels" of market volatility. Revenue declined 4% to US$13.91 billion, with bad loan costs nearly doubling to US$1.16 billion. Despite this, pre-tax profits beat estimates and the bank is on track to meet cost targets. Group CEO Stuart Gulliver attributed the resilience to the bank's efforts to cut costs and focus on Asia businesses, where there is growing momentum.

site_title: South Korea's April inflation holds at 1% as oil continues to drag
summary: South Korea's annual inflation stayed at 1.0% in April, unchanged from the previous month, due to low global oil prices. The consumer price index rose 0.1% in monthly terms. Core inflation, which strips out food and fuel prices, remained at 1.8%. Analysts predict the central bank will not cut interest rates this year, but instead expect inflation to gradually pick up after June. The Bank of Korea's base policy rate remains at a record low of 1.50%.

site_title: Cacola proposes rights issue to raise up to S$31m
summary: CACOLA Furniture International proposes a rights issue to raise up to S$31m, issuing up to 1.6 billion new shares at 1.9 Singapore cents each, or 0.475 Singapore cents per new share, a 21% discount. The issue aims to enhance shareholders' value for working capital and potential acquisitions.

site_title: Update: Australian Craig Wright says he created Bitcoin
summary: Australian entrepreneur Craig Wright, 45, claims to be the creator of Bitcoin, a decentralized digital currency. Wright, a cyber-security expert, presented proof to three media outlets, including the BBC, and demonstrated the signing of a message with the public key associated with the first Bitcoin transaction. However, some experts remain skeptical, citing a need for further verification. Bitcoin's creator, Satoshi Nakamoto, used a pseudonym, and Wright's claim has drawn criticism from some in the tech community. Wright denies seeking fame or honors, stating he wants to be left alone.

site_title: UBS posts Q1 profit slump amid market uncertainty
summary: Swiss bank UBS reported a 64% drop in net profit for the first quarter of 2016, falling to 707 million Swiss francs, due to volatile markets and low investment banking revenues. The bank attributed the decline to negative market performance, client risk aversion, and abnormally low transaction volumes. However, UBS's private banking businesses saw a net new client assets of 29 billion francs, the highest for a first quarter since 2008, providing a positive outlook for future revenue. The bank plans job cuts to save hundreds of millions of dollars in its wealth management business.

site_title: Govt to provide support as industries transform
summary: Singapore Prime Minister Lee Hsien Loong emphasized the need for industries to transform and compete on "fair terms" with new operating models. He highlighted the government's support for this transformation through the Industry Transformation Programme, which aims to help industries use R&D and technology to adapt and prosper. However, Lee also acknowledged that jobs in Singapore will change as the economy undergoes transformation, with older jobs being displaced by technology or moving elsewhere. The government and labour movement must work together to match workers' skills with available jobs, with the prime minister encouraging employers to be bolder in their approach.

images.alt_text: Lee U-Wen

site_title: US: Stocks push higher as dollar retreats
summary: US stocks rose 0.8% on Monday, ending a two-day losing streak, ahead of the April jobs report and other key data releases. The dollar retreated against the euro, with the euro crossing US$1.15, potentially leading to a higher increase in the single currency. Analysts attribute the market's strength to the dollar's weakness, which is seen as a sign that the US Federal Reserve won't tighten monetary policy until September at the earliest.

site_title: Apple's suppliers gear up to bring new screens to 2017 iPhone
summary: Apple's suppliers, including Applied Materials, are gearing up to produce brighter, higher-definition OLED screens for the 2017 iPhone. The technology upgrade is expected to provide a significant impact on the iPhone's design and functionality, potentially rekindling growth in the smartphone market. Suppliers such as Samsung, LG Display, and Sharp are investing heavily in OLED production, with Applied Materials reporting a fourfold increase in orders for display equipment. The new screens will be thinner, more energy-efficient, and offer higher contrast, making them a key feature in the upcoming iPhone model.

site_title: New SF MoMA aims to be not just a giant, but global
summary: The newly expanded San Francisco Museum of Modern Art (SF MoMA) is set to rebrand itself as a global institution, boasting the largest exhibition space in the Bay Area and the most gallery space than the current MoMA in Manhattan. The museum is incorporating global contemporary art, film programs, and community-driven projects, with a focus on emerging artists from diverse backgrounds. Major commissions include works by Julie Mehretu and a survey of recent donations featuring artists like Ai Weiwei and Njideka Akunyili Crosby. The museum aims to attract a younger donor base and engage with the local community while exploring the global art world.

site_title: Commercialising innovation to go international
summary: Singaporean SMEs are expanding globally through commercializing innovation, such as Kwanpen's internationalization through sustainability and ethical practices. Meanwhile, researchers at NUS are working to halve the price of sustainable marine fuel. OCBC aims to provide $5 billion in loans to serial entrepreneurs by 2028, while Shatec cuts staff and puts its campus up for sale. Local businesses are also rebranding heritage and traditional products, such as Munchi Pancakes' modernized min jiang kueh, to appeal to younger generations. Chinatown Business Association is seeking compensation from Nanyang Old Coffee over outdoor area use.

site_title: Trading secrecy for transparency
summary: Trafigura, a large oil trading firm, has made efforts to increase transparency in its business, issuing its first annual report and sustainability report. The company's CEO, Jeremy Weir, believes this is a natural evolution for the firm and the sector. Weir argues that transparency is necessary to maintain credibility and build trust with stakeholders. Trafigura has joined the Extractive Industries Transparency Initiative, which requires resource companies to disclose payments to foreign governments. The company has also published a sustainability report, which highlights its shortcomings, including a high rate of workplace fatalities. Weir attributes the firm's decision to increase transparency to the lessons learned from a 2006 environmental scandal in Ivory Coast, where Trafigura dumped toxic waste. The company is now focusing on engaging with local communities and deepening its presence in Asia, particularly in Singapore.

site_title: Glencore becomes top shareholder in Australia's Atlas Iron via debt-to-equity deal
summary: Glencore has acquired a majority stake in Australian iron ore miner Atlas Iron through a debt-to-equity deal, becoming the company's top shareholder. Atlas had negotiated with creditors to fend off collapse due to weak iron ore prices, with Glencore's subsidiary Maru Sky acquiring a portion of Atlas' debt and converting it into equity. Glencore now holds 8.47% of Atlas' shares, with Commonwealth Bank of Australia holding 6.36%. The deal marks Glencore's direct exposure to iron ore production, despite the company's history of avoiding it.

images.alt_text: Glencore has emerged as the top shareholder of embattled Australian iron ore miner Atlas Iron after a debt-to-equity transaction, giving the global mining and trading company its only direct exposure to production of the steelmaking ingredient.

site_title: Abe throws weight behind Cameron in Brexit debate
summary: Japanese Prime Minister Shinzo Abe expressed support for British Prime Minister David Cameron's stance on Brexit, stating that a UK exit from the EU would make the country "less attractive" to Japanese investors. Abe emphasized the importance of the UK as a gateway to the EU, citing the significant economic ties between the two nations. New economic data showed the UK's economy is "near stalling," with factory, construction, and services indexes all falling more than forecast last month.

site_title: Rolling Stones, Paul McCartney in line-up for mega concert
summary: The Rolling Stones, Bob Dylan, Paul McCartney, Neil Young, Roger Waters, and The Who will perform at a mega festival, "The Desert Trip," at the Empire Polo field in Indio, California, from October 7-9. The six iconic artists will each play a full set over three nights, with tickets ranging from $199 to $1,599. The event is expected to be one of the greatest concerts ever, with all performers in their 70s, and could mark a final appearance for The Who.

images.alt_text: The Rolling Stones, Bob Dylan, Paul McCartney, Neil Young, Roger Waters and The Who will perform at a mega festival in October, organizers said Tuesday.

site_title: Malaysia govt opponents cry foul as state slams door
summary: Malaysian opposition leader Azmin Ali claims he was barred from entering the state of Sarawak ahead of a state assembly election, accusing the ruling coalition of illegally blocking government opponents. This is the latest in a string of politicians and activists being barred from Sarawak, with the opposition calling it a violation of political rights. The move is seen as a sign of jitters within the ruling Barisan Nasional coalition, which is expected to retain control of Sarawak despite corruption allegations surrounding Prime Minister Najib Razak.

images.alt_text: One of Malaysia's top opposition leaders said he was blocked Friday from entering the state of Sarawak and accused the ruling coalition of illegally turning away government opponents ahead of a weekend election.

site_title: SDP's Chee sets out promises to residents
summary: Singapore Democratic Party (SDP) candidate Chee Soon Juan has promised voters in the Bukit Batok constituency that if elected, he will become a full-time Member of Parliament, manage the town council without a managing agent, and act as an alternative voice in parliament. He highlighted his plans to save residents money and provide a "win-win situation" if they vote for him. Chee also criticized the ruling People's Action Party (PAP) for its handling of employment data, saying he was correct to state that 100 jobs were created in 2015 when the actual number was 700.

images.alt_text: Dr Chee after his rally at Bukit Batok on Thursday night. He said the Town Council will be run without a managing agent so as to save substantially on their fees, adding that the savings can then be passed back to residents.

site_title: Hock Lian Seng Holdings, Diamond Land win JTC tenders for two industrial sites
summary: JTC has awarded tenders for two industrial sites to Hock Lian Seng Holdings and Diamond Land. Hock Lian Seng won the 4,890 sq m site at Tampines Industrial Drive with a bid of S$3.708 million for a 20-year tenure. Diamond Land secured the 33,300 sq m site at Tuas South Link 1 with a S$37.5 million bid for a 30-year tenure, both zoned "Business 2" with gross plot ratios of 1.4 and 2, respectively.

images.alt_text: JTC has awarded the tenders for two industrial sites at Tampines Industrial Drive and Tuas South Link 1 to the highest tenderers, Hock Lian Seng Holdings and Diamond Land respectively.
Nisha Ramchandani

site_title: China to simplify rules for cross-border gold trade
summary: China has simplified procedures for cross-border gold trade, allowing companies with frequent imports and exports to apply for a single permit for up to 12 shipments. The trial, starting June 1, aims to reduce paperwork and speed up gold imports. The move follows China's expansion in gold consumption, driven by rising incomes and economic growth, and to diversify its foreign-exchange reserves. The central bank also plans to establish a regional benchmark for gold prices, with the Shanghai Gold Exchange experiencing a 20% price increase this year.

images.alt_text: China's central bank and customs will allow companies that have "frequent imports and exports" of gold and gold products to apply for a single permit that can be used in as many as 12 shipments.

site_title: Oil rebels blow up Chevron facility in Nigeria: navy, firm
summary: Militants from the Niger Delta Avengers group have blown up an offshore oil facility operated by US oil group Chevron in southern Nigeria, near Escravos. The facility, known as the Okan platform, was attacked on Wednesday night, and Chevron confirmed that it was shut-in and assessing the situation. The attack is the latest in a surge of violence targeting oil and gas facilities in Nigeria, which could hit exports and the country's economy. The navy is working to track down the culprits, and Chevron has deployed resources to respond to the resulting spill.

images.alt_text: Militants have blown an offshore oil facility operated by US oil group Chevron in southern Nigeria, the navy and the company said on Friday, in renewed violence that could hit exports in Africa's largest oil producer.
